column2: LONDON, Feb. 23 -- About 350 mountain gorillas, the biggest anthropoids on earth and the last survivors of their species, are threatened by extinction as a result of new tribal movements in the Belgian Congo.

CHICAGO. Feb. 23 -- Orlando W. Wilson, selected to clean up this city's police department, warned Chicagoans today to obey the law and "stop carrying $5 and $10 bills clipped to their driver licenses" as intended bribes.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- A bill providing a possible compromise to the controversial relief residency issue was introduced it the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- (UPI) -- The House cut $82,000,000 from the Post Office Department's record-breaking new budget today despite a threat by the Postmaster General to retaliate by drastically curtailing mail service.

DOUALA, Cameroon, Feb. 21 -- The referendum today was a crucial test of strength for Premier Ahmadou Ahidjo. So much was at stake that the Government called on Moslem chiefs in the north to round up illiterate pagans and assure a blizzard of "ayes" to smother an expected "nay" majority in troubled areas of the south.

At Ebbets Field yesterday men swung sledge hammers, the dugout crumbled and an iron ball crashed like Pete Reiser against the wall. After forty-four years as the home of the Dodgers and a monument to daffiness, the park began to vanish in favor of a proposed 1,-317-family middle-income housing project.

Record construction activity last year, together with expansion into the cement and ceramic tile fields, enabled the National Gypsum Company to post new records in sales and earnings for 1959. Melvin H. Baker, chairman, said the construction industry might set another record this year "despite a 10 per cent decline in the number of housing starts to about 1,200,000."

The United States pulp and paper industry is in "very good shape" and should attain new records in production this year, John R. Kimberly, president of the American Paper and Pulp Association, said yesterday.
TOKYO, Feb. 23 -- Japan celebrated today the birth of a son to Crown Princess Michiko. The child is next in line to his father, Crown Prince Akihito, in succession to the Japanese throne.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senate Republicans began a retaliatory attack today on Democratic critics of the Administration's defense program.
BRASILIA, Brazil, Feb. 23 -- President Eisenhower saw dramatic evidence today of Brazil's determination to progress ever at the risk of runaway inflation and financial chaos.

A stock dividend by another name may be a stock split. This may sound somewhat confusing -- and little wonder. Corporations and the public are often confused as to which term is the right one at the right time. Recently, for example, under the heading 'Dividends Announced," the financial pages carried this report:
The Pittsburgh Steel Company, the nation's fifteenth largest steel producer, announced yesterday a three-pronged program designed to strengthen its iron ore supply.

LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Diplomatic sources said today that intervention by the heads of government or their foreign ministers would be necessary to reconcile Western policies for the forthcoming summit conference.
A passenger-ship terminal on the Hudson River capable of berthing simultaneously five of the largest Jiners in the world has been proposed by Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs here.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Following are the texts of Governor Rockefeller's special message to the Legislature today on discrimination in housaning of the proposed administration bill to outlaw such discrimination:
The Democratic and Republican National Committees have created a hot issue for the television networks.

All women are young, laughing-eyed and Audrey Hepburn. They dress for Gregory Peck or Maurice Chevalier and they dine at the Ritz. Or at least this is the inner dream of a French designer named Bob Bugnand (rhymes more or less with oonion).

The dust has not quite settled yet after the flurry caused by the plan of the Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiary National Broadcasting Company to institute a special FM radio program for physicians.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- The management of the Crane Company decided at a board meeting today not to run Robert B. Crane, great-grandson of the founder of the Chicago plumbing company, for re-election to the board at the annual shareholder's meeting April 26.
Voluntary gifts and grants to the nation's colleges and universities reached a record total of more than $750,000,000 in the 1958-59 academic year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Federal investigators have found evidence that a dynamite blast near the seat occupied by a heavily insured New York lawyer caused the crash of an airliner last month near Bolivia, N.C.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The United States Government is willing and ready to enter negotiations with Cuba, "but not with its hands tied behind its back."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Lyndon B. Johnson, Democratic leader of the Senate, said today that he would start calling round-the clock sessions next week to speed Senate action on civil rights legislation.

Motors were weakes and drugs were strongest yesterday in a generally lackadaisical session of the New York Stock Exchange. Volume continued to diminish. The aggregate market value fell about $1,600,000,000.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 23, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Approved thirty-three bills and vetoed four minor ones.

In the annual report of the New York Stock Exchange published yesterday, Keith Funston, president, urged the Federal Reserve Board to reduce the present 90 per cent margin rate "to a more normal level in the relatively near future."

A two-year breach in the ranks of Local 88, the largest union within the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, may be closed today in one of the longest ballot counts in recent years.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for a comparatively easy-to-prepare rice dish.
POTSDAM, N.Y., Feb. 23 -- Clarkson College suffered a 13-4 defeat tonight at the hands of Queens University of Kingston, Ont. The visitors scored seven goals in the second period.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following ski conditions:
Fred J. Loughran, taking the witness stand in his own defense, denied yesterday that he had extorted money or conspired to extort money from butchers who had shortweighted meat customers.

PARIS, Feb. 23 - Paul Reynaud, 81-year-old former Premier mid a leader of the conservative Independent party, resigned today from the party's directing committee over the question of self-determination for Algeria.

The threat of a strike set for today by three unions in the derrick division of Merritt-Chapman Scott receded last night. But so did the long-range hopes of the unions' members for continued employment in the operation of the derricks.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 5 points off to 9 points up yesterday. The far months showed the most strength. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Adamant Republican Assemblymen served notice today that they would reject virtually all the major proposals in Governor Rockefeller's highway safety program.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he favored giving the Board of Education a freer hand in administering its own budget.
Pig Latin has preserved many secrets from inquisitive adults, but it proved the undoing of an ex-convict, who was charged with assault and robbery.

THE team-of-four contest that wound up the four-day holiday tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association Monday night was won by the team of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Sheinwold of New York, and Peter Fender and Mrs. Muriel Kaplan of Philadelphia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since Brotherhood Week is a period for saluting deserving top echelon exponents of improved human relations -- social, religious, educational and political leaders -- may I, in addition, call to your attention the truly unsung practitioners of brotherhood at its most basic and productive level, the volunteer workers in our social and welfare agencies who foster brotherhood through unselfish personal effort.

BRASILIA, Brazil, Feb. 23 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a speech by President Juscelino Kubitschek of Brazil, in unofficial translation from the Portuguese, of a speech by President Eisenhower, and of a declaration issued jointly by them:

St. James Court, Inc., has bought the seven-story apartment house at 214 West Ninety-second Street, southeast corner of Broadway, from the Z. Management Company in a deal negotiated by Lennard Sons, Inc., brokers.
Boston University decided yesterday not to let John Thomas take another crack at the world high-jump record in the New York Chapter Knights of Columbus Games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) -- The United States Parole Board said today it had refused a third time to grant parole to Henry Winston. American Communist party leader who was convicted at the original Smith Act trial in New York in 1949.
Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., missile-company executive and a blunt critic of the Administration's defense program, is leaving his job to give himself greater freedom to pursue his attack.
Organized labor's principal spokesman here suggested yesterday that the city be prevented by law from doing business with "anyone paying less than a minmum wage of $1.25 an hour."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the National Labor Relations Board had gone too far in holding that a partial strike or so-called "harassing activities," during negotiations constituted in themselves a refusal to bargain in good faith.
A total of 776 persons were injured in traffic mishaps in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yeaterday. This is a decrease of fifty-two injuries compared with 1950 in that period.

WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Feb. 23 -- An effort was made tonight by the Township Committee to remedy an error in the division of the cost of running the Washington Township-Westwood Consolidated School District.
LONDON, Feb. 23 -- Industrial shares were in steady demand here today and rises, generally in pennies, predominated on the stock exchange.

Good Breakfasts Months We are nearing the midpoint of Good Breakfasts Months. The name suggests it is hard to tell just where the special days, weeks and months with which the calendar is peppered will end.
A landlord who was jailed two weeks ago for failing to provide sufficient heat was back in housing court yesterday on the same charge.
An art auction sale for the Museum of Modern Art will be held on April 27 and is expected to bring more than $500,000.
Venereal disease is increasing in the United States, especially among teen-agers, a nation-wide study disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Senator John F. Kennedy announced today the appointment of Representative Chester Bowles as his foreign policy adviser in the campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.
RUTH MORRIS, Philadelphia-born soprano and student of Lotte Leonard at the Mannes College of Music, made her debut in recital at Town Hall last evening.
A new basis for the link that has been suggested between cigarette smoking and lung cancer was discussed in preliminary research findings reported here yesterday.

A Queens patrolman was about halfway through a nerveracking week of uncertainy last night. He is waiting to find out if he has contracted a dangerous disease in the course of his duty or if he is simply a lucky young man.
AMERICA'S own ice princess won her Olympic crown only after fifteen years of self-imposed slavery.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- Robert E. Wilson, former chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), was named by President Eisenhower today to be a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

FLANNERY O'CONNOR, whose talent for fiction is so great as to be almost overwhelming, is a sort of literary white witch. She writes with blazing skill about the most appalling horrors and sometimes makes them seem entirely real and perfectly natural -- major and inevitable elements in the sinful lot of man.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 23 -- Leading by 4 points with 4:33 to play, Fairleigh Dickinson's basketball team scored 16 straight points and defeated St. Michael's of Winooski Park, Vt., 84 -- 69, tonight. The game was the last of the home season for the Knights, who finished with an 11 -- 1 record on their count.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- The Labor Department is investigating more than 500 complaints of violations of the new labor-reform law.
ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Governor Rockefeller submitted to the Legislature today the draft of a broad new law to bar racial and religious discrimination in private housing.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 23 (AP) -- More than one-third of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's trains reached three stations late during the last half of 1959, a witness for the railroad told the state Public Utilities Commission today.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 23 -- The men's slalom race looms as the big event tomorrow in the sixth session of the Winter Olympic Games. Seventy-three racers have been named for the competition.

LEROY WHITNEY has embarked on a new career, made possible by the American craze for buying everything, including hunting and fishing, in packages. But he doesn't expect to pursue it much beyond his hundredth birthday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 23 -- If zeal and eagerness to get to work count for anything, the Yankees already look to be off to a flying start on the 1960 baseball season.

Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country, with the exception of Alaska and Hawaii, amounted to $2,192,949,000 last month. This was a decline of 5 per cent from the comparable month last year, when the amount was $2,319,167,000, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York has signed a contract with Harcourt, Brace for the publication of a book to be called "Discrimination -- U.S.A." It will be an analysis of the current status of discrimination against racial, religious and national minorities.

Black, Sivalls Bryson A reduction in the quarterly dividend was reported yesterday by Black, Sivalls Bryson, Inc., refinery equipment maker. The company will pay 20 cents a share on March 23 to holders of record of March 1, compared with 35 cents in previous quarters.

Directors of the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation yesterday proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock and announced record sales and earnings for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31. Following news of the stock split, the company's stock on the Big Board advanced yesterday to 118 1/2 where it closed for a gain of 1 3/4 points on the day.

Jefferson High of Brooklyn rallied and defeated Lane of Queens, 59 -- 49, in a second-round game of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship at Madison Square Garden yesterday. John Adams of Queens defeated its borough rival, Bryant, 67 -- 45, and gained the quarter-finals with Jefferson.
THE battle lines are forming for a show-down involving the Big Four powers of lawn tennis-the United States, Britain, France and Australia -- that could wreck the amateur game.

THEATREGOERS who have become weary and surfeited with the stark realism of today's stagecraft might profit from a visit to the New York City Center. There they will find the activities of the Piccolo Teatro dl Milano not only edifying, but also amusing.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Feb. 23 -- The erection of two new Delaware River vehicular, bridges and two new marine terminals along that waterway were proposed today.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 -- James R. Hoffa said today that he would demand a single national contract covering 400,000 local and long-distance truck drivers in negotiations with trucking employers next year.
BRASILIA, Brazil, Feb. 23 -- The Presidents of the United States and Brazil proclaimed today a "hemispheric crusade for economic development."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 23 (AP) -- Navy scored an 80-52 basketball victory over Delaware today. The Blue Hens scored only one field goal in the last nine minutes.
If there is a mental block in tonight's Rangers-Detroit game in the Garden, it should rest or the visitors, who have not beaten the Blues in a National Hockey League contest since Nov. 22.

Wilt (the Stilt) Chamberlain put on an eye-catching one-man show before a capacity turnout of 18,496 basketball buffs Madison Square Garden last night. With Chamberlain scoring 53 points, the Philadelphia Warriors whipped the Celtics, 126 -- 108, and delayed Boston's clinching of a fourth straight Eastern Division championship in the National Basketball Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23 -- The Screen Actors Guild announced today that actors would go out on strike against the major movie studios on March 7. Such a strike would, almost certainly, shut down movie production at the studios here.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Dave Charnley, the British and Empire lightweight boxing champion, punched his way to a ten-round decision over the French titleholder, Sauveur Benamou, at the empire pool tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- The American Bar Association narowly declined today to oppose repeal of the Connally reservation limiting United States adherence to the International Court of Justice.
CAIRO, Feb. 23 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to be trying to soothe Arab and Israeli passions.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 23 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek, who welcomed President Eisenhower in Brasilia, today, is an energetic man of immense staying powers, an infectious grin and a charm so great that the criticisms of his policies have never turned into personal antagonisms.

With the end of the heating oil season approaching, the oil industry is going through a period of readjustment. To prevent excessive increases inventories, several refiners have curtailed operations. In addition, there has been some increase by refineries in gasoline prices and a reduction in heating oil quotations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- President Eisenhower vetoed today a bill to increase efforts to clear pollution from rivers. He did so because it required the use of more Federal funds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A spokesman for car manufacturers reported to Congress today that much progress had been made in reducing the emission of poisonous gases by engines.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23 (AP) -- One of the factions seeking control of Managed Funds, Inc., $62,000,000 St. Louis mutual fund, sent out proxies to share-holders today along with a letter saying nine candidates would be nominated for a new board.
THE world of custom-made clothes is reserved largely for a fashionable few. The champagne and caviar of Amercan fashion, custom-order collections are lingering luxuries in an age of mass production.

Wool futures prices rose sharply in moderately active trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Sevety-nine grease wool notices 112 top (cleaned wool) tent were posted. The ready acceptance of the deliveries strengthened the market despite lower prices at the Australian auctions.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- White college students joined Negroes today in sitdown protests here.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 23 -- After a few days of illness Chancellor Adenauer is back at his office determined, according his associates, to Keep on crying alarm over the Berlin problem.

The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority expects to undertake the first financing of the $300,000,000 Narrows Bridge project with an offering of about $100,000,000 of revenue bonds on or about April 19.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 -- The Argentine Navy officially conceded today that the submarines it had been hunting in territorial waters for twentyfour days had got away.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI) -- There was the usual confusion at Squaw Valley today.
The public market for fixed income securities was mostly on the defensive yesterday. Business was light.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An editorial published in The Times of Feb. 9 and a Feb. 8 article by your correspondent Paul Kennedy present El Salvador as a country where political and social unrest prevails due to a difficult economic situation and to adverse political conditions impairing the stability of the country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 -- A divided House Ways and Means Committee voted today to give President Eisenhower broad new powers to raise interest rates on some Government bonds.
ALGIERS, Feb. 23 -- The police and army forces looked among European extremists today for the perpetrators of a bombing attack in which several downtown stores were heavily damaged last night.

A completely new approach to the problems of the textile industry, "possibly even a protectionist approach," was urged yesterday by Harry L. Dalton, vice chairman of American Viscose Corporation, to forestall a harmful buildup of imported goods.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- In submitting a bill today to ban discrimination in private housing, Governor Rockefeller has set the stage for what may be the last major civil rights battle to be fought out in the Legislature.

THIS department receives many requests for sources of prepared hors d'oeuvres. It therefore welcomed notice of two new developments that have recently occurred in this field -- one very fancy, the other a little more down to earth.
The police were confronted yesterday with a mystery of dead pigeons.

The Norfolk and Western Railway, which merged with the Virginian Railway late last year, reported yesterday consolidated net income for January of $4,962,006. This was 10 per cent above the $4,506,511 cleared in the 1959 month.

FOOD and emotions can be closely related and few know this better than Manorama Phillips. Miss Phillips is a diminutive, dark-haired young woman with a mercurial smile who has lived in the United States for nearly four years.
After a five-hour hearing yesterday Federal Judge Alexander Bicks refused to free a landscape gardener who contended that he was being illegally held by the Army as a war-time deserter.
YESTERDAY (Feb. 24, 1960) THE PRESIDENT In Brazil. Sent reassuring report on space program to Congress.
TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- Dr. Alfred Kahn called on institutions that treat juvenile delinquents today to adopt more effective and specific programs.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- The West German Defense Ministry is going ahead with plans to establish military supply bases in Spain despite mounting opposition to the idea throughout Western Europe.

The Bethlehem Steel Com- pany's shipbuilding division was ordered yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board to produce by Monday all its financial records of contracts for Navy and private ship con- struction work from 1946 to 1959.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Eddie Goldberg sparked a Syracuse rally in the last ten minutes that downed Colgate, 83 -- 71, in basketball tonight.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 24 -- Violence flared through the streets for the second straight day today, threatening often to explode into a racial riot. Cool police action averted more serious trouble.
CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Barring an upset by challenges of fifty votes counted yesterday, an insurgent group will win the presidency and three other top offices in the strife-ridden Local 88, largest union within the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.
Geoffrey Atkins, the world champion, scored the deciding victory for the United States yesterday in the international racquets match with Britain at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Fordham lost to Rutgers in overtime, 98 -- 84, in a basketball game marked by fifty-four personal fouls last night in the Rams' gymnasium. The Rams played the final twenty seconds with only four players.
Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith, directors of the American Ballet Theatre, have announced the personnel and repertory of the company's forthcoming season at the Metropolitan Opera House.
An American invention that went abroad to be developed may give new impetus to the sale of economy imported cars.

Tonight's the night when Tom (Satch) Sanders, the 6-foot 6-inch New York University captain and center, expects to become the fourth player in Violet basketball history to reach a total of 1,000 points.
In another effort to solve the German problem, the United States is preparing with its allies a new plan to be submitted to Premier Khrushchev at the summit meeting in May.

CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Major league baseball moved today to "assure" the future of the players' pension fund by extending the TV-radio contract for the world series and all-star games through 1966 at $500,000-a-year rise in revenue.
PORTAGE, Wis., Feb. 24 -- Senator John F. Kennedy emphasized in speeches today the importance of the Wisconsin primary election for the nation.

DECLARER'S play in the deal shown, which occurred in a New York club game, has recently been much discussed and also much admired, because several of the best players and card analysts failed to find the winning play when the deal was shown to them.

Manhattan Borough Presided Hulan E. Jack asked yesterday that the indictment against him be dismissed because the charges that he had conspired to obstruct justice and violated the City Charter had been improperly joined.

A SPRITELY and hilarious small revue, with Beatrice Lillie, Cyril Ritchard, Tammy Grimes and Tony, Randall sharing in the honors of the hour, was presented last night on the "Pontiac Star Parade" over Channel 4.
REGINALD ROSE was dealing with profound concepts in "The Cruel Day," his drama on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2 last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -- The Transport Workers Union announced today that contract negotiations with the Pennsylvania Railroad had broken off and a strike vote would be taken.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Juscelino Kubitschek's welcome to President Eisenhower on his arrival here today, of General Eisenhower's response and of the United States leader's address to a joint session of the Brazilian Congress, and excerpts from an address by Dr. Kubitschek at a dinner at the Foreign Ministry tonight:
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 24 (AP) -- Alabama collected income tax from the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on $27,000 of disputed earnings before he was charged with making false tax returns.

Dame Myra Hess is celebrating her seventieth birthday today. She will not be celebrating it with music. Her schedule calls for a free night, and she hopes to "have a nice time" in Washington -- talking to a few old friends in England, thinking about her years before the public and thinking about the years to come.
MISCHA ELMAN played a violin recital at Carnegie Hall last night that made it clear that the playing of this remarkable artist has not lost its individual quality.
A MATTRESS that a woman can lift with one hand has been developed by the William Intner Company.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 24 -- With no Alpine events on the schedule, cross-country at near-by McKinney Creek will hold the skiing spotlight in the Winter Olympics tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Justice Department has declined to take a position either for or against a proposal to ban the death penalty for civilian defendants in Federal courts.
At the end of next football season Jim Lee Howell will step down from the Job of head coach of the New York Giants and up to the job of the same organization's director of player personnel.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Irish-bred Seaneen won the $23,250 Christopher J. Fitzgerald Handicap on Santa Anita's turf course today.

Net income of the White Motor Company and its subsidiaries climbed last year to $14,209,244, or $6.94 a share, from $7,191,352, or $3.48 a share the year before, it was announced yesterday. Net sales rose to 333,101,125 from $269,476,766.
SQUAW VALLEY, Feb. 24 (UPI) --Two Europeans led the field today in the men's Olympic figure skating and three of the next four places were filled by United States representatives.

WHEN John Martin Murtagh, one generation removed from County Mayo, moves today from the office of Chief City Magistrate to that of Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions he will leave a record difficult to match.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- A sharp setback in Government securities had a slightly unsettling effect on industrial prices in the stock market here today.
CHATTANOOGA, Feb. 24 (AP) -- When the crowds refused to disperse today, Mayor P.R. Olgiati ordered hoses used.
Americans gave $7,800,000,000 for philanthropic purposes last year -- $700,000,000 more than in 1958 -- an annual study of giving habits showed yesterday.
"A Ball in the Opera House" will follow a performance of "The Gypsy Baron" at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 8.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- Army tallied its thirteenth hockey victory today by defeating the University of Pennsylvania, 12 -- 2, at Smith Rink.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 24 -- Cariocans by the hundreds of thousands came from the hills, beaches and backwaters of the Guanabara Bay area today to join in welcoming President Eisenhower to Rio de Janeiro.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare told Congress today that the automobile industry should equip all new cars with devices to control gases that are polluting the air.

A strong protest by Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco and Staten Island civic leaders led Mayor Wagner last night to promise a review of this year's 26.7 per cent increase in real estate assessments in the borough.
The International Mining Corporation in an announcement issued for release today disclosed a proposal to acquire the Canton Company of Baltimore.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The United States and Canada remained unbeaten and tied for first place in the championship round-robin of the Olympic Winter Games tonight as each scored its third straight victory.

Rio de Janeiro anticipated the carnival that begins a few days from now and made a happy, exuberant holiday of yesterday for President Eisenhower. Taking this as the first South American capital to be visited, it certainly was an auspicious start for the President's trip to the southern continent.
City school officials, in their quest for greater authority over the education budget, said yesterday they were actually seeking powers they had long held but had not used.
What attracts the consumer? What makes him want to buy?
Nineteen rare new flamingoes were shown to the press by the Bronx Zoo yesterday. They had been captured in an ice-fringed salt-water lake at an elevation of 14,800 feet in the Bolivian Andes.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Both entry fees and qualifications for membership in the old comrades' defense association maintained by the United States and British Governments have risen in the last ten days.
Charles Van Doren reappeared yesterday in the public debate on television and contended that censorship would be useless.

WHEN Mrs. Olga Gordon deplaned at Valencia, Spain, last fall, she stepped into a world where a woman's voice is seldom raised outside the home. During the two weeks following, Mrs. Gordon literally talked morning, noon and night persuading twenty-seven furniture manufacturers to restyle their offerings for the American market.
CRYSTAL does to a room what diamonds do to a simple black sheath. However, the strain on the pocketbook need not be comparable.
Details of a comprehensive planning study of the six-mile stretch of North River waterfront from the Battery to West Seventy-second Street were outlined here yesterday.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- The State Commissioner of Conservation and Economic Development declared today that 254 of the 279 municipalities in north Jersey had residential areas with at least some evidence of blight.

CHALKHILL, Pa., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- A mountaineer rifleman killed four persons and wounded five others before he was flushed out of his barri caded home today by a twentyfive-ton tank and shot to death while trying to escape in a car.

WORLD WAR II inspired many new inventions. The latest one to be adapted to civilian use is a process developed by American Cyanamid for strengthening paper to provide waterproof, tough maps for military use.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Senate investigators presente figures today showing that only a few companies produced som of the major drugs.
An 18-year-old girl with a pony-tail hair-do was relieved yesterday of having to defend herself in Housing Court against charges of not supplying enough heat in a Manhattan tenement.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- The Soviet radio and television have been ordered to revise their policies and modernize their techniques to provide more effective and better propaganda and entertainment.

Helen Hayes and Jason Robards Jr. will co-star in "The Bat," the premiere offering of the "Hour of Great Mysteries" television series to be produced by Robert Saudek Associates. The series will begin March 31 (9 to 10 P.M.), over the National Broadcasting Company network.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Joseph F. Carlino, the Assembly speaker, was denounced on the floor of the lower house today for asserting that New York City was getting the reputation of being the "worst governed" city in the country.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 24 -- At the 1932 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y., a reporter was a man with a notebook hovering at the end of a ski course or a bobsled run waiting for the judges to do their figuring and announce the winners.
A new free-trade zone at Mayaguez, P.R., offering virtual tax exemption and other benefits, was pictured yesterday as providing a major stimulus to United States exports.
HAVANA, Feb. 24 -- The Soviet exhibition in the Palace of Fine Arts, which closes tomorrow, has turned Russia into a "neighboring country" in the minds of Cubans.

THE GOVERNOR Sent to Senate for confirmation the reappointment of James A. Fariey Jr. of New York City as member of the State Athletic Commission for term ending Jan. 1. 1963. Conferred with Burch McMorran, State Public Works Commissioner.
DSCHANG, Cameroon, Feb. 23 -- A band of rebel youths drugged with hashish gave this town a night of horror last week.

The Metropolitan Regional Council, a voluntary organization of elected officials in counties and local governments of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, has decided after prolonged study to seek official status as a tri-state federation. The vote for such formalization was overwhelming; the only active dissent came from Bergen and Essex Counties in New Jersey.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 24 -- In a dramatic comeback that had a crowd of 4,000 roaring, Austria regained some of her lost skiing prestige today.
A laboratory test to prevent serious mistakes of diagnosis among asthma patients is being developed by a physician at the Brooklyn Hospital.
A cab driver struck a 4-year-old girl in West Harlem yesterday, gathered her into his arms and said he was taking her to a hospital.

The Elizabeth River Tunnel Commission, in Virginia, is planning to offer $41,500,000 of revenue bonds for public subscription on Feb. 26 to finance construction of a second vehicular tunnel linking Norfolk and Portsmouth and to refinance the first tunnel.
It's much too late to second-guess the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League fight, but it isn't too late for the last-place Blues to take another look at Al Rollings, their goalie.

The American Theatre Wing, the organization devoted to training talented professional and nonprofessional performers, will set in motion next month a program that will bring live theatre to various high schools in the city.
BAL HARBOUR, Pla., Feb. 24 -- James R. Hoffa complained today about the high cost of watchdogs.

A vacant plot of land, 65 by 100 feet, at the southeast corner of Broadway and West 239th Street, in the Riverdale area of the Bronx, has beer sold for $25,000 by T.J. O'Brien in a deal negotiated by John A. Moran Son, brokers.

Justice Phillip B. Thurston of the Children's Court warned a group of Harlem parents yesterday that school-attendance laws must be obeyed. He said, however, that whether children went to public or private schools was a matter of individual preference.

Organized labor, management and state and Federal Governments share responsibility for the general exclusion of Negroes from the nation's apprenticeship training programs, a report to the Administration charges.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Treasury is "seriously considering" the insertion of optional call provisions in future issues of long-term bonds, Secretary Robert B. Anderson said today.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 24 -- Seventeen Dominicans, including university students, were fired on by a Dominican plainclothes man today as they drove onto the grounds of the Brazilian Embassy residence today to seek asylum.
ROME, Feb. 24 -- The Cabinet of Premier Antonio Segni resigned today.

Capt. Donald Macintyre of the British Navy, who has one book scheduled for publication next month, will have a second published in April. On March 4 Norton will issue "The Thunder of the Guns," a history of the battleship.

A faculty member who was to have been dismissed tomorrow from the United States Merchant Marine Academy won a stay yesterday until March 4. His case will be reviewed Monday by the Maritime Administration.

George A. Brenner, a former surrogate and county judge in Westchester was sentenced yesterday to four to seven years in prison. He had pleaded guilty to charges of forgery and grand larceny in a $718,425 stock fraud.
A spokesman for the kraft paper industry said yesterday that the industry was "standing still' while competitive packaging materials, particularly plastics, were "running off" with its markets.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24 -- The Moscow Hippodrome's dreams of trotting glory got a rude jolt today from a scatning public attack on the fitness of its managers, drivers, horses and clientele.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Governor Rockefeller made an impassioned plea to members of the Legislature today on behalf of his program for mandatory fall-out shelters.
QUEMOY, Feb. 24 -- The island of Quemoy, confronted on three sides by Communist China's guns, presented a deceptive picture as it basked under a warm sun today.
BOSTON, Feb. 24 -- Willem M.L. van Rie categorically denied today that lie had killed Lynn Kauffman.
Stock market interest concentrated on a few issues yesterday as prices and volume fell.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Southern opponents of civil rights legislation announced today that they would fight the Senate leadership with every available parliamentary obstructing device. Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, leader of the Southern Democrats, said that beginning tomorrow he would not permit any business to be transacted by unanimous consent.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The ninety-six winners of special 1960 state scholarships for chil- dren of dead or disabled veterans were announced today by the Education Department.

THOSE old-fashioned souls who like to read of an evening had better start learning, Braille. The reading lamp, already overwhelmingly outnumbered in stores by decorative "accent" and general lighting lamps, seems doomed to extinction.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

American Crystal Sugar Co. American Crystal Sugar Company has declared an extra dividend of 25 cents and the usual quarterly of 45 cents on the common, payable on March 31 to holders of record of March 15. No extra was paid last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- An assistant Attorney General of Louisiana told the Supreme Court today that voters in his state could be disqualified for failing to dot an "i" or cross a "t" on their registration forms.
The State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York questioned Rosa J. Di Spagno, former assistant to Richmond Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco, in closed session yesterday.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the No. 1 railroad in the nation, had a net income of $333,976 last month. The New York Central Railroad, second only to the Pennsylvania, cleared $1,096,039, or three times as much as the Pennsylvania.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 24 -- Top leaders of the National Council of Churches fired their first public broadside here today against detractors and critics of the interdenominational body.
A $17,000,000 expansion of aluminum facilities in India was announced yesterday by Aluminium, Ltd.
Record sales in the third and fourth quarters of 1959 raised last year's volume of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company to $539,640,773 from $531,972,823 in 1958.

The Committee for Economic Development has published another of its always studious and constructive papers dealing with contemporary questions of public policy. The subject of this one is indicated and its central theme clearly suggested by its title, "National Objectives and the Balance of Payments Problem."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is only natural that public attention paid to the current proposals to secure Negro voting rights by "referees" or "registrars" should take the form of a comparison of the Administration and Civil Rights Commission bills, with liberals asking: Which is stronger?
ELMONT, L.I., Feb. 24 -- The ancient abacus and the modern electronic calculator are being used to teach mathematics to 1,300 pupils at the Alva. T. Stanforth Junior High School here.
Cotton futures moved 7 points (35 cents a bale) up to 3 points (15 cents) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The American Legion, steadfast foe of foreign ideologies, embraced today an election idea that found its stimulus in the propagandistic needling of a girl tourist guide at the Kremlin.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: James Reston's disquieting articles on Cuba in The New York Times point to plans for possible with- drawal of United States credits in Cuba and to the promotion of favor- able trade deals with other Latin-American neighbors to foster the isolation of Castro's Cuba from the rest of the hemisphere.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Communist China's propagandists are using some of their most critical phrases to describe President Eisenhower's visit to Latin America.

C. NORTHCOTE PARKINSON, the eminent lawgiver, calls his new book "The Law and the Profits." It is a blazingly funny attack on high taxation and it appears, of course, in a season when that infernal subject is much on the minds, if not deep in the hearts, of men and women and candidates for the Presidency.

THE National Academy of Design's 135th annual exhibition of painting, sculpture, prints, murals and architectural design opens today at the Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue. The exhibition, open free to the public from 1 to 5 P.M. daily, including Sundays, will run until March 20.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Senate Republicans lined up today behind a cut in the state income tax. They did not specify how much it would be, but estimates ranged from $32,500,000 to $45,000,000.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- British suspicion and distrust of West Germany exploded tonight as a result of the Federal Republic's quest for military bases in Spain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Cuba has in effect retracted statements made by Premier Fidel Castro that Ambassador Philip W. Bonsal of the United States engaged in plots against the Cuban Government.

The Board of Standards and Appeals refused yesterday to void a zoning exemption it had granted to a dry-cleaning plant to operate in a residential area on East Sixty-fourth Street between Second and Third Avenues.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- One of the nation's leading space scientists told Congress today that the space program was being hampered by confusion, indecision and increasing military domination.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today that there were no inherent flaws or dilemmas in the present system of international payments an reserves.
TORONTO, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs gained ground in a bid for second place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-1 decision over the Montreal Canadiens.
TACKLE manufacturers, parading their new stuff to catch the erratic fancy of the bold, hardy outdoorsmen, swell with commercial pride over advertised advances that are often quite real.

In a new booklet, "Dividends For More than A Decade,'' the American Stock Exchange lists its honor roll of 311 companies, or 44 per cent of the stocks traded, that have paid dividends from ten to 111 years.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The President's Committee on Government Contracts announced today a new action program to breach the barrier to employment of Negroes on Federal construction contracts.
ALBANY, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Department of Commerce:

Mayor Wagner accepted yesterday a station invitation to join with Governor Rockefeller in a televised "open discussion" of state financial aid for the city. In Albany, Governor Rockefelle rhad "no immediate comment" on the invitation extended to him.
ALGIERS, Feb. 24 -- The French police tightened their control of travel between Algeria and mainland France today.

Production of electric power rose to 14,226,000,000 kilowatthours in the week ended last Saturday from 14,071,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before. A year ago the figure was 13,259,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
TAMPAKSIRING, Indonesia, Feb. 24 -- Premier Khrushchev conferred with President Sukarno of Indonesia for an hour and a half today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The Writers Guild announced tonight an agreement with Universal-International Studios that would give writers a share of profits from sale of post-1948 U-I theatrical films for home or pay television.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Federal Government is adopting a single set of regulations for the contracts it lets on competitive bids.

The central tank at the National Outdoor Exposition in the Coliseum, the scene daily of vaudeville-type acts that include a high-wire performer and a boomerang thrower, also contains a field dog demonstration. The dogs are real hunting dogs, not trick dogs.

The Jewish population of New York City was put at 2,114,000 persons in a study released yesterday by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. Adherents of the Jewish faith now make up 27.1 per cent of the population of the city.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 24 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States would "consider it intervention" in the internal affairs of the Americas if any power denied freedom of choice to any republic in the Western Hemisphere.
IN the last act of Benn W. Levy's "The Tumbler," put on at the Helen Hayes Theatre last evening, a series of classical relationships do take hold of an audience's imagination.
WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 24 -- The twenty-two pupils of a one-room school in Greasy Creek, Ky., have presented two handmade maple chairs to the Bedford Elementary School here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: New York University has been attempting for four or five years to obtain a site for a faculty-staff housing project somewhere in the Washington Square area. Each site that was studied had certain object- tionable features.

M.H. Lamston, Inc., a chain of variety stores, has leased substantially the entire ground floor and basement area of the eighteen-story apartment house under construction at 773-81 Lexington Avenue, southeast corner of Sixty-first Street.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation announced yesterday the second consecutive cut in its quarterly dividend and a sharp drop in earnings for 1959. At the same time, the company disclosed the development of a new form of propeller for a wingless airplane.
MIAMI, Feb. 24 -- The Tally-Ho Stable's My Old Flame showed speed and soundness in winning the $24,300 Florida Breeders Stakes at Hialeah today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 24 -- President Eisenhower's visit to Rio, which began today, is likely to be the last big event that this city will witness as Brazil's capital. Within two months Brasilia will become the seat of government.
Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh was named yesterday to be Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions.

"The Lincoln Lords" We have no better evidence of the role that literature plays in our lives than to recall the many char- acters in fiction who have so cap- tured our imagination that they have been welcomed into the lan- guage.

A PROPOSAL to guarantee New York City women teachers a "child-care period" as part of basic maternity leave may indicate a new trend. This innovation would permit a new mother up to five years' leave from her position before she returns to teaching.
Two new screen adaptation of plays by Pulitzer Prize-winnig dramatists have been booked at local theatres.

The new Middle East representative of an American oil company, fresh off the plane from New York, opened his suitcase in the bedroom of the strange house his family would occupy for the next three years.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Harold J. Gibbons, right-hand man of James R. Hoffa, and five other teamster union of ficials were indicted today on Federal charges of illegal political contributions.

ALTAMONT, Tenn., Feb. 24 -- The executive council of the inter-racial Highlander Folk School announced today that it would continue and expand the school's program regardless of the outcome of litigation to dissolve its charter.
Bond prices moved irregularly yesterday. There was an improved demand for United States Government securities of short and intermediate term, but otherwise prices tended generally to sag.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Robert C. Sprague, who was cochairman of a Presidential committee on national security in 1957, told Congress today that the Soviet military threat was more serious than President Eisenhower has indicated.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 24 -- The French Army command in West Germany has restricted a Soviet military liaison mission to its headquarters compound in Baden-Baden.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24 -- The Yankees' 1960 spring training season did not quite get off to the impressive start today that Casey Stengel had planned so carefully. For of all things, good old trusty Iron Mike came up with a sore arm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Ezra Taft Benson indicated totoday that the Administration could accept a wheat bill that would provide for slightly lower Federal price supports and a continuation of production controls.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics tonight clinched at least a tie for the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division title and set a league record for games won in a season by thrashing the Minneapolis Lakers, 131 -- 110.
Following is President Eisenhower's official program for his South American trip. All times are regional (Eastern Brazil and Argentina are two hours ahead of Eastern standard time.)
PARIS, Feb. 24 -- Three Algerian nationalist chiefs and a number of Frenchmen suspected of aiding the Moslem rebel movement have been arrested in Paris, the Interior Ministry announced today.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the election of John A. Fuller as a director. Mr. Fuller is president of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company, Montreal, and chairman of Shawinigan Chemicals, Ltd.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (UPI) -- The Bellehurst Stable's Warfare, the champion juvenile of 1959, heads a list of 161 nominations, released today, for the eighty-fourth running of the $150,000 added Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on May 21.

Trade short covering, new purchasing and chart buying raised wool prices yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange This was the second consecutive day of sharp advances. Scale-up hedging, new short selling and commission house liquidation supplied the contracts.

Fred J. Loughran admitted yesterday at his extortion trial in Kings County Court that he had borrowed $5,000 from a group of Brooklyn kosher butchers in 1952 and had paid it back after it was demanded four years later.
LIFE in the horse latitudes has been sometimes pleasant, always interesting and occasionally vexing for Spencer J. Drayton in the last fourteen years.

The Duquesne Light Company sold $20,000,000 of fifty-year sinking fund debentures to First Boston Corporation and associated investment banking houses at an interest cost to the utility of 4.992 per cent.
PARIS, Feb. 24 -- France's biggest farm organization asked today that Parliament meet to back farm agitation for price supports.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 24 -- A 110-ton Titan, designed as this country's mightiest war rocket, roared from its launching pad here today in a "highly successful" flight that carried a data capsule more than 5,000 miles down the South Atlantic missile range.

The Department of State has called to the attention of the legislature at Albany the international implications involved in passage of a bill permitting foreign banks to establish branches in New York State.
ALBANY, Feb. 24- - Legislation to implement a major part of New York City's fiscal program at Albany was filed through the Assembly Rules Committee today.
PARIS, Feb. 24 -- France's biggest farm organization asked today that Parliament meet to back farm agitation for price supports.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 24 -- A 110-ton Titan, designed as this country's mightiest war rocket, roared from its launching pad here today in a "highly successful" flight that carried a data capsule more than 5,000 miles down the South Atlantic missile range.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 25 -- Arthur M. Loew, former president of Loew's, Inc., has withdrawn an offer of his $400,000 estate to the residents of this city because he feels he will lose his privacy.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 5 -- The Middlebury College women's ski team took three of the first four places today in the downhill race, the opening event in the twenty-ninth winter carnival here. The women's meet will end tomorrow with the slalom.

Tom (Satch) Sanders of New York University reached the 1,000-point mark of his three-year varsity career, but Tony Jackson of St. John's just missed that magic circle by 1 point during the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.
Fluffy, thick flakes of snow filled the metropolitan air yesterday with pretty polar patterns and then obligingly faded away on concrete and macadam.
The bond market in genera lacked assurance yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Truck loadings in the nation last week were above 1959 levels and only slightly ahead of those of the week before. The combination of two area-wide snow storms last week and the observance of Lincoln's Birthday at some points in the preceding week affected the week-to-week tonnage figures.

THERE were five persons in the hut -- four Chinese Communist guerrillas and their prisoner, a 19-year-old English girl. A huge swamp and many miles of tropical jungle lay between them and the towns and plantations of the Malayan coast. Behind them was the largest mountain range of the peninsula.
Dr. Robert W. Burgess, the census director, yesterday joined top officials who will direct the census-taking here five weeks from today in beating the drum for enumerators.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Inconsistency's name can sometimes be "mother," a psychiatrist said here today. And the child who seems to be "asking for trouble" by his misbehavior may really be asking for consistent maternal discipline.
Marc Blitzstein's partly completed opera based on the Sacco and Vanzetti case has been commissioned by the Ford Foundation and may be performed at the Metropolitan Opera.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Government has sharply reduced the level of strontium 90 intake permitted for humans over a lifetime.
Motor vehicle officials representing eleven Northeastern states and six Canadian provinces agreed yesterday to exchange information on convictions of out-of-state driven.

The United States will have to make a "tremendous push" to increase forest resources if it is to meet future needs for wood products, Richard E MeArdle, chief of the United States Forest Service, said yesterday.
MIAMI, Feb. 25 -- Charles Kehoe of Miami won the Miami Lightning regatta today by defeating Tom Fallon of Buffalo in the third and final heat.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Fifty-six House members set up today a committee to combat the announced plans of James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, to try to defeat them in November.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 25 -- Argentina's sprawling capital awaited President Elsenhower's arrival tomorrow in a sweltering summer heat wave. The Weather Bureau forecast scattered showers.
CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Rye futures today became the third commodity this week to sell at new low prices for the season on the Board of Trade.

Mayor Wagner assured Staten Island real estate taxpayers yesterday that they would receive a sympathetic hearing of their complaints, but pointed out that assessing the valuation on property was the "sole prerogative of the city's assessors."
ABOARD U.S.S. GLACIER, Off Antarctica, Feb. 24 -- This icebreaker was on her way early today to help the Argentine icebreaker trapped near Marguerite Bay on the west side of Palmer Peninsula.

The American Seal-Kap Corporation of Delaware, a diversified holding company, announced yesterday that David W. Wallace had been named executive vice president. Mr. Wallace, 36, until November of last year was vice president of the Allegheny Corporation, holding company that controls the New York Central Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A prominent business executive today described as inadequate the United States effort to meet the Soviet threat to its security. He was Thomas J. Watson Jr., head of the International Business Machines Corporations who said he was unaffiliated with either political party, but had voted twice for President Eisenhower.

BOUNCE ANDERSON is hanging around New York giving to all hands the details about the explosion of biggame fishing in the last couple of years along the Outer Banks of North Carolina, while he whips everyone into a frenzy about the international blue martin tournament slated for June.

The Winter Garden has been designated as the home for "Camelot," starring Richard Burton and Julie Andrews. The next show by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, creators of "My Fair Lady," will open there Nov. 17.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 25 -- The two chief spokesmen for American protestantism vigorously defended the National Council of Churches today against charges that it was infiltrated with Communists.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- A banker and a lawyer on opposite side of the question of allowing New York City banks to expand to the suburbs joined today in questioning the constitutionality of one way the state proposes to bring this about.
MIAMI, Feb. 25 -- Open View of the Elkcam Stable won the feature event on the Hialeah program today, to the satiafaction of the favorite players in the crowd of 17,118.

JACQUES HEIM Is an understanding man. Judging from the French couturier's sixth collection for Bonwit Teller, shown yesterday and witnessed by M. Heim, he understands that all young \vomen do not wear sandals, petticoats and uncombed hair and look as though they had been washed up on a muddy beach.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif Feb. 25 -- The chances are just about 10,000,000 to 1 that you will never have to score a figure-skating competition. But knowing how it's done can be a great social asset, not to say a secret weapon.

Mayor Wagner received from the City Planning Commission yesterday a tentative draft of the proposed $100,000,000 redevolopment plan for the twenty-five-acre site of the antiquated Washington wholesale fruit and produce market.
Two trucking associations have protested to the Federal Maritime Board over an Increase in pier loading rates that has been in effect here since Feb. 15.

The hope of Federal civil rights legislation this year was strengthened when a bill designed to help the would-be Negro voter was taken out of committee in the House and scheduled for debate next month. Meanwhile, the Senate has its own bill, which was brought to the floor by one of those parliamentary tricks which everybody applauds when they help his plans and everybody deplores when they interfere with his plans.

TUNIS, Feb. 25 -- A new Algerian nationalist call for peace talks with the French Government, which is to be issued Monday, will be made by Ferhat Abbas, head of the Provisional Government, and will include three points, according to authoritative quarters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Music lovers in many parts of the world have heard the famous Navy Band, some of whose members perished today in a plane collision over Rio de Janeiro.

Stockholders of Loew's, Inc., at their annual meeting here yesterday approved a name change to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc. Trading under the new ticker symbol -- MGM -- will begin today on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Simplex Building Company, manufacturer of electronic equipment, has sold the six-story office building and two-story warehouse at 92-96 Gold Street and 11-17 Jacob Street, near Fulton Street, to an investing client of Walter Scott Co. Joseph Lynn was the broker.

Italy has now begun what may prove to be the most serious political crisis of the post-war era. This would be true even if the crisis were temporarily patched up and Premier Segni were induced to carry on for some months longer.

A champagne-less champagne bottle for christening pleasure boats is one of the novelties on display at the Jersey Coast Boat Show, which will continue its seventh annual run in Convention Hall, Asbury Park, through Sunday night The christening bottle is a big seller.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday opened an inquiry into charges that college theses, term papers and examinations had been ghost-written for a fee by private agencies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Two Senators accused the Department of Defense today of defying the will of Congress by exceeding the limit imposed on military aid to Latin America in last year's foreign aid bill.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Sixteen juniors from five colleges and universities have been selected to participate in the first year of an experimental European summer study program in international affairs.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System has been a disappointment in its coverage of the Olympic winter games in Squaw, Valley, Calif.
THE new Acting Chief City Magistrate, Abraham Micah Bloch, is a clean-city judge. He has imposed stiff fines on litterbugs, telling them sternly:
On next Wednesday the Association of Newspaper Classi ied Advertising Managers will make an award to R.H. Macy Co. in recognition of Macy's beginnings in advertising.
United Air Lines yesterday chose a foreign-designed airliner for short-range pure Jet opera tions in this country.

A CHIC young American woman of Swedish background born and reared in Twin Falls, Idaho, flew out of Idlewild Airport recently for Israel. Her mission is to help the Israelis,create a new cuisine that will be distinctively their own.
MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 25 -- The executive head of the Israel Bond Organization called on American Jews today to intensify their investment in Israel's economic development.
An elementary school official, fighting demotion from principal to assistant principal, involved both himself and the Board of Education in an unusual situation yesterday.
A slate of Democratic convention delegates heavily favorable to the Presidential candidacy of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts was named last night in Queens.

Tenement dwellers displaced by public-works projects under the jurisdiction of the Department of Real Estate will get up to $300 more in relocation benefits under action taken by the Board of Estimate yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower was upheld today in his veto of a bill to increase Federal grants for water pollution control. It was his first veto of the 1960 election year.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 25 -- White and Negro leaders jointly blocked a recurrence of racial violence today over demonstrations against segregated lunch counters.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Women skiers will compete in Alpine and cross-country events tomorrow in the Winter Olympic Games.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- A British physician gave wives pointed advice today on how to keep their husbands alive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25 -- Contract negotiations between the Screen Actors Guild and the Association of Motion Picture Producers resumed today in a tense atmosphere after a lapse of more than three weeks.

WHERE most designers take to the limelight with ease. Bergriorf Goodman's reticent custom-order designer, Leslie Morris, shuns it. Although she has been with the store since 1928, Miss Morris has kept her own identity as carefully guarded as the Lone Ranger's.
Colombia University announced yesterday that 500,000 pages of confidential Japanese archives had been microfilmed and made available for historical research.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Republican leadership in the Legislature embraced today the proposal to make Queens a separate judicial district by severing it from Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 25 -- An instrument that can analyze the polluted air of a smokefilled room or a city street was exhibited here today as a device that could help to eliminate smog.
The winners of the twelfth annual George Polk Memorial Awards for significant achievements in journalism in 1959 were announced yesterday by Long Island University.
The nation's petroleum stocks reacted seasonally in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported.

GEORGE RAPEE, who is one of the best-known champion players and whose name is especially well known to readers of this newspaper, in recent months has not played bridge more often than any other business man who also happens to be a bridge addict.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- late Macleod, Secretary of State for the Colonies, made a strong closing appeal at the Kenya constitutional conference for the protection of property rights and the preservation of a judiciary free of politics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- A physician charged today that "many more people" will be killed by some drugs now on the market "than by all the contaminated cranberries and stilbesterol-treated chickens combined."
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 25 -- The struggle between the Trujillo dictatorship and a determined but nearly despairing opposition continues without any sign of a solution.
Capital Airlines, the country's fifth largest air passenger carrier, announced yesterday that it was having its corporate face lifted.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Paul Hindemith, conductor, Aldo Parisot, 'cellist, Carnegie Hall. 8:30; Herbert Fromm's Sabbath Service, Temple Emanu-El, 5:15; "Die Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera, 7:45; Arturo di Rocca, tenor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Emil Gilels, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:40.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Congressional auditors have prepared a report charging that the Defense Department had wasted millions of dollars worth of military equipment in Turkey, it was disclosed today.
VIENNA, Feb. 25 -- Reports from Warsaw indicated today that the leadership of the Communist party organizations in Poland's provinces was being reorganized.

The Citizens Union urged the city's "civic forces" yesterday to back a bill in Albany to ease the way for a petition by which the voters could obtain a referendum on a charter revision commission here in November.

Two members of England's Oxford Union Debating Society will fly here from London to appear in a televised debate about capital punishment and the Caryl Chessman case.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Consumer prices dropped in January for the second straight month, the Department of Labor reported today. They were at the lowest level since last September.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower warned today against the dangers of material progress achieved at the cost of individual rights and freedoms.
Third and Lexington Avenues will become one-way about the middle of May, Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley said yesterday.

Fred J. Loughran insisted, on cross-examination in Kings County Court yesterday that he saw nothing morally wrong in accepting $5,000 from a group of Brooklyn butchers to cover a second mortgage on his East Islip, L.I. home.
Short-covering and trade buying advanced potato futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading was active.
SHANNON, Ireland, Friday, Feb. 26 -- An Italian airliner carrying fifty-two persons crashed into a cemetery and exploded early today just after taking off for New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call note by which the House upheld today President Eisenhower's veto of a pollution control bill. The vote was on the question of overriding, with two-thirds needed.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Feb. 25 -- President Nasser charged the Western powers today with "premeditating aggression against us" by maintaining their guarantee of the Arab-Israeli frontiers.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 14 points (70 cents a bale) up yesterday. The 1961-crop deliveries were strongest.

Wingate, Van Buren and Port Richmond advanced to the quarter-final round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball play-offs yesterday at Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 13,000 witnessed the triple-header.
The air collision at Rio de Janeiro yesterday and the crash at Shannon Airport raised to 326 the toll of eight major aviation disasters recorded so far in 1960.
A Nobel Prize-winning scientist explained here yesterday how he hopes to drack the natural code that connects the structure of hormones to their biological actions.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 25 -- Brazil's largest city and her economic heart, Sao Paulo, has the reputation of being perhaps the world's fastest-growing metropolis.
ROME, Feb. 25 -- President Giovanni Gronchi will start tomorrow on the political "consultations" that are part of Italian constitutional procedure in Cabinet crises.

A progress report came yesterday from, the seven north-eastern development credit corporations -- the organizations formed to aid small business with loans and advice. In the second half of 1959 the development concerns lent out $2,100,000, raising the total lent to $32,700,000 since the formation of the first corporation in Maine nine years ago.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- One of the oldest and thorniest conservation issues before the Legislature -- what to do about the roccus saxatilis -- erupted here again today.
The writer of the following letter is president of the New York State Citizens Committee for the Public Schools.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Rockefeller accused State Controller Arthur Levitt tonight of making a "misleading and demagogic" attack on his plan to make state income tax laws confirm to Federal practice.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Rockefeller today set up a special advisory committee to examine the state's "competitive position" in industrial and scientific research.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Feb. 25 -- Israel is apprising nine nations and Secretary General Hammarskjold of the United Nations of the build-up of major troop concentrations on her frontier with Egypt.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 25 (AP) -- A stubborn snowstorm that refused to change to rain, as expected, forced Bowie to cancel today's nine-race horse racing program.

WAUSAU, Wis., Feb. 25 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, campaigning amid snow squalls in north-central Wisconsin today, said the challenges of the next decade called for the election of a vigorous and progressive President this year.
IF you have a touch of the winter blues, try a 50-cent cure in the form of a pound of frosh asparagus. The first appreeiable quantities of this vegetable recently arrived from California.

An issue of 541,700,000 of long-term, revenue bonds to finance construction of a second vehicular tunnel connecting the Virginia cities of Norfolk and Portsmonth was marketed successfully here yesterday.

DENPASAR, Indonesia, Feb. 25 -- President Sukarno reaffirmed today Indonesia's friendship with the Soviet Union. He ridiculed nations that "criticized" the Moscow-Jakarta relationship but did not name the nations.

Borrowing by commercial and industrial concerns from leading New York City banks dropped $49,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday. The decline occurred mainly because utilities used the proceeds of recent financing to repay loans and because tobacco concerns reduced their borrowings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Republican Senate leaders are becoming convinced that a historic vote to cut off debate will be essential to break Southern opposition to a civil rights bill.

The report of the National Labor Relations Board on the representation elections it held last year carries disturbing news for organized labor -- news that indicates some of the problems that unions are up against these days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Washington is getting at least one sample these days of legislative investigation at its very best. This is the inquiry being conducted by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, into the operations of the policy-making machinery of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Air Force manual linking United States churches with communism had its day before the House Committee on Un-American Activities today with indecisive results. Following were the highlights:
BONN, Germany, Feb. 25 -- Defense Minister Franz-Josef Strauss said today that West Germany would not conclude military undertakings with Spain without the agreement of its allies.
MADRID, Feb. 25 -- The Spanish press erupted today in Government-directed wrath over the disclosure that West Germany had been quietly negotiating for military facilities here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recent anti-Semitic incidents in Germany have given rise to certain criticisms of the Government of Konrad Adenauer which seem unwarranted. One of these stresses the retention of Dr. Hans Globke in the important post of State Secretary in the Chancellery.
Stocks moved up quietly on increased volume yesterday, adding about $1,000,000,000 to the value of issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 2 per cent below the level of a year ago.
IN a large group show, the Downtown Gallery, 32 East Fifty-first Street, combines young aspirants with painters whose reputations stand unchallenged.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Following are the texts of remarks made by President Eisenhower on his arrival at and departure from Sao Paulo today, and of a speech he made at a luncheon:
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 25 -- A woman bookkeeper was accused here today of stealing $250,000 in the last five years from the U.S. Knitwear Company of Port Chester by juggling the company's records.
As the man in the street can already testify, banks are going in for advertising in a big way.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The United States has informed West Germany that it disapproves of Bonn's independent efforts to arrange for storage depots or air-training sites in Spain.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 25 -- The chances of the United States to gain its first hockey gold medal in Winter Olympic history went skyrocketing to night when the host team defeated Canada, 2 -- 1, at Blyth Arena.
In the week since Al Rollins joined the last-place New York Rangers as goalie, his teammates have come to look upon him as a life preserver in their storm-tossed sea.
RICHMOND, Feb. 25 -- Virginia enacted today three antitrespassing laws aimed at discouraging sitdown protests against segregated eating facilities.
BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- Three witnesses were accused today by Willem M.L. van Rie of lying during his trial for murder.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 25 -- James R. Hoffa created a new headache for the high command of the merged labor federation today.
Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch was named Acting Chief Magistrate yesterday by Mayor Wagner. The appointment will be made permanent as soon as the bar associations endorse Mr. Bloch.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 25 -- President Eisenhower stood hatlesa for more than an hour in a drenching downpour today to promote Brazilian-American friendship. The 500,000 Paulistas watching took him to their hearts.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 25 (UPI) -- Frank Stranahan of Crystal River, Fla., carded an eight-under-par 32, 32 -- 64 and took a three-stroke lead in the opening round of the $20,000 Texas open golf tournament today.
PARIS, Feb. 25 -- The Ministry of the Armed Forces announced plans today to establish an entirely motorized nuclear division.

"Politics U.S.A.: A Practical Guide to the Winning of Public Office" will be published May 27 by Doubleday. Designed to advise professional as well as amateur politicians, the book will contain articles by twenty-three contributors, all of whom have achieved success in practical politics.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The partial withdrawal of Government support for its securities caused prices to fall heavily in the stock market here today.
Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the Rockefeller Institute and the National Academy of Sciences, collapsed last night while delivering a lecture at Columbia University.

THREE more or less contemporary composers -- contemporary about 170 years ago, that is -- were featured on the Music Forgotten and Remembered concert last night at the Metropolitan Museum. They were Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven, and each was represented by a work not too often heard in concert.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Two new facts concerning the state Department's role in the reprieve of Caryl Chessman came to light today.
RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 25 -- Virginia's three-man Pupil Placement Board, set up three years ago as a defense against school integration, has resigned.

HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Private foreign investment in Cuba will be accepted only if delivered to the Government to be used as it sees fit, Premier Fidel Castro said today. His announcement marked the start of his much-heralded program of industrialzation.
Recent work in the Soviet Union in the rehabilitation of retarded children was described here yesterday by Prof. Aleksandr R. Luriya, a visiting Russian psychologist.
Murray Silvern, a real estate agent, was sentenced to thirty days in the workhouse, fined $1,735 and given two years' probation in Housing Court yesterday.
Volunteers who donate blood, but get much of it back again, are helping science to understand one of the vital mechanisms of the human circulatory system.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Devotees of sporting weapons fired a collective volley today at a series of bills backed by the New York City administration to tighten controls on firearms and ammunition.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission laid ground rules today for the operation of variable annuity companies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- An agreement by the National Broadcasting Company to buy television station KTVU in Oakland was announced by the station today. A battle to prevent consummation of the deal was-threatened immediately.

The establishment of a legal commission to evaluate the problems of a rapidly changing society and to bring the law into tune with it was urged last night before a meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
