Sales of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., last year were 19.4 per cent above those in 1958, while earnings rose 41.3 per cent. In 1959, sates totaled $143,123,142, co pared with $119,821,596 the year before. Earnings last year came to $6,209,905, equal to $2.27 a common share, against $4,395,446, or $1.56 a share, in 1958.
WASHINGTON Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Navy issued tonight a revised list of bandsmen listed as missing in the plane crash at Rio de Janeiro. A revised list of crew members of the plane also follows.
The real estate licenses of eight brokers and salesmen were suspended yesterday for allegedly accepting illegal bonuses in the renting of apartments.
ALTHOUGH "Toys in the Attic" is not the greatest play in the world, it is head and shoulders above the level of the season, and it provides opportunities for some extraordinary acting.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP) -- Guy Peirillat, a 20-year-old French skier, was officially designated today as the 1960 world champion for Alpine combined events.

Dayton Power Light Company awarded $25,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds yesterday to Halsey, Stuart Co. and associated investment bankers. The group's winning bid was 99.642 for obligations bearing 5 1/8 per cent interest coupons.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Israel complained to the Security Council today against "warlike threats" and "extensive military preparations" by the United Arab Republic.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 25 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics defeated the Detroit Pistons, 121 -- 107, tonight and clinched their fourth straight Eastern Division title in the National Basketball Association.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Britain has advised West Germany that it would be wiser for it to seek military facilities among the members of the Atlantic aliiance than to negotiate with Spain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Cornelius J. Haggerty of California was chosen today to be president of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- The Coastwise Line, the last offshore common carrier serving the Pacific Coast, abandoned its route yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 25 -- President de Gaulle called on the Algerian rebels today to stop fighting and join other Algerian elements in preparing for self-determination.
Private housing contracts in the last week were the biggest since last July and volume for the year to date is up 31 per cent over a year ago. The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday.
TRENTON, Feb. 25 -- The New Jersey Public Utility Commission won a round today in its battle to keep commuter railroads in operation.
An appeal to Harvard College to "seek out" young men of promise, regardless of their ability to pay tuition, was made yesterday by a faculty committee of senior professors.

The Townsend Corporation of America, a diversified holding company with offices in New York and Short Hills, N.J., announced plans yesterday for developing an industrial research center at Princessville, N.J. between Trenton and Princeton.

Eddie Machen of Portland, Ore., a one-time leading contender for the world heavyweight championship, will be' on the spot when he faces Detroit's Billy Hunter in a scheduled tenround heavyweight fight in Madison Square Garden tonight.

The Atchison, Topeka and Sante Fe Railway's earnings dipped 10 per cent last month, to $3,008,971 from $3,323,214 in the 1959 month. On a common share basis, earnings fell to 10 cents, from 12 cents last year.

THE show at Gallery Mayer, 762 Madison Avenue, provocatively entitled "The Wondrous World of Pehr," consists of numerous quaint little pictures that, not without a certain amount of saucy charm, juggle motifs from surrealism and form artists as far removed as Chagall, Redon and the anonymous artists of the Las Lascaux Caves.
Yale's quintet, demonstrating smooth inside patterns, crushed Columbia, 85 -- 72, last night to gain sole possession of seventh place in the Ivy League.

The Realty Equities Corporation, operators, bought the six-story apartment house for thirty-six families at 51 Buchanan Place, northwest corner of Grand Avenue, the Bronx, from the estate of Max Marcus. The property, 75 by 100 feet, was bought for cash over mortgages amounting to $223,000.
HENDERSON, N.C., Feb. 26 -- (UPI) -- Negro college students hiked seven miles in near-freezing weather from a rural campus today to stage a protest against lunch counter segregation.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- Army routed Cornell, 7-2, in hockey today. It was the cadets' fourteenth victory against five losses and one tie. Cornell has dropped sixteen of seventeen games.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 26 (AP) -- William Hal Bishop's Maribu won the featured Chestertown Purse, the seventh race at Bowie Race Track, today.

The price decline in long-term United States Government bonds of post-war issues continued at a more drastic rate yesterday. Otherwise, the trading session was largely an echo of Thursday's -- inclined to weakness.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Senate rackets committee said today that it had shown up as completely dishonest James R. Hoffa's repeated pledges to stamp corruption out of his Teamsters Union.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 points off to 3 points up yesterday. A definite trend was lacking. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Dartmouth broke a two-game losing streak in Ivy League play tonight with a 67-61 basketball victory over Penn. The Big Green had lost six days ago to the same team at Philadelphia.

Premier Castro's announcement of a program under which about $150,000,000 will be invested in Cuban economic development this year is obviously to be welcomed. Clearly the problem of raising the standard of living of the poverty-stricken mass of the Cuban people requires that new sources of producing wealth be created: new factories, new mines, improved methods of agricultural production and the like.

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs demanded yesterday that Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley be "rebuked" for announcing plans to convert Lexington and Third Avenues to one-way operation. The demand was quickly rebuffed in a sharp retort that had tacit City Hall approval.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Final figures for 1959 showed today that farmers' net income dropped to $11,000,000,000, from $13,100,000,000 in 1958.

TWO hundred years ago, so the story goes, Benjamin Franklin put a pair of "bends" on a straight-backed wooden chair and created an American institution -- the rocker. Tomorrow the rocker's many manifestations, from the sublime to the ridiculous, will be the subject of commemorative exhibits at the sixteenth National Antiques Show.
EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Feb. 26 -- Senator John F. Kennedy campaigned today amidst a rather taciturn group of farmers in western Wisconsin and was not sure how effective he had been.

President Eisenhower is making history on his trip to South America, but he is also the prisoner of past history. This was nowhere more obvious than in Buenos Aires, where Mr. Eisenhower spent the day yesterday. He cannot talk or act as if the long course of Argentina's history, traditions and way of life never existed.
The festive air of Shrove Tuesday celebrations in many parts of the world had a New York preview last night.

GENEVA, Feb. 26 -- The Soviet Union warned today that there could be no treaty to ban nuclear tests unless the West accepted its proposal for a small number of inspections based on political negotiation.

Two City Councilmen criticized hotel, laundry and department store officials because they did not testify yesterday at a public hearing on low wages.

QUEBEC, Feb. 26 -- More than 200 couples attired in period and contemporary costumes gathered tonight in the Chateau Frontenac to attend the Grand Regency Ball, held in connection with the city's sixth Winter Carnival.

Michigan Schools The Fraser, Mich., School District has sold $1,100,000 of serial bonds due from 1962 to 1985 and callable in 1980 to Braun, Bosworth Co. and associates at an interest cost of 4.743 per cent.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 26 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker was kicked in the head and cut in a fall from a horse at Santa Anita today, but apparently escaped serious injury.
New York's only outdoor pulpit stands quiet and all but forgotten in the historic close, or chantry garden, of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Tenth Street.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 26 -- The Air Force failed today in its first experimental attempt to put into orbit a satellite having practical military utility.

CRISTOBAL BALENCIAGA, when I first met him in Paris in 1937, was a gentle-voiced Spaniard with fine, pale skin the texture and color of egg shells and dark hair that lay thick and glistening in wavy layers on his well-shaped head.

The House Ways and Means Committee has approved legislation which, while it pays lip service to the continuance of the 4 1/4 per cent interest rate ceiling now obtaining on longer-term Government securities, would free the Treasury, at least for purposes of the immediately foreseeable future, of the potentially dangerous effects of this anachronistic and mischievous provision of the law.

MIAMI, Feb. 28 -- A 3-year-old horse can win $90,880 tomorrow. The Flamingo Stakes, the first $100,000 added event of the season for 3-year-olds, will be run for the thirty-first time and a dozen colts are listed for the competition.
Moslems in the city will join their religious brethren over the world tomorrow in beginning the month's fast of Ramadan.
The Board of Education taking a new look at the National Defense Education Act to see if more Federal funds can be obtained for vocational education.
City Council President Abe Stark demanded yesterday that the Legislature act now to replace potentially dangerous school buildings.

Many persons entertained last night before the silver anniversary Colonial Ball, which observed the 228th birthday of George Washington, at the Plaza. Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower was honorary benefit committee chairman.

A program of good tenant relations offers the possibility of improving the income from commercial real estate, according to James J. Kennedy, vice president of Huberth Huberth, building managers.

The American-Marietta Company will spend a record of $30,000,000 this year for improvements and modernization of facilities, compared with $22,230,000 expended in 1958, according to Robert E. Pflaumer, president.

SMALL apartment dwellers with large record collections no longer have an excuse for piling the albums on the floor, under the bed and in the closet. Leslie Creations has come up with a new wall-hanging record rack of black wrought iron that has five compartments to hold 100 lone-playing record albums.
BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Bob Cousy sparked the Boston Celtics to a 128-111 victory over then Minneapolis Lakers in a National Basketball Association game today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Mutual funds will be required to disclose more about the companies that advise them and manage their investments, beginning next Friday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 5 -- President Eisenhower left Brazilians optimistic today on the prospects of greater United States support for Latin-American development.

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Tom Mboya, the African nationalist leader, declined today to commit himself or his followers to support the constitutional proposals for Kenya hammered out in the five-week conference that ended here Sunday.

The Grace Line, Inc., and the Federal Maritime Board signed a $52,630,980 contract yesterday with the Bethlehem Steel Company, Shipbuilding Division, for the construction of three ship.

In ten years computers and related electronic data processing equipment should be in universal commercial use -- even by the corner grocery store. This prediction came yesterday from Frank H. Muns, director of data processing and procedures for Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

CAIRO, Feb. 26 -- Official sources dismissed today charges by Israel that President Gamal Abdel Nasser had shown "hostility" in recent speeches in Syria, the northern region of the United Arab Republic.

"An Outline of Man's Knowledge of the Modern World," edited by the late Lyman Bryson, will be published March 8 by McGraw-Hill. It is an interweaving of the thoughts of thirty-three scholars and critics to provide an understanding of modern thinking and research.

Electronics, steels and nonferrous metals moved ahead but motors and oils held back in a generally strong session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Aggregate market values rose about $1,250,000,000.

The Parents League of New York is planning its second annual Concert for children, to be held on the afternoon of April 16 in Carnegie Hall. Leopold Stokowski, who will conduct the Symphony of the Air, will donate his personal services.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Senate hearings on drug industry practices were suspended indefinitely today with a statement by Senator Estes Kefauver that slanted advertising claims created an intolerable situation.

MIAMI, Feb. 26 -- Another sad chapter in the odyssey of the migratory farm laborer is nearing an end in south Florida, with a much smaller toll in human misery than had been feared.

The National Broadcasting Company confirmed yesterday that a Congressional subcommittee had requested a kinescope recording of Jack Paar's Jan. 12 show.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- In a fast round of cat-and-mouse on the Senate floor, Senator Lyndon B. Johnson won majority support today for his effort to force a civil rights vote with round-the-clock sessions next week.

Offerings of municipalities will supply most of next week's activity in the new capital market. Of more than $235,000,000 in stocks and fixed-interest securities, municipal offerings will account for some $160,000,000.

More mortgage credit will become available if the interest ceiling on long-term Government bonds is removed than if it is continued, Julian B. Baird, Under Secretary of the Treasury, said here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Some findings of the National Juvenile Deliquency Study requested by Congress were presented here today jointly by the United States Children's Bureau and the National Institute of Mental Health.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The head of the United States nuclear rocket program predicted today that atomic power could be used to place a manned expedition on the moon within ten years.
A Queens father, joined by his three sons, battled early yesterday morning to subdue a young former boxer who had broken into his St. Alban's home and had terrified his 13-year-old daughter.

Warner Le Roy, Off Broadway's multiple threat man (he's operator of the York Playhouse and producer-director-adapter of "Between Two Thieves"), has acquired a new script called "Small Packages," by Ben Starr.

Florida Power Corporation has reported gains in residential, commercial and industrial sales of electricity during 1959. The annual report noted that each of the 230,289 residential customers used an average of 4,137 kilowatt hours during the year, the first time usage had topped 4,000 k.w.h. for each customer by 771.

Leaders of four major Protestant denominations demanded here yesterday that Representative Francis E. Walter "retract his untrue statement" charging Communist infiltration of the churches and "apologize to the 60,000,000 members of Protestant churches in America."
BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- Willem M.L. Van Rie, a ship's radio operator, completed his third day on the stand today in the Suffolk Superior Court with a second firm denial that he had murdered Lynn Kauffman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., of New York received this week the largest patent ever granted. It covers elaborate improvements to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's automatic accounting system for customers' charges on long distance direct dialing.
LONDON, March 26 -- Princess Margaret, only sister of Queen Elizabeth II, is to marry Antony Armstrong-Jones, a professional photographer.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 26 -- The all-important hockey game between the United States and the Soviet Union will provide the highlight of the next-to-last program of the VIII Olympic Winter Games tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The State Department in effect denied tonight reports from Bonn that Secretary of State Christian A. Herter had approved last December West German plans for establishing supply depots and air training bases in Spain.

Plymouth Rubber At the annual meeting yesterday in Boston, stockholders of the Plymouth Rubber Company, Inc., were told by Joseph M. Hamilburg, president, that the company's business so far in the fiscal year that began Dec. 1 lacked "the push" it had a year ago.

SHANNON, Ireland, Feb. 26 (Reuters) -- Physicians struggled tonight to save the lives of critically injured passengers dragged from the wreckage of an Italian airliner that plunged flaming into a cemetery here early today with fifty-two persons aboard.
A police sergeant who was questioned on whether he was a collector of police pay-offs from gamblers retired from the force yesterday. His identity was not disclosed.

An Atlantic-bound storm pounded New England yesterday with heavy snows, winds and high tides. In its 1,500-mile wake, Midwesterners struggled with snow drifts up to ten feet high and Southerners shivered in a cold wave that destroyed crops.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller was asked today to support Federal legislation to confirm the right of local law enforcement officers in the state to conduct wiretapping operations under specific court orders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Feb. 13 entitled "The Fairness of State Aid" contains cogent and convincing reasons for the necessity of solving the fiscal problems of New York City, particularly as they relate to education.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 26 -- Record-breaking runs in the downhill race and the dramatic mountain rescue of an injured skier highlighted the Middlebury College winter carnival today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The House Appropriations Committee conceded today, in effect, that it was licked.

JUSTICE WILLIAM O. DOUGLAS of the United States Supreme Court is troubled by a calculation that in about forty years there won't be much room left on earth for mountains, forests and wildlife unless the conservation of those things picks up briskly.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- The stock market was considerably more settled today than yesterday and despite the small turnover both industrials and Government securities staged a rally.

Miss Anne C. Mott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Livingstone Mott of New York and Litchfield, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to John T. Booth. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Booth of 1172 Park Avenue.

Jim McGregor of Portland, Ore., a former coach of national basketball teams of several countries, filed a $750,000 libel suit in the United States District Court yesterday against the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, its secretary-treasurer, James F. Simms, and the honorary secretary, Daniel J. Ferris.

AS one of the distinguished composers of our time, Paul Hindemith might have chosen only his own music in his first appearance as guest conductor with the New York Philharmonic. But the measure of his stature as an artist was that he elected to make Bruckner's Seventh Symphony the big work of his program at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 26 -- Premier Khrushchev before Indonesia's Parliament endorsed fully today President Sukarno's declaration that the forth-coming summit conference would not be representative if it excluded the voice of neutralist Africa and Asia.
EASY does it. No one telis a joke or turns a cartwheel in "A Thurber Carnival," which opened at the ANTA Theatre last evening.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 26 -- In the daylight the scene of the Winter Olympics is all color, activity and excitement.
The First Army announced yesterday that it would proceed with the court-martial of a Queens man who contends he was in an Army hospital at the time the Army charges he had deserted.

Madison Square Garden's final invitation meet of the exciting pre-Olympic indoor track campaign will bring many of the season's winners and assorted interesting newcomers to the mark tonight.
Four hundred scientists spent yesterday afternoon here discussing the workings of an intricate assembly line on which the basic element of life is turned out.

Behind the recent unsuccessful attempt by the Federal Reserve System to transfer its retail reporting activities to the Bureau of the Census a controversy has beeen seething. The key questions have been -- and still are -- how should the nation's $220,000,000,000-a-year retail trade be measured, and who should do the measuring.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Old crop months of all grains weakened today as dealers began a move toward evening commitments on the Board of Trade in advance of the first day of notices of intention to deliver on March contracts.

The pre-Lenten gaiety of society in old Russia was recaptured last night at the annual Mi-Careme Ball at the Sheraton-East.

Conference on "Education and the American Cause" under the auspices of AWARE Inc. in cooperation with the American Education Association and the Intercollegiate Society of Individualists, Wellington Hotel, 10 A.M. Afternoon session, 2 P.M.
Commodity price movements were generally irregular yesterday on New York exchange. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume. Trading was dull.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Winter weather curtailed rail freight loadings last week.
RIVERHEAD, L.I, Feb. 26 -- Suffolk County plans war against the Golden Nematode, a microbe menacing its $25,000,000-a-year potato industry.
Andrew Jackson, displaying depth and versatility, won the fifty-sixth annual Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field championships last night at the 102d Engineers Armory.

State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday charged Governor Rockefeller with resorting to "name-calling" instead of explaining why "a select group of taxpayers" should be favored in income tax legislation.

MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 26 -- Jewish leaders declared today that "Israel has become a strong force for the democratic way of life in Asia and Africa." They said this was because of the technical and scientific assistance Israel was giving to under-developed countries on these continents.

NO men have surer authority for criticizing their wives' cooking than chefs in leading hotels and restaurants. Those professionals can tell from a mere sip if a sauce is over-salted by even a few grains. One "eye" of fat left floating in the gravy of veal kidneys en casserole can send temperamental culinarians into a towering rage.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer had a 7-under-par 65 today to surge into the lead at thirty six holes in the $20,000 Texas open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) -- Representative Walter responded to the telegram by offering the church officials of a chance to testify before his group.
As might be expected, two films now before the local cameras. "Butterfield 8" and "Murder, Inc.," are racing to beat the March 7 strike deadline set by the Screen Actors Guild.

"OURSELVES TO KNOW"* is John O'Hara's most unusual novel. It has a Dostoevskian plot of passion, crime and punishment. It is told with the maddening circumlocution of the great nineteenth-century novelists. And it holds the traditional artist's mirror up to life at an angle meant to reveal the narrator to the reader as searchingly as anyone else in the cast.

Each Friday and Saturday night some gypsies and derelicts and a few pickpockets are among those who converge on 133 Allen Street for their weekly visit to Manhattan's last public bathhouse. To them, and to the thousands of other poor people who patronize it, the public bath is a kind of tiled Taj Mahal.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- A committee told the Government to day that nuclear-powered merchant ships could be built and operated within acceptable standards of safety.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Republican National Committee said today that Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri had failed as Secretary of the Air Force, yet posed as a defense expert in criticizing defense policies of the Eisenhower Administration.
The formation of an organization of lawyers in New York State that all lawyers would be required to join was urged yesterday by Chief Judge Charles S. Desmond of the Court of Appeals.

VIROQUA, Wis., Feb. 27 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's campaign caravan wound through the snow-covered countryside of western Wisconsin today but without its star performer. The Minnesota Senator, suffering from a cold and a fever, was in bed in a Minneapolis hotel.

MADRID, Feb. 27 -- Spain insisted three months ago that West Germany advise and gain the consent of the United States, Britain and France before sending a mission here to negotiate for military facilities in Spain, it has been learned on unimpeachable authority.

MIAMI BEACH. NOT since Hurricane Hazel disrupted the mink-and-bikini nirvana of this Florida resort has the Hotel Fontainebleau rocked to such indignities and irreverence. The Lucullan calm and cathedral-like air of this inn (approximate cost a mere $34,000,000) have been blasted by Hollywood's unpredictable Jerry Lewis, here, with the full cooperation of the management, to film his comedy, "The Bellboy."
Fifty debutantes from many sections of the United States will be presented at the First American Debutante Ball, to be held on July 1 at the Grand Hotel in Rome.
TRAVELlNG to Europe with children is wonderful if you realize right from the beginning that you are not taking them along for their sake but for yours.
Washington is taking an interest in the maintenance of New York City as a world financial center.
SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer maintained tight hold on first place in a $20,000 Texas open today with a 5-under-par 67 that lifted his total for fifty-four holes to 201.
Mayor Wagner hit back yesterday at critics of his plan for "meaningful" revision of the City Charter.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- The countries at the far end of the Mediterranean Sea offer the tourist an easy excursion away from the more traveled routes, with full comfort at moderate prices. In Lebanon, Syria and Jordan travel is different -- but not so different that it becomes difficult or disagreeable.

MOST of the popular books about Mark Twain are biographies, or psychological studies of his devastating personality. This one deals rather with Mark Twain's writing and traces hs indebtedness to the lusty humorists of the antebellum South.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 27 -- The surprising United States hockey team upset the Soviet Union, 3 -- 2, today before a deliriously happy standing-room crowd of 9,000 at the VIII Olympic Winter Games.
Patrons have been announced for the twenty-fourth annual bridge party and luncheon of the Catholic Big Sisters. The fete will take place Tuesday in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

AN anonymous writer in the august London Times Literary Supplement is unhappy about the British edition of a recent American translation from the French of "Portrait of a Man Unknown" by Nathalie Sarraute.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Capt. John McBride lifted his Princeton season scoring record to 51 points today as he led the Tigers' hockey team to a 6-1 victory over Cornell in an Ivy League game at Baker Rink.

The gulls had a bad day. Her was a morning when they coul have rested atop their favorit buoys in New York harbor, savoring the snacks churned up in the wake of three luxury line arrivals. But a 450-ton Coast Guard cutter, the Hickory, came bearing down the channel routing them to flight.
Mr. President, it is a high honor to have you as my guest for these few hours this evening.

One of the more prolific architects of development houses in the East, Herman H. York, recently completed a task that was especially close to his heart. He designed a house for himself and his family.

FRANCIS POULENC is a composer full of paradoxes. Best known as the witty and iconoclastic member of "Les Six" who revels in banal music-hall tunes, he has none the less written one of the most successful operas of recent years, "Les Dialogues des Carmelites," on a thoroughly spiritual subject.

LITTLE ROCK, Feb. 27 -- Some time in the next three weeks Governor Orval B. Faubus can be expected to make an announcement with significance that reaches far beyond the borders of Arkansas. He has promised to reveal by March 15 his plans for the 1960 political season.

MIAMI, Feb. 27 -- Bally Ache of the Edgehill Farm showed today that he could run a distance. The 3-year-old son of Ballydam raced to victory in the $143,200 Flamingo at Hialeah at a mile and an eighth.
BOWIE, Md., Feb. 27 -- Mystic II won the $20,000-added Southern Maryland Handicap at Bowie Race Track today, defeating the heavily favored Yes You Will by three-quarters of a length.
A novel application of nuclear power to ship propulsion -- the maritime gas-cooled reactor -- is described by an expert as able to power a large tanker on a economically competitive basis.

YOU can attend only a certain number of exhibitions by living painters without wondering how they support themselves, who buys what pictures, and why. Business is brisker than it has ever been in the galleries, but there is no very good way to know exactly how much painting is sold at what average price to what kind of person.

TO THE BOATING EDITOR: Is there a water route From New York to Lake Placid? I have a 16 1/2-foot Lyman with a 48 h.p. Evinrude outboard newly purchased. Would it be practical for a family of three, plus dog and baggage, to make a trip from the city to Lake Placid in this boat?

SHANNON, Ireland, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A Shannon airport official told an inquest jury tonight that he had desperately tried to avert the crash of the Italian airliner that plunged into a cemetery yesterday.

From more than a dozen leading Institutions devoted to the study of mental and nervous diseases there are encouraging reports on the prelimnary trials of a new synthetic psychotherapeutic drug. The experts say it may be "one of the major developments in the field to date."

TWO American museums announced major acquisitions this week, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts with an Egyptian sculpture of the Ptelemaic period and the National Gallery in Washington with a large historical painting by the American Benjamin West.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 27 -- Westchester County Democratic and Republican leaders have nearly completed their slates for the June 7 primary.

THE earliest flowers to herald spring are the winter aconites, snowdrops and crocus. In most areas, the aconites have a little edge on snowdrops, and are nearly always ahead of crocus by at least ten days.

BONN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- The Germans learned again this week just how strong a current of distrust and fear of them still runs through Western Europe; and, as it does each time, the lesson came as a shock.

TO THE EDITOR: "TOPICS OF THE TIMES" alluded to my recently published "Meade of Gettysburg" as a book on a Civil War personage ignored till now. It is quite as important to realize that the vast store of Meade Papers in the Historical Society of Pennsylvania Library has also been ignored.

GENEVA -- Paris is about the only European city you can be in exile from without ever having been in residence in. All you need to be an Amateur-Exile-from-Paris is to have visited the city once, and to have fallen in love with a street or a park or the smell of tobacco or a string of lights shining up from the river.
NAHA, Okinawa, Feb. 16 -- United States authorities here are encouraging increased Japanese participation in the development of the Ryukyu Islands.

VALETTA, Malta -- This island with a 5,000-year-old history will turn back the calendar to 60 A.D. this summer, when it celebrates the shipwreck here of the Apostle Paul. A heavy influx of American Catholics and other tourists is expected for the observance, which will start on July 10 and continue for a year.

The editor-in-chief of the Jesuit weekly America said yesterday the United States had entered a "post-Protestant era" in which the image of the President was no longer that of an Anglo-Saxon with a Masonic background.

LIKE the well-trained newspaper man that he is, John Scott, special assistant to the publisher of Time magazine, with which he has been associated since 1841, brings out this pithy, compact book at the very moment when the United States and its Western European allies are reviewing their policies of aid to the underdeveloped countries.
An accidental discovery that may improve techniques for producing vaccines to fight virus epidemics has been reported by scientists from Cornell University and the Rockefeller Institute.

Albert Lecron has been elected as a director of the American-Saint Gobain Corporation. Once with the Saint Gobain organization, he is president of the French concern, SOVIREL, makers of electron tubes and optical glass.

HOW easy, as the years wheel by, to forget the debonair figure of Anthony Eden so strikingly imprinted on the first half of this century: the brave soldier of World War I; the scholar of oriental languages; the charming, courteous companion contributing: his own style in headgear to the haberdashery of an age; the astute politician, learning at Stanley Baldwin's feet; the astonishingly young Foreign Secretary, abandoning office rather than truck with dictators.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27 -- Two Yale swimmers broke pool records today as the undefeated Eli swimming team rolled to its eleventh victory of the season, beating Princeton, 74 -- 21, in Dillon pool.

A tentative schedule of thirty-six regattas counting toward Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound class championships has been prepared for the clubs west of Rye. It is not in final form, but the season will run between May 21 and Sept. 11.

PROBABLY no literary incident in the history of American letters is better known than Walt Whitman's printing the first edition of his "Leaves of Grass" in 1855 at his own expense and sending a copy to Emerson, who impulsively hailed it as "the most extraordinary piece of wit wisdom that America has yet contributed."

BONN, Germany, Feb. 27 -- Chancellor Adenauer declared today that West Germany always had carried out and would continue to carry out its military build-up in agreement with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

In an exceptionally full week of exhibitions there are forty-seven one-man shows opening and a large number of group shows, among them the American Abstract Artists Association's annual exhibition opening today at the Riverside Museum.
GUATEMALA, Feb. 27 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes declared today that dictatorships were obsolete forms of government and a dictator was living politically beyond his time.

Mrs. Edward M.M. Warburg listens to Spanish records on her "Victrola" each morning as she dresses. Though her Spanish is "fluent and correct," she feels that this keeps her ear attuned. Languages play an important role in Mrs. Warburg's life, since most of her volunteer hours are devoted to the Institute of International Education (I.I.E.)
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Western experts here have nearly reached agreement on the disarmament proposal to be laid before the Soviet Union at Geneva.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- Yankee training will start in earnest Wednesday when the infielders and outfielders hold their first workout here. Up to now only the battery men have been taking their preliminary exercises.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 27 -- Linmold, a lightly regarded California 4-year-old, won the $145,000 Santa Anita Handicap in a stunning upset today. Closing with a rush, he beat eleven rivals.

The programs for the blind and visually handicapped of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind will be furthered as a result of the ninth annual members' luncheon and fashion show, sponsored by the organization's Women's Division.

TOKYO -- Ever anxious to please, the solicitous Japanese this year are pulling aside some of the so-called "chrysanthemum curtain" that is said to stand between the foreign visitor and a real understanding of this country, its people and how they live.

BOSTON, Feb. 27 -- While the political spotlight in New England has been concentrating on New Hampshire -- with its Presidential primary March 8 -- developments in Maine this week drew some attention.

ADKLAND, New Zealand -- This country has been labeled a wonder world in miniature. It is one of the most highly concentrated packages of scenery and outdoor sport to be found anywhere. Now that jets are opening up the South Pacific, New Zealand is little more than one' day's flight from the United States.

The vagaries of the weather bore down on retailers just before the Washington's Birthday week-end and sales in the nation's department stores fell by 2 per cent. This was the first decline from comparable year-earlier figures for any week since the beginning of October, 1959.
TROY, N.Y., Feb. 27 -- St. Lawrence defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 6 -- 3, tonight before 6,000 fans and won its second straight Tri-State League hockey title.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) -- The Air Force has sent its commands a warning to treat sightings of unidentified flying objects as "serious business" directly related to the nation's defense, it was learned today.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- Until the last year or so, Australia was too pre-occupied with her rapid post-war expansion, and insuring her prosperity boom, to bother very much about tourism. THE early-flowering shrubs proclaim spring's arrival on the winter landscape Species that flower as early as March and April are unpredictable as to the dates that they will set flowers each spring.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- Scandal-burdened Chicago got a new police superintendent this week, a man with extensive theoretical and practical experience. But whether he will be able to use it effectively depends upon factors beyond his control.

HOLLYWOOD. IN an atmosphere of dramatic contrast so beloved by Hollywood, labor strife took an ominous turn last week against the gala background of Oscar nominations. For, on Tuesday, the day after the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences revealed the nominees for the Oscar competition, the Screen Actors Guild called a strike for March 7.

MINEOLA, L.I, Feb. 27 -- School referendums involving $11,495,500 will be voted on in six Nassau County communities next month.

LONDON -- In 1959 the inhabitants of the British Isles enjoyed a summer of continuous sunshine -- the best summer, it seemed, since the Battle-of-Britain summer of 1940. It gave a welcome shot in the arm to the hotel business, and many hoteliers believe that a high proportion of Britishers who had the habit of going abroad may be persuaded this year to holiday at home.

MADRID -- Spain, almost the last outpost of genteel feudalism left in the Western world, has a marked attraction for Americans these years. There are two basic reasons: the sun shines and prices are low.

A 45-year-old jeweler wielding a metal rod yesterday fought off two hold-up men in his store on upper Broadway, but was shot. The alleged robbers and their lookout were captured after a brief chase and an exchange of shots.

COLOMBO, Ceylon -- The unsettled political situation in this country should cause little concern to the tourist. Life continues to run as smoothly and unobtrusively as ever, and the last three months, in particular, have been particularly peaceful.

George Lester, the character whose philosophy is summed up in the pregnant title, is the affably corrupt boniface of an exurban wayside inn specializing in French cookery for the expense-account trade.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The announcement in The New York Times that the U.S.S.R. plans to open a university for students from under-developed countries constitutes a real threat to the free world: that this university will be practically free to its incoming students greatly increases this threat.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 27 -- Dr. Willard Uphaus, a self-styled Christian pacifist, will be given a new day in court here Tuesday. This will consist of arguing briefs before the State Supreme Court on an appeal to have him freed from jail.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- The Secretary of Defense is organizing what is in effect a "truth squad" to cope with attacks on the country's defense program.

WHITEFISH, Mont. -- Winter carnivals in snow-covered sections of the country are becoming almost as common as sunshine festivals in the South. It comes as little surprise, therefore, that this town in northwestern Montana is making elaborate plans for its first winter carnival, which, it hopes, will become an annual event.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 -- James A. Hart, hotel executive who created two internationally famous Chicago dining rooms, the Pump Room in the Ambassador East Hotel and the Buttery in the Ambassador West Hotel, died today in Wesley Memorial Hospital.

ST. AUGUSTINE once remarked that he knew what time was until someone asked him. We are entering an election year and it is unlikely that our minds will be much troubled by St. Augustine's metaphysical worries about time. But we shall have troubles of our own, for it is certain that we are going to have to live with another word whose meaning everyone knows until he is asked.

PARIS -- It is safe to predict that the most lasting impression this year's tourist to France will take home with him will be of France's new currency. REHEARSALS started a week ago for the American Ballet Theatre's three-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House, from April 19 through May 7; director Lucia Chase has done a skillful job of pulling together a company and a repertory after more than a year of inactivity, and Mayor Wagner has proclaimed the engagement as "The American Ballet Theatre's Twentieth Anniversary Celebration."

BOYNTON BEACH, Fla. -- According to the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey, the Gulf Stream comes closer to shore at Boynton Beach than at any other point along Florida's east coast. MR. ADAMS invested $20,000 in corporate and government bonds -- his anchor to windward, he calls them. He receives about $1,000 a year in interest. His objective for this part of his port-folio is safety with as much income as he can reasonably expect.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. THEY stand poised against the sky, solid on the world's spinning surface, massive in their tenstory strength, yet strangely tentative. The great Titans in their gantries here at Cape Canaveral, and beyond them, stretching across the earth's curve, the line of Atlases, also perched and waiting on their pads, are awesome symbols of man's impatience to leave this planet.

THE forty-day racing season in Florida's Hialeah Park ends on Wednesday, and once again the bird-lovers will take over the track from the horse-followers. The birds that sight-seers come to admire -- and more than 500,000 came during the non-racing season last year -- are flamingoes.

The massive inertia in legislative circles at Albany that has greeted Governor Rockefeller's appeal for compulsory construction of radioactive fall-out shelters should not be permitted to stand as the last word. This is certainly a case of none so deaf as those that will not hear, none so blind as those that will not see.

Lenten regulations were read at masses yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral and in all other churches of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. The six-week period of prayer and penance begins on Ash Wednesday of this week.

"Monopoly power" has become one of the chief arguments of those who would put far more drastic curbs on labor unions than did the Landrum-Griffin measure. The varsity set will take over Madison Square Garden Saturday for New York's fifth and last major indoor track meet of the season.
