NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 29 -- Admiral Jerauld Wright retired today.
HONG KONG, Feb. 29 -- The National People's Congress, Communist China's legislature, will meet in Peiping near the end of March.

IN the matter of dictators this country has always had the good sense to be far behind Europe and other parts of the world. During the last thirty years, for example, we produced nothing to match Italy's Mussolini, Germany's Hitler, the Russian-roulette players of the Kremlin or even so wilted a specimen as England's man-who-would-be-something, Sir Oswald Mosley.

A strike of operating engineers who maintain pasteurizing and packaging machinery was voted last night against twenty-six milk-processing plants. Union members authorized the walkout for midnight tonight.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Supreme Court cleared the way today for full-scale enforcement of the Civil Rights Act of 1957.

PARK FALLS, Wis., Feb. 29 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, sounding a little angry at times, repeatedly emphasized today that he wanted to fight the Wisconsin primary battle on the basis of issues rather than personality appeal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Senator John F. Kennedy accused the Administration today of "gambling with our national survival." He called for increased defense spending, financed if necessary by higher taxes.

New York State's largest electric utilities announced yesterday plans for a 220-mile high voltage power line network. When completed, the network will enable them to exchange about four times as much electricity as is now possible.

Robert Moses made it clear yesterday that he would accept the presidency of the 1964 World's Fair in New York. He is expected to be appointed formally by the fair's board of directors at a meeting later this week.
State, local and Federal officials urged more day-care services for children yesterday as Day Care Week opened in the city with a luncheon at the Astor Hotel.
Universal-Cyclops Steel Corporation said yesterday in a report that favorable fourth-quarter results contributed substantially to its record sales and earnings last year.

A good demand appeared in afternoon trading yesterday for United States Government securities of all classifications. However high-grade corporate and local government obligations continued their downward drift.
ROME, Feb. 29 -- The President of the Senate, Cesare Merzagora, resigned this afternoon, complaining that a recent speech of his had been misunderstood and wrongly criticized.

TODAY is pancake day in England. The Englishman who does not manage to consume at least a few pancakes on Shrove Tuesday feels cheated indeed. They are an item on virtually every restaurant menu, and at home many a housewife will be busily practicing her pancake turning.
Offerings to the public of new securities declined in February from those of the preceding month and a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Democrats and Republicans on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee clashed today on the Administration's economic policy. But their views on policy essentials and the out look for the year ahead were not far apart.

The Department of Defense is opposed to the transfer of United States-controlled tankers from "flags of convenience" registries to those of the nation's allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 29 -- Why can't the United States win more gold medals in international winter sports competition? That was a dominant question today as the VIII Olympic Winter Games stepped into their niche in sports history.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Feb. 29 -- An hour or more before launching time, the Thor blockhouse got so crowded people had to start turning sideways to get past one another.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The United States agreed today to negotiate its differences with Cuba, but not under conditions laid down by Premier Fidel Castro.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The New York City Opera Company's visit here with three contemporary American works has had what can only be called a lukewarm reception.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Treasury bill rates rose further today in its rebound from early February lows, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 29 -- Changes in Westchester's planning procedures to compel more neighborly expansion within the county were proposed today.
The Bethlehem Steel Company may not have to produce thirteen years of records from its shipbuilding division in a labor dispute now before the National Labor Relations Board.

Trading opened yesterday on an R coffee contract on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The R futures contract covers grades of coffee produced in Africa and supplements the B market which permits delivery of Brazilian grades and the M contract which deals in mild grades from Colombia, Mexico and Central America.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Ninety-day tests, like those the Government ran on lipstick colors, are not sufficient to determine if a substance is cancer-producing, a scientist testified today.

FLORENCE, S.C., Feb. 29 (AP) -- Melvin Purvis, who was special agent in charge of the Chicago office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation when John Dillinger was trapped and slain, committed suicide today.

"A Clash of Destinies," an account of the long struggle to establish a Jewish state in Palestine, has been written by Jon and David Kimche. Jon Kimche, who observed the Arab-Jewish conflict as a newspaper correspondent, is editor of The Jewish Observer and Middle East Review.
LONDON, Feb. 29 -- With demand small and selective, industrial share prices drifted lower in the stock market here today. However, there was no selling pressure and most losses were in pennies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of a United States note delivered today to Dr. Raul Roa, Cuban Minister of State, by Daniel Braddock, United States charge d'affaires in Havana, as made public by the State Department:

HAVANA, Feb. 21 -- Twenty years ago a young American climbed one of the foothills of the Organos Mountains in Pinar del Rio province to the west of Havana and looked down at the jungle in the valley below him.
A Coast Guard civilian hearing examiner yesterday dismissed two of three specifications in charges of negligence brought last year against Walt Welles, second mate of the liner Santa Rosa.
A top-caliber field of 3-year-olds will be drawn from the 143 nominations received up to yesterday for the June 11 running of the $125,000 Belmont Stakes.
Stocks ended the month with little change from the Jan. 31 level in spite of some wide fluctuations. Trading so far this year has been 16 per cent below the 1959 volume.

New York University had too much height and too much Tom Sanders for little City College as the Violets' basketball team scored a 72-54 victory last night at Wingate Gymnasium. With this contest, C.C.N.Y. ended its season, as well as its formal court rivalry with N.Y.U.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 29 (AP) -- A cry of "Thief!" went up today in the almost-deserted Olympic Village. Several athletes complained of the loss of valuable equipment.

Truer words were never spoken than Mayor Wagner's week-end statement about his formula for home-made City Charter reform. "If we don't get real and meaningful Charter revision," said the Mayor, "we'll be laughed out of town."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The round-the-clock sessions on the civil rights bill may turn out to be the biggest North-South encounter since Appomattox and leave feelings as embittered. But the opening skirmish today was more like a battle between admiralty and Philadelphia lawyers. Nobody got bruised.

The Leap Year Assembly, which originated in 1924 as a combination of social reciprocity and gentle chiding, was held for the ninth time last night. The scene was the ballroom of the Plaza. The event was omitted in 1944 because of the war.
BONN, Germany, Feb. 29 -- Western embassies here were caught by surprise tonight by reports from Washington and London that high-altitude flights to West Berlin might soon be resumed.

MIAMI, Feb. 29 -- "When I was young, I do so many theengs foolish," said Manuel Ycaza, now a wise old man of 22. "Crazy keeds do lotsa crazy theengs. Now I have experience on my back and in the back of my head. The past she is over."

Experienced lawyers forecast yesterday that 500 to 600 members of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York might attend tomorrow's special meeting in a dispute over Magistrate Robert P. Mahoney's not being reappointed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 29 -- Even though the spring training season is barely off the mark, with the second squad not due for another forty-eight hours, problems already are beginning to pile up for Casey Stengel.

The State Department's latest note to Cuba will, we believe, be generally approved in this country. The note welcomes the Cuban Government's expressed willingness to negotiate outstanding problems between the two nations, and invites Cuba to submit concrete proposals looking to the opening of such negotiations. The note pledges our Government "to continue by its conduct and through its utterances to reaffirm the spirit of fraternal friendship" between our two peoples.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Before the filibuster of the Southern Democrats in the Senate has come to an end, it may be that the Senate rules which almost impregnably protect unlimited "debate" will have been applied more intensively than ever in their history.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : President Eisenhower's present trip will undoubtedly be a personal success -- and a public relations triumph, however short-lived. Unfortunately, it will not register, or basically contribute to, an integrated United States economic policy toward Latin America.
ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- An influential citizens group that helped push through last year's court reorganization plan is threatening to withdraw its support if certain changes are made this year.
ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- A bill requiring that grand jury presentments be kept secret if they do not accuse anyone of a crime was approved tonight by the Assembly. The vote was 120 to 22.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products increased about eight-tenths of 1 per cent between mid-January and mid-February.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 29 -- Argentina was thrown into official mourning today just as President Eisenhower finished his three-day visit and proceeded to Chile.

They laughed when Pablo Robertson stood up to play. He was 4 feet 9 inches tall, a head shorter than the waterboy, and he looked as if he had trailed a wandering marble onto the basketball court. Pablo was 14 years old and a freshman at DeWitt Clinton.
The Franklin Community High School Building Corporation, Ind., is planning the sale of $2,490,000 of first mortgage revenue bonds on March 15. The issue will come due serialy from 1963 to 1987.
ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- If your teen-age daughter earned a few dollars baby-sitting last year or your son picked up some extra cash caddying, the State Tax Commission wants to know about it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- French objections are the only remaining obstacle to Western agreement on a three-stage general disarmament plan, Western officials said today.

The twenty-fifth annual Spring Dance for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on May 5. Mrs. Theodore S. Gary, chairman, has been holding executive committee meetings at her home at 176 East Ninety-third Street, to formulate plans for the silver anniversary dinner dance.

Federal Insurance Consolidated net of the Federal Insurance Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, Vigilant Insurance Company, was $6,734,000 in 1959, or $2.18 a share, it was reported yesterday. This compared with $5,990,000, or $1.94 a share, in 1958.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 29 -- Incurable outdoorsmen around here are just now trying to make the painful change from hunting to fishing. They are not yet having the best of luck with it.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 29 -- Chileans turned out en masse today to greet President Eisenhower enthusiastically.
LONDON, Feb. 29 -- Britain's Defense Minister warned the Soviet Union today that any surprise attack would not protect it from "massive and terrible retaliation" by the Royal Air Force.

THERE is combined bridge and television news for those who have followed the "Championship Bridge" series Sunday afternoons at 3 o'clock on Channel 7 in New York, and coast-to-coast on other channels at the same or other times.

Jules L. Freed, executive vice president of H.L. Green Company, declined late last night to confirm or deny published reports that his company might sell its holdings of United Stores Corporation to B.T.L. Corporation, formerly known as Butler Brothers.
Seven planes will fly an American production of "My Fair Lady" to the Soviet Union for an eight-week tour beginning April 18.

A WOMAN who survived Auschwitz -- and who once doubted she could ever again lead a normal life -- is determined that her Israeli children should be reared in a normal atmosphere, free of prejudice. She tells them not to condemn Germany as a nation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- An angry, red-faced chairman of the Federal Communications Commission turned on one of his agency's chief Congressional critics today.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, March 1 -- The Senate burned the midnight oil last night as a powerful bipartisan bloc held it in non-stop session designed to break a Southern civil rights filibuster for the first time in history.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- An expert writing for the coming White House Conference on Children and Youth said today that an increasing proportion of the juvenile population appeared to be becoming fat.
Jack McCartan, the goalie who did such a fine job for the United States team in the Olympic Winter Games at Squaw Valley, has the Army to consider before thinking about a professional hockey career.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) -- Relatives found last fall on the once-secret Senate payroll are on the new salary list issued today.
A state commission announced yesterday that it would "take appropriate legal action to enforce its right to examine city files whenever this proves to be necessary."

Proceeds from the premiere performance of the motion picture, "Can Can," at the Rivoli Theatre and a champagne supper ball at the Astor on March 9 will help defray the cost of training, transporting and housing United States athletes competing in the Olympic Games in Rome this summer.
ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller met today with Republican legislators from New York City with a view to developing an affirmative program for the city that would bear the Republican label.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The United States has decided to resume supply flights into West Berlin above the 10,000-foot ceiling the Soviet Union has sought to impose on Western Allied air corridors to that city.
Steel production this week will continue to show a slow but steady decline, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Wilt (the Stilt) Chamberlain, a spectacular record-breaker in the National Basketball Association, was voted two awards yesterday by the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association.
TUNIS, Feb. 29 -- The majority of Tunisian Moslems appeared today to be observing the daylight fast of Ramadan despite official discouragement. Tunisia's population is nine-tenths Moslem.

The price for the services of the nation's best bowlers took a big climb in recent days. The rise was the result of talk of the formation of a professional bowling league patterned after the baseball and football leagues.
Harry W. Bruggemann, the man responsible for letting Columbia students see light, celebrated his fiftieth year on the Columbia staff yesterday.

Premier Khrushchev implies in an ambiguous statement in Jakarta that unless the East-West summit meeting scheduled for May reaches agreement, not only on Berlin but on an all-German settlement, he will conclude a separate "peace treaty" with its East German puppet regime which (in his mind) will invalidate all war and post-war agreements and put West Berlin under that regime's authority as part of its territory.
TIME is of the essence to Horace Westcombe Eiliott, president of one of the oldest clockmaking concerns in the world.

Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., is about to announce its expansion into the foreign market. The agency is the only one among those with the top five billings that does not now have an important foreign operation.
James H. Scheuer, a building contractor, announced yesterday that he would oppose Representative Ludwig Teller in the Democratic primary in Manhattan's Twentieth Congressional District.
THE Republic of France ran second to the Radio Corporation of America last night. The fashion show entitled "Paris a la Mode," presented over Channel 4, was a brilliant display of color television.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- A sharply divided Supreme Court held today that a state or local government may dismiss employes who refuse to answer a Congressional committee's questions about alleged subversive activities.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 29 -- After President Eisenhower had undergone another round of grueling official functions, it was announced today that he was feeling fine and that his personal physician considered him in excellent physical condition.

Directors of the Miami Copper Company approved yesterday a plan for the transfer of the company's operating assets to the Tennessee Corporation. Under the plan, Miami Copper then would be liquidated and its net assets distributed to stockholders.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 29 (UPI) -- Three student participants in sitdown protests Saturday against lunch counter segregation were fined a total of $160 here today. Thousands of Negroes sang hymns and the National Anthem outside the courtroom.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 29 -- The population of Bergen County rose 17,991 last year, according to an estimate made public today by the County Planning Board. The board put the total at 746,035 as of Dec. 31.

Sir Michael Redgrave has changed his mind about appearing here in "The Aspern Papers," the successful adaptation he made from Henry James' novelette. Besides furnishing the dramatization, he is one of the stars in the London production, of which he is a co-sponsor.

Officials in Albany who persist in including teen-agers' wages for part-time work as taxable income may find that they are fostering juvenile delinquency, cutting car production in Detroit, plunging parents into the captivity of their progeny and breeding rebellion against the government.
Lieut. Gen. B.M. Bryan Jr., commanding general of the First Army since 1957, retired from the Army yesterday in ceremonies at his headquarters on Governors Island.

HONG KONG, Feb. 29 -- Chinese Communist newspapers denounced today the decision by the International Olympic Committee to allow participation in the summer Olympics of athletes from Nationalist China's island stronghold of Taiwan.
LONDON, Feb. 29 -- The British Government has sharply rejected a renewed claim by Guatemala to British Honduras.
CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- Details of a $36,000,000 apartment and office project financed by a janitors' union were announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today that six nations were prepared to provide $410,000,000 for the development of the Indus River as part of a water-sharing agreement between India and Pakistan.
Fallowing is the text of the statement issued yesterday by Robert Moses:
"THE PLAY OF THE WEEK," recovering from a tedious slumming expedition, has regained its reputation for presenting stimulating, provocative theatre on television.

Stocks held moderate until just after the noon hour yesterday, then dipped closed with moderate but fairly widespread losses. Electronics and tires were the only major groups that showed more p than minus signs.
CHICAGO, Feb. 29 (AP) -- Trade in grain futures was at a fairly rapid clip here today as prices worked generally higher on the Board of Trade.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 29 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower invoked the Railway Labor Act today to head off a threatened strike of conductors against the New York Central Railroad. The strike was to begin Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- For years a sign has hung on the wall behind the desk of Admiral Robert Lee Dennison. "Bob Dennison, Sailor," it reads -- and that is about as much as anyone can get the admiral to tell of himself.
A title bout double-header was envisioned yesterday by Jack Fugazy, managing director of Feature Sports, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Manufacturing statistics for January released by the Department of Commerce gave some support today to those who doubt that business will be at boom levels in the first half of this year.
ALBANY, March 1 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions compiled today by the State Department of Commerce:
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- A New York chemist who challenged the validity of Government tests of lipstick colors testified today that he had never gone over the basic data.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., March 1 -- Why did residents of this town defeat a $90,000 plan for further school expansion?
United States Government securities continued their upward price surge yesterday in a trading session marked by enlarged activity among obligations of short and intermediate term.

Agadir, the town that was devastated by an earthquake Monday night, first came to prominence during the Morocco crisis of 1911, when the German warship Panther paid it an unsolicited visit. Of no great importance then, it has grown since as Morocco's southernmost port, a favored winter resort and gateway to the fertile Sous region.
ALBANY, March 1 -- A bill extending the law of criminal libel to defamatory statements made on radio and television was passed unanimously by the Assembly today.

Cocoa futures continued to fall to new lows for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Commission house liquidation and new selling touched off stop-loss orders. Scale-down manufacturer buying absorbed the offers.

Newark, N.J., decided yesterday not to go through with a scheduled sale of $15,000,000 of serial bonds secured by the general taxing power because city officials were dissatisfied with the cost of borrowing.
The chief spokesman for the nation's airlines urged yesterday that the Government remove the "antiquated transportation tax" on passengers.

Acquisition of electronic companies and marketing of new electronic products are the objectives of the recent alliance between a small electronics company, a brokerage house partner and a giant private organization.

CARLE PLACE, L.I., March 1 -- A jury of twelve youngsters and teen-aged judges, lawyers, plaintiffs and defendants will act out fifteen civil law cases in a simulated courtroom at the Carle Place High School tomorrow.

Harry G. Silverstein Sons, realty investors, have contracted to buy two office buildings at 7 West Forty-fourth Street and 15-17 West Fortyfourth and an industrial building at 137-39 Varick Street in a package deal.
Frank Kenna, Queens Republican leader, announced yesterday his party's slate in the county for Congress, the Legislature and the judiciary.
HALIFAX, N.S., March 1 (AP) -- The Panamanian freighter Georgios A. was sold for $159,000 at sheriff's auction here today to settle creditors' claims.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Dan Topping, the co-owner and president of the Yankees, revealed today he had asked Mayor Wagner again for help in increasing the parking facilities for Yankee Stadium.

John Levy of the City Athletic Club and Jim Fuchs of the Yale Club, seeded third and eighth, respectively, advanced as firstround competition continued last night in the Class C singles tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Eric Schoeppner of Germany yesterday accepted a $50,000 offer to challenge Archie Moore for the light-heavyweight championship, Jack Fugazy, the managing director of Feature Sports, Inc., revealed. Fugazy said the acceptance was received in a cablegram from Walter Englert, Schoeppner's manager.

A two-year-old dream, envisioning a showcase for new dramatists, will be realized next Wednesday night when a new play by a new playwright, "Answered the Flute" by Sam Robins, will be presented at the Finch Theatre, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street.
ALBANY, March 1 -- A bill to increase annual state housing subsidies by a maximum of $5,000,000 has been submitted to the Legislature by James W. Gaynor, State Housing Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Leather lungs, oak legs, a cast-iron stomach, an expert knowledge of Jefferson's Manual, a panoramic view of United States history, a fund of anecdote and a store of righteous indignation--these are the qualifications for a varsity filibusterer.

Helped by an extra selling day last month, sales of the eight major New York department stores and their metropolitan branches climbed 10 per cent above those of February, 1959. The gain was the best for a month since September, 1958.

Lamar Junior College of Colorado will bring its own rooting section to the national junior college wrestling championships, which will be staged in Farmingdale, L.I., on Friday and Saturday under the sponsorship of the Long Island Aggies.

BALTIMORE, March 1 -- Two of this city's largest financial institutions, the Fidelity-Baltimore National Bank and the Maryland Trust Company, will merge to form a bank with assets of $420,000,000, according to plans made public today by the boards of both institutions.
MOSCOW, March 1 -- Mikhail A. Sholokhov, Soviet novelist, denied today that he had changed the ending of the sequel to his novel "The Virgin Soil Upturned."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 1 -- A thousand Negro students prayed and sang the National Anthem today on the steps of the first capital of the Old Confederacy in a peaceful protest against segregation.
EATONTOWN. N.J., March 1 -- Central New Jersey's newest and largest shopping center opened today at Eatontown Circle and Route 35.
A campaign to eliminate tuberculosis in the United States through treatment with available drugs was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- An Air Force attempt to fire an Atlas missile 9,000 miles into the South Indian Ocean was canceled today. It will not be rescheduled until after President Eisenhower returns Sunday from his South American tour.
Nine minutes and thirteen seconds after the Moroccan town of Agadir was shaken into ruble, an array of twenty-five seismographs, rooted in the rock of the Palisades, began to record the event.
Shortages of physicians, nurses, social workers and a variety of other professional employes continued to threaten the operation of the city's twenty-eight municipal hospitals last year.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- There, are no current plans within the Administration to press for suspension or abolition of the import tax on copper of 1.7 cents a pound, officials said today.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 1 -- A Negro minister called today for a sustained policy of nonviolence and Christian forbearance to end racial discrimination.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 -- Benito Nardone, an immigrant Italian portworker's son, became President of Uruguay's National Council of Government today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 1 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's address today to Americans and Chilean-United States groups in a theatre here, of his speech before a joint session of the Chilean Congress, of his reply to a letter from the Federation of Students of Chile and of the official statement listing topics discussed by Presidents Eisenhower and Jorge Alessandri:

The unlamented, Supreme Court ripper bill proposed some years ago by former Senator Jenner included a provision designed, as Senator Jenner frankly stated, to overrule the court's 1956 decision in the case of Harry Slochower, Brooklyn College professor. Professor Slochower had refused to answer a Congressional committee's questions about alleged subversive activities, relying on the Fifth Amendment's privilege against self-incrimination.

CROSS HILL, S.C., March 1 -- This is another installment in the biography of a young setter bitch named Pat, but the trouble with it is that it depends on the word of a man who was hunting alone, and on the last day of the quail season at that.
The threat of a strike of operating engineers against twenty-six milk processing plants, scheduled for last midnight, was postponed indefinitely by the engineers' union.
The revised plan for the highly controversial $36,000,000 Riverside-Amsterdam urban revewal project was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- The feed grain and soybean futures posted additional small gains here today, but wheat and rye ran into profit-taking and slipped major fractions in spots.

BALTIMORE, March 1 -- In mellow Peabody Hall, where Sidney Lanier once played flute in the Peabody Symphony, a new opera by James Conn called "The Fall of the City" had its first performance tonight under the direction of Laszlo Halasz.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 1 -- Harvey Guerin of Chester, N.J., a retired school teacher who is now a prosperous farmer, is considering running for Morris County Freeholder on a very unpopular platform-in favor of a jetport in the Great Swamp.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 1 -- For the second successive month peace-time transit records were set by the Panama Canal during February. Despite the short month, 956 ocean-going ships were handled, the canal company reported.
BOSTON, March 1 -- The murder case against Willem M.L. van Rie went to the jury at 5:43 P.M. today.

General Lucius Clay, chairman of the Continental Can Company, has been designated as chairman of the American Advisory Committee for the forthcoming British Exhibit at the New York Coliseum, June 10 to 26.

NEWARK, N.J., March 1 -- Increases last year in life insurance in force, earnings on investments, assets and sales of sickness and accident policies were reported here today by the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., March 1 -- A speeding Santa Fe passenger train collided in a fiery explosion this afternoon with an oil tank truck. A spokesman for the railroad said that seventeen persons had been killed and fifty-five injured.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A thin gray line is once again deployed against superior forces to resist what the Old South regards as an unwarranted assault on its way of life. The field general again is a man whose dignity, integrity and high principle are recognized even by his opponents.
DORADO BEACH, Puerto Rico, March 1 -- The United States asserted tonight that its private investors were creating wealth for Latin America by pouring in capital at the rate of $600,000,000 a year.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 1 -- The commandant of the prison where many political prisoners are held has been arrested, according to a report.
SAN GREGORIO, Chile, March 1 -- President Eisenhower came briefly into contact today with Latin America's dramatic struggle to house its violently expanding populations.
Presiding Justice John M. Murtagh, who began a "get tough" policy with gamblers in Special Sessions on Monday yesterday turned his attention to lawyers and bondsmen linked with gambling racketeers.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A Times-tested recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Domestic automobile production last month, slipped 4.3 per cent below the January level. However, output was still 37.8 per cent above that of February of 1959.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens said yesterday that state legislation offered no hope of curbing airplane noise at Queens' two commercial airports -- La Guardia and New York International.
An apartment-house landlord haled into court and fined as a result of a recent "crash inspection" protested yesterday that the city officials were making "landlord" a dirty word.

PARIS. If all goes well we may soon be told that France's fighter force is being placed directly under the orders of General Norstad, NATO's able Supreme Commander. This would help coordinate Europe's air defenses, but remains a far cry from the integration of these defenses Norstad wants.
YESTERDAY (March 1, 1960) THE PRESIDENT In Chile.

Although insurance-company advertisements often show retired couples with new homes sitting out their final years on porch furniture, Julian S. Myrick, a life-insurance salesman who turned 80 yesterday, resists retirement.

CLARION CONCERTS completed its third season last night at Town Hall. That it was able to give its final program with the numbers that were planned originally was thanks to the skill and nerve of a 27-year-old soprano from Charlotte, N.C.
MIAMI, March 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's Liberal Lady, leading all the way, defeated the heavily favored Jimmer by half a length today in the featured sixth race at Hialeah.

KABUL, Afghanistan, March 1 -- Preparations were being completed here today for Premier Khrushchev's arrival tomorrow. A round of sightseeing and ceremony has been planned for the Soviet leader before he leaves for Moscow Saturday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 1 -- Premier Khrushchev told President Sukarno that Communist China's industrial achievements were being made "at too great a cost," authoritative Indonesian sources said today.
ALBANY, March 1 -- The Senate approved and sent to the Assembly today a budget that neither the Republicans nor the Democrats were too happy about.

LONDON, March 1 -- Blisters, trickery and the weather have eliminated hundreds of contestants in a walking race the length of Britain. But the doughty 56-year-old woman who started it all is looking for longer roads to conquer.

Filibustering, to paraphrase another Johnson, is the last refuge of a Senator unwilling to accept majority rule. It springs from the same philosophy as that which denies the vote to Negroes in the first place: a rejection of democratic political procedure.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 1 -- President Eisenhower acknowledged today that the United States had made mistakes in Latin America and might make more.

THE New York Stock Exchange may be visited Mondays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., except holidays. Tours begin every fifteen minutes and include an explanation of trading on the floor; demonstrations of how the stock ticker operates, and an animated show depicting the placing and execution of orders from all over the country.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today new labeling standards to make clear to consumers how types of orange juice have been processed.
LONDON, March 1 -- A Government defensepolicy endorsing West Germany as a "firm and equal partner" in the Atlantic alliance won a smashing victory tonight in the House of Commons.
It was cold yesterday. It was windy. It was March 1.
The Grace Line may withdraw from its Great Lakes cargo operations, service established only last year between Lakes ports and the Caribbean. The results were highly unsatisfactory.
RABAT, Morocco, March 1 -- In one of the gravest catastrophies in Moroccan history, nothing is known of the fate of the seven American families reported to be living there.

THE HUMBLER CREATION,"* by Pamela Hansford Johnson, is a very good novel, the best I have read in more than four months. Miss Johnson, Lady Snow in private life, is the wife of the distinguished novelist C.P. Snow (Sir Charles). She is a true novelist, a writer whose principal interest is in the drama of human life, the situations in which ordinary well-intentioned people find themselves because they are human.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation announced yesterday that its sales and earnings rose to record highs last year, with profits 40 per cent above the 1958 level on a sales gain of 25 per cent. Owen R. Cheatham, chairman of the diversified forest products company, said earnings in 1960 were expected to be 25 to 30 per cent higher than last year.
The possibility that the 1964 World's Fair in New York would be extended into 1965 was emphasized yesterday by Thomas J. Deegan Jr., the present chairman and president of the corporation.

THERE is a new book out by Terence Reese, the British master whom many -- including some Americans -- rate the best bridge player in the world and who is surely the most prolific writer among the world's great players.

Ten years ago the 13-year-old Michael Rabin made his New York debut, playing a concerto with the National Orchestral Association in Carnegie Hall. Last night he appeared there again, with the same orchestra, in the Beethoven Violin Concerto.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The House voted today to use $100,000,000 from the sale of property seized from German and Japanese nationals during World War II to compensate Americans for wartime property losses from enemy action overseas.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has leased a floor in Grand Central City, the skyscraper planned by Erwin S. Wolfson on the site of the old Grand Central Office Building, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, March 2 -- The Senate wag still locked in a stand-off contest of will and stamina today as the non-stop session to force a civil rights vote continued toward its third day.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- Events in the Yankee holdout situation moved with considerable speed today, but not fast enough to suit Casey Stengel.
CALCUTTA, India, March 1 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Premier Khrushchev had a forty-five-minute talk at Government House here tonight.

A semi-tropical setting patterned after the market place and streets of Port-of-Spain provided the atmosphere last night for the Trinidad Carnival Ball. It was held in the ballroom and Trianon Room of the Sheraton-East for the benefit of the Cancer Foundation of the Variety Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The United States foreign-aid director predicted today that Communist China's growing economic strength might set off "an important power shift" in Asia and the Far East in about ten years.
MADISON, Wis., March 1 -- There is something sad, and paradoxical, and even a little absurd about the Wisconsin Presidential primary election.

BERLIN, March 1 -- A Soviet spokesman said today that the Western Allies must negotiate with East Germany and the Soviet Union if they wanted to fly above the Soviet-imposed 10,000-foot ceiling in the air corridors linking West Berlin with the West.
Lent begins today, with Ash Wednesday services here opening a season of voluntary abstinence and of reflection in many Christian communions.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 1 -- Maj. Venn Fey, who was awarded the Military Cross for bravery against the Mau Mau during Kenya's terrorist emergency, said today that he would shortly begin a hunt throughout the Aberdare Mountains for the rare bongo antelope.

IT is lunch rather than dinner that is likely to present more problems in menu planning during the forty days of Lent that begin today. The austere abstinence of earlier times has been so relaxed that it is now permissible to serve meat once a day except on days of abstinence.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 1 (AP) -- The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company said today that without its knowledge some of its television commercials had been "filmed through an open or rolled down automobile window."
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Labor's Industrial Union Department installed two new operating heads and announced a "revitalization" program today.

The Spence-Chapin Adoption Service will benefit from theatre parties on March 15 and April 18. The former will be to "A Thurber Carnival," starring Tom Ewell, Peggy Cass and Paul Ford, at the ANTA Theatre, and the latter to "Greenwillow," a new musical starring Anthony Perkins, which is scheduled to open on Tuesday at the Alvin Theatre.

THE Continental influence, which has crept quietly into the American man's wardrobe, can be attributed, in part, to Gaetano Savini Brioni, the talented Roman tailor whose designs are meeting increased acceptance in this country.
A ten-foot-long laboratory device that simulates the operations of a block-long paper-making machine has been put into operation at the research center of Texaco, Inc., at Beacon, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Although there is a blizzard of civil rights bills whirling about Capitol Hill, most of the discussion about what may ultimately be passed centers on two measures.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department at Agriculture follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The disputed territory on the Sino-Indian border as reported in the press has recently been inflated from 40,000 to 51,000 square miles. Yet no one here knows where the McMahon Line is supposed to have been drawn. Your distinguished commentator C.L. Sulzberger remarked on Dec. 28, 1959, that "its precise location has never been officially communicated to Washington."
ALBANY, March 1 -- Governor Rockefeller today challenged recalcitrant Republican Assemblymen to accept his program for the promotion of highway safety.

Representative Ludwig Teller's bid for re-election in Manhattan's Twentieth Congressional District got under way yesterday with the announcement that former Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora would be campaign manager.

GUATEMALA, March 1 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes asked his people today to turn away from the political past, "dictatorships and fictitious democracies," and to look forward to the "triumph of democracy, industrialization and victory over political infirmities."
MIAMI, March 1 -- Paul Richards hobbled down the dugout steps, slumped on the bench, clutched his right ankle and grimaced.
Following is the remainder of President Eisenhower's program for his South American trip All times are regional (Chile is one hour ahead of Eastern standard time and Uruguay three hours ahead).
DETROIT, March 1 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings strengthened their grip on a National Hockey League playoff position with a 3-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The civilian space agency broadened its program today to cover biological phenomena.

Chance Vought Aircraft, Inc., set back by the cancellation of substantial aircraft contracts last year, has diversified its activities into nonmilitary business and formed five divisions to serve the changed requirements of the space age.

Debentures of the Municipality of Metropolitan Toronto valued at $41,318,000 are being offered to the public today by investment bankers jointly managed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and The Dominion Securities Corporation.
BOWIE, Md., March 1 (UPI) -- Tinkalero led all the way in scoring a length victory over Allchain today in the feature race at Bowie.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 1 (AP) -- Ted Williams reported to the Boston Red Sox' training camp today with a sore neck and the dour prediction he might be through with baseball. He has played eighteen seasons with Boston.
LONDON, March 1 -- Further falls in British Government issues depressed other sections of the stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to consider the constitutionality of an Alabama law that changed the boundaries of the City of Tuskegee to exclude virtually all Negroes as residents.
JERSEY CITY, March 1 -- A court ruling today ended a nine-day-old strike by seventy-three employes of the Jersey City municipal incinerator. The walkout had halted garbage collections here.

AGADIR, Morocco, March 1 -- Two earthquakes, a tidal wave and fire left this resort a vast heap of rubble and cracked shells of houses. The toll of the dead was estimated tonight at more than 1,000 and of the injured additional thousands.

VANCOUVER, B.C., March 1 (Canadian Press) -- Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, opened a bid for her fifth consecutive world figure skating title today by taking an 11-point lead in the unofficial standings after the first two compulsory figures.
A threatened walkout by 4,500 community center workers was averted yesterday after a meeting between their representatives and Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Governor Rockefeller disowned all responsibility or affection today for the law that requires parents to pay taxes on the baby-sitting and caddying fees of their enterprising children.

At Madison Square Garden last night it was so quiet one could almost hear an antique drop. In fact a chipped coffee cup at the Antique Show in the Garden's basement probably would have caused more of a stir than the Knicks' 124-121 defeat by Syarcuse.

A contractor has told a state investigation that extensive records, some of them bearing on perhaps 94 per cent of a $2,000,000 West Side sewer job, were stolen last year from a trailer parked at the project.
LONDON, March 1 -- Prime Minister Macmillan told the House of Commons today that the Government had decided not to permit the televising of Parliamentary proceedings.

WAUKESHA, Wis., March 1 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota delivered a blistering attack on the Eisenhower Administration today as he wound up a three-day swing through Wisconsin in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
Now it's not in the bag -- it's on the bag.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Government called upon four Massachusetts radio stations today to justify renewal of their Federal licenses in the light of payola that they or their employes may have received.

Slow days on the Toronto Stock Exchange have worried members into changing their mind about new headquarters. Yesterday they voted at a special meeting not to finance the building of new quarters, a plan announced with some fanfare last May.
Combined net income of 2,404 United States corporations increased 20 per cent in 1959 to $17,700,000,000, the First National City Bank of New York reports in its Monthly Bank Letter, published today.
AT the Phoenix they are performing one of their best civic duties. In the production that opened last evening, they are reminding us that "Henry IV, Part 1" is one of the richest Shakespeare dramas.

A billion-dollar enterprise that would improve the lot of 50,000,000 people and help India and Pakistan to fortify their growing sense of common destiny in the face of the Communist menace has come a long step nearer realization with the announcement by the World Bank that six nations stand ready to join in financing the Indus River project.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 1 -- President Eisenhower said today that allegations that the United States supported dictatorships were ridiculous.
A bill to increase the fees charged by the city for Buildings Department processing and examination of plans for construction was sent to the City Council yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Phyllis Preuss of Pompano Beach, Fla., today led the qualifiers for the thirty-second annual Florida East Coast women's golf tournament.
AGADIR, Morocco, March 1 (UPI) -- Americans, British and German tourists as well as the permanent inhabitants of Agadir wandered in confusion through the rubble of this ruined city tonight.
The Columbia Broadcasting System television network will switch "Face the Nation" to Monday evening next fall and initiate a half-hour news program to be presented Friday evening.
ALGIERS, March 1 -- Mahdi Benhadad was installed today as prefect of a department in the Aures Mountains. He was the first Moslem to attain such a high office in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The head of the country's largest farm organization labeled a Democratic bill today a "step toward collectivization" of farmers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- Universal-International will continue to make films even if a strike by actors called for next Monday closes down the biggest movie studios here.
BRITISH couturiers are out to show the world just what is meant by inimitable English tailoring and a grandeur in ball gowns that has all but disappeared.

Ferro Corp. Ferro Corporation, Cleveland, yesterday acquired the Vitro Manufacturing Company, Pittsburgh, a division of Vitro Corporation of America, for $500,000 in cash. Vitro manufactures a line of glass and overglaze colors, glaze stains and porcelain enamel oxides.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: State Education Commissioner Allen's proposal that the basic formula by which the state distributes aid to local school systems be modernized deserves the support of all who are concerned with proper financing of our public schools.
Three 12-year-old boys were arrested last night for painting more than 100 swastikas, Stars of David and obscene words and pictures on walls inside Amsterdam Hotises, a West Side housing project.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The Administration has investigated leaks of secret information given to Congressional committees by United States intelligence agencies.
The New York Central, outwitted by some of its passengers, asked the State Public Service Commission yesterday for relief in the form of a fare increase.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 -- Captain Mike Graneys 22 foot slap shot at 14 seconds a sudden-death overtime Harvard a 4-3 hockey triumph over Princeton tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission opposed today a series of House bills designed to stop or slow the wholesale discontinuance of commuter trains to the big cities.

The number of persons injured by automobiles here last week was sixty-five greater than in the same period a year ago. The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 845 persons had been injured in the period this year as opposed to 780 the year before.

"The Man Who Is France: The Story of General Charles de Gaulle," by Stanley Clark, will be published March 14 by Dodd, Mead. The biography traces de Gaulle's career from World War I to his "recall to power" in the post-World War II period and as a world figure as President of the Fifth Republic.

Most cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange mostly declined yesterday. The far July and December positions rose 9 and 2 points, respectively. Other options were unchanged to 8 points below Monday's close.

An "old" expert with a new auto has started the 1960 sports car rally season with a victory. Richard Smith, the Quakertown, Pa., restaurateur who has been among the first ten in national rally competition for the last five years, driving Porsches and Saabs, won the Pennsylvania Sports Car Club's annual February rally last week-end in a Fiat 2100.

A schoolboy basketball performance that would have done credit to almost any player any time at Madison Square Garden was turned in by Ken Guzzardo of Cleveland High before 11,000 spectators at the Garden yesterday.

Prices jogged downward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The losses were moderate but widespread. Only the motors, helped by good February production figures, and the electronics, aided by the mystery of the future, rose.

GENEVA, March 1 -- The governing body of the International Labor Organization acted today to set up a special institute to deal with labor problems and leadership training. The accent will be on bringing to it the new labor leaders of Asia and Africa.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The Eisenhower Administration today threw its weight behind proposals to impose an import fee of 8 cents a pound on cotton textiles entering the United States to offset the cost disadvantage of United States textile mills.
The third annual Hearts and Diamonds Ball will be held on April 7 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate defeated at 6:33 A.M. today a motion of Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, to adjourn the Senate at 8 o'clock tonight in the civil rights debate:

IF there were nothing more to "Simon Boccanegra" than the Council Chamber scene, it would repay going miles to hear and see. For this is the magistral Verdi of "Otello" and the Requiem who can combine furious intensity with forgiving compassion.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 1 (UPI) -- Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, proposed today a four-point program at the high school level to deal with "economic illiteracy" in this country.
PARIS, March 1 -- The United States urged economic cooperation on the West today in the interest of its own growth as well as that of underdeveloped nations.
WHITE PLAINS, March 1 -- A stone shaft 300 feet high was proposed today for the top of Chatterton Hill here as a permanent memorial to the crucial battle of White Plains in the Revolutionary War.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation set records last year for sales and for increased earnings, according to the report issued for release to some 75,000 shareholders today.
CONAKRY, Guinea, March 1 -- Guinea withdrew from the franc zone today in a move that apparently severed her last close ties with France.

VANCOUVER, B.C., March 2 (AP) -- Carol Heiss of Ozone Park, Queens, gained a big lead today in defense of her world figure-skating championship. She completed the compulsory figure program with an unofficial total of 939.9 points.
In an insiders' list that was shorter than usual, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday reported major changes in stockholdings by executives of only five companies.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- An Agriculture Department official said today it was "no concern" of the Government that ships carrying American surplus food to Arab countries were barred from trading with Israel.

BOSTON, March 2 (AP) -- Boston's aroused Eastern Division Champions, playing without Frank Ramsey, toppled Philadelphia to a 133-119 National Basketball Association defeat tonight. The Minneapolis Lakers downed the New York Knickerbockers, 123-113, in the opener of the Boston Garden double-header.

TUNIS, March 2 -- President Eisenhower was authoritatively reported today to have suggested to President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia that a temporary truce in the Algerian war might serve to get peace talks under way.

MIAMI BEACH, March 2 (AP) -- Luis Rodriguez, Cuba's unbeaten welterweight contender, reached up to the middleweight class tonight and decisively outpointed Chico Vejar of Stamford, Conn., in a ten-round nationally televised bout at Miami Beach Auditorium.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 2 -- Uruguay has given President Eisenhower's National Advisory Committee on Inter-American Affairs a list of development projects for which $137,000,000 in foreign financing is sought.

TORONTO, March 2 (Canadian Press) -- John Inglis Company, Ltd., announced today that it had purchased the assets -- except for real estate, buildings and machinery -- of the Pusey and Jones Corporation, paper-machinery manufacturers of Wilmington, Del.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 2 -- Uruguay is a country that puts her faith in a weak Presidency, good neighbors and a sound peso.

LOS ANGELES, March 2 -- Senator Kennedy's decision was approved today by Governor Brown as "a welcome one for California Democrats."
PARIS, March 2 -- President de Gaulle plans to be in Algeria tomorrow to renew direct contact with the French Army there.
DETROIT, March 2 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams, who has led the Democratic party in Michigan through eleven years of political resurgence, will announce tomorrow that he will not run for another term.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points (60 cents a bale) up to 7 points (35 cents) off yesterday. The market closed below its highs of the day.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The year 1960 opened auspiciously for a big improvement in the United States balance of payments, Government figures revealed today. The balance of payments is the difference between total exports and total imports.
KABUL, Afghanistan, March 2 -- Premier Khrushchev of the Soviet Union arrived here today to a rousing welcome, probably the most enthusiastic of his Asian tour.
A National Labor Relations Board trial examiner ordered the Bethlehem Steel Company yesterday to produce financial records of its shipbuilding division for a period close to three years.
HOW do some parents inadvertently destroy a child's self-confidence?
Oscar Robertson chalked up another "first" yesterday when he was picked for the 1960 United Press International all-America college basketball team.

The age of automation has cost one of the nation's largest stock brokerage houses a quarter of a million dollars. The company's electronic bookkeeping was so complex that an embezzler worked for eight years without detection.

Eli Wallach is to have a starring role in "Rhinoceros." He will depict a young man who refuses to conform, in the Eugene lonesco play, translated by Derek Prouse. The same part is currently being enacted by Jean-Louis Barrault in the successful Paris version.

Lent began yesterday with the distribution of ashes in Roman Catholic and some Protestant churches in the city and with an appeal from, the Pope to Catholic children for gifts to aid less fortunate children overseas.

TRENTON, March 2 -- Senator Clifford P. Case announced his candidacy for renomination today. He will be opposed in the Republican primary April 19 by Robert Morris of Point Pleasant and David Dearborn of Elizabeth.

The annual report of the Boston Fund, mailed yesterday, disclosed that, by sharply reducing its common stock holdings in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 the big balanced mutual fund was in a favorable investment position before the recent declines in equity prices.

Phillip P. Zipes, realty operator, has purchased three fivestory buildings containing seventy-five apartments and occupying a plot 160 by 100 feet at 1333-37-43 Merriam Avenue, between East 169th and 170th Streets, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- In an effort to reconcile French views with a disarmament plan agreed to by four other Western powers, Western disarmament experts are prolonging their conference here.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- The man who took over today as Chicago's Acting Police Commissioner has a lot to learn about this city, but he will need no extensive research on the theories of police administration.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 2 -- A fancy new night club called Continental Bar opened in downtown Bucharest last night.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 2 (AP) -- American Comet, ridden by Tommy Barrow, captured the $28,200 Arcadia Handicap today on Santa Anita's grass course.
A far-sighted Philadelphian has built his electronic version of musical church bells into a $2,000,000-a-year business.
HANOVER, N.H., March 2 -- Dartmouth's hockey team moved one step closer to its second straight Ivy League championship tonight by beating Brown, 2 -- 1.
MIAMI, March 2 -- Royal Native showed the speed that has made her one of the best fillies in the land today.
LONDON, March 2 -- The three Western powers will postpone the renewal of high-altitude flights to West Berlin, authoritative sources said tonight.
Despite the weakness in the stock market, dividends are definitely rising. The Standard Poor's Corporation, which keeps a running count of payments made by the major companies, has this to say:

Mayor Wagner was asked yesterday to investigate a possible "conflict-of-interests" case involving Fordham University's acquisition of land for its midtown campus on the Lincoln Square slum clearance site.
Vince Shomo of New York, a hard-hitting lightweight, scored two first-round knockouts to retain his Eastern Golden Gloves championship in Madison Square Garden last night.

The B.T.L. Corporation yesterday completed the purchase from the H.L. Green Company, Inc., of its stock holdings in the United Stores Corporation, according to announcements by Bert R. Prall, chairman of Green, and Harry Wachtel, executive vice president of B.T.L.
CHICAGO, March 2 -- Orlando W. Wilson took charge of the scandal-plagued Chicago police force this morning as acting commissioner.
While other studios are holding future production plans in abeyance until resolution of the actors' strike threatened for Monday, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is proceeding with business as usual.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, March 3 -- The Senate's civil rights filibuster flowed toward its third dawn today on a torrent of Southern oratory that shows no sign of ebbing.

BOSTON, March 2 -- Willem M.L. van Rie was acquitted today of the charge of murdering Lynn Kauffman, 23-year-old divorcee, at sea Sept. 18. The verdict came at 9:12 A.M., after the male jury had considered the case fifteen and a half hours.
Twelve advertising agencies have been invited by the Pepsi-Cola Company to discuss with company officials the services and approaches each would provide if the account were theirs.

Fred J. Loughran, former director of the city's Bureau of Weights and Measures, was acquitted early today on charges of extortion and conspiracy growing out of an investigation of the cheating of housewives by butchers.

GREENWOOD, S.C., March 2 -- This Bill Clyburn must be operating for the sheer pleasure of discouraging amateur bird-dog trainers. He trains only three or four dogs a year beside his own three pointers, and those only on desperate pleas.

The nation's supply of gasoline last week was at its highest level in nearly two years. The American Petroleum Institute reported that stocks on last Friday totaled 215,623,000 barrels, against 212,942,000 the week before and 207,744,000 barrels a year ago.
Representatives of civic groups were unanimous yesterday in calling for a higher minimum wage in testimony before a City Council committee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2 -- Gene Scott's five goals paced Yale's hockey team to an 11-2 victory over American International College tonight. The Elis, in their final game of the season, broke a four-game losing streak.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The amount of alcohol that may be consumed before the capacity of a person to drive becomes impaired varies according to the person's weight.
ALBANY, March 2 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Department of Commerce:

A stout, bald 77-year-old man sat at the ringside watching the judging at the recent Madison Square Garden dog show. Perhaps those who were near watched him with interest, too. He was Henry J. Kaiser, the international industrialist.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- When Duke Snider paid his first visit to the Dodger training camp last week, he surveyed Larry Sherry with the appraising eye of a carnival pitchman who has the weight-guessing concession. Even before he said hello, the Duke studied every angle, lips pursed.
ALBANY, March 2 -- A bill to grant tax relief to landlords who install central heating in tenements and so-called single-occupancy dwellings in New York City was approved by the Assembly today.

PARIS, March 2 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, announced today that the United States, Britain and France had "tacitly" agreed to integrate a battalion each into a task force that would have atomic weapons.

The scoreboard clock at Madison Square Garden showed one second remaining. Thirty feet away from the basket Tony Jackson leaped into the air and released a high, soft one-hander. The buzzer sounded. The crowd gasped.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Girls are better students in grade schools and high school, and boys are better students in college, according to a study made public today.
A drive to increase private United States investment in Israel by $300,000,000 by 1965 was announced yesterday with formal opening of an investment promotion center at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The popular image of the Senate in mid-filibuster has the atmosphere charged with electricity, Senators snapping angrily at one another, tension and bitterness mounting.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- The medal winner, Phyllis Preuss of Pompano Beach, Fla., and the national amateur champion, Barbara McIntyre of Lake Park, Fla., scored easy victories in the first round of the thirty-second annual Florida East Coast women's golf tournament today.

THE vague titles chosen by Pat Adams for her small paintings at the Zabriskie Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street, are clues to her temperament. She is a mystically Inclined dreamer who expresses "The Troubling of Phenomena" and the "Unsald."
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- At Miller Huggins Field today the Yankees held what was to have been their first full practice with a full complement of players. But it wasn't full at all.
Motors and electronics skidded wildly in yesterday's stock market but the downward movement was checked near the close and losses in other parts of the list were moderate.

Final plans are being made for the performance of the Georgian State Dance Company from the Soviet Union at the Metropolitan Opera House on March 20. Proceeds will benefit the Speedwell Society. This will be the only appearance of the group at the Metropolitan.

A SIX-FOOT-SEVEN knight on a jet plane has arrived in New York. His sincerity, youth, intelligence, manners and humor are all the defense the French couture needs to fend off slings of "crazy," "gone" and "unwearable" -- words that fill the air after each Paris collection.

DORADO BEACH, Puerto Rico, March 2 -- United States relations with Latin-American dictators are helping the Communists in Latin America, according to many observers meeting in the Caribbean Assembly at Dorado Beach.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 2 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute defeated Middlebury College, 7 to 1, in hockey tonight. The Engineers scored five goals in the first period. The victory brightened their chances for an Eastern national collegiate playoff bid.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 2 -- The United States policy of patience in Cuba has received the approval and sympathy of the Governments of the four countries President Eisenhower has visited on his current trip.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The Legislature approved Governor Rockefeller's $2,035,000,000 budget today, exactly as the Governor had submitted it.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- New York members of Congress were asked today to campaign for legislation to permit state law-enforcement officials to use wiretapping in their fight against crime.
The sale of $50,000,000 of New York Thruway, state-guaranteed bonds was postponed indefinitely yesterday because of unfavorable market conditions.

Charles T. Ireland Jr., executive vice president and counsel of Alleghany Corporation, has been nominated by that holding company for election as a director of five mutual funds with assets of more than $3,000,000,000.
LONDON, March 2 -- With the banks refraining from further selling of British Government securities, a small rally occurred in this section of the stock market here today.

Nine Negro students were ordered expelled from an Alabama college yesterday while more than fifty Negro men and women were arrested in Nashville, Tenn., after refusing to leave a bus station lunch counter in the face of a bomb threat.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) -- Some members of the House Armed Services Committee rebelled today against terms of a bill to curb alleged influencepeddling by retired military officers hired by private concerns.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., March 2 -- The death toll in the fiery collision yesterday between the Santa Fe Chief and an oil truck near here was set today at fourteen. Forty-five persons remained in hospitals, three in critical or serious condition.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 2 -- Early next year commuters on the New Haven Railroad between Stamford and New York City can look forward for the first time since 1954 to an occasional new car.
A feud that appears to be more than a tempest in a demitasse cup has closed what many consider the finest French restaurant in the United States.

Natus Corp. The Natus Corporation (formerly National U.S. Radiator Corporation) announced yesterday that directors have not declared the quarterly dividend normally paid on the common stock in March "in view of their intention to seek favorable opportunity for the employment of approximately $19,000,000 of net resources of the corporation."
GENEVA, March 2 -- The Soviet Union warned today that it might return to its demand for veto rights over the operation of the proposed treaty to end tests of nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended last Wednesday.

A Graduate School of Nursing will open this fall at New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. The college said yesterday it would offer college graduates who had no nursing education a two-year course to qualify for a Master of Nursing degree.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 2 -- The junior high school must help to re-establish the balance between the "child-centered" elementary school and the "subject-centered" high school and college, Dr. James B. Conant told the annual convention of National Association of Secondary School Principals here today.

Former Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. has informed the county Democratic chairmen of the state that he is returning to politics to campaign for Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts for President.
The owner of five East Harlem tenements against which more than 300 complaints have been lodged in several courts was found guilty yesterday, at his first trial.

Manufacturing statistics released by the Department of Commerce this week show that business inventories increased sharply for the second successive month in January. The total increase for the two months was in the neighborhood of $1.6 billion.
An offering to the public of 78,000 common shares of Electro Instruments, Inc., at $54 a share was made by Bear Stearns Co. and associated underwriters.

Cocoa futures fell to new lows for the lives of the contracts on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. This was the fourth consecutive trading day of new lows. Liquidation, new selling and light stop-loss ordering lowered prices 14 to 19 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 337 lots.
People will sit in Ebbets Field seats this summer. But the seats will be on Hart Island.

The rally that got under way early this week in the market for United States Government securities gathered force yesterday and spread into investment-grade debt securities of corporate and local government issue.
A campaign to obtain qualified college graduates for city jobs was started yesterday by the Department of Personnel. Hiring procedures that normally take several months will be cut to a few hours.

Production of electric power dipped to 14,092,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday from 14,226,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The comparable 1959 figure was 12,972,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

Clifton Fadiman has written a discursive guide to 100 books and authors from Homer to Hemingway. In his book, called "The Lifetime Reading Plan," he prefaces each recommended volume with a commentary on the author and his work and tells what the reader may gain from it.

A syndicate headed by L. and N. Silberstein and Charles Bick has purchased the blockfront on the east side of Amsterdam Avenue, between Seventy-second and Seventy-third Streets. The seller was Belmont Equities, Inc.

A four-year fight for control of Wall Street's smallest bank may be nearing a decision. The annual meeting of the American Trust Company, already once postponed, seema likely to be adjourned again today.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday the letting of construction contracts for one of the world's longest microwave beam systems. Walter P. Marshall, president, said that the new coast-to-coast network, to be completed late in 1961, would provide a circuit to be leased to the Air Force as well as a link for more than 50,000,000 miles of telegraph channels for private wire and data-processing systems, facsimile and other company services.

Potato futures soared 17 to 20 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The volume, 3,578 car lots (50,000 pounds to a car), was the largest since the record high of 4,041 cars was set on April 11, 1958.

MOTHERS familiar with the frantic search for the right department as their sitter time clicks away should be delighted with Stern's new second-floor children's section. Twelve "Young Shops," each clearly marked as to size range, cater to boys and girls 14 years old and younger.

CHRISTINE ARNOTHY, a beautiful Hungarian emigree, is a talented member of the younger generation of European writers. Whether the publication of her fourth book, "It Is Not So Easy to Live,"* will help matters Is doubtful.

IN a snow-mantled city that should have made a Moscow resident feel at home, Pavel Lisitsian, leading baritone from the Bolshoi Opera, last night made his debut at the Metropolitan Opera. Millard Fillmore was President of the United States when the first general conflict-of-interest law was passed in 1853. UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the last fortnight had seen a temporary improvement in the critical situation in the Middle East.
The year's heaviest snowfall hit New York yesterday, crippling road and air travel, closing schools and disrupting business and communications.

VANCOUVER, B.C., March 3 (AP) -- Europe's champion, Alain Giletti of France, opened a spirited bid today for the men's world figure-skating championship left vacant by David Jenkins of Colorado Springs, who retired after gaining the Olympic crown.

UTICA, N.Y., March 3 (AP) -- Mohawk Airlines today raised salaries of its sixty stewardesses by an average 6 per cent, but whether the move would avert a threatened strike still was in doubt.

CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- The grain futures market today erased all its general gains of yesterday as selling became as aggressive on the setbacks as the buying was on the run-ups of Thursday's session.

This one began in 1954 and must follow its predetermined course -- like the Carlist struggle in Spain, General Markos' Greek uprising, or the affair in Indochina.

SAN JOSE, Calif., March 4 (UPI) -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, today challenged Air Force Gen. Thomas B. Power's contention that 300 Soviet missiles could wipe out the United States' retaliatory force.
LONDON, March 4 -- The stock market was quiet here today, subdued by the decline in Wall Street and the normal end-account influences.

MITCHELL ANDREWS, who made his debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, is an excellent pianist who plays in a clean-cut, technically expert fashion.
With Columbus Circle galoshdeep in winter, the Forty-third International Flower Show will open at the New York Coliseum today, forcing spring on Fifty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Navy, in its plans to pull its destroyer escort picket ships out of the Distant Early Warning System, had the approval of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. In authorizing the change the Joint Chiefs overrode the recommendations of the Chief of the North American Defense Command.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Mrs. N.M. Schenck's Cobul, the 9-to-5 favorite captured the featured seventh race at Gulfatream Park today. She led all the way. Narrissa was second and Betty Linn finished third.

CONAKRY, Guinea, March 3 -- President Sekou Toure signed an agreement to implement the granting of Soviet credits totaling $35,000,000 the day he proclaimed Guinea's separation from the French franc zone.

THOSE searching for unusual antique items to give Individuality to a room might head for Dolphin Importers at 187 East Sixty-fourth Street. This store was recently opened by Mr. and Mrs. Jose David, both avid collectors of French antiques.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration today opposed any changes in the transportation law designed to prevent the hasty abondonment of rail and ferry commuter service.

American University of Washington, D.C., scored a 83-74 victory over Upsala College last night in the opening game of the Eastern regional play-offs of the National Collegiate Athletic Association college-division basketball tournament at Wagner College on Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, Saturday March 5 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas predicted yesterday that the Senate would pass "a good voting rights bill" despite a Southern filibuster now breaking all endurance records.

Next week promises to bring a large volume of fixed interest securities into the new capital market, but two $100,000,000 issues will account for most of the $280,000,000 involved in the major offerings.
Victor Zalazar of Argentina gained a split decision over Yama Bahama of Bimini in their ten-round middleweight bout at Madison Square Garden last night. A chorus of boos greeted the official verdict.
The "cross fire" between public and private schools was deplored yesterday by a leading educator who urged the two groups to share their equipment and teachers.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Rear Admiral George Calvin Weaver, retired, died this morning in near-by Arlington, Va., after his car ran off the road into a snowbank. He was 54 years old.

AMMAN, Jordan, March 4 (AP) -- A United States expedition of divers seeking the lost Biblical cities of Sodom and Gomorrah has reported that it came across promising evidence of ruins at the bottom of the Dead Sea.

LONDON, March 4 -- Certain key British Government departments believe they can discern the effect of the Presidential election campaign in a gradual slowing in the tempo at executive levels in Washington. The British, who expect a pre-election slowdown every four years, usually meet it with stoic calm.

Volume in potato futures trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange was the second highest of the year -- reaching 2,873 car lots (50,000 pounds to a car lot.) The peak volume for the year was set last Thursday when 3,578 car lots were traded.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission acknowledged to investigators in the House of Representatives today that he had accepted six days and nights of hospitality from a broadcasting company official during a Florida vacation last month.

Leonard Warren, one of the greatest operatic baritones ever developed in the United States, collapsed and died on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of Feb. 25 "The Payments Deficit" you comment on the paper issued by the Committee for Economic Development (C.B.D.). After citing the deficit of $7 billion in our international account and the loss of over $3 billion in gold in the past two years, the report concluded that such a trend could not be allowed to continue.
