Somewhat bad news for life insurance salesmen came yesterday with the news that sales of life insurance in this country showed a slight decline in January from the 1959 level. The face amount of policies sold totaled $4,752,000,000, down more than 1 per cent from the $4,814,000,000 in January, 1959, the Life Insurance Agency Management Association reported.
Jack Paar returned to television last night, twenty-five days after he had walked out in the middle of his show because the National Broadcasting Company had censored a joke.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Government's plan for the stimulation of United States exports were discussed today at a closed conference of business executives. Public announcement may come within a week.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 7 -- Premier Ben-Gurion took off for the United States tonight to start a tour of Western capitals for pre-summit talks.

Nine teen-agers from Queens went to City Hall yesterday to ask support for a city-wide youth conference on solutions to juvenile delinquency. They received assurances of cooperation from Mayor Wagner and top officials of youth and social agencies.

Another large nation, comprising some 90,000,000 people, passed under an authoritarian regime over the week-end when President Sukarno of Indonesia suspended Parliament indefinitely and therewith removed the last symbol of Western-style parliamentary democracy. He had already assumed increased powers last July when he dissolved the Constituent Assembly and reinstated Indonesia's first wartime Constitution, which stripped Parliament of its principal prerogative in a parliamentary democracy -- namely, the right to overthrow the Government.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Vice President Nixon repudiated tonight Governor Powell's charge that Senator Kennedy had shown "softness toward communism."
Alexander Mackendrick has withdrawn as director of "The Guns of Navarone," which Carl Foreman has written and will produce for presentation by Columbia.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Federal Reserve Board repealed today an amendment to its stock market margin regulations that had been designed to curb bank lending that evaded the regulation.

The Celanese Corporation of America realized an increase of 36 per cent in earnings last year on a sales gain of 18.5 per cent from the 1958 levels, according to the annual report issued for publication today.
Nadine Conner, soprano, will give her last performance at the Metropolitan Opera when she sings Marguerite in Gounod's "Faust" on Saturday.

Ed Harding of the Harvard Club, seeded first, and Stewart Dunn of Short Hills, seeded second, were among the winners in third-round matches in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C singles competition last night.
CONCORD, N.H., March 7 -- Fireworks erupted in the last day of New Hampshire's primary campaign today.

About 300 members of the School Crossing Guards Association paraded outside City Hall yesterday while two of their officers presented demands for increased pay and benefits to Jacob Lutsky, legal assistant to the Mayor.

During the past dozen years the United States has been engaged in the moat gigantic international aid program in history. In recent years there has been a shift of emphasis from civilian reconstruction to military cooperation. This aid has been and doubtless will long continue to be bilateral -- that is, based on contracts between ourselves and a series of individual nations.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Prime fixed interest investments improved in price again, yesterday, but to a lesser extnet than in the closing sessions of last week.
Cotton futures moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 6 points (30 cents) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI) -- A watered-down bill to curb influence-peddling by retired military officers won tentative approval today from the House Armed Services Committee.
RUTH GRAVES and Elaine Moore, the two Greenwich Villagers behind the "Gussie and Becky" sportswear company, first swung into business making fringed hula hoops.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 7 -- Ahmet Emin Yalman, eminent Turkish editor, entered the Istanbul jail today to begin a sentence of fifteen and a half months on charges of having violated national press laws.
For want of a few thousand dollars, the nation's best-known bowling proprietor is spending his time as a bowling proprietor.
ALBANY, March 7 -- The Assembly moved today to make inexpensive school plans available to districts that want to save money by not designing their own new buildings.
Mickey Mantle, the Yankee outfielder who is holding out against a reported $15,000 cut in salary, apparently means to stand his ground.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Dr. George N. Schuster'a defense of Hans Globke in The Times of Feb. 26 is indeed a distressing and disturbing document.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 7 (AP) -- Four white youths tonight tied a Negro man by his feet to a tree, beat him with chains and carved six K's into his chest and stomach.

An increase of 50 per cent in the capacity of existing deepdraft ship anchorages in the Upper Bay will be advocated today by the Port of New York Authority at a public hearing by the Army Corps of Engineers.
The Masters Children's Center at 75 Horatio Street and the Masters Nursery in the Amsterdam Houses will be the beneficiaries of the April 19 performance of "The Good Soup" at the Plymouth Theatre.

MILWAUKEE, March 7 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey served notice on his party today that he would fight for a liberal platform at the national convention to fit the campaign he would conduct if nominated.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Tuscarora Indians lost in the Supreme Court today their long fight to prevent the use of their land in western New York for the Niagara Power Project. The court held, 6 to 3, that Congress had given the necessary authorization to the New York Power Authority to condemn the land.
PARIS, March 7 -- President de Gaulle called on the Moslem rebels tonight to join other Algerians in establishing an Algerian polity linked to France.

Big City: a Modern Cancer? It is probably good that man is not easily alarmed by what other men say. Sticks and stones may break his bones but words rarely disturb him deeply, possibly because there are so many of them.

WOMEN whose table setting problems are limited mostly to feeding a family in an orderly manner three times a day for 365 days a year (maybe just twice on Thanksgiving) have it "made" compared with the problems of some people.
HAVANA, March 7 (AP) -- United States business men predicted today that Cuba would hasten to seize all American property as a result of the uproar over the munitions ship disaster in Havana harbor.

CINCINNATI, March 7 (AP) -- The University of Cincinnati basketball team forced home-town rival Xavier out of its ball control, type of game tonight and scored an 86-68 victory before 11,096 fans at Cincinnati Garden.

The International Harvester Company yesterday announced acquisition of the Solar Aircraft Company of San Diego, Calif., through an exchange of stock. The big farm equipment manufacturer said the required 80 per cent of Solar common, stock had been deposited.

General Sessions Judge Irwin D. Davidson announced yesterday that he would no longer approve wiretapping applications submitted to him by the District Attorney's office. He is the first member of General Sessions Court to make such a decision.

IT is a pleasure to have one of the finest stories by Ivan Turgenev (1818-83) in David Magarshack's fresh, lively new translation. This is a tale of sacred and profane love in a wildly romantic era. Many authors, generally speaking, could, and did -- and, no doubt, still will -- tell it. But none so well as Turgenev.

A report of nationalist insurrection in Angola with arms smuggled in from abroad came yesterday from two directors of the American Committee on Africa. They have just returned from the Portuguese territory in West Africa where they made secret contact with nationalist groups while traveling as tourists last month.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House today from his two-week tour of South America after a three-hour flight from Ramey Air Force Base in Puerto Rico.

The Maritime Administration may become the reluctant owner of a fleet of new tankers by fall, if Congress does not act promptly to tide United States tanker owners over the current depression in shipping.

The State of Louisiana sold $15,000,000 of highway bonds secured by the general taxing power yesterday at an interest cost of 3.7956 per cent. The sale supplanted that of Jan. 20, which was canceled because of an error in the advance notice of sale.

Klausner Associates, Inc., realty operators, purchased the five-story building containing fifty-four apartments and four stores at 1216 First Avenue near Sixty-sixth Street. The parcel, 75 by 100 feet, was sold by the Joblaed Realty Compan in a deal negotiated by Mrs. Shirley Stamm of the Curti Solove Company, brokers.

A slight rise in steel production this week was forecast yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. Production of ingots and steel for casting is estimated at 2,647,000 net tons, or 92.9 per cent of rated capacity.

IF the French have their wits about them, Ethel Frankau will be next in line for the Legion of Honor. Miss Frankau, director of Bergdorf Goodman's Custom Salon for forty-five years, has distinguished herself and the French couture with a superb new collection of imports.
PROVO, Utah, March 7 (UPI) -- The University of Utah basketball team defeated Southern California 80 -- 73, tonight in a first-round National Collegiate play-off game.
NEW DELHI, India, March 7 -- India has accepted a Soviet offer to build a nuclear power station, officials announced today.
Mayor Wagner's proposed appointment of a niece of former Mayor William O'Dwyer as a magistrate drew fire yesterday from Queens women lawyers -- on principle, rather than personality.

The primary campaign, said Adlai Stevenson, "is not a suitable testing ground for Presidential candidates." It certainly is not a sure one, for in the first Democratic primary of 1956 it was Estes Kefauver who received 84 per cent of New Hampshire's preference vote.
YONKERS, March 6 -- "Music," bellowed the coach. A mellifluent string quartet filled the chilly gym with waltzes.

Short covering firmed copper prices early in the session yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. However, 109 delivery notices were issued and circulated most of the day. The circulation of the notices induced commission house liquidation and light stop-loss selling.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- An advance today of 75 cents a hundred pounds sent the butcher hog market to a new eight-months high. Buyers quickly cleared the smallest Monday supply in six months.

THE name of Harry J. Fishbein, president of the Mayfair Bridge Club in New York, appears with great frequency in bridge articles for a simple reason. Bridge columnists dote on unusual bridge hands, and Mr. Fishbein is a collector of such hands.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for a comparatively easy-to-prepare main dish.

The five 1960 recipients of the Justice Louis D. Brandeis Gold Medal awards of the Jewish Forum were greeted and congratulated by Mayor Wagner yesterday in a two-hour presentation ceremony at City Hall.

"Oh, Kay!," another musical hit of old Broadway, will be revived off Broadway next month. It will open April 12 at the East Seventy-fourth Street Theatre, under the auspices of Leighton K. Brill, Fred Lewis Jr. and Bertram Yarborough.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter summoned Cuba's Charge d'Affaires today and angrily told him that Premier Fidel Castro's implication that the United States was involved in a Havana munitions ship explosion was "baseless, erroneous and misleading."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Ten Arab envoys jointly expressed to Secretary of State Christian A. Herter today their "deep concern" over the visit to the United States next week of Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel.

The Eastern regional elimination round of the National Collegiate basketball championship opens with a triple-header tonight at Madison Square Garden and five of the coaches were here yesterday with kind words for their teams and for the opposition.

TORONTO, March 7 -- Hollywood's complex economics, which led to today's walkout of film stars from major Studios on the West Coast, is the reason for the experimental introduction of pay-as-you-see television in the Toronto suburb of Etobi-coke.

A light covering of snow fell last night and early today over the residue of last week's crippling storm. The Weather Bureau said two-tenths of an inch had fallen by 1 A.M., but that no heavy accumulation was expected.

Four records were set last year by the New York Life Insurance Company. Payments to policy holders and beneficiaries, assets, life insurance in force, and premiums received, were at new highs, but sales of life insurance dipped slightly from the year before, the company reported yesterday.

"We remain of the opinion that the market is headed lower." "The market has some way to go before the downward trend is halted." "The market has been very much technically weakened in the last twelve to eighteen months and the process of correcting this weakness has seemingly not even begun."
LONDON, March 7 -- The Soviet Union has reinforced its submarine fleet in the eastern Mediterranean, the British Admiralty said today.

NEW HAVEN, March 7 -- A member of the Yale University staff was arrested today as the police pressed their investigation of a ring of dog wardens who collected fees for supposedly destroying unclaimed dogs and then sold the animals to Yale for medical research.
A JOHN CAGE musico-the-atrico extravaganza was the feature of last night's Composers Showcase at the Circle in the Square, but the evening's music was provided by Henry Cowell.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Government's short-term borrowing costs dropped sharply today, in keeping with the renewed strength of the bond market during the last week.
THE Composers Group of New York presented a program of new works at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, a feature being the first performance of four poems by Boris Pasternak.

Although Christmas is more than nine months off, toy manufacturers have begun showing their 1960 lines at the New Yorker Hotel, the Sheraton-Atlantic Hotel, 200 Fifth Avenue, 1107 Broadway and permanent show rooms in the area.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March -- A Negro leader said today that further protest demonstrations would likely be staged here to dramatize disatisfaction over segregation.
Aaron Copland and Lukas Foss will visit the Soviet Union for a period of four weeks under the exchange program of the State Department.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 7 -- A couple of hunting machines on the Ridgewood Shooting Preserve here enable the heirs of Daniel Boone, who roam hardily across the country in gleaming cars and executive planes, to live it up even more adventurously.
On April 1, the biggest countdown in the history of the country will get under way. The census taker will begin knocking on doors.

LONDON, March 7 (AP) -- A television audience estimated at 50,000,000 people will Watch this year's running of the Grand National steeplechase, one of the world's most gruelling races, on screens throughout Europe.
Eight men rounded up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation were accused yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, of hijacking more than $100,000 in freight from trailer trucks in the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Administration is reviving plans to place atomic weapons in the hands of some Allies without requesting Congress for a change in the Atomic Energy Law.
BONN, Germany, March 7 -- The West German Government was represented today as unwilling to compromise in the slightest its rigid stand that West Berlin's present status must remain unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, March 8 -- A deep split over strategy for ending the Southern filibuster appeared yesterday in the Senate's powerful civil rights bloc.

Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation reported yesterday that sales, revenues, net income and share earnings set records in 1959. Ernest R. Acker, president, said gas revenues rose 8 per cent and electric revenues 5 per cent.
ST. LOUIS, March 7 (AP) -- A military funeral today for ten Air Force men came nearly sixteen years after their deaths in the crash of a B-25 in a remote section of New Guinea.
The Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service, Inc., of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will hold its annual benefit, a bridge party, at the Colony Club on the afternoon of March 21.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The angry zeal with which Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, prosecutes his function is unusual in this office, as a his concept of its function. This burning passion to impose conformity to his particular brand of political philosophy on all Democrats or expel them from the party, plus his penchant for indulging in personally derogatory comments about Republicans, have impaired his usefulness is a party chairman.

A Columbia University professor and literary critic charged yesterday that the famed Oberammergau Passion Play was anti-Semitic, tainted with nazism and "an offense against both history and religion."

DETROIT, March 7 (AP) -- Automobile production in the nation continues to run about 20,000 units a week ahead of the 1959 level.

Twin apartment houses in Forest Hills, Queens, have been sold by the R. D. Realty to a client of Lindenbaum Young, lawyers. The property consists of the six-story buildings at 110-35 and 110-55 Seventy-second Road.
The latest monthly survey of the National Association of Purchasing Agents makes two points: business is good; the widely predicted 1960 boom has failed to materialize.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- A Minnesota farm youth who built an atom-smasher was named the winner of the annual Westinghouse science talent search tonight.
ALBANY, March 7 -- A large increase in applications for admission to member institutions of the State University was reported today by Governor Rockefeller.
WILLIAM FAULKNER'S "Tomorrow," translated to the television screen by Horton Foote, contained some moving moments last night on Channel 2.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- The forty-nine-foot yawl Pacifica sailed across the finish line tonight about seven miles ahead of her closest competitor in the 360-mile Miami-to-St. Petersburg yacht race.

FORT WORTH, March 7 (UPI) -- Texas Christian's athletic director, L.R. (Dutch) Meyer, warned Cotton Bowl officials today they "would live to regret" any move to permit pro football on Saturday nights.

HOBART, Tasmania, March 7 (UPI) -- Betty Cuthbert of Australia, an Olympic champion, set a world record of 23.2 seconds today in winning the 220-yard dash in the Australian women's track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Democratic National Chairman apologized today to President Eisenhower and the American people for any implication by him that the President had been responsible in any way for the deaths of nineteen Navy bandsmen in a recent airplane crash in Brazil.
Civic leaders charged yesterday that families uprooted for the Hammels Rockaway slum clearance project in Queens were being resettled in shabby bungalows and deteriorating tenements.

LONDON, March 7 -- A British prosecutor charged today that a former Royal Air Force flying officer who deserted to the Soviet Union had given Soviet officials information on British and United States military operations.
NEW DELHI, India, March 7 -- The Indian motion-picture industry, the second largest in the world, has threatened to close down in protest against a new levy imposed by the central Government.
A 21-year-old man confessed early today to the rape and robbery of a minister's wife on a subway platform Feb. 24, the police reported.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he was renewing his efforts to improve the state's relations with New York City.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 7 -- Senator Wayne Morse today filed as a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in the Maryland primary May 17.

OLD BRIDGE, N.J., March 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard Combs, who may lose their 4-year-old foster daughter because the state says she is too bright for them, said today they would appeal to Gov. Robert B. Meyner.
CHICAGO, March 7 (AP) -- Late profit taking chopped away some of the extreme advances today in the grain futures market, but it still closed generally higher.
Everything from the latest wiring devices to a 2,300-pound voltage motor starter was on display yesterday at the fifth National Electrical Industries Show in the New York Coliseum.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold plans to ask the United Nations to place a special fund at his disposal for the benefit of the newly independent states of Africa. He is discussing the possibility of an initial program of $5,000,000.
IN the words of Judge Irwin Delmore Davidson of General Sessions, "God has not been too good to many people."

VANCOUVER, B.C., March 7 -- Fishermen on this coast where three men out of four spend their week-ends with rod and line are aghast at a decision made by a Royal Canadian Mounted Police officer yesterday to the effect that contest fishing is a lottery within the meaning of the act, and therefore illegal.
YESTERDAY March 7, 1960 THE PRESIDENT Returned to the White House from South American tour.
AFTER a season's absence, Martha Moedl returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night. The role she sang was one with which she has been closely associated. Bruennhilde in "Die Walkuere."

GENUINELY inspired cookbooks are nearly as rare as saffron. Genuinely inspired cookbooks dealing with herb cookery are 'even rarer. A splendid new work dealing with the subject is "The Bible Herb Book" by Marian Maeve O'Brien (The Bethany Press, St Louis, Mo., 1960). It should be a joyous addition to the kitchen library of any cook.

CHICAGO, March 7 (UPI) -- De Paul converted twenty-one of twenty-three free throws tonight to overcome superior shooting from the floor by the Air Force Academy and scored a 69-63 victory. A crowd of 2,010 saw the first-round game in the National Collegiate basketball tournament.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- The Yankees, who dropped to third place last year, went farther back today. They went all the way back to fundamentals.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters asked a Federal court to forbid the monitors of the union to give any information or statement to newsmen.

The March 18 performance of "Greenwillow" at the Alvin Theatre and an after-theatre supper party at The Lambs will benefit Cancer Care of the National Cancer Foundation. The musical starring Anthony Perkins is scheduled to open tonight.
The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago is acting as agent in an offer to purchase 97,000 shares of the common stock of United Stockyards Corporation at $20 a share.
Two old brownstone houses that are sandwiched between the Museum of Modern Art and St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church on West Fifty-third Street off Fifth Avenue have been deeded to the museum.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter published Feb. 29, Harvard Prof. Seymour Harris has done a service by publicizing the plight of the textile industry. He is certainly correct when he states that the Government ought to help labor and capital adjust, but the form that this help is to take is questionable.
Record sales and earnings were attained last year by the National Cash Register Company, Stanley C. Allyn, chairman, reported yesterday.

Presidential candidates and how they become their party standard bearers are the subjects of two books to be published this season. The first to appear will be "White House Fever," by Robert Bendiner, a work of nonfiction.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- A strike by film actors today shut down movie production by seven of the eight major studios here.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., who quit a $60,000-a-year missile company job to speak out for greater defense efforts, warned today that the United States must spend an extra $4,000,000,000 a year to avoid losing World War III.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 7 -- A nine-year hiatus here in United States-Bulgarian diplomatic relations was ended today with the arrival of Edward Page Jr. as American Minister.
California was named the major college basketball champion for the regular 1959-60 season yesterday by the United Press International board of coaches.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7 -- Cairo is sending a high-level mission to Latin America to woo Latin Americans into firmer and friendlier ties with the Arab world.

Off Broadway, which generally functions in the town's most inaccessible places, moved midtown yesterday to the more formal confines of the Plaza Hotel to pay tribute to Brooks Atkinson, drama critic of The New York Times, who will retire from his post in June.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Following is the text of remarks today by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter to Enrique Patterson, Cuban charge d'affaires, as made public by the State Department:

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 7 -- The State Power Authority ran an Indian gantlet for two years as it sought authorization to utilize fully the United States share of the hydroelectric power potential of the Niagara River.

HAVANA, March 7 -- Donald L. Chapman of North Bend, Neb., was rearrested briefly today by intelligence authorities in connection with the explosion of the munitions-laden French freighter La Coubre in Havana harbor Friday.
Robert Moses sharply critisized yesterday a city adminisration revenue-raising measure crrently awaiting action before the Legislature.
Radio operators up and down the East Coast picked up a series of messages last evening purportedly from a ship in distress 200 miles south of Iceland. It was believed the calls were a hoax.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 7 (UPI) -- Llangollen Farm's speedy sprinter, Restless Wind, scored a surprise victory in the $28,200 San Bernardino Handicap at Santa Anita today. Linmold, the Santa Anita Handicap winner, finished out of the money.
Robert Moses sharply critisized yesterday a city adminisration revenue-raising measure crrently awaiting action before the Legislature.

ONE of the homemakers' greatest quandaries is how long cooked left-overs are safe for her family to eat. It is easy to see when bread is moldy, but how can one Judge the quality of roast meat or poultry, potato salad or a custard-type dessert when the signs of spoilage are less evident?

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Officers of five local unions affiliated with the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union of America started action today toward the removal of James G. Cross and Peter N. Olson as president and secretary-treasurer.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The outlook for the enactment of Governor Rockefeller's proposal to ban discrimination in privat housing faded today.
Joseph Papp, whose dispute with Park Commissioner Robert Moses over free Shakespeare in Central Park made headlines last year, was a guest yesterday at Gracie Mansion.
WHITE PLAINS, March 8 -- A subpoena served on a newspaper here today by the White Plains Commissioner of Public Safety touched off a fight over press freedom.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's radio-television report to the nation from Washington last night on his Latin-Ainerican tour, as transcribed by The New York Times:
Cook County (Chicago), Ill., borrowed $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance expressway construction.
CONCORD, N.H., Wednesday, March 9 -- New Hampshire voters gave a massive endorsement to Senator John F. Kennedy as the Democratic nominee in the nation's first Presidential primary yesterday.

THE Monet exhibition announced some months ago by the Museum of Modern Art opens today under the title "Claude Monet: Seasons and Moments." It is worth the wait -- a good show that should please everybody, from those who expect of Monet only beautifully tinted pictures of London, Venice and the French countryside to those who are interested in Monet -- as the museum is -- as a tributary force in contemporary painting.

LONDON, March 8 -- Industrial share prices continued to fall in the stock market here today. Many shares were at their lowest levels for 1960. The Financial Times index of industrial common stocks fell 2.2 points, to 311.2, its lowest since 310.6 on last Dec. 9.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Republican state chairman started a late-session campaign today to whip reluctant party members into line behind Governor Rockefeller's major bills.

Jack (Doc) Kearns, the manager of the light-heavyweight champion, Archie Moore, signed yesterday to have the champion defend his title against Erich Schoeppner of Germany. The contract with Feature Sports, Inc., guarantees Moore $200,000 and Schoeppner $50,000.

PARIS. Twelve years ago, at a top secret meeting of American, British and French generals, it was agreed that the Western Big Three would elaborate a common strategy involving "the entire world." The direct consequence of these talks was the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The City Council unanimously requested the Legislature yesterday to increase state assistance to the four municipal colleges from $2,700,000 to about $10,000,000 a year.

New York University's confusion in the early minutes of last night's contest with Connecticut was attributed in large measure to the Violets' failure to recognize an offensive pattern they had seen before -- in their game against Navy earlier this season.

NEXT to Winston Churchill's cigar, perhaps his most photographed accessory is his bumbershoot, a sturdy black umbrella with what appears to be a Malacca handle. Henri Bendel, a store with a sense of fun, is in possession of a smaller version for little boys.

Charles Townsend Copeland, who died in 1952 in his ninety-third year, was known to thousands of Harvard men as "Copey." He was considered one of the greatest teachers of this country, a wit and a "character" about whom stories have "clustered in profusion."
TOLEDO, March 8 (AP) -- Bob Wheeler and Frank Iannarelli of Ashland, Ohio, moved into first place in the doubles division of the American Bowling Congress championships today with a 1,287 series.
Five new films will open at New York theatres today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (AP) -- Dr. James A. Lehman, a surgeon who flew to Switzerland a year ago to operate on Princess Grace of Monaco, was indicted with his wife today on a charge of evading $284,198 in income taxes.

LONDON, March 8 (UPI) -- The United States and Britain will propose a world maritime plan providing for a six-mile limit on territorial waters and a further six-mile strip for national fishing rights, informed sources said today.
The New York Central Railroad apologized to its commuters yesterday for recent service disruptions, and said all track damage had been repaired.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today that $11,000,000 had been restored to the budget of Project Rover, to accelerate the development of a nuclear-powered rocket.
TRENTON, March 8 -- New Jersey's second highest court today heard the case of a 4-year-old child who may be taken away from her foster parents because the state contends she is too bright for them.
Price of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday.

JUNEAU, Alaska, March 8 (AP) -- A law legalizing the noted Nenana lottery, other lotteries and certain other nonprofit gambling activities was placed among Alaska's statutes yesterday over Gov. William A. Egan's veto.
TO see Friedrich Duerrenmatt's "The Visit" again is to understand why it has lingered so powerfully in memory. It happens to be one of the more trenchant and mordant plays of our time.
New York's largest advertising display, the most expansive electrical shower of light in the world, is being dismantled.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 8 (AP) -- The police broke up a Negro protest demonstration on the campus of Alabama State College today and toog thirty-four students and a faculty member to jail.

Leffert Holz is a lawyer, a real estate executive and a former State Superintendent of Insurance. But it is not generally known that for years he also has been an acting rabbi at prayer services in Temple Emanu-El.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Premier Ben-Gurion will urge President Eisenhower to use United States influence to keep the peace in the Middle East.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 8 -- A correspondent of The New York Times was in effect forced to leave the Dominican Republic today.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
Two of television's songbirds will wing their way to Europe next month.

"PEOPLE OF MOROCCO," a photographic study of the Moroccans, including the Berbers of the Atlas Mountain Region, may be seen at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and Seventy-ninth Street.

Jack McCartan, the United States Olympic goalie who gained a standing ovation Sunday night when he made his professional hockey debut with the New York Rangers, hasn't had "time to catch my breath" since that triumphant effort.
RIO HATO, Panama, March 8 -- More than 1,200 United States paratroopers completed today what was probably the longest airborne mission in history.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Four starving Soviet soldiers, adrift in a small boat in the Pacific for forty-nine days, were rescued Sunday by the crew of the United States aircraft carrier Kearsarge.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 8 -- Foreign Minister Pierre Wigny told Parliament today that France had revived an old claim to a "right of preference" on the Belgian Congo. Belgium denies such an option can be exercised when the Congo receives independence June 30, he added.
MOSCOW, March 8 -- Premier Khrushchev was reported today to have declared that the Soviet Union was ready to enter a world-wide pact to destroy all nuclear weapons "under proper surveillance."
BOSTON, March 8 -- David Ben-Gurion, Israel's Premier, arrived today at Logan International Airport. He declared that his nation looked to "the future with confidence."

SKILLFUL acting did much to bring off Moliere's comedy, "Le Misanthrope," given last night in French and in modern dress at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West Twenty-seventh Street. Scholars have long regarded it as among Moliere's best plays, but it is a pretty slow-moving and talky affair and has never been popular except with the more advanced sort of Moliere enthusiasts.
Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said last night that the United Nations wished to help newly independent African states in a spirit "not of paternalism but of realism and understanding."
When Flight 541 of Delta Air Lines takes off from Newark Airport tomorrow, bound for Charlotte, N.C., the New York University basketball team will be among those fastening their seat belts.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 (UPI) -- The forty-six-foot sloop Solution was named the winner of the Miami-St. Petersburg yacht race today.
A joint effort by labor, management and public representatives to prevent steel strikes will start here today.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 8 -- Rumania's planners envisage a 25 per cent increase in foreign trade this year over 1959 figures and a doubling by 1965. They hope that the increase will be distributed equally between the West and the Soviet bloc.

HAVANA, March 8 -- Cuba rejected tonight the United States' criticism of charges by Premier Fidel Castro that the United States was implicated in the "sabotage" explosion of a munitions ship in Havana harbor last Friday.
THE remarkable Pierre Monteux conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in a Carnegie Hall concert that glowed with creative energy.
WASHINGTON, N.H., March 8 -- The people of this lovely New Hampshire village -- population 278 -- met today in their annual town meeting to talk politics and vote.
YESTERDAY (March 8, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Made television-radio report on Latin-American trip.

OBERAMMERGAU, Germany, March 8 (AP) -- The director of the 1960 Oberammergau Passion Play, asked to comment on a charge that the play was anti-Semitic and tainted with nazism, said tonight, "We have a clear conscience."

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 8 (UPI) -- Ohio University, with Howie Jollif starring under the boards, defeated Notre Dame, 74 -- 66, tonight, in the preliminary round of the National Collegiate Mideast regional basketball tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Eisenhower said tonight that with few exceptions the United States' relations with Latin America had reached their highest point.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 8 -- Sir Ferdinand Cavendish-Bentinck, who resigned last week as speaker of the Kenya Legislative Council, bitterly attacked today the British Government's policy on Kenya.
GENEVA, March 2 -- "Don't curse," said the economist to the driver alongside him, who was about to do so. "Don't curse. A traffic jam is a thing of beauty."

A touring Australian cricket team will meet a picked New York eleven at Walker Park, Staten Island, on May 19. This announcement was made yesterday by the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association, which will manage the fixture and select the players to meet the tourists.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Eisenhower received from Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov today a personal message from Premier Khrushchev. Neither the White House nor the Ambassador would give a hint of its contents.
YESTERDAY (March 8, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Visited Albany Institute of History and Art to confer with advisory council of institute. Greeted several hundred school children visiting legislative session.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The Republican legislative leaders agreed today to support a rise in state education aid higher than the $25,000,000 a year that Governor Rockefeller recommended in his 1960-61 budget.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- "The wind is still blowing in the same direction, only it obviously isn't blowing so hard." This was the comment of a Federal Reserve official today on recent events in the economy. His implication was that the Federal Reserve might be in the process of relaxing somewhat its tight money pressure, although he did not say so directly.

Patrons for the theatre benefit next Tuesday for the Riverdale Neighborhood and Library Association have been announced by Mrs. J. Howard Rossbach, patrons chairman. Mrs. William Bennett Lewis heads the committee planning for the event at the performance of "Greenwillow."

Permit the build-up of a "sizable" Treasury surplus by keeping taxes high, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York urged Congress yesterday. The surplus could be used to aid the fight against inflation and "disturbingly high interest rates," the bank said.

NEWARK, March 8 -- An article published in The New York Times on Feb. 16 erroneously reported that Donald C. Hulbert of Dryden Road, Bernardsville, was one of four men indicted by the Essex County grand jury on charges of swindling insurance clients of more than $200,000 in premiums paid on false policies.
PARIS. THERE are two new stars -- with a commercial twinkle -- on the couture horizon. Louis Feraud and Jacques Esterel two young couturiers who are rising rapidly to fame in the Paris fashion world.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- The practice of some colleges and universities in using scholarship funds to recruit desirable, but no necessarily needy, students was deplored today at the National Conference on Higher Education.

The two-story truck garage at 575 Washington Street has been leased by the 575 Washington Street Corporation, a holding company of the Astor Estate, to the McLaine Service Corporation, a truck renting service.

Conditions in the sugar industry are too fluid for major changes in the sugar program of the United States at the present time, according to Robert H. Shields, president and general counsel of the United States Beet Sugar Association.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Assembly approved by a heavy vote today the first significant item in Governor Rockefeller's highway safety program.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The split in the three-man board of monitors of the Teamsters Union deepened today.
LOGAN, W. Va., March 8 (AP) -- Hope faded tonight for eighteen men trapped behind a fire four miles deep in a coal mine.
A popular misconception about the flight of birds has been exploded by modern high-speed photography.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As principal champion in the United States Senate of legislation to honor Samuel Wilson, the progenitor of the "Uncle Sam" symbol, I feel impelled to answer Hamilton F. Potter Jr.'s critical letter which appeared on March 4.

THERE is a satin-banked oasis of flawless taste on East Forty-ninth Street. Within, fashion blooms serenely, flatteringly and, not to mince facts, expensively. This is no accident. This is the house that Hattie Carnegie built.

In two bills submitted to the City Council the Wagner administration is attempting to transfer to property owners more of the expense of meeting damage claims for accidents attributed to defective sidewalks and roadways. Such claims have been mounting in recent years, for various reasons, and run to about $10,000,000 in awards annually.

TORONTO, March 8 -- If there is one luxury that television cannot afford it is the closed mind that presumes to know whether the chicken or the egg comes first. The Toronto experiment in payas-you-see television may not provide definitive results for a year, but meanwhile its cultural implications can play hob with rigid rationalization of the status quo.
PARIS, March 8 -- Western disarmament specialists were instructed today to work almost around the clock in an attempt to reach agreement on putting a single plan before the Soviet bloc.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) -- Exporters of cotton and importers of cotton textiles told the United States Tariff Commission today that a proposed new import fee of 8 cents a pound on textiles might reduce overseas sales of United States cotton.
BONN, Germany, March 8 -- Some sort of mystery seems to be developing over the status of Guinea's recognition of Communist East Germany.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- Old-crop wheat futures contract posted additional good gains to day, but all other prices on the Board of Trade were steady to weak.

As measured by The New York Times averages, stock market prices yesterday touched their lowest levels in thirteen months. Aggregate market values fell $3,000,000,000 and widened the loss for the year to date to 10.72 per cent.
The general counsel of the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency urged yesterday the removal of "burdensome state laws" that obstructed the flow of mortgage funds across state lines.
ALBANY, March 8 (UPI) -- The skiing-conditions report compiled today by the State Department of Commerce:

The thirteenth annual Salute to Summer cocktail party and tea dance will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on May 16 for the benefit of philanthropic activities of the Society of Memorial Cancer Center.
The Zenith Radio Corporation and another big company will ask the Government in a few weeks to authorize a "large scale" pay television test in this country.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 8 (AP) -- Two Negro students were convicted today on charges stemming from demonstrations against segregated lunch counters.
Ernest Ulmer, pianist, who made his debut at Town Hall in 1954, gave a recital there last night.

Among our many allies and friends Turkey has long enjoyed high esteem in this country because of its stanch stand against Communist aggression and its valiant struggle to become a viable and modern democracy. It was one of the first two countries, together with Greece, to which the United States offered aid under the Truman Doctrine.
A Federal Court order banning wiretap disclosures at state criminal proceedings was assailed yesterday before the full bench of the United States Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) -- A bill to provide tax relief for American concerns operating overseas ran into formidable opposition in the House today. As a result, Democratic leaders postponed a showdown vote indefinitely.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- The Yankee holdout situation was reduced to one name today. But it's still an important one -- Mickey Mantle.

It is impossible to read the news from Cuba these days without a heavy heart. Last Friday's amunitions ship explosion in Havana has been followed by a tragedy of even greater proportions and much more dangerous possibilities: the deliberate fomenting of a national hysteria directed against this country on the fantastic assumption that the United States was responsible for the catastrophe.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 (UPI) -- California, the defending National Collegiate basketball champion, entered the semi-final of the N.C.A.A. Western regionals tonight by overwhelming Idaho State, 71 -- 44.

LONDON, March 8 (UPI) -- Two American welterweights -- Virgil Akins, the former world champion, and Del Flanagan -- had hard luck at Wembley's Empire Pool Arena, tonight. Akins was outpointed and Flanagan and his opponent were disqualified for holding.
IF Ed Wynn had not been such a consummate actor in "The Perfect Fool" on Broadway in 1922 the Chamber of Commerce of the United States probably would have had to look elsewhere for its new president.

Wool prices were strong in moderate trading yesterday or the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops rose 1 to 1.7 cents a pound and grease wool advanced 1.5 to 2 cents. Light, scattered selling supplied the contracts. Heavy short covering in March was reflected across the board.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Legislation to develop a new state medical college in Nassau County appeared headed for approval today. A bill setting up a special county commission to study the need for one was reported by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.
MONTREAL, March 8 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull's late-season spurt has carried him into first place in the National Hockey League point-scoring race.

The Book of the Month Club, which maintains a warehouse at 616 West Forty-sixth Street, has leased the one-story building across the street at 615 West Forty-sixth Street. The lot is 25 by 100 feet. The lease was negotiated by Robert Joseph Co., brokers, who have arranged seven leases for the concern in the last three years.
The Federal Aviation Agency undertook 3,000 enforcement actions against individuals and organizations in 1959, nearly 50 per cent more than the 2,138 in the previous year.

STERN'S new import adaptations are frankly geared to career girls. The collection which will be in the store Monday, includes copies of original designs from Nina Ricci, Jacques Heim, Balenciaga, Laroche amd Gres, of the French couture, and Capucci, Fabiani and Simonetta, from the Italian.
Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. of Missouri expressed confidence last night that Congress would adopt legislation to improve the voting rights of Negroes.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 8 -- American settlers in Israel balked today at issuing a call to Jews in the United States and Canada to settle in Israel.

A veteran of sixty-two years in the copper industry, Walter C. Bennett, 77, has retired as chairman of the Phelps Dodge Refining Corporation, a subsidiary of the Phelps Dodge Corporation. No successor has been named Carleton Harloff continues as president and chief executive officer.
Eliza Doolittle no longer has anything on Lola Fisher.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 -- The Soviet Union is demanding that a Russian get the job of organizing and directing the proposed United Nations scientific conference on the exchange of information about outer space.

PRESSMEN'S HOME, Tenn., March 8 (AP) -- J. Frazier Moore of Detroit has defeated Jack P. Torrence, the incumbent, in a three-way contest for vice president of the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union.
The trial of Representative Adam Clay ton Powell Jr. on charges of income tax evasion opened yesterday in Federal court here before Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan.
State Senator Jacob H. Gilbert, a Democrat, romped to victory in a three-way special election for the House of Representatives yesterday in the Twenty-third District in the Bronx.
The Cape Codders Courageous Rally, one of the oldest events sanctioned by the Sports Car Club of America, will be run by the New England Region on April 2 and 3. This will be its tenth edition.
The United Artists Corporation is expanding its television business through the purchase of Ziv Television Programs, Inc. The transaction involves $6,750,000.
Adoption experts yesterday generally disclaimed any policy of trying to match the I.Q.'s of parent and child in placing children.

Both the Federal and state governments were called on by the City Council yesterday to establish a $1.25-an-hour minimum wage in business and industry. The Council adopted unanimously two resolutions making the requests to Washington and Albany.
American Export Lines announced yesterday the schedules for ten cargo liner voyages to be made this year in its St. Lawrence Seaway and Great Lakes service.

THE cocktail party was being given to introduce a new novel by a promising young writer. Two men who did not know each other were making conversation. "Tell me," asked one, "since you seem to know something about it, is publishing an occupation for gentlemen or is it a real business?"

Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz approved yesterday a compromise of the Petroleum Research Fund case worked out to prevent "protracted and expensive litigation whose result could not be predicted."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today issued a report on foreign private investment in underdeveloped countries in which he noted that the United States, Japan and Western Germany provided insurance for such investments against non-business risks.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson called an end to around-the-clock Senate sessions tonight.

ALFRED SHEINWOLD, bridge author and columnist, flew to Las Vegas yesterday to direct a different kind of card tournament -- the fourth annual gin-rummy tournament sponsored by eleven Las Vegas hotels for that city's hospitals and some other community benefits.
HARTFORD, March 8 (AP) -- Approval of rate increases for the Connecticut Blue Cross, effective July 1, was announced today by Insurance Commissioner Alfred N. Premo.
HAVING selected an enchanted fable, Frank Loesser and his associates have had the taste to preserve its humors and sweetness.
What keeps flowers fresh and chic though they have been on view for four days at the international show? Patient attention and the 68-degree temperatures maintained at the Coliseum.
ALBANY, March 8 -- Senator John H. Cooke's omnibus banking bill was approved today by both the Senate and Assembly committees on banking.

Following is the text of one of two almost identical resolutions calling for a $1.25 on hour minimum wage adopted unanimously yesterday by the City Council. One resolution was directed to the Federal and the other to the state government.

DETROIT, March 8 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings gained their first home decision over the Montreal Canadiens in nearly three years tonight, beating the Canadiens by 3 -- 0. Terry Sawchuk tied for second place in National Hockey League shutouts.

OLDSMAR, Fla., March 8 -- The coziest cavalry post on racing's so-called leaky-roof circuit is a track that was dropped amid the palmettos, scrub palms, swamps and rattlesnakes on the fringe of this metropolis some thirty-odd years ago. It is named Sunshine Park and it is here that Jimmy Pitt trains most of his horses.
MANCHESTER, N.H., March 8 -- Vice President Nixon learned in New Hampshire today that it is actually possible to "lose" an uncontested election.

Winners of thirty-two awards were named yesterday by the Ford Foundation. The grants will "assist talented persons from several branches of the arts to deepen their experience in the legitimate and lyric theatre."

A group of young men, who must be as sturdy as the proverbial March lion, have consented to become fashion arbiters for an hour or so. They will serve as judges at a luncheon and fashion show to be given at the Sheraton-East on March 23 by students and alumnae of Finch College.

The Lever Brothers Company, noted for such products as Lux, Lifebuoy, Lucky Whip, Rinso, Pepsodent and other products, turned in the highest sales and earnings in its history in 1959. The annual report was issued yesterday to the company's 7,500 employes by Milton C. Mumford, president and chief executive officer and William H. Burkhart, chairman.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Within the last two weeks the economic views of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. have been criticized on your editorial page twice (Feb. 17 and 23).

If you get a busy signal at Circle 5-1540 this week, be patient and dial again. It's the telephone number of the Eastern College Athletic Conference and that hydra-headed organization is snowed under right now by the administrative details of simultaneously conducting five major championship meets and tournaments in five different sports at five different sites this week-end.

A petition was filed yesterday asking for an investigation of the role of local bar associations in the failure of Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney to win reappointment. The petition went before the Judicial Conference of the State of New York.
The jet plane needs a good deal more than a longer runway to stay in business.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Democrats teamed up in the Senate today in charging that President Eisenhower lacked leadership in world affairs.
General Motors Acceptance Corporation sold $100,000,000 of 5 per cent twenty-one year debentures yesterday at an interest cost of about 5.11 per cent.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- Movie production was almost negligible here today as the actors' strike against seven of the eight major movie studios went into its second day.

ALBANY, March 8 -- A full-scale Democratic revolt against Mayor Wagner's party leadership erupted in the Legislature today over proposed World's Fair legislation. The uprising was prompted by a series of proposed amendments drafted at the request of Robert Moses and approved by the Mayor.
Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State, was named yesterday to receive the Page One Award in Public Affairs of the New York Newspaper Guild.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 8 (UPI) -- The American League today announced the adoption of a new suspended-game rule after a meeting between Joe Cronin, the league president, and his umpiring staff.
JERSEY CITY, March 8 -- A baby adoption racket, in which infants were sold to childless couples for $3,000 each, was broken up today.
STUART, Fla., March 8 -- Anglers in both fresh and salt water have been living in pain for a week or more here, but now, they say, they are about to get well. The weather is mending.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce elected itself an outspoken, hard-sell president today. He is Arthur H. Motley, known to all as "Red."

The State Senate has done it again. For the second time in two years it has passed a bill establishing a year's residence within New York as a prerequisite (except for a thirty-day emergency period) for state-aided home relief. "It will close our borders to the chiseling free-loader," stoutly says Senator John H. Cooke of Erie County, sponsor of this anachronistic, useless and inhumane measure.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Air Force told a House panel today that the President should have power to take over private air transportation in emergencies as well as in war.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 8 -- There are indications that Bulgaria is entertaining the idea of reopening a window to the West.
Cardinal Spellman deplored last night recent attacks in an Air Force manual on the loyalty of some United States churches and clergymen.
CHICAGO, March 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Two contractors on a Federal construction project disclaimed today any hiring policy -- past, present and future -- that discriminated against Negroes.
BERLIN, Conn., March 8 -- A woman and seven school children were killed about 8:40 A.M. today when their station wagon was struck by a New Haven Railroad train at an unguarded crossing.
Record sales and earnings were achieved last year by Charles Bruning Company, Inc., manufacturers of copy reproduction machines, sensitized papers and allied products.
United States Government securities led the bond market in another material rise in prices yesterday.
A total of 661 persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was 192 fewer than in the comparable 1959 period.

MOSCOW, March 8 -- Soviet men mobbed stores today in a wild scramble for paper flowers, cut-glass ashtrays, perfume and candies. It was Women's Day -- no day for even the sturdiest of women to buck the retail scrimmage lines.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) -- The House Banking Committee approved a billion-dollar housing bill today despite Republican protests that it called for unnecessary and irresponsible Government spending.

WANTED: 8,000 housewives in New York area for job of national importance. Must have strong leys (on feet eight hours a day, some overtime), ability to keep secrets, steady, tireless writing hand. Must pass test, including examination on map reading.
Top-seeded Ed Harding of the Harvard Club led the way into the quarter-final round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C singles championships yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, March 8 -- A recently formed political group, the Swatantra (Freedom) party, has sharply attacked Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's socialistic policies. The group was constituted last June to provide an alternative platform to that of the Congress party.
Two deteriorating West Side rooming houses were selected by the City Housing Authority yesterday as the first target for its rehabilitation program in the area.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 9 -- A tenants' group won a court victory today in a dispute with the management of a large garden type of apartment development in near-by Norwalk.
BONN, Germany, March 9 -- The Federal Government resorted to its taxing power today to slow West Germany's economic boom.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- Two brothers, publishers of The Trade Union Courier, were fined a total of $25,000 today because they continued unauthorized solicitation, of advertisements from business men in defiance of an order of the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 9 (AP) -- Albert Camplese, 32, a sales j man from Ashtabula, Ohio, today, came within twenty pins of overtaking Phil Caporusso in the all-events division of the; American Bowling Congress tournament. The seventy-nine-day tourney opened last weekend.

Several years ago the great novelty in the city was the frozen malted-the drink one ate with a spoon. Early next week the third issue of a new magazine will be on the stands. It is a magazine one "reads" with his ear.
Cartoon motion-picture techniques have made possible a new X-ray system for studying bone growth.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Eisenhower hopes to visit Lisbon on the way back to the United States after the East-West summit meeting in Paris beginning May 16.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- The United States Japan Trade Council told the Tariff Commission today that arguments in favor of an extra duty of 8 cents a pound on cotton textile imports were either unimpressive and exaggerated or false and spurious.
The Tampa Electric Company reported yesterday operating revenues of $36,209,192 for 1959, against $31,826,653 in 1958. Net income of $5,605,004 was equal to 98 cents a share.

Touched by the wistful photograph of a young Chinese-American who had come to this country from Communist China but had been repudiated by his American father, a New York couple has offered the youth a home and an education.

The Universal Pictures Company, Inc., made a sharp recovery in its operations in the first and second quarters of this fiscal year, Milton R. Rackmil, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting held here yesterday.
BONN, Germany, March 9 -- West German officials put the best face tonight on their public reaction to President Eisenhower's decision not to resume high-altitude flights to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- Senator Richard L. Neuberger was mourned today in the Senate and political arena by Democrats and Republicans alike. He was hailed as an able, courageous and warm-hearted legislator.
BUENOS AIRES, March 9 -- President Frondizi today officially opened the 927-mile oil pipeline that links the northern Campo Duran oilfields with the Sen Lorenzo refinery on the Parana River.

The report of J. Anthony Panuch as special adviser to Mayor Wagner on housing has been awaited with great interest. It is now delivered and lives up handsomely to high expectations. The 112-page document is, by way of inventory, a kind of Baedeker to the maze of interrelationships of people and agencies that deal with myriad housing problems in New York City.
LONDON. BRITONS had their first opportunity last week to at a typical American home of the "junior executive" range.
The Federal Government has notified officials of the Port of New York that it plans to stop the storage of grain in mothball ships of the Reserve Fleet.
BOSTON, March 9 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics set a National Basketball Association record for games won in a season tonight while routing the New York Knickerbockers, 148-128, before 3,921 fans.

Believing that it has become increasingly difficult for new writers to obtain a hearing in New York, Studio Three, a non-profit group headed by Marshall Young and John Larry Washburn, last night began a project designed to remedy the situation.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that the Administration had not considered breaking off diplomatic relations with Cuba. But, he said,, circumstances might arise to make this necessary.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has ordered new standards of taste and timing for commercials on network television shows.

Coastal States Gas Producing Company debentures, with attached warrants, valued at $20,000,000, were offered to the public yesterday by investment bankers led by Paine. Webber, Jackson Curtia and Blair Co., Inc.
LA CROSSE, Wis., March 9 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today his strong showing in the New Hampshire primary would be a "terrific help" in the crucial Wisconsin vote April 5.

Electric power production rose to a five-week high of 14,262,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday, according to the Edison Electric Institute. A week before the figure was 14,092,000,000 kilowatt-hours and in the comparable 1959 period it was 12,945,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

PIANO duet playing is the most intimate form of music-making there is. The players sit thigh to thigh and hand to hand, in utmost danger of being pinked by a flying fingernail or pushed completely off the bench by an overenthusiastic hip.
New York set a record last year for conventions of business and professional organizations.
LONDON, March 9 -- Princess Margaret will marry Antony Armstrong-Jones in Westminster Abbey May 6.
ROME, March 9 -- Premier Antonio Segni, who resigned two weeks ago, undertook conditionally today to endeavor to form a new Cabinet.
EVERY spring it seems as if the potters of the world open their ovens wide, and out come the vases, bowls and jugs ready to hold the season's first blossoms.
CHICAGO, March 9 -- There has been too much scare talk about growing foreign competition for trade, Edwin D. Canham, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said here today.

The Sounds of Civilization The report that a carillon is being installed at Pearl Harbor in memory of the men who died on the Arizona on that "day of infamy" eighteen years ago adds another note to our growing awareness of the sounds of civilization.
A committee seeking a longterm formula for eliminating steel strikes began yesterday to explore ways of giving workers as much information about their companies as directors get.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 9 -- The Marine Midland Corporation, New York's only state-wide banking company, gives its stockholders "very full" disclosure of important financial information, Baldwin Maull, president, told the annual meeting here today.
ATLANTA, March 9 -- A decision on when Atlanta schools must begin desegregation was postponed today until May in Federal District Court.
HAVANA, March 9 -- The Cuban press and radio exploded today in the most scathing attack on the United States Government of the last few months.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 9 -- President Sukarno was unscathed but eighteen others were injured in attacks by an Indonesian jet plane today on the presidential palace and Jakarta's port area.
The report J. Anthony Panuch submitted to Mayor Wagner yesterday was one of the most unusual literary productions dropped in the City Hall bin in years.
The city's Superintendent of Schools played hooky yesterday morning to visit the children's exhibit area of the Interntional Flower Show at the Collseum.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The House of Representatives squared away today for what promised to be the decisive stage of the civil rights battle.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The Assembly narrowly defeated today a bill that would have modified the capital punishment laws of the state.
TORONTO, March 9 (UPI) -- Led by Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion's three goals, the National Hockey League-leading Montreal Canadiens defeated the second place Toronto Maple Leafs, 9 -- 4, tonight.

The copper Industry, tarnished somewhat by long strikes last year, has a bright outlook for 1960, but faces an excess of world production capacity in the next three to five years. That prediction Was made by Robert G. Pages, president of Phelps Dodge Corporation, in the company's annual report, released yesterday.
Magistrate Morton Tolleris issued two warrants yesterday for the arrest of a landlord whose attorney said he had obtained a promise that his client would not be prosecuted.
BOWIE, Md., March 9 (UPI) -- Arlington Stable's Bright Gem, leading most of the way, won the feature today in Bowie's first racing program since snow interrupted the meeting last Thursday.

IT was the turn of the French last night. The Lamoureux Orchestra from Paris, making its first New York appearance at Carnegie Hall, waved the banner proudly for France in a program of French music.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 9 -- A group of Israeli archaeologists has discovered a letter from a debt-ridden peasant of Jedah that they believe was written on a piece of an earthen pot about twenty-seven centuries ago.

The State of California borrowed $100,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction of government buildings and loans to war veterans acquiring homes or farms. The money was raised on serial bonds running out to 1986 at interest costs ranging from 3.9447 to 3.9524 per cent.

A theatre party at the New York premiere of the Soviet film, "The Cranes Are Flying," at the Fine Arts Theatre on the evening of March 21 and a party afterward in the Terrace Room of the Plaza will aid the Near East Foundation, 54 East Sixty-fourth Street.
The Bronx Democratic organization designated City Court Justice Hyman Korn yesterday to run for County Court. He will seek the seat Judge Samuel J. Joseph is vacating because of age.
KABUL, Afghanistan, March 4 -- A cautious competition of culture and words is in progress here between the United States and the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- The House of Representatives approvede today a bill to authorize appropriation of $915,000,000 for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the 1961 fiscal year, which begins next July.
