David B. Solove, realty investor, has purchased the five-story building containing twenty-tour apartments at 927 Grant Avenue in the Bronx. Rubin Solove was the broker. The building is on a plot of 115 by 49 feet.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 9 (UPI) -- The National Association of Basketball Coaches today put Oscar Robertson of Cincinnati at the head of its all-America team for the second year in a row.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday he was "willing to accept fundamental features" of fiscal proposals by a state commission that he had harshly criticized in the past. The State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York in turn agreed that modifications he suggested could be fitted into its plan.
Starting today an airline may not serve an alcoholic drink to a tipsy passenger; and a passenger -- tipsy or sober -- may not swig from his own bottle. So says a new Federal air regulation.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- A wheat certificate bill was introduced in the House today by Representative J. Floyd Breeding, Democrat of Kansas, and several other House members.
THE GOVERNOR Received twenty foreign government workers who are touring country under auspices of International Cooperation Administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9 -- Events of the last decade suggest strongly that the phrase "dry as the Sahara," valid for centuries as a, simile, will have become invalid by 1980 or earlier. In short, not all the gushers in the great African desert are spouting oil.
MORTON SYLVAN ROBSON, the man who is prosecuting Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. on charges of income tax evasion, would probably not fit the bill for a Hollywood courtroom scene.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 9 -- Forces for abolishing the death penalty in California made their big pitch today.
Prices of cotton future on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) up to 6 points (30 cents) off yesterday.

TORONTO, March 9 -- One of the peculiarities of the American television executive is to sit dejectedly in the bar car on the run from New York to Old Greenwich, Conn., and think his problems are unusua.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: During Day Care Week we ask citizens to give a share of their attention to the needs of the children of migrant farm workers.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- A revival of general buying imparted strength to the grain futures market today, and most contracts finished strong.

After seven successive days of declines, stocks staged a technical rally yesterday. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange rose $3,100,000,000 or 1.1 per cent, enough to cover Tuesday's loss with a little to spare.

YESTERDAY (March 9, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Saw Dr. Raymond Saulnier, chairman of Council of Economic Advisers; Gordon Gray, special assistant for national security, and Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.
NEW DELHI, India, March 9 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today it was not true that India had agreed to accept Soviet help in building a nuclear power station.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 9 (AP) -- L. B. Sullivan, Police Commissioner here, said today:
BECAUSE of its partnership aspect, bridge is traditionally a married couple's game. The typical game occurs when the Smiths have the Browns to dinner and play bridge afterward, family against family.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your lead editorial of Feb. 23 on the status of Puerto Rico is misleading and far from the reality.
The State Commission Against Discrimination has ordered Capital Airlines, which serves many of the major Southern cities, to abandon a policy of barring Negroes from flying jobs.

UNITED NATIONs, N. y., March 9 -- Diplomatic sources said today that the question of a United Nations "presence" in Berlin would be brought up again Monday when Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany and Secretary Dag Hammarskjold are scheduled to meet at the Waldorf-Astotia.
GENEVA, March 9 -- The Soviet Union contended today that no on-site inspection would be required under a treaty that did not ban all testing of nuclear weapons.

The northeast corner of Third Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, a plot fronting seventy-five fee on the avenue and 145 feet on the street, has been purchased by the Almid Realty Corporation for improvement with an eighteen-story office building.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- While all about them were losing sleep in battle against the Southern filibuster, most of the Senate's Democratic Presidential candidates had scarcely an interruption in their nightly dreams of glory.

Final arrangements are being made for a card party for the benefit of the Student Nurses Scholarship Fund, Department of Nursing, Columbia University. The fete will be given in Maxwell Hall, 179 Fort Washington Avenue, next Wednesday.
LONDON, March 9 -- The decline in stock market prices continued and broadened here today and the dullness was virtually unrelieved.
NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania, March 9 -- Premier Moktar Ould Daddah said today Mauritania would remain in the French Community despite pressures from Morocco and the Mali Federation.

WE should all walk quietly when we enter the world of Francoise Sagan's new novel, "Aimez-vous Brahms . ." The people in it are terribly tired. They need rest from work, rest from play, rest from one another's importunities and the superbly lacquered banality of the plot.
The nation's oldest post-season college basketball tourney, the National Invitation Tournament, opens tonight in Madison Square Garden.
Harry Markson, the managing director of the Garden Boxing Club, yesterday said that Don Jordan would defend his world welterweight championship at Las Vegas, Nev., May 27.
A man described by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan as "the largest producer and purveyor of pornographic material in the United States" was arrested here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Following is the transcript Secretary of State Christian Herter's news conference today as released by the State Department:

DALLAS, March 9 (UPI) -- Commissioner Joe Foss of the new American Football League said today the National Football League's expansion into Dallas was being studied by the Department of Justice for possible antitrust action.

The annual benefit bridge party of the Women's Auxiliary of the French Hospital will be held in the Trianon Room of the Sheraton-East on the afternoon of April 4. Mrs. J. Harvey McCoy and Mrs. Evariste Orteig are co-chairmen for the event.
PARIS, March 9 -- Western diplomats indicated tonight that general agreement on a Western disarmament plan was within sight.

Barry Controls The backlog of Barry Controls, Inc. continues slightly greater than that of $1,500,000 at the end of 1959, Ervin Pietz, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Watertown, Mass., yesterday.

Officers and directors of major corporations tended to be sellers rather than buyers of their companies' stocks, according to the latest insiders' lists published yesterday by the New York and American stock exchanges. For example, two officers of the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company made substantial reductions in their holdings.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 9 -- A plan to hasten the development of the European Common Market will probably be put aside for further study at the request of France.

Democratic Governors of ten states of the Midwest and Northwest have formed what is described as a new form of farm bloc to spearhead its own program of farm legislation. The Governors have adopted a credo which declares: "We call upon Congress to enact without delay a comprehensive agricultural program to give the American farm family equality of economic opportunity."
MOSCOW, March 9 -- The foreign trade of the Soviet Union was represented today as growing much faster than that of capitalist nations.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A bill to set up an Office of International Medical Research under the Department of Health, Education and Welfare was voted unanimously today by a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee.
PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- The Committee of Seventy, a nonpartisan group that keeps watch on municipal government, sought today a special grand jury investigation of vote frauds here.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- New Hampshire has spoken -- with about one-third of its small electoral voice -- and now begins again a leap year of political claims, counter-claims, death sentences and reprieves. These judgments will be confidently asserted by candidates, their campaign managers, oracles without benefit of the printing press or the airwaves and political reporters with access to both.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- "Well, what do you know?" said Stan Musial, not quite believing what he saw. He was watching movies late last season and it was not one of Hollywood's productions that left him gasping. It was an up-to-the-minute film record of Stan Musial swinging a bat.
CONCORD, N. H., March 9 -- Senator John F. Kennedy emerged, today from the New Hampshire primary with the endorsement of 42,969 Democrats who hope to see him win the Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Politicians rated Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts today as the big winner nationally from yesterday's preferential primary in New Hampshire.

TRENTON, March 9 (AP) -- The New Jersey Bar Association wants the state Supreme Court to rule that title companies cannot prepare bonds, mortgages and other papers involved in mortgage loans and real estate transactions.

In an address permeated with the spirit that created the miracle of modern Israel, Premier Ben-Gurion has warned again that the situation in the Middle East remains precarious and that Israel in particular is still beleaguered and its independence still in danger. He spoke at Brandeis University yesterday on receiving an honorary degree, of Doctor of Laws, and his warning is squarely in line with the patent facts.

Joseph P. Storey of Cleveland probably could give the "What's My Line?" television panel a difficult time because only three other men in the country do what he does. He is a former professional handler who attends dog shows regularly and gets paid for it, but never shows a dog or wears a badge.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company achieved, for the quarter ended on Jan. 31, the highest sales for any first three months in its history, according to the report of Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman, and Raymond C. Firestone, president.

Potato futures climbed sharply yesterday in active trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The inactive November position was unchanged but the other months rose 14 to 16 points (hundreds of a cent a pound). The volume was 3,193 car lots, 50,000 pounds to a car, the second largest of the year.
Southern Governors declared states of emergency and Midwest towns were paralyzed yesterday in a new, record-breaking March snowstorm.
OLD BRIDGE, N.J., March 9 -- Twenty-six-year-old Mrs. Richard Combs leaned uncertainly against the pine-paneled wall of her trim little kitchen.

TRENTON, March 9 -- A group of top New Jersey officials will go to New York tomorrow to make a major bid to get the wholesale produce business concerns now operating in Washington Market to move to their state.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The White House is scrutinizing the conduct of John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, in accepting a broadcaster's hospitality during a Florida vacation last month.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower named today the three members of an emergency board to investigate a dispute between the New York Central Railroad and its brakemen and conductors.
DETROIT, March 9 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons rallied in the final minutes and beat the Minneapolis Lakers, 117 -- 116, tonight.
ALBANY, March 9 (AP) -- The bridge being built between Brooklyn and Staten Island will be called the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, like it or not.

Although the Olympic Winter Games have been over for more than a week, forty top European stars have been lingering at Stowe, Vt., to take part in an international ski meet at the Green. Mountain resort starting tomorrow.

STUART, Fla., March 9 -- It is hard to decide whether to think about how Sally Johns handles a boat for two bass fishermen or how to fish those blasted plastic worms. It is probably better to think about Mrs. Johns.

David Rosen, who was the director of the department of conservation and technical research of the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore from 1934 to 1954, died Tuesday in his home here at 112 East Tenth Street after a short illness.

LAST Saint Patrick's Day when Margaret Burke of County Roscommon, Ireland, awakened in New York she got the surprise of her life. Her hostess, a Fifth Avenue matron, waltzed into the room with green ribbons billowing from a couple of green chrysanthemums pinned to her bosom.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 9 -- A University of Minnesota physics major hung to an impatient balloon early today until, at a shouted command, he let it soar toward the fringes of space.

The nation's gasoline stocks set another record last week according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 3,315,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday brought supplies to a record 218,930,000 barrels.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 8 -- An incident that went almost unnoticed on the United States mainland is causing heated discussion in Puerto Rican political circles. It was yesterday's trip to Washington in President Eisenhower's plane by Luis A. Ferre, the Opposition candidate for Governor of Puerto Rico in next November's election.
Robert Moses has decided to remove himself from the city's housing program. He apparently made the decision some time before he was asked to become president of the World's Fair Corporation.
State legislation to authorize the use of Flushing Meadow Park for the 1964 World's Fair ran into fresh snags yesterday in both New York and Albany.

Dr. James J. O'Leary of the Life Insurance Association of America predicted yesterday that residential mortgage money would be more easily available this year than anticipated a few months ago, but said that it was unlikely that mortgage rates would decline.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 9 -- Senator Richard L. Neuberger died today, eight hours after he had suffered a cerebral hemorrhage at his home.

Leslie B. Bain, author of "The War of Confusion" and "Chaos or Peace," was one of few American newsmen in Budapest during the Hungarian revolution of 1956. He has written a report on conditions in Central Europe before and during the revolt.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 9 -- A survey of industry in Bergen County indicates that every third person engaged in manufacturing is employed in the transportation equipment field, such as automobile and aircraft parts, the County Planning Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- President Eisenhower has ruled out high-altitude flights to Berlin by United States planes for the time being.
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department at Agriculture follows:

WALTHAM, Mass., March 9 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel stressed today that the future of his nation would not depend on physical expansion but rather on the enhancement of its spiritual and scientific resources.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- The possibility that a compromise might be found to end the strike of actors against major movie studios was seen today as the union and studios agreed to hold the first of a series of meetings here on Friday.

FOR more years than educators care to count, the I. Q. (intelligence quotient) rating, now Exhibit A in a bitter custody fight in New Jersey courts, has been causing trouble for parents, educators ... am children.
ALBANY, March 9 -- A plan to insure the public character of grand jury presentments was laid before the Legislature today.

Ken Strong, a former all-America football player at New York University and a star professional with the New York Giants, was named head of a selection committee yesterday to pick the college elevens that will play in New York's first Gotham Bowl game on Dec. 10.
ALBANY, March 9 (UPI) -- The following ski conditions were reported today to the New York State Department of Commerce:
Carol Heiss, bright and smiling, was driven up Broadway yesterday to the muted sound of clapping gloves.
Jack McCartan, the goalie for the United States' Olympic hockey champions, offered new evidence last night at Madison Square Garden that he was National Hockey League timber.

Consent judgments were signed in Federal Court here yesterday ending the Government's civil antitrust suit against thirteen of twenty-three defendants accused of attempting to restrict the manufacture of watches in this country.
CHICAGO, March 9 -- Colleges and universities were urged today to discard some courses and programs that clog the curriculum.
Nineteen members of an exclusive club, who are selected because they are medical "blue bloods," held a solemn rite last night.

HAVANA. THE immediate impression of a visitor in Havana is that the scarcest commodity on this lush green island is the relaxed rich tourist. Shops, expensive restaurants and de luxe hotels, once sustained by American tourists, look as though a mysterious evacuation had swept away everybody but the bored waiters and clerks who stand poised, ready for the customers who do not come.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The House Education and Labor Committee approved today the first ten of eleven titles of a school construction bill that would provide $325,000,000 for classrooms for each of three years.

United States Government securities continued to advance in price yesterday, but at a rate visibly behind that of the week's earlier trading sessions. Dealers were less inclined to bid for issues at the elevated price levels engendered by successive price gains each day.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt visited the Food Trades High School yesterday and found its equipment and surroundings "deplorable."

Dr. James T. Shotwell, historian and diplomat, was cited yesterday as "still a young professor" in his eighty-sixth year at a luncheon in his honor at the Carnegie Endowment International Center, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.
CAIRO, March 4 -- Industrial development in the United Arab Republic has progressed to such an extent that the Government plans to give it an increasingly important role in international relations.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for a comparatively easy-to-prepare main dish.

PARIS, March 9 -- The Communist-dominated labor unions in the Paris Region have distributed tens of thousands of tracts in the last few days calling on French workers to greet Premier Khrushchev next week.

MANHATTAN, Kan., March 9 (UPI) -- Two sophomores, Wayne High tower and Jerry Gardner, led Kansas to an 84-82 overtime victory over Kansas State tonight and a berth in the Midwest regional tournament of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

THE concrete facts known about the peoples who inhabited archaic Japan are the sculptures they left behind them. At the Asia House, 112 East Sixty-fourth Street, fifty-five rare clay sculptures ranging from about 5,000 B.C. to 600 A.D. offer not only a great deal of information about life in ancient Japan but also the first comprehensive view of Haniwa as an artistic style.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Will Ye, the lightly regarded half of the Del Carroll-trained entry, defeated Vox Pop by a neck in the $10,000-added Hutcheson Handicap at Gulfstream Park today. Run for Nurse was third in the blanket finish, a nose behind Vox Pop.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today denied thirty Federal agencies the right to classify information, as secret. But he gave this privilege to eight other agencies, some of which already had such authority through predecessor agencies.
ALBANY, March 9 -- Support for the Wilson proposal designed as a compromise to the relief residency bill came today from the Legislative Commission, of the New York State Council of Churches.
Sales of the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries in 1959 exceeded $1,000,000,000 for the first time, according to a report issued for publication today.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the House today agreed to consider a civil rights bill:

STUART, Fla., March 10 -- Most of Herbert Krapp's personally trained black bass in the South Fork of the St. Lucie River are sulking right now, or using their training against their benefactor. But if he can't get any action out of them, nobody else can either.
Carnations these days are wearing unusual colors, including gray, cocoa, tangerine and champagne.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 10 -- Bulgaria is trying to induce Greece and Turkey to relax their tough policies toward her.
Boys High and Columbus, playing below top form, were good enough yesterday to advance to the semi-finals of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament.
The Treasury is unhappy about a practice that has grown up in connection with the maturing of tax anticipation bills, officials of the department disclosed yesterday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Unusually bad weather throughout much of the Eastern part of the nation resulted in decreased freight loadings at many points last week. Both rail and truck freight was markedly behind 1959 levels, while rail freight was slightly above -- and truck loadings slightly below -- levels of the preceding week of this year.
A SUBWAY to Macy's beats a jet to Paris -- for a quick but sweeping view of last month's French collections.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- Two Senators urged Congress today to provide free television time to Presidential nominees.
A suburbanite has been having some trouble with the circulation department of The Farm Journal. In the process an interesting magazine policy has come to light.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The six-year labor dispute, between the Kohler Plumbing Fixture Company of Wisconsin and the United Auto Workers got a new hearing today.
Mayor Wagner and Park Commissioner Robert Moses reached an agreement in principle yesterday on changes in World's Fair legislation pending at Albany.

A spring dance to be held March 19 at the National Arts Club in the old Samuel Tilden Mansion at 15 Gramercy Park South will benefit the scholarship fund established by the club's younger members committee to assist young people in the field of the creative arts.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning to offer for sale $20,470,000 of serial bonds. Proceeds would finance permanently the development of projects subsidized by tax forgiveness by the city government. It is planned to take bids on the issue on April 27.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 10 (AP) -- The chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Banking Laws declared today that he was opposed to an extension of the freeze on formation of new bank holding companies.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Cuba spent $120,000,000 of her scarce foreign exchange during 1959 for military supplies, according to estimates received in Washington today from informed sources in Havana.

Just what part does institutional buying play in the stock market? Yesterday the New York Stock Exchange provided an answer. Institutions owned about $51,000,000,000 of the $307,700,000,000 of Big Board stocks at the 1959 year end, or 16.6 per cent.

The Dynamics Corporation of America is extending its activities abroad with the acquisition of Winston Electronics, Ltd., manufacturer of military, commercial and medical electronic equipment at Shepperton, England.
PARIS, March 10 -- President de Gaulle's supporters on the political Left and Center are showing signs of disillusionment as a result of his failure to end the Algerian war quickly.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 -- Harvard's Bob Kaufmann and Yale's Bill Chase stole the spotlight as the twentieth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League individual championships got under way in the Harvard pool today.
The Appellate Division provided a novel device yesterday to safeguard the right of union members to check on alleged election irregularities without violating confidential union membership lists.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Advocates of a broad civil rights bill were badly trounced today when a Senate majority over-rode their petition to cut off debate and start voting.

Eighteen trustees of the Greenwich Savings Bank have joined in an effort to oust a nineteenth because, they say, his "insobriety, intemperate and irresponsible conduct" threatened the bank with "irreparable damage."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Congressman Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn threatens to launch an investigation of the Port of New York Authority. He has also introduced a resolution designed to put the authority under the thumb of Congress. The Citizens Union believes that the Congressman is straying from his proper field of activity.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The nation's active money supply drifted downward again hi February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This was the third consecutive monthly decline, and the biggest of the three.
LONDON, March 10 -- The Czechoslovak Ambassador went fishing today in the troubled waters of British-German relations.

The Overseas Press Club announced yesterday the winners of its annual awards and citations for excellence in foreign reporting and interpretation of foreign news in 1959. The awards were made in eleven categories.

The resignation of John C. Doerfer as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission is to be welcomed. The immediate reason for the resignation was Mr. Doerfer's recent acceptance of substantial hospitality on the yacht and plane of George B. Storer, head of a corporation which holds Federal licenses -- subject to F.C.C. supervision and periodic renewal -- for five television and seven radio stations.
OUT of commonplace materials, Patricia Joudry has written a commonplace drama.
Great Britain and Italy have joined a Scandinavian bloc of shipping nations protesting a Federal grand jury investigation into the practicies of their steamship lines.
Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., will go into the Madison Square Garden ring tonight as an underdog against Emile Griffith, a New York welter-weight.

Two Government witnesses from abroad testified yesterday at the trial of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. on charges or preparing fraudulent income tax returns on money his wife, Hazel Scott, earned in a concert tour of Europe in 1951.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner were reported near agreement yesterday on a program that would increase state aid to New York City by $25,000,000 to $30,000,000 a year.
CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- A large volume of delivery notices on March wheat futures contracts set off brisk selling of the old crop months here today and prices sagged fairly sharply.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The fiscal relationships existing between New York City and New York State are so complex that the adjustment of inequities must in some cases be left to the experts. But in certain areas of state responsibility the city has a pretty clear case on which to bring a charge of discrimination.
YESTERDAY (March 10, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Had breakfast meeting with Republican legislative leaders. Proclaimed April as Cancer Month. Greeted E.R. Vadeboncoeur, president of State Cancer Society.

The March and May potato positions climbed to a new high for the lives of the contracts, and April equaled the old high yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The volume, 4,491 car lots (50,000 pounds to a car), was the heaviest since trading began in 1941.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 10 (AP) -- The widow of Senator Richard L. Neuberger announced today that she would seek her husband's Senate seat.

PARIS, March 10 -- The Western powers agreed today on a revised general disarmament plan that gives heightened priority to studying the problems of nuclear disarmament.

Gerosa and the State Commission on Governmental Operations of the City of New York, headed by Frank C. Moore.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 10 -- The thermometer at Roosevelt Raceway read 27 degrees at 9:27 this morning. The sun had not yet appeared and In the heavy gray skies there was a threat of snow.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Dr. John A. Hannah, chairman of the Civil Rights Commission, has protested what he calls "abusive treatment" of a commission staff member during secret questioning by staff workers of the Senate Permanent Investigating Subcommittee.
Something new in packaging, canned annual reports, were mailed to more than 96,000 stockholders of the American Can Company this week.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Alien Geiberger, who joined the professional golf tour only last January, took the first-round lead in the Pensacola open today with an 8-under-par 64.

UNTIL a few days ago I thought that I had read a historical novel about every section of the American frontier from Plymouth Rock to the Golden Gate. Hundreds of poor ones, dozens of competent ones, a few splendid ones such as the best of Conrad Richter, A. B. Guthrie Jr. and Elizabeth Maddox Roberts.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Republican legislators lined up today behind one of their colleagues to defend him against a purge by the Suffolk County chairman.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower tonight praised Representative Charles A. Halleck as a "top-flight tough, fighting little Hoosier" who put his country's interest first in Congress.

Visitors this week to the Long Island Boat and Sportsmen's Show at Jamaica are handling, studying and planning how to use a new gimmick for outboard craft. It is a variable-propeller. One of them is especially for a trolling fisherman.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad assured a Congressional committee today that there were no plans to turn over United States atomic warheads to a newly proposed brigade within the North Atlantic Treaty Command.
ROME, March 10 -- Premier-designate Antonio Segni moved fast today to form a new Government and end the Italian Cabinet crisis, now more than two weeks old.
LONDON, March 10 -- Prime Minister Macmillan announced today that the Government was planning a major reorganization of the nationalized railroad system to put it on a more ecoomical basis.
OLD BRIDGE, N.J., March 10 -- Alice Marie continued to be the center of attraction in her home community today.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y. -- The Westchester County American Legion protested last night against "Left-Wing leaders in the mental health field" who address Parent-Teacher Associations and other school groups.

LIKE sun after a snowstorm, the pineapple makes a welcome appearance in many stores this week-end. While most food prices are suffering from the cold, large pineapples may be purchased for the very reasonable price of 29 cents each.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- A meeting that the movie industry hopes may be a turning point in the actors strike is scheduled to be held here tomorrow.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 -- Alas, poor Adlai: even this arsenal of political ideas, once his impregnable stronghold, is slipping away to Senator John F. Kennedy!
Federal and state housing officials yesterday warmly endorsed the basic aims of J. Anthony Panuch's plan to consolidate and invigorate the city's housing and urban renewal programs.

The first combined Oxford-Cambridge squash racquets team to come to this country arrived here on two flights from London yesterday for an American tour.

David Sarnoff, chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, proposed last night that broadcasters exchange ideas about television with leaders in other fields at closed annual conferences.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Two labor leaders said today that Canadian authorities discriminate against American pilots who attempt to take ocean-going vessels through Canadian sections of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

Titles to the Biscayne Apartments on Sixty-seventh Road, between Yellowstone Boulevard and 102d Street, in Forest Hills, Queens, and the Gramercy Apartments on Sixty-fourth Avenue, between 102d and Ninety-ninth Streets, in the same community, have been taken by a syndicate sponsored by Hanover Associates, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- Following are the texts of letters exchanged today between President Eisenhower and John C. Doerfer, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, on Mr. Doerfer's resignation:
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Deep dissatisfaction with the way the nation's space program is being run was expressed today by a key official appointed by President Elsenhower to help run it.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 10 -- Most baseball men agree that Charlie Dressen is one of the best managers in the business, an opinion that is enthusiastically shared by Charlie Dressen himself. The little fire-brand is currently entrusted with the task of Igniting the Milwaukee Braves, a team that hitherto has been about as inflammable as a cement sidewalk.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 3 points (15 cents) up yesterday.

The New York Central Railroad finally is going to try to become a Delaware corporation. Directors of the carrier have approved plans for the move and stockholders will be asked to vote on the proposition at their annual meeting in Albany on May 26.
YESTERDAY (March 10, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Saw Israeli Premier David Ben-Gurion.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 10 -- The California Legislature rejected Gov. Edmund G. Brown's appeal for abolition of the death penalty today. It later adjourned a special session on capital punishment.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel conferred with President Eisenhower today on the prospects for an East-West agreement on the Middle East at the summit conference.

The Kurt Weill -- Bertolt Brecht opera "Mahagonny" will not be performed by the New York Philharmonic under Leonard Bernstein because of difficulties in obtaining the rights for the use of the libretto.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The often rowdy House of Representatives wrapped itself in an unfamiliar toga of dignity and decorum today for the opening of its debate on the civil rights issue.
KABUL, Afghanistan, March 4 -- Despite economic and military dependence upon the Soviet Union, Afghanistan appears to be striving to maintain a neutral foreign policy and her national integrity.

HOUSTON, March 10 (UPI) -- Owners of the Houston Buffs baseball club have reversed themselves and refuse to go along with a tentative agreement to merge with holders of a Continental League franchise.

The Federal Reserve has not changed its monetary policy and has made no significant change in policy emphasis, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. As customary, he made no prediction of future policy action.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Federal Government gave a go-ahead signal today to more vigorous state antitrust action.
The bare austerity of 155 city courtrooms goon will be relieved by inscribing the words "In God We Trust" on the wall behind the judge's bench.
WHAT moves a man to create a new hair style? Is it the weather, the newest waistline or the stock market? Women are usually the last to know.
Contracts have been signed for the sale of three large properties on South Broadway in Yonkers. One of the parcels will be improved with a supermarket and one of the others with a taxpayer.

TEANECK, N.J., March 10 -- A program designed to solve the commuter railroad problem by using funds obtained from passenger automobile tolls has been sent to Gov. Robert B. Meyner by Mayor Matthew Feldman of Teaneck.
TRENTON, March 10 -- New Jersey's primary election on April 19 Will involve Senate races in both major parties and contests for House seats in eight of the state's fourteen Congressional Districts.
WASHINGTON. March 10 -- A House inquiry committee member said today that the American Broadcasting Company had received a 7-cent "royalty" on each "Dick Clark record-carrying case" sold.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed tonight that pension-vesting rights be granted under certain conditions to members of the State Employes Retirement System.

The Right Rev. Hanns Lilje, Latheran Bishop of Hanover, Germany, declared last night that while man had reached new heights in science his religious life had not developed "beyond the horizon of an immature youngster of 15."
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 10 -- The two highest elected officials in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland foresee serious trouble for many new African governments.
WHITE PLAINS, March 10 -- The right of a patrolman to criticize superiors was at issue here today when James P. Bogan was tried for violating departmental rules.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The United States Military Academy will lose a $300,000 bequest by Mary Williams Crozier unless it uses the money to build a memorial hall to her late husband on a site specified in her will, the United States Court of Appeals ruled today.

Jack Klein of 225 East forty sixth Street, founder and president of the Klein Institute for Aptitude Testing at 711 Third Avenue, died Wednesday in Chicago while on a business trip. He was 64 years old.
BATON ROUGE, La., March 10 -- Turner Catledge, managing editor of The New York Times, said today that an "explosion of knowledge" had characterized this generation.

BONN, Germany, March 10 -- The United States Army in Europe has laid down the rule that five years is long enough for its civilian employes to work uninterruptedly abroad. It holds that a restorative tour of duty at home is generally needed to keep up an employe's professional competence.
CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A New York City policeman helped to speed critical medical aid for a 4-month-old baby yesterday by interpreting for her father the only language the father knew -- Chinese.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Air Force leaders promised Congress today that they would, as one put it, "set our house in order" on the subject of training manuals.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- It is clear, from the replies Secretary of State Herter made to news conference questions, that elevating the altitude of flights to Berlin had powerful support in the Administraion. Otherwise another survey would not recently have been made of the "operational necessity" and other "needs" of raising the flying pattern employed during the Berlin airlift of 1948.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 10 (AP) -- Fay Crocker, a South American pro, fired a 75 today at the Augusta Country Club for the first-round lead in the twenty-first Titleholders women's golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A Government survey forecast a strong and continuing upward trend in business spending for expansion and modernization this year, up 14 per cent from last year's figure.
GENEVA, March 10 -- The United States urged the Soviet Union today to overcome its outdated fear of the foreigner for the sake of progress in disarmament.

Postponement, the seasonal hazard of thoroughbred racing, reached out and touched the New York Racing Association yesterday. Although the turf sport is not yet under way here, many preparatory operations are going on and the timetable is tight.
City Council President Abe Stark urged yesterday that the state and city jointly build new recreation centers and subsidize settlement houses and private recreational units.
AN audience of 1,100 assembled at Town Hall last night for the brief program given there by Denise Duval, soprano from the Opera-Comique, and Francis Poulenc, who played her accompaniments.

The president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York challenged yesterday the contention of George Champion, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, that savings and loan associations were operating counter to the Federal Reserve's policy of over-all credit restraint.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Army asked Congree today for $11,400,000 to buy 1,700 lightweight guided missiles that a combat soldier can fire from. his shoulder.
PITTSBURGH, March 10 (AP) -- Spare the rod and spoil the child? Not Bohden Pashkowsky, a teacher at Langley High School here. He paddled thirty boys. Why?
Villanova won by 2 points and Providence triumphed by 1 in the opening-round games of the twenty-third annual National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.
BRUSSELS, Belguim, March 10 -- The project of setting up a mission to Washington to represent the European Economic Community received conditional approval again today.
ALBROOK AIR FORCE BASE, Canal Zone, March 10 -- The first inter-American maneuvers completed their tactical phase late today and may have set a pattern for fixture hemispheric military cooperation.
TRENTON, March 10 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner made it clear today that he would not intervene in the Alice Marie custody case while the matter was before the court.
The city was warned yesterday that it was risking unsafe beaches and higher ultimate costs of correcting the situation by failing to cleanse the waters around New York adequately.

The work of the Child Study Association -- the training of professionals who will be able to instruct parents in proper child rearing -- will be aided by the proceeds from a theatre benefit on April 26. It will be the performance of "Greenwillow" at the Alvin Theatre.

LONDON, March 10 -- Taking its cue from Wall Street, the stock market here did a sharp about-turn today. A measure of the improvement was a 1.8 point rise in The Financial Times common stock index to 307.9. The industrial share average had fallen 5.1 points yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- Mickey Mantle, the Yankees' holdout center fielder, caught the entire club off base tonight.
A New England automobile dealer who loves discussion has bought a year's supply of "Open End" programs for a Boston educational television station on which he is not allowed to advertise.

IN case there is a woman who still does not know, a "copy" of a French or Italian couture original preserves the shaped and general mood of a dress, but the fabric is often different and some details, which would be too expensive to duplicate, are omitted.

Although the snowstorm predicted for the East failed to materialize, skiing enthusiasts still were envisioning a busy week-end yesterday. Conditions almost everywhere from the Poconos in Pennsylvania to the Laurentians in Canada are good to excellent.
NEW DELHI, India, March 10 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has suggested that his meeting with Premier Chou Enlai about the Indian-Chinese border dispute be held April 20 in New Delhi.

LONDON. OFFICIALLY it is still winter with undoubtedly more to come. However, a week of warm sunshine with carpets of crocuses in bloom, window boxes sprouting daffodils and tulips, bowler hats tilted rakishly in Pall Mall and another fine summer forecast, has given the town a general feeling of joie de vivre.

Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $198,000,000 to $595,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average reserve balances in excess of requirements declined $62,000,000 to $376,000,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 10 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers, led by Elgin Baylor's 37 points, trounced the Knickerbockers, 133 -- 108, tonight as the two teams closed out the regular National Basketball Association schedule.

Earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation declined sharply last year, reflecting a 10 per cent drop in sales and a substantial rise in expenditures for research and development, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
The bond market lapsed into inactivity yesterday.

Thirty-three destitute seamen from an American-flag freighter lying bankrupt at a dockside in Naples, Italy, arrived home yesterday on the liner Independence. They traveled as "consular passengers" in tourist class and the United States Government paid their fares of $3,135.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., March 10 -- Two British subjects who have exchanged teaching positions with an American couple from the Sewanhaka High School here are finding that while some things are different children are basically the same.

LONDON, March 9 -- After seven months of teaching science and English in two "secondary modern" schools near London, Mark and Arlene Abels are convinced it is extremely difficult to make a fair comparison between the British and American educational systems.
Approximately $50,000,000 of the $64,000,000 estate left by Howard Gould, last surviving son of Jay Gould, railroad builder, will go for estate taxes.
ALBANY, March 10 -- The Rockefeller Administration bill setting a new measurement of a driver's safe-drinking capacity was passed by the Assemby today and sent to the Governor for his signature.
JERSEY CITY, March 10 -- The first public budget hearing to be held here at night ended after eight hours at 3 A.M. today as five city commissioners set a record-breaking tax rate.

Last December, it was reported that Julie Harris had been invited to appear in "Little Moon of Alban." Yesterday the star acknowledged that she had agreed to do the part, which was enacted by her in the television variation of James Costigan's drama in 1958.

DETROIT, March 11 (AP) -- A Detroit banker testified today that he made two trips to Florida in 1956 to deposit a total of $500,000 in an Orlando bank in connection with a Teamsters Union's real estate project. The project, in Sun Valley, Fla., is now defunct.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A former supervisor of Government-owned surplus farm stocks acknowledged today that he had made a profit of $83,250 from a silent partnership in a company that stored Federal grain without investing any of his own money.
KENOSHA, Wis., March 11 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota and Edward Kennedy crossed paths here today in search of hands to shake.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 11 (AP) -- A Dominican court today convicted in absentia Edward C. Burks, a correspondent for The New York Times, on a charge of defamation of character.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The prospect of Congressional approval of a legal code of ethics was regarded today as having been strengthened by the resignation of John. C. Doerfer as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.
WHITE PLAINS, March 11 -- The redevelopment of WestChester's overcrowded, winding parkways will begin in 1962, County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian said tonight.

The Liquor Salesmen's Union charged in Supreme Court yesterday that Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. had "advised" Harlem retail store owners that they would be picketed unless they bought from Negro salesmen.

TREACLE tart, a pastry something like Pennsylvania Dutch shoofly pie, climaxed a typical English dinner served here recently. The cook, Mrs. Dodo Harris, was a visitor to this country with her husband, Richard T. Harris, managing director of Coates Plymouth Gin.
A 30-year-old law partner of Republican Senator Jacob K. Javits was chosen yesterday by Democratic leaders to run for Congress in the Seventeenth (Silk Stocking) District in Manhattan.

For the second successive day, an easier tone dominated trading in fixed-income securities yesterday. The market still appeared to be tired after the emphatic run-up in prices that came to an end in the middle of the week.
CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- A late rally gave a good lift to soybean and old-crop wheat futures contracts today after the market had dawdled for hours with trade virtually stalled.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The first national conference on consumer and investor protection closed a two-day meeting today on a theme of close Federal-state cooperation in dealing with business racketeers.
OSLO, Norway, March 8 -- Four small rooms in a basement serve as the headquarters of an organization that is waiting to expand into a four-nation Nordic Institute for Maritime Law.

BONN, Germany, March 11 -- Gen. Pierre Billotte, former French Minister of Defense, called on West Germany today to support President de Gaulle's bid for a senior position in the strategic councils of the Western Allies.
ALBANY, March 11 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to add a "cost-ofliving" increase to the pensions of retired state and local employes and teachers.
CARMEL, Calif., March 11 -- Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews, explorer and naturalist, died here tonight of a heart attack at Peninsula Community Hospital. He was 76 years old.
The full cooperation of Federal and state officials with the city was pledged yesterday to speed the construction of $94,000,000 in arterial highways to the site of the 1964 New York World's Fair.
The twenty-third annual National Invitation Tournament, the oldest post-season college basketball competition, resumes today and tonight at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The United States today shot a 94.8-pound sphere, packed with scientific instruments, into in unending orbit around the sun between the planetary paths of Earth and Venus.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letter published March 5 O.R. Strackbein takes issue with The Times for commending the Committee for Economic Development on its conclusion that in our attempts to remedy our payments deficit "we should avoid any course that involves restraints upon imports or United States foreign investments."

NEW ORLEANS, March 11 (AP) -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 2 to 1 decision today, ordered the school board at Dallas, Tex., to submit a public school desegregation plan by May 1.

Henri Soule plans to reopen Le Pavillon Tuesday, the deadline he had set. The restaurant, widely acclaimed for its elegant cuisine, closed two weeks ago in dispute between M. Soule, the owner, and the chef, Pierre Franey.
Dr. Jonas E. Salk is negotiating with officials of San Diego, Calif., for the establishment there of a multi-million-dollar institute for biological research.

SEATTLE, March 11 (AP) -- California took another stride toward the defense of its National Collegiate basketball championship by trouncing Santa Clara, 69 -- 49, tonight in a Far West regional semi-final game.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 11 -- Whether the New York University basketball team goes to San Francisco for the national semi-finals of the National Collegiate tournament will be decided here tomorrow night.
Thirty-three sermons on a single theme -- a call for a deeper commitment among professing Christians -- will be preached here at a week-long Christian Life Convention beginning tomorrow.
BEERSHEBA, Israel, March 2 -- The mayor of this teeming, dusty city, which is bursting with growth and littered with the debris of construction is losing interest in his job.

The recently organized Gate Repertory Company is planning one of the most ambitious of off-Broadway ventures for next season. It hopes to do seven productions. The project will get under way on Sept. 20.

New York University fencers proved superior with the foil again last night in the intercollegiate championships. The trio coached by Hugo Castello turned in a brilliant exhibition in retaining the title and winning the Little Iron Man Trophy for the fourth year in a row.
Two former Federal prosecutors, a psychiartist and a psychologist worked together without fees to win freedom, yesterday in Federal Court for a man serving a fifteen-yearto-life state sentence.
Two youths on trial in the shooting of a 15-year-old girl were convicted last night of first-degree murder under a rarely invoked section of the Penal Code. The jury recommended leniency.
The original stockholders in the Manhattantown slum clearance project have begun legal action against Webb Knapp, Inc., to protect their interest in $850,000 in notes they hold against the project.
ABIS, United Arab Republic March 1 -- Reclaiming farm land from the Egyptian desert has been going on for centuries. But taking it from the salty sea is something new in Egypt.

THANKS to an invitation from Leonard Bernstein, a former student, Fritz Reiner has begun a fortnight's visit with the New York Philharmonic. One of the eminent conductors of our time, Mr. Reiner last had a guest appearance with the Philharmonic in 1943. Orchestral policies operate in odd ways.
Automobile producers of the Nineteen Twenties rejected a fuel device, and this decision tiggered a climb by the old home heating equipment industry to a sales volume of almost $300,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Following is a summary of proposed postal rate increases issued today by the Post Office Department:
LONDON, March 11 -- This ancient capital is being rebuilt it the rate of fourteen acres a week.

Events today: "La Forza del Destino" at 2 P.M. and "Faust" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Brooklyn Philharmonia, youth concert, Brooklyn Academy, 3; Robert Baker, organist, Temple Emanu-El, 4; Chung Choo Oh, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic, Fritz Reiner, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
Firing the Pioneer V space vehicle into an orbit veering inward from the earth's orbit, closer to the sun, was an exercise in rearward marksmanship.

WEST JEFFERSON, N.C., March 11 (UPI) -- Rescue and disaster teams ruished food, fuel and medicine into raugged, snowcovered mountains today and battled twenty-five-foot drifts to reach an estimated total of 1,270 families stranded by severe storms.

The report or the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People on "The Negro Wage-Earner and Apprenticeship Training Programs" throws a much-needed light on a field of Which far too little is publicly known.
THREE French actresses sent this message to one million prospective American women tourists: Take few clothes but ones with personality.

Thousands of New York state residents were defrauded of more than $100,000 by a Manhattan company that said a device would turn "ordinary house wiring into a super-power 500-foot television antenna," the State Attorney General charged yesterday.
Rent reductions were recommended yesterday after a team of rent administrators found living conditions in five East Harlem tenements "deplorable."

SECAUCUS, N.J., March 11 -- A hole in the pavement of the bridge over the Hackensack River caused traffic jams today that extended westward for six to eight miles on Route 3 and for three miles on Route 17.
WHITE PLAINS, March 11 -- Primary candidates for Congress and the Legislature were chosen tonight at the annual convention of the Westchester Republican County Committee.
The Metropolitan Opera will raise its prices in all ticket categories next season.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Postal rate increases intended to yield about $550,000,000 a year in added revenues were urged by President Eisenhower today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The index of average wholesale prices at the primary market level rose 0.3 per cent to 119.7 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Commodity futures prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges in dull trading. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

LONDON, March 11 -- Industrial price changes were irregular in the stock market here today. Wall Street's failure to maintain the rally checked the improvement here, and although selling was extremely light there was little demand.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11 -- Penn State held a slight advantage over Lehigh and Pittsburgh as the quarterfinals of the Eastern intercollegiate wrestling championships ended tonight at Princeton's Dillon Gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- David Ben-Gurion, Premier of Israel, said today that the West could contribute to the development of the United Arab Republic if Cairo would resolve to live in peace with its neighbors.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 11 -- The nation's first major mutual fund proxy fight held here today turned into little more than a polite Midwestern gabfest.

Thomas Mellon Evans, the acquisition-minded chairman of the H.K. Porter Company and of the Crane Company, was reported yesterday to have acquired a large interest in the Brown Company, a New Hampshire manufacturer of pulp, paper and other wood products.

Official United States statistics indicate that this country's trade with Cuba declined sharply in 1959, the first year of Premier Fidel Castro's rule. Data published in the De- partment of Commerce magazine, Survey of Commerce Business, show that last year American exports to Cuba declined more than $100,000,000, or almost 20 per cent.

American television is preparing elaborate coverage of Princess Margaret's wedding to Antony Armstrong-Jones May 6, although it is not yet certain whether cameras will be admitted into Westminster Abbey.
Sales declined on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday but rather general gains added almost $2,250,000,000 to market values.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 (UPI) -- Paul Arizin, Philadelphia's old pro, poured in 40 points tonight to lead the Warriors to a 115-92 victory over Syracuse in the opener of the two-of-three series in the Eastern Division semi-finals of the National Basketball Association.
LOME, Togoland, March 11 -- A plan to organize the French Community states in Africa and Togoland and Cameroon into a bloc was disclosed today by Togoland's Premier, Sylvanus E. Olympio.
The chairman of the Board of Higher Education declared yesterday that the city's public colleges were entitled to the same measure of state aid now given to units of the State University.

STUART, Fla., March 11 -- The plastic-worm caster who arrived a few days ago and has been defending himself with the desperate fury of a cornered animal was finally straightened out today. He rolled a big bass on top water bait, nearly hooked him, and is now staring frigidly down his nose at any man who uses any underwater lures.
BONN, Germany, March 11 -- The United States and British Army commanders in West Germany ordered sharp travel restrictions today against the Soviet military missions attached to their forces.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- At a recent staff meeting of all top officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, two eminent lawyers became locked in a debate over a legal definition of space.

Foreign capital -- including United States money -- brought Canada a gain in 1959 of $627,000,000 invested in stocks and bonds. This capital inflow from securities transactions, however, represented an increase of only $17,000,000 over that in 1958, Canadian Press reported yeserday from Ottawa.

NAHA, Okinawa, March 11 (AP) -- An international uproar began building up today in the case of two Ryukyu islanders wounded while gathering scrap on a United States Air Force gunnery range. Okinawa newspapers said they had been strafed by an American jet plane.

Nearly 600,000 high school students played football last season, according to the National Federation of State High School Athletic Associations. There were more heroes on the nation's gridirons than there were basketball players, runners or baseball players.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation appeared assured yesterday of a "prestige" contract in the nation's shipping industry. The contract calls for the maintenance and servicing of the world's first merchant nuclear ship, the Savannah.

PARIS. New United States policy toward the Soviet Union favors expanded trade with that country. While we are not prepared to sell strategic materials to our adversary, we do hope to encourage greater Russian commerce.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Senate killed a major section of the Administration's civil rights bill today as organized labor intervened against new provisions.

A SUMMIT, N.J., housewife, some anonymous Navajo Indians, a Temple University psychology student, an industrial designer, a Japanese-American who studied on an Indian reservation and a former department store display man have combined their talents to produce a lively exhibit of hand crafted rugs at America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Negotiations were resumed with the Atomic Energy Commission today for a $28,000,000 contract to sell uranium from North and South Dakota lignite ores.
A man who gave his occupation as "hoodlum" was accused by the police yesterday of having driven the getaway car in a $23,937 Brooklyn payroll hold-up in which two Brink's guards were wounded.
MINEOLA, L.I., March 11 -- An off-duty New York City fireman was credited with saving the lives of three children who were trapped by a fire that destroyed their home here today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote on a motion by which the Senate knocked out of the Administration's ciil rights bill a section making obstruction of court orders in school desegregation a Federal crime:

An industrial building and four and one-half acres along the Central Railroad of New Jersey tracks and the Arthur Kill in Carteret, N.J., have been sold by Benjamin Moore Co. to the De Long Corporation of New York, engineering and construction organization.
HAVANA, March 11 -- Three sugar mills and a railway in Oriente Province owned by Americans and Cubans were seized late yesterday by the Cuban Government.

The February issue of The Engineering and Mining Journal published an annual article on gold, the author of which for a number of years has been Dr. Miroslav A. Kriz, formerly with the foreign reserve division of the New York Federal Reserve Bank and now associate economist of the First National City Bank.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The state Division of Military and Naval Affairs has proposed legislation to enable the state to dispose of obsolete armories in New York City.
THE PRESIDENT Saw NATO chief Gen. Lauris Norstad. Met with Cabinet. Asked Congress for increased postal rates. THE SENATE Continued civil rights debate.
Spring loses its eight-day lease on the Coliseum today when the flower show closes at 6 P.M.
APPLETON, Wis., March 11 -- Long before Senator Kennedy arrived tonight for another of the crowded evening receptions that have marked his Wisconsin campaign, he was assured of a good turnout.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa was accused yesterday of seeking to disown by "an amazing about-face from the facts" an attack on a state commission's proposals to improve the city's fiscal procedures.
Purim -- the Jewish Festival of Lots, commemorating the deliverance of Jews in ancient Persia -- will begin at sundown today and will be celebrated through tomorrow.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 11 (AP) -- Mike Totsky, a 31-year-old barber from Wyandotte, Mich., today took first place in singles and all-events in the American Bowling Congress championships with the first 700 series of the week-old tournament.

Two witnesses testified yesterday that Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. received $1,500 for a series of ten articles in The Amsterdam News that the Government says Mr. Powell never reported as income.

PRESCHOOLERS in this area are finding "homes away from home" in some unusual places. In an effort to attract young mothers who might otherwise be tied to the house for lack of a sitter, a wide variety of enterprises -- from women's clubs to bowling lanes -- are getting up child care facilities.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the quite appropriate concentration of The Times on the tactics of the current filibuster in the Senate, prospects for compromise legislation, and the more extreme statements of the Southern orators against desegregation measures of the Federal Executive and Judiciary, a very meaningful and eloquent comment has gone unreported.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Golden Hours, closing fast on the outside, scored an upset victory in today's feature at Gulfstream Park before a crowd of 14,903. Gaylad finished second and Sweet William third.
Vera Wang, 10 years old, won the juvenile ladies' singles title last night in the thirty-ninth annual Middle Atlantic figure-skating championships at Iceland.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 11 -- President Francois Duvalier assailed today what he called the arrogant, dishonest and grasping tactics of some public servants in his Government.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) -- Representative Donald L. Jackson charged today that some newspapers had "deliberately distorted" a statement by Cardinal Spellman into a blanket defense of the loyalty of Protestant churchmen.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- In no more than it takes him to scoot from home plate to first base, Mickey Mantle brought his holdout siege to a close today.

EVERYBODY has emotional problems. Some have the emotional equivalent of the sniffles. Others are incapacitated by the equivalent of influenza, tuberculosis or heart disease. A few may be likened to diabetics; they have learned to live with their illness.
The last hazard to navigation on the nation's busiest inland waterway, the Arthur Kill Channel, was blasted yesterday into 30,000 tons of dust and mud.

MOSCOW, March 11 (AP) -- The Soviet Government accused the North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations tonight of trying to thwart world disarmament by pushing ahead with plans for an international nuclear striking force.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 11 -- Figures made available today indicate that Bulgaria's socialized economy may have led the rest of the Soviet bloc last year in the rate of production increases.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture ran into Congressional criticism today for delaying a stand on whether the Government should outlaw food and cosmetic colors classed as possible cancer producers.

The opening of the National 12 Goal Polo Tournament at Squadron A Armory at Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street next Friday evening will benefit the New York City Society for Crippled Children and Adults.
BOMBAY, March 11 -- The Reserve Bank of India put a brake on credit today to check speculative activity in the country's stock market and its inflationary consequences.
Steel output during February took a tumble from peak January production levels, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

THOSE wandering up Madison Avenue on the east side of the street, even on these cold March days, might be stopped by the spring window display at E. Braun Co. Linens, 717 Madison Avenue (near Sixtythird Street).
CHICAGO, March 11 (UPI) -- John Thomas, the Boston University sophomore, leaped 7 feet 2 1/2 inches tonight to set a world indoor high-jump record, bettering his old mark by a half-inch.
Members of the younger set have been enlisted to aid in the planning for the Hearts and Diamonds Ball, which will be held April 7 in the Plaza to benefit the Heart and Lung Foundation.

ROME, March 11 -- The possibility that British-Italian talks before the April summit meeting may be canceled has put strong pressure on Premier-designate Antonio Segni to resolve the Italian Cabinet crisis with all possible speed.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Seven Western nations and Japan agreed today with the United States on the necessity of stepping up aid to underdeveloped countries.
ALBANY, March 11 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Department of Commerce:

STOWE, Vt., March 11 -- France and Austria shared the giant slalom honors in the opening skirmishes of the three-day American International ski races on Mount Mansfield today. The races were held in sub-zero temperatures.
Action to halt alleged manipulation of Natus Corporation stock by Bertram Goldsmith, J.T. Ross and the firm of Goldsmith Ross was taken yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
BLUE POINT, L.L, March 11 -- Representative Stuyvesant Wainwright 2d was endorsed tonight by the Suffolk Republican committee after a move to displace him had collapsed.
With the expectation that the return bout between Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson will be held June 22, the new International Soccer League has rearranged its schedule.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11 -- Another meet record by Harvard's 400-yard free-style quartet and outstanding individual performances by Dartmouth's Charles Brown, Yale's Bill Chase and the Crimson's Fred Elizalde and Frank Gorman highlighted the Eastern College swimming championships in the Harvard pool tonight.
The city actually makes a profit on funds it contributes to urban renewal projects, according to a study just completed by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council but not yet published.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Negotiations to settle the actors' strike against seven of the eight major studios here took a hopeful turn today.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- In a futuristic complex of brightly lit, glass-partitioned rooms, a corps of thirty men and women was keeping minute-to-minute track tonight of the far-ranging movements and experiences of the Pioneer V.
A Queens grand jury yesterday termed "astounding" the award of a contract for electrical work to courthouse contractors who bid $2,800,000 when the city engineers' estimate was only $1,400,000.

OLD BRIDGE, N.J., March 11 -- The policy-making body of the State Board of Child Welfare will meet on Thursday to review the case of Alice Marie Combs, whom authorities consider too bright for her foster parents.
Almost all means Of transportation, except the horsey equivalent of shanks' mare, are being used to transport the thoroughbred to Aqueduct and Belmont Park in anticipation of the local racing season.
MANILA, March 10 -- A hard struggle is being waged for the selection of a candidate to oppose President Carlos P. Garcia in the elections of November, 1961.
PARIS, March 11 -- The West plans to propose at the disarmament conference opening in Geneva Tuesday that the Soviet Union and the United States limit their military manpower to 2,100,000 men each.

Among the many distinguished visitors coming to these shores, Chancellor Adenauer is always assured of a welcome. He is due to arrive here tonight on an informal visit en route to a formal state visit to another of our allies, Japan. For a man of 84 such a trip is in itself a formidable undertaking. But his visit here is presumably the most, important part of his journey.
KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Feb. 29 -- Few Afghans are invited to parties given by most of the thirty-three American families who live in Kandahar, the major city in southern Afghanistan.

BOSTON, March 11 -- Federal indictments charging tax evasions aggregating more than $790,000 were returned here today against Bernard Goldfine, whose gift-giving forced the resignation in 1958 of Sherman Adams as the Assistant to President Eisenhower.

The sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 975 Park Avenue, souteast corner sold by the Nine Seventy Five Associates to Eugene M. Grant for investment. The house conof Eighty-third Street, has been tains sixty-eight apartments of six to eight rooms and occupies a plot 64 by 150 feet.

MANHATTAN, Kan., March 11 (AP) -- Cincinnati easily routed De Paul of Chicago, 99 -- 59, and Kansas rallied to beat Texas, 90 -- 81, tonight to gain the final of the National Collegiate Midwest regional basketball tourney.
LONDON, March 11 -- Hugh Gaitskell denounced his rebellious comrades today for wanting to shelter behind United States nuclear weapons.

A literary critique called "Love and Death in the American Novel" has been written by Leslie A. Fiedler, Professor of English and director of the Humanities Program at the University of Montana. The discussion covers American fiction from 1789 to the present.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, March 11 (UPI) -- Shareholders of the Aeronca Manufacturing Company here and Buensod-Stacey of New York voted overwhelmingly today in favor of merging.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer, shooting for his third straight victory, forged into the lead of the $15,000 Pensacola open golf tournament today with a second-round 65.
For the first time, man sent a "live" messenger on its way deep into the solar system yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, March 11 -- The suspension of all recreational activities of the Municipal Department of Parks and the dismissal of 130 department employes were announced today.
The market for new capital is expected to be moderately active next week, with a $57,000,000 offering of General Telephone and Electronics common stock the standout item on the docket.

BUENOS AIRES, March 11 -- Paraguayan parties in exile denounced today the one-party election to be held Sunday for a new Paraguayan Chamber of Deputies. They said it would be a "sham and an offense to the democratic conscience" of the Americas.
TRENTON, March 11 -- Sixty-five new, three-foot-square, red, white and blue road markers will appear in New Jersey Monday.
Cotton futures moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) up to 6 points (30 cents) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Emile Griffith, the 9-5 favorite, registered an unpopular split decision over Denny Moyer at Madison Square Garden in the ten-round welterweight main event last night. Each boxer weighed 150 pounds.

THE spring national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League begins today at Jackson, Miss, -- ten days before spring begins officially, even in Mississippi, but for two days the league's directors have been meeting in sessions averaging more than eighteen hours a day.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Tea Council of the United States of America, Inc., received a patent this week for a restaurant machine that makes "a very, very good cup of tea." This high rating rests on the authority of Robert Compton, a New York tea importer and chairman of the council's brewing committee.

LONDON, March 11 -- The signal to separate the 94.8-pound satellite from the third-stage rocket was transmitted at 1:27 P.M., (Greenwich Mean Time) (8:27 A.M., Eastern Standard Time) through the radiotelescope at Jodrell Bank.

THE NEW YORKER magazine's articles on American Indian affairs are ably represented in today's book, "Apologies to the Iroquois."* First there is a wonderful study by Joseph Mitchell of the Mohawks who at perilous heights rivet steel on bridges and skyscrapers. Then there is a longer narrative by Edmund Wilson about the imperiled Iroquois Confederacy.

LOUISVILLE, March 11 (AP) -- All-America Jerry Lucas scored 36 points tonight in leading Ohio State to a 98-79 victory over Western Kentucky in the Mideast semifinals of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.
The focus on the shipyard strike against the Bethlehem Steel Corporation shifted from the courtroom to the bargaining table yesterday.

As New York State tax enforcement machinery improves, some non-residents who have not filed state income tax returns in the past are wondering if they can safely assume they needn't file in the future.

Chancellor Adenauer is scheduled to arrive at 7 o'clock tonight at New York International Airport on a special charter flight from West Germany.

HONG KONG, March 11 -- The Premiers of Nepal and Communist China stressed prospects today for increased friendship between their countries.
AMATEURS of European old and modern master drawings will find much to stimulate the eye, and much to question in the way of attributions in the show at the Bayer Gallery, 51 East Eighteenth Street.

NEWARK, March 11 -- The Newark Housing Authority has invited bids for the last two public housing projects now planned by the city in its slum-clearance program. The cost is estimated at $35,000,000.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 11 -- Missile workers here rejoiced today as Pioneer V went roaring off toward an eternal orbit of the sun.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Representative Aime J. Forand, Democrat of Rhode Island, made public today letters from two prominent physicians endorsing his bill to extend the Social Security system to provide health benefits to retired workers.

Three new International One-Design Class yachts have arrived from Norway to raise the number that will be in competition on Long Island Sound to thirty-three. It is the highest number here since the original twenty-five boats were delivered twenty-three years ago.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., March 12 -- Richard (Richie) Regan today was named varsity basketball coach at Seton Hall University to replace the retiring Pirate mentor, John (Honey) Russell. Regan signed a two-year contract, the Rt. Rev. Msgr. John J. Dougherty, the president of Seton Hall, announced.

AN ambiguous 18-year-old is the first-person narrator of "Absolute Beginners," And because the story he tells is so insistently his own it is an ambiguous story, with some of the blurred effect which always attends a novel that tries to go two ways at once.

The fourth annual benefit for the Retarded Infants Services will be held Friday in the Grand Ballroom of the Delmonico. Mrs. Michael J. Gluck, chairman, has been meeting with members of her committee at Essex House to plan for the dinner dance.

Dr. Benjamin A. Cohen, former Under Secretary of the United Nations, died of cancer yesterday at 3 P.M. in Doctors Hospital. He would have been 64 years old next Friday.

MONTREAL -- The Laurentian resort country, which this winter had one of the most successful seasons in its history, is getting ready for a bountiful period of spring skiing. DORTMUND, Germany, March 2 -- One of the beat-read publications in Ruhr executives' suites this winter is a glossy, nineteen-page pamphlet entitled "Traffic and Air Defense."

IN a word-association test, the response to "shamrock" would be either "Ireland" or "St. Patrick," and the reply to "St. Patrick" either "Ireland" or "shamrock." For the shamrock has become the national symbol universally worn by Irishmen and their well-wishers on St Patrick's Day, replacing the Patrick's Crosses and rosettes of former years and even displacing the "wearing of the green" that once signified such gallant courage.
