WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers urged the House of Representatives today to keep in its civil rights bill a provision dealing with Federal court orders in school desegregation cases.
Cardinal Spellman presided yesterday at the annual Red Cross mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Pete Newell of the University of California received a plaque here last night as the basketball coach of the year. The presentation was made at the twenty-seventh awards dinner of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association.
RICHMOND, Va., March 13 -- Virginia, a tobacco-growing state, imposed its first tax on cigars and cigarettes today.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 13 (AP) -- Minneapolis, led by Elgin Baylor and Frank Selvy, routed Detroit, 114 -- 99, today to sweep the National Basketball Association Western Division semifinal play-offs in two games.

PITTSBURGH, March 13 -- Steel order volume was off again last week after having shown a little improvement two weeks ago. The slow downward trend in steel output also continued, with more of the same expected this week.
A husband and wife cannot save on income taxes due New York State by pooling their incomes and filing a joint return, as they can with Federal income taxes.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 14 points (70 cents a bale) lower yesterday than on Friday.

Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation plans to offer to the public $35,000,000 of first mortgage pipeline bonds, due in 1980, and 800,000 shares of common stock, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey has challenged a recent statement by Premier Khrushchev that the United States will possess, within the next two years, "larger armed forces than the Soviet Union."
ALBANY, March 14 -- Democratic legislative leaders advised Mayor Wagner tonight to reject Governor Rockefeller's program to resolve disputes between the city and state administrations.

Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Premier David Ben-Gurion sat down together here yesterday and talked about German-Jewish relations and world conditions. It was the first meeting between the West German and Israeli leaders.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The bulk of the Rockefeller administration's 1960 labor program was introduced in the Legislature tonight.
Lehigh Valley Industries, Inc., has received a plan from its financial consultants that could result in a recapitalization.
A study to evaluate the selection and training of men for police work, to raise the standards, was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 14 -- Being an old pro with a practical turn of mind, Alvin Dark shrugs off the trade that sent him from the Chicago Cubs to the Phillies.
ALBANY, March 14 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt has decided to set up a special auditing unit to keep a sharper eye on public authorities.
ALBANY, Marh 14 -- The Wagner Administration won approval in the Assembly today for one of its key proposals for tightening building law enforcement.

The nation's barge operators are out to sidetrack the nation's railroads. The battle begins today in Washington in hearings before the Interstate Commerce Commission. The issue stems from an application by the Illinois Central Railroad Company and the Southern Pacific Railroad for permission to buy the John I.

James R. Hoffa told 8,000 cheering teamsters and members of their families last night that he planned to build a web of union alliances covering millions of workers as an answer to the Landrum-Griffin labor reform law.
The indictment against Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack was dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Gerald P. Culkin.

WHITE PLAINS, March 14 -- State speed limits of fifty miles an hour on winding country roads were criticized today at a meeting of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors. J. Edward Fox, New Castle supervisor, said that of the ninety-six miles of highways in his town, seventy were maintained by the town although it had no right to determine speed limits on them below the general state limit.

-- After hearing testimony today After hearing testimony today on the number of locomotives out of service for repairs, two state Public Utilities Commissioners criticized the New Haven Railroad on its maintenance program and said new locomotives "are not the answer to the problem."
The American Tramp Ship-owners Association has asked the Secretary of Agriculture to halt the movement of grain to foreign-aid recipients in ships owned by oil companies.

Tom Stith of St. Bonaventure and Tony Jackson of St. John's were unanimous choices on the 1960 Catholic College all-America basketball team picked yesterday for the Catholic Digest magazine by ten college coaches.
LONDON, March 14 -- Richard H.S. Crossman, a recent rebel against the Labor party's defense policy, has resigned from the party's shadow cabinet.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Commerce Department proposed today a seventy-eight-point plan to make the nation's transportation system more balanced and efficient.

Title to the plot on the south-west corner of Rockaway Park-way and Avenue L in the Canarsie area of Brooklyn has passed to the Bankers Federal Savings and Loan Association, which will erect a branch office on the site, according to C. Harry Minners, president.
The two finest high school basketball players in the city face each other today at Madison Square Garden.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Because of the public interest involved I should like to comment briefly upon your editorial of March 9 concerning the proposed local laws that would require prior written notice to the city and impose liability upon abutting owners in claims for injuries alleged to result from sidewalk and roadway defects.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- America's second sun satellite passed the 500,000-mile mark today in its flight into deep space between earth and Venus.
CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- Two post office investigators were shot to death in their car tonight, the police said, by three prisoners in their custody.
FOUR young American composers, Stanley Hollings-worth, Paul Ramsier, Charles Turner and Lee Hoiby, shared a program of their music very neatly last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

BOCA RATON, Fla., March, 14 -- The American Automobile Association made known today plans for a national drive to defeat "devious proposals" aimed at shackling passenger car use in downtown areas for the benefit of mass transit.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 14 -- A test of Negro rights in big city shopping centers was started on the way to higher court jurisdiction today.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The six Southern states which have passed, or are expected to pass, new laws by which their Presidential electors could be chosen unpledged to any party nominee will not be joined by Virginia, their historic leader.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Twenty-one liberal Democratic Senators formally urged the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board today to make four major reforms in Federal Reserve and money market opera tion.

THE National Symphony of Washington gave its second and final concert of the season last night at Carnegie Hall. The program consisted of two good-sized modern works, balanced by Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto, with Benno Moisehvitsch as the soloist.
YESTERDAY (March 14, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Conferred with Mrs. Clare B. Williams, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, and with Secretary of State Herter.
BOWIE, Md., March 14 (AP) -- Turning in the fastest six furlongs of the meeting, Cashel II galloped to a four-length victory in the $4,500 Warwick Purse at Bowie today.

DENVER, March 14 (AP) -- Nine present and former officials of the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers were sentenced to prison and fined today for conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government.
JERSEY CITY, March 14 -- Superior Court Judge Charles W. Broadhurst ordered the City Commission today to show cause why it should not be restrained from adopting a record municipal budget.

ELISABETHVILLE, Belgian Congo, March 14 (AP) -- The toll in three days of savage battling by two rival political factions is thirteen Congolese killed and more than 100 injured, officials said today. The combatants fought with machetes, clubs and fists.
The association of young composers and high-school musical organizations will continue for a second year with the aid of the Ford Foundation.
CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- A general broad advance in grain futures here today raised all distant oats deliveries to new highs for the season and left May wheat only a fraction below its peak.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As things stand at this writing, a large ball will start swinging some time this summer and Carnegie Hall will be reduced to rubble. Why must this great violence to New York City's pride and cultural greatness take place?

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The House of Representatives brushed aside today efforts to broaden its civil rights bill. It began working out a new approach to the bill's attempt to guarantee Negro voting rights.
Following is the text of General Sessions Judge Gerald P. Culkin's decision yesterday in the Hulan E. Jack case:
Attention New Jersey and Connecticut owners of power boats rated at more than ten horsepower:
DETROIT, March 14 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company has just passed two production milestones -- the 200,000th Thunderbird and the 200,000th Falcon.
BUENOS AIRES, March 14 -- President Arturo Frondizi and his military secretaries discussed today methods of dealing with Peronist terrorism and electoral abstention.

Allie Brandt, a 5-foot 5-inch bowler, rolled a three-game series in 1939 that still stands as about the toughest single scoring mark to break in the sport. Last week, at 56, Brandt was named to the American Bowling Congress Hall of Fame.

EXPLORE the surfaces of Eduardo Paolozzi's bronzes -- complex as a cartographer's fantasy -- and, rather suddenly, you will find yourself not outside at all but within the cavernous voids so important in his work.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 14 (AP) -- Fay Crocker won the twenty-first Titleholders golf tournament today by seven strokes. She turned in a 76 for 303 in taking the tournament for the first time.

"My Fair Lady" The notion that the market place is a just, albeit stern, judge, and that in the long run the greatest talent earns the widest plaudits as well as the greatest compensation, certainly receives a major boost with the story of an artistic endeavor that marks its fourth birthday today.
Two events are being planned for the benefit of the Manhattanville Community Centers, Inc., an interracial, nonsectarian settlement house group.
LONDON, March 14 -- Britain will seek Soviet agreement to a code of rules for East-West coexistence at the coming summit conterence, an unimpeachable source disclosed today.
WASHINGTON', March 15 -- A crack appeared today in the New Jersey Congressional delegation's solid bipartisan front to obtain a new jet airport for the state.

Jack McCartan and Coach Alf Pike will be back with the Rangers next season if Muzz Patrick has his way. Muzz, the Blues' general manager, said yesterday that he expected to sign both within the next three days.

Trade buying and short covering steadied potato futures prices early yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading early in the session was influenced by a Department of Agriculture report late Friday that showed that holdings were sharply lower than in 1959.

Papercraft Corp. The LePage division of Johnson Johnson, New Brunswick, N.J., manufacturer of surgical dressings, has been sold to the Papercraft Corporation of Pittsburgh, maker of gift wrappings, it was announced yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, March 14 -- Nearly half of the entire population of South Korea has been declared eligible to vote tomorrow for a President and a Vice President of this twelve-year-old republic.

ACCRA, Ghana, March 14 -- Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah warned African independent states today against defense pacts with powers outside Africa. Such pacts, he said, would compromise and undermine the independence and sovereignty of African states.

LONDON, March 14 -- Share prices advanced on a wide front in the stock market here today. The more confident note was ascribed to Wall Street's rise on Friday, but it was helped by a continuing flow of good company reports and affirmative comments by financial writers.

Residents of ten of fourteen Staten Island communities were promised "some reduction" in real estate tax evaluations yesterday by Tax Commissioner Irving Rivkin when he started hearing a record number of protests.

The leaders of Democratic reform clubs in the Seventeenth Congressional District in Manhattan struck a favorable bargain yesterday with the old-line leadership on delegates to the party's national convention.

A BOOK about an important subject is not necessarily an important book. This truth bedevils the lives of editors and critics. Every year we see volumes by the dozen blazoned because they deal with tremendous matters of immense public concern. Yet a few weeks or a few months after they appear they are with ten thousand others in limbo.
JACKSON, Miss., March 14 -- In a national tournament such as the one in progress here, the contestants3,000 of them-have a private ranking system comparable to pecking rights in a barnyard.
St. John's, the defender, and Bradley make their first appearances in the National Invitation Basketball Tournament at Madison Square Garden tonight.
FOR three hours and twenty-five minutes Sunday night the WNTA-TV (Channel 13) program, "Open End," provided a remarkable discussion on the sensitive topic of religion.

Una Festa a Posillipo, this year's Italian Renaissance Ball, will be given in the ballroom of the Plaza on April 19. The event, which is held each year under the auspices of the Renaissance of Italian Youth Foundation, headed by Miss Rosetta Valenti, will aid Orphans of Italy, Inc.
HONG KONG, March 10 -- Hong Kong is watching closely the move by United States textile interests to have tariffs or some other restrictions applied to textile imports.
One of the "Many Loves of Dobie Gillis" has been considered a little too suggestive for television and will not be shown tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

MILWAUKEE, March 14 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota said tonight that one of the challenges facing the next President of the United States would be the finding of "a dignified place in society" for the nation's aged population.
DOUGLAS, Ga., March 14 (AP) -- By a narrow margin, southeast Georgians told the State's School Study Committee today that public schools should be closed if necessary to prevent integration.
Two California physicist have carried out a study that they believe shows that the Van Alien radiation belts around the earth cannot be fed by particles ejected from the sun.
Subscribers have been announced for the March 29 performance of "Toys in the Attic" at the Hudson Theatre, which will benefit Encampment for Citizenship.
The winners of the Newbery and Caldecott Medals for the most distinguished children's books of 1959 are Joseph Krumgold and Marie Hall Ets.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior today reported that 301.041 barrels a day of imported crude oil were being exchanged for domestic crude oil by the importers during the six months ending on June 30.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Republicans sought today to link a figure in the Senate investigation of Indiana pinball scandals with the Presidential campaign of Senator John F. Kennedy.

LAMBERT BROTHERS, Lexington Avenue at Sixtieth Street, has come up with a lasting gift idea suitable for both brides and babies. A white book, with the individual name stamped on the cover, commemorates birth or wedding with a collection of clippings on the iniside pages.

Reginald Stewart, who resigned as director of the Baltimore Symphony in 1952 and of that city's Peabqdy Conservatory two seasons ago, played a Town Hall recital last night, which marked his first appearance here as a pianist since 1941.

RICHMOND, Va., March 14 (AP) -- The sale of a municipal swimming pool by the city of Greensboro, N.C., to private owners to avoid racial Integration "does not constitute state action or conduct" that a Federal court may prohibit, the Fourth Federal Circuit Court of Appeals said today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Administration's wheat program was received with coolness today by the House Agriculture Committee.

Jose Gonzalez of the Bronx, using a five-pound weight edge to good advantage, upset Antonio Marcilla, a welterweight from Argentina, in the main event at St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 1,117 paid $2,414.25 to watch the five-bout card.
PARIS, March 14 -- Official and unofficial theatre critics here have now had their say, and the verdict is virtually unanimous: Franchise Sagan has done extremely well in her debut as a playwright.

The defense moved for a mistrial yesterday in the income-tax evasion trial of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. on the ground that Government counsel had made an improper remark before the jury Decision was withheld.
The five-story apartment building at 514 West 184th Street has been sold by Werner and Marion Schefftel to a client of Hyman Bass, lawyer, according to Nehring Brothers, brokers in the transaction.
ALBANY, March 14 -- The Legislature gave the final approval today to lowering the minimum age for caddies from 14 to 12 years.
LONDON, March 13 -- Volunteers from Britain's armed forces are undergoing experiments with nerve gas, a War Office spokesman confirmed tonight.
A Federal Aviation Agency order grounding airline pilots more than 60 years of age went into effect at midnight, after the Federal courts had refused to enjoin the ruling.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Defense Department is planning to accelerate development of an early warning satellite that would detect missiles as they left the launching pad.
Art collectors in Chicago, Dallas and Los Angeles will join New York competitors, through the medium of closed-circuit television, in bidding on paintings and sculpture at an auction April 27.

NEW ORLEANS. ALTHOUGH spring is officially six days away it is very much in evidence in this gastronomic center of the South. In the parks and on the lawns the azaleas are in blossom, and in the restaurants the finest fish and shellfish, vegetables and fruits appear on the menus.

Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., established record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, according to the annual report issued for publication today. The company makes food products, glass and metal containers, matches and plywood.

HAVANA, March 14 -- The semi-official newspaper Revolution brought to the fore today the issue of the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay by publishing a report charging mistreatment of Cuban employes of the base.
National chains affected by lunch counter sitdown strikes said yesterday they would continue segregation or if necessary close their lunch counters until Southern public opinion agreed to a change.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- The United States appears to have earned a heaping measure of goodwill among Russians by its recent rescue of four starving Soviet service men adrift in the Pacific.

CHARLOTTE, N.C, March 14 (UPI) -- An official of Burlington Industries warned today that the domestic textile industry "is in danger of strangulation from foreign imports if they are permitted to come into this country in unlimited quantities."
JACKSON, Miss., March 14 -- Boyd Hughes of Columbia, S.C., led a field of 344 bridge players yesterday after the first of two sessions of play for the open individual contract bridge championship.
GENEVA, March 14 -- The Western powers presented to the Soviet Union today their careful prescription for world disarmament: a measure of disarmament for a measure of control.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Rockefeller's proposal for a $75,000,000 bond issue for the acquisition of park lands appears to have clear sailing in the Legislature.

The Commission on Money and Credit is the group set up almost two years ago (in May, 1958) to make an over-all study of the nation's monetary and credit institutions. This is a project that was long overdue, since the last such study was the three-year inquiry by the so-called Aldrich Committee early in the present century.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A highly placed Democratic organization source expressed belief tonight that Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts probably would be nominated for President on an early-ballot at Los Angeles.
The Port of New York Authority will erect a 200-room addition to the International Hotel at New York International Airport at a cost of $3,170,000.
Resurging of bond prices yesterday made it clear that last week's emphatic rally in the market standing of prime fixed-income securities was not a flash in the pan.
PARIS, March 14 -- Most people here incline to the belief that Premier Khrushchev certainly was tired and at least sniffling after his twenty-four-day tour of Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Following is the Western general disarmament proposal in the ten-nation disarmament conference opening at Geneva tomorrow:
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 14 (AP) -- Davey Moore, the world featherweight champion, was knocked out tonight by Carlos Hernandez, the Venezuelan champion. Moore's title was not at stake.

PARIS. ABEARDED young Frenchman, who has chosen law as his career, sparked a revolution this week. The place, however, was not Algiers but Paris' Crillon Hotel, and the young man was not Pierre Lagaillarde but one of a handful of students whom Pierre Cardin, the widely known designer of women's fashions, had chosen to model his new collection of ready-to-wear clothes for men.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- A meeting that may lead to a quick ending of the strike of movie actors is scheduled to be held here Thursday.

YESTERDAY (March 14, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Sent special message to Legislature proposing $75,000,000 bond issue for park land acquisition. Met with Advisory Council on the Advancement of Industrial Research and Development.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Two influential organizations lined up today behind the latest version of the Rockefeller administration's court-reorganization plan.
For ten years Federico Thompson fought in the tank towns of South America. He sold himself cheap, but it didn't matter.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Municipal housing experts accused the Public Housing Administration today of setting up obstacles "deliberately calculated to discourage local authorities" in the development of housing projects.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- The Detroit Tigers, who last year set some kind of record with one of the most amazing backward leaps ever made from a standing start, apparently are not out to repeat that performance this year.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 14 -- Rocky Colavito, the Bronx baseball star who eluded the Yankees, wants nothing better, he says, than to stay in Cleveland.

The unaccountable lack of humor in advertising today * * * is traceable to the fact that business will permit itself to be discussed only in the noblest of terms, Caskie Stinnett, assistint director of public relations for the Curtis Publishing Company, said yesterday.
TUNIS, March 14 -- The nationalist Provisional Government of Algeria charged today that President de Gaulle had "closed the door on negotiation and peace" in the five-year-old Algerian rebellion.
The decentralization of the city school system -- possibly through the creation of four or five new divisions -- is being considered by school officials.

Investment bankers offered yesterday 775,000 common shares of General Telephone and Electronics Corporation at $73.62 1/2 a share, one of the largest offerings made to the public this year. Investment bankers led by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Stone Webster Securities Corporation and Mitchum, Jones Templeton managed the 119 members of the underwriting syndicate.

General Mills, Inc., the nation's leading flour producer, is proposing to diversify its operations further through the acquisition of the Daven Company, Livingston, N.J., supplier to the electronics industry.
PHILADELPHIA, March 14 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain secret 53 points tonight and led the Philadelphia Warriors to a 132-112 victory over the Syracuse Nationals.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 14 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel declared today that he saw the prospect of an end of war in this generation.
The first breach in merged labor's policy of boycotting exchanges with Soviet trade unions was made yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union.
The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York defended its franchise for medical services to municipal employes and their families yesterday against other services in this field.

PALM BEACH SHORES, Fla., March 14 -- This was a sun-tan day along these beaches and many a bare chest was arched vigorously at the sun. The fishing for king mackerel was brisk and pleasant, too, but of course not nearly so inspiring as the display of red-blooded American manliness.
BONN, Germany, March 14 -- The Soviet Union, with the forthcoming summit conference in mind, rescinded today its latest bid to force indirect Western recognition of Communist East Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Treasury bill rates took another steep tumble today, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) --The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

"I LOVE Ohrbach's in the springtime; I love Ohrbach's in the fall" is the bi-annual refrain of French and Italian fashion aficionados in New York. Twice a year, the Thirty-fourth Street store shows reproductions of the haute couture to a loyal and increasingly large audience.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Senator John F. Kennedy hit a jackpot of political friendliness today at a mass meeting of building trades union leaders from fifty states.
Two witnesses who testified against Fred J. Loughran at his extortion trial received suspended sentences yesterday for their parts in the conspiracy to short-weigh meat sales in Brooklyn.

Until now, Arthur Laurents has written four Broadway dramas ("Home of the Brave," "The Bird Cage," "The Time of the Cuckoo" and "A Clearing in the Woods") and two musicals ("West Side Story" and "Gypsy").
A Federal grand jury indicted six men and a corporation here yesterday for conspiracy to manipulate the market in the common stock of the Beilanca Corporation and to sell unregistered shares.

In the statesmanship of accommodation that has been going on recently as to city-state relations reports have been heard in Albany that an arrangement might be reached on a new approach to revision of the New York City Charter. While chances for such an arrangement may be debatable, the issue is important enough to warrant discussion.
Except for small imposts already announced, there will be no new or increased special taxes in the fiscal year beginning next July 1, Mayor Wagner promised yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 14 (UPI) -- Al Lawrence, who made a 9,500-mile trip from the University of Houston to win a berth on his country's Olympic track team, failed badly today in his first bid.
MASSAPEQUA, L.I., March 14 -- Oyster Bay Supervisor John J. Burns said today that the Town Board was negotiating for fifty-two acres of vacant land here as a future waterfront recreation area.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 14 -- Five non-betting races were held at Roosevelt Raceway today 33 qualifying events for the spring meeting opening next Monday. One race was for trotters, the others for pacers. There were thirty-two starters in all and twenty-one passed the tests.

Breezy Point, the summer colony on the western part of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, is planned to be converted into a huge, privately financed community that might house as many as 220,000 persons.

A TERRACE on the seventeenth floor of the Criminal Courts Building in Lower Manhattan is said to run a close second to the Botanical Gardens. In good weather, a stocky, middle-aged judge tends the flowers and sometimes sits looking at them by the hour.

"Thimayya of India: A Soldier's Life," by Humphrey Evans, which had been planned for publication this month by| Harcourt, Brace, will be issued April 11. It is a biography of Gen. K. S. Thimayya, India's Army Chief of Staff.
It was three months ago yesterday that Hulan E. Jack first walked into the District Attorney's office to talk about his affairs.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., March 14 -- A $5,000,000 fire that burned out of control for almost six hours destroyed the unoccupied nine-story Nautilus Beach Club here today. Five firemen were injured slightly.
TRENTON, March 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner named Charles W. Engelhard today to succeed Thorn Lord on the board of the Port of New York Authority.
Stocks opened a little higher yesterday, ran around in little circles for the rest of the day and closed with small gains in the averages.
A halt in further sales of allegedly unregistered securities by Matthew M. Fox and Television Industries, Inc., was sought yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Everett McKinley Dirksen called oysters, vines and fig trees to his aid today in a lonely battle for one segment of the Administration's civil rights bill.

Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for twelve months ended on Feb. 29. Operating revenues were $269,414,443, against $249,284,931 a year earlier.
A mixed reception greeted the city's proposed new zoning resolution yesterday at the first of seven public hearings to be held by the City Planning Commission.
ALBANY, March 14 -- A bill that would have prohibited the New York City Board of Health from requiring the dating of milk sold in the city was narrowly defeated in the Assembly tonight.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- Premier Khrushchev's departure for a state visit to France, delayed because of an attack of influenza, has been set for March 23, it was announced today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 14 -- The Roman Catholic Bishop of Skoplje, Macedonia, and four other persons, including two Catholic priests, will go on trial Thursday on charges of smuggling and illegal dealings in foreign currency, an official source said today.
TRENTON, March 15 -- Four-year-old Alice Marie can be adopted by her foster parents even though the state says she is too bright for them.

The Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company sold yesterday $25,000,000 of 40-year debentures to investment bankers led by Halsey, Stuart Co. on a bid of 101.26 for a 5 per cent coupon. This set an interest rate to the utility of 4.93 per cent.

Two steamship companies have discovered that it sometimes does not pay to underwrite research projects for the Federal Maritime Board. The companies financed a study the agency is now using to block their shipbuilding plans.
ALBANY, March 15 -- The Rockefeller Administration has filed a bill designed to increase the yield on investments of the seven pension funds of the state and New York City.
GENEVA, March 15 - Geneva's latest battle of the tables ended today when a Bulgarian politician sat down next to a Canadian general.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI) -- Following is the text of a joint United States-West German statement issued at the White House today after a conference between President Eisenhower and Chancellor Adenauer:
GENEVA, March 15 -- The Soviet bloc began its attack on the Western disarmament plan today in the opening minutes of the ten-nation disarmament conference.
LONDON, March 15 -- Prime Minister Macmillan declared tonight that Britain welcomed the growth of nationalism in Africa as she had in Asia. "We have done much to further it," he added.
BEDFORD, Mass., March 15 (UPI) -- The Air Force announced today that a new photography technique had produced maps of the moon showing its surface was "no more rugged than that of the earth."
A PSYCHIATRIST took Madison Avenue to task recently for making parents feel guilty over not keeping up with the Joneses.
Despite recurring rumors that some copper would be sold from, the Government's stockpile, no such action is contemplated at this time, a leading Government official said yesterday.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Plans to build a two-lane, $20,000,00 bridge across the Hudson River to connect the upstate cities of Newburgh and Beacon were announced today by Governor Rockefeller.

JACKSON, Miss., March 15 -- The open individual championship in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here was won today by Don Wolfson of Hudson, Ohio, who scored 400 match points in two sessions of play.
Earnings of the Borden Company on most of its foreign operations rose at a much faster pace last year than did earnings on its domestic operations, which also reached record levels.
LOGAN, W.Va., March 15 (UPI) -- Thirteen of eighteen miners entombed for more than a week, in a fire-ravaged mine near here were found huddled in death today.
IRISH tales, which can already be heard all over town, will be spun tomorrow at the Washington Heights branch of the New York Public Library, St. Nicholas Avenue and 160th Street.

The new disarmament conference at Geneva has begun with expressions of goodwill, including a pledge of cooperation from Premier Khrushchev. But the opening speeches show that despite a dozen years of talk the basic differences between East and West remain.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- The American Medical Association demanded today that a memorandum issued by the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations' Committee on Political Education be retracted.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Ten Midwestern Democratic Governors carried the "plight" of farmers to Capitol Hill today.

WHEN President Eisenhower named Fredrick McCurdy Eaton last December to head the United States delegation to the East-West disarmament conference in Geneva, a friend remarked that it seemed unusual that a Wall Street lawyer should be appointed to negotiate with the Russians.

Famous Bathrobe, Inc., a concern that maintains a showroom at 110 West Thirty-fourth Street, has leased an entire floor for the manufacture of bathrobes at 180 Varick Street. The lease, which involves 20,000 square feet of space, was negotiated by Gallant-Roth Co., brokers.
Simone and Francoise Pierrat, two young Frenchwomen who besides being sisters, are a 'cello and piano duo, made their New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
SALEM, Ore., March 15 -- Gov. Mark Hatfield appointed a lifelong Democrat on the State Supreme Court to the United States Senate today, leaving Mrs. Maurine Neuberger on the sidelines.

YESTERDAY (March 15,1960) THE GOVERNOR Opened American Legion poppy sale by receiving first poppy from Mrs. Ken E. Hack of Catskill. Opened Easter Seal drive in Albany area with Meg McBride, Miss Easter Seal of 1960.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The hope of mankind rests on the issue of the total disarmament talks initiated by Premier Khrushchev and the United States President. There is no other means of escape from the Frankenstein of A and H bombs.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- Old-crop wheat months continued their higher trend today on the Board of Trade with the May future climbing to a new high for the season. Gains were in major fractions of a cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 15 -- Four pale young Soviet Navy men in United States Navy dungarees landed by helicopter today on the San Francisco waterfront. They had been rescued by the United States aircraft carrier Kearsarge March 7 after forty-nine days adrift in the Pacific in a small disabled landing craft.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 15 (UPI) -- Directors of the Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie (Soo Line), the Wisconsin Central, and the Duluth, South Shore and Atlantic railroads reached agreement today on a plan to merge the three lines.

The possibility of higher commutation fares if the Long Island Rail Road lost freight traffic brought expressions of concern yesterday from representatives of New York City and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 15 -- At their meeting yesterday Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and Chancellor Adenauer devoted half of their discussion to the problems of Africa.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Governor Rockefeller signed into law today the bill making it a traffic infraction to drive an automobile while under the influence of alcohol.
TUNIS, March 15 -- A new military effort is expected by the Algerian nationalists in consequence of the hardening of the French position on a negotiated peace, according to indications here.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Administration's voting-referee plan was almost killed in the House of Representatives today. It was saved at the last minute.
Strength continued to prevail in all parts of the market for fixed-income investments yesterday.

The Metropolitan Package Store Association, Inc., was stayed yesterday from directing owners of Harlem liquor stores to buy their supplies only from a selected list of wholesale salesmen, mainly Negroes.

THERE have been many crises in painting in the last 100 years, and the cry that easel painting is finished has accompanied nearly every decade since the turn of the century. Yet there are still easel painters.

ANYONE with a salt tooth has little to worry about. There is small danger that the world supply of sodium chloride will be exhausted for the next millennium or two, if the Sterling salt mine in this area is used as a criterion.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 15 -- A spokesman for the maritime industry urged the Maritime Administration today to bolster the dwindling amount of ocean-borne cargo in United States-flag vessels by implementing a "crystal-clear mandate" in the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.

Continued long liquidation touched off stop-loss selling of potato futures early in the session yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The market firmed on short covering and trade buying, reflecting strengthen cash markets, Evening of holdings lowered prices from the highs of the day near the close.
Wall Street drowsed yesterday through a lackadaisical session of the New York Stock Exchange in which relatively light volume produced relatively wide gains for a number of key stocks.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Republican leaders confirmed today that President Eisenhower would ask Congress for authority to cut Cuba's quota of the United States sugar market if he found this action necessary in the national interest.

HAMILTON, Ohio, March 15 (AP) -- Karl R. Bendetsen, 52, an executive vice president of the Champion Paper and Fibre Company, was named president today.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A Labor Department official today forecast economic improvement at least through spring.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago Irvin Swartzberg, an advertising salesman, was squeezing lemons in the kitchen of his Chicago home. He had been muttering impatiently over the same chore for several mornings, ever since his doctor prescribed a daily glass of hot water with lemon juice before breakfast.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Proponents of the omnibus banking bill appeared ready to throw in the towel today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Leo Trachtenberg's letter published March 4 concerning automotive exhaust gases raises, several points.

Jack McCartan, who has been a saving grace for the last-place Rangers, will play for them for the last time this season when he guards the Blues' nets against the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game in Madison Square Garden tonight.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that Judge Edmund L. Palmieri of United States District Court here had signed a temporary restraining order enjoining Bertram Goldsmith, G.T. Ross and the firm of Goldsmith Ross from further violating the anti-fraud provisions of the Securities Exchange Act.
YESTERDAY (March 15, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Met with Republican Congressional leaders.
ALBANY, March 15 -- The Moore Commission asked the Legislature today for unquestionable power to give witnesses immunity from subsequent criminal prosecution.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Chancellor Adenauer of Germany was in Washington today, looking very dour and leathery. At 84, he is a physical phenomenon: strong, stubborn, elemental and timeless, like an old Indian chief.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey called tonight for the resignation of Paul M. Butler, chairman of the National Democratic Committee. He said Mr. Butler had taken sides in the race for the party's Presidential nomination.
DENVER, Colo., March 15 -- Mayor Wagner of New York charged tonight that the Eisenhower Administration was hurting workers, farmers, small business men and consumers.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Eisenhower reaffirmed today his determination that the people of West Berlin shall remain free.

The One William Street Fund, Inc., has stepped up its holdings of common stocks to 95 per cent of total net assets at the end of February, Dorsey Richardson, president, told yesterday's second annual meeting of the mutual fund.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Vice President Nixon has told friends he intends to ride the "high road" in the 1960 election campaign.
The Tricot Institute of America, Inc., has been, formed by the country's tricot fabric industry, manufacturers of most of the fabrics used in intimate apparel, for a wide-ranging promotion program.
LONDON, March 15 -- Stock market prices advanced again here today and virtually every section benefited from the more cheerful atmosphere.
The Continental League, widening its search for players, has agreed to subsidize a new minor league.

Boys High of Brooklyn proved it had anything but a one-man basketball team as it was forced to play without its star, Connie Hawkins, through the fourth period and managed to edge Wingate, 62 -- 59, before a crowd of 11,000 at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

St. Bonaventure routed St. John's, 106 -- 71, and Bradley wore down Dayton, 78-64, at Madison Square Garden last night. As a result of these quarter-final contests in the twenty-third annual National Invitation Tournament, there will be a most pressing engagement on the same court tomorrow night.

Following are the texts of remarks read yesterday at the opening of the East-West disarmament conference in Geneva for Premier Khrushchev and Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, and of addresses by Fredrick M. Eaton of the United States and Valerian A. Zorin of the Soviet Union (the texts of the statements by Messrs. Khrushchev and Zorin were transmitted by Reuters; the others were obtained directly by The New York Times):
A new teachers' organization, the United Federation of Teachers, is expected to be established formally here today.

The five-story building containing twenty-three apartments at 317 Crimmins Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Soltzer-Lampert, realty operators, to a client of Milton Freindlich. The property, including a plot 48 by 80 feet, was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $34,000.
BOWIE, Md., March 15 (AP) -- James B. Robertson's Giewith gained an upset victory in the spill-marred Belair Purse at Bowie today.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, March 16 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee has been officially declared reelected President of the Republic of Korea for the fourth consecutive term.

The nation's proved recoverable reserves of crude oil and natural gas liquids and natural gas were at new peak levels at the end of last year. According to reports issued by the American Petroleum Institute, such reserves amounted to 38,241,000,000 barrels.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 15 -- Ray Narleski lost the hop on his fast ball last year and a search party led by Tom Ferrick is helping him find it. The one-time relief king of the American League fervently hopes that the posse will have better luck than he himself did with an effective knuckler that he misplaced about a dozen years ago.
The city's first underground garage, tucked into a small hill in Brooklyn and sprouting a park on its roof, will open within two weeks.

Horacio Lafer, Brazilian Minister of Foreign Affairs, arrived here last night for talks with United States and Canadian officials on common action for economic development to bar communism from the Western Hemisphere.
DETROIT, March 15 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks clinched a Stanley Cup semifinal play-off berth in the National Hockey League with a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy approved today the nomination of Robert E. Wilson as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission after the former oil company executive took a public stand against full-scale resumption of nuclear tests.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 15 -- Dr. Jonas E. Salk, the developer of poliomyelitis vaccine, outlined to the San Diego City Council today impressive plans for a major center for basic scientific research here. But he ran into a small conflict with the University of California about real estate.

Archbishops, metropolitans and bishops of all the canonical Eastern Orthodox jurisdictions in the United States held a closed meeting here yesterday at which they took steps to establish a standing Conference of Orthodox Bishops in America.
A crew of structural iron workers began yesterday to relearn a skill unused in this area in twenty-two years -- spinning cable for a huge suspension bridge.
The Transit Authority tried out some equipment yesterday designed to clean half a century's accumulation of grease, grime and steel dust out of subway tunnels.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 15 -- Negro students carried out demonstrations in four South Carolina communities today, but no serious disorders were reported. The largest demonstration occurred in Orangeburg, a community of about 25,000, about thirty-five miles from Columbia.
TRENTON, March 15 -- A high consumption of alcohol by New Jersey residents has confronted the state with a major highway safety problem, 350 police chiefs and magistrates were told today.

"The Dandy: Brummell to Beerbohm," a study by Ellen Moers, will be issued April 7 by Viking. It is a look at the sartorially splendid type of gentleman from bis origin in Regency England to his "final blooming" in the Eighteen Nineties.

ACCRA, Ghana, March 15 -- Ghana announced tonight that she was strengthening her security forces following the aleged discovery of a plot in which neighboring "Togoland would he used as a base for an armed attack upon Ghana."
Jack Twyman, a former teammate of Maurice Stokes on the Cincinnati Royals, received the Sportsmanship Brotherhood award for outstanding sportsmanship yesterday at a luncheon at the Astor Hotel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: That leaders of the free world, and specifically the United States, are able to think and act creatively and boldly has been demonstrated by the Marshall Plan and subsequently by the development of technical assistance generally.
TOKYO, March 14 (Reuters) -- Arrangements by which Tokyo supplies credits in yen to overseas shipowners are helping Japanese shipyards get orders from under-developed countries.

ALTHOUGH a number of contemporary French novelists seem to be moral nihilists, mired up to their chins in disgust and despair, several of the most gifted are not. Among those who have written with passionate sincerity about moral issues are the late Albert Camus and Romain Gary, author of "A European Education."*
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 15 -- The United States is providing nearly $7,000,000 in economic aid to Haiti this fiscal year. The emphasis is on agricultural development.

Production of an irradiated polyethylene film, said to be the first of its type commercially successful, was announced yesterday by the Cryovac division of W.R. Grace Co. The film has exceptional shrinking qualities that were described as making possible new types of packaging.

THE Metropolitan Opera's new production of Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" was designed in part for Leonard Warren and Renata Tebaldi. At the premiere a fortnight ago Mr. Warren sang the title, role, and it turned out to be his last complete, opera Miss Tebaldi missed that performance but was in the cast with the baritone three nights later when "La Forza del Destino" ("The Force of Destiny") was played out in real life.

OLD BRIDGE, N.J., March 15 -- "They'll never regret it," Mrs. Richard Combs said this afternoon on learning that the State Board of Child Welfare had reversed its administrative staff and would let her and her husband adopt Alice Marie.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 15 -- It long has been a basic principle with Casey Stengel that if you want to impress your importance on a rival, there is nothing like putting fear in him right at the start.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 15 -- A common salt-water marsh mosquito -- Aedes sollicitans -- has now been identified as one of the carriers of the virus responsible for the outbreak of eastern viral encephalitis in New Jersey last year.

The city's revamped program for resettling families uprooted by public-works projects moved yesterday from the talking to the working stage.

LONDON. Chiefs of government, these days, function increasingly as their own foreign ministers and combine the role with that of political salesman. Should this trend continue, democracies like our own risk impairment of administrative efficiency.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation told striking shipyard workers yesterday to stop mass picketing at its Quincy, Mass., shipyard as a prerequisite to a new labor agreement.

Four hundred Queens residents received a promise yesterday of a special conference on their zoning problems after their leader had engaged in a pushing and shouting contest with a policeman at City Hall.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 15 -- One of baseball's batting giants, Frank (Lefty) O'Doul, is back at his favorite hobby -- teaching another generation of Giants the fundamentals of hitting.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March, 15 -- Four-engined planes of the Military Air Transport Service and troops and equipment of the Army's Strategic Army Corps were accumulating impressive arguments here today for a modernized and strengthened military air-lift capability.
Cotton futures moved 9 points (45 cents a bale) off to 5 points (25 cents) up yesterday in light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Another round ended yesterday in the four-year battle for control of Wall Street's smallest bank. But it seemed likely that the final bell had not yet been sounded.
Sales and earnings of the American-Marietta Company reached record highs in the quarter ended on Feb. 29, Robert E. Pflaumer, president, reported at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.

Judge Frederick van Pelt Bryan heard arguments yesterday on a defense motion for a mistrial in the Federal income-tax evasion proceedings against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies rose 4.3 per cent last month above their volume for February, 1959. Sales for the first two months of the year were 4 per cent higher than in the 1959 period.

Sales and earnings of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation last year set new records in sales and income for the tenth consecutive year, according to the annual report of Ernest Hart, president, and Paul L. Davies, chairman.

Provisional President Hoffa's dream of filling, and overflowing, Madison Square Garden with his teamsters and their families, there to hear him talk, turned out to be just another delusion of grandeur. In spite of the free bus transportation from the outlying areas, and all the advance ballyhoo, only about 8,000 of the 150,000 union members in the metropolitan area -- not to mention their families -- finally turned up.
ALBANY, March 15 -- A bill giving owners of motor scooters and motorcycles the right to park their vehicles at an angle instead of parallel to the curb was unanimously adopted by the Assembly today.
JERSEY CITY, March 15 -- Members of the Jersey City Commission were told today to "sit down like men and not spoiled children" to resolve their differences over budget cuts.

If there is morality in betting at the race track, then off-track betting is moral, the City Council was told yesterday. If one is immoral, so the argument went, the other is immoral; there cannot be a mixture of the two.
Earnings of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company in 1959 were 38 per cent greater than in 1958 and sales were up 18 per cent, the seventy-sixth annual report disclosed yesterday.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 15 -- The Government of Northern Ireland is making a determined effort to attract industrial plants.
The best-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final series in the National Hockey League will open next week in Montreal and Toronto, with the exact dates depending on the final league standing.

JACKSON, Miss., March 15 -- The chairman of the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here, Mrs. Louise Durham of Durant, Miss., is credited by the assembled bridge multitudes with doing a fine job of promoting and managing the tournament.

The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is suggested for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

THE "Candid Camera" portions of the "Carry Moore Show" on Channel 2 have been providing many laughs this season and last night's segment was one of the best.

The American Broadcasting Company has acquired television rights to National Collegiate Athletic Association football games for 1960 and 1961.

THE calm before the storms -- the sudden, flooding spring rain storms -- is the time when housewives should prepare to outwit nature. Weather authorities say that there are more than 1,000 flood-endangered urban communities in the United States.

The New York Housing Authority sold yesterday $27,125,000 of temporary loan notes to further four state-subsidized projects at an average interest cost of 2.76801 per cent.

STUART, Fla., March 15 -- Handling a rowboat in a brisk wind on a narrow, winding stream while trying to cast popping bugs and plugs for bass and snook is about like bowling on roller skates. There probably are people who can bowl on roller skates, but it is a sign of a misspent youth.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The House Armed Services Committee approved today, 34 to 1, a bill to curb high military officers from becoming salesmen for defense-production industries.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- A group of men's clothing manufacturers joined a union in the industry today in urging Congress to lift the $1 Federal minimum wage to $1.25 an hour.

The President yesterday sent to Congress proposals for new legislation to replace the present Sugar Act, which expires at the end of this year. As was indicated by earlier reports, the President has asked Congress for discretionary authority to change quotas assigned distant suppliers.
WASHINGTON, March 16 The upward movement in the economy came to a dead stop in February, two key economic indicators disclosed today.

The Park Association of New York City yesterday urged Mayor Wagner to appoint John A. Mulcahy, assistant executive officer of the Park Department, to succeed Robert Moses as Commissioner of Parks.

FAMILY controversy of a very special kind is being stimulated today as more and more couples become art conscious and desire fine works for their homes. Patrons and patronesses have been announced for the theatre party to be held at the April 21 performance of the musical "Greenwillow" at the Alvin Theatre. Proceeds will aid the Professional Children's School.
