WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Chancellor Adenauer called today for a plebiscite in West Berlin on a change in its status. The vote should be held before the East-West summit meeting scheduled to begin May 16, he said.

St. Bonaventure's and Providence, having already eliminated the No. 3 and No. 4 seeded teams, will go after the big ones tonight in the semi-final round of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

Plans for a New York Philharmonic tour of the Far West and Hawaii are at a standstill, pending negotiations with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. But the New York Philharmonic Society said yesterday that the orchestra would make a three-week tour of several cities, beginning Sept. 8.

The nation's largest freight-forwarding organization, The United States Freight Company, is negotiating for control of American Export Lines, one of the country's largest subsidized operators of passenger and cargo vessels.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- A meeting that may be the most important held here since the movie actors went on strike on March 7 is scheduled to be held here tomorrow. The session will be between the Screen Actors Guild and the Association of Motion Picture Producers, which represents the major studios.

About ninety breed winners at last month's Westminster show in Madison Square Garden were watched on film in Luchow's Restaurant yesterday by about as many admirers of dogs. The occasion was the public introduction of a motion picture, "Westminster 1960," before the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club meeting.
Blyth Co., Inc., and associated underwriters offered yesterday 500,000 common shares of Genesco, Inc., at $33.50 a share.

A thirty-seven-story office building will rise near Grand Central Terminal on the west side of Madison Avenue, between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets. The site has been acquired in the sale of the blockfront by the First National City Bank, the major tenant.

Sepp Ruschp, the president of the Mount Mansfield Company, which operates the Mount Mansfield and Spruce Peak areas at Stowe, Vt., is going to bid for the 1966 Federation Internationale de Ski (F.I.S.) world Alpine championships.

THIS is the day when Irish faces incite all sorts of pleasurable sentiments in the non-Irish. For those who feel the St. Patrick's Day parade is not enough, there are a number of shops that offer Irish products.

OKEECHOBEE CITY, Fla., March 16 -- Fishing the lonesome, nameless shallow ponds of the Kissimmee Prairie is an exercise in geography and geometry, to say nothing of the bug-eyed astonishment involved for the stranger.

In the summer of 1871, five brothers and some friends put together a circus and invited their neighbors of McGregor, Iowa, to attend a performance at 5 cents each. That was the beginning of the now famous circus, Ringling Brothers -- Barnum Bailey Combined Shows.
ALBANY, March 16 -- A bill authorizing restricted licenses for motorists whose driving privileges have been suspended or revoked was approved unanimously today by the Senate.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 16 -- Princeton's intercollegiate squash racquets champions defeated the Oxford-Cambridge team, five matches to one, today.
TEL AVIV, March 16 -- The Knesset debated today a Communist attempt to unseat Premier David Ben-Gurion because of his meeting in New York with Chancellor Adenauer.

JACKSON, Miss., March 16 -- Forty-four teams began, play today for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup and the national open team-of-four championship in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would make no "deal" with Governor Rockefeller's Republican administration to obtain state financial aid for the city.

The Gillette Safety Razor Company and the American Broadcasting Company disclosed yesterday a new year-round television sports program including college football, major league baseball and professional boxing.

GENEVA, March 16 -- The disarmament conference here has become a little like a playwright's nightmare. Two sets of actors stand center stage facing the audience, reading at the top of their lungs from scripts.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Atomic Energy Commission, in the face of some complaints from private industry, staked out a continuing role for its laboratories today as pioneers in discovering and developing new uses for atomic energy.
BEFORE designing anything from a cooking pot to the interior of an automobile, Harley Earl talks with women:
PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Fourteen concerns and eighteen individuals were arraigned today in United States District Court on charges of having fixed prices in the sale of heavy electrical equipment.

The city was again unable yesterday to serve a summons on Joseph Di Girolamo, and the trial of his brother Michael was postponed for the fifth time despite tenant protests that they still had no heat.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- There were indications, today that the Administration was prepared to compromise on its request to Congress for Presidential stand by power to cut Cuba's quota of the United States sugar market.

A famous name is about to disappear from the New York Stock Exchange, providing stockholders of the Madison Square Garden Corporation and Graham-Paige Corporation approve a proposed merger at meetings on April 6.
A leading copper producer and an aircraft company have joined with a West German cable maker to form a new company, United States Under-seas Cable Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The President at his news conference today strongly implied his belief that personal service establishnents, privately owned, such as hops and taverns, neither act unconstitutionally nor deprive others of their constitutional guarantees when they decline to serve Negroes or any other group they may select.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Sharp questioning and wrangling between Democrats and Republicans marked the long-delayed appearance today of Secretary of Defense Thomas S. Gates Jr. as a witness before the Senate Preparedness sub-committee.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that preparations were being made to conduct an underground nuclear test to determine the feasibility of using nuclear explosives for peaceful purposes.

The gala opening of the American Ballet Theatre's twentieth anniversary season at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 19 and the Red Roses Ball at the Versailles Suite of the Astor after the performance will benefit the company.

ONE of his hobbies was photography. He used to come into this building festooned in cameras of awesome calibers and intricacy. Those of us who had not yet quite mastered picture-taking with a Brownie were appreciatively impressed. Yet we knew that no one needed less such stuff to capture the places, moods and people of the passing scene.
A carved table attributed to Paul Gauguin was picked up at a small New York auction house about three years ago for $15. Today, the piece will be offered at $50,000.

Electric power production in the nation climbed to a six-week high in the week ended last Saturday. The output, at 14,271,000,000 kilowatt-hours, compared with 14,262,000,000 the week before and 12,996,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year ago, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

Stocks made good gains but faltered yesterday. Prices were higher at the start and pushed ahead for most of the day but started to slip an hour before the close. The averages retained only two-thirds of their gains.

Judge Frederick van Pelt Bryan overruled yesterday a defense motion for a mistrial in the Federal income-tax proceedings against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. However, he restricted the Government's case by barring any testimony on alleged overstatement of expenses in 1952.

As far as could be ascertained yesterday, a couple of problems are bothering the Circle in the Square triumvirate of Leigh Connell, Theodore Mann and Jose Quintero. The difficulties stem from their heralded Broadway productions of works by Eugene O'Neill, whose "Iceman Cometh" (revival) and "Long Day's Journey Into Night" were expertly staged by Mr. Quintero for his group.
ATLANTA, March 16 (UPI) -- Biracial committees, several of them appointed during recent disturbances, are functioning in many Southern cities in efforts to ease racial friction.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The President's Committee on Government Contracts decided today to press its anti-discrimination campaign in all Government construction.
JACKSON, Miss., March 16 -- Last week comment was made in this space on the preponderance of names beginning with S among the highest-ranking married couples who play in tournament bridge.

MANILA, March 16 -- President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines gave assurances today that the controversial Filipino First policy of his Administration would not lead to the expropriation of foreign investments.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 16 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts, whose Democratic Presidential hopes rest on forging quickly a series of firm alliances, met with a group of West Virginia "neutralists" today.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in coat. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 16 (AP) -- The Boston Red Box today traded Sammy White, a catcher, and Jim Marshall, an infielder and outfielder, to the Cleveland Indians for a left-handed-hitting catcher, Russ Nixon.

It was in April of last year that Secretary of Labor Mitchell made his well-remembered wager that unemployment, then standing at 4,362,000, would fall below the three-million mark by October (the month the number of jobless is normally at its low point of the year). He lost his bet and publicly made good his promise to "eat his hat on the front steps of the Labor Department Building."
MOSCOW, March 12 -- The Soviet Communist party is concerned about the fitness and qualities of new members.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Department of Agriculture proposed today an average reduction of 19 per cent in the rates it pays commercial concerns for storing and handling grain under "the Federal farm, price support program.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The recent proposal of Dr. John Theobald for "teachers-emeritus" is designed to achieve a break-through in the teacher shortage, which has already reached monumental proportions. The assumption, is that the problem can be solved by recruiting an adequate number of teachers, new and retired, to man the schools.

MORGANTOWN, Pa., March 16 (AP) -- Nine Amish farmers refused last night to pay $19 each in fines and costs for failing to send their children to school. They are serving a five-day sentence in the county jail.

BONN, Germany, March 16 -- The published results of the talk between President Eisenhower and Chancellor Adenauer in Washington left a strong impression here today of a stiffened United States position for the Berlin negotiations in the coming East-West summit conference.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : During the last four years I have lived in Puerto Rico, close to the American people and within the sphere of direct influence of your system of government. This has made it possible for me to study and evaluate, with better elements of judgment, some of the traits of the United States Government which perhaps might escape the observation of a European living in Europe.
In a major shift, the Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it was taking its Dodge Car and Truck division accounts to Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc.
THE subject of suicide was examined in an authoritative dramatization on "Circle Theatre" over Channel 2 last night.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 16 -- The largest United States aid program in Haiti, a $4,300,000 irrigation project, has been suspended.

BILBAO, Spain, March 2 -- Basque nationalism, though mocked by some Basques and repressed by the Franco regime, is still being financed by local business men and by Basque sympathizers in Latin America.
Vice President Nixon, who as a youth proclaimed the attractions of a gaming wheel to carnival-goers in Arizona, received a gold membership card here yesterday as an "honorary barker."
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Eisenhower made it clear today that he wanted Vice President Nixon as the next President of the United States.
GREENWICH, Conn., March 16 -- A marked change in the pattern of Fairfield County's industrial growth was reported today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- The Washington Senators arrived in this juvenile haven today, bringing with them the solution to their short-stopping problem. Cookie Lavagetto isn't aware of it yet but Cookie is only the manager, a realist who insists on being shown. If the man would only listen, though, he could stop worrying.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Administration has no intention of granting the request of Chancellor Adenauer for compensation for German property seized during World War II, officials said here today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- If television viewers wonder whether there ever will be a decline in the volume of repeats and reruns on the home screen, the answer is strongly in the negative.
BOWIE, Md., March 16 (UPI) -- Cyprian Cat won the feature race today while snow again hit the beleaguered Bowie race track. Snow twice had halted racing at Bowie in the past two weeks.
Savings banks and insurance companies investing widely in out-of-state mortgages were advised yesterday to precede their purchases with a careful analysis by legal experts.
STRETCH pants, with their sleek, second-skin look and elastic fit, have done as much for skiing in this country as snow on the mountain sides.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that a preliminary check showed an "alarming" increase of 7 per cent in crimes against the person in the nation's larger cities.

MANILA, March 16 -- Gabriel (Flash) Elorde brought the Republic of the Philippines its first world championship tonight when he knocked out Harold Gomes of Providence in the seventh round of a scheduled fifteen - round junior - lightweight title bout.

LEGEND says that dates grew in the Garden of Eden and records show that they flourished on the banks of the Nile 8,000 years ago. This sacred fruit of the Moslems is still cultivated and exported from Middle Eastern regions in sizable quantities.

The nations of the West must work for economic solidarity, both to sustain Western prosperity and to meet the challenge of less developed nations, the president of the International Chamber of Commerce said here last night.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 9 points (45 cents a bale) off yesterday.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 16 -- Carl Michael Yastrzemski Sr. should be the happiest potato farmer in the United States today.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Does "unusual hospitality" mean the same thing to all persons?
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Democratic liberals won a small civil-rights victory today in the House of Representatives.
PARIS, March 16 -- In defiance of President de Gaulle, a majority of the National Assembly asked today for a special session to consider rural unrest.
PARK RIDGE, N.J., March 16 -- The Ides of March and the anniversary of Caesar's death were observed last night by the Latin Club of the Park Ridge High School with a Roman banquet.

The Metropolitan Opera gave its fine revival of Beethoven's "Fidelio" the sixth and last performance, of the season last night. Again Karl Boehm conducted, and all but one of the principals were those who sang their respective parts in earlier performances.
A pert little auto with patent leather fenders moved silently in Central Park yesterday with the help of California sunshine and Consolidated Edison electricity.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., March 16 -- A 16-year-old junior at the Wheatley School solemnly intoned the words "incipiatur supplicatio" and a procession of toga-clad teen-agers and teachers marched into the gymnasium here tonight to celebrate the life and death of Julius Caesar.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that its export subsidy on raw cotton would be cut from 8 cents to 6 cents a pound on Aug. f, the start of the 1960 crop marketing year.
LONDON, March 16 -- Hugh Gaitskell's campaign to clarify arid modernize the aims of the Labor party ended tonight in compromise and confusion.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 16 -- New Jersey's mosquito fighters were reported today to have developed a program to meet any emergency in the forthcoming pest season similar to the outbreak of eastern encephalitis in the state last year.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- The butcher hog market here advanced to an eight months' high of $16.85 a hundred pounds today as prices rose as much as 75 cents. It was the broadest one-day gain in several weeks.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 16 (UPI) -- The Cain Hoy Stable's One-Eyed King rallied midway in the $12,450 Green Valley Handicap today to defeat Amos II by a half length at Gulfstream Park.
The city's Commission on Intergroup Relations found yesterday that complaints of anti-Catholic bias in The Phoenix, a student publication at Queens College, were justified.
Americans were urged yesterday to regard trade competition as a stimulus to increased collective strength of the Western industrialized nations.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Treasury said today that interest rates had not declined far enough to permit it to sell long-term bonds within the legal ceiling of 4 1/4 per cent or interest rates.

Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel left for England last night expressing confidence that "men of goodwill will work tirelessly for peace among all nations in the Middle East and in all other parts of the world."

Insurance Co. of No. America Shareholders of the Insurance Company of North America at their annual meeting yesterday approved a proposal to increase authorized capital stock to 15,000,000 shares from 10,000,000. This would provide for a planned 100 per cent stock dividend.

In the compact car race, the Ford Motor Company's Falcon continued to outsell the second-running Rambler of the American Motors Corporation. Through the first ten days of March this year, 80,433 Falcons were sold, compared with 72,113 Ramblers.

The terrorism in Argentina and the strong measures being taken by the Frondizi Government to repress the Peronists are disturbing phenomena. They show the depth of the unrest, the continuing strength of Peronism, the growing threat of communism, the discontent of labor and the power of the military forces. These are all elements of political instability and a danger to Argentine democracy.

STARVED ROCK STATE PARK, ill., March 16 -- The wives of three prominent Chicago executives were found beaten to death today. The bodies, partly disrobed, were in a cave at the bottom of a canyon in this snow-covered, 1,470-acre state park, a popular vacation area.
NATHAN GOLDSTEIN, the young American violinist who has been absent from the local scene for a few years, returned last night for a Town Hall recital.

The State Public School Building Authority of Pennsylvania announced plans yesterday for the sale of $16,022,000 of school lease revenue bonds. Bids for the issue will be taken by the authority on April 6.
ALBANY, March 16 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Comemrce Department:

CHICAGO, March 16 -- Frank W. Jenks, president of International Harvester Company, announced today that sales volume so far this year had been slightly below expectations but that the company still expected 1960 to be a "good year" for sales.
European visitors to the United States exhibit at the International Horticultural Exposition, which opens in Rotterdam on March 25, will learn something new about American design and living.

Tribute to the Irish The enthusiasm with which so many of us, regardless of national origin, become "Irish" today only in part is lecause of the infectious gaiety of he proceedings, highlighted by the annual St. Patrick's Day parade.

Gross output of crude petroleum and condensate in the week ended last Friday averaged 7,049,060 barrels a day. This was 103,750 barrels fewer than a week earlier. It compared with the production of 7,154,520 barrels in the 1959 week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Bids outstripped offerings in the bond market again yesterday. The demand improved prices of Government securities by as much as 18/32 of a point and those of high-grade corporate obligations by about 1/4 point.
PARIS, March 16 -- Airlines will offer a seventeen-day round-trip excursion fare next winter between New York and London for as low as $320 aboard propeller craft and for $350 by jet.
Aggressive short-covering and trade buying of potato futures touched off stop-loss purchasing yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

A state commission announced yesterday it would not support its own proposal to ease the city's borrowing power unless new borrowing safeguards were agreed upon with City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.
Snow started to fall in the metropolitan area last night, and the Weather Bureau predicted that it would continue in some sections until nearly noon today.
The Corn Products Company in 1959 had the highest sales and earnings from operations in its fifty-three-year history, according to the annual report of William T. Brady, president.

AS the Metropolitan Opera season nears its end "last performances" are becoming more frequent. Last night it was the turn of "Rosenkavalier" and the Richard Strauss opera had its sixth and final performance of 1959-60.

New highs for the lives of the potato contracts were established on record volume yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The active April and May positions climbed 21 and 22 points (hundredth of a cent a pound), respectively.

ONE dress designed and made in a Paris couture salon can have a dizzy destiny. A private customer can buy it for hundreds of dollars. So can a New York store for an even higher price and then duplicate it by the dozens in a cheaper fabric and call it a "line-for-line copy."

WHITE PLAINS, March 17 -- The Westchester District Attorney's office reported today that more than 100 high school and college students in communities near Long Island Sound had been using narcotics at dances and parties for the last six months.

JOHN WEITZ, whose crystal ball has been working overtime, sees women of the future wearing only two kinds of clothes, which he calls "unders" and "overs" Labeled "Wardrobe X," and presented yesterday to the press, the idea was composed of parts to be worn next to the skin (unders) and a part to be worn next to the air (overs).
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he accepted the tag of "Labor Senator" because he agreed with the goals of unions.

The Small Business Administration, the Federal agency set up in 1953 to provide financial aid to the "little fellow," has made some 19,000 business loans totaling $882,000,000 since its inception. This and other pertinent information was disclosed in an interview yesterday by Philip McCallum, Small Business Administrator. Mr. McCallum succeeded Wendell B. Barnes as head of the agency last November.
Twenty years away from the easel on which he daubed canvas With color in dingy Greenwich Village lofts, Paul Newman has created his masterpiece.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The naval attache of the Cuban Embassy resigned today and charged that the Cuban Government was "under the most absolute influence of international communism."

Boys High was almost frozen out of its second consecutive Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday. The Brooklyn team defeated Columbus, 21 -- 15, but for minutes at a time everything, including the Madison Square Garden clock, stopped cold.

ST. LOUIS, March 17 (AP) -- Led by Elgin Baylor's 40 points, the Minneapolis Lakers defeated the St. Louis Hawks, 120 -- 113, tonight, squaring the National Basketball Association Western play-off series at one game apiece.

Sales and earnings of the Corning Glass Works in 1959 were the highest in the 108-year history of the company, according to the annual report yesterday of William C. Decker, president. The company is a leading manufacturer of specialty glasses and ceramics.
A cab driver confessed early today to the hit-and-run death of a 4-year-old girl in West Harlem on Feb. 24, the police said.

A former private secretary to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. testified yesterday that he had directed her to transfer certain apparently nondeductible income tax items to deductible categories in his financial records.

A VERY ISLAND, La. THIS bit of land called island is not an island at all. It is a gently rising low hill surrounded by marshlands, a swampland and the Petit Anse Bayou. It is principally famous for three things -- its oil wells, its salt mine and the hot pepper sauce known as Tabasco.

The second game in the world championship chess match between Mikhail Botvinnik of Russia, the defending titleholder, and Mikhail Tal of Latvia was played yesterday at the Pushkin Theatre in Moscow before another large throng, according to a report reaching here last night through Soviet news sources.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Five weeks of Senate debate produced today the first section of a new civil rights bill.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 17 -- After a sixteen-hour debate the Puerto Rican Senate passed a resolution today condemning what Popular Democratic party leaders have described as undue intervention by President Eisenhower in Puerto Rican politics.
ALBANY, March 17 -- The Assembly passed by a narrow margin today a bill requiring a year's residency in the state for relief eligibility.
ALBANY, March 17 -- Relief from the noise of commercial jet planes is the objective of two bills that were approved unanimously by the State Senate today. The measures now go to the Assembly.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 17 -- In a decision that could have a far reaching affect, Superior Court Judge J. Wallace Leyden has upheld a contention by the state that all tidelands inundated at mean high, tide are owned by the state.

STUART, Fla., March 17 -- A good game warden has got to be a man who believes serenely that the game laws are right and that he is right, but he needs a strong native caution, too, especially when he tackles a woman with a powerful natural talent for legal definition.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Chancellor Adenauer left Washington for Los Angeles today after three days of top-level talks.
MONTREAL, March 17 (UPI) -- Two last-period goals by Gary Edmundson, a rookie, helped the Toronto Maple Leafs gain a 6-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight in the National Hockey League.

Muzz Patrick, the manager of the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League, yesterday announced the signing of Alf Pike as coach of his team for the campaign of 1960-1961. Pike joined the club on Nov. 12, succeeding Phil Watson.

EVEN the tellers of tall fishing tales must have been put off by the weather of recent weeks. Apparently those who fish for a living also have found conditions far from their liking, to judge from the small supplies reaching this city.
Underwriters managed by Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and Equitable Securities Corporation offered yesterday $4,000,000 of 5 per cent first mortgage bonds of Mississippi Power Company.
A television broadcaster reported last night that General issimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina of the Dominican Republic had told him "you'll know I'm retired when you hear that I'm dead."
CHICAGO, March 17 -- A veteran Superior Court judge and a business man were among the prominent persons who perished today in the crash of a North-west Airlines plane in southern Indiana.

Now that Tennessee, Williams is awaiting the November arrival here of his next play, "Period of Adjustment," he is already working on another one called "A Night of the Iguana." Actually, it is a full-length treatment of a short play running an hour and twenty minutes, that was performed at last summer's Spoleto (Italy) Festival.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 17 -- World exports established a new record of $150,000,000,000 in 1959, surpassing by 4 per cent the previous high set in 1957, a United Nations statistical office reported today.

A development that promises to open up a new market for 500,000 tons of asbestos fiber each year for use in asphalt road pavings was disclosed by the Johns-Manville Corporation at the annual meeting yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.
Cotton futures closed, unchanged to 35 cents a bale off yesterday in slow trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- The business of plugola, the technique of embellishing a television program with extra commercials not paid for by the show's sponsor, is experiencing a recession.

Time magazine announced yesterday that Roy Alexander, managing editor of the news weekly since 1949, had been appointed to the post of editor. Otto Fuerbringer has been named managing editor and Thomas Griffith assistant managing editor.

ALBANY, March 17 -- A plan to force Democratic legislators to support stand-by telephone tax legislation by including it in the same bill with financial aid to New York City was disclosed today by the Republican legislative leaders.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 17 -- A study of racial attitudes among white persons in Southern Rhodesia has disclosed a willingness to grant Africans more political and economic opportunities but an insistence on segregation.
New York State taxpayers who have attached withholding statement IT-2102 to their Federal income tax returns will wonder where the yellow form went when they prepare their state income tax returns.

A woman in red standing in the official reviewing stand at Sixty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, her cloak soggy and the great gold chain of her office glittering dully in the rain, had only graceful praise for the city's annual and zany metamorphosis into Irishness yesterday.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 17 -- The San Francisco Giants' National League pennant hopes still depend heavily on the WOW boys -- Willie, Orlando and Willie.

A dispute over hours of flying duty has arises between Pan American World Airways and the pilots of its pistonengined planes. It was precipitated by recent Government demands that two pilots be on duty in airline cockpits at all times.
The Sheltering Arms Children's Service will benefit from a spring tea dance to be held in the ballroom of the Pierre on April 24.
The Sanitation Department introduced something new to help the St. Patrick's Day sloshers on Fifth Avenue yesterday -- motorized squeegees to clear the street of slush.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Once again Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman, has succeeded in embroiling the party it is his principal duty to compose on a common front against the Republicans. His many past performances of the same kind make it impossible to come to a confident conclusion whether they are deliberate, with full awareness of their consequences, or are involuntary reactions from sudden and irresistible impulse.

New York University yesterday announced plans to construct two residence halls for students at its Washington Square Center.
HONG KONG, March 17 -- A Roman Catholic Bishop, Ignatius Kung Pin-mei, was sentenced in Shanghai today to life imprisonment for treason.

DUBLIN, March 17 -- The weather and many Dubliners had one thing in common today -- both were dry.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 17 -- The last political meetings of the three-month election campaign were held tonight. The election is Saturday.

IN lieu of a new drama, Katharine Cornell and Brian Aherne are appearing in an intelligent adaptation of the letters between Mrs. Pat Campbell and Bernard Shaw. "Dear Liar" is the title Jerome Kilty has applied to the script.
TUNIS, March 17 -- Contrary to diplomatic usage, the Tunisian Government is holding a pick-and-shovel party in the garden of the French Ambassador without invitation.
ALBANY, March 17 -- Legislation revising the residency requirements for members of the New York City Board of Education was approved unanimously in the Senate today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Thank you for printing my letter on March 6 concerning flood control and water conservation for the upper Allegheny River. I wish to correct an omission which occurred.

THE exhibition of "American Romantic Landscape Painting" at the Kennedy Galleries is not, aside from its including a fine, unsleepy late Inness, an outstanding affair. But it is a pleasant one, re-enacting the progress of native artists as they gradually freed themselves from European conventions, and began to see that America had a face all its own, and not one of which Claude or Richard Wilson had ever dreamed.
Simone Signoret will make her American television acting debut May 15 on the "General Electric Theatre" over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

TUNIS, March 17 -- The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government was reliably reported today to have offered "about a month ago" to send a spokesman, to Paris to meet President de Gaulle or an authorized French representative.
They think of everything, these purveyors of yachting gear, gadgets and gimmicks -- even the matter of seasickness.

GENEVA, March 17 (AP) -- Most of the brief opening session of the United Nations conference on the law of the sea today was taken up by Soviet-bloc protests against the failure to invite Communist China, East Germany, North Korea and North Vietnam.
The dynamic Marc B. Rojtman indicated yesterday he had resigned as president and director of the J.I. Case Company last month because the Case board's sales goal was too conservative for him.
What is reported to be a treasury of hitherto unpublished melodies by Jerome Kern was disclosed yesterday.
Reform Democrats on Manhattan's West Side united last night behind a candidate to oppose Representative Ludwig Teller in the June 7 primary.

Bradley University's basketball team again proved last night that it must be rated with the nation's best by defeating St. Bonaventure, 82 -- 71, in a National Invitation Tournament semi-final. The setback was the first for the Bonnies in nineteen games.

LONDON, March 17 -- John Hay Whitney, United States Ambassador to Britain, cautioned a British-American audience today against believing all the pessimistic reports about "the present state of America's health."

Bantam Books, Inc., publisher of paper-backs, has leased two floors at 271 Madison Avenue, between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Street, from the Thibaut Realty Company. Robert Joseph Co. and Huberth Huberth, Inc., were the brokers.

The elegant Charles Gregory Cannon, who has been living it up at the rate of $10,000 a month and sporting a broad British accent, a silver-handled cane and sundry disguises, met some agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday.

Sylbern Properties, Inc., has contracted to sell the six-story building with seventy-two apartments at 255 Seventy-ninth Street, Brooklyn. The buyers are a syndicate of investors who are paying for cash over mortgages amounting to $285,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is with sadness that one reads and hears of the recent rash of Negro passive resistance protests against segregation in the United States. It is sad because it seems incredible that in the year 1960 the Negro is forced by white segregationists to resort to demonstrations to obtain full citizenship rights.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday two loans -- one for a project in Japan and the other in Mauritania -- totaling $106,000,000.

At a meeting with Governor Rockefeller yesterday Mayor Wagner asked for modification of a proposed state-city agreement that would make a potential of $82,000,000 in additional revenues available to the city.

One-sixth of one per cent of our total population: this was the figure which President Eisenhower suggested yesterday as a basis for annual immigration into this country. This comes to approximately 300,000 persons, or about twice as many as our antiquated immigration laws now permit. To this quota might be added, as the President suggests, "authorization for the parole into this country of refugees from oppression."
ALBANY, March 17 -- Following is the vote by which the Assembly today approved, 7.7 to 70, a bill to require all relief recipients to be residents of the state for a year or more:

Eighty bicycle, tricycle and wagon wheels, a piano of sorts, some metal drums, an addressing machine, a child's cart, an enameled bathtub, a meteorological trial balloon, a bunch of bottles, and a certain amount of material picked up in city dumps in New Jersey, all painted white, were scheduled to commit mutual murder and suicide by sawing, hammering and melting one another in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art last evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 -- Dr. Edward Teller contended today that atomic explosions equivalent to that at Hiroshima could be hidden. He made his statement on the basis of new data from underground explosions of conventional highr-explosive material.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- "If I had won the Masters championship in 1956," said Ken Venturi, "I never would have turned pro."
James P. Warburg last night renewed his attack on the United Jewish Appeal's fund-distributing policies, asserting that much of the money raised was diverted to other than charitable purposes.

The Rev. Dr. Mark Wayne Williams, formerly pastor of the Hanson Place Baptist Church in Brooklyn, died on Wednesday at the Veterans Administration Hospital at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn. He had observed his eighty-fifth birthday on Sunday.
GENEVA, March 17 -- The Soviet Union expressed today its regret over the United States' announcement that it was considering an underground nuclear explosion next year.
AMMAN, Jordan, March 17 -- King Hussein announced yesterday that he would agree to a plebiscite among former Palestinians living in Jordan to decide the future of Jordan's West Bank.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A thirty-four-man delegation of the National War College will soon visit Moscow.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 17 (AP) -- John B. Hussey, a member of the Federal Power Commission, died here today. He was in San Antonio to make a speech. He was 53 years old.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The statements made by Bishop James McManus of Ponce in his letter to The Times published March 10 about Puerto Rico's political status reveal that Bishop McManus does not take pains to be well-in-formed juridically.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Adverse weather at many points on the Eastern seaboard resulted in decreased freight loadings last week.
MINEOLA, L I., March 17 -- The Long Island Rail Road yesterday settled for $1,500 a false-arrest suit Drought by a man arrested for not paying a 3 cent Federal ticket tax.

Believe it or not, the consumer, whether a fickle housewife, a teen-ager with many buying desires, or the man of the house with varied wants, turns out to be a more stabilizing influence on the economy than the conservative business man.
Student journalists from thiry-five states swarmed over the campus of Columbia University yesterday as the thirty-sixth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association opened.
The bond market lost much of its recent bullish momentum yesterday without sacrificing its basic appearance of firmness.

MANILA, March 13 -- A generation ago, when the Philippines were under United States jurisdiction, any Filipino who hoped to make his mark in the world wore a white linen suit and shirt and tie to the office, even if he was a low-paid clerk in a Government bureau.
ALEX KATZ is a peaceable artist whose simplifications of his experience with people, seascapes and the countryside are on view at the Stable Gallery,-924 Seventh Avenue, at Fifty-eighth Street.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Government started a major drive to promote exports today.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming is seriously considering a voluntary insurance plan for medical care of the aged, subsidized jointly by Federal and state governments.
AN unusual filmed interview with Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo of the Dominican Republic was shown last nght over Channel 2.
The annual luncheon for the Lots for Little Thrift Shop, 1343 Third Avenue, will be given this year by the St. Paul Guild, Inc., 4 East Seventy-third Street.
ALBANY, March 17 -- The Assembly passed and sent to the Senate tonight a bill to require public hearings before the sponsor of a slum clearance project can make substantial changes in it or sell it.

ASPEN, Colo., March 17 (UPI) -- Jack Morbeck of Kellogg, Idaho, and Barbara Ferries of Houghton, Mich., captured the boys' and girls' downhill titles today at the opening of the national Alpine ski championships on Aspen Mountain.
A merry, indomitable people -- the Irish -- marched here yesterday despite the worst St. Patrick's Day weather since 1932.

TELL CITY, Ind., March 17 -- A Northwest Airlines turboprop plane blew up in flight today killing all sixty-three persons aboard. A second explosion followed as the craft's fuselage plunged into an Ohio River hill country farm and disintegrated.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Ezra Taft Benson declined today to follow President Eisenhower's ead and endorse Vice President Nixon for the Republican Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 6 per cent below the year-ago level.

A mandatory requirement that 50 per cent of the nation's oil imports be carried in United States-flag tankers would immediately add more than $100,000,000 in costs to the country's annual fuel bill, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Eisenhower urged Congress today to double the number of quota immigrants accepted each year and to authorize the entry annually of at least 10,000 refugees from oppression and persecution.
A fifteen-block area on Manhattan's Upper West Side was designated by the City Planning Commission yesterday for extensive neighborhood rehabilitation and conservation.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Federal Communications Commission disclosed today that it had found illegal payola "prevalent" in many forms in radio and television stations.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- The Yankees caught it fore and aft today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has had to raise $40,000 to defend students arrested in lunch-counter demonstrations, its chief counsel said today.
GENEVA, March 17 -- More than eighty nations met here today to attempt to find a compromise agreement on how far to sea a coastal nation can claim sovereign rights.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Eisenhower's remarks yesterday about the lunch-counter controversy in the South tell a lot about his concept of the Presidency.

TRENTON, March 17 -- Two hundred and seventy families here face imminent rent increases and possible eviction and 1,548 others throughout the state soon will be in similar circumstances because of Gov. Robert B. Meyner's decision to veto a bill.

The West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association intends to raise the dividend rate from 3 3/4 to 4 per cent on regular savings accounts in the April-June quarter, Dr. Herman L. Reis, president, announced yesterday.
GENEVA, March 17 -- The East-West disarmament conference dropped opening-round formalities today and got down to the task of political probing.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Two proposed constitutional amendments designed to aid the establishment of a,new State Industrial Development Authority were given initial approval in the Senate today and sent to the Assembly.

BOSTON, March 17 -- Michigan Tech's fast-skating, hardchecking sextet trounced St. Lawrence, 13 -- 3, tonight and dimmed the East's hopes of breaking the West's stranglehold on the National Collegiate hockey title.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 17 -- Baby sitters in this suburban community have laid down the law to their employers in a sort of fair employment practices act, or "Where do they keep the diapers in this house?" rule.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Negotiators trying to end the actors' strike against the major movie studios here declined to say today how close they were to an agreement.
Starting with the purchase of equipment for supermarkets and other forma of American retailing, Finland has embarked on a program for a substantial increase of imports from the United States.

The New York State central school district composed of Poughkeepsie, La Grange, Pleasant Valley, Beekman, Union Vale, Hyde Park, Washington, East Fishkill, Wappinger, Pawling and Dover borrowed $2,799,000 in the bond market yesterday.

Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $131,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $726,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average reserves in excess of requirements increased by $121,000,000 from the week before to $486,000,000.

What seemed like a simple equation in Puerto Rican politics has -- to change the metaphor -- turned into a hornet's nest. President Eisenhower thought it natural when he stopped in Puerto Rico on his South American trip to show his favor for the Republican party associate, running in the Puerto Rican Governorship elections that take place in the autumn.
BEDFORD VILLAGE, N Y., March 17 -- A one-room country school among big Westchester County estates received a year's postponement of its death senence today.

LONDON, March 17 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel held unofficial talks today with British Government leaders on pressing problems confronting his nation.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Soybean and rye futures were under fairly heavy selling pressure today and led the setbacks in a generally weak market on the Board of Trade.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The Senate vote on bills to authorize state bank holding companies and the expansion of branch banking powers was put off today. A postponement was decided upon when Republican sponsors were unable to muster the votes to pass either bill.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- The Soviet Government is under strong pressure to alter its farm policies to give the peasant a larger and fairer share of the nation's economic pie.

LONDON, March 17 -- Share prices continued to advance or the stock exchange here today However, there was a modest reaction in late trading on Wall Street's failure to maintain its rise of the last few days.

The stockholders of the Gillette Company elected Charles F. Adams and Cecil F. Abderhalden to the board of directors at the annual meeting in Boston yesterday. The company makes shaving products, hair preparations and ball point pens.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 17 -- The legality of the slate of Republican delegates pledged to Vice President Nixon in California's primary election June 7 was challenged today on the floor of the Assembly. Republican members brought complaints into the open.

Fifteen private liberal arts colleges "that are high on academic standards but low on funds" will receive grants of $5,000 each from the C.I.T. Foundation. The colleges will have to match the grants in two years.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (UPI) -- A brilliant team effort darned the Philadelphia Warriors to a 115-110 triumph over the Boston Celtics tonight, squaring the best-of-seven series for the National Basketball Association's Eastern championship at one victory apiece.
JODRELL BANK, England, March 18 -- Princess Margaret pressed a button today and turned on the radio transmitter aboard the Pioneer V, sun satellite, a million miles away.
EVERYONE has contributed to the accuracy of Beverley Cross' "One More River," which opened at the Ambassador last evening.

CLEVELAND, March 18 (AP) -- Hayes Jones of Eastern Michigan romped over the 50-yard high hurdles in 5.9 seconds for a world record tonight in the twentieth Knights of Columbus Games. He defeated Lee Calhoun, 1956 Olympic victor, for the seventh straight time.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Philip W. Bonsal, United States Ambassador to Cuba, will return to his post "at an early date," the State Department announced tonight.

Governor Rockefeller proposed to the Legislature three weeks ago a new law that would prohibit racial and religious discrimination in the rental, sale or financing of private housing and in the sale or lease of commercial space. On residences its application would be limited to buildings containing three or more apartments or to a real estate development having ten or more housing units.

LONDON, March 18 -- Early hesitancy among the industrials was soon overcome in the stock market here today and prices closed at their best levels. Demand was not heavy but with sellers holding off rises of around 9 pence (10 1/2 cents) were common in most industrial share groups.

Mayor Wagner and his colleagues on the Board of Estimate will meet at Gracie Mansion tomorrow morning to discuss the $82,000,000 package of additional state aid offered to the city by Governor Rockefeller.
Men will not have to join the moles in dank catacombs to survive a nuclear attack, if a student project of the Cornell University College of Architecture points the way to the future.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Part of the Wagner administration program for combating youth crime still has a "fighting chance" to get through the Legislature, in the opinion of some ranking Republicans and Democrats here.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Another year of record or near-record production of crops appeared possible today. A Government survey showed that surplus-harassed farmers planned to plant about as many acres of cropland this year as last.

Negotiations leading toward an independent Cyprus have finally passed the silly stage. A Levantine haggle over customs on goods for British forces based there is now over. The only remaining question is the size of bases to which those forces shall be confined.

SEOUL, Korea, March 18 -- President Eisenhower was reported today to have refused to acquiesce in a proposal by President Syngman Rhee for a Soutt Korean military attack on Communist-held North Korea.
LONDON, March 18 -- Jeremy Fry will be best man at the wedding of Princess Mar- garet to Antony ArmstrongJones on May 6, Buckingham Palace announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Chancellor Adenauer has given assurances to victims of nazism that he will do all he can to obtain just compensation for those who suffered under the Hitler regime.

A 21-year-old Columbia University student was arrested yesterday in the hit-run death of a woman in Queens Thursday night. The police said the accident had happened less than a half-hour after the student was told by a passing patrolman that he was too drunk to drive.
The possibility of an industrial park on the site of Flushing Airport in Queens is to be studied by the Department of City Planning.

The resignation of Rufo Lopez-Fresquet as Cuban Finance Minister represents another significant milestone in the development of the Cuban revolution. Like all milestones, it is passed on the same road that has been traveled, in the case of Cuba, for almost fifteen months since New Year's Day, 1959.
New York's first television editorial on local affairs was presented last night over WCBS-TV.

GREAT NECK, L.I., March 18 -- Efforts to insure the passage of Governor Rockefeller's fair-housing bill will be undertaken next week in Albany, Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino of Long Beach said tonight.

The Howe Sound Company, which has diversified its activities into manufacturing, particularly in the metal field had a net income in 1959 of $6,631,739, equal to $2.37 a share, on sales and operating revenues of $83,714,817.
Student journalists in 500 private, public and parochial schools in thirty-five states heard professionals explain methods and problems in journalism yesterday.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 18 (UPI) -- The president of Oberlin College criticized the United States Supreme Court last night for having failed to "dig deeply" for pertinent facts in recent cases involving basic civil rights.

CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- Another setback in the grain futures market today dropped all rye contracts to new lows for the season and returned corn and soybeans to the fringes of their minimums for the season.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 -- New York University's gallant bid for the National Collegiate basketball title ended tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The dismissals of school teachers in California for alleged Communist affiliations was described here today as a development of an experiment by the House Un-American Activities Committee.

The National Council of Young Men's Christian Associations said yesterday that negotiations had been completed for what it described as the first official exchange of professional youth workers between the United States and the Soviet Union.
MILWAUKEE, March 18 -- The executive director of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's organization in Wisconsin said tonight that "scurrilous" anti-Catholic literature had been circulated in the state.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Four big horses and four long shots line up tomorrow in the $100,000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap. It will be the last big race for older thoroughbreds on Florida's racing calendar.
YESTERDAY (March 18, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Met with Treasury Secretary Anderson and economic advisers. Set up special emergency board to investigate threatened strike against Pan American Airways.
NORFOLK, Va., March 18 -- Government aid to American-flag shipping has given the nation a healthy merchant marine and thereby helped the national economy, a shipping executive said today.

IT would be interesting to know how many cookbool authors actually cook front their own books. One who ob viously does is blond, petite June Platt. Attesting to its hard usage, her copy of "The June Platt Cook Book" (Knopf, $5) is battle scarred and full of markers.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- United States scientists will attempt to map the earth precisely by taking readings from a satellite flashing intense light.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower created today a three-man emergency board to investigate a dispute between Pan American World Airways and some of its employes. The action was taken to head off a threatened strike.
MIAMI BEACH, March 17 -- Families of three generations can exist happily without sharing the same house, specialists on problems of family and aging suggested here.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 18 (UPI) -- Dan Toronski of Cleveland took second place in the singles and Ron Jones of Lansing, Mich., fourth place in the all-events of the American Bowling Congress tournament today.

LONDON, March 18 -- "The Future Labor Offers You" was the title of a pamphlet issued by the Labor party during last fall's election. Now, less than six months later, Britain's key political problem is whether the party itself has a future.

A London employment agency that has hopes of "exporting" English secretaries to this country ran into an unexpected snag yesterday. The State Commission Against Discrimination announced that it had started an investigation of the project.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The news dispatch from Manila which appeared March 12 by correspondent Jacques Nevard is one of the most fair and accurate accounts on the current Philippine political picture by a foreign correspondent.

BARCELONA, Spain, March 18 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco and Don Juan, Count of Barcelona and pretender to the Spanish throne, are planning to meet Monday at Ciudad Rodrigo, near the Spanish-Portugese border.
TELL CITY, Ind., March 18 -- Aviation experts started a search for clues today for the cause of the explosion that destroyed an airliner in flight yesterday, killing all sixty-three persons aboard.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's forces are ready to charge that Senator John F. Kennedy's record in Congress "makes him at best a fair weather friend of American agriculture."

LONDON, March 18 (AP) -- Top-seeded Judy Devlin of Baltimore and Margaret Varner of Wilmington, Del., won their matches today and set up an all-American final in the all-England women's badminton championships.
William L. Montgomery, flutist, with Harold M. Hirsh, pianist, gave a program of music for that instrumental combination last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
CHICAGO, March 18 --The Chicago office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation opened an inquiry today into the Tell City plane crash.

HIGHLAND PARK, N.J., March 18 -- Homes on South Adelaide Avenue here are normally dark after midnight. But for the last two weeks a light has shown through the kitchen window at the David Aaron house shortly after 3 A.M.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., March 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Gols have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annemarie Gisele Gols, to Rudolph E. Schutz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schutz of Mineola.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board renewed for seven years today the authority of New York Airways for its routes in the New York City area.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 18 (UPI) -- Eight Negro lunch-counter demonstrators offered themselves as "sacrificial lambs" today and chose sixty-day jail sentences instead of fines.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- William Presser, president of the Joint Council 41 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in Cleveland, Ohio, was fined $100 and sentenced to two months in jail today for contempt of Congress.
Stocks rose gently and fell gently yesterday, ending the day with little change, but on the upside.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- Something always happens when Chuck Dressen, the bustling new skipper of the Milwaukee Braves, comes to town. That's all right with Casey Stengel except that most of it happened to Casey's Bombers today.
GENEVA, March 18 (AP) -- The big Western maritime powers suffered defeat today on a significant procedural matter in the eighty-four-nation conference on the law of the sea.

TUNIS, March 18 -- The Algerian National Liberation Front offered to send a representative to Paris to meet President de Gaulle a month ago "without posing any prerequisite conditions or agenda of discussion," well-informed quarters said today.

A collection of letters from famous men to their children, exploring the meaning of the fatherly role, will be published March 28 by Rinehart. It will be titled "The Father." The book's 100 letters were chosen by Evan Jones, a free-lance writer and co-author of "Hidden America."
A 16-year-old high school senior who feels that loyalty oaths are a form of coercion has challenged a Board of Education loyalty requirement that dates to World War I.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Southern bloc in the House of Representatives, with Republican help, came within three votes today of a major victory in the civil-rights fight.

Four five-story buildings at 523 to 529 East Eighty-second Street, between East End and York Avenues, have been purchased by the East 55th Associates, builders. The buildings on a plot 109 by 102 feet, will be demolished to make way for an apartment house.

OTTAWA, Ill., March 18 (AP) -- There are "three fairly good suspects" in the slaying of three women from suburban Chicago, William Morris, head of the Illinois State Police, said tonight.
CHICAGO, March 18. (AP) -- The representative of Pope John XXIII in the United States said today that American Roman Catholics were pleased with the freedom enjoyed by their church in this country.

LOS ANGELES, March 18 (AP) -- One of the crucial questions of the future may be not how to keep Communist China out of the United Nations but how to keep her from staying out, Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today.

NEWTON, Ga., March 17 -- Voting-rights proposals before Congress promise the Negro little help when viewed in the framework of this Black Belt community. Elections in Baker County are considered "white folks' business."

MOORE HAVEN, Fla., March 18 -- It may not be so every year, but this year strong, constant winds are the curse of the Florida fresh water fisherman. It has been so for a couple of months and there are no signs of any change.

New York University captured four of the seven events last night to take a commanding lead over Pittsburgh, the defending champion, in the thirty-first annual Eastern collegiate swimming championships at the Violets' pool.

Federal judge Archie O. Dawson yesterday set April 14 for a hearing on final approval of an amended plan of reorganization for the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company. The plan was submitted by Herman T. Stichman, trustee for the road.

Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner engaged in a good-humored scramble over eggs and pancakes yesterday while sitting with two Boy Scouts on a rug in the Biltmore Hotel. A State Department official denied yesterday that President Eisenhower had been moved by election year political considerations in asking Congress to revise the immigration laws.
HONG KONG, March 17 -- Collective living is increasing in the cities of Communist China.

PARIS, March 18 -- President de Gaulle precipitated a conflict with Parliament today by refusing to call the National Assembly into special session to consider farm problems. The President defied a majority of the Assembly that had signified its desire for the session by sending in letters in conformity with the Constitution.
HAVANA, March 18 -- The Cuban Government accused "international interests" today of being responsible for the defection of Captain Pons Goizueta.

WHITE PLAINS, March 18 -- Joseph F. Gagliardi, District Attorney of Westchester County, was in a quandary today. He wondered how he could tell parents that their teen-age children were using narcotics without the youths denying it and the parents becoming vociferously indignant.
MOSCOW, March 18 (UPI) -- The Russians named craters on the far side of the moon today for Thomas A. Edison and other notables, including Jules Verne, science fiction writer.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 18 President Gamal Abdel Nasser appointed four army officers and three career civil servants today to the Cabinet of the Syrian region of the United Arab Republic. President Nasser, who had been in Syria since Feb. 14, left today for Cairo.
The National Broadcasting Company's Philadelphia radio and TV stations were exchanged yesterday for Boston stations owned by R.K.O. General, Inc.
The former secretary to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. insisted yesterday that she did not know where he got $1,400 that she said he gave her in 1951 to pay bills.

The second game for the world's chess champioriship flayed Thursday between Mikhail Botvinnik, the defender, and Mikhail Tal, was typical in that the strategy in holding the draw in hand, was logical for the one holding the lead.

Now, Through April 15 National Design Center, 415 East Fifty-third Street. A new exhibit, "Felt in Contemporary Design," shows how room dividers, wall hangings and decorative wall plaques can use the various shades and weights of felt.
A group of nonprofessional movie actors have just completed a $150,000 film that will be shown intensively around the country over the next few weeks.
Brazilian Volkswagens -- light panel-truck variety -- and Japanese sedans, sports cars and station wagons were named entries yesterday in the race for a share in the American auto market.

LOME, Togoland, March 17 -- Sylvanus E. Olympio, Premier of the United Nations trust territory of Togoland in West Africa, dismissed today Ghana's charge of plans for an armed attack as a Ghanaian pretext for jailing more political opponents without trial.
ALBANY, March 18 -- A bill that is pending here would abolish statutory exemptions from jury duty. It could also require Connecticut, and New Jersey residents to sit on New York City juries.

HOMEMAKERS on a strict budget should avoid the novelty department on Altman's street floor. It has just burst into bloom with countless irresistible fake greens, trees and flowers. Of special note are the rows of white urns filled with bright orange marigolds, vivid blue cornflowers or purple, white and yellow iris.

TWENTY-FOUR years after it was composed Bela Bartok's Piano Concerto No. 1 came to the Philharmonic. It was conducted by Fritz Reiner, who also had participated in the American premiere with the composer as soloist in 1928.
A record volume in rubber futures dealings for the year was recorded yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. A total of 2,170 tons changed hands, the largest since Feb. 16, when 1,800 tons were traded.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Atomic Energy Commission reported today on recent experiments in a Louisiana salt mine to determine the concealability of underground nuclear explosions.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 18 (AP) -- At least six teachers subpoenaed by the House Un-American Activities Committee have been dismissed or forced to resign by their local school boards, the State Department of Education said today.
ZOLTAN KODALY'S "Hary Janos" is a flimsy, ingenuous affair. It is easy to believe that last night's Juilliard Opera Theatre's production was the first complete staged version in this country.
Eduardo (Kayo) Lausse of Argentina entered an American ring last night for the first time in four years and won in the same sensational fashion that marked his earlier triumphs.
As a part of the Golden Jubilee Year of Boy Scout activity in this country, the Golden Jubilee Gala was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor.
Bradley University's star center, Chet Walker, may be unable to play against Providence for the 1960 National Invitation Tournament basketball title in Madison Square Garden this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Leaders of three Washington bridge clubs were involved today in a controversy as heated as any dispute over how to play a complicated hand.

HONG KONG, March 18 -- Bishop James Edward Walsh of Cumberland, Md., was convicted today in Shanghai of having directed a group of Chinese Roman Catholic priests in plots, espionage and other counter-revolutionary activities against Communist China.
Twenty-seven residents of the Riverdale area of the Bronx appeared yesterday at a City Hall hearing of the City Planning Commission to support the proposed rezoning program.

GENEVA, March 18 -- The Soviet Union is expected to announce tomorrow its readiness to accept a limited treaty on the banning of nuclear weapons tests, provided that it is coupled with a moratorium on tests not formally outlawed by the treaty.
Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York said yesterday that "no one will take seriously the absurd charges" by Communist China against Bishop James Edward Walsh of Cumberland, Md.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 18 -- Nearly 3,500,000 persons are expected to vote tomorrow to determine Ceylon's political future.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals gave fie Air Force some more manual trouble today.

George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, received an apology yesterday from Mayor Stanley Church of New Rochelle for his "fights" against the railroad over the last sixteen years.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., March 18 -- This community of small homes and large families was confronted today with an $11,443,969 school budget that called for the highest property tax rate in the history of Nassau County -- $6.76.

A lawyer under indictment in a lye attack that partly blinded a woman was ordered jailed yesterday after his $105,000 bail was revoked.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points (50 cents a bale) up yesterday. The far July contract showed the best rise.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 18 (AP) -- The national champion, Barbara McIntire of Lake Park, Fla., led the way as favorites advanced in the first round of the North-and-South amateur golf tournament today.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, March 18 -- An outbreak of anti-American feeling has coincided here with increased interest in the United State Constitution.

JACKSON, Miss., March 18 -- There was a time when bridge teams in national tournaments, such as the Vanderbilt Cup Team of Pour contest currently being played here, had geographical designations. The New York team would play the Cleveland team and the winner would play the Boston team, and so on.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- Commissioner Harry J. Anslinger said today he had ordered the Narcotics Bureau to delete an "objectionable" reference to the Supreme Court from an agency publication on the problems of law enforcement.

JACKSON, Miss., March 18 -- Two teams remained undefeated and ten in all were still eligible for the bridge championship tonight as the contest for the Harold F. Vanderbilt Cup and the National Open Team of Four championship entered its sixth session.
A pastoral letter from Cardinal Spellman will be read tomorrow in the 401 parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Dr. Horacio Lafer; Brazilian Foreign Minister, urged the United States today to give "priority" to the problems of the Western Hemisphere.

Two landlords convicted earlier this winter of failing to provide sufficient heat were served yesterday with papers containing the same and other charges as they left court.

PARIS, March 18 -- Announcement of the program for Premier Khrushchev's visit to France was delayed tonight, with only five days left before his arrival. Snags have arisen, but no information was available on their nature.
LONDON, March 18 -- Israel intends to use the waters of the Jordan River. regardless of what the Arabs may do about it, Premier David Ben-Gurion declared today.
GENEVA, March 19 -- The Soviet Union, in a move of major political impact, proposed today its own formula for ending explosions of nuclear weapons.

ART gallery schedules seldom offer so happy a coincidence as the simultaneous appearance of the Alexander Calder and Leonard Baskin exhibitions, which opened not only on the same day last week but also next door to each other, at the Perls and Borgenicht Galleries, respectively Paired, the two sculptors set off each other's virtues without revealing each other's shortcomings, if either has any.

A wave of concern for Southern Negro college students is stirring at campus after campus in the North. The feeling is deep enough to be seeking -- and in many cases finding -- immediate, active expression.
The teaching of foreign languages to the nation's pre-teenagers appears to be on the rise. But the rise is not rapid.

It is good news that Amabssador Bonsal is returning to Havana. There is nothing more striking about the state of relations between Cuba and the United States than the abyss of misunderstanding which divides our two countries. Whatever chances there are of bringing about a reasonable solution to the conflict between us will obviously be increased by having au envoy of the experience and ability of Mr. Bonsal in Havana.

WEST BERLIN. IT is not easy to measure the ambitions and dreams, the fears and complex concerns of 18,000,000 people in the course of a tour, particularly a tour of a Communist state, where by definition public opinion must be the opinion officially proclaimed.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 19 -- Senator Stuart Symington insisted today with a straight face that he was not a Democratic candidate, for President. But in the same breath and a broad grin, the Missourian admitted he was becoming "increasingly interested in the nomination."
Bill Bailey, minister, school teacher, fireman and bus driver, is trying to find out how to make his rural school as good as its big-city counterpart.

MOSCOW, March 12 -- Eager young experimentalists and their tradition-conscious guardians and tutors collided vigorously here this month at a ballet conference that typified the developing clash in many areas of Soviet art.

THE unrelenting grip of winter this year" has tended to curtail the production of maple syrup in the Northeast. Nevertheless, there will be maple festivals to herald the special yield of the stately tree, which habitually is responsible for two crops of tourists a year: one in the spring at sugaring-off time, and the other in the autumn, when its richly tinted leaves share in the panorama of foliage aflame.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 10 -- A small crowd held a demonstration here today in support of the Cuban revolution. The demonstrators chanted "death to Yankee imperialism" and "Cuba, yes -- Yankees, no."

TO THE EDITOR: Thank you for your lively and informative article on slang. I think it's too bad about what's happening to the word "this." Has it occurred to you that the displacement-action there is really a sign of our times in that insecure people (show-business types) want to clutch everything to themselves, to make as much as possible part of themselves?
HARTFORD, Conn., March 19 -- Connecticut's first Republican Congressional primary since the adoption of the state primary law in 1955 may be held this summer in Fairfield County.

In March, 1953, the late John Foster Dulles responded to the announcement of Stalin's death with a remark that world affairs had been dominated for the ten previous years by the "malignant power" of the grim old dictator. The Secretary of State of the self-confident new Administration predicted that the Stalin Era would now be replaced by the Eisenhower Era.

HOILYWOOD. AN end to the strike of movie actors seemed. In sight toward the end of last week and not even the most sophisticated cynics were ashamed, to be caught cheering for a happy ending, no matter bow contrived. In this instance a compromise was well under way, as of Thursday night, despite earlier setbacks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The recent resignation of John C. Doerfer as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission is the latest in a series of cases involving "conflict of interest." It was preceded by, among others, the Hulan Jack case, Sherman Adams, the late Secretary of the Air Force, Harold Talbot, not to mention numerous individuals in the Truman Administration.

THE Floriade, the largest international horticultural exhibition ever assembled, opens Friday in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Visitors to the 125-acre site will be greeted by mass displays of flowers from opening day through Sept. 25, when the show closes.
PARIS, March 19 -- The program for Premier Khrushchev's twelve-day visit to France, published today, leaves time for up to twelve hours of talks with President de Gaulle.

THIS superb novel by Jean Cayrol poses some interesting paradoxes. It dilates on the sordid and despicable -- and yet it is a powerful affirmation of life. Its framework is a sequence of the ambiguous reveries of a half-drunk murderer -- and yet the picture it draws has dramatic lucidity.
LONDON, March , 19 -- Hugh Gaitskell appealed to the faltering Labor party tonight to forget its quarrels and unite against the Conservatives.

NOW that Sweden's versatile Ingmar Bergman has become almost an American household word -- well, at least, a recognized film genius -- because of the rash of stories that have recently come out about him in national magazines, it is both a boon and an embarrassment to have released here some of his early pictures that were made before the ones on which his fame is based.

LONDON. NINETEEN SIXTY means to me anno 15 p.H., where "p" stands for post -- after -- and "H" stands for Hiroshima. I say that not because I like to remember that episode, nor as an act of penance -- for after all we were not consulted -- but for a factual and unsentimental reason.

GOOD taste, bad taste, just plain taste (which Webster's New World Dictionary defines as "the ability to notice, appreciate, and judge what is beautiful, appropriate, or harmonious; or what is excellent in art, music, decoration, clothing, etc.") -- do Americans have it?

TORONTO, March 19 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, with Red Kelly scoring his twelfth goal of the season, blanked the Chicago Black Hawks, 1 to 0, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 14,015 fans.
MALVERNB, L.I., March 19 -- The question of possible racial segregation has become a prime issue in a referendum to be held here Wednesday on a new elementary school.

JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla. -- This resort area, eighteen miles east of Jacksonville via U.S. 90, has its big innings in the spring and summer. On Sunday, April 24, it will observe its annual Welcome Day, which marks the opening of the ocean bathing season.
PARIS, March 19 -- Many more brickbats than flowers were thrown at President de Gaulle today for his refusal to accede to the desire of a majority of the National Assembly for a special session.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 19 -- An interracial, interfaith dinner last night was the high point of an eventful week in San Antonio, during which five downtown stores opened their lunch counters to all persons, regardless of color.

N.B.A. THE National Book Awards -- those $1,000 prizes given by the industry, itself, to the best of 1959's volumes of fiction, non-fiction and poetry -- will be announced on Wednesday. It will be the eleventh year of such awards, and one with a somewhat different look.
New measures to help United States exporters meet increased competition through Government-backed export credit insurance may produce even more competition.
The tick of the clock lessens the hopes for passage of any banking legislation at Albany this year.
Tenants in an apartment house on Central Park West that is being converted into a cooperative may buy their apartments on the installment plan.

A new world's champion liar was proclaimed a while back by the Burlington Liars' Club. This is an organization founded in 1929 in Burlington, Wis. -- which lies well within the Poul Bunyan domain -- and is solemnly devoted to the perpetuation, encouragement and honorable recognition of the tall story.

KILCOCK, Ireland, March 19 -- A small United States-owned plant in this County Kildare town of 700 is an excellent example of how foreign investors are helping solve Ireland's economic and human problems.
