A SURPRISING thing about America today is that so many new office buildings are going up. What the country really needs is more restaurants, for that is where much of the nation's business is transacted. The "business lunch," that lavish exercise in spending the boss's money, has fastened such a grip on our cities that to lunch with someone for pleasure is almost indecent.

TRYON, N.C. -- In March and April the Sandhills section of North Carolina is a meeting place for spring vacationists from up North as well as down South. They come here for the spring sports events, the refreshing spectacle of blooming gardens, both private and public, and the generally mild weather.
HELENA, Mont., March 19 -- At least three politically powerful Montanans will oppose Senator James E. Murray, Democrat, for his seat in the June 7 primary election.
MOSCOW, March 19 -- The Soviet Union has set itself up as the leading champion of complete, universal disarmament and world peace.

ATLANTIC CITY -- A late winter marked by chill winds and a white mantle of snow has been unable to discourage visitors at New Jersey's shore resorts. Since Washington's Birthday, strollers have been appearing in increasing numbers along the boardwalks from Cape May north to Asbury Park.

LONDON. THE archaeologists of today are exploring the past as energetically as the astronomers are exploring space -- and far more cheaply. Everywhere the work goes on. Although excavations are not conducted in quite so lavish a way as once they were, there are probably more of them.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., March 19 -- William Shakespeare is a great hit these days with the pigtail and cowboy set here.

The New York County Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society will benefit for the second consecutive year from the spring production of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas by the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd. The amateur group will present the double bill of "Trial by Jury" and "H.M.S. Pinafore" at the Hunter College Playhouse April 20 through 23.
The scholarship fund of Bennington College will be the beneficiary of the May 4 evening performance of "Toys in the Attic" at the Hudson Theatre.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 19 (UPI) -- Two judges asserted today that they had been pressured by the State Department to settle without a jail sentence a speeding charge against the grandson of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of Nationalist China.

THE most successful book about Washington, D.C., in recent years has been Alien Drury's novel, "Advise and Consent," the theme of which is that ours is predominantly a Government of men rather than laws.

LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- Judy Devlin of Baltimore feated Margaret Varner of W. mington, Del., today and too the British women's badminton championship for the four time. She then teamed with her younger sister, Sue, to win the women's doubles title.

The sale, it is understood, should bring the author more than $350,000, an obviously rewarding figure.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Many United States officials and Western diplomats are convinced there is virtually no chance that a plebiscite will be carried out in West Berlin in advance of the summit meeting in May, as suggested by Chancellor Adenauer.

IN Edward Hyams, England has a writer of multifarious interests, among them horticulture, viniculture, the lore of the sea and the air. Into his absorbing, serious new novel he has packed much knowledge of all these subjects.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- Representative James C. Wright Jr. said today that House investigators, were digging up mounting evidence of "both grand and petty graft" in the multi-billion-dollar interstate highway program.

AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- The St. Augustine Historical and Preservation Commission has established headquarters in a downtown office here, appointed a staff of consulting experts and approved a master plan for the restoration of historical aspects of this ancient city in accordance with an act passed by the 1959 Florida Legislature.

LOUISVILLE, Ky. -- Farmington, one of the Midsouth's classic old residences, is 150 years old this year. Designed by Thomas Jefferson and built by John and Lucy Fry Speed, it was recently opened to the public.

Mrs. William C. Langley, chairman of special projects for the New York Heart Association, has announced the members of the men's committee for the fifth annual Heart of America Ball.
Patronesses have teen announced for the fifteenth annual Bal des Berceaux being sponsored by the Committee of French American Wives on April 1 in the St. Regis Roof.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 19 -- Having progressed successfully from the era of the jeep-mounted prospector and the penny-stock prospectus in a decade, the West's uranium producers -- with output at an alltime high -- have joined the nation's farmers, automakers, missile-men and the like in wondering what the future and Washington hold in store.
The earliest combined horse racing season in the history of the pari-mutuel era in New York State will start tomorrow, with action listed on both the thoroughbred and harness horse fronts.

IT comes as no surprise that a wellknown Brooklyn department store now offers free weekly bridge seminars for the public, with guest experts who stroll from table to table during the practice sessions stopping to explain why a certain bid or play will succeed and then stopping to explain why it didn't.

PARIS, March 19 -- French aspirations for the forthcoming summit season center on three subjects -- maintenance of Germany's status quo, progress towards disarmament, with nuclear weapons first to go, and East-West cooperation in development in Asia and Africa.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 19 -- Preparations are under way at near-by Camp Drum for occupancy by troops who will participate in Operation Iroquois Hatchet from April 11 through May 15.

A private collection, that of Mr. and Mrs. Nate B. Spingold, including paintings by Modigliani, Renoir, and Vuillard, is one of the important openings of the week, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

TANCARVILLE, France -- The way has been made straight, or at least straighter, for the American motorist who intends to invade Europe this spring by way of Le Havre. Here at Tancarville, the new bridge that has been opened over the lower Seine helps to reduce the driving time between Le Havre and Paris and also provides a fine observation point for a view of the surrounding countryside.

THIS book is the well-translated autobiography of a German novelist, Gustav Regler, born in the Rhineland three years before the present century began. A civic group in Summit, N.J., acting on its own initiative and with its own capital, has alleviated a housing problem that vexes many communities.

MOORE HAVEN, Fla., March 19 -- This Lake Okeechobee is a phenomenal piece of big water, natural in the beginning but now managed and double managed and sometimes overmanaged by man until it amounts to a huge water interchange.

PARIS. DURING the past year the French movie industry has been not only rocked but virtually reshaped by a unique phenomenon labeled by an enthusiastic Paris press "la Nouvelle Vague" -- the New Wave.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 -- George Bayer of Gleneagles, Ill., and Lionel Hebert of Lafayette, La., each carded a six-under-par 66 today and shared the lead after the first round of the $15,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

SEOUL, Korea, March 19 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea said today that he would seek better relations with Japan in his fourth term, possibly through the good offices of the United States.

MIAMI BEACH -- The vacationist who comes to this Gold Coast resort in pursuit of more than sun and fun can now find any number of cultural and historical attractions to interest him. LONDON, March 19 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers and Blackburn Rovers, two of the last four clubs in the English Football Association Cup competition, both were beaten, 2 -- 1, today in league games by Leicester City and West Ham United, respectively.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 9 -- The Government is stepping up investments in agriculture this year in the hope an increase in production will enable it to fulfill its assigned role as a source of farm products in the Soviet bloc.

MONTREAL, March 19 (UPI) -- Three second-period goals helped the Montreal Canadians knock Boston out of play-off contention tonight. The National Hockey League champions defeated the Bruins, 5 -- 1, in their final home game of the regular season.

LOS ANGELES -- Spring has come to the deserts of Southern California, bringing with it the widely heralded spectacle of the desert wildflowers. This paradox of nature, radiantly beautiful flowers blooming in arid wastes, carpeting entire sections and brushing canyons and mountainsides with brilliant color, or growing individually in a variety of bright hues and fascinating forms, is one of Southern California's most popular outdoor attractions.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Home, school, society, church and synagogue must reverse the process of decay in ethical values threatening this country's youth.
In a tremendous comeback in the closing minutes that caught a crowd of 16,421 by surprise Bradley University won the twenty-third annual National Invitation Basketball Tournament yesterday.
HAVANA, March 19 -- The Biltmore Yacht and Country Club, one of the big private clubs here, was seized today by the Government. It was the first private club to be seized.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended March 12 were 6 per cent below the year-ago level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. In the preceding week sales fell 17 per cent from the 1959 level, also because of bad weather and a later Easter this year.

STARVED ROCK STATE PARK, III., March 19 (UPI) -- A man, his wife and three children were found today shot to death in their home about twenty miles east of where three Chicago-area women were slain Monday.
A cooperative housing movement led by A housewife is gaining wide support in Greenwich Village.

BOTH the arts of India and those of the Indonesian archipelago were until recent years uncongenial to Westerners. Disconcerted by the combination of tropical voluptuousness and exalted spirituality; puzzled and repelled by the strange complexities of Hinduism and Buddhism, travelers to the subcontinent would conclude that the frescoed caves of Ajanta and the rock figures at Ellora were no more than startling curiosities.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In gauging the wisdom of a large-scale shelter system, it is not enough to reckon the number of lives that the system (hopefully) would save in a nuclear war. One must also weigh the effect of building and maintaining the system on our chance of keeping out of war.

TO THE EDITOR: WILLIAM M. KUNSTLER in his fine review of Walter Gellhorn's "American Rights'' wishes "that the author had gone further in exploring certain fields," and this reader wishes in turn that Mr. Kunstler had gone further in his perceptive comments.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 19 -- A campaign to raise more than $1,000,000 each year in the United States to finance family planning in underdeveloped areas abroad will be started tomorrow.

Some have quit work because of compulsory retirement plans; some are widowed or alone in the world, and seek to start a new life; some are weary of the rigors of Northern winters; some need the sun to fight illness.

RECORD clubs today gross the equivalent of $70 to $75 million at list price a year. This figure represents approximately 18 per cent of the entire record industry in this country". WASHINGTON, March 19 -- In both, houses this week the Eighty-fifth Congress continued its centipedal crawl toward the Civil Rights Act of 1960. The debate, which began in the Senate Feb. 15, is now more than a month old, and no early end is in sight.

Will there be an elimination contest among U S. hydroplanes to provide a challenger to the Canadians?
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur underwent a successful operation yesterday for removal of his prostate gland. A First Army spokesman said last night that his condition was "excellent."
OCEANSIDE, L.I., March 19 -- Rameses II, the mighty Egyptian monarch who reigned about 1300 B.C., would have reason to be grateful today to a group of boys and girls at the Oceanside High School.

ST. LOUIS, March 19 -- Two bond issues to provide $29,535,000 for school construction will be on the ballot at a special city election Tuesday. The ballot will also have a proposal to increase the school tax rate 26 cents to $1.77 per $100 of assessed valuation.

FIVE years ago Lane Kauffmann made his debut with a novel of murder called "The Perfectionist," which proved to be witty, urbane, perceptive and original, and quite a brightener of the 1955 season. After two well-received straight novels ("Six Weeks in March" and "A Lesser Lion") he now returns to murder with WALDO (Lippincott, $3.75); and once again, happily, the same adjectives will apply.

Summerfield has scheduled in commemoration of the picturesque Pony Express postal service of a century ago.

IT is not easy to say anything that is both new and true about the Greeks, but it is much to be desired that scholars should from time to time try to reassess their achievement in the light of modern experience and ask what in it matters most to us.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., March 19 -- About 450 women attended the annual luncheon of the women's division of the Rockland County Democratic Committee in the Villa Lafayette here today. They heard national, state and county leaders explain the preparations for the campaign.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 19 (AP) -- Bolivian troops crushed a revolt by a National Police regiment today after a five-hour battle in the outskirts of La Paz, the Government said. Ten persons were reported killed in the fighting and thirty wounded.

Miss Abbie Mitchell, actress and singer, and former executive secretary of the Negro Actors Guild of America, died Wednesday in Harlem Hospital, after a long illness. She lived at 149 West Eighty-seventh Street.

TO make perfectly straight cuts on a large panel of plywood when using a portable power saw, use a straight wooden, board as an improvised rip guide. Clamp the board (a 2x4 will do fine) to the top of the panel after laying the plywood across two saw-horses.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- The "Golden Gateway" to the Pacific basked this week in a new international role. Two weeks before a combined Oxford-Cambridge team plays for the first time in New York at Columbia's Baker Field, Yale and Westchester met in the opening rugby football match of the local season yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 19 (UPI) -- Al Lawrence, who has run two and three mile races faster indoors than anyone else, gained a berth on the Australian Olympic track team today by winning the 10,000-meter race.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Prospects for Bermuda's tourist business this year and for several years to come are exceptionally bright. The completion of one new large hotel is now only weeks away, the building of another hotel has already begun and extensive renovations are being made on two others.

Amid the dispute over the proposed new zoning resolution for New York City, a major aspect of the code has received little attention: the consolidation on a single map of the zoning functions now governed by three maps.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., March 19 -- Two high school students were arrested here today on charges of having beaten another student so severely in a fraternity hazing that he was hospitalized for five days.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 19 -- Heavy snows this winter have caused serious flood threats in Iowa, Kansas, Nebraska and Missouri, and more snow is predicted in the Mississippi-Missouri basin. Officials say the flood danger is greater this year due to the frequent storms and cold weather which has not allowed the heavy blanket of snow to melt normally.

Russian Premier Khrushchev's pending official visit to General de Gaulle is bringing into the French spotlight a financial issue that has been simmering almost unnoticed for nearly fifty years. Some taxpayers seem to be having trouble with New York State's new $25 head-of-house-hold tax credit. The credit may be claimed on income tax returns filed with the state for personal income earned in 1959.

In the Northern Hemisphere of our small planet, this time of the year is traditionally a time of hope reborn. WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A black Scottish terrier, Ch. Blanart Bewitching, received what amounted to an advance birthday gift tonight. The dog will be 3 years old next Sunday. The National Committee Against Mental Illness urged New York State yesterday to adopt a $25,200,000 program, to speed the discharge of patients from mental hospitals.
ALBANY, March 20 -- The Republican leader of the State Senate called today for a $30,000,000 income tax cut, effective in 1961.

LONDON, March 20 -- The British draft of a code of international rules for a period of coexistence and negotiation between East and West will be submitted to the United State and France this week, diplomatic sources said today.
HAVANA, March 20 -- Philip W. Bonsal, United States Ambassador, returned today to a Havana that was officially more hostile to the United States than when he left for Washington two months ago.
Speculation and bartering. Those are two words seldom connected with mutual funds. Yet two new funds based on those words came to the public last week.
John E. Gefaell, retired newsprint executive, died Sunday in his home at 530 Park Avenue after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- By a vote of 5 to 4, the Supreme Court reaffirmed today an important tax decision it had rendered by a vote of 8 to 1 in 1958.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- An Alabama law that changed the boundaries of the City of Tuskegee and excluded most Negroes will be examined by the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, March 21, (UPI) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to the White House today after a two-week stay at a beauty resort near Phoenix, Ariz.
HAVANA, March 21 -- Cuban soldiers shot down an American private plane today and captured its pilot and co-pilot.
NEWTOWNARDS. Northern Ireland, March 21 -- James Warden, one of this town's leading citizens, remembers when all the women hereabouts wore shawls and some were barefoot.

THE Presidential race so far this year is almost as exciting as the account of a tea party in one of Trollope's novels. We are still nowhere near achieving the heady stage Lord Bryce called "the spectacle of half the honest men supporting for the headship of the nation a person whom the other half declare to he a knave."
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Fernando Maria Castiella, Spanish Foreign Minister, will arrive here tomorrow to consult on questions that may be discussed at the Big Four summit conference next month.
Pentron Electronics Corporation, Chicago, is offering through Stanley Heller Co., investment banker, 250,000 common shares at $3 a share.
The one-story industrial building at 4217 Vireo Avenue at East 233d Street in the Bronx has been sold by the Esso Standard Oil Company to Benjamin Kopf and Werner Krebs, painting contractors.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 21 (UPI) -- Senator John F. Kennedy flew to Indiana today to enter the Presidential preference primary and was greeted by a delegation of demonstrators challenging him to a debate on the religious issue.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 21 -- The police opened fire today on thousands of Africans besieging a police station at Sharpeville, thirty miles south of Johannesburg. Officials reported twenty-five Africans had been killed and fifty wounded. Unofficial reports indicated about fifty had been killed.
A simple slogan contest may yet touch off one of advertising's biggest wars.
MOORE HAVEN, Fla., March 21 -- People who ought to know better are always underestimating the size of fish. It is sometimes enough to make an angler lose faith in the human race.

PARAMUS, N.J., March 21 -- A State Highway Department plan for a $200,000 clover leaf linking Route 4 and Hackensack Avenue, Hackensack, on the south side of the state highway was endorsed here today at a public hearing.

ALBANY, Tuesday, March 22 -- Following is the vote by which the Legislature approved the omnibus banking bill regulating bank holding companies and permitting branching privileges for many institutions. The vote in the Senate last night was 43 to 20, and in the Assembly early today, 91 to 56.
Earnings of the Rockwell-Standard Corporation, maker of auto parts and heating equipment, rose more than $10,000,000 in 1959 to a record $19,138,978.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent to 120 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended Tuesday, March 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) The future of consumer credit depends on keeping its operation and development free from any kind of government control, Arthur J. Morris, founder of the Morris Plan system of credit and savings banking, said today.

Prairie Farmer Publishing The stock of the Prairie Farmer Publishing Company has been sold to American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The stock represents the ownership of half interest in radio station WLS, Chicago, and a chain of farm publications.

LONDON, March 21 -- The stock market was hesitant here today. Demand was small and selective following the announcement on Friday of a deficit in Britain's trade balance with the rest of the world for the last quarter of 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The United States, for reasons of bargaining and principle, will probably neither reject nor accept the latest Soviet proposal for a nuclear test ban.
CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets, here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The House completed Congressional action today on a bill to honor the S.S. Meredith Victory and her captain, and crew for a heroic exploit in the Korean War.
GATLINBURG, Tenn., March 21 -- The Federal Civil Right Commission decided today to investigate charges of discrimination in law enforcement.
An acting challenge has beer accepted by Tallulah Bankhead absent from Broadway since "Eugenia" (1957.) The star will develop a characterization in "Midgie Purvis" that she has not attempted before.
The Metropolitan Opera Company will perform eight operas in thirteen cities in the United States and Canada during its annual tour.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 21 (AP) -- A Negro editor and thirty-six Negro students, arrested during sitdowns Saturday at all-white public libraries here, were fined for disorderly conduct today.
LONDON, March 21 -- The Cunard Line announced today virtual agreement to acquire controlling interest in Eagle Airways, an independent airline, and its associated companies.

BREAUX BRIDGE, LA. ALMOST every country celebrates the time of the crayfish. In Sweden, for example, the season begins officially in mid-August when the citizens of that country gather by moonlight and eat the freshly boiled crustaceans with caraway-flavored akvavit.

The Board of Higher Educa- tion last night turned down a recommendation from the city's Commission on Intel-group Relations that it direct the municipal colleges to impose specific punitive measures if antireligious or anti-racial articles were printed in campus publications.
Better weather in most parts of the country spurred greater demand for spring and summer merchandise, resident buying offices reported last week.
The Brooklyn Real Estate Board told the City Planning Commission yesterday that the proposed new zoning resolution would drive industry from the city.

PARENTS who press for Government censorship of the mass media propose to turn over to the state "the most significant job of parenthood," Eric Johnston warned yes- terday. Mr. Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, stated that it was a parent's duty to help a child distinguish between truth and falsehood good and evil, wisdom and folly.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- George Bayer sank a chip shot from 4 feet off the green today for a birdie on the first extra hole and beat Jack Fleck in a sudden-death play-off for first place in the $15,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament.

Five uptown apartment buildings have been sold in a package deal by Harry Nystad, real estate investor and operator, to Eugene Berger and Herman Doft. The properties are 41, 43 and 63 West 117th Street; 64 East 117th Street and 227 West 123d Street.

BONN, Germany, March 21 -- Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss argued West Germany's case, for foreign training and supply bases in a meeting today with Thomas S. Gates Jr., United States Secretary of Defense.

A defense motion to exclude communications between Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and a lawyer on Income-tax matters was denied yesterday in Mr. Powell's trial in Federal Court on charges of tax evasion.

The top salary of New York City patrolmen ranks fourth among thirteen of the nation's largest cities, an economist reported yesterday. The starting salary puts this city's Police Department in ninth or tenth place, he added.
MOSCOW, March 21 -- Premier Khrushchev will depart for Paris Wednesday morning, apparently healthy after a touch of influenza and apparently satisfied with his revised eleven-day itinerary.
Electronic devices to improve and prolong people's lives in a multitude of ways were described yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two and one-half months have passed since your Jan. 1 editorial welcoming "Mayor Wagner's rededication to the challenges of the city and his determination that they will be met quickly and efficiently."
ALBANY, March 21 -- College enrollment in New York Institutions reached a peak of 401,343 students last September, 21,520 more than last year, the State Education Department reported today.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa asked yesterday whether a state commission's debt program might not let the city spend almost as much on construction projects as the $500,000,000 school bond issue rejected by the voters last fall.

ALBANY, March 21 -- The Senate approved tonight a bill mandating free bus transportation for private and parochial school pupils who live not more than ten miles from their school. The measure was attacked by upstate Republicans, who said it would upset an existing arrangement, which permits school districts to provide transportation for private pupils on a voluntary basis.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- Approximately 30,000 Muscovite fervently applauded three "sneak preview" showings over the week-end and tonight of the American film "Roman Holiday," one of the ten sent here under the Soviet-United States cultural exchange program.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 21 -- Roosevelt Raceway started its twenty-first season of harness racing tonight before 28,282 fans who wagered $1,940,533. Everyone, including the losers, had to agree that the turnout, the action, everything connected with the opening, exceeded expectations.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21 -- Hopes of holding a United Nations scientific conference on outer space this year have virtually disappeared as a result of a Soviet demand that a Soviet scientist be placed in charge.
CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- The old crop grain futures contracts were in good demand today and worked well ahead despite a slight weakness in some new crop contracts on the Board of Trade.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 21 -- Chancellor Adenauer told 10,000 persons at the University of California today that it was the duty of the free world to arm its people with knowledge and training "to conduct a moral struggle against communism."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21 -- Premier Khrushchev will be a contributor to The Sousa Blue and Gray, a Bronx junior high school yearbook, this year.
The Los Angeles, Calif., Flood Control District is planning the sale of $10,000,000 of serial bonds on March 29. The issue will come due from 1961 to 1989.

Members of society from many parts of the East and South and leaders of the sporting, industrial and financial worlds attended the opening program yesterday at the Aqueduct race track in Ozone Park, Queens.

Old-line and reform Democrats agreed last night to ask "a prominent Democrat who would be acceptable to everyone" to run for national convention delegate in Manhattan's Seventeenth Congressional District.
ISLAND PARK, L.I., March 21 -- The spiritual leader of the Greek Orthodox Church in this country expressed belief tonight in the reported "weeping" of a religious portrait in a home here recently.
Sales and earnings of the J.C. Penney Company set records in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.
DETROIT, March 21 (AP) -- For the second straight week Chevrolet production of standard-size cars has topped the entire output of the Ford Motor Company, which builds six lines of cars.

PARIS, March 21 -- President de Gaulle and African leaders of the French Community met here today in a conference that market a sharp evolution of the community since its inception a year and a half ago.
ST. LOUIS, March 21 (AP) -- The Channing Corporation of New York today won the proxy battle for control of Managed Funds, Inc., $58,000,000 St Louis mutual fund, by a margin of 532,804 shares.
A 25-year-old man surrendered last night as the motorist whose car had seriously injured a 9-year-old girl more than five hours earlier.
Legislation to permit children with poor school records to seek full-time employment at 15 rather than the legal age of 16 was recommended yesterday by a Kings County grand jury.
Cities Service Company and subsidiaries recorded in 1959 a gain of 10.6 per cent in net income.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association named the personnel today for the two all-star squads that will join Ohio State, the 1960 varsity champion, as the N.C.A.A. representatives in the Olympic basketball tryouts at Denver March 31, April 1 and 2.
Clarification, or resolution, of the perennial defense controversy about military airlift requirements may result from exercise Big Slam/Puerto Pine, now starting its second week.
HONG KONG, March 21 -- An agreement on the boundary between Nepal and Communist China was signed in Peiping today.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) -- The Plumbers Union withdrew today from organized labor's Industrial Union Department in a dispute with the head of the department, Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers.
A New York television, station that editorially attacked proposals to legalize off-track betting on horse races last week has made equal time available to the Wagner administration for a reply.
ALBANY, March 21 -- An agreement to provide New York City with a substantial increase in potential state revenues appeared to be measurably closer tonight.

The morning sun obviously attracted a lot of players to Aqueduct today who would have assigned themselves elsewhere if they had had any idea how cold it was going to be. There were long lines in front of the admission windows long before noon, many of the customers expressing the hope that things would warm up by post time.
AS the author of plays in the Chinese tradition, Aldyth Morris sets our theatre a problem. Who can act plays so alien to our tradition?
Trade short - covering and chart buying raised wool prices to new highs for the move yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trade hedge selling and profit-taking limited the advance.
On Feb. 25 and 26 of 1959, the Pfeiffer team of Detroit knocked over pins at a record clip in the annual American Bowling Congress tournament in St. Louis.
ALBANY, March 21 -- A bill abolishing the requirement that policemen pursue speeding drivers for a quarter of a mile was approved by the Assembly tonight and sent to Governor Rockefeller.
Johnny Dio, the labor racketeer, and his bodyguard, Theodore Ray, went on trial yesterday on charges of income-tax evasion. Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld is hearing, the case without a jury.
A further sharp drop in the discount rates on Treasury bills held the center of attention in the market for prime fixed-income investments yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- Though there is a lull in negotiations towards settling the strike by movie actors, there is no letup in the heated campaign of actors and movie studios to win votes for the Oscars to be awarded on April 4.
WESTBURY, L.I, March 21 -- Not all roads led to Roosevelt Raceway for the opening of the harness racing season tonight. Those that did, though, were smoothly paved and inviting.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 21 (UPI) -- The Boston Red Sox signed Russ Nixon, a former Cleveland catcher, today and defied the Indians to try to get him back.
Five members of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations have agreed to appear on television Sunday evening in a live, unrehearsed discussion of world affairs, station WNTA-TV announced yesterday.
GENEVA, March 21 -- The Soviet Union offered today to present a new disarmament timetable, moving total prohibition of nuclear weapons up from last place to first.

YESTERDAY (March 21, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Discussed state aid for New York City in phone conversation with Mayor Wagner. Met with Republican legislative leaders. Attended reception for Maj. Gen. and Mrs. Almerin C. O'Hara.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Supreme Court of the United States reached down to the police court of Louisville, Ky., today to set aside two $10 fines for loitering and disorderly conduct.

LYNN, Mass., March 21 -- Twenty - two shop stewards shifted their support, to the rival United Electrical Workers Union today in a bargaining election scheduled Friday at General Electric plants here and in near-by Everett.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney told a House Appropriations subcommittee in testimony released today that a speedy method had been devised to measure cancer-producing agents in city air.

The Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, maker of shirts and men's wearing apparel, had record sales and earnings in its fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, Seymour J. Phillips, president, reported yesterday. Net sales, before discounts and including

The Republic Aviation Corporation has made an agreement to acquire a one-third interest of the Royal Netherlands Aircraft Factories Fokker for about $1,000,000. The Dutch company ranks fourth or fifth among the aircraft builders on the Continent.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Secretary of the Treasury said today that the United States had a balance of payments problem that it must solve if it was to continue to perform its function of world leadership.
Counting their blisters, thirty schoolboys rested yesterday from a week-end of bilgewater and birdshot.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Voice of America resumed Spanish-language broadcasts to Latin America today while the State Department softly answered heated Cuban words and gestures directed against the United States.
ROME, March 21 -- The most harried man in Rome these days probably is Gen. Luigi Magliaria-Galanta, the Chief of Protocol and Ceremony for the Olympic Games next summer.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 21 -- Dudley S. Senanayake became Prime Minister of Ceylon tonight.
VEREENIGING, March 21 (AP) -- At least fifty Africans were killed and scores wounded today during demonstrations against the South African Government's strict segregation policies.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers accused the Navy of strike-breaking today after two Navy vessels were moved from strikebound yards in East Boston and Quincy, Mass., of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21 -- This was a day the venders, crying "You can't tell the players without a score card," had a field day.
The president of American Export Lines urged Cleveland business men yesterday to launch an "aggressive selling campaign" to promote the city as a world port.

Fellowships will be distributed by the Ford Foundation for studies or research in the creative arts. They will go to persons not regularly associated with academic institutions. The grants will not apply to creative development.

The prospects of holding Chinese Communist aggression in check have been enhanced by the re-election of two of the most determined anti-Communist leaders in the Far East as Presidents of countries that are loyal allies of the United States. The two leaders are President Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China, whose rule is now confined to Taiwan and some additional islands, and President Syngman Rhee, head of the only legitimate Government in Korea.
MIAMI, March 21 (UPI) -- The light plane shot down near Matanzas, Cuba, today was rented to a sandy-haired Miami automobile salesman here yesterday for a brief flight in Southern Florida.

PART of the experience of theatregoing is to encounter a play that may not be one's favorite but nonetheless holds a decided reward. Such was the case last night in the revival of Henrik Ibsen's "The Master Builder" on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13.
TRENTON, March 21 -- The State Assembly voted and sent to the Senate today bills that would appropriate $15,000,000 for two new state office buildings.

Subscribers have been announced for the musicale by Nathan Milstein, the violinist, in the Grand, Ballroom of the Plaza on April 11. Mr. Milstein is giving his services and Mr. and Mrs. Giovanni Buitoni are sponsoring a supper party to follow the recital.

Although not a word was said or written about it, it must have been more than sheer coincidence that last night's all-Bach program of the Harpsichord Music Society at Town Hall fell on Bach's birthday.

The thoroughbred horse racing season opened at Aqueduct yesterday, the earliest opening for the runners in the local history of pari-mutuel betting. Although the weather, was chilly and hardly inviting, a crowd of 40,022 attended, the program, which was headed by the traditional opening-day feature, the Paumonok Handicap.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The New York Times' comment of March 9 on "Turkey and a Free Press" deplores the sentence passed against the editor of the newspaper Vatan of Istanbul, Ahmet Emin Yalman, but overlooks certain basic facts and legal realities involved in the case.

Artist's Reaction to Critic Homer's words in the "Iliad," that "the man who acts the least, upbraids the most," expresses at an early age in the development of the Western world what seems to be a normal reaction of artist to critic.

BERLIOZ, like Verdi, was fascinated by the musical possibilities of Shakespeare. Like Verdi, whose last opera was a sunset evocation of the fat Knight, Falstaff, and his friends, Berlioz drew his final work from Shakespeare.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senator Stuart Symington, long an unannounced candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, will make it official soon, possibly by the end of this week. The Missourian is booked for five political speeches in nine days, beginning Friday.

Oregon is engaged in a determined drive to attract new industry. A sales "pitch" to that effect was made here yesterday by Mark O. Hatfield, its 37-year-old Governor, at a press conference and again at a luncheon for more than 100 company presidents and executives.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 (UPI) -- The Big Five voted today to choose its Rose Bowl opponents from "the nation's outstanding collegiate football teams."

WHITE PLAINS, March 21 -- Westchester officials reported today that they had begun private conferences with the high school and college students who had been exposed last week as occasional users of narcotics.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Arthur S. Flemming testified today for the Administration's program of Federal guarantees on long-term bonds to finance college construction.

ROBERT D'ARISTA broods on the power of enveloping darkness in his paintings at the Alan Gallery, 766 Madison Avenue at Sixty-sixth Street. Several of his recent oils are large, thickly painted black matrices, in which he picks out isolated lights on faces and figures.
The National Tea Company expects sales and earnings to set records this year, H.V. McNamara, president and chief executive officer, told the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.
The Women's City Club of New York said yesterday that there was not a single "truly effective" local school board in the city and recommended that the boards either be strengthened or abolished.
ALBANY, March 21 -- Republican legislators agreed today to back a program providing local school districts with $63,000,000 extra in state aid for the next school year.

JACKSON, March 21 -- The accompanying hand is "cute," according to Alvin Roth of New York, who, with Robert Jordan of Philadelphia as his partner, scored a runaway victory in the national open pair contest played here over the week-end.
The steel industry this week will operate at less than 90 per cent of capacity for the first time since the week of Nov. 23, 1959, the American Iron and Steel Institute predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Federal Aviation Agency will hold an unusual conference tomorrow with the companies that make and fly the Electra airliner. The purpose is to explore the causes of two recent crashes and prevent others.

Audiences here and in Los Angeles will be treated to the centuries-old spectacle of the authentic, Japanese Kabuki popular theatre when a troupe of sixty players, dancers and musicians begins a tour at the City Center on June 2.
One of the fastest growing corporate bowling enterprises in the nation recently turned in what may become a "300," or perfect game.

ALBANY, Tuesday, March 22 -- The Legislature gave final approval and Governor Rockefeller signed early today an omnibus banking bill. The measure permits New York City banks to extend operations into Westchester and Nassau Counties.

The House of Representatives will be continuing today its consideration of a new civil rights bill. The expression "civil rights" has a fairly precise meaning this year. It signifies the right of the Negro in several Southern states to be treated as the Constitution directs.
Carol Heiss, the Olympic and women's world figure-skating champion, plans a professional career.

The International Association for Iranian Art and Archaeology will be assisted by a Persian dinner at the Astor on April 27. The fete is part of the Fourth Congress of the Association that will take place from April 24 through May 3 in New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Washington.
ALBANY, March 21 -- A serious threat to Governor Rockefeller's political prestige and standing as the leader of the state Republican party has been posed by Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21 -- It was like a class reunion during graduation week. Since the majority of the Yankees and Athletics have studied at one time or another under that eminent professor, Charles Dillon Stengel, they wandered all over Al Lang Field early this afternoon in a mass outbreak of handshaking and backslapping.

Outmaneuvered by Mikhail Botvinnik, the world chess champion, and behind in material to the extent of a minor piece and a pawn, Mikhail Tal had recourse to a perpetual check that enabled him to draw the third game of their match after thirty-seven moves, according to the score received here yesterday from Moscow.
BOCA RATON, Fla., March 21 -- The electric automobile shorn of its nostalgic appeal was revived today.

GENEVA, March 21 -- The Soviet Union suggested today that its proposed moratorium on the explosion of nuclear weapons might last four or five years. After that time, the Soviet delegation said, scientists should have worked out methods of detecting small-scale underground tests and a treaty covering all explosions could be drawn up.

JACKSON, Miss., March 21 -- Three contract bridge teams out of forty-four that started last Wednesday remained in competition tonight for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup, emblematic of the national open team-of-four championship.

Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) in the quarter ending on March 31 are expected to be lower than in the 1959 period, Frank O. Prior, chairman, said yesterday. Results for the entire year, however, are expected to exceed 1959 earnings, Mr. Prior said.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Dr. John J. Theobald gave Public School 616 a high grade yesterday after visiting the school at Rikers Island.
Stocks continued to tr with neither enthusiasm nor direction yesterday, finally closing almost unchanged on New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- President Eisenhower says he is ready to support a natural-gas bill.

THE first signs of the easter season are appearing in florist windows and toothsome candy store displays. The Elder Craftsmen Shop, 850 Lexington Avenue (at Sixty-fourth Street) has decorated its tiny window with a novel group of Easter egg trees.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- In his televised discussion yesterday of the Negro demonstrations against denial of service to them at privately owned Southern lunch counters, during which he furnished a model example of high intelligence, tone and temper, Roy E. Wilkins of the N.A.A.C.P. spoke of this service as among Negro "rights," and of local police protection of the discrimination as illegal.
GENEVA, March 21 -- The Soviet Union was reported ready today to introduce the question of fishing rights into its traditional stand in favor of a twelve-mile limit for territorial seas.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 21 -- When Dudley Shelton Senanayake returned to politics in 1957 after a year in retirement he was reported to have told friends: "I don't want to be Prime Minister; I just want to save Ceylon from totalitarianism."

THOUGH in 1951 and again last year, Rudolf Bing has presented Verdi's "Requiem" on Good Friday, he has not strayed far from the Metropolitan Opera's tradition of presenting Wagner's "Parsifal" at Easter time. And, last night, he showed his fidelity to that tradition by restoring the consecrational festival drama to the repertory.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Treasury bill rate took another dive this week, the Treasury reported tonight.
The Columbia Broadcasting System announced last night that It was discontinuing its policy of identifying canned laughter or applause used on television, programs.
SUN PRAIRIE, Wis., March 21 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota campaigned for the votes of Roman Catholics in rural Wisconsin today with a new attack on peddlers of "hate and bigotry."

IF men's caps begin to occupy almost as much closet space as women's hats, Charles LeMaire is the man to blame. The former costume head of Twentieth Century-Fox has been busier than a subway guard at rush hour since he branched out on his own last spring.
The annual hunt for dissatisfied electronics engineers was on here yesterday with the opening of the yearly convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
TMIMI, Libya, March 21 -- The fictional states of Taffiya and Deleria were in battle near here today and British forces were trying to repel the invading Taffiyans.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of Harlem thrust an olive branch yesterday in the direction of Hulan E. Jack, Manhattan's Borough President.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The South was beaten again today, and this time easily, in its fight in the House to weaken the voting referee plan.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 9 points (45 cents a bale) down to 3 points (15 cents a bale) up yesterday.

YESTERDAY (March 21, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Returned from Camp David, Md. Nominated Bruce Savage as Federal Housing Commissioner Conferred with Secretary of State Herter, Deputy Under Secretary Merchant and Army Secretary Brucker.
Chicago's Golden Gloves team beat the stuffings out of New York's representatives in the annual intercity fisticuffs at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Two Senate committees are vying for watchdog authority over the 1959 labor reform law.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to examine a complaint against Chicago's movie censorship ordinance.
LONDON, March 21 -- The Government agreed today that all British children should be required to attend school for an additional year beyond the present school-leaving age of 15.

Stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation at their annual meeting in Hoboken on May 2 will vote on a proposition that is believed never before to have appeared in a corporate proxy statement. The proposition, opposed by management, is that the company provide a secret ballot for stockholders.
LONDON, March 22 -- Angry protests against the shooting of South African rioters were sounded today from many quarters in Britain.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 22 -- Rioting in protest against South Africa's racial laws continued today.

Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan last night joined the "united Democratic leadership team," put together during the last year in Harlem by Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Mr. Powell had strongly suggested at a press conference Monday night that such a course would be wise for Mr. Jack, and it was Mr. Powell who announced last night that Mr. Jack had accepted the suggestion.
MILWAUKEE, March 22 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's new campaign tactics of sharp, direct attacks on the voting record of Senator John F. Kennedy backfired today.
Manhattan's comment yesterday on the City Planning Commission's proposed zoning resolution for the borough was a chorus of general approval and one dissent from the Real Estate Board of New York.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Organized labor is playing a waiting game in the Presidential election, but the trend among the leaders now seems to be running pro-Kennedy and anti-Nixon.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Air Force disclosed a new regulation today that would permit the elimination of kitchen police at many of its bases.

GENEVA, March 22 -- Western diplomats hope to avoid a commitment on Soviet proposals for a moratorium on nuclear weapons tests until Moscow has shown its hand on the key problem of the right of inspection.
Scientists, preparing to land an earthquake detector on the moon, have begun to test its parts by dropping them out of airplanes, then seeing if they still work.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Rockefeller vetoed today a bill that would have barred welfare payments to persons who had not lived in New York State for at least a year.

JOHANNESBURG, March 22 (AP) -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd, whose Nationalist party is the driving force behind South Africa's racial laws, announced today that 132 members of the Pan-Africanist Congress held in Johannesburg would be charged with sedition.

One of the most dramatic, and welcome, last-minute legislative changes of heart recorded at Albany in recent memory was completed early Tuesday morning when within a few brief hours the omnibus branch banking bill -- generally believed destined to defeat -- was passed in swift succession by Senate and Assembly and immediately signed by Governor Rockefeller.
"ET in Arcadia ego." And I too was in Arcadia. The words are always melancholy because Arcadia is always far away and long ago.
EUGENE LIST gave a piano recital last night at Carnegie Hall that was listed as his "twenty-fifth anniversary program."

ALBANY, March 22 -- Assemblyman Joseph J. Weiser, a Manhattan Democrat, made an impassioned plea to his colleagues today to save Willard Parker Hospital from the Consolidated Edison Company. His plea got nowhere.
A sudden lunge and punch by a defendant at a robbery hearing yesterday knocked out an assistant district attorney in General Sessions Court.

ALBANY, March 22 -- A bill creating a new authority to take over the operation and rehabilitation of Westchester County parkways was approved unanimously in the Assembly today. It now goes to the Senate for consideration.

WAKEFIELD, Mass., March 22 -- Leo and David Bakalar are thirteen years apart in age and nearly as far apart in temperament. But as a brother team in the electronics industry, they are an effective combination.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Stomach cancer, for unknown reasons, is rapidly decreasing in the United States. Lung cancer is sharply increasing.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 22 (AP) -- Tony Puglie of Detroit took third place in the all-events and, with the help of Don Glinski, fourth place in the doubles of the American Bowling Congress championships today.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare failed today to win President Eisenhower's support for a subsidized system of voluntary health insurance for the aged.
Dossie Hollingsworth is a tall, curvaceous, cow-eyed actress who has never been a Broadway star because, among other things, she walks, talks and looks too much like Carol Channing.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 22 (AP) -- Negro pressure against segregation brought new sitdowns here today, at a public art gallery and at a downtown branch library.

THE GOVERNOR Met with legislative leaders. Vetoed bill requiring a year's residence in state for relief eligibility. Visited by John Johnson, publisher of The Watertown Times. Discussed administration bill on housing discrimination with Algernon D. Black, chairman of New York State Committee on Discrimination on Housing.

FOR a few women, who were able to forget the galoshes on their feet and the colds in their heads, spring was really here yesterday despite the weather. These few were the fashion reporters who saw Arnold Constable's collection of new spring millinery on the third floor.

JACKSON, Miss., March 22 -- Among bridge experts of the very highest ranks, such as the members of the finalist teams in the Vanderbilt Cup tournament here, every player is fully familiar with every kind of play, both straightforward and deceptive.
TELL CITY, Ind., March 22 (UPI) -- The mass grave of the sixty-three persons who died in the crash of a Northwest Electra airliner Thursday was uncovered here today.

Mrs. Jesse Asinof, chairman, has announced that seats in the orchestra and loges at Madison Square Garden are still available for Monday's performance by the Soviet Union's Georgian State Dance Company, which will benefit Childville.

Wintery winds have blown more than the usual number of customers to the railroads so far this year, while snowstorms have reduced freight traffic. Seaboard Air Line Railroad, for example, reported that passenger business to Florida in the first three months of 1960 ran 18 per cent above that in the 1959 period, which in turn was 10 per cent better than in 1958.
One of the questions facing persons paying income taxes that is generally overlooked stems from out-of-pocket expenses incurred by employes who cannot get reimbursement from their employers.
The drive for off-track parimutuel betting on horse races received a renewed push at City Hall yesterday, both from Mayor Wagner and the City Council.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Fernando Maria Castiella y Maiz, the Spanish Foreign Minister, was welcomed here tonight by Secretary of State Christian A. Herter.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The Conservation Department today announced Coast Guard approval of New York State's new registration program for motorboats. It goes into effect April 1.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The United States is preparing to announce intensified measures to prevent unauthorized flights by private planes to Cuba.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- Annoyances continued to pile up for Casey Stengel today.

Sales and earnings of the National Dairy Products Corporation in 1959 set new records, it was reported yesterday. The nation's top dairy products producer expects to have an even better year in 1960, according to E.E. Stewart, chairman.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN will conduct the New York Philharmonic Orchestra in a Young People's concert Saturday noon in Carnegie Hall. The theme of the concert is "Unusual Instruments of Present, Past and Future."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday.
June Allyson's show and the "Du Pont Show of the Month," both televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System, may be switched by their sponsor to another network in the fall.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Secretary of State Christian. A. Herter conceded today that the summit meeting was a "gamble" and said that he was not optimistic that it would yield much progress toward settling East-West disputes.
LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams today signed Elroy (Crazy Legs) Hirsch, their former end, as general manager.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Some grain futures contracts hit their highest and lowest prices of the season here today as final prices of March deliveries moved over a broad range.

ST. LOUIS, March 22 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor, with 40 points, led the Minneapolis Lakers to a 117-110 overtime victory over the St. Louis Hawks tonight in the fifth game of the Western Division play-off finals. A crowd of 10,043 saw the contest.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System's new policy of encouraging its local television and radio stations to editorialize appears to have been productive on two counts.
An experimental research program to develop a scientific method for selecting and training promising recruits for the police force was started here yesterday.
Eight hundred thirty-six persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This is 163 fewer than in the same week in 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A member of Congress reduced "unusual hospitality" still further today.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Navy reported today that "unparalleled progress" had been made in charting the location of radio stars by a giant pair of astronomical "ears" in a California valley.
THE PRESIDENT Met with Republican Congressional leaders.

PARIS. We are about to be treated to a new aspect of bouncy Nikita Khrushchev. Already familiar in many character parts -- the Iowa corn connoisseur, the Balinese balletomane, the trade union expert (a failure on Britain's political stage) and the ingenuous Indian peacemonger -- this versatile actor now appears in France.
An electronics engineer and a physician reported the discovery yesterday that muscles emit electrical signals in a frequency range once used for trans-Atlantic radio broadcasts.

A group of tenants accompanied by Councilman Louis Okin traveled from Housing Court to a tenement near Lincoln Square and back again yesterday. Their purpose was to find out if the heat, long off, had been turned on.

STUART, Fla., March 22 -- Everything changed radically today; neither the weather nor the salt-water fishing could have been much better. Even sailfish were rising a little, after an absence of ten days or so.

"The Sword Over the Mantel: The Civil War and I," retells yarns that were a part of the boyhood of the author, J. Bryan 3d, in Richmond, Va. Mr. Bryan, a former jounalist, is now serving on the staff of Gen. Lauds Norstad of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Edison Township, N.J., sold yesterday $2,175,000 of school bonds due serially from 1961 to 1985 to B.J. VanIngen Co., Inc. and associates. The price paid was 100,274 for 4 1/4 per cent obligations, an interest cost of 4.22 per cent.
ALBANY, March 22 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported today by the State Commerce Department:
THE formidable Charms of Rex Harrison were regrettably dissipated last night in a sixty-minute item of strained sophistication on "Ford Startime" over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The State Department expressed regret today over the violent police suppression of African demonstrators in South Africa. It did so while acknowledging that its statement was an intrusion into the domestic affairs of another country.
IT is mothers-to-be day at Lane Bryant's. Its spring collection of maternity designs by Helene Scott has been chosen with thought and taste.

Brown Bigelow The stockholders of Brown Bigelow, manufacturer of advertising specialties, approved a merger with the Standard Packaging Corporation at a meeting in Chicago yesterday. The merger previously had been approved by shareholders of Standard Packaging.

The former secretary of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. testified yesterday at his income-tax evasion trial that she had inadvertently led him to overstate his wife's income for 1951 instead of understating it.
A colony of "town houses" is planned for the Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney estate at Old Westbury, L.I.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The latest version of the Rockefeller Administration's court reorganization plan breezed through the Senate today with only two votes cast against it.
ALBANY, March 22 -- A new agreement between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner on a program to provide New York City with additional revenues was in the drafting stage tonight.

In the Landrum-Griffin Act Congress called for a massive reporting operation by labor unions designed, through public disclosure, to curb improper practices such as were revealed in the McClellan committee hearings. The organization finances and the democratic rights of some 18,000,000 union members are involved. The job of getting this done is being carried on mostly by the Bureau of Labor Management Reports in the Labor Department.
BOSTON, March 22 -- The Navy moved two vessels out of strikebound shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company today.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 22 (AP) -- Seven Negroes applied for enrollment today at the white University of Alabama Center here.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- Despite a touch of acrimony, a meeting was arranged for Thursday to try to settle the strike by actors against the movie studios.

JACKSON, Miss., March 22 -- The Silodor contract bridge team won the thirty-second annual contest for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup and the national team-of-four championship in a final match tonight with the von Zedtwitz team.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The House of Representatives hammered out today the firm framework of what will probably become the Civil Rights Act of 1960.
CAIRO, March 22 -- An office to recruit Arab volunteers to fight in the Algerian rebellion against France is being opened in Cairo.
PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- Family physicians were urged today to take the initiative in organizing and supervising inplant illness-prevention programs for employe groups in small business.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The State Commissioner of Education, Dr. James E. Alien, announced today the names of 250 winners of Regents College Teaching Fellowships.
Ampex, Inc. had a net income of $2,446,000 for the nine months to Jan. 31 which equaled $1.02 a share before the three-for-one split that was
A union's refusal to install $17,700 in air-conditioning equipment threatens to halt $470,000,000 in construction work here.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22 -- Harvard University has undertaken to find out what effect the increasing use of Federal funds is having on its programs.

That the United States would be outdoing Rip van Winkle if it failed to be wide awake to new expanding opportunities for export sales was the observation yesterday by Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller.
The Moore state commission cut down its debt proposals for the city yesterday -- for the time being -- to a single permissive bill to be offered to the Legislature today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 -- In their devotion to the Giants, Bay area sports fans have not lost their long-standing interest in track and field. Outdoor meets at the University of California and Stanford were well attended last Saturday and produced eye-popping results for the sun-basking railbirds.

LONDON, March 22 -- What must have been the ultimate in fashion shows was presented today at one of England's most famous houses, Osterley Park in Middlesex. It was put on by the Incorporated Society of London Fashion Designers in the presence of Queen Mother Elizabeth and Princess Margaret.
A richly designed Persian mosaic wall from a sixteenth century synagogue in Isfahan has been re-erected this month in a gallery of the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

Oscar Gruss Son, members of the New York Stock Exchange and dealers in foreign currency, have leased office space in the building being constructed at 80 Pine Street. The concern plans to take occupancy in September.

WESTBURY, L.I, March 22 -- Two jet driers, aluminum-enclosed jet airplane engines that direct heat into the surface of the race track, were among the biggest bargains in the $20,000,000 modernization program at Roosevelt Raceway.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The Wagner administration asked the Legislature today to authorize the construction of an underground parking garage for 1,000 automobiles in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Mrs. J. C. Austin has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julie Adelaide Morris, to Carter Lee Marshall Jr. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marshall of Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, formerly of New Haven, Conn.
A Manhattan dress manufacturer testified in Federal Court yesterday that Johnny Dio had told him "not to worry" about difficulties his concern was having with a labor union, in 1950.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Postmaster General Summerfield and the President have just loosed on the press such a mass of erroneous statistics regarding postal rates and deficits that I feel compelled to point out the more serious distortions.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- The Air Force successfully fired its Titan intercontinental missile today over a 5,000-mile course for the second time.

The West End Ninety-ninth Street Corporation has sold the "five-story apartment house with four stores on plot 50 by 10 feet at 1381-85 St. Nicholas Avenue, northwest corner of West 179th Street, in Washington Heights.

WARSAW, Poland, March 22 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the United States statement on Ambassador Jacob D. Beam's protest to Ambassador Wang Ping-nan about the sentencing of Bishop James E. Walsh:
ROBERT MANGALISO SOBUKWE, organizer of the current campaign against restrictive pass laws for Africans, is one of the new group of intellectuals who are leading the struggle for African nationalism.

Some of the members of a Protestant Episcopal church on Park Avenue, whose parishioners include many socially prominent persons, are going to have a fair to raise funds to aid the building plans of an Episcopal church in a tenement section of the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- House investigators reported today that the Army had squandered $100,000 by shipping 30,000 foot lockers to an air base in Germany that had ordered only 300.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator Stuart Symington, who is expected to announce his candidacy tomorrow, told today why he wanted to be President of the United States.

Formula Junior racing, introduced into this country less than a year ago, has had a phenomenal growth. From a single entry -- a Stanguellini brought from Italy by Alfred Momo and driven at Montgomery, N.Y., last summer by Walter Hansgen -- the field has increased to such an extent that thirty-six cars of more than ten makes have been sent to Sebring, Fla., for a thirty - lap race there Friday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Bing Crosby of Hollywood drew the gallery but Dave Ragan of Orlando, Fla., won most of the cash in the Seminole Golf Club pro-amateur tournament today, picking up $1,700.
Former Postmaster General James A. Farley agreed yesterday to run for Democratic convention delegate in Manhattan's Seventeenth Congressional District.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The Assembly approved and sent to Governor Rockefeller today a bill requiring school districts to provide free bus transportation for private and parochial school children.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The Assembly acted today to revive the state's stalled public housing program.

MONTREAL, March 22 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull, the Chicago Black Hawks' first scoring champion in a decade, and Jacques Plante, Montreal Canadiens' goalie, were in line for a $1,000 prize each today for their feats in the National Hockey League this season.
Prices of some grades of paper are on the rise, although others remain relatively weak, David L. Luke 3d, executive vice president of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, said yesterday.
Trade between Sweden and the United States will continue to grow in the Nineteen Sixties, according to Lars-Erik Thunholm, president of the Stockholm head office of the Skandinaviska Banken.
JOHANNESBURG, March 22 (Reuters) -- South Africa's pass laws first were introduced in 1807. The first organized demonstration against them occurred in 1903.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was saddening but not surprising to read, in Damon Stetson's March 14 story on automobiles of the future, that the automotive industry's preoccupation with improved transmissions, central hydraulic systems, bigger small cars, and smaller big cars precludes, as usual, any serious efforts toward making the automobile of the future safer than the one of today.
An armored truck moved quickly through the steel-gray emptiness of Fifth Avenue not much after dawn yesterday, leaving wet slashes in the snow. Inside, guards stood watch on two foot lockers.
THERE must be an easier way for Eugene Ionesco to say what he has in mind.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grant Merrill Palmer Jr. of Weston, Mass., to the Rev. Robert Ernest Grant took place yesterday in the Colinton Parish Church at Colinton Dell, near Edinburgh, Scotland.

THE ANTA Matinee Series at the Theatre de Lys got back onto safe ground yesterday with a brace of beautifully produced one-acters. The plays, by a couple of irreverent Irishmen named O'Casey and Carroll, were "Time to Go" and "The Coggerers."
Mayor Wagner took a short course in modern geography yesterday at Junior High School 167, at 222 East Seventy-sixth Street.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 22 (UPI) -- Barbara McIntire of Lake Park, Fla., used precision putting today to register a 5-and-4 victory over Joanne Goodwin in the final round of the fifty-eighth annual North and South women's amateur golf championship.
BOSTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain returned to form with 50 points and paced the Philadelphia Warriors to a 128-107 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.
GKNEVA, March 22 -- The West and the Soviet bloc threw some sharp accusations at each other today in the disarmament conference, which had managed to keep things gentle for a full week.
Prices again rose in the bond market yesterday as holders of prime fixed-income securities showed greater unwillingness than before to supply investments to bidders.
Winter set the stage at Aqueduct yesterday for a performance by Henry Moreno, the 108-pound rider from Downey, Calif., that combined the best and the worst of racing luck.
ALBANY, March 22 -- The Legislature voted today to eliminate the house-to-house check of voters now required in areas where the permanent personal registration system is in effect.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's suggestion that Congress come up with another natural gas bill received short treatment today from House Speaker Sam Rayburn, Democrat of Texas.
PARIS, March 22 -- France was braced today -- with mixed feelings -- for the arrival of Premier Khrushchev for a State visit, half serious international business, half propaganda spectacle.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The United States filed a strong protest with Communist China today against its treatment of the Most Rev. James Edward Walsh.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, said today that Democratic critics of the Administration's interest rate policy were "speculating with the national credit" in a "reckless" bid for votes.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 22 -- A coastal marsh came within seven feet of swallowing forever the body of Julian A. Frank, heavily insured New York lawyer who is suspected of having carried the bomb that caused the crash of a New York to Miami airliner near here on Jan. 6.

A GOOD fish store is as rare a treasure nowadays as a restaurant that serves top-quality meals at bargain prices. One such market, of special interest during this Lenten period, is the Tudor fish shop, 1154 First Avenue, between Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth Streets.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 22 (AP) -- Princeton, already well represented in the Football Hall of Fame after ninety years of intercollegiate competition, has six names on the 1960 list of nominees released today.

Passage of the omnibus banking bill by the Legislature early yesterday brought cries of legalized invasion from Westchester County leaders and a charge of conflict of interest from a Long Island banker.

The largest peacetime military airlift operation in history -- Exercise Big Slam/Puerto Pine -- now in its second week has posed, and may attempt to answer, a number of major air transportation problems.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 22 -- A 12-year-old girl surprised nobody today at a science fair when she demonstrated that females are sharper than males at getting what they want.4

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Sammy White said today he had retired from baseball only because the Boston Red Sox had traded him. The catcher added that the Red Sox management knew what he would do if traded.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The surprise approval of a major banking bill by the Legislature in the early hours of this morning came as a direct result of the collapse of a heretofore solid Democratic coalition.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday angrily denounced the hit-run drivers who have killed nineteen persons in the city from Dec. 28 to midnight Monday. Thirty-one other persons have been critically injured.
Prices rose on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday more from a lack of selling pressure than from an increase in demand. Volume held about steady, 2,490,000 shares, against 2,500,000 on Monday.

As practitioners of an artful diplomacy in which words bear no relation to deeds, the Soviets display notable dexterity in maneuvering at the two Geneva disarmament conferences sufficient to capture headlines in the world press. They continue to reject the Western plan for a step-by-step approach to comprehensive disarmament by balanced and controlled armament reduction, both nuclear and conventional.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would undertake a $400,000 project to reconstruct and replace the parts of the subway signal system "most vulnerable to breakdowns."
