AS customary in the series of New Music Concerts under the direction of Eric Simon, several new works dotted the program. Heard for the first time in this city at last night's concert, in Carnegie Recital Hall, were Jiri Pauer's Sonatina for Violin and Piano, three songs by Thomas Briccetti and two works by Salvador Ley -- Piece for Viola and Piano and "Semblanza" for piano, in memory of Maryla Jonas.
THE National Design Center has taken the stuff bathtubs are made of and created a spectacular exhibit of decorative objects and architectural materials for the home.

Potato futures rose sharply in active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The active near positions climbed the daily limit of 35 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) from the official settlement price established by the exchange on Monday.
HAVANA, March 22 -- The Cuban Government has given no indication of a serious desire to negotiate its differences with the United States despite the return of Ambassador Philip W. Bonsal to Havana.
It was the third day of spring yesterday, but nevertheless most New Yorkers trudged through thick snow showers.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 22 -- A senior Polish diplomat has secretly left Indonesia and was reported today to have requested asylum in the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An important bill is now pending before the New York Legislature. This is the Wise-Calli bill to conform our state personal income tax definition of income to the definition in the Federal tax law.
Five singers who competed in the New York area are among the seventeen finalists of the annual auditions sponsored by the National Council of the Metropolitan Opera.
GATLINBURG, Tenn., March 22 -- Racial segregation breeds its own excuses to justify the practice, the Federal Civil Rights Commission was told today.
The downturn in steel demand made itself felt in several areas yesterday.

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritanian Republic, March 11 -- One of the biggest and emptiest of the emerging African states, Mauritania, is like an elephant nibbled by ducks. She feels menaced by comparatively tiny but aggressive neighbors. Westerns, no older than those seen on television in New York.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A Federal judge threw out today a motion by the teamsters' union to block a flow of information from the Board of Monitors to the public.

LONDON, March 22 -- The second son of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh will be christened Prince Andrew Albert Christian Edward. The name was disclosed when William Prince, Registrar of the City of Westminster, called at Buckingham Palace today to register the birth.
GENEVA, March 22 -- The Soviet Union and Mexico proposed today that the rights of coastal states to fix the limit of their territorial waters at a maximum of twelve nautical miles be recognized.
Customers on the Lexington-Avenue Route 3 line or the Fourteenth Street Crosstown may be fascinated to learn that traveling by bus has become quite the proper thing to do.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- The world champions played a ball game at Al Lang Field on this bright, sunshiny afternoon. In the normal course of events this would have meant the Yankees. But in the upheavals of last season the Los Angeles Dodgers emerged with the designation.
The International Longshoremen's Association sought yesterday to invoke the LandrumGriffin labor reform law, which it fought vigorously to kill last year in Congress.
LONDON, March 22 -- South African gold-mining stocks fell sharply on the stock market here today after yesterday's riots near Johannesburg and Capetown.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The Senate today approved a proposal by Governor Rockefeller to grant pension-vesting rights to the 210,000 state and local government workers in the state employes' retirement system.
One of the more controversial aspects of radio and television commercials is the use of advertising words to accompany familiar songs.

William Saroyan, acknowledged for years as one of the most outlandish as well as impressive writing talents of this country, is now causing a furor in London with his unusual technique of play writing.
Mikhail Tal and Mikhail Botvinnik drew in the fourth game of their match for the world chess title in Moscow yesterday, according to a report received here.
The Port of Buffalo is preparing for the second season of the St. Lawrence Seaway with a huge new terminal designed for general cargo.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 22 -- Merchants in the European Common Market will be protected by a commercial "boomerang" against any dumping of goods across the borders of the six member states at prices below cost.

Man's first exploration of deep interplanetary space has confirmed that the earth wears a great electric belt around its waist. The space vehicle, Pioneer V, also appears to have intercepted a magnetic cloud before the cloud reached the earth.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee took action today to free the foreign aid program from the effects of the Arab economic boycott of Israel.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson branded as "a phony" today the latest Soviet proposal on nuclear weapons testing. He suggested that the United States break off the Geneva negotiations for a treaty to ban nuclear tests if the Soviet Union did not negotiate more realistically about international controls.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Senator Stuart Symington disclosed information today that some Agriculture Department employes had disposed of outside interests after an inquiry had started into conflict-of-interest cases.

A former tax aide of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. testified yesterday that he had overstated the Congressman's income by $2,500 in preparing Ma 1951 return but had understated that of Mr. Powell's wife by $3,300.

Howard Taubman will succeed Brooks Atkinson as drama critic of The New York Times at the beginning of the fall season, Sept. 1. An announcement by Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher and chairman of the board of The Times, also named Harold C. Schonberg, a member of the newspaper's music department, as senior music critic to succeed Mr. Taubman.

Dog shows would not amount to much without women. They form a large proportion, perhaps a majority, of dog exhibitors, breeders and caretakers. There are women professional handlers who are as capable as any men and better than many.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 23 -- Israel will get $500,000,000 from West Germany in loans or investments over the next ten years, according to a report broadcast today by the state radio.
LONDON, March 23 -- South African gold-mining shares erased a good part of yesterday's losses on the stock market here today.
BONN, Germany, March 23 -- A policy struggle that is likely to settle the political future of Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Vice Chancellor and Minister of the Economy, has begun in the Government's top rank.
Governor David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania declared yesterday that the Democrats would win the Presidency this fall "unless we commit some incredible error of judgment."

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan plans to present evidence to a grand jury concerning "any false statements" that may have been made by witnesses under oath in his investigation of television quiz shows.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The House of Representatives completed a five-part civil rights bill today and prepared to send it to the Senate tomorrow.
Alastair B. Martin and Robert Grant 3d, both former national champions, reached the semi-final round of the national court tennis doubles tournament yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
A debate on whether professional boxing should be abolished brought tears to the eyes of Jersey Joe Walcott at an otherwise cheerful Kiwanis Club luncheon yesterday.

TORONTO, March 23 (UPI) -- First-period goals by Gordie Howe and a rookie, Len (Comet) Haley, were all the Detroit Red Wings needed tonight as they beat the favored Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 1, in the opener of their Stanley Cup semi-final series.

Figures for less than a year's operation of the St. Lawrence power project show that consumers will save an "excess of $4,000,000" annually, Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, said yesterday.

At a special meeting yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla., the directors of Automatic Canteen Company of America elected John W. Cox as president and Frederick L. Schuster, vice chairman. Two Metuchen (N.J.) realtors said yesterday they had begun negotiations for the transfer of the Kansas City Athletics to the New Brunswick area of New Jersey.

Plans arc being completed for the April Ball, a benefit for Willoughby House Settlement in Brooklyn. The fete, sponsored by the Inter-School Committee, will take place tomorrow in the Roof of the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn Heights.

The Mississippi River Fuel Corporation is continuing to increase its holdings in the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company. Tickets are still available for the April 5 performance of "Greenwillow" at the Alvin Theatre, which will benefit the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. They may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, March 23 -- In a move to mollify legislative sensibilities, Governor Rockefeller has decided to scrap the words "task force" to describe the special study groups he has established and to call them, instead, "legislative cooperating committees."

GENEVA, March 23 (AP) -- Ambassador Arthur H. Dean, United States delegate at the conference on the law of the sea, said today many nations were pressing for an extension of their territorial waters with an eye on future claims to territorial space.
A floor in 19 Rector Street has been leased by the Erie St. Lawrence Corporation, through Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers. The lessee transports yachts and automobiles to Florida by ship.
City administration appointments are made on the basis of ability and integrity and will continue to be made that way, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.

In his last pre-summit appearance abroad Premier Khrushchev is now paying a twelve-day visit to France that is also his most ambitious effort to wreck the Western alliance system. For the evident and only thinly disguised purpose of his trip is to lure France away from the North Atlantic alliance and into a new French-Soviet Alliance against another Atlantic ally and partner, Germany.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) off to 5 points (25 cents) up yesterday.
LONDON, March 23 (UPI) -- The trend of Britain's exports and imports continued to rise strongly in the three months ended with February, the Board of Trade said today.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Legislation to outlaw rigging of television quiz shows and other irregularities in the broadcasting industry was introduced in the House of Representatives today.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Rockefeller disposed of his shareholdings in the Chase Manhattan Bank before he signed the omnibus banking bill, it was learned today. At a press conference, the Governor told reporters that there was "no conflict of interest" in his acting on the measure.
Favorite players enjoyed a good day at Aqueduct yesterday. George D. Widener's Yorktown won the featured Fresh Meadows as the sixth of seven successful public choices on the nine-race program.

PIERRE FRANEY, the celebrated chef who resigned recently from Le Pavilion when he became involved in a dispute with the owner, has joined the Howard Johnson Enterprises. He will be in charge of quality and flavor control for the chain's 00 restaurants and thirteen ommissaries throughout the United States.

PROVIDENCE, March 23 -- Martin Dalton, 91 years old, sentenced to a life term in 1896 for the murder of a New York business man, died today in the state prison he refused to leave when eligible for parole more than thirty years ago.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa rejected yesterday the Proposals of a state commission for changes in the city's debt program. He contended that they would "undo everything I have done to strengthen the city's credit."
The last tests for census takers in New York City will be held on Saturday in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Vice President Nixon appears to have flunked a scoring test of voting records by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Six thousand retired trade unionists overflowed Manhattan Center yesterday in a labor rally supporting passage of the Forand Bill. They booed President Eisenhower when a labor leader accused him of being dilatory on the proposed legislation.
Kidder, Peabody Co. and White, Weld Co. and associated underwriters are offering to the public today $12,000,000 of twenty-year 4.75 per cent debentures of Collins Radio Company.
Progress toward a new labor agreement covering 2,000 marine workers of eleven railroads in the Port of New York was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Government's foreign-aid chief gave more details today on the new aid policy of concentrating economic development help in "key" promising situations -- meaning Taiwan, India and Pakistan.
PARIS, March 23 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Premier Khrushchev's speech today to the France-U.S.S.R. Society, as distributed in English by Tass, the Soviet press agency:
THE woman who becomes top A sergeant In her home -- barking commands at her submissive husband -- has won a battle but lost a war.
TOKYO, March 22 -- U Nu of Burma has reappeared in Japan as a leader of Asian opinion outside his own small country.
It was Man versus Pigeon forty-nine stories above Park Avenue yesterday.

To THE EDITOR OF T HE NEW YORK TIMES : In his column of March 17 Arthur Krock indicates his agreement with the view of an "enlightened" Negro that enactment of the votingrights legislation now before Congress will endanger the Republic by adding "millions more of the unqualified to the voting rolls" in Southern states.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The White House has made a curt reply to a letter from Senator Hubert H. Humphrey in which he asked President Eisenhower to make "a clear statement" to the nation of the Government's Berlin policy.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- Patience, a virtue with which baseball men are not overly blessed, came to the rescue of the harried Yankees today.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Eisenhower has selected as a member of the Federal Communications Commission one of the severest critics of "crime, corn and commercials" in current radio and television.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Rockefeller withdrew today his program for mandatory fallout shelters in all public and private buildings.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Following is the roll call vote by which the House confirmed, 295 -- 124, its approval of the voting referee plan in the civil rights bill:
ALBANY, March 23 -- After prolonged debate, the Assembly passed a bill tonight authorizing the state to designate motion pictures that are fit to be seen by school-age children.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Jerome Kenneth Kuykendall, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, is a private-power man whose philosophy led him Into a public war with Senate liberals In 1957.

THE Beaux-Arts String Quartet, which played Quartet, which played last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, is clearly one of the superior ensembles of its kind.

East -- the Far East, that is -- meets West next season when the American Broadcasting Company introduces "Hong Kong" in direct competition with the National Broadcasting Company's highly rated "Wagon Train."
Audiences at New York's firstrun theatres this spring should be able to see more than thirty major films from the seven leading Hollywood companies, according to present release schedules.

JACKSON, Miss., March 23 -- The match last night that gave the Vanderbilt Cup for the second successive year to the team of Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia, John R. Crawford and Tobias Stone of New York and Norman Kay of Merchantville, N.J., was a series of well-played but dull bands.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The emphatic, unequivocal editorial stand taken by The New York Times on March 17, opposing the construction of a two-story sidewalk cafe at the southeast corner of Central Park adjoining Fifty-ninth Street and immediately west of the Plaza at Fifth Avenue, should receive the unanimous approval of all civic organizations and leading citizens.

General selling and profit taking following Tuesday's limit ise dropped potato futures prices sharply early in the ses sion on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later, short covering and new buying raised futures to new highs for the lives of the contracts.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., March 23 -- Plans for a multimillion-dollar redevelopment of Cretan's business and residential districts and of Westchester County's Croton Pdint Park have been drawn.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The New York State report to the 1960 White House conference on children and youth urged today "preventive services to forestall family breakdowns."

LISBON, Portugal, March 23 (Reuters) -- Portugal said today that secret "military documents," which two United States investigators this month put forward as evidence of an African nationalist rising in the Portuguese colony of Angola, were imaginary operation orders for a military exercise.

The city of Philadelphia and the Pennsylvania State General Authority will follow the Pennsylvania State Public School Building Authority in major borrowings in the public bond market this spring, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, March 23 -- The Soviet delegation told the West today that Moscow stood for strong international inspection and control of disarmament from the time the first soldier put down his rifle until the last nuclear bomb was destroyed.

TAMPA, Fla., March 23 -- Two avowed enemies of standpatism, the daring Frank Lane of the Indians and the equally daring Gabe Paul of the Reds, swung an interleague trade last fall that could have disrupting effects on either or both pennant races. Anxious to seal the Tribe infield, the ebullient Frantic Frankie pried loose from the Reds the slick-fielding Johnny Temple, who also is a 311 hitter.
A West Side political club sought to demonstrate yesterday that decent living was possible even in one of the city's worst slum tenements.

RABAT, Morocco, March 23 -- Firm action taken against activists of the National Union of People's Forces has provoked the flight of several prominent Moroccan officials and caused a threat of insurrection in the Atlas Mountains.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., March 23 -- Englewood was given a plan today "designed to preserve and enhance the community's essential character and to forestall obsolescence in residential and business districts."
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- H.L. Hunt, the Texas oil man, visited Secretary of the Interior Fred A. Seaton today to appeal for leases on some potential oil lands in the Gulf of Mexico.
BOSTON, March 23 (AP) -- Sammy White, the key figure in a Boston-Cleveland baseball battle, tonight reaffirmed that he would retire from the game, apparently ending week-long, confusing squabble.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The United States announced today a new program of controls to prevent illegal flights and export of arms to Cuba.
Once again an American plane, piloted by an American, has been brought down in Cuba. The State Department has properly denounced this species of international outlawry and expressed its regrets.
Mothers should have a bounteous time of it on Mother's Day, May 8.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Llangollen Farm's Eagle Admiral scored a onelength victory over Bally Ache the l-to-5 favorite, in today's 517,675-added Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park Power Dam finished third and Cuvier Relic fourth.
MONROVIA, Liberia, March 23 -- President William V.S. Tubman of Liberia denounced as "most barbarous" today the shooting down of African demonstrators by the South African police.
Dr. Peter Goldmark, inventor of the long-playing disk, and his associates at C.B.S. Laboratories have perfected a longplay tape machine.
Many persons will commemorate Tunnel Day today, appropriately but unknowingly, by pushing onto subway trains with the energy of stampeding buffaloes.

LINCOLN, England, Man 23 (UPI) -- English owned and trained Mustavon 'scored a three-quarters of a length victory today in the Lincolnshire Handicap, the first major stakes event of the British flat racing season.

Big business takes a paternal interest in showing how much it depends on small business. Thus, in recent years General Motors Corporation has reported on the number of its suppliers and the varied (and often odd) products they sell the automotive giant.

More plentiful supplies of money and lower rates, including the Wall Street report that call money costs would decline in the near future, were given the credit for a brisk revival in the stock market yesterday.
A major advance in electronics was described here yesterday at a meeting of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- State Department officials maintained today that they had "no choice" morally but to speak up against South African police violence against African demonstrators.

MOSCOW, March 23 (AP) -- Usually reliable informants say former Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin, ill and plagued by denunciations as a member of the socalled anti-party group, has been retired on a pension and is back in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that the new Soviet formula for a ban on nuclear testing, combined with earlier United States proposals, offered the basis for an international agreement stopping such testing.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 23 -- Evidence was presented today indicating that a dynamite explosion occurred aboard a New York-to-Miami airliner on Jan. 6 near the legs of Julian A. Frank, a heavily insured passenger, shortly before the plane crashed near Bolivia, N.C.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown Friday throug Sunday, unless otherwise noted.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Rockefeller reported tonight that an agreement between himself and Mayor Wagner on a state program to help New York City could be expected "momentarily."

HONG KONG, March 23 -- The steadily developing movement to increase the use of machines in Communist China's city and countryside has intensified the government's determination to eliminate illiteracy.
George Meany issued orders yesterday for a shotgun wedding of the feuding factions of tha American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in New Jersey.
Fifty persons picketed the F.W. Woolworth store at 33 West Forty-second Street yesterday, then marched a mile uptown to demonstrate at the South African consulate.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- There is a split among the Democrats, and in the Republican Administration and party, over whether Congress shall legislate an exclusive medicalcare subsidy for citizens over 65, to be paid for by a special tax levy on citizens in lower age brackets.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Scientists of the Atomic Energy Commission laid claim today to having achieved a controlled thermonuclear reaction.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare told Congress today that the Administration was united in its opposition to any form of compulsory health insurance for the aged.

A Bronx junior high school girl who got a letter from Premier Khrushchev a few days ago received a phone call from Moscow yesterday. The schoolgirl, Gail Bartley, 14 years old, told the caller, a correspondent for Komsomolskaya Pravda, that she was "much excited."

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 23 (UPI) -- Johnny Podres appeared in midseason form today in pitching the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 3-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The loss was the seventh in a row for the Orioles.

Two plays, which were seen on the screen, will be examined at the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa. They are "12 Angry Men" and "Operation Mad Ball." The former will open May 23 and the latter will follow two weeks later on June 6.
The Transit Authority opened a new medical clinic for employes yesterday at the 207th Street yards, 3961 Tenth Avenue.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Both houses of the Legislature approved a bill today to require special classes for severely retarded children. These are children with, intelligence quotients of 50 and under. They are trainable but not educable.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 23 -- South Africa expressed concern today over the condemnation by the United States of violent action by the police against African political demonstrators.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Thursday, March 24 -- Two long-term prisoners seized sixteen hostages inside the state prison here late yesterday and sent out word three hours later that "we want our freedom or there will be wholesale murder."

The former site of Seton Hospital in the Riverdale area of the Bronx brought more than double its upset price when it was sold at auction yesterday for $685,000. The upset figure the price at which bidding is permitted to start, was $325,000.
PARIS, March 23 -- Premier Khrushchev arrived today to be met by President de Gaulle and by crowds of polite and curious but not notably enthusiastic Frenchmen.

The Pennsylvania Railroad operated in the red last month, more than wiping out the profit of $333,976 it had in January. The system reported net loss in February of $2,279.000. This resulted in a net loss for the first two months of this year of $1,945,000.
The bidding up of the prices of high-grade bonds continued unabated yesterday in a way that left professional dealers almost breathless with perplexity.
DALLAS, March 23 -- With Michigan favored to capture team honors for the fourth straight year, the thirty-seventh annual National Collegiate swimming championships will get under way here tomorrow.

The six-story building Containing sixty-four apartments at 4163 Frame Place, corner of Sanford Avenue, in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by Peter Demetriou, a client of Robert P. Sheldon, Lnc., the broker in the transaction.
Queens home owners' associations rallied yesterday behind the city's proposed new zoning resolution as a protection against encroachment by apartment houses, commerce and industry.
The Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center Auxiliary will give a luncheon and fashion show Wednesday in the Roof Garden of the Pierre.

Spring Had Better Hurry Sring is on its way, creeping slowly northward, about to touch Virginia, then Delaware and the Jersey shore, then this town. Up New Hampshire way they'll have to wait a bit longer, but since they enjoy skiing, they probably won't mind too much.

The State Banking Department will accept no applications from New York City institutions for suburban branches in Westchester or Nassau Counties until July 1, the date the new omnibus banking law becomes effective, it was learned yesterday.
BOWIE, Md., March 23 (AP) -- First Money, owned and trained by Pete Anderson, was the winner of the $4,500 Carrolton Purse at Bowie today.

Franklin P. Adams, the F.P.A. of many newspaper columns and the "Information Please" radio program, died last evening in the Lynwood Nursing Home, 306 West 102d Street, at the age of 78. He had suffered from arteriosclerosis for five years and had been confined to the home for most of that time.
CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- The only old-crop wheat future contract still open on the Board of Trade posted another new season high today as the market generally worked into a steady to firm range.
LONDON, March 23 -- Colonial Secretary Iain MacLeod, left by air today for the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland where the racial situation is reported to be deteriorating rapidly.

A Japanese company has begun mass production of a twenty-one-inch color television set and is making arrangements to export it to this country. The company is Hitachi, Ltd., of Tokyo. The color set is being made under a license from the Radio Corporation of America and will be capable of receiving American color television transmission.
Adams-Millis Corp. An 18-cent quarterly dividend on the new common stock was voted yesterday by Adams-Millis Corporation, hosiery manufacturers, for payment on May 2 to holders of record of April 22.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The Rockefeller administration's 1960 court-reorganization plan won final approval in the Assembly today by better than 3 to 1.
HAVANA, March 23 -- One of Cuba's best-known television commentators was bitterly attacked today for having denounced the inroads of Communist influence here.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., March 23 (AP) -- The police broke up a picket demonstration today by girls at Skidmore College protesting discrimination against Negroes in the South.
PARIS, March 23 -- The French Communist party had a hard but generally successful day today at the start of Premier Khrushchev's official visit to France.

In a surprise statement at the close of the Monsanto Chemical Company's annual meeting yesterday, it was announced that Charles H. Sommer, executive vice president since last June, had been named president and chief executive officer.

Speaking before the International Executive Association here, Frederick H. Mueller, Secretary of Commerce, was enthusiastic about the prospects' for a rising rate of merchandise exports by the United States this year. He indicated that 1960 might show an increase over 1953 of "between 10 and 15 per cent."
ALBANY, March 23 -- The Assembly passed the bulk of Governor Rockefeller's anti-crime program today, despite scattered opposition -- most of it from New York City Democrats.

"Politics 1960," edited by Francis M. Camay and H. Frank Way Jr., will be issued tomorrow by the new Wadsworth Publishing Company of San Francisco. The book offers background information and insight into the current political scene.

HAVANA, March 23 (AP) -- Revolucion, newspaper of Premier Fidel Castro's movement, charged today that Prensa Libre, the nation's largest newspaper, was pro-American and guilty of "treason to the fatherland."

MIAMI BEACH, March 23 (UPI) -- Florentino Fernandez of Cuba used his formidable punching power tonight to gain a ten-round decision over Ralph Dupas before a crowd of 3,081 and a national television audience.
YESTERDAY (March 23, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Saw Secretary of StateHerter; Chairman McCone of A.E.C. and Spanish Foreign Minister Castiella.

NEWARK, March 23 -- A study group working under the direction of Newark's Superintendent of Schools has proposed an occupational-academic program for public school children who have failed to respond to the present curriculum.

Crew members of tramp ships that have been stranded in foreign ports for nonpayment of wages, port charges and other costs have refused to sign on unless they can be assured that these expenses will be met.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 23 -- When the local harness racing season moved into its third program tonight at Roosevelt Raceway some of the regulars were wondering what had happened to Bob Cherrix and his trotting and pacing stock.

PARIS, March 23 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President de Gaulle's welcome to Premier Khrushchev today and the latter's response, and excerpts from General de Gaulle's toast to the Soviet leader at a dinner tonight and from Mr. Khrushchev's answering toast:
The thrice-delayed Turkish passenger ship Tarsus finally left port yesterday after clearing legal hurdles involving safety, the United States Coast Guard and creditor claims.

CHARLES MUNCH indulged himself by conducting three of his favorite pieces at Carnegie Hall last night. Because he directed them with burning devotion and because the Boston Symphony is a great orchestra, works that are familiar took on special and renewed expressiveness.

LONDON, March 23 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion left London for Israel today convinced that Britain and the United States regard his country as a stabilizing force in the Middle East that must be kept strong.
Prosecution and defense lawyers developed differing accounts yesterday of why Leon Bregman, a dress manufacturer, paid Johnny Dio $17,375 from 1950 to 1952.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Your editorial of March 17 entitled "In Central Park -- No," in which you objected to Huntington Hartford's gift to the city of a sidewalk cafe at the edge of Central Park on Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, demonstrated that your news columns, which gave such excellent coverage to the announcement, are not controlled or colored by your editorial predilections.
A new Goverment policy that requires broadcasters to name on the air contributors of records, trips, props and prizes is causing consternation and confusion in the industry.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The United States offered Spain a helping hand today in her efforts to become a fully accepted member of the Western community of nations.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Federal Trade Commission is strengthening its staff of advertising monitors and broadening its coverage to include newspapers and magazines as well as radio and televsion.
THE sneezes, the sore throat and the sniffles are bad enough, but the worst results of a cold often are in a woman's appearance. She is demoralized, and she looks it.
The Liberal party threw its support officially last night behind Representative Ludwig Teller's bid for re-election in Manhattan's Twentieth Congressional District.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 23 -- The new Ceylonese Prime Minister, Dudley S. Senanayake, announced today an eight-member Cabinet. It was sworn in by Governor General Sir Oliver Goonetilleke.
The abnormally cold weather again has resulted in a sharp reduction in the nation's fuel oil stocks, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- A Senate Banking subcommittee started hearings today on a bill requiring that persons buying on credit must be informed of the total finance charges and interest they pay.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The chairman of the Federal Power Commission acknowledged today that he had had off-the record talks with a gas company representative shortly before the commission approved its application for a pipeline.

STUART, Fla., March 23 -- A new, dark-horse candidate has been nominated for the title of Outstanding Pineknot Porter of 1960. If nobody outstrips him in the next eleven months he will be awarded a plaque by somebody, without doubt. He is Bill Kaplan of New Jersey.
A prediction was made yesterday that consumers and retailers alike might soon be able to buy fabrics used in apparel and household furnishings with an assurance of minimum performance.
THE recent emergence of the indifferent, even bored, 8-year-old theatregoer was the subject of some backstage soul searching at a two-day Showcase of Theatre for Children, which ended yesterday.

Things took on a little brighter hue at Aqueduct yesterday, what with the sun shining at least part of the afternoon. In comparatively endurable weather, a crowd of 20,417 attended the activities at the spacious race track, making for the biggest turnout, since opening day Monday.

Owners of pleasure boats face a new registration and numbering procedure. It is complicated by ifs, ands and buts. In New York State, for example, this applies now to boats mechanically powered regardless of horsepower.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 14 -- A newly formed anti-Communist united front, linking several of Indonesia'ss most important , political parties, launched tonight an all-out attack on President Sukarno's plans for a "guided democracy" Parliament.
GARDEN CITY, L.I, March 24 -- The Nassau Physicians Guild tonight reiterated its opposition to a labor organization's plan to purchase the Hempstead General Hospital.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Government investigators are looking into possible connections between an agent of the Cuban Government and one of the two Americans captured last Monday after their private plane was shot down in Cuba.

IT is a fine week for greens at vegetable counters. Escarole, parsley, spinach and even green onions are fresh in color, crisp in texture and, most important, reasonable in cost. Broccoli is another handsome buy, and many chain stores are offering asparagus for from 23 to 25 cents a pound.
LOS ANGELES, March 24 (UPI) -- The Times-Mirror Company of Los Angeles and the New American Library of World Literature, Inc., of New York will be merged, it was announced today.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Lobbying by employer and insurance groups against Governor Rockefeller's health insurance conversion bill prompted the Governor and Republican legislative leaders today to make an unusual joint appeal for the measure's passage.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- Simone Signoret folded paper napkins carefully, then slit them geometrically with a drink stirer while she organized her observations on Hollywood in Oscar time.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the House passed and sent to the Senate today the civil rights bill:

For most bank customers in Westchester and Nassau counties, the coming of New York City banks to their areas may seem like a choice between a regional supermarket chain such as Gristede's or Bohack's and a larger chain such as Safeway or A. P.
The Board of Estimate voteo yesterday to acquire a forty-one-acre site in Bayside, Queens, for the new Queena Community College.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 24 (AP) -- Three of the world's top players were eliminated today as competition reached the semi-finals in the men's division of the Caracas international tennis tournament.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 24 (AP) -- Minority stockholders of a banana-hauling railroad went before New York State's highest court today with a $65,000,000 claim against the railroad's major customer, the United Fruit Company.
THE fine examples of such European chamber groups as "I Musici and the Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra have disturbed some American musicians. Why don't we have any comparable groups?

The Federal Reserve System, in open market operations, reduced its holdings of United States Government securities $372,700,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- The United States District Court refused today to accept pleas of nolo contendere [no defense] from defendants charged with fixing prices in the sale of $1,000,000,000 in heavy electrical equipment.

COLUMBUS, Ga., March 24 (AP) -- Joyce Ziske, Bonnie Randolph and Betty Jameson tied for the first-round lead in the Columbus women's open golf tournament today. Each shot a par 72 on the 6,557-yard Columbus Country Club course.

STUART, Fla., March 24 -- The vast lowlands around Lake Okeechobee, as seen from a low-flying small plane, seem to guarantee limitless opportunity for deer, quail, turkey and wild-pig shooting and for black-bass, bream and crappie fishing.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- House investigators disclosed today that they planned to hold hearings on off-the-record discussions between a gas company and members of the Federal Power Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today the National Labor Relations Board's right to apply retroactively new rules for elections to determine collective bargaining agents.
New complaints were ordered yesterday against a landlord after a hearing at which it was testified that conditions for which he has already been fined still existed at 53 and 55 West 105th Street.
A housepainter and a laborer were indicted yesterday for faking accidents to collect insurance.
Evidence that drug-resistant germs may be invading the community in epidemic proportions from hospitals where they breed was reported today by a team of Government and university scientists.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -- The Army Corps of Engineers today estimated at $264,000,000 the cost of developing the water resources of the Delaware River basin to meet the needs of the area for the next half-century.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Chances for Congressional action on a refugee bill this session rose sharply today with a strong push from Representative Francis E. Walter.
A series of research projects has established, in general terms, how much nicotine is absorbed by those who puff cigarettes, those who inhale the smoke and those who chew tobacco or take snuff.

Down, down, down go the prices of Cuba's bonds. In fact, the more Premier Pidel Castro has shouted, the lower the bonds have sunk. Back in 1956, the Republic of Cuba 4 1/2s of 1977 sold as high as 114 1/2. In the next two years, the high was 106.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Four suburban counties in the metropolitan area are scheduled to get $17,778,000 more in state aid in the next fiscal year than they are now getting.
