The Board of Estimate yesterday approved the City Housing Authority's plan to seize and refurbish two deteriorating West Side rooming houses.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Legislation authorizing a $75,000,000 state bond issue to be used to purchase new park and recreation land moved halfway through the Legislature today.

BUENOS AIRES, March 24 -- The army announced today that a wave of arrests and the seizure of documents in raids throughout the nation had uncovered a Peronist insurrectional plan based on terrorism and sabotage.
The Federal Trade Commission charged yesterday that a television commercial for Schick safety razors had egally frightened prospective purchasers of competing razors.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., March 24 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman informed two officials of the Detroit branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today that he had been correctly quoted on a statement he made about Southera lunch-counter sitdowns.
HAVANA, March 24 -- Cuba has questioned the full exercise of jurisdiction by the United States over its naval base at Guantanamo in southeast Cuba.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain will meet here Monday in an effort to resolve differences over the Soviet Union's latest plan to ban nuclear explosions.
Mayor Wagner announced last night pension benefits or salary increases for 180,000 city employes that will cost $31,000,000.

Federal policy for dealing with the explosive growth of the American metropolis yesterday was called "a jungle of disconnected programs and projects, strewn among a variety of administrative agencies."
In less, than four months the Democratic and Republican conventions will nominate their candidates' for President, one of whom will be the next President of the United States.
YESTERDAY (March 24, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Met with National Security Council.
Maurice Heckscher of Episcopal Academy, the top-seeded player, was defeated in the sixteenth annual interscholastic squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday.
GREENFIELD, Mass., March 24 (AP) -- Frederick Huff Payne, Assistant Secretary of War under former President Herbert Hoover, died today at the home of his son, Groverman. He was 83 years old.

ERIK HILLMAN gave a piano recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. He devoted himself to the music of Bach, and for this purpose he brought his own piano along. It was a lovely looking old Steinway, with an inlaid blond case, and it had no pedals.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Senator Stuart Symington announced his candidacy for President today on a platform of national unity, "lasting peace and unparalleled progress."
JACKSON, Miss., March 24 -- The Mississippi Legislature has passed a bill aimed at preventing integration of Methodist congregations in the state.

A group headed by Mishulam Riklis, president and chief executive officer of the B.T.L. Corporation, has arranged to acquire working control of the Glen Alden Corporation from the Albert List interests, according to usually well informed sources.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today tabled a civil fights bill amendment to combine the Administration's court - appointed referee plan with an alternative for Federal enrollment officers to protect Negro voting rights:
Rights to Shepherd Mead's popular book, "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," published by Simon Schuster, have been purchased by Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin.

Thirty-six dates for championship regattas during the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound west-of-Rye season were approved at the organization's spring meeting in the New York Yacht Club last night.
Thomas K. Finletter taxed the Liberal party yesterday with adopting "a narrow view" in endorsing Representative Ludwig Teller for re-election in Manhattan's Twentieth District.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney told a New Jersey legislative delegation today that the New York State nonresident tax bill was doomed unless his bill for resident tax relief was approved by the Legislature.

The Military Air Transport Service, whiph is flying an average of almost 7,000,000 tonmiles daily during the two weeks of Exercise Big Slam Puerto Pine, hopes the maneuver will clarify some of its problems.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 24 (AP) -- Pittsburgh threatened tonight to interrupt the West's dominance of the National Collegiate wrestling tournament by taking a slim lead after the first two rounds.

DALLAS, March 24 -- Lance Larson, Southern Californ's tremendous all-round swimmer swept the record slate clean tonight in the 200-yard individual medley event of the National Collegiate championships.
PARIS, March 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech by Premier Khrushchev at a lunchepn given today by Premier Michel Debre, as distributed in English by the Soviet press agency, Tass:
An insurgent group in the largest local of the International Organization of Masters Mates and Pilots won a two year fight yesterday for control of its local, No. 88.

"ALBANY, March 24 (AP) -- Senate Majority Leader Walter J. Mahoney said today it was 'inconceivable' to him that the Legislature would give tax relief to non-residents 'while refusing any to the people of New York State.'"

Television viewers can anticipate another year of Hope -- Bob Hope. The comedian will star next season on eight one-hour shows under the sponsorship of the Buick division of the General Motors Corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Air Force proposed to Congress today a drastic cutback in development funds for the Bomarc air defense missile on the ground that it was becoming obsolete.
"ALTHOUGH gallons of milk come in here each day," John Kazanas remarked cheerfully as he surveyed his small factory in the Bronx, "I doubt if I drink more than one glass a year."

Talk of declines in money rates caused the stock market to open with gains yesterday, but the improvement at that time was virtually the entire rise for the day. Thereafter, stocks held about even until they slipped in the final thirty minutes.
John Lardner, columnist for Newsweek magazine and The New Yorker, died last night of a heart attack at his home, 59 West Twelfth Street. He was 47 years old.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- Bob Goalby, a 29-year-old Illinois product playing out of Crystal River, Fla., shot a four-under par 67 and took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $40,000 DeSoto Lakes open golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Speculation was strong here today that the Treasury might offer a bond of more than five years to maturity in its financing to be announced next week. The Treasury itself was saying nothing, following an informal rule barring discussion of impending financings with only a week to go.
GENEVA, March 24 -- The United States announced today that it would stand by a three-mile limit for the territorial sea rather than accept expansion beyond six miles.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Union leaders said today they would end an eightweek strike against East Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company, if President Eisenhower named a Federal factfinding board to look into the labor dispute.
HONG KONG, Friday, March 25 -- Communist China and Nepal have agreed to form a committee to demarcate the China Nepal boundary.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The overwhelming vote by which the Senate today referred the House equal rights Mil of 1960 to its. Judiciary Committee, with instructions to report it in five days, brings near to consummation new Federal protections of Negro rights to voting equality with all other citizens.
Britain has begun to install a device in its new bombers and airliners that lands the plane in any weather completely automatically.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The publication in The Times of letters from G.P. Tschebotarioff (Jan. 25) and Edward M. O'Connor (Feb. 9) concerning the status and rights of national minorities in Russia requires factual corrections. Professor Tschebotarioff erroneously attributes to the Nazis the original authorship of the treacherous plan for total dismemberment of Russia.
PARIS, March 24 -- President de Gaulle and Premier Khrushchev began private talks today to define their "reciprocal views," which appear to be almost diametrically opposed, on European problems.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 24 -- Two armed convicts gave up the nineteen hostages they had held in a captured prison office for twenty-five hours and surrendered today. But they obtained a compromise agreement from state officials.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A former major official of the Department of Agriculture has told Senate investigators that he was forced to resign his $16,000-a-year-post.

IF "Some Angry Angel," a preposterously souped-up novel by Richard Condon, weren't so entertaining it would be just awful. Never before (except perhaps in the works of Tiffany Thayer) have so many wildly vibrating words been used to tell a triter or more crudely melodramatic story. Mr. Condon's prose is a thing of wonder and a source or consternation forever.

Average borrowings by member banks from the Federal Reserve declined by $139,000,000 to $587,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average reserves in excess of requirements declined $69,000,000 to $439,000,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 24 (AP) -- A prominent clergyman said today that Protestant thinking was tinged with Marxist ideas and many Protestant leaders "are leaning too heavily in the left-wing direction."
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The nation's department store sales last week were 6 per cent below the level of a year ago. Volume was off in all districts.
A two-way trade agreement involving a large volume of world-wide watch business was announced yesterday by the Bulova Watch Company, Inc., and the Citizens Watch Company of Japan.
IN the early depression years after the 1929 stock-market crash, contract bridge was about the only booming business there was.
North Tonawanda, N.Y., borrowed $3,086,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance sewerage, street and water system improvements. The money was raised by serial bonds due from 1961 to 1987.
Electronic computers in the near future will make 80 to 90 per cent of industry's executive decisions, D.B. Paquin predicted yesterday.

Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba and Federico Thompson of Argentina, a pair of welterweights who were little known half a year ago, meet in a scheduled 'welve-round fight at Madison Square Garden tonight The winner has been promised a shot at Don Jordan's 147-pound title in May. Paret is an 8-to-5 favorite to spoil Thompson's American debut.
The sharp price rise in Treasury and other prime-risk bonds was checked yesterday by the disinclination of dealers to keep following each other's bids upward.

FOR a career diplomat and P student of international law, Fernando Maria Castiella y Maiz has had a singularly active, not to say violent,. career. Since his college days, the Spanish Foreign Minister has embraced controversy.
The Philadelphia and Reading Corporation lifted sales by 79 per cent last year to a record $141,642,840 from $79,175,202 in
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- A key House Republican forecast failure today for a Democrat's effort to force a vote this session on Government-paid health benefits for the aged.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 24 -- Perhaps driving a harnes horse has developed into a younj man's game. However, amon the pilots cnjrrently at Roosvelt Raceway, the owner of th best record is Warren Dennis who only last night observe his seventy-second birthday.

WASHINGTON. March 24 -- The United States reassured the members of the European Free Trade Association today that its approval of the latest move of the European Common Market did not reflect any animosity toward the association.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate Government Operations Committee refused today to approve a resolution to take over some functions of the expiring rackets committee. The vote was 5 to 4.
JULIUS CARLEBACH heeds the call of the wild -- when it comes to jewelry.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at the telegraph offices yesterday at the time indicated in paren-

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday that the city's bankers agreed with him in opposing a state commission's proposals for revising the city debt program. He called the proposals "owe-as-you-go," rather than "pay-as-you-go."
WARSAW, March 24 -- The Polish regime and the Roman Catholic hierarchy are reported to have reached a compromise on limited objectives.
John Dell Isola, the New York iants' line coach for the New easons, yesterday was named efensive coach for the New York Titans of the new American Football League.
LONDON, March 24 -- Demad for industrial shares trailed of on stock exchange here today after a buoyant start. Net movements were small and too mixed to show a definite trend.
IN the last act of Jean Anouilh's ''Jeannette," acted at the Maidman Playhouse last evening, one of the characters remarks: "The main thing is not to be taken in."
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The "other America" was back In the news today: not "the affluent society" we hear so much about, but the indigent society that once dominated the front pages.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 24 -- The Government banned all meetings today until the end of June in the heavily populated areas of South Africa.

GENEVA, March 24 -- The Soviet Union said today that it would not permit aerial inspection of all its territory until the world was completely disarmed. Once the goal of complete disarmament had been attained, the Soviet delegation said at the East-West disarmament conference here, Moscow would open all its skies to inspecting planes.
Sterling Drug, Inc., had its best year in 1959 with sales and earnings at records, J. Mark Hiobert, chairman and president, reported in the annual statement issued yesterday.
World sugar futures rose sharply in late trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The volume was 26,650 tons.

The Charles P. Young Company, financial printers since 1902, leased the ground floor in 39 Chambers Street, opposite City Hall, through A.J. Goldstein Co., brokers. Helmsley-Spaar, Inc., is agent for the building.

The noted aviatrix, Amelia Earhart, her navigator and her plane disappeared in 1937 while on the last lap of a round-the-world flight. Although very little evidence was found, many rumors sprang up about their fate.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate today passed a bill to create an agency to borrow up to $525,000,000 to finance private housing.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: J. Anthony Panuch, Special Adviser to the Mayor on Housing, has now published hig report and mads certain recommendations to the Mayor.

The Child Development Center theatre benefit, originally scheduled for the April 5 performance of "The Good Soup," has been changed to May 3 because of the closing of the French comedy. The theatre party will now be held at "The Best Man," a new Gore Vidal play starring Melvyn Douglas, which is scheduled to open at the Morosco Theatre next Thursday.

LONDON, March 24 -- Prime Minister Macmillan will urge acceptance in principle of the latest Soviet proposals of a nuclear test ban when he confers with President Eisenhower Monday, authortitative sources said tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics won the Eastern Division championship of the National Basketball Association tonight with a 119-117 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors. The winning basket was scored by Tom Heinsohn as time ran out.

New York State has prepared an explanation of the law pertaining to its income tax to help the nonresident minimize his payment and perhaps obtain a refund from the state on April 15 of any overpayment under withholding.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A $2,250,000 civil antitrust suit was filed in Federal Court yesterday against Arthur Murray, his dance studio corporation, two other persons and another corporation.

LONDON, March 24 -- The Government finally broke its official silence on the South African riots with a carefully worded motion today in Parliament expressing sympathy for "all the people of South Africa."
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Justice Department and the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers disclosed today a new step to discourage payola.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House of Representatives passed its civil rights bill today and sent it to the Senate. The vote was 311 to 109.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24 -- Mickey Mantle made his long-deferred debut in the exhibition campaign today, but it scarcely was a success. In fact, the Switcher, along with all the other Yankees, found himself rather painfully overshadowed as a peppery band of Cardinals flattened Casey Stengel's Bombers, 10 to 3.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- Old-crop wheat and new-crop oats futures contracts hit their highest prices of the season again today as they continued to lead further advances on the Board of Trade.
A woman who accompanied Hazel Scott on a piano concert tour in 1951 testified in the income tax trial of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. yesterday that she had been paid $50 a week.

Operators of resorts in the northlands kept talking in terms of Easter skiing yesterday. New snowfalls were reported at such upstate points as Saranac Lake and Speculator in the Adirondacks and Stowe and Jeffersonville in Vermont.

Charges that the new state college at Oyster Bay, L.I., which is intended to be an engineering school, has no regular engineering course were made yesterday by three faculty members whose contracts have not been renewed.

With Prime Minister Macmillan arriving in Washington over the week-end and Premier Khrushchev already in Paris, preparations for the East-West summit meeting are now going into high gear. With prospects for political agreements dim, efforts are apparently under way by both sides to prepare some agreements on disarmament which the summit meeting could then ratify and present to the world as achievements justifying it and more such meetings in the future.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (A.P) -- Senate investigators heard testimony today that slick time-sales plans were being used by some salesmen to disguise usurious credit and interest charges.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 24 -- A program was begun today to train 1,515 employes of the New York Thruway Authority to administer emergency medical treatment within their ranks.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 to 25 points (15 cents to $1.25 a bale) up yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24 -- Trading activity among the big league clubs was far more feverish than normal last winter, all deals being shrewdly designed to add strength or balance or both to each team. But one exchange seemed to make no sense whatsoever. The Pittsburgh Pirates gave Ronnie Kline, a top-ranking pitcher, to the St. Louis Cardinals for Gino Cimoli, an outfielder they don't appear to need.
A map of the far side of the moon, published in a recent issue of the Soviet newspaper Pravda, sprinkles its honors as widely over the world of science as it does over the hidden face of the moon.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 24 -- The Asian and African group of nations decided today to ask for an immediate meeting of the Security Council to consider recent outbreaks of Violence in South Africa.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The United States denied today, with comment and a document, the Communists' contention, that Berlin is part of East Germany.

MONTREAL, March 24 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens got off to a winning start in defense of their National Hockey League Stanley Cup championship tonight. They defeated the crippled Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 3, in the opening game of the best-of-seven semi-final series.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Fernando Mario Castiella y Maiz, Spanish Mnistcr of Foreign Affairs, pictured Spain today as a victim of the world press.
Motorists' tolls continue to be the dominant factor in the success of the Port of New York Authority.
ALBANY, March 24 -- New York City and its four suburban counties could receive 56 per cent of $63,500,000 in additional education aid under Republican legislation scheduled for passage next week.
In a stunning reversal, Jimmy Bostwick and his brother, G. H. (Pete) Bostwick Jr., were beaten in the national amateur court tennis doubles championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- A bill designed to heip state and local governments solve the problem of declining rail commuter services was introduced today by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Following is the text of a statement today by Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, announcing his candidacy for the Presidency:

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Rail and truck loadings last Week were both' below the 1959 levels. Rails showed a marked Increase -- and truck freight showed a slight decrease -- from the preceding week, however.
The president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation (I.T. T.) expects "over the next five years at least a doubling in our volume and a greater improvement in our earnings."

The twelve-story apartment house for sixty families at 777 West End Avenue, southwest corner of Ninety-eighth Street, has been purchased by Weinreb Management for cash over mortgages amounting to $400,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- A prominent Western o man today asked Congress to pass legislation to encourage the expldration of so Called tar sd oil or shale deposits on lands in the - public domain.

The evening performance of "Duel of Angels" on April 27 in the Helen Hayes Theatre will be a benefit for the Speyer Hospital for Animals. This will replace the event that was to have been at the April 20 performance of "The Good Soup," which closed.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The Senate voted and sent to the Governor today a hill to prohibit New York City health authoriies from requiring that milk containers be dated to show vhen the milk was pasteurized and delivered.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 24 -- Orders banning the export of pirated editions of foreign-language books were issued today by the Chinese Nationalist Government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your March 22 editorial "Two Presidents Re-elected" notes that the recent Korean election "was accompanied by violence * * *." This unfortunate affair, of course, imperiled orderly democratic development in that country and no doubt greatly concerned its guardian, the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 25 - The Pentagon announced today a major shift in defense plans to counterbalance "weapons on which the Soviet will have to rely for decisive attacks within the next several years."
THE hero of Caskie Stinnett's new novel, "Out of the Red,"* is a young-man-about-Washington-bureaucracy always at war with himself: a Cavalier with a Puritan conscience.
The decision by Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia Warriors to withdraw from National Basketball Association play apparently took everyone by surprise yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, March 25 (AP) -- Ed Macauley will be replaced as coach of the St. Louis Hawks by Paul Seymour, The Associated Press learned tonight.

American Factors, Ltd., has proposed a two-for-one split of the capital stock. The proposal will be presented to stock-holders at the annual meeting on April 12 in Honolulu. If the split is approved, the company intends to pay dividends of 20 cents a quarter on the new shares.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In his letters published on March 6 and March 18 Dr. Arthur Morgan proposes another alternative -- his seventh -- to the Allegheny River Reservoir. Since the proposal is similar to five others studied in great detail in 1958, I can only conclude that it has been put forward as a delaying tactic in order to prevent this urgently needed flood control project from being constructed.
CHICAGO, March 25 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission yesterday charged Crane Company with violating the anti-trust laws by acquiring interests in five competitors within the last two years.
TELEVISION'S accomplishments and aberrations were demonstrated last night in a witty and enjoyable program preceding the "TV Guide Awards" on Channel 4.
A diet rich in fats interferes with the body's ability to dissolve blood clots, according to a scientific report delivered here yesterday.
Mikhail Tal, the challenger in the world chess championship match with Mikhail Botvinnik at the Pushkin Theatre in Moscow, continued to hold the lead yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- All new-crop oats contracts posted highs for the season again here today. May wheat, which paced a generally higher trend throughout the week, had a setback.

COLLEGE PARK, Md, March 25 -- With his spirits as high as an elephant's eye, Tommy Evans of Oklahoma tonight predicted that his muscular Sooners would capture the thirtieth annual National Collegiate wrestling title The youthful coach was not going out on a limb.

The odds in last night's twelve-round welterweight fight, at Madison Square Garden between Benny (Kid) Paret, 145 3/4 pounds, of Santa Clara, Cuba, and Federico Thompson, 146, of Buenos Aires were 'pick' 'em at ringside-time.
DALLAS, March 25 -- Records of all descriptions continued to be clay pigeons tonight for the sharpshooting varsity swimmers in the thirty-seventh annual National Collegiate championships.
The teaching of "togetherness" was assailed yesterday by a leading educator.

'"The Origin and Meaning of Hasidism," by Martin Buber, edited and translated by Maurice Friedman, will be published by Horizon Press on April 25 In it Professor Buber completes his life work of recreating and interpreting the communal Jewish mysticism that flourished among the Jews of eastern Europe in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.
Alcoholism afflicts about per cent of the nation's industrial. work force, a conference in alcoholism in industry was told here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, asked a Federal District Court today to disqualify Martin F. O'Donoghue as chairman of the court-appointed monitors assigned to watch over the union.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Frederick H. Mueller, Secretary of Commerce, said today there was a "truth gap" In criticism of the Administration's military and economic policies.

WITH the-death of Dorothy Rice Sims Thursday, bridge lost the last and most lovable of the greatest. and most colorful foursome it ever knew, Ely Culbertson and his wife Josephine, and Hal Sims and his wife Dorothy.
Mary MacKenzie, mezzo-soprano from Del Mar, Calif., won the Metropolitan Opera auditions yesterday afternoon.

FERNANDEL proves himself a model vagrant in "The Easiest Profession," yesterday's arrival at the World, but it is Ginette Leclerc, as a member of an even older profession, who provides the comedy's healthiest laughs.
LONDON, March 25 -- Some important persons here see Prime Minister Macmillan's visit to Washington as a chance to sound Administration opinion on a range of international issues.

PARIS. It is always delicate to contemplate the impact of religion upon politics. We Americans are made familiar with one embarrassing aspect of this question as Senator Kennedy's campaign gathers momentum.
Frederick W. Scholem, who owns the buildings at 155-57 East Thirty-ninth Street, has purchased the adjoining property at 151-53 East Thirty-ninth Street and now controls a plot 82 by 100 feet.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March '25 -- Boys and girls from sixty-six high schools in ten states held a mock United Nations session at the United Nations today.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, young people's concert, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, noon; "Andrea Chenier" at 2 P.M. and "La Traviata" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch, conductor, Gary Graffman, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Vienna Choir Boys, Town Hall 2:40, and Beaux Arts Trio of New York, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:30.
PARIS, March 25 -- This was Mme. Khrushchev's day for culture in her visit to France with her husband and three daughters.
That proposal for a "secret" ballot for elections appearing in United States Steel Corporation's proxy statement has raised the question "How?"

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Two scientists have invented the first optical maser, a device that is expected to have great importance in communication by light waves. The Instrument produces a very sharply defined beam of light, which has possible uses in sending signals to or receiving signals from satellites and other bodies in space.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain, a basketball legend after only one season as a professional, quit the Philadelphia Warriors an the National Basketball Association today in a surprise move.
COLUMBUS, Ga., March 25 (AP) -- Patty Berg gained a first-place tie with Joyce Ziske at 149 today after the second round of the Columbus women's open golf tournament.
AINTREE, England, March 25 (UPI) -- Twenty-seven thoroughbreds will compete tomorrow in the Grand National Steeplechase, which decides sweepstakes winners throughout the world.
TRENTON, March 25 -- Boardwalk and amusement-park games of chance will become legal in New Jersey on Monday for the first time since June, 1956, when they were outlawed by the State Supreme Court.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

GREENSBORO, N.C., March 25 -- Negro student leaders in this city where lunch-counter demonstrations began have warned that they will march back into the stores unless desegregated service is established.
Volume in potatoes futures trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange was heavy. A total of 2,682 carlots of 50,000 pounds, each changed hands.

The Ingersoll-Rand Company and the Black Decker Manufacturing Company are discussing the possibility of merging, Robert H. Johnson, chairman of Ingersoll-Rand and Robert D. Black, chairman and president of Black Decker, have announced.
"We Must Find a Design" The news item: Ernest Marples, Minister of Transport, announced in London that he plans to establish a long-term study group to solve Britain's traffic problems.
A mixed reaction to the proposed new city zoning law was given yesterday at the City Planning Commission's hearing for residents of Staten Island. The hearings at City Hall drew 150 persons.

LA CROSSE, Wis., March 25 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey swung jubilantly through Wisconsin's Third Congressional District today. He declared he was "riding a wave of support" that will carry him to victory in his Presidential primary fight April 5 with Senator John F. Kennedy.

The National Council of Churches and its member denominations "are and always have been unalterably oppesed to communism," the Rev. Dr. Roy G. Ross, general secretary of the organization, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Federal Communications Bar Association protested today that one bill aimed at preventing, improper influences on Federal, regulatory agencies was so broad that it might cover innocent acts.
BUENOS AIRES, March 25 -- Terrorism continued today as the campaign before Sunday's Congressional election drew to a close.

The annual report of Conde Nast Publications, Inc., disclosed yesterday a net loss of $622,835 for 1959. Of the total, $471,459 represented a loss in the fourth quarter for Street Smith Publications acquired last August.

To speed the construction of a final 500-mile link in a new rail line linking Colombia's Caribbean and Pacific coasts, the Colombian National Railways has purchased seven Diesel-electric locomotives from the General Electric Company here for hauling rock ballast.
Small changes characterized trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Only dozen or so issues rose more than a point and even fewer dropped that much.
A DRAMATIC and faithful TV version of "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" appeared on Channel 2 last night.
ALBANY, March 25 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported to the State Commerce Department today:

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 25 -- Two fugitives from the Dominican Republic -- one a brother-in-law of Lieut. Gen. Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina Jr., son of the dictator, and the other a Dominican Air Force officer -- sought political asylum of the United States here today.

Lynch Corp. Sales of the Lynch Corporation in the first two months of 1960 were 60 per cent higher than in 1959, Will Freeman, president, said at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday. Earnings "showed a very substantial increase," Mr. Freeman reported.
Eddie Hodges will star in a sixty-minute TV special on the Columbia Broadcasting System network on June 23.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission opened an unlimited investigation of the passenger services and financial affairs of the New York, New and Hartford Railroad today.

GADSDEN, Ala., March 25 -- Three youths hurled a fire bomb against the window of a crowded synagogue tonight. When several members of the congregation rushed out, two were hit by shots from the youths' car.

Warrants were issued yesterday for the arrest of two owners of buildings at 53 and 55 West 105th Street alter a clergyman had used hacksaw, hammer and pliers to restore gas and electricity for tenants.
Widely divergent views over the way viruses cause cancer were expressed at a meeting of scientists here yesterday. The controversy centered on the target of tumor virus attacks.

NEWARK, March 25 -- Last November Linda Rodrigues of 91 McWhorter Street, a fifth-grade pupil at the Lafayette Street School, read a newspaper account of a boy in Memphis, Tenn., who had written to the Soviet Union for soil samples.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 25 -- The 7-year-old mare, Clara Song, broke in the first race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Such a break may temporarily break her backers and a disgruntled loser might express disappointment, as some among the 19,517 fans did.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Governor Rockefeller appointed R. Burdell Bixby of Hudson, N.Y., as chairman of the State Thruway Authority today. The authority supervises the 559-mile highway from New York City to Buffalo and the Pennsylvania state line.
More than 1,500 members of the United Federation of Teachers voted yesterday afternoon to authorize a strike if necessary to gain higher wages and other beneifts.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The average level of consumer prices last month climbed back to the historic peak established in November. An official of the Labor Department said that the outlook was for more bad news.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 25 -- President Sukarno rebuffed today an appeal to postpone formation of a Parliament amenable to his ideas. The appeal was issued yesterday by an anti-Communist coalition known as the Democratic League.

The "winter" race meeting continued at Aqueduct yesterday. With the temperature in the 20's and with the wind blowing at more than thirty miles an hour, the horses performed as scheduled, and there were 17,611 customers on hand to speculate on what the runners could do.
A military court last night found Anthony J. Savello, a 31-year-old Queens landscape gardener, guilty of desertion from the Army in 1952.
OCEANSIDE, L.I., March 25 -- Fire swept the widely known Church of St. Anthony's Shrine here today, destroying relics that had attracted thousands of pilgrims.
MADISON, Wis., March 25 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts said tonight that the Soviet Union's proposal for banning nuclear tests "cannot be lightly tossed aside or dismissed."
BRADENTON, Fla., March 25 -- The Yankees finally bobbed up today with a performance for which Casey Stengel had been waiting these many weeks.

Nofthrup Knox of Buffalo and Aiken, S.C., the world champion, and his brother, Seymour Knox, will defend their national, amateur court tennis doubles title at noon today at the Racquet and Tennis Club. Their opponents in the final round will be Alastair B. Martin and Robert Grant 3d of New York, both former champions.

Except for the Treasury's discount bills, prime debt investments tended to ease slightly in price yesterday. The adjustment in market values seemed to be of the stabilizing kind, one that evened, off the price heights explored during the bullish trading sessions early in the week.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 25 -- After three days of late and unexpected rain, the sun probed tentatively through cloud layers that began scattering today over most parts of Israel.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that parts of the latest Soviet proposal for a ban on nuclear tests were unacceptable to the United States Government.

The Board of Education indicated yesterday that some parents who had purchased or rented expensive apartments so their children could attend Public School 6, a so-called "silk stocking" school at Eighty-first Street and Madison Avenue, would be disappointed.
LONDON. CLOTHES designed by Seventh Avenue's Mr. Mort and looking as American as any snappy Madison Avenue secretary, arrived here recently with a bang.
DETROIT, March 25 -- Rivals of Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts pushed a determined stop-Kennedy movement today at a conference of Democratic leaders from fourteer Midwestern states.

The parking lot at 32 to 44 Clinton Street, off Pierrepont Street, in the Heights area of Brooklyn, has been sold by Charlotte Mark to the Lion Management Corporation for about $250,000. The site is 130 by 100 feet and will be improved with a twelve-story apartment house.

Twenty players representing colleges from all sections of the United States will take part in the thirteenth Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund Bast-West all-star basketball game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: British newspapers carry advertisements welcoming us to the United States. President Eisenhower is quoted as proclaiming 1960 as a "Visit the United States of America Year." The advertisement assures us that from the Atlantic to the Pacific "the whole country is your host."

Mayor Wagner announced his opposition yesterday, to a measure approved Thursday by the Legislature that would prohibit the city's Board of Health from requiring the dating of milk containers to show when the milk was pasteurized and delivered.
ROME, March 25 -- The Italian Cabinet crisis was at least temporarily resolved today, a month and a day after it had been precipitated by the resignation of Premier Antonio Segni.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad experienced a $1,016,774 net railway operating loss last month. In February, 1959, the deficit was $665,244.

GENEVA, March 25 -- The Soviet Union turned down today a Western request for immediate, detailed negotiation on the first jobs and powers to be handed over to an international disarmament organization.

NEWARK, March 25 -- A civil suit seeking $6,000,000 in damages and injunctive relief from six unions was filed in the Federal District Court here today by the Newark Morning Ledger Company. The suit also named sixteen individuals.

In order to establish the juridical basis for a discussion of Germany and Berlin at the East-West summit meeting, the State Department has republished both the Russian and English texts of the basic protocol governing the situation.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Representative Charles H. Brown, Democrat of Missouri, campaign manager for Senator Stuart Symington in his effort to win the Democratic presidential nomination, said today Symington organizations were "established and going in six states" and half a dozen are being formed.

ALBANY, March 25 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today-authorized the New York Central Railroad to increase the price of twenty-six-trip tickets in the metropolitan New York City area, effective April 1, next Friday.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Department of Justice will present its case for the House-passed civil rights bill to the Senate Judiciary Committee on Monday.
Some bogland pizzlers of nature are now on display at the Bronx Zoo. All are frogs from Trinidad.
Mayor Wagner's Committee for Off-Track Betting disclosed yesterday that under its plan bettors would be allowed to bet on credit.
MEXICO CITY, March 25 -- Lieut. Comdr. Jaime Varela Canosa, Cuban naval attache in Mexico, has defected and is seeking refuge in a near by country.

THE mystery of what the vacuum cleaner devours has been solved by a cleaner with a see-through window. In taking the guesswork out of whether the dust bag is full or not, Lewyt has saved time and messy fingers for the operator, and, since overloading is harmful, possibly damage to the machine.
In a ceremony rich in solemn reverence, the Rev. Canon James Stuart Wetmore was consecrated a Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday.

HAVANA, March 25 -- Anti-Communists and pro-Communists, mostly students, engaged in fist fights today in front of a television studio. The fighting began during demonstrations of partisans and opponents of Luis Conte Aguero, a commentator who has been the target of violent official attacks for his anti-Communist statements.

SEEKING, Fla., March 25 -- Jim Hall of Dallas and Paul Richards of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., were victors today in two races that served as preliminaries to tomorrow's twelve-hour world championship sports car race.
The current strike of grain trimmers in the Port of New York was building to a crisis yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent, to 120.1 per cent of their 1947-49 level, during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Common stocks and fixed-interest securities will share the spotlight in next week's new capital market. A full calendar consisting of more than $130,000,000 of bonds and debentures and eight major offerings of common stock contrasts sharply with the moderate activity of recent weeks.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 25 (UPI) -- Baseball Commissioner Ford Frick today stepped directly into the controversial Sammy White case by ordering Boston to return Russ Nixon to Cleveland and hinting that the Indians and Red Sox might work out their problems with a new trade.

SEOUL, Korea. March 25 -- The Ministry of Agriculture anounced today that the South Korean Government had decided to export 30,000 tons of rice to Japan. It was reported earlier that Japan had agreed to import Korean rice.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 -- The Wells Fargo Bank American Trust Company, with combined resources of $2,604,000,000, came into being today as the eleventh largest bank in the nation.

WITH his Second String Quartet Elliott Carter rivets his right to be regarded as one of the most distinguished of living composers.

The International Air Transport Association said yesterday that its seventeen airlines flying between Europe and North America had carried a record of 1,539,934 passengers in 1959, an increase of 19.2 per cent over 1958.
STUART, Fla., March 25 -- The way the native Floridian puts it, a fisherman was subject to catch a bass on any cast today, once he had located an area of spawning beds in shallow water.
BOWIE, Md., March 25 (AP) -- The well-traveled Amerigo, owned by Mrs. Tilyou Christopher, is slightly favored in the $l00,000 added John B. Campbell handicap here tomorrow.
School officials in four suburban counties here expressed guarded pleasure yesterday a the prospect of increased state aid for their schools next year.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 25 -- Venezuelan officials are reported to be increasingly disillusioned over recent developments in Cuba.

Roger Brown, Connie Hawkins and Bob Barnek, probably the finest front-court players in the Public Schools Athletic League, will lead a tall, strong Brooklyn-Queens all-star team into Madison Square Garden tonight against the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond squad.

SEWAREN, N.J., March 25 -- The ferrvboat Niagara, once in the flee of the New York Central Railroad, faces a prosaic future. After forty-seven years of serving West Shore division commuters and motorists the craft is now a floating field office for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.
PARAMUS, N.J., March 25 -- A. Federal judge urged the courts tonight to become more receptive to modern scientific knowledge and let psychiatrists testify more freely in criminal cases.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The National Council of Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. urged today an end as soon as possible to the program of importing Mexican nationals for seasonal farm work.
The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that "Lady Chatterley's Lover" by D.H. Lawrence was not an obscene book and could be sent through the mails.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Eisenhower's requested appropriation for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in the next fiscal year was increased by $197,400,550 today by the House Appropriations Committee.

With 250, short-subjects submitted for competitive screenings, the sponsors of the second annual American Film Festival gauged yesterday, the potentialities of the nation's largest 16-mm. movie assembly. It will be held here from April 20 through 23 at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- Jerry Barber of Los Angeles posted a three-under-par 68 today for a 137 total and a two-stroke lead at the halfway point in the $40,000 De Soto Lakes open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Exports in February were even better than the much-improved level of January the Department of Commerce reported today.
ROME, March 25 -- Pope John XXIII received Dom Salomao Barbosa Ferraz, formerly head of the schismatic Free Catholic Church of Brazil, and recognized him as a Bishop of the Roman Catholic Church.
PARIS, March 25 -- Premier Khrushehev made today the sharpest attack on Germany of his current French visit and renewed threats to sign a separate peace treaty with East Germany.

Waterfront management and labor began a search yesterday for a formula to make handling of cargo in containers more palatable to longshoremen.
Cigarette smoking makes the heart work harder without a proportionate increase in oxygen supply, thus causing anginal pain, a medical study has shown.

LONDON, March 25 -- South African mining shares took another tumble in the stock market here today. With demand lacking, a little Continental selling again found prices sensitive and many shares were marked down further to discourage selling.
MADRID, March 25 -- A split has developed in the Spanish Cabinet.
MOSCOW, March 25 -- Two American composers won mixed plaudits of Moscow music-lovers tonight in a joint concert of American and Soviet music at the Tchaikovsky Conservatory.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A Congressional leader in the welfare field called today for a "major national blueprint" to control juvenile delinquency.
RECENT wood-cuts by Antonio Frasconi at the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue, measure the widening advance of this graphic artist in both technique and interest of subject-matter.

LYNN, Mass., March 25 --The International Union of Electrical Workers retained bargaining rights at the General Electric Company plants here and in near-by Everett tonight in a bitterly contested election.
General Sessions Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer has a Case before him that he will be able to try in his living room if he chooses.

Critics and other well meaning people are always advising young musicians to venture off the "beaten" track"; but sometimes they forget to warn the performer there are dangers lurking on some of music's dark and tangled bypaths.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Capital Airlines, the fifth largest airline in the United States, applied today for a Federal subsidy to rescue it from an accelerated rate of losses. None of the major airlines is now on subsidy.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 25 -- The head of the Jewish Labor Committee called on the State Department and other Federal agencies today to cease what he termed discrimination against potential employes of the Jewish faith.

SHAI K. OPHIR, a first-rate mime who has displayed his talents in night clubs and on television, offered last night a display of a fulsome repertoire at the Forty-first Street Theatre. Mr. Ophir calls his program "41 in a Sack," which, if you spell it out, denotes the number of variations being presented, a sackful, indeed.

TWO years before Walter Deane Fuller retired as chairman of the board of the Curtis Publishing Company, he became concerned about the thousands of healthy, capable executives -- like himself -- who eventually would be relegated to retirement.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI) -- The typical home builder is 41 years old, has been in business eleven years, built twenty houses last year and used Government-backed home loans in 40 per cent of his sales.

WHITE PLAINS, March 26 -- An "intensive care unit" will soon be established at the White Plains Hospital. Some of the funds for it will be raised by the White Plains Women's Auxiliary of the hospital at its fourth annual Charity Ball on May 7 at the Westchester Country Club in Rye.

THE high admiration that Dylan Thomas expressed for Vernon Watkins' genius will not influence an objective reviewer, but the conclusion is still unqualified praise. A program of absorbing interest was played by Joseph Wolman, pianist, at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

TRENTON, March 26 -- New Jersey's Republican voters are witnessing a most unusual Senatorial campaign.
A modernized forty-year-old apartment building, intended to serve as a pilot project for private owners in urban renewal areas throughout the country, has been opened by the University of Chicago.

THE State of Maine has beat its remaining covered bridges to the draw. It has decided to do something about them before the spans become liabilities and lose their status as a valuable part of the state's vacationland appeal.

Probably no one knows better that persistence pays than Wilma Soss, founder of the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business, Inc. That organization fights for stockholders' rights -- particularly from the women's angle.

WASHINGTON. WE are haunted by the remembered moment in 1945 when a Vice President suddenly was called to serve in the place of a deceased President, and by the three moments since 1955 when we have had a chilling hint that this could happen again.

Henry Cabot Lodge said last night that the crucial question facing the new nations of the world was whether man could raise his standard of living and retain the right to speak his mind and make his own decisions.

IF the New York Philharmonic and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians choose to negotiate a new contract for next season in privacy, they are acting with discretion. So much labor negotiation nowadays involve playing to the grandstand that unpublicized talks like those between the Philharmonic and the union seem like a rare, unencumbered way of doing business.

FEW experiences give the home vegetable grower a greater thrill than the discovery of a new variety that is in some way superior to the one he has been growing. No matter how long he has grown his favorite variety, the gardener looks to the breeder for improved types.

TORONTO, March 26 -- Thirdperiod goals by Frank Mahovich and Bob Pulford carried the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-2 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in the second game of their Stanley Cup semi-final series.
ON Oct. 20, 1948, the Danish tenor Aksel Schiotz made his debut before a Town Hall audience whose curiosity had been whetted by the super's recordings that had preceded his arrival.

ACADEMIC MINUTEMEN -- Some New England college students have created their own solution to the teacher shortage while trying their teaching wings. The program involves a score of Harvard, Radcliffe and Massachusetts Institute of Technology students who volunteer as "assistant teachers" in Greater Boston schools.

It was rather a cold reception Premier Khrushchev received in Bordeaux yesterday as he began the barnstorming trip that will take him through much of France this week. As his performances in Paris revealed, the Soviet leader is going over President de Gaulle's head in an appeal to the French people to forsake the Franco-German entente which de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer have forged, offering the alternative of a Franco-Soviet alliance instead.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- United States intelligence analysts have completed an extensive study of Communist aims and tactics in dealing with newly emerging nations. The report is circulating among Government officials responsible for countering such Moscow-directed tactics.

WASHINGTON. ENJOYING the most successful season in its ten, Arena Stage is bringing to a climax its long sought dream: a permanent home seems assured for September, 1961.

BOWIE, Md March 26 -- Under a precisely judged ride by Larry Adams, the Marylandbred Yes You Will, 9 -- 1, staged an impressive stretch run today to defeat nine rivals in the $115,400 John B. Campbell Handicap.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain arrived here this evening for two days of talks with President Eisenhower about a response to the Soviet Union's latest proposal for banning nuclear weapons tests.

EVERY team that plays in a bridge tournament is required to have a captain. This rule is largely for the convenience of tournament officials. When an official line-up must be designated to play in a match or when a team's vote is needed on some question, it saves time to have an authorized spokesman.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 26 -- When Andy Cohen joined the Giants in 1926, he merely had to beat Frank Frisch for the job at second base. No one was beating Frisch for anything in those days. A year later the Fordham Flash had been traded for Rogers Hornsby, and; The Rajah took over the job at second.

ANTWERP, Belgium, March 22 -- Twenty-four American jewelers who are accustomed to display their gems reverently on black velvet stared in amazement today at the way fortunes in diamonds were strewn on the tables of the Beurs Voor Diamant, the world's biggest trade center for the jewels.

ONE of the by-products of the hasty, haphazard manner in which most jazz recording is done is the seemingly thoughtless, haphazard manner of playing to which even the best musicians may sometimes resort to get through a date.

Home buyers -- especially those who have just put down a deposit on their first house -- have been known to have two nightmares before moving day. One is that the builder went broke. The other is that the builder didn't go broke.

Camden High, the New Jersey champion, routed Bishop Loughlin, 67-48, yesterday at New York University's Alumni Gym. The basketball game, televised over Channel 7, was Camden's forty-eighth consecutive victory in two years.

Even though the age of military dictatorships seems to be running out its course, the officer corps, with few exceptions, still wield immense influence in the formulation of policies, for good or for evil, throughout that vast and restless area.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 26 -- A record number of National Guardsmen and Army reservists of the First Army area will undergo training at Camp Drum near here this Summer. More than 87,718 men will report for duty in seven periods of two weeks each, it was announced at the camp today.

IN the rush by governments to develop their tourist facilities following World War II, Greece, Turkey and Yuoslavia were late starters, and although conditions in all three countries are steadily improving, driving around them today untill requires some of the attributes of a do-it-yourselfer.

GATLINBURG, Tenn. -- While the most popular of National Parks, Great Smoky Mountains, has had record storms this last winter, pelted with a succession of heavy near-blizzards, officials at Park Headquarters here do not believe that the normal spring influx of tourists will be hampered when they start arriving.

MANY restaurants have become popular and are remembered not only for their entrees or desserts but also for the appealing hot breads that are offered during the meal. Taking a cue from their success, the home cook might well serve piping hot muffins to glamorize an otherwise simple menu.

WASHINGTON. THIS Sunday hundreds of thousands of Wisconsin citizens are fighting out the Presidential primary campaign of 1960. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson will probably announce his candidacy for President a month or two before the Democratic National Convention.

LIBERIA has a concert pianist in residence. The man the West African republic appointed to the job is Robert Pritchard, a 31-year-old American from Syracuse, N.Y. PARIS. "WOMAN is given to man to bear children; she is therefore his property, as the tree is the gardener's." IN the first flush of the announcement out of Paris on March 16 that the International Air Transport Association had agreed upon a new schedule of fares, the I.A.T.A. members sped the good word through their press-release telegrams that they would "provide reduced rates on low-fare services, as well as special excursion and group travel discounts on many intercontinental routes."

HONG KONG, March 27 -- Communist China is in the midst of a new campaign to progadandize the infallibility of Mao Tse-tung.

TAMPA, Fla., March 27 -- Base-runners barreling into second base have held no terrors for Roy McMillan, the short-stop of the Cincinnati Reds. As agile as he is adroit, the wiry wizard gained the reputation of being practically indestructible. There was one stretch of almost four years when he didn't miss a game -- or a baserunner, either.
BOZEMAN, Mont., March 27 (AP) -- The University of Colorado retained its National Collegiate ski championship yesterday at Bridger Bowl.

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs declared yesterday that Mayor Wagner should ask Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack to relinquish his office pending a final disposition of charges against him.
LONDON, March 27 -- The quiet tone prevailing on the stock market here last week was caused largely by the imminence of the budget.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 27 (AP) -- St. Louis bowlers, including the winners of the doubles championship two years ago, produced the only changes today in the American Bowling Congress tourney's top ten standings for singles and doubles.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address at the opening session tonight of the White House Conference on Children and Youth:

SEBRING, Fla., March 27 (UPI) -- Olivier Gendebien, who put Porsche in contention with Ferrari for the world sports-car championship, said today that he would return to the Ferrari factory racing team.

New York State is planning to borrow $150,000,000 on tax anticipation notes, Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday. The borrowing is necessitated by the state's commitment to distribute $295,000,000 in school aid grants to school districts on April 15.
Advice to the well-meaning business man came yesterday from Earl W. Kintner, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. Don't, he urged, attack governmental functions in an indiscriminate manner.

MADISON, Wis., March 28 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and his backers among top Minnesota and Wisconsin state officials will campaign long and hard through Wisconsin in the last days before the Democratic Presidential primary April 5.
Plans to picket six or eight Harlem liquor stores that have Bought supplies from persons other than "eligible salesmen" were announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 28 -- Something that potently triggers abnormal growth in human tissues has been filtered from specimens taken from five cancer patients, a research scientist reported here today.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- Representative Oren Harris announced today he had arranged for an independent study of the services that rate the popularity of radio and television programs.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 28 -- When Charlie Dressen opened training camp as the new manager of the Milwaukee Braves, he started at the very beginning -- with fundamentals. Among them was the practically lost art of sliding and no one was exempt. Oddly enough, the highly individualistic Braves seemed to enjoy the novelty.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of March 10 "Auto Insurance Rates" was rather obtuse. Presumably you are against the Barrett-Russo bill because it "might" result in "a steep rise in automobile insurance rates."
The pleasant weather attracted a surprisingly sizable crowd of 32,401 to Aqueduct yesterday.

NICE, France, March 28 -- One after another most of the Austrian and French skiing stars were returning home from the Winter Olympics last week. Many had stopped off at other American ski resorts en route, including the Austrian, Hias Leitner, who won the Harriman Cup at Sun Valley.

As President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan confer at Camp David on a predisarmament ban on nuclear weapons tests the five Western powers at the Geneva disarmament conference have presented a detailed skeletal plan that is a challenge to the Soviets to reveal their real position on inspection and control.

TOKYO, March 28 -- Labor trouble in Japan's ailing coal industry erupted today into a violent battle among thousands of members of two rival unions. Wooden swords, firecrackers and other simple weapons were used.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 28 (Reuters) -- The United States and Canada would be reimbursed for excessive costs of operating weather ships in the North Atlantic under an agreement adopted in principle today.
THE Metropolitan Opera season has only three more weeks to run, and last night the company began its twenty-third week with Mozart's "Don Giovanni."
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Tuesday, March 29 -- Fifteen Africans are feared dead and scores have been injured in a new outbreak of violence in South Africa.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 28 -- It is amazing what a difference a year and some seventeen games in the won and lost columns can make.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Administrator advised Congress today not to buy makeshift planes in its eagerness to build up the Military Air Transportation Service.

"The Laureates: Jewish Winners of the Nobel Prize," by Tina Levitan, will be issued May 23 by Twayne Publishers. It presents word and photographic portraits of the forty eminent Jews who have received the international prize.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Russian proposal made on March 19 at Geneva is a major step forward in the negotiations for cessation of nuclear weapons tests. Provided the details can be satisfactorily cleared up, it seems to me a suitable basis for a treaty.

GENEVA, March 28 -- The West presented to the Soviet Union today skeletonized proposals for a veto-free international disarmament organization loosely connected to the United Nations. Under the Western outline, the new organization would be responsible for inspecting every disarmament step from the laying down of rifles to the destruction of nuclear stockpiles.
Mayor Wagner declined yesterday to make any request to Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan to relinquish his office pending a final disposition of charges against him.
ALBANY, March 28 -- The Assembly completed action, today on a bill to increase the penalties for motorists leaving the scene of an accident involving personal injuries.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens charged yesterday that his borough had been "consistently short-changed" on highway maintenance funds.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Rockefeller agreed today to add 5,800,000 to the education aid that will be distributed to school districts for the 1960-61 school year. Most of the new funds would go to five upstate counties.

BONN, Germany, March 28 -- The Social Democrats have scored a resounding electoral victory in Bavaria, getting more votes than the Christian Social Union for the first time in the post-war history of that predominantly Roman Catholic southern state.
A new policy has been set for the Gamblers Part of Magistrate's Court under which so-called "tough judges" will be presiding over gambling cases.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 28 -- Coach Dale Hall Issued his first call for spring football practice at the military academy today.
The first combined Oxford-Cambridge rugby team to come to the East Coast of the United States wil arrive Thursday.

GLASGOW, Scotland, March 28 (Reuters) -- Nineteen firemen were killed tonight and forty injured when a warehouse filled with $28,000,000 worth of Scotch whisky exploded, burying them under tons of debris.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- One of Washington's hottest debates, over ownership of patents resulting from Government research and development contracts, has been refired by proposed amendments to the Space Act.

EVEN when she is asleep, with cold cream on her face and curlers in her hair, the American woman does not relinquish the right to be well dressed. The clothes she wears to bed often seem as carefully selected as the rest of her wardrobe.

Mayor Wagner's move to increase the take-home pay for himself and other top city officials by new pension benefits "violates the spirit" of the State Constitution and the Home Rule Law, Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs charged yesterday.

EUGENE HERMAN is a dreamer of ruins, as many artists before him have been. His Italy -- described in paintings and sketches at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street -- is the time-tarnished Italy that, to the imaginative artist, offers endless prospects.
LONDON, March 28 -- A good deal thinner but as forthright as ever, Aneurin Bevan disclosed today that he had no intention of abandoning his political career.

FRONT Street, down near the tip of Manhattan, is paved with cobblestones. Not one of its old brownstone office buildings, some with colonial facades and leaded windows, is more than five stories high. A stroller there might think he was back in the early nineteenth century if it were not for the skyscrapers of Wall Street towering to the west.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- Representative Chet Holifield said today a survey showed that civil defense was in "deplorable shape," with only 1,565 home fall-out shelters built in thirty-five states.
Much of the city's housing program has been in suspended animation since early this month, when J. Anthony Panuch, the Mayor's special adviser, called for a major revamping.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Match 28 -- The Western powers are discussing a procedural arrangement under which the Security Council would take up the Asian-African complaint against South Africa Wednesday without a vote.
ALBANY, March 28 -- The first three segments of the Rockefeller administration's labor program were approved in the Assembly today over some Republican opposition.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) up to 10 points (50 cents) off yesterday. The far July contract showed the only rise.

Women in the Hall of Fame Those who maintain in that our society is a matriarchy gain little sustenance from the Hall of Fame for Great Americans. For the American Pantheon at the University Heights campus of New York University, overlooking the Palisades and the valleys formed by the Hudson and Harlem Rivers, pays relatively little attention to the women who have helped make our nation great.

While the attention of Congress and the country is focused, as it should be, on the extension of civil rights to Negroes of the South, the civil rights of Washington's million inhabitants -- both black and white -- ought not be overlooked either.
BOSTON, March 28 -- Bernard Goldfine, Boston textile industrialist, and his secretary, Miss Mildred Paperman, pleaded not guilty today to charges of evading Federal income taxes.

LONDON, March 28 -- United States opposition to the further disclosure of nuclear weapons secrets is expected to block plans for making the North Atlantic alliance the world's fifth nuclear power, qualified sources said tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Weather Bureau announced today that it was increasing its efforts to solve the mysteries of invisible turbulence at high altitudes.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Prime Minister Macmillan brought up British concern over European trade developments today with top State Department officials.

PERHAPS the appeal of bridge lies partly in the fact that one can never be sure that anything one does is unimportant. In today's hand, a play that seemed completely inconsequential at the time resulted in the loss of a trick.
BOSTON, March 28 (UPI) -- The memory of a defeat that set nine records impressed the losing coach of the St. Louis Hawks not a whit today.
The operation of the city's new Board of Ethics has resulted in two resignations from the Real Estate Department's fifteen-member advisory commission.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 28 (AP) -- Forty-three Negro students charged with trespassing during lunch counter protests were convicted here today.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Thomas G. Corcoran was paid $305,907 for legal services and expenses by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company from 1954 through 1958.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 28 (AP) -- Carrier Corporation resumed production at its two strikebound plants here today, after hundreds of steel workers crossed their union's picket lines to work. The company put the number at 1,530.

Forty schoolboys hunched over the chessboards, their faces twisted into masks of concentration. They scowled at kings in danger and tried to put body English on a knight's gambit. It was mental warfare.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A plan to end destructive rate competition in the transportation industry was put before a Senate subcommittee today by inland water carriers.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 28 -- What kind of a year will it be for Billy Haughton, the Babe Ruth of harness racing, who swung into action at Roosevelt Raceway tonight?
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The discount rate on ninety-one-day Treasury bills dropped subtantially again this week, the Treasury reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Over the outraged protest of Justice William O. Douglas, the Supreme Court refused today to look into the legality of a Government program to spray DDT from airplanes over 4,000,000 acres in ten states.
David Tudor has been known to perform on a "prepared" piano, but last night at the Living Theatre he had to play a repaired piano.

Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union is facing an uphill battle to retain his world chess championship in Moscow. The challenger, Mikhail Tal of Latvia, evolved a surprise combination, with the sacrifice of a knight, in the sixth game on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senator Albert Gore charged to- day that James J. Wadsworth, head of the United States dele- gation to the nuclear test ban talks in Geneva, was responsible for misleading the press and the public.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The much-cited estimate that only 3 per cent of American youth becomes delinquent or disturbed was disputed here today in a forum on Youth in Conflict at the golden anniversary White House Conference on Children and Youth.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 -- The young lady adjusted the rhinestone-studded crown on her auburn hair, turned on her friendliest smile and assumed one of her duties as Princess April for the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce.

BUENOS AIRES, March 28 -- The Government of President Arturo Frondizi retained a narrow majority in the Chamber of Deputies today despite a serious loss of voting support in yesterday's Congressional and provincial elections.

Spring slipped into New York a little late yesterday after a chilling, snowy March. The air was soft and sweet smelling; the sun shone at least half the| day and at 1:35 P.M. the temperature stood at 69.6 degrees -- the highest since 1960 began.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 28 -- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan began their talks at Camp David today with a confident forecast of early agreement on how to handle the Soviet Union's latest proposal to ban all nuclear test explosions.

Land for a fourteen-story apartment building to be built on the northwest corner of First Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street has been assembled by a client of John B. Avanzino in three transactions, according to Albert Friedlander, broker.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner warned today that this country "must learn to strike a sensible balance between meeting the needs of our diverse economic interests and the needs of our people as human beings."

The seven-story apartment building at 3070 Hull Avenue, south of 204th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Marall Construction Company, which built the structure in 1940. It was purchased by the Realty Equities Corporation in a deal negotiated by Darling McDonald and Pirk Struble as co-brokers.
Long liquidation and stop-loss selling depressed potato futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The decline followed sharp rises earlier this month.
A bitter landlord-tenant dispute has erupted in a new high-rent apartment house in Greenwich Village.
BALTIMORE, March 28 -- William F. Schmick Sr. retired today as active head of The Sunpapers after a newspaper career that began in the last century.
A combine has been formed by Harriet Parsons, Paul Vroom, William Dean and Charles Hollerith Jr. to put on plays as well as their screen counterparts.
THE GOVERNOR Conferred with Republican legislative leaders. Sent special message to Legislature on convertibility of health insurance.

Plans are being made and committees have been chosen to arrange "American Fashions for Fashionable Americans," a style revue at a luncheon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza on April 19. Proceeds will aid the Children's Health Service.
Doug Jones scored a bruising ten-round decision over Von Clay of Philadelphia in the main event at St. Nicholas Arena last night.
ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature in a special message today to require convertibility privileges on group health insurance policies.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Senate rackets committee concluded today that James R. Hoffa's claims to protecting the interests of his union's members were a pretense and pose.

LONDON, March 28 -- With the budget message just a week away, the stock market marked time here today. Government securities were virtually unchanged and movements among the industrials were small and irregular.

CHICAGO, March 28 (UPI) -- Great Lakes cities are building new docks to entice salt water ships and build up foreign trade through the use of the St. Lawrence Seaway.

The Louisiana Power and Light Company sold yesterday $20,000,000 of thirty-year 5 per cent first mortgage bonds to an investment banking syndicate managed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., Kidder, Peabody Co., and Harriman Ripley Co.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Senator John J. Williams said today that the Internal Revenue Service reduced its delinquency tax load 22 per cent last year.
DIJON, France, March 28 -- The little man who wasn't there made the news today on the third day of Premier Khrushchev's tour of France.
ROME, March 28 -- Three unidentified prelates were unexpectedly made Cardinals by Pope John XXIII in a consistory this morning, along with seven whose names had been announced earlier.
FALLS accounted for nearly half of the fatal accidents in the home last year, according to a report issued yesterday at the annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council.

ON the theory that women are not only getting slimmer, but also demanding younger and gayer styling, Peck Peck is introducing a complete new group of junior sportswear in all its stores.

Yet, as John Wicklein wrote in this paper yesterday, a bitter and ignorant attack is now being made on a Protestant organization, the National Council of Churches, on the ground that it is infiltrated by Communists and other Left-Wingers.
The coaches of the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference welcomed the balmy weather yesterday by forming a league for freshmen.
Those television commercials of revolving Greek statues on behalf of Ban deodorant will apaear in modified form beginning next Monday.

Prices of high-grade bonds declined sharply in an inactive trading session yesterday. The market retreat extended to the short-dated discount bills of the Treasury, which rose in discount by as much as ten one-hundredths of 1 percentage point from the levels reached last Friday.
