DIETERS might be wise to avoid the Housewares Fair, which opened yesterday at Abraham Straus. Here, enticing snacks are being offered continuously by demonstrators of the newest appliances. And, during appointed hours, renowned chefs will prepare and offer samples of their favorite recipes.
CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- The grain futures market finished mostly lower today as the weight of trading shifted to profit taking in wheat, oats and rye.

A Texas oil corporation's common stock that was fraudulently promoted from $2 to $16 a share cost the investing public $6,500,000, a Federal grand jury charged yesterday. The present value of the stock is $2 a share.

Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell, who has served as assistant manager of the Atomic Energy Commission and as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, is slated for a top executive post with the 1964 New York World's Fair.

The Siegler Corporation, a major electronics manufacturer, is interested in acquiring Jack Heintz, Inc., a company well known for its defense work and for its employe welfare program during World War II.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee went through the motions today of holding hearings on the House-passed civil rights bill.
ALBANY, March 28 -- A last minute bill authorizing special tax relief for the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad, operator of the Hudson tubes, was submitted to the Legislature tonight.

The readjustment of state aid to New York City announced over the week-end by Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner is generous beyond all expectations. It increases state aid by $41,000,000, of which $19,000,000 is, however, the city's share of larger aid to education to the whole state agreed upon between Mr. Rockefeller and legislative leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Navy ordered a speed-up today in its Polaris ballistic missile program.
In a stodgy, uninteresting session that seemed to be without momentum, prices on the New York Stock Exchange made a small decline yesterday.

The United States Court of Appeals blocked the union-appointed trustees of the Typo-Publishers Welfare Fund yesterday from adopting a self -insurance program instead of paying premiums to independent insurance companies.
ALBANY, March 23 -- A se- ries of slumbering bills creating new judgeships in the New York metropolitan area and upstate suddenly began showing signs of life tonight.

Census takers, who will start collecting information here Friday, began an intensive three-day training course yesterday. At the outset they received the sobering ad- monition that if each census taker in the nation were to miss only two persons, the national count would be short by a number equal to the population of Nevada -- 160,083, according to the 1950 census.
CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A protest that "an overt apologist" for television networks had been made the first speaker at the mass-communications forum of the White House Conference on Children and Youth wag voiced today.
WASHINGTON, Match 28 -- The Supreme Court affirmed today, 5 to 4, the conviction of Col. Rudolf Ivanovich Abel as a Soviet spy.

The evening performance of "Bye Bye Birdie" on April 27 has been chosen by the Berk- shire Farm for Boys as its annual spring theatre Benefit. The new musical comedy is sched- uled to open at the Martin Beck Theatre on April 14.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 28 -- Few members of any South African Cabinet have stirred up so much controversy as Francois Christiaan Erasmus, the Minister of Justice. Mr. Erasmus is an aggressive man with little sense of humor.

HAVANA, Tuesday, March 29 -- Premier Fidel Castro announced early today that he would not send his ambassador back to Washington unless the United States modified its "unfriendly" policies toward Cuba.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 28 -- Venezuela recommended tonight that the proposed Havana conference of under-developed nations be postponed.
Mayor Wagner expressed hope yesterday that a state inquiry into the city's affairs would concentrate on studies of the City Charter, in effect dropping any scandal-hunting role.

Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that he might appoint Mrs. Joan O'Dwyer O'Neill, niece of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, as a City Magistrate if the New York County Lawyers Association should reverse itself and approve her for the post.
GENEVA, March 28 -- The United Nations World Health Organization's experts agree that cigarette smoking is a major cause of the increase in lung cancer.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court upheld today the right of the Federal Government to regulate insurance companies doing an interstate business by mail even though they have headquarters in a state with its own insurance laws.

The nation's steel mills this week are scheduled to operate at less than 90 per cent of capacity for the first time since the industry got back into full production last November following the 116-day strike, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- The charter captain's life is full of tragedy, when it is not full of triumph, and it is his dudes who make it either fine or pathetic. Fishing dudes are unaccountable.
DETROIT, March 28 (AP) -- The auto industry winds up the first quarter this week more than 300,000 units shy of the production record it originally sought.
WHITE PLAINS, March 28 -- Westchester County asked today to be exempted from the provisions of a law that permits New York banks to open branches in Westchester and Nassau.

F. SCOTT FITZGERALD'S "Six Tales of the Jazz Age and Other Stories"* appears now with an introduction by his daughter, Frances Fitzgerald Lanahan. Ring Lardner's "You Know Me Al" appears now with an introduction by his son, John Lardner. An intervening generation thus sponsors with authority work that should not lose its luster for new readers or old in our century.

The Italian Government and Radio Corporation of America will soon start a large scale electronic industrialization of southern Italy. The area now is poor and predom- inantly agricultural. The joint project was announced yesterday by the American electronic giant and Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale (Industrial Reconstruction Institute.)
Senate racket investigators added a bulging installment yesterday to the catalogue of wrongdoing they have charged to James R. Hoffa.

For those concerned with Argentine political stability and the continuance of the drastic economic stabilization program the results of Sunday's Congressional elections are disappointing. President Frondizi and his Intransigent Radical party took a bad beating. They polled many fewer votes than the combined Peronists and Communists, who cast blanks because their parties are outlawed.
The state Attorney General's office is considering action to dissolve the corporation that owns a West Side tenement where two children were recently bitten by rats.

STRASBOURG, France, March 28 -- The six-nation European Parliamentary Assembly was urged today to support a speedup in achieving the European Common Market as a defense against any Soviet trade war against the West.

THERE are moments in Truman Capote's "The Grass Harp," which opened last night as this week's bill on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13, that capture beautifully and poetically the essence of the free human spirit that has enough sense to dream.
The latest developments in paper products, from cups with a big lip to a new toothpick dispenser, went on display at the annual Paper Show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
The Pepsi-Cola Company set new records in sales and earnings last year, Herbert L. Barnet, president, informed shareholders in the annual report issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Supreme Court overruled today a finding of the National Labor Relations Board that peaceful picketing to regain recognition for a union was illegal prior to the 1959 labor law.
ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Rockefeller announced tonight that his administration had achieved pay-as-you-go financing a year earlier than he had expected.
Several prospective top-management changes were announced yesterday in Chicago by Sears, Roebuck Co., Inc., big mail-order and retail chain.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Thomas E. Dewey has given the Republicans an impressive illustration of what a master political tactician (except in the 1948 campaign), with a good memory and plenty of boldness, can do to turn what has been conceived as a visceral attack on a party and its Government regime into a most effective counter-attack.

Consolidated net sales of the General Dynamics Corporation last year increased 11 per cent to a new record, but earnings declined sharply from the level of 1958, largely because of heavy research and development expenditures and expenses for the commercial jet transport program.

The election of three new vice presidents of the Raytheon Company was announced yesterday. Those promoted were T.C. Wisenbaker, general manager of the missile systems division; Paul F. Hannah, general counsel and secretary, and George Ingram Jr., controller.
A striking union decided last night not to comply with a Federal judge's order to halt a walkout that threatens to tie up $470,000,000 in construction here.
No general pay increases for city employes are in sight beyond the $31,000,000 package of pension benefits and salary rises announced last Thursday, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Prof. Abraham J. Herschel of the Jewish Theological Seminary urged today that the aim of education be changed "from a high standard of living to a high standard of doing."
A score of spokesmen for municipal employe groups gave their views yesterday on the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, the only one to which the city contributes on their behalf.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. has decided to continue sponsorship next season of the June Allyson show and "Du Pont Show of the Month" over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- A spokesman for the American Pharmaceutical Association protested today that a Senate inquiry on drug prices had been unfair and "hardly more than a kangaroo court."
The agreement yesterday between President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan seems to pave the way for a possible accord between the Soviet Union and the West on halting nuclear testing.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee changed the Administration voting-referee plan today to require Negroes to face opposing lawyers in public proceedings if they want to register to vote.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson predicted today that the income of the nation's farm population from all sources would be about as large this year as last.

ALTHOUGH the Dada movement that swept Europe during and after World war I proclaimed its disaffection with what was generally considered "art;" eventually the best of the Dada works were reintegrated into the body of art.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- Leo Durocher first saw Bill White swing a bat before a Giant-Pirate game at Forbes Field in 1952. White, then an 18-year-old freshman at Hiram College, was up for a private tryout. He blasted away at the offerings of wily George Spencer with such violence that the Lip called a halt.
ALBANY, March 29 -- Assemblyman Theodore Hill Jr. of Westchester has been picked by Governor Rockefeller to succeed former Gov. Charles Poletti as a trustee of the State Power Authority.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You published a letter from the South (R.L. Simonton, issue March 21) which stated that here in the North in a few years we will regret our present stand on civil rights.
BOWIE, Md., March 29 (AP) -- Southfield Farm's Noops returned $34.20 for $2 by winning the $10,000-added Prince George's Stakes today.

Bobby Ussery rode Edward W. Bradley's 3-year-old filly, Silver Song, to a two-length victory over the 7-10 choice, Flower Bonnet, ridden by Eddie Arcaro, in the $7,500 Rockaway Beach yesterday at Aqueduct.

THE series of New Music Concerts under the direction of Eric Simon gave an Austrian program last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Under the patronage of Dr. Karl Wolf, Austria's Consul General here, the program contained three works, only one of which could remotely be considered "new music."
PRINCETON, N.J. March 29 -- The Rev. Dr. James Iley McCord was inaugurated here this afternoon as the fourth president of Princeton Theological Seminary.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March, 29 (UPI) -- Wake Forest College students voted 742-604 today against admitting Negro students to the all-white Baptist college.

THE end of the blue jeans era looms. After seeing Macy's new dress collection, the teen-age population may consider forsaking pony tails, bobby sox and possibly, though this may be expecting too much, bubble gum.

ANTHONY BALLATORE is the newest master at the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- by a long shot. The artist is of the Henri Bendel, Bonwit Teller and Saks Fifth Avenue school of window display, and it is strongly suspected that few of the museum officials know, he is under their roof.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The Legislature is scheduled to act tomorrow on bills implementing the agreement on new state aid for New York City that was reached last week-end by Governor Rockefeller and Mayo Wagner.

CHICAGO, March 29 --Lawrence A. Kimpton, Chancellor of the University of Chicago for the last nine years, has submitted his resignation. It will take effect when a successor is appointed, according to an announcement today by Glen A. Loyd, chairman of the university's board of trustees.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Company sold $50,000,000 of 4 3/4 per cent general mortgage bonds yesterday to investment bankers headed by the First Boston Corporation on a bid of 100.10999 for a net interest cost to the company of about 4.743. per cent.
A resolution offered in the City Council last night assailed as "high-handed" Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley's plan to make Lexington and Third Avenues one-way on May 15.
GENEVA, March 29 -- The West offered today the "forecast" that a range of specific disarmament steps could be completed within a year if the Communist powers accepted the Western, disarmament plan.

DORA PERELMANN, composer - conductor - pianist who studied at the Imperial Conservatory of her native St. Petersburg, Russia, and in Vienna, and who now lives in New York, made her debut at Carnegie Hall last night with an orchestra made up of members of the Symphony of the Air.

The International Business Machines Corporation has leased two floors and part of a third in the Corning Glass Building, 717 Fifth Avenue, at Fifty-sixth Street. Occupancy is scheduled for May 1. Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building, arranged the lease.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 29 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said tonight that if his duties " President included meeting with Soviet Premier Khrushchev, nothing would interfere with carrying out his public function to meet with him.
WHITE PLAINS, March 29 -- Six Bedford estate owners filed a suit in State Supreme Court here today to annul the new town zoning that would permit a large research laboratory near their homes.

The Buildings Department will begin today notifying the owners of the city's 14,000 rooming houses and 755 single-room-occupancy houses that they must have $10 annual permits to continue to operate after April 9.
Howard J. Cox, a retired steel executive who from 1952 to 1955 was Republican leader in Bergen County, N.J., was indicted here yesterday in the hit-run death of a Texas lawyer.

By putting the state back on a pay-as-we-go basis at the end of his first fiscal year in office Governor Rockefeller has done in one year what he thought would require two years. He is putting money into reserve, instead of taking it out. He has stopped bond-issue borrowing for capital construction.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Without benefit of prior discussion or public hearing and just ten days before the end of the legislative session, drastic proposals in the state's unemployment insurance law have been proposed which will impose on the workers of this state unduly harsh disqualification provisions.
MOSCOW, March 29 -- Four young Soviet sailors were welcomed home today as heroic examples of the new Communist man for having survived a forty-nine-day ordeal at sea.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In Corporation Counsel Tenney's letter published March 15 concerning the proposed local laws intended to impose liability upon owners of abutting property in claims for injuries resulting from sidewalk and roadway defects, he recognizes to some extent the hardships that would be imposed upon the public.
RHEIMS, France, March 29 -- Premier Khrushchev accused Chancellor Adenauer today of reviving "Hitlerite" theories of a "divine mission" for Germany to save Western Europe.

CROSS HILL, S.C., March 29 -- These South Carolina bass fishermen have a some-what different definition of the word clear or clare, in reference to water for fishing purposes. And the difference may vary with the season.

DETROIT, March 29 -- In an industry often characterized by somewhat frantic-and brash rivalry, James O. Wright, a young-looking, seemingly cool vice president of the Ford Motor Company, represents a calm voice -- backed by management know-how, solid Statistics and careful market research.
ALBANY, March 29 -- The Legislature gave unanimous support tonight to the Republican program to increase education aid to localities by $69,500,000 for the next school year.

Speculator short covering and stop-loss buying raised potato prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Futures rose 2 to 16 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 3,626 carlots, 50,000 pounds to a car, the fourth most active day of the year.
A group of women athletes from Great Britain and Ireland debarked from the Queen Elizabeth when the Cunard liner docked here yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., March 29 -- Some of the eleven harness racing drivers "invited" to a hearing at Roosevelt Raceway today felt the sting of the judges' "get tougher" policy.
THE young college graduate just emerging from her ivy tower and the matron who has been home raising children for several years pose two major types of job-hunting problems.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 (UPI) -- Awards for technical and scientific achievement in films were announced today by B.B., Kahane, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

MADRID, March 29 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco and Don Juan de Bourbon, self-exiled pretender to the Spanish throne met today near the Spanish-Portuguese frontier to discuss terms for the eventual restoration of the monarchy.
LONDON, March 29 -- With trading volume small, prices moved narrowly and irregulary on the stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The tragedy of the Southern "sit-ins" is only matched by the of Congressional filibustering to deny the Negro his rights, the White House Conference on Children and Youth was told today.
A short course to help students achieve happy home lives will be introduced next fall in the city's high schools.
Federal tax officials in this area are hopeful that people who have not yet done so will get around to filing their income tax returns immediately.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The House voted a $197,500,000 increase in health and education funds today despite Administration protests.
Albany, March 29 -- The Senate approved today without debate a bill designed to permit foreign banks to open branches with full deposit privileges in New York State.
State revenue from the consumption of alcoholic beverages totaled $81,911,264 last year, for a record, the annual report of the State Liquor Authority showed yesterday.
Injuries in city traffic last week totaled 1,009 persons, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was thirteen fewer than the number injured in the comparable period of 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, challenged Presidential aspirants today to say whether Negro sitdowns at lunch counters violated private property rights.

HAVANA, March 29 -- Luis Conte Aguero, popular television commentator whose charges of Communist infiltration in the Cuban Government have aroused Dr. Castro's anger, was reported tonight to have fled into asylum at the Argentine Embassy here.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A speaker for organized paraent groups warned today that unless television programs for children improved "many of us will not only turn off the dial, but also unplug the set and se that it stays unplugged."
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 28 -- Popular support for Governor LeRoy Collins' plan to form biracial committees throughout Florida is running far ahead of the political response.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29 -- New rains swelled floods from broken irrigation dams tonight devastating towns and farmlands in northeastern Brazil.
PARIS, March 29 -- Seven Western European nations sought today to prevent six others from organizing trade discrimination against them July 1.

Mrs. Julius W. Noyes, chairman of patrons for the May 16 Salute to Summer Cocktail Party and Tea Dance to benefit the Society of Memorial Cancer Center, has released some of the names of the women sponsoring the fete.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 29 -- The Security Council prepared today for what promised to be an extensive debate on violence in South Africa in a session scheduled for 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.
Ollvier Gendebien of Belgium and the Porsche Spyder RS 60 in which he and Hans Hermann of Germany won the Scoring (Fla.) twelve-hour race last Saturday, came to New York yesterday for a brief visit.
Thousands fled their homes last night ahead of icegorged flood waters that smashed levees and swept down main streets in Iowa and Nebraska.
More ballots than there were registered voters were cast in last September's primary in several election districts of the Fourteenth Assembly District East in East Harlem.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee dodged a showdown today on a proposal to repeal a controversial United States restrictions on the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- A story of mismanagement, chaotic planning and indifference in high places in the vital Donets Basin coal fields was told here today by Pravda, the Communist party's official newspaper.
ALBANY, March 29 -- The Legislature moved into the preadjournment rush in earnest tonight, sitting far into the evening in both the Senate and Assembly.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A special committee of the National Academy of Sciences entered its nomination today for the first man to go to the moon -- a "hard-rock geologist."

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Department of Justice has begun an investigation into the off-the-record talks that Thomas G. Corcoran had with three members of the Federal Power Commission in a gas company case.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 29 -- James R. Hoffa said tonight he would undertake to organize New Jersey's 5,000 egg farmers and all egg farmers in the nation, who wanted to join the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Efforts to obtain a contempt-of-court citation against a union whose walkout threatens to tie up widespread construction here were begun yesterday by the struck employer.

Dennison Manufacturing Stockholders of the Dennison Manufacturing Company at their annual meeting in Framingham, Mass., yesterday approved the two-for-one split of the Class A and voting common stocks.

Earnings of the Consolidated Foods Corporation rose 27 per cent in the thirty-six weeks ended March 5 on a sales gain of 20 per cent over the preceding year's period. The results set records for the nine months, according to the report of the Chicago food processor and distributor.

DETROIT, March 29 (UPI) -- Jerry Melnyk scored an overtime goal tonight to lift the Detroit Red Wings to a 2-1 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs, squaring their semi-final series in the National Hockey League Stanley Cup play-offs.
On Sunday morning, April 24, six men from Ireland are due to step from an Aer Lingus plane onto the concrete of New York's International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The adventures of the United States submarine Wahoo and her officers and crew are told by Forest J. Sterling in "Wake of the Wahoo." The author joined the crew just before the submarine left on her second patrol.

An agreement for the design and construction of a large steel rolling mill in Buenos Aires was announced yesterday by Patterson-Emerson-Comstock, Inc., of Pittsburgh. The project, which is expected to take five years, will involve as a "first phase" the shipment of an armor-plate mill from Gary, Ind., to Buenos Aires.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 29 -- The United States and Britain agreed today to join the Soviet Union in a moratorium on underground nuclear explosions provided the Russians submit to a system of international inspection and control.
An Ohio-born broadcaster for Nazi Germany who is seeking to recover his American citizenship offered his explanation yesterday for renouncing it in Berlin in the spring of 1940.
CHICAGO, March 29 (AP) -- Grain futures prices worked slightly higher most of the time today but weakened near the close and finished with small losses in wheat, oats and rye.
The New York County Lawyers Association defended yesterday the committee method by which it passes on qualifications of would-be judges.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- The strike by actors that has crippled movie production here was on the verge of settlement today.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Thomas G. Lanphier Jr. said today that President Eisenhower "has led us incompetently to a point where we are in jeopardy of our national life."

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas complained today about $2,000,000 the Eisenhower Administration, was asking to house its test dogs and cows.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI) -- The National Mediation Board has found contract negotiations between the country's railroads-and eleven non-operating unions hopelessly deadlocked. It has recommended that their differences be submitted to arbitration.

LONDON, March 29 (UPI) -- Dave Charnley, the British and British Empire lightweight champion, took the European lightweight crown from Mario Vecchiatto of Italy tonight by scoring a tenth-round knockout in their scheduled fifteen-rounder.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- About 540 persons died of polio in this country during 1959, more than double the 255 victims in 1958, the Public Health Service reported today.

Virtuoso performances by a dozen or so issues marked an otherwise humdrum session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- American manufacturers of typewriters urged the Tariff Commission today to impose a 30 per cent tariff on imported typewriters, with a minimum of $10 for each machine.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 11 points up to 3 points off yesterday, with the near months strongest. A point is 5 cents a bale.

YOUNG stargazers and their parents can take up positions at ten telescopes on Sunday evening at Jones Beach. The high-powered lenses will be focused on Arcturus, a giant star known as the "astronomer's robin," a celestial herald of spring.

THE Tip Toe Inn on Broadway at Eighty-sixth Street does not provide lodgings, as might be assumed from its name, but it does offer many other services. Food and drink are served in the large, comfortable dining rooms of the restaurant, which has been in continuous operation, there for forty years.

Northwest Airlines plans to replace Lockheed Electra turbo-prop airliners with piston aircraft on some of its long-range routes beginning today. The action stems from the crash of a Northwest Electra at Tell City, Ind., on March 17, in which sixty-three died.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 29 -- The Rev. Dr. James Iley McCord, who was inaugurated today as fourth president of Princeton Theological Seminary, is a rare theologian. He makes sense to his theological peers as well as to the man in the pew.

Magistrate Evelyn Richman called yesterday for grand-jury investigation of a landlord whose wife or agent has been in Housing Court more than thirty times in the last two years to answer for violations on his property.

Henry Goelet, New York realty investor and builder, has purchased two seven-story apartment houses at 3 and 5 Washington Square, Larchmont, in Westchester County. The buildings are within walking distance of the railroad station and shopping district.

CHICAGO, March 30 (UPI) -- Eddie Perkins of Chicago cut Chico Rollins on the left eyelid in the fourth round tonight and then worked on the wound to Score a seventh-round technical knockout.
