BOSTON, March 30 -- The National Labor Relations Board petitioned today for injunctions against both sides in the nine-week-old Bethlehem Steel Company shipyard strike.

Manuel Ycaza rushed, from New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, to the Aqueduct race track just in time to ride the Circle M. Farm's Mommy Dear to victory in the $28,050 Correction Handicap yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) off to 15 points (75 cents) up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
New York University will increase its tuition fees Sept. 1, Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, the president, announced yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 30 -- A state of emergency was declared today in much of South Africa.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Lieut. Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, Air Force research chief, told Congress today that greater urgency was required in the development of satellites that would flash a warning of an enemy missile attack.

FOR its second program at the City Center, the New York City Ballet last night took one of the numbers out of its full-evening program of last season called "Panamerica" and tried putting it into, the general repertory.

WESTBURY, L. I., March 30 -- For 27 - year - old Clarence Hand, this was a night to remember. It was the night about which he had been dreaming since he was a 9-year-old on a farm at Flemington, N. J. It was the night on which he drove his first winner in an official harness race.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended March 23:

FOR the last two days the most interesting Fifty-seventh Street store windows have had humans on display. At Milgrim's a male glove cutter and a woman glove sewer were snipping and stitching in the store windows.
A Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to ten years in prison for attempting to pass a counterfeit $100 bill in a liquor store.
A fund to stimulate original television drama has been establlshed by the sponsor of the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" series.
Stocks rose a little -- or fell a little -- yesterday, depending on the yardstick used, but the tone of the market was soft.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 30 -- Following are excerpts from addresses today at the session of the Security Council on South Africa:
A major promotional effort with a special twist will be started in May on behalf of Maine's sardine industry.
The move to save Carnegie Hall gained impetus at City Hall yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that Vice President Nixon would be "absolutely stupid" if he stood pat on Administration policies.
AUTOMATIC false-carding plays and optional false-carding plays are both part of the lore of contract bridge and are known to all good players.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Eisenhower made it clear today, that adequate, inspection and control are a vital condition of his agreement with Prime Minister Macmillan to join the Soviet Union in a suspension of underground nuclear weapons tests.
The Chicago, Ill., Board o Education borrowed $25,000,000 in the bohd market yesterday on serial obligations due from 1962 to 1980.
Edward D. Stone, one of the most prominent architects in this country, will design an elementary school for the Board of Education.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- Jim Owens, fined $600 because of a barroom fracas, quit the Philadelphia Phillies today but later the pitcher changed his mind, deciding he would be foolish to toss away a promising career.
The Yankees won't be able to raise the championship pennant at the Stadium this season, but they will be able to hoist a few more customers into the ball park.

Management and labor in the shipping industry have a mutual interest, in stopping the "dissipation" of shipping revenues through excessive personnel illness and injury claims, a leading shipping official said here yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, March 30 (UPI) -- Senator John F. Kennedy campaigned for the Presidency in cold, wet Wisconsin today, out the front line was at his election headquarters, where the Kennedy family was accused of having backed Vice President Nixon in 1950.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Senate rewrote the House civil rights bill today to provide new criminal penalties for obstructing all types of court orders. The vote was 68 to 20.
LAUREL, Md., March 30 -- The Laurel Race course's twenty-nine-day meeting got underway today, and Mrs. Walter F. Wickes Jr.'s Vendetta won the feature, the $10,000-added Capitol Handicap.

OTTAWA, March 30 -- Canada Will end the 1959-60 fiscal year with a Federal budget deficit estimated at $405,800,000, the second highest in peacetime history, according to a White Paper presented to Parliament today.

A hospital workers union announced last night that it had won bargaining recognition at two member hospitals of the Greater New York Hospital Association. Such recognition had been sought unsuccessfully by the union last year in a forty-six day strike against Seven association hospitals.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Prime Minister Macmillan surprised and somewhat disturbed United States officials during his visit here with the vehemence of his views on the rapidly approaching trade split in Europe.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 30 -- Danny Terrasi, a shy little boy with dark hair and big brown eyes, was the envy of his neighborhood, today. He celebrated his fourth birthday riding a Diesel locomotive as the guest of the Long Island Rail Road.

THIS account of a hunting-dog man gone wrong came from a person in the vicinity of Stuart, Fla., but it cannot be verified. The reporter said it concerned an old man whom he called Job Smitchie and who lived north of Okeechobee City, Fla., and hunted there all his life.
Wool prices fell sharply in active trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange Grease wool dropped 1.7 to 2.5 cents a pound and tops were off 1 to 2 cents a pound.

BACK in the good old days of Horace, the Roman poet and satirist, it was believed that the penetrating odor of parsley excited the brain to agreeable thoughts. Wreaths of parsley were worn on Roman heads, and Homer supposedly fed his horses with it to induce them to greater speed.

STEPHEN PACE'S new paintings at the Howard Wise Gallery, 50 West Fifty-seventh Street, are abstractions in which energetic elements battle their way to equilibrium. No matter how baroque Mr. Pace's compositions are -- and they are nearly all fretted with tilting and bucking forms -- they do, ultimately, come to rest.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, March 29 -- The commander of the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay near here defended today the recent dismissal of a Cuban labor leader by the base, which brought a protest from the Cuban Government.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 30 -- A scientist reported studies today that he believes demostrate clearly that virus is a essential factor in causing human leukemia.

In the current issue of Foreign Affairs Polish Communist leader Wladyslaw Gomulka has taken advantage of an opportunity to speak directly to interested Americans and present his views on a wide range of problems. His statement of his case is welcome and it is to be hoped that American statesmen will have similar opportunities to present our country's point of view to the Polish people.

RICHMOND, Va., March 30 (AP) -- Senator Kennedy has reiterated that his actions, if elected President, would be guided by the public interest and not by "the dictates of any ecclesiastical authority or group."

Net income of S. H. Kress Co. from operations in 1359 dropped to $1,892,071, or 80 cents a share, from $4,818,223 and $2.03 in 1958, the variety store chain announced yesterday. The 1959 earnings did not include a nonrecurring gain of $1,132,137, or 47 cents a share, from the sale and leaseback of store properties.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board Issued a bitter rebuttal today to long and critical memorandum chat a board member submitted to President Eisenhower upon resigning last September.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The eighteenth census of the people of the United States will start tomorrow night at 10,000 hotels and motels.

ALBANY, March 30 -- supporters of nondiscrimination in private housing pinned their last hopes tonight on intervention by Governor Rockefeller to get the administration's anti-bias measure out of a hostile Senate Finance Committee.
The United States utilities industry moved yesterday to regain the lead from Russia in extra high voltage transmission of electricity.
ROME, March 30 -- Pope John XXIII placed red birettas today on the heads of seven of the ten Cardinals elevated in a secret Consistory Monday.

MOSCOW, March 30 -- With an eye toward the tremendous increase of tourists to the Soviet Union expected this summer, four western European airlines plan to inaugurate new jet services on their regular schedules to Moscow early in April, it was reported today.
TOKYO, March 30 -- "Boston Symphony Plans Shock Japan's Promoters," said a, three-column headline on the front page today of The Asahi Evening News, a Tokyo English-language newspaper.

WARREN, Vr. WARDROBE conditions are as crucial as snow conditions at Sugarbush Valley, where the warm sun is now summoning spring skiers. Skis, poles and boots are only the basics at this, the St. Moritz of the Bast. Here women select their ski clothes as carefully as they would, a gown for the April in Paris ball.
GENEVA, March 30 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that it was willing to extend the four year time limit in its plan for total disarmament.
FAIRVIEW, N. J., March 30 -- Philip Meo, 52-year-old superintendent of a struck concern, was beaten unconscious outside his home here this morning.
ROUEN, France, March 30 -- Premier Khrushchev said today there was no common ground between the Soviet and Western proposals for disarmament.

A syndicate headed by Abramson Brothers, lawyers and realty investors, has purchased the twenty-six-story office and store building at 50 East Forty-second Street, diagonally opposite Grand Central Terminal.

ST. PETERSBURG, FIa., March 30 -- As the fly ball arched gently toward the outfield, the Yankee base-runner on first took a few steps down the line and then stopped to watch. Bobby Richardson, knowing that all base-runners should gallop like crazy with, two out, leaped to his feet in the dugout.

THERE are not many more exacting roles for the acting singer than Scarpia in "Tosca." Hermann Uhde, German baritone, sang the part for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera last night. And as if to burden himself with the memory of one of the greatest Scarpias in the theatre's history, he donned the costume of Antonio Scotti.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The letter published March 21 by Geraldine E. McGaughan, suggesting the use of paperback textbooks in the schools, is much to the point. The undersigned was Superintendent of School Supplies of New York City's schools when the first paper-bound book experiment was conducted.
HAVANA, March 30 -- Ecclesiastical quarters reported today that Cuba's eight Roman Catholic Bishops had drafted a pastoral letter expressing their concern over the inroads of communism in Cuba.
The Contemporary Music Society and the Rockefeller Institute precepted a program of contemporary works at the institute's Caspary Hall last night.

The way to a first step toward armament control has been opened by President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Macmillan in their Camp David agreement. This agreement will be presented to the Geneva nuclear weapons test conference today. It has still many hurdles to surmount, and the final word on it is likely to be spoken by Premier Khrushchev at the East-West summit meeting.

The issuance of a Presidential Proclamation requiring that 50 per cent of the nation's oil imports be transported in American-flag tankers would provide "opportunity for unconscionable profiteering," a Texaco spokesman declared yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, March 30 -- A spiritual leader of American Reform Judaism deplored today what he termed "dues-paying but otherwise inactive synagogue members."

Testimony at the tax-evasion trial of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. showed yesterday that he had overstated his wife's income by more than $11,000 in 1951 and had also failed to deduct $2,600 in allowable expenses.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Uncle Sam may not have a reputation for being light on his feet, but he knows the difference between a dance contest and, a sales contest.

Mrs. Roslyn Newman, a Brooklyn housewife, has an idea and the name for an organization, but nothing more after three years of effort. The name is the Volunteer Dog Walkers. So far there have been no volunteers and no walkers.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A Democratic Representative suggested today that the Securities and Exchange Commission look into what appeared to be a "misrepresentation" in a gas-company case now under the scrutiny of House investigators.

The tournament program of the Metropolitan Golf Association, which spans six months was announced yesterday. It opens with the district intercollegiate championship, May 11, at the Essex Country Club, West Orange, N.J.

HERBERT GOLD gives his stories a wry, bright air of wonder. He takes some of the most hackneyed situations you ever saw and makes them seem fresh, astonishing, new. He is a born storyteller, and, in the world of creative writing, there are no reliable substitutes for that.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Administration has decided not to support farm labor legislation this year.
HONG KONG, March 30 -- A program for continued large scale economic advances in Communist China this year was announced in Peiping today.
A utility, a financial institution, a manufacturer of precious metal products and a hearing aid manufacturer announced yesterday plans for financing.
ALBANY, March 30 -- Governor Rockefeller appeared tonight to have rejected a recommendation that Federal, state and municipal subsidies be provided for commuter railroads.

Three years have elapsed since the Broadway premiere of Paul Osborn's "Maiden Voyage" was canceled after its Philadelphia tryout. In situation like this, especially where a prominent author is involved, an explanation is usually issued to the effect that the script will be revamped for a future hearing.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30 -- The South African representative withdrew from the Security Council debate today after the Council had placed on its agenda an Asian-African charge that his Government was responsible for "large-scale killings" of unarmed demonstrators.

"Lament for a Generation," a new book by Ralph de Toledano, will be issued by Farrar, Straus Cudahy on Monday. The author, who was born in 1916, gives an account of his generation -- one that came of age in the Depression, flirted with communism in the Thirties, went to war in the Forties and came to terms with "a world in convulsion" in the Fifties.
MADRID, March 30 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco virtually cleared the way today for Don Juan de Bourbon, Count of Barcelona, to ascend the Spanish throne if the monarchy is restored.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) made three loans totaling the equivalent of $40,000,000 to the Belgian Congo to develop African agriculture and improve transportation.

There was a tight market yesterday in Federal Funds, those reserves that commercial banks lend to each other overnight. Hundreds of millions of dollars often chaneg hands over the teletype in a single day in such transactions.
LONDON, March 30 -- British concern with the crisis in South Africa deepened tonight with the announcement that events there had produced a state of emergency and new threats of bloodshed.

Cats may be smarter than people. Would a woman faced with an impending confinement select the safe deposit vault area of the Chemical Bank New York Trust. Company office at Sixtieth Street and Lexington Aveaue as a haven?
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Eisenhower supported today the views of those concerned about the softness of American youth.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The response of the President and the British Prime Minister to Soviet Russia's latest nuclear disarmament proposal gave Premier Khrushchev what he wanted. This is the indefinite continuation of the moratorium on tests of nuclear weapons, including tests underground.

The Symphony of the Air will undertake a tour of Italy this spring in memory of Arturo Toscanini as the first of a series of global cultural projects to be sponsored by the American International Foundation. Mr. Toscanini conducted many of the orchestra's members when it was the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra.

PATRICK AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Thursday, March 31 -- A huge Air Force pistonengine refueling plane with fourteen men aboard ditched in the Atlantic about forty miles off Cape Canaveral at 8:30 o'clock last night.
ALBANY, March 30 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported to day to the State Commerce Department:

The State Legislature has now put up to Governor Rockefeller the question of what should be done about the Youth Court Act. It was passed in 1956, but its effective date has been postponed each year since then while controversy has raged about whether or not it should be scrapped altogether. Now the Legislature has passed two bills: one to repeal the act and the other to put off its effective date for another year.

UNDER the title of "Strangers in the City," station WCBS-TV offered a documentary examination last night of the status of Puerto Ricans in New York. If not too much of the material was especially new, the program Was a worth-while reminder that many of the problems associated with Spanish-speaking citizens existed long before their arrival.
YESTERDAY (March 30, 1960) THE GOVERNOR Met twice with Republican legislative leaders. Sent several emergency messages to Legislature to permit immediate consideration of new bills.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The merger plans of the Erie Railroad and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western. Railroad received the backing here today, as had been expected, of Hyman J. Blond, an examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission.
YESTERDAY (March 30, I960) THE PRESIDENT Held news conference. THE SENATE Heard British Prime Minister Macmillan.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower opposed today any compulsory insurance system to provide medical care for the aging.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Merger of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank and the Chicago National Bank was approved today by directors of the two Loop financial institutions. The directors ordered submission of the merger agreement to separate special meetings of the shareholders on May 4 and set Oct. 24 as the effective date of consolidation.

SUFFERN, N.Y., March 30 -- The Geigy Chemical Corporation of Ardsley has contracted to buy 140 acres here to build a plant for packaging and ware housing its pharmaceutical products. The purchase is contingent upon a rezoning to permit such operations.

A recount of ballots was completed yesterday in a disputed primary election held Sept. 15 for Republican leader, of the Fourteenth Assembly District East in East Harlem. The resuits were not disclosed, pending a report to the District Attorney.
The four New York and New Jersey Senators took steps yesterday to recover for Port of New York an annual Army cargo movement of 59,000 tons.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., which operated in the red in 1956, 1957 and 1958, turned in the second highest earnings in its history last year.

AT the height of the Luftwaffe blitz on London in World War II, a squat, muscular man would climb to the roof of South Africa House in Trafalgar Square a tin hat resting on his curly hair and a gas mask slapping against his thigh, to take up his post in defense of his country's diplomatic center.
ALBANY, March 29 -- A bipartisan agreement to add six new justices to the state Supreme Court in the First Judicial District and five in the Second was in sight tonight.
SYRACUSE, N. T., March 30 (AP) -- Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc., announced today it would transfer typewriter manufacturing operations at Syracuse to its plants in Cortland and Groton.
South Africa has 10,000,000 Africans of Bantu stock and 3,000,000 whites. There also are Indians and persons of mixed blood in the population of 14,500,000.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Eisenhower expressed disappointment today over the lack of progress in settling United States-Cuban differences.
PARIS, March 30 -- Western Europe's two rival trading blocs agreed today to substitute fact-finding for hand-writing.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The Assembly and Senate quickly approved today the bill, providing $22,000,000 in additional state aid for New York City.
Sears, Roebuck Co. made a greater profit in 1959 than in any previous year in its history, Sales exceeded four billion dollars for the first time.

A one-time stockroom clerk, African "white hunter" and Shanghai cafe "bouncer" yesterday was elected president and chief executive officer of Hazel Bishop, Inc. He is Herman L. Johnson Jr., former executive vice president of the cosmetics company.
A liquor-store association consented in Supreme Court yesterday to an injunction restraining it from instructing its Harlem members to patronize only a list of salesmen, predominantly Negroes.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Prime Minister Macmillan flew back to London tonight after three days of talks with President Eisenhower that left officials on both sides less than satisfied.

JOHANNESBURG, March 30 (UPI) -- The crisis in South Africa touched off a heavy wave of selling on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange which toward the close reached what one veteran exchange observer described as "panic proportions."
LONDON, March 30 -- The Government said today that 1960 could be a year of economic progress for Britain -- as last year was -- but it added a number of if's.

Tenants who have been spending one morning a week for the last six weeks in Housing Court, awaiting a chance to testify against their landlord, burst into outraged shouts yesterday when he implied that they had nothing, better to do.

LONDON, March 30 -- A series of clinical tests conducted quietly in England during the last year have shown that hormone, compounds used as oral contraceptives are still producing too many side effects to be satisfactory.

WARNINGS to would-be collectors of the prized European porcelain figures of the eighteenth century were sounded Tuesday evening by Edward Arthur Lane, keeper of ceramics at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.
TOLEDO, Ohio, March 30 (UPI) -- Bosco (Boss) Yovanovich and Ed Markulis of Akron, Ohio, took fourth place in doubles today with a 1,294 in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

PARIS, March 31 -- The seeds of a disagreement over the North Atlantic alliance's military supplies were sown today by an implied British suggestion that they ought to be lower than the present level, which is calculated to be sufficient to wage a ninety-day war.
For most of yesterday stocks staged a cautious retreat, but in the final thirty minutes of trading the retreat turned into a rout.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- The United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., has been called home to participate in preparations for the Big Four summit meeting in Paris in May.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
LAKELAND, Pla., March 31 -- Casey Stengel never looks down on the less fortunate. His greeting to Jimmie Dykes was typical as the Yanka and the Tigers prepared to tangle today.

Industrial corporations stepped up their prepayment of bonds in March before maturity, and, as a result, the total of all bonds called for redemption before maturities rose to $34,302,000 from $18,427,000 in February. A year ago, $64,780,000 in bonds was redeemed in March prior to dates of maturity.

LONDON, March 31 -- The Foreign Office labeled as entirely inaccurate today published accounts of some of the remarks Prime Minister Macmillan was reported to have made during his visit to the United States.

A Government tax agent testified yesterday that when Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was indicted in 1958 for understating his wife's income for 1951 by $5,365.77 the grand jury did not Know of duplications in the return of more than that amount.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- Following are excerpts from statements today at the Security Council session on South Africa:
United States private investments in the Union of South Africa, totaling more than $350,000,000, are not large in comparison with such investments in other countries.

MILWAUKEE, March 31 -- The religious issue again took the spotlight today in Wisconsin's Presidential primary campaign despite angry protests by the two Democratic candidates -- Senators John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Four more official estimates of economic conditions gave further evidence today that things were not as boomy now as the New Year's Day predictions had said.

THE age of specialization is making increasing inroads on the fashion world. Since the ready-to-wear industry first started making shirtwaists by the gross, at the turn of the century, the gap in sizing and styling between ready-made clothes and dressmaker fashions is steadily lessening.

Several hundred angry property owners jammed the City Council chamber yesterday to protest a Wagner administration proposal that would make them liable in injury suits resulting from sidewalk hazards.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 31 -- Chief Albert Luthuli is president of an organization that is an important force in the opposition, to the Government's racial policies.

The New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad sold $6,930,000 of fifteen-year equipment trust certificates yesterday to investment bankers led by Salomon Bros. Hutzler on a bid of 99.321 for certificates bearing a 4 3/8per cent interest coupon.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Eleven non-operating railroad unions rejected arbitration of their wage dispute today.
TOLEDO, Ohio, March 31 (UPI) -- Vince Lucci, a former coal miner from Trenton, took a thirty-four-pin lead in all-events today at the American Bowling Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Education Forum of the White House Conference on Children and Youth today urged Congress to help raise school financing from 3 to 10, per cent of the gross natlonal product.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Rockefeller signed nine bills today effecting the first changes in his long-range program for reorganizing the state government.
MILWAUKEE, March 30 -- "Abolish the caucus and convention," declared the speaker. "Go back to the first principle of democracy; go back to the people."
A strike of 300 sheet-metal workers that had tied up twenty-nine major construction jobs in the metropolitan area for thirteen days enedd yesterday.
HAVANA, March 31 -- Janio Quadros, a leading candidate for the Brazilian Presidency, has decided to cut short his visit here. He is reported to be annoyed at being "misquoted" by Cuban newspapers.

WILMINGTON, N.C., March 31 (AP) -- Tom Nieporte, a 30-year-old Bronxville, N.Y., professional, shot a 64 and took a three-stroke lead in the first round of the $15,000 Azalea open golf tournament today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) up on the near July contract and were steady to 6 points (30 cents) off on the other months.
Illegal gambling "in all its aspects and ramifications" is the major law-enforcement problem in New York, the State Investigation Commission said yesterday.

Patronesses have been announced for the May Festival Ball, which will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on May 9 to celebrate the tenth anniversary of Just One Break, Inc. (J.O.B.). Harry Winston, Inc., and Helena Rubinstein, Inc., are sponsors for the fete.
Two new features, a prize-winning documentary on Africa and a comedy adapted from a Broadway play, have been scheduled for openings at first-run houses in the midtown area.
The Royal Dutch-Shell Group had a net income of $175,535,000 in 1959, or $491,498,000 at the official rate of exchange. Sales and other operating income amounted to u2,578,932,000 ($7,221,065,600).

Premier Castro should be realizing by now that the issue of communism in Cuba cannot be brushed aside or treated as an unjustified maneuver of his political enemies. Moreover, it is becoming clear that he cannot maintain the internal unity he seeks and still permit the Communists to have leeway, even in the lower levels of the Government, army and trade unions.

Plans, for a three-year trial run of subscription television in Hartford were announced yesterday by the Zenith Radio Corporation and R.K.O. General Inc. No date has been set for the start of the service.

WASHINGTON. March 31 -- loadings of freight for both raills and trucks last week were lightly below 1959 levels. Rail Jadings were well above -- and truck loadings were slightly below -- those of the preceding week of this year.
EDGEWATER, N.J., March 31 -- Shad fishermen along the Hudson River were set today to string their nets on Saturday night in the hope of an early catch in time for the Lenten market.

Operations of the W.T. Grant Company in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31 resulted in the highest sales, and earnings in the fifty-three-year history of the variety chain, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 31 -- A New Jersey couple become the legal parents today of a precocious 4-year-old foster child the state had called too bright for them. This closed a bitter struggle for her custody.

Just about every one of the 22,403 spectators at Aqueduct yesterday apparently wanted Hirsch Jacobs to make racing history. The 55-year-old trainer needed only one victory to attain a score of 3,000 winners in a career dating back to 1926, and he had four horses ready to do their best.

THE Big Nonsense, or Opening Day of Trout Season, begins this morning as early as anybody wants to get up. Reason says that the day will find few except children on the streams; experience says that reason is a liar.
Radio had a big day yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 31 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadians and their goalie, Jacques Plante, shut out the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 2-0, and gained the Stanley Cup finals for the tenth consecutive year. As a result of their victory the Canadiens remain on the path toward their fifth straight Cup triumph.
"The Promising Sixties" will be the theme of the 148th anniversary dinner of the New York City Mission Society, to be held next Thursday in the Grand Ballroom of the Delmonico.

In 1945 Igor and Svetlana Gouzenko, members of the Soviet Embassy in Ottawa, defected and sought asylum in Canada. In 1954 Igor Gouzenko published "The Fall of a Titan," a novel about Soviet life. Now Svetlana Gouzenko has written a book about her life in the Soviet Union.

ST. LOUIS, March 31 -- Dewey Short, Assistant Secretary of the Army, made a strong plea here today for parents to instill in their sons-an "awareness and understanding of why they must fulfill their military obligations."
COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., March 31 -- The Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire said here yesterday that by advancing the "social Gospel," leaders of the National Council of Churches were helping the spread of communism.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 31 -- President Romulo Betancourt urged the United States today to break off diplomatic relations with the Dominican Republic.

Mexicana Airlines has announced the cancellation of a general traffic and sales agency agreement with Pan American World Airways, effective today. Pan American, which owns a 20 per cent interest in Mexicana, has represented the Mexican line since 1935 on traffic and sales.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- In their fourth successive small advance this week, July and September corn contracts again reached new high prices for the season on the Board of Trade today.

A West Side sewer contractor bid "excessively high" prices for certain types of work on which the estimate of city engineers had been far too low, it was asserted yesterday in a court action by a state inquiry here. The resulting cost to the city was $300,000 above a $1,674,590 bid.
WHITE PLAINS, March 31 -- The Fund for Adult Education, which will end its operations next year, announced its final series of fellowships today.

Loans to business at the larger New York City banks were unchanged in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the week last year, business loans were down $132,000,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- An 11-year-old schoolboy from Thailand who is making a world trip alone spent his first day in New York today seeing the sights with his United Nations "family."

WESTBURY, L.I., March 31 -- The judges at Roosevelt Raceway, continuing their "get tougher" policy, cracked down on another driver today. Because of what they termed an "inconsistent drive," the officials suspended Marcel Dostie for fifteen nights, effective at once.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 31 -- At a special meeting today stockholders of the NAFI Corporation voted overwhelmingly to buy the outstanding common shares of the Chris-Craft Corporation for $40,000,000. Next Tuesday is the effective date of the transaction.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at the telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses:
IT will be forty years next August since tot melodrama, "The Bat," opened on Broadway for a long run during which it chilled many patrons.
YESTERDAY (March 31, I960) THE PRESIDENT Saw Treasury Secretary Anderson and the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Two vice presidents of the A.F.L.C.I.O. endorsed Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri today for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The sickness of South Africa yesterday reached halfway round the world, from the tense cities of Capetown, Johannesburg and Durban to United Nations headquarters on the East River, where the Security Council was in the second day of a discussion of the race troubles that have shaken the Western world.
A dog and a kangaroo met on Madison Avenue yesterday and caused a small traffic jam.
CONCORD. N.H., March 31 (AP) -- The New Hampshire Supreme Court refused today to free Dr. Willard Uphaus, 69-year-old pacifist serving a one-year jail term for contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products increased 3 per cent between mid-February and mid-March. This increase narrowed the gap between farm prices being received this year and those of a year earlier.
Board of Education officials asserted yesterday that the city school system had suffered a "catastrophe" when the Legislature rejected a bill to permit administrative reorganization of the system.

Stock transactions on the New York Stock Exchange this year have produced the largest first-quarter losses in the forty-nine years' history of the New York Times average of fifty representative stocks.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 (UPI) -- The defending champion in the 191-pound class, Frank Rosenmayr of the San Francisco Olympic Club, tonight gained a decision over Jim Mills of the Los Angeles Y.M.C.A., in the Amateur Athletic Union's national wrestling tourney.

The Danlev Holding Corporation, represented by Samuel K. Beier, lawyer, has purchased the eight-story mercantile building at 12 West Seventeenth Street and will renovate the lobby and install new elevators. The property was sold by the Nored Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $100,000.

GWYN GRIFFIN, whose name suggests that he is Welsh, has not to my knowledge been publicly numbered among Britain's angry young men. Nevertheless, he is much angrier than any other British writer, old or young, whom I have encountered in years. Mr. Griffin is furious with the men who still administer the remnants of Britain's declining empire.
THE nightmarish imagery that appears in William Scharf's paintings is more like the brilliant flashes of form that occur when we press our closed eyes than like any phenomena observed open-eyed.

PORT CANAVERAL, Fla., March 31 -- The pilot of an Air Force refueling plane that ditched forty miles off the coast last night said today that "the worst turbulence I've ever Seen" and a subsequent loss of oil pressure had forced the plane down.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Yongjeung Kim's letter to The Times published March 26 quotes from its March 22 editorial "Two Presidents Re-elected," but fails to show his understanding of the purpose of the editorial. Had he understood the editorial thoroughly, he would have noted that the overwhelming support of the Korean people was given to Dr. Syngman Rhee as the greatest anti-Communist statesman.
MEMO to friends bearing gifts to air-borne tourists: Do not bring the presents to the airport. Send them in advance so they can be packed, or left at home.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 31 -- Most of the student body at Southern University, the nation's largest all-Negro college, boycotted classes today and a substantial number requested withdrawal forms. The actions were taken to protest the expulsion of eighteen students who took part in lunch-counter sitdowns and other anti-segregation demonstrations here.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Vice President Nixon was reported encouraged today about his Novembe prospects in normally Democratic Southern states.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Census Bureau's temporary army of 160,000 enumerators will fan out across the land at daybreak tomorrow to count 179,921,434 persons.
PARIS, March 31 -- Negotiations for independence of the West African republics of Senegal and Sudan, which together make up the Mali Federation, were successfully concluded with France today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Supporters of the Forand bill to provide health insurance for Social Security pensioners lost the first and perhaps decisive battle today in their fight for favorable Congressional action.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The legislature gave New York City the power tonight to impose an annual tax of $100 on taxicabs and a new levy on trucks and other commercial vehicles.

HINSDALE, Ill., March 31 (UPI) -- The defending champion, Tan Joe Hok of Indonesia, and the top-seeded United States player, Jim Poole of San Diego, gained the quarter-finals of the United States amateur badminton tournament today.

ALBANY, Friday, April 1 -- Following are the texts of comments by Governor Rockefeller yesterday and early today on his housing discrimination bill. The first was a message to the Legislature yesterday. The second was a statement this morning after the Assembly had approved the bill but the Senate had shelved it.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, March 31 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson, the world heavyweight champion, today said he would go to New York on April 13 to sign official contracts for his return title fight with Floyd Patterson. The bout tentatively is scheduled for June 22 at the Polo Grounds.

TAMPA, Fla., March 31 -- Whitey Lockman watches the batting cage out of the corner of an eye as he performs his daily chore of slapping grounders at the infielders during hitting practice. If any member of the Cincinnati Reds is dilatory about taking his turn, Whitey drops his fungo stick, grabs a real bat and hurries into the cage for a full-bodied cut at the ball.

The Federal Maritime Board said yesterday it had agreed to subsidize part of a $60,000,000, five-ship replacement program of the Prudential Steamship Corporation. The 27-year-old company operates, a cargo service between Atlantic Coast ports and the Mediterranean area.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Southern Senators opened an offensive today to make weakening changes in the voting referee plan contained in the civil rights bill.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., March 31 -- This Westchester County city of 18,287 persons has had more than its share of school troubles recently.

Governor Rockefeller opened the New York Legislature's 1960 session on Jan. 6 with a testimonial to democracy. The Legislature responded with a session that was a convincing demonstration of independent-minded, working democracy, perhaps more than the Governor counted on. Mr. Rockefeller succeeded in getting a large part of his program through while, at the same time, suffering some setbacks.

Enumerators last night began to count the overnight lodgers in the city's hotels and motels. They distributed questionnaires requiring thirty-five answers as the eighteenth census of the United States got under way here.
MILWAUKEE, March 31 -- Don F. Ebert, a husky, young, small-town building contractor, leaned against the door of The East Troy News in Republican Walworth County of Wisconsin.
OTTAWA, March 31 -- A balanced budget with no major tax changes was presented to the Canadian parliament tonight by Finance Minister Donaid Flemming.

An elderly woman was found dead yesterday on a pile of rags in the bedroom of her Bronx apartment. Amid the trash, the police found bank books and stock certficates that indicated her wealth exceeded $100,000.
Robert Moses has tentatively accepted the presidency of the 1864 New York World's Fair.

The Colonial Sand and Stone Company, Inc., had the highest sales and earnings in its forty-eight-year history last year. Anthony Pope, president, said the results were achieved despite a summer strike by teamers that lasted nearly four weeks.
More new securities were marketed here in March than in the preceding month or in March, 1959.
Eight warrants were issued yesterday for the arrest of Herbert S. Wolfe, an owner of slum properties against which numerous health and housing complaints have been filed.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 31 (AP) -- A six-engine Stratojet Air Force bomber exploded above Little Rock today, killing five persons.

Boris Spassky, a former world Junior champion and one of the two Soviet players in the chess tournament at Mar del Plata in Argentina, defeated Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the United States champion, in the second round yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 31 -- It may prove possible to find new ways of mobilizing one of the body's longest known natural defense systems for a more effective attack against cancer, a specialist suggested today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior has told Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) it cannot expect an increased residual fuel oil import quota just because it exhausted about 70 per cent of its six-month allotment in two months.
JOHANNESBURG, March 31 (AP) -- The police shot one African dead and wounded three others tonight as violence again erupted in scattered points around Johannesburg.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 31 -- Adlai E, Stevenson deplored today Cuba's apparent disavowal of the inter-American defense pact signed in Rio de Janeir in 1947.

SINCE Anglo-American relations survived the antics of J. Fred Muggs, the monkey who cavorted on Channel 4 on the morning of Queen Elizabeth's coronation, there Is no reason for serious concern over Jack Paar's visit to London.
THE great success of Italy's world champion team is often attributed in part to the iron discipline exerted on the team by its nonplaying captain, Carl' Alberto Perroux.

LONDON, March 31 -- With Investors remaining cautious, industrial shares drifted lower in the stock market here today. However, the selling was also light and most falls were below a shilling (14 cents). The Ficial Times index of industrial common shares fell 1.9 points to 321.2.

ALBANY, Friday, April 1 -- A clash between Governor Rockefeller and Senator Walter J. Mahoney led to the sudden death early this morning of legislation proposed to add more justices to the Supreme Court in New York City.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, March 29 -- The people of Santiago de Cuba, stronghold of Fidel Castro during his two-year revolution against the Batista regime, are looking at the Castro Government today with critical eyes.

A DECADE ago, when Josef Petermann bought the country store In West Townshend, Vt. (population 140) he knew very little about aging cheese. Now he is an expert who sells from seven to eight tons of aged Cheddar yearly, much of it by mail order.

All of Joseph Kipness' entries since he became a Broadway producer in 1943 were brought here with the aid of others. Thus far the list includes such popular entertainments as "High Button Shoes" and the current "La Plume de Ma Tante."
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The six-man United States Tariff Commission told Congress today in a 300-page report of the depressed state of the nation's lead and zinc industries.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The coin machine industry, which does a gross business of $300,000,000 a year, is infested with underworld characters, Senator John L. McClellan told the Senate today.
The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service expects to devote more of its ships to scientific projects, such as missile tracking and recovery, in the Nineteen Sixties.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 31 -- George Breen, now an Indianapolis schoolteacher, stepped back, to the head of the class in American distance swimming today. He turned in a record-shattering performance in the first final, of the Amateur Athletic Union's National indoor championships.
LAST night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center did not go in for novelty, but it certainly concentrated on performance with excellent results.
A nearly fatal slip in an elevator yesterday afternoon left a 57-year old man hanging by his legs, head down, for more than two hours in a downtown loft building.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The chairman of the Federal Power Commission said today that the Midwestern Gas Transmission Company case was the first time his agency had not fixed a definite rate of return for a company's pipe line investment.
A 20-year-old Bulgarian stowaway, on the move ever since he fled his Communist homeland four years ago, appeared in Federal Court here yesterday in the hope of remaining in a United States jail.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The Legislature, despite some upstate opposition, approved an understanding between leaders of the Liberal party and Republican party in New York City tonight.
Ten large concerns here are switching to a new system of handling incoming telephone calls to speed their telephone traffic and save money.

BAD shipping conditions continue to cause bad shopping conditions as far as meat and eggs are concerned. Althoush the year started off in fine style at egg counters, large grade A white eggs now are 12 cents higher than they were a year ago.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Rivers were rising and losses mounting today in a vast flood zone that extended from Nebraska to New York state. Fugitives from high waters were moved by boat, helicopter and ambulance.
News organizations should spend more time, talent and money on presenting a balanced picture of world affairs, Eric Britter, chief of the New York City Bureau of The Times of London, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States is entering into a cooperative atomic energy program with Yugoslavia in preparation for the sale of a nuclear research reactor to the Communist country.
The chances for any immediate reunion between the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Churches are "slim," the Rev. Gustave Weigel said last night.
LOS ANGELES, March 31 -- A $1,000,000 medical rehabilitation center, the largest in the West, was dedicated today at the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital.

New York City is planning to sell $75,000,000 of serial bonds on April 27 to finance school construction, repairs to streets, expansion of sewage disposal plans, purchases of roiling stock for the Municipal transit system and the payment of city contributions to certain transit system pension funds.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, said today that the Air Force Minuteman missile, mounted on railroad cars, was the best land-based weapon system the United States had developed.

MARSHALL, Tex., March 31 (UPI) -- The president of Bishop College, a Negro institution whose students were quelled with fire hoses at a demonstration last night, today discharged Dr. Doxey Wilkerson, a faculty member Identified as a former member of the Communist party.

The Greatest Show on Earth opened cold at Madison Square Garden last night for the first time within memory. But it soon warmed the hearts of its audience with peerless pachyderms, clown cavalcades, hurricane horsemanship, high-wire heroics and death-defying daredeviltry in thirty alliterative acts.

LONDON, March 31 -- The Government assured an aroused Opposition today that two South Africans who had fled into Bechuanaland to escape arrest would not be forced by the British High Commissioner to return.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- Following is the text of a draft resolution on South Africa introduced before the Security Council today by Ecuador:
Vice Admiral Thomas S. Combes, who held more command titles than any active naval officer, was retired yesterday in colorful ceremonies aboard the Topeka at the Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

The market for high-grade corporate bonds was shaken in late afternoon trading yesterday by the announcement that the Treasury would include in its April cash financing a twenty-five-year 4 1/4 per cent bond callable in fifteen years.
When nominations closed yesterday for the 1960 elections to the Hall of Fame at New York University, it was discovered that the man who had received the most mentions was not eligible.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- He probably didn't mean to do it, but the fact is that President Eisenhower has just shoved Vice President Nixon off the high dive into deep water.

Net operating earnings of the 508 member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District increased 15.8 per cent last year to $800,300,000, a new earnings record, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Mrs. Oscar Erickson, who will retire in May from E.R. Squibb Sons after thirty-five years, looks just like someone who will retire at, the age of 65 after being a secretary many years.

The week of April 3-9 will mark the third annual observance of National Library Week. The observance is sponsored by the National Book Committee, a nonprofit group, and the American Library Association. The long-range aim is to encourage support for better library service and to urge more people to read in order to develop a mentally alert, well-informed public.
COMING from a political family, Gore Vidal knows which skeleton to stow away in which closet.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

"For the iron horse the new tecade will be the 'snorting Sixties' if he is given a reasonable head," Daniel P. Loomis, president of the Association of American Railroads, said yesterday in discussing the prospects for the railroad industry.
PARIS, Friday, April 1 -- France successfully exploded her second atomic bomb this morning in the Sahara.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 7 per cent below the year-ago level.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 31 -- Ecuador proposed today that the Security Council ask Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to try to obtain South African compliance with the provisions in the United Nations Charter ruling out racial discrimination.
GENEVA, March 31 -- The Soviet Union gave its first official reaction today to the new Western move to end tests of nuclear weapons. It was: "Encouraging."

Average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased $15,000,000 to $602,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Average reserve balances in excess of requirements declined $162,000,000 to $291,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- In this space (under date of March 30) it was estimated that the stimulation by active Soviet Russian propaganda of world opinion agains further nuclear weapons testing had played a controlling part in forming the Eisenhower Macmillan decision at Camp David.
ALBANY, March 31 -- State Thruway revenue last year was 36 per cent higher than in 1958, chiefly because of a 25 per cent increase in tolls and the doubling of the cost of annual permits.
BONN, Germany, March 31 -- The uneasy relationship between Britain and West Germany received another airing today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee cut $136,500,000 today from President Eisenhower's foreign-aid, request of $4,175,000,000. The committee also asked that no further aid be given to the Cuban regime of Premier Fidel Castro.

WHITE PLAINS, March 31 -- Methods of retrieving for public use some of the 316.38 acres of watershed lands sold by New York City were debated today by Westchester and state officials. The consensus was that condemnation would be easiest.

Two groups of demonstrators infiltrated each other's ranks by accident outside City Hall yesterday morning. The result was that a picket line protesting a proposal to end city liability in lawsuits arising from sidewallk injuries was joined by pickets opposing the projected $90,000,000 Lower Manhattan Crosstown Expressway along Broome Street.

Cities Service The Cities Service Company has acquired a one-third stock interest in ABC-Petrolifera Italiana S.P.A., large independent petroleum marketer in Italy. Burl S. Watson, chairman of Cities Service, said this would provide the company with an important outlet for its petroleum products in one of Europe's fastest growing markets.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 31 (UPI) -- White Sewing Machine Corporation will merge with the Twin Coach Company, according to reliable sources here today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Treasury announced today that it would put on the market next week its first long-term bond in nearly a year.

IT is notable that the sanest and most credible character in "Please Don't Eat the Daisies," the family comedy Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has made from the collection of humorous horror stories written by Jean Kerr, is a wellbred English sheepdog.
Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, announced the appointment yesterday of Lewis Jordan as news editor, effective today. He succeeds Ernest von Hartz, who died on March 24.
WARSAW, March 31 -- United States Ambassador Jacob D. Beam presented foun mobile health units to the Polish Government today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recent dispatches by Edwin L. Dale have given prominence to the view that a more rapid rate of economic growth will enable the United States to rectify the alleged deficiency of its public services, while at the same time reducing the Government's share of the gross national product.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A group of delegates to the White House Conference for Youth bade President Eisenhower today to use his office to bring about complete school desegregation. But it declined to criticize him for being absent or tardy in the matter to ate.

World sugar futures rose sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Final prices were unchanged to 7 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher. A total of 20,350 tons changed hands.
There are instances under the complex Federal and state tax laws in which it is difficult for the taxpayer to judge if he is entitled to claim someone as an exemption.

DENVER, March 31 (AP) -- Oscar Robertson steered the All-America-laden National Collegiate Athletic Association University All-Stars to a 97-79 victory over the Bartlesville (Okla.) Amateur Athletic Union team, and the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletic All-Stars stunned Ohio State, the N.C.A.A. champion, 76-69, in the first round of the United States Olympic basketball trials tonight.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 31 -- New arrests today brought to 300 the number seized and jailed as South Africa felt the full impact of the state of emergency proclaimed yesterday by the Government.

PARIS, March 31 -- Premier Khrushchev returned to Paris today after an exhausting five-and-a-half-day tour of the French provinces to begin serious diplomatic discussions with President de Gaulle. They will last through Saturday.

STRASBOURG, France, March 31 -- The six-nation European Parliament endorsed today the plan to speed up establishment of the Common Market An almost unanimous vote foreshadowed adoption of the program by the Governments of the bloc despite opposition from other European states.
LONDON, March 31 -- Despite objections by representatives from British Guiana, a new constitution for the Caribbean Crown Colony will go into effect in August, 1961.
A package wage rise of 21 1/2 cents an hour was agreed on yesterday for 125,000 unionized workers in the men's clothing industry.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- A group of airline pilot accident investigators today challenged Congressional testimony that linked the mental outlook of a plane captain to a fatal crash.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The White House Conference on Children and Youth ended today with its 1,600 recommendations still to be shaped into a final document.

Chesapeake Ohio The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway had a net income in March of $3,661,000, compared with $3,840,000 in March, 1959. Earnings last month were equal to 45 cents a common share, down from 47 cents a year ago.
Disciplinary action was formally approved yesterday against a state worker who had been found guilty of coding cards to designate white and non-white job applicants.
School officials and teachers' organizations expressed disappointment yesterday at Mayor Wagner's proposed budget allotments for education.

CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- The fourth gain this week in soybean futures lifted that commodity today to its highest levels in several weeks. All oldcrop months were up major fractions to more than a cent.

The State of California is planning to market new issues of state bonds more frequently in the future and in smaller volume. The purpose of the change, according to Bert A. Belts, State Treasurer, is to promote more competition among banking syndicates bidding on the bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Following are two rollcall votes by which the Senate adopted an amendment to the civil-rights bill to require that hearings by proposed voting referees be fixed by the courts and by which it tabled one that would have provided for an anti-job discrimination commission:

From his desk on the fifth floor of the Federal Building in Brooklyn, United States Attorney Cornelius W. Wickersham Jr. commands a splendid view of Cadman Plaza, as well as of the cotton stuffing in his divan.

At 1:15 P.M. yesterday, Mrs. Grover T. Odenthal, the wife of a lawyer In St. George, S.I., turned the youngest of her six children over to a neighbor and picked up a cardboard briefcase containing eighteen pounds of paper.

Daily net demand and time deposits of New York City Clearing House Association banks averaged $25,800,000,000 during the three months ended yesterday, according to M.A. Schapiro Co., bank stock specialists. This figure was down $1,000,000,000 from the banks daily average holding of such deposits during all of 1959.
New York's trout season opened yesterday, but not very much.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Vice President Nixon has indicated that he has an open mind on a possible approach to Governor Rockefeller as a prospective Vice-Presidential running mate.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- The Government today filed a civil antitrust suit to force the Aluminum Company of America to divest itself of the Rome Cable Corporation.
PARIS, April 1 -- Premier Khrushchev and President de Gaulle got down to serious and very private business today as the Soviet leader neared the end of his twelve-day visit to France.
OTTAWA, April 1 (AP) -- The Government today authorized the export of 6,529,000,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas to the United States.
WHITE PLAINS, April 1 -- An audience of 350 adults in the County Center here today was told of a new language parents should learn in the fight against children's use of narcotics.
PARIS, April 1 -- France moved a sizable step closer today to having a compact operational nuclear weapon with the successful explosion of her second atomic bomb.
Delay in reaching a settlement in the lengthy strike of about 18,000 shipyard workers against the eight East Coast yards of the Bethlehem Steel Company was indicated here yesterday.

ZOMBA, Nyasaland, April 1 (UPI) -- Dr. Hastings K. Banda, leader of the Nyasaland African National Congress, was released today after more than a year's detention in Southern Rhodesia as a subversive. He was flown here.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- Eight Roman Catholic hospitals today accused the Philadelphia Blue Cross of "benevolent tyranny." They made the charge in a statement following the midnight withdrawal of the hospitals from Blue Cross.
The American Bible Society has called upon Protestants over the nation to join in "a mass reading" of the Resurrection story at sunrise on Easter Sunday, April 17.

A SPLASH of color is a welcome note on virtually any informal dining table. Bound to enliven a luncheon or dinner are Gimbels' new vinyl mats, which are attractively embossed with a washable "homespun weave and backed with foam rubber.

Arthur T. Roth, a "country" banker from Long Island with $669,585,178 in assets, wants to keep it that way. Mr. Roth, who heads the multimillion dollar Franklin National Bank of Long Island, Franklin Square, was the leading opponent of branching privileges for the New York City banks in his territory.
The American Merchant Marine Library Association is appealing for contributions of books, magazines and money to support its "Public Library of the High Seas."

ST. LOUIS, April 1 -- The need for providing social, recreational, religious and educational services to service men and their dependents as a family unit on military installations was emphasized today by the head of the National Jewish Welfare Board.
Curtis High, the runner-up the past two years in Public Schools Athletic League baseball competition, probably will be the team to watch in this year's title race.

March sales in the eight major New York department stores and their metropolitan branches, helped by an added selling day, rose 2.5 per cent above the comparable 1959 level, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Managed Funds, Inc., of St. Louis, a $62,000,000 mutual fund, took preliminary steps today to restore Itself to the good graces of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Events today: "Simon Boccanegra" at 2 P.M. and "Madama Butterfly" at 8, Metropolitan Opera; Ma Si-Hon, violinist, and Tung Kwong-Kwong, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 2:30; Anna Maria Fritz, soprano, Town Hall, 5:30; Hadassah Sahr, pianist.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A news item in The Times of march 19 prompts me to write on a subject less profound than is usually published in your newspaper. I refer to the article regarding the 'importing" of British secretaries because they are believed to be more efficient and their accents are considered chic.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Is it possible that your editorial "Limits on Contingent Fees" in your issue of March 23 was written without an appreciation of all that is involved in subjecting lawyers as a professional group to fee prescription by the judiciary before whom they practice?

Mayor Wagner's executive budget for the fiscal year 1960-61 proposes an operational expenditure of $2,338,857,547, an increase of $160,266,357 over the present year. The Mayor's budget-making task was made easier by the unexpectedly large increase in state aid negotiated by Governor Rockefeller, for which the Mayor's present message gives only grudging thanks.
PRESTON, Cuba, March 25 -- The sugar harvest is at its height here on the north coast of Oriente Province and two big mills of the United Fruit Company are operating around the clock.
LONDON, April 1 -- Industrial shares showed a definite improvement in the stock market here today. Selling flattened and the increase in buying was sufficient to raise prices on a wide front.

An antibiotic discovered twenty years ago but ignored here until recently because of its high toxicity has been used effectively against several types of cancer, medical scientists reported yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 1 (AP) -- Bill Alley of Kansas threw the javelin 252 feet 11 1/2 inches today in the highlight of preliminaries in the Texas Relays. Favored Kansas advanced eleven qualifiers to eight events.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan charged today that "certain interests" were trying to block any attempt to follow up the investigations of the Senate rackets committee.

A process of collision, fragmentation and reconstitution, occurring as many as 4,500,000,000 years ago, may have formed meteorites and even some of the planets of our solar system, Dr. Harold C. Urey said yesterday.

The following table shows executive budget recommendations for the various city department for 1960-61, as submitted by Mayor Wagner to the Board of Estimate and the City Council. It gives a comparison between the budget for 1959-60, as modified to March 15, 1960, and the executive budget for 1960-61.
A disorderly conduct charge was dismissed in Long Island City Magistrate's Court yesterday against a man who allegedly told an airline ticket clerk that his luggage contained a bomb.

OXFORD:contributed to the education of Julian Starke. He was not enrolled in any of the colleges. But it was there he learned some of the amenities of street paving, there he faced an unfriendly magistrate, in court, there he lost an attractive, intellectual and slightly wayward girl.
ROANOKE, Va., April 1 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge Roby C. Thompson ruled today that seventeen Negroes must be admitted to an all-white high school in Pulaski, Va.
Aggressive trade and commission house buying raised potato futures prices yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Volume was strong at 3,739 carlots of 50,000 pounds each.
GREENSBORO, N.C. April 1 -- Negroes resumed their sitdown strikes in two chain stores here today, ending a cooling-off period in the city where the lunch-counter demonstrations began Feb. 1.

Jun Tsei Tai, Chinese antique dealer, has purchased for investment the five-story town house with elevator at 18 East Sixty-seventh Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. The seller was Alice Stursberg. Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., was the broker.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 -- The Yankees are compiling a record in the Grapefruit Belt that would sour anybody's grapefruit. They also are souring Manager Casey Stengel's disposition.

THE first performance this season of George Balanchine's "Gounod Symphony" by the New York City Ballet last night at the City Center may well have been the best performance this lovely work has yet received.
The Governors of New Jersey and Connecticut criticized yesterday the defeat by the New York Legislature of income tax relief for nonresidents.
BALBOA, C.Z., April 1 -- For the first time since the Panama Canal was cut, 1,000 sea-going ships were lifted from ocean to ocean in one month.
The constitutionality of the city's Fair Housing Practices Law was upheld yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer.

A candidate's religion is relevant to a voter's decision, but only so far as it bears on relevant political issues, the Fair Campaign Practices Committee declared in a statement made public here yesterday.
The corporation that owns a West Side tenement where two children were recently bitten by rats was dissolved in Supreme Court yesterday.

Warfare, the Bellehurst Stable colt that had been regarded as the standout for the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes, has suffered an ankle injury and will not participate in any of those triple-crown events.

Robert Youngson is not a filmmaker to rest on his laurels, past or present. At the moment, critical laurels are crowning the small Sixty-eighth Street Play house on Third Avenue, where last Wednesday Mr. Youngson's "When Comedy Was King" topped the forty-five-year-old theatre's record for opening-day grosses.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : May I request a little more of your valuable space to answer the letter and accusations of Governor Munoz Marin published March 18.

HAVANA, April 1 -- Cuba announced last night a far-reaching trade pact with Poland. Cuba will receive industrial plants and equipment, ships, planes and helicopters on credit and in exchange for goods.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- In an afternoon of angry personal quarreling, the Senate killed the Kefauver amendment to the civil-rights bill today. The vote was 69 to 22.

The Government attempted to show yesterday that, even though Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. made errors and duplications of more than $11,000 in computing his wife's gross income for 1951, he still had understated her net income by $8,260.
Mayor Wagner submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday a record executive expense budget of $2,338,857,547 for the fiscal year starting July 1.

"She was a woman that used to play the stock market very big," said an East Bronx jeweler, Boris Rubinstein, on Prospect Avenue yesterday. "Everybody used to say 'Get on to her, she's got plenty of money.'"

THE man chiefly responsible for scuttling much of Governor Rockefeller's legislative program in the Legislature just ended is one of the most powerful leaders, not of the opposition, but of the Governor's own Republican party.

The career of Hirsch Jacobs reached a pinnacle yesterday, a week short of his fifty-sixth birthday. The New York-born trainer became the first of his calling whose horses have won 3,000 races when Willie Shoemaker brought home Blue Waters by three lengths in the second race at Aqueduct.
Unusual and sometimes amusing situations were encountered by enumerators as they started to collect advance census report forms in the nation yesterday.

AN old wagon wheel makes a delightful patterned herb garden. Simply choose a sunny spot, for most herbs need plenty of sun, and lay the wheel flat on the ground for a ready-made geometric bed. Each space between spokes is planted with a contrasting herb.

FASHIONS in iris are changing each year. New varieties supplant the old as hybridizers develop new colon, forms and even types. Current interest centers chiefly on a new group of median iris, and new flower forms and colors in the popular tall bearded iris.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The House Ways and Means Committee is now writing the fourth consecutive biennial bill to liberalize the Social Security laws. This time, however, it seems that at least a sizeable and highly vocal segment of the country's 15,500,000 citizens over 65 years of age are unwilling to settle for the usual election-year fare of higher pensions, broader coverage and the like.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 2 -- The twenty-seventh annual bridge sponsored by the Westchester Alumnae of Gamma Phi Beta will be held here at the Siwanoy Country Club on Thursday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 2 -- Navy's crew made the debut of Coach Lou Lindsey a successful one today, opening its season with a four-length victory over George Washington University.

Harland (Swede) Svare, 29-year-old linebacker, was appointed defensive coach of the New York Giants of the National Football League yesterday.

THE COLLECTED STORIES. Isaac Babel. (Meridian. $1.55.) Isaac Babel (1894-1939?) was called by Maxim Gorky the most gifted Russian prose writer of the post-Revolutionary period. This collection of his brief vignettes of life among the Odessa Jews during the years of revolution and civil war gives English-speaking readers their first chance for a full look at the work of a master of subtle irony and pathos.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI) -- A bill intended to close the door on alleged influence peddling by retired generals and admirals came under attack by its sponsor today as likely to open the door wider than ever.

Surgeon-novelist Frank G. Slaughter will mount a dais an hour later at Live Oak, Fla. Spring selling at the retail level is picking up steam. The stimulating factors include some improvement in the weather and a few balmy days. They tend to remind consumers that spring wardrobe replenishment and home refurbishings are in order.

Mayor Wagner revised yesterday the new program of pension benefits and pay rises for city employes to provide that no city worker will get a salary improvement of less than $200 a year or its equivalent.

TO THE BOATING EDITOR: I am planning a cruise through the Trent-Severn canal system this summer, but as yet have been unable to determine the height above mean water level of the lowest fixed bridge on this waterway.
Because of the popularity of the Monet exhibition, the Museum of Modern Art will remain open on Thursday nights until 10 P.M. The show, drawing record crowds, closes on May 15.

THE Conrad revival has been going on steadily now for well over ten years. Conrad's stature as one of the three or four greatest of modern English novelists and as one of the great novelists of all time seems assured.

"The Compleat Gentleman," "The Way to Wealth," and the handbook of the Boy Scouts of America. A CONSERVATIONIST study made not long ago calculated that more than 100 kinds of mammals and a similar number of birds have become extinct because of man since the time of Christ. The tempo of extinction has been increasing in recent times, and in the present century mammal species have been disappearing at a rate of about one a year.
ROME, April 2 -- Pope John XXIII said today that he was looking forward to the Olympic Games, which will be held in Rome this summer.

One of New York's best-known construction companies last week joined the growing list of realty, concerns that are selling securities to the public. Nixon.

The three-story, office and commercial building at 577 Ninth Avenue, adjoining the southwest corner of Forty-second Street has been sold by David Green, realty operator, to an investing client of Robert P. Sheldon, Inc., the broker in the deal.
Twenty persons aboard a passenger train that had just arrived in Pennsylvania Station from Florida were injured yesterday when the train was jolted severely as it was being coupled to a locomotive.

Week Ended April 1, 1860 Firmness for the British pound sterling and a softer undertone for the Canadian dollar marked the foreign exchange trading for the past week. Business transacted was fairly heavy at times.
OTTAWA, April 3 (Canadian Press) -- Finance Minister Donald Fleming has given provinces and municipalities a strong warning about borrowing in the United States bond market.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- A man of action is the Rev. John McDonald, Roman Catholic priest from Hawaii, who was determined to hear what went on at the White House Conference on Children and Youth.
SMITHTOWN, L.I., April 3 -- Three girls and an aunt died early today when fire destroyed a house in Smithtown.

The New York State Income Tax Bureau may have to spend some of its money training extra mail-room personnel for its Albany headquarters if taxpayers from other districts persist in mailing their returns there.
HAVANA, April 3 -- It was a hot, quiet Sunday in Havana Even the revolution seemed to be on a holiday.

Communist China's two internal revolutions, one institutional and the other economic, are to be pushed ahead rapidly this year. Chief planner Li-Fu-chun's report in Peiping discloses that the once-postponed program to turn the cities into communes, on a par with those in the countryside, is being carried out rapidly. Meanwhile, the target for raising gross industrial and agricultural output has been set at 23 per cent.

The United States Weather Bureau has signed a lease with Rockefeller Center giving the bureau office and roof space for a new midtown weather headquarters at the Radio Corporation of America Building.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, denied today that President Eisenhower and Vice President Nixon had split over a health insurance plan for older persons.

SESTIERE, Italy, April 3 -- Hias Leitner of Austria won the men's slalom, the final event of the Arlberg-Kandahar ski meet, today. Adrien Duvillard of France, who finished fifth, won the combined title, thanks to his convincing victory in the downhill yesterday.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 3 -- Joseph Eder, a 2 year-old competitor from Allentown, Pa., won the $1,000 first Prize in the 500-bird trapshoot at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island range today.

TORONTO, April 1 (Canaidian Press) -- Foundation Company of Canada, Ltd., cleared $787,482 in 1959, compared with $1,786,547 in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Modification of the legal ceiling on interest rates of Government bonds has been moved to the bottom of the legislative agenda in Congress.

Gerosa declared yesterday that he did not believe elected city officials should be given increases in take-home pay by having the City assume part of their contributions to pension systems. Although evidence of winter is still on many campuses, officials of the New England Interscholastic Lacrosse Association plan to start operations next Sunday. They have arranged for a clinic to be held at Williston Academy in Easthampton, Mass.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The average number of days of hospital care required by aged persons is almost three times greater than during their earlier years. THE year 1536 was notable in the reign of Henry VIII for two things. That was the year Anne Boleyn, Henry's second Queen, was beheaded, on a low platform in the yard of the Tower of London. Henry had had numerous others executed before, but his murder of his own wife was so peculiarly horrible that it dramatized as nothing else had that England's only law was the will of her monstrous sovereign.
