The five-story walk-up apartment house at 526 West 160th Street has toted sold by Geisinger Germain, real estate operators, to a client of William Stock, lawyer. The deal, which was negotiated by Sheldon Greenberg, broker, was for cash above mortgages totaling $43,000.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said tonight he was thinking of running for the Legislature in his adopted state of Pennsylvania.
SYRACUSE, April 4 (AP) -- State investigators questioned several men, including two in the boxing world, about gambling and narcotics links today.

Mac Hodesblatt is a modest man. In twenty years as basketball coach at Thomas Jefferson High in Brooklyn he never had a losing team. He guided the Jeffs to eighteen Public Schools Athletic League play-offs and to one city championship.
The Federal Government threatened yesterday to withdraw about $50,000,000 from the city's housing program unless definite plans were produced promptly for 3,050 lowrent dwelling units.

ONE of the chief lures of an antiques show is its open house atmosphere. "Poking around" is encouraged; dealers are relaxed and seldom offer to help unless they are asked, a state of affairs that most potential customers find ideal.

THE New York Philharmonic's pension fund concerts are always something special. They have to be to fill Carnegie Hall at the prices charged. Last night's was no exception. It presented Renata Tebaldi, singing no fewer than six arias with the orchestra.

At Geneva yesterday Soviet delegate Zorin rejected the Western plan for a balanced and controlled step-by-step approach to general disarrnament. He also ruled but any progress at the conference unless the West first accepts as a basis of negotiation Premier Khrushchev's plan for total disarmament in four years -- this to be accomplished prior to effective controls and without any international police to keep the peace.
Sir Tsibu Darku, chairman of the Ghana Cocoa Marketing Board, asked cocoa, merchants yesterday to help his country market a record crop at a fair price level.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) -- The Chief of the Strategic Air Command appealed to Congress today for $571,000,000, nearly seven times what President Eisenhower has proposed, as a down payment on a continuous airborne alert.
PARIS, April 4 -- The list of United States, Canadian and European products allowed to enter France free of restrictions will be lengthened tomorrow.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 4 -- William A.M. Burden, United States Ambassador to Belgium, found a warm feeling toward the United States in the Belgian Congo during a three-week tour of the colony, which is to become independent June 30.

Counsel for Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. contended yesterday in Federal Court that the grand jury that indicted him in 1958 on charges of income-tax evasion did not have before it the evidence on which the Government is now attempting to prove his guilt.
HAVANA, April 4 -- Cuba will begin a labor census April 18. It is expected to bring workers, employers, the self-employed and unemployed under control of the Government.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Eisenhower tonight scored his Democratic defense critics as "ignorant" and "blind."
Competition for the Vanderbilt Cup, one of the oldest and most famous of automobile racing trophies, will be revived.
An unemployed garage mechanic who had told the police that he had witnessed the lover's lane shotgun slaying of an 18-year-old girl in Brooklyn on March 27 was charged with the murder yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The United States will share the weather pictures obtained from Tiros I and future meteorological satellites with the rest of the world, a space agency official told Congress today.

The American Association for the Advancement of Science is preparing to "move into all the modes of mass communication" in an effort to serve as "translator" between scientists and the American public.
2,000 persons fled their homes in the bottomlands of Illinois and Missouri as the river threatened more breaks in a fifty-mile stretch from Keokuk, Iowa, south to Louisiana, Mo.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, April 5 -- The movie industry opened its most important ballot box last night and learned that it had chosen "Ben-Hur" as its best film of 1959 and had given to this Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer picture more awards than any movie has ever received.

GENEVA, April 4 -- The Soviet Union refused point blank today to join in an agreement to prohibit the launching into orbit of satellites carrying nuclear bombs unless the United States agreed to liquidate its military bases abroad.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The House of Representatives passed today a bill to prohibit most bank mergers without prior approval from one of the Federal banking agencies.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Senate killed today the Administration's proposal for Federal grants to school districts undertaking desegregation programs. The vote was 61 to 30.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The month-long drop in short-term Treasury bill rates nearly halted this week, but the decline in rates on six-month bills resumed. The Treasury disclosed tonight that $1,100,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills sold today at an average discount rate of 2.731 per cent, only slightly below the 2.792 per cent of last week.

The Metropolitan Opera, the Chicago Lyric Opera and the San Francisco Opera are planning to form an association in an effort to cut coats share artists and repertory and promote a more favorable reception in this country for opera.

A Profession Grows Up A new profession has teen growing to maturity under our noses. It la social work. Ones thought of as basket-on-the-arm assistance to the poor, it now is a discipline, scientific in method and artful in manner, that takes remedial action on problems in several areas of society.
ALBANY, April 4 -- Governor Rockefeller's office announced today the creation of a new state council on health and mental hygiene.

The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation and its subsidiaries experienced in 1959 its "most progressive year since it began operations in 1948," W.M. Elmer, president, told stockholders in the annual report mailed yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 4 -- What's wrong with the Yankees?

PARIS, April 4 -- Premier Michel Debre confirmed tonight that the recent talks between President de Gaulle and Soviet Premier Khrushchev had been limited to "posing the problems" rather than finding solutions.
MOSCOW, April 4 -- Premier Khrushchev said today that he would do his best to negotiate a settlement on Germany "on grounds that can be acceptable to the Western powers."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa does not favor the proposal made by J. Anthony Panuch that a uniform policy of tax exemption be established to stimulate the construction of moderate rental housing.

Cottonseed oil futures rose yesterday in an active market on the New York Produce Exchange. Prices closed unchanged to 8 points (hundreds of a cent a pound) up. A total of 400 tank cars, 60,000 pounds to a car, changed hands, the fifth highest volume of the year.
CHICAGO, April 4 -- Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today that failure to resolve the division of Germany "will inevitably result in jeopardizing the peace of the world."

TRENTON, April 4 -- A comprehensive rail commuter plan was offered today to the Governor and Legislature. It is designed to restore service in the metropolitan area to a profitable basis until a long-range solution can be arranged.

It is no exaggeration to say that acquisition of woods, streams and open spaces for park and recreational purposes is one of the most urgent problems now facing town and county governments adjacent to New York City -- as it is of suburban authorities in the vicinity of every expanding metropolis throughout the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The nation's railroads asked a Federal court today to limit the mandatory scope of their bargaining with non-operating employes.
Methods of collecting and analyzing statistics to give a longer view into the business future have reportedly been developed by the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
A man's right to evict his estranged wife from their home was upheld yesterday in the State Supreme Court. The case involved a wife who had overstayed a time limit she had agreed to.
BOSTON, April 4 (AP) -- Overwhelming approval of a plan to consolidate was announced today by the Unitarian and Universalist Churches, after a count in a plebiscite completed March 31.
Mayor Wagner and two other members of the Board of Estimate backed away yesterday from accepting for themselves planned pension benefits raising their take-home pay.

The International Basic Economy Corporation (IBEC), New York financing, investment and development concern with world-wide interests, had record sales and earnings in 1959, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 4 -- Squads of policemen swinging clubs charged demonstrators today as widespread violence was renewed in South Africa.
TRENTON, April 4 -- The State Supreme Court upheld today, by a vote of 4 to 2, the constitutionality of New Jersey's 1959 law restricting sales on Sunday.
Under the leadership of a handful of electronics issues, stocks worked a bit higher yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) A member of the Teamsters' Union Board of Monitors told Federal Judge F. Dickinson Letts today that be was unable and unwilling to serve on the panel any longer.
One of every six city pupils goes to school on curtailed or special schedules because of overcrowding, the Board of Education reported last night.

Ornette Coleman, an alto saxophonist who has roused more controversy in the jazz world than any musician since Charlie Parker, gave his first full concert in New York last night at the Circle in the Square. He appeared with his quartet -- Don Cherry, trumpet; Charlie Haden, bass, and Billy Higgins, drums.

ROME, April 4 -- The new Premier, Fernando Tambroni, presented his "business Government" to Parliament today and asked for a vote of confidence. His Government, composed only of Christian Democrats, lacks a majority in both houses.

A modest bit of lobbying aimed at gaining the sympathies of the seventy-five members of the Anierican Bowling Congress' executive committee has begun in Toledo. Groups from three cities are at work to get the 1965 A.B.C. tournament placed in their home towns.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) -- A member of the House Commerce Committee called today for an investigation of unofficial contacts between a lawyer and members of the Federal Power Commission in a recent gas case.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 4 -- Since 1955 the Soviet Union has been importing consistently larger amounts of goods from mainland China than she exports to that country. By the end of 1958, the United Nations yearbook of trade statistics showed on its publication today, the unfavorable balance had reached $247,250,000 at the official rate of exchange.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 8 points (40 cents a bale) up yesterday.

The six-story apartment building at 1230 Woodycrest Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Jacob Tutnauer to a client of Robert Jaul, lawyer. The sale, which was for cash over mortgages totaling $202,000, was negotiated by Brass Rubin Associates, brokers.

NEW DELHI, India, April 4 -- Communist China was reported today to have laid claim to Mount Everest, the highest mountain in the world. The 29,028-foot peak has traditionally been accepted as straddling the Nepalese-Tibetan border.
The John Burroughs Medal for 1960 was presented last night to John Kieran in recognition of his recent book, "A Natural History of New York City."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 5 -- Sentiment appeared to be growing among South Africans today for a softening of their country's harsh racial policies. Violence brought on by these policies continued.
The State Department is considering waiving the provision in the Cargo Preference Act that 50 per cent of foreign-aid materials be carried in American-flag vessels.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 5 -- Hunger forced thousands of leaderless Africans today to abandon their paralyzing strike against South Africa's apartheid policy of racial segregation.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Alberto Lleras Camargo of Colombia, who arrived today for a thirteen-day state visit, received a warm welcome from President Eisenhower as "one who reveres those great values of freedom and human dignity."
WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- The newly formed American Football League will seek an injunction against the National Football League if the Justice Department does not act.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 5 -- Israel began pressing the Soviet Union today for a meeting between Premier David Ben-Gurion and Premier Khrushchev.

New York City banks charged business borrowers slightly lower average interest on shortterm loans in the first half of March than in the first half of December, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

An offering to the public of $25,000,000 of thirty-year 4 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds of Carolina Power Light Company is being made by investment bankers managed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. Priced at 100.393, the bonds will yield 4.85 per cent to maturity.

This is a frequently read sign on almost any highway in the United States. Seldom, however, does a motorist stop or even slow down to see what the marker has to say. Perhaps he hasn't the time or he just isn't interested in history.

ATLANTA, April 5 (UPI) -- Local biracial committees seeking solutions to lunch-counter sitdowns and other anti-segregation demonstrations in the South have found opinion sharply divided, a survey showed today.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities invited a court decision today on its authority to investigate alleged Communist activities outside the mainland of the United States.
The Dutch are still making voyages of discovery to these shores, but with a new kind of explorer.
The Arabian-American Oil Company was accused yesterday of using questionnaires "that would make the Nuremberg laws look like the Boy Scout Manual" to weed out Jews from among employment applicants.

The nation's economy apfeared to move "sideward" in March, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday in its latest monthly review. The side-step came after a February in which some business indicators registered gains, some slight declines.
The board of the Metropolitan Opera has voted that it would be pleased to have the New York City Center of Music and Drama as a constituent member of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors confessed today that automobile finance contracts confused him.

GREAT NECK, L.I. April 5 -- Adlai E. Stevenson was nominated as the Democratic Presidential candidate today at a teen-age political convention.
LONDON, April 5 -- Harold Wilson taunted the Conservative members of the House of Commons today by asserting they lacked enthusiasm for the 1960-61 budget.
FREEHOLD, N. J., April 5 -- Hot music and cool shorts came to a parting of the ways today for taverns in Belmar, N. J.
GALVESTON, Tex., April 5 -- Lunch counters were voluntarily integrated today in Galveston. Negroes started eating Beside whites without incident.

No manager in baseball, it would seem, has greater respect for old age than Senor Alfonso Ramon Lopez. The Happy Hidalgo now has the finest collection of antiques in the baseball business. He added another to his White Sox gallery the other day with a slick trade that brought him Roy Sievers from the Washington Senators.

Accommodation of two supposed enemies -- mutual funds and insurance -- moved a step nearer yesterday with the announcement that the Channing Corporation had acquired a majority interest in the Wolverine-Federal Insurance Companies of Battle Creek, Mich.

The outstanding characteristic of Mayor Wagner's annual messages and reports to the City Council has been the disarming modesty of his claims to success in meeting the city's problems. "In government, few goals are ever fully achieved," said the Mayor yesterday. Furthermore, he added: "That we have made and will continue to make errors, I do not dispute * * * We cannot boast; neither need we be pessimistic.
NEW JERSEY'S trout season will open at 8 A.M. Saturday. The state wants everybody to know that the trout, at least. will be present.
MILWAUKEE, April 6 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts defeated Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota in yesterday's Wisconsin Democratic Presidential primary.

The office of State Controller Arthur Levitt announced yesterday the terms of a short-term borrowing of $150,000,000 to help finance a payment on April 15 of $295,000,000 in state aid funds to local school districts.

HOLLYWOOD continues to encounter difficulty in honoring itself. Save for Tony Randall's intensively impromptu prologue from the Brown Derby restaurant, the telecast of Monday evening's distribution of the Oscars was a far tidier affair than a year ago.

Four irate mothers paid an unexpetced visit to a school principal yesterday and insisted upon inspecting Public School 135, at First Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street. Harsh words resulted, Hut the mothers finally were allowed to inspect the school.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Eisenhower and Republican Congressional leaders moved a step toward agreement today on a subsidized program of voluntary health insurance for the aged.
MIAMI, April 5 (AP) -- Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, dictator of the Dominican Republic, says the West has already suffered a rout at the hands of communism in the Caribbean.

NORWALK, Conn., April 5 -- A group of seventeen property owners in the Shorehaven area is seeking injunctions to stop the Msgr. Finn Council, Knights of Columbus, from using a building the organization bought on Shorehaven Road.

Negotiations for new union contracts in the aircraft and missile industry moved into the crucial stage on the West Coast yesterday after the International Association of Machinists had signed a new wage agreement with the Republic Aviation Corporation on Long Island.

THE big excitement of last night's Philadelphia Orchestra concert, conducted by Eugene Ormandy, came after the intermission. That was when Rudolf Serkin walked on stage, with his nervous stride and his nervous smile, and sat down to play the Brahms Second Piano Concerto.
The Crosby family, John and Michael (no relatives of the Hollywood Crosbys, Bing and sons), figures prominently in the Broadway theatrical news today.

POLAND'S past is documented in its arts and crafts. Judging from the brilliant display of weaving, woodwork, painted glass, basketry and ceramics that goes on view today in Fifty-seventh Street's newest establishment, there is much to be learned of this nation, that goes beyond the headlines and far back into history.

"A Night in Old San Juan" is the theme of the ninety-first anniversary ball for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital. It will be held in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East on May 6 with Mayor Wagner as honorary chairman.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Paul M. Butler, national chairman of the Democratic Party, named fourteen National Committee members today to an arrangements committee for the party's July convention.

SALISBURY, Md., April 5 (UPI) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, carried his Presidential campaign into Maryland tonight. He made another demand for the elimination of, "monumental waste" in the Federal Government.

The oil industry's present problems arise from economies as well as from legislation and Government regulations, according to Eugene Holman, chairman, and M.J. Rathbone, president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

THE Musical Art Quartet presented a program of chamber music last night at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young- Women's Hebrew Association.
Two subjects of great importance to military personnel, but of even broader concern to the social fabric of the nation are before Congress this week.

The General Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday what it described as the first major management realignment in the company's forty-five-year history. The executive changes centered around members of the controlling O'Neil family.

General Time The General Time Corporation, clock, and watch manufacturer, had net earnings of $205,751, or 41 cents each on 501,221 shares outstanding, in the twelve weeks ended on March 19, Donald J. Hawthorne, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday.

LONDON, April 5 -- Prime Minister Macmillan declared today that the "tragic situation" in South Africa was "a source of deep regret" to him. But he cautioned against any action that might produce a crisis in the British Commonwealth.

TRENTON, April 5 -- Legislators and railroad executives expressed qualified approval today of the latest plan to alleviate the commuter rail problem in the metropolitan area. Commuters, for the most part, were cautious in their comment.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Tiros I satellite is working so well that the space agency is worried that it may unintentionally have placed a blurry-eyed spy in the sky.

YESTERDAY (April 5, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Saw Congressional leaders; welcomed the Colombian President, Dr. Alberto Lieras Camargo, to the United States and gave a dinner for him and his wife at the White House.

Charles de Gaulle has a sense of history. The deep emotion he showed yesterday morning, when the Queen of England greeted him in London and 100,000 Britons cheered as he drove to Buckingham Palace, must have been compounded of many memories. Surely none could have been more vivid than that of the day twenty years earlier -- June 17, 1940, it was -- when he flew from Bordeaux, one Frenchman, after the fall of France.
An incandescent electric light bulb, said to be the first that is shatter-proof -- has been developed by the Duro-Test Corporation.

The market for prime-risk debt securities for the most part marked time yesterday, waiting for the outcome of the Treasury's $2,500,000,000 cash borrowing. The Treasury is offering 4 per cent notes due in two years and one month and 4 1/4 per cent bonds due in twenty-five years and callable in fifteen years.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad yesterday granted Alfred E. Perlman a seven-year contract as president and chief executive officer of the road.
New York City is entitled to and intends to get a far greater degree of home rule than it has, Mayor Wagner told the City Council yesterday.

IF, as they say, you can tell a man by his anger, then Philip Evergood's restrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum tells a great deal. For Mr. Evergood has followed an undeviating course of responding to various social evils with indignation.

WITH typical foresight, one of his colleagues at Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday. Prof. Archibald Cox considered the likelihood that he would be called upon to help arbitrate a railroad wage dispute.

BONN, Germany, April 5 -- Chancellor Adenauer and Mayor Willy Brandt agreed today that the decision whether to hold a plebiscite in West Berlin before the East-West summit conference next month must be left to the city government.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The United States gold stock declined by only $48,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, final Treasury figures for the quarter revealed today. The gold stock at the end of March was $19,408,000,000.

The continuing reports that natives in Capetown are being forced back to work by police use of "clubs, whips and guns" are not only shocking in themselves but indicative of one of the basic weaknesses in South Africa's hopeless program of apartheid.
NEWARK, April 5 -- The battle over the constitutionality of New Jersey's Sunday sales ban MI certain items will be pressed in Federal Court.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Commodity futures moved in narrow ranges in dull and featureless trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, sugar, copper, rubber and zinc rose; potatoes and hides declined, and price movements for cottonseed oil, wool, coffee and lead were mixed.
MILWAUKEE, April 5 -- Religion played a major role in Senator John F. Kennedy's victory in the Wisconsin Presidential primary, returns indicated tonight.
MOSCOW, April 5 -- The Soviet Union loosed a broadside of charges today against West Germany's Minister for Refugees, Dr. Theodor Oberlaender. The purpose was to paint him as a war criminal.

Six New York State District Attorneys warned here yesterday that recent judicial decisions restricting the use of wiretapping by prosecutors posed an immediate and serious threat to law enforcement in the state.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 5 -- Hal Frost, a 6-year-old bay horse whose failure to show anything in his last outing resulted in the suspension of his trainer-driver, Marcel Dostie, won the Class A-1 pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- Rising rivers smashed holes in dikes and threatened new breaks in the Midwestern flood zone today.
The movement in the City Council to block the conversion of Lexington and Third Avenues to one-way traffic on May 15 gained impetus yesterday.
The $2,200,000 Adele Lehman Hall-Wollman Library at Barnard College, which developed from, dream to reality in four years, was dedicated yesterday.

WEST HAVEN, Conn., April 5 (AP) -- Armstrong Rubber Company called today a special meeting of stockholders to vote on a proposal to achieve full ownership of the company's affiliate, Armstrong Tire and Rubber Company, Natchez, Miss.
United States Olympic team aspirants are finding it tough to make the grade except in the sprints, hurdles and a few field events.

GENEVA, April 5 -- The West rejected today Premier Khrushchev's proposals for complete disarmament as the basis for any disarmament compromise.
CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- The grain futures market withstood fairly general selling most of the time today but weakened late in the session and closed lower for the second successive day.

IT is circus time again. Ringling Bros. and Barnuni Bailey have again taken possession of Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Performances are daily at 2 P.M. and 8:30 P.M. Admission is $2 to $6.50.

The number of persons injured by automobiles here was greater last week than in the same period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. Last week 975 persons were injured, compared with 961 in 1959. This was a rise of fourteen.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES Your rousing editorial "An Attack on Religion" (March 29) which fol lowed John Wicklein's splendid account of those dissident Protestant groups that are earnestly attempt ing to lock Christian faith inside the sanctuary was a much needed breath of fresh air.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Frederick W. Ford, newly appointed chair man of the Federal Communica tiohs Commission, today called upon broadcasters to operate in the public interest "rather than risk the imposition of re strtctive measures."

The difference between preparing New York State income tax returns and Federal returns may be disconcerting to the taxpayer. The Wise-Calli bill, designed to alleviate the situation by bringing the state concept of income more in line with that of the Federal Government, was passed last week and awaits Governor Rockefeller's signature.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana accused Democrats: today of sponsoring what he called budget-busting political payola legislation "in an effort to buy votes at the next election"
THE New York City Ballet began its second week at the City Center last night.

Ogden Corporation, which owns 99 9/10 per cent of Teleregister Corporation stock, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday of its plan to spin off the electronic data processing concern.
The cotton futures market opened unchanged to 2 points up and closed 6 points off to 6 up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
CHICAGO, April 5 -- An arbitration hearing on the wage dispute between the nation's railroads and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers began here today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 5 -- Scientists from both sides of the Iron Curtain amicably discussed here today one of the most highly technical problems in modern construction -- the capacity of steel to withstand extreme heat and stress in buildings, naval vessels and other structures.
Federal Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan dismissed yesterday the third count of a three-count Federal indictment charging Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. with income-tax evasion.

In the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, the Lerner Stores Corporation had record sales and the highest earnings in eleven yearsj Harold M. Lane, president, reported in the annual statement released for publication today.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 5 (AP) -- "Santa Maria!" exclaimed Angel Miguel of Spain. "Six hundred pesetas for a caddie -- I could hire a bag boy for a month with that in Madrid."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 -- A touching epilogue to last night's annual drama of the Oscar awards developed here early this morning, hours after the regular show had ended.

Easy Prey returned to the races after a long vacation and scored an easy victory in the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old from the High Tide Stable made his first start since August in the Forest Park Purse and the majority of the 18,225 fans didn't give him much of a chance.

A high school mathematics teacher suspended from the city school system on charges of lying about past membership in the Communist party was described by his principal and department head yesterday as an excellent teacher.
DETROIT, April 5 -- Passenger car sales showed a sharp upturn in late March with some manufacturers reporting new records.

Brazil, one of the leading soccer nations of the world, has entered the new International Soccer League, which will bring professional big-league competition in this oldest of all football games to New York this year.

Fisher Brothers, builders, announced yesterday they had bought the ten-story store and apartment building at 786-87 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Sixtieth Street, and the adjoining six-story store, office and showroom building at 785 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) -- The House Armed Services Committee, in a surprise move, strengthened today its bill aimed at halting the improper use of influence by retired military officers who work for defense contractors.

LONDON, April 5 -- Twenty years ago Charles de Gaulle fled to London, a little-known general of a discredited army and a beaten country. He returned today as President of France to be welcomed by Queen Elizabeth II and cheered by her subjects.

ALFRED DUGGAN'S first historical novel, "Knight With Armor," was published in England in 1950. Today "The Cunning of the Dove," his tenth, is published in this country. Mr. Duggan also has written two biographies and a work of history. Thirteen books in ten years! It is too many, even for as brilliant a writer as Mr. Duggan, who is one of the most accomplished living masters of historical fiction.

If a woman is ever gauche enough to ask a man how her make-up looks, she almost de serves the normal reply: "You've got too much on." Men like make-up to make, women look younger and beautiful, but they do not like it to be apparent unless they are taking a ballet dancer or a model out to dinner and she has not had time to wash her face.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : In his amusing column on the closing of the current session of the Legislature your Albany correspondent Douglas Dales charitably omitted the most significant reason for the shameful proceedings by which our representatives annually disgrace themselves.

Otis Carney's second novel, "Yesterday's Hero" (Houghton Mifflin), received the $1,000 award of the Friends of American Writers, a Chicago women's organization. The award is made annually for a book published in the previous calendar year and written fay a native or resident of the Midwest, or a book with a Midwest locale.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 5 -- Two American scientists were named here today to be recipients of the 1959 Atoms for Peace Award and two to be recipients of the 1960 award.
IN decorating, as in most areas of life, the pendulum of attitudes and preferences swings slowly, but constantly, from or extreme to the other.
BONN, Germany, April 5 -- A threatened economic split of Western Europe July 1 was postponed today by the action of the West German Government.
With the encouragement of March figures on retail automobile sales and with a number of earnings estimates circulating in Wall Stree, motor shares led the stock market upward yesterday.
The general traffic manager of a major oil company proposed yesterday that rail, highway, water and air transport be integrated under corporate managements.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- A new complaint filed in Federal Court today said that James R. Hoffa's act in permitting a convicted perjurer to remain in union office was sufficient ground for removing Mr. Hoffa as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Readers of this newspaper have now had a fresh, balanced and factual description of the Dominican dictatorship in the three articles by Edward C. Burks, the last of which is published today. This is a case where nothing could be more damning than straightforward facts.
City officials were criticized from the bench again yesterday for assigning only one lawyer to handle a large volume of cases against landlords in three courtrooms.
With spring practice in progress or about to start at most institutions that conduct it, football talk is beginning to fill the air.

The Government-owned Panama Line, operated by the Panama Canal Company, is planning an extended life for its two ships.

PARIS. As a result of Khrushchev's recent conversations with Western leaders, above all his colloquy with de Gaulle, we know what the shrewd little Soviet leader wants from next month's summit conference. He is not likely to get it.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 5 -- Whatever Casey Stengel told his players when he lectured them for more than an hour yesterday, it had a lasting effect. At least, it lasted for twenty-four hours.
LONDON, April 5 -- The stock market here maintained its firm undertone today, and yesterday's budget appeared to have little immediate effect on trading and price movements.
American-style installment financing will be extended to the United Kingdom and West Germany by the C.I.T. Financial Corporation and the American Express Company.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A subcommittee of the House of Representatives has criticized tie Department of State for alleged errors and waste.

The signs in the Dominican Republic point to further attempts to overthrow Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina. If the dictator is forced out, many long-suppressed forces will scramble for power.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 5 -- The Netherlands Government will set up in Netherlands New Guinea in the next year a council designed as "a training ground in which the members can learn the tricks of the political trade."

Higher academic requirements, which could lead to the dropping of as many as 8 or 10 per cent of Queens College students, will go into effect at the college next Feb. 1. The school has 4,300 undergradutes.

Bobby Fischer, the three-time chess champion of the United States, yesterday retained second place in the international tournament at Mar del Plata, Argentina, with a brilliant effort in the sixth round against Alberto Foguelman of Argentina.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The House Labor Committee refused today to add an antidiscrimination clause to a bill to permit picketing of construction jobs handled by more than one contractor.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The United States is increasingly outgunned in the international war of the air waves, Voice of America officials said today.

Gamble Benedict, 19-year-old New York heiress, eloped again with her 35-year-old Rumanian suitor, Andre Porumbeanu, and yesterday they applied for a marriage license in Dillon, S.C.
PARIS, April 5 (UPI) -- A 16-year-old boy had his first public fight last night and 2,000 fans had visions of French ring glory to come.

The City Planning Commission approved a program yesterday with which the city hopes to demonstrate that rehabilitation, rather than demolition and replacement, is the best way to make a run-down section of the West Side respectable again.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: The question of franchise for Washington's residents cannot airily be disposed of as the right of franchise for its million inhabitants. Washington is not just another city. It is the headquarters and seat of the Government of the entire United States and all its 170,000,000 inhabitants.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 6 -- South Africa announced today it was reintro ducing the enforcement of laws requiring Africans to carry identity passes. It was this requirement that touched off the current racial violence in the country.
PRESS agents up and down the land are getting heated up again, some of them with serious stuff and others with stuff that they regard as serious.
Fordham defeated New York University, 14 -- 3, at Ohio Field in the Bronx yesterday.

BONN, Germany, April 6 -- The West German Government, target of a months-long Soviet campaign of defamation, hit back today.
The following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

BOSTON, April 6 -- The National Labor Relations Board began today the presentation of pleas for injunctions against the Bethlehem Steel Company and unions representing 8,000 striking shipyard workers in this area.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Guy L. Brown, grand chief engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, testified before a six-man arbitration panel today that wages of locomotive engineers were substandard when compared with rates of pay in other industries.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 off to 25 points up yesterday. The 25-point rise was a bid price an the new March contract. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- Wind and waves pounded dikes on the Mississippi River today. Officials called for 200 more volunteers and tons of hay and Straw to bolster the levee in the Gregory Landing, Mo., area.
A 51-year-old man confessed early this morning that he had burglarized a midtown messenger service nineteen times since January, the police reported.

A further drop of 2,893,000 barrels in the nation's light fuel oil stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This brought the home heating fuel inventories on last Friday to 75,119,000 barrels, compared with 78,951,000 a year ago.
CLEVELAND, April 6 -- Chemical "siren songs" for luring male insect pests to destruction were among developments revealed by scientists here today.
Senator John F. Kennedy's primary victory in Wisconsin failed yesterday to cause any bandwagon movement for him among Democratic party leaders in New York.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The colloquial meaning of "to badger" is to worry everybody in range, and that describes the results of Tuesday's Presidential preference primary in the geographical subdivisioin commonly referred to as the "Badger State."

NEW DELHI, India, April 6 -- India has protested to Communist China against repeated flights of Chinese planes over India's North East Frontier Agency, V.K. Krishna Menon, Defense Minister, said today.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 6 -- The Governor General, Sir Oliver Goonetilleke, reaffirmed today Ceylon's principle of "strict neutrality and nonalignment with power blocs" when he opened the parliament elected March 19.
A recluse's collection of jewel-studded ornaments brought $1,095,460 at an auction yesterday at the Parke-Benet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Charles A. Hurth, the president of the Southern Association for the past thirteen years, yesterday was named general manager of the New York entry in the new Continental Baseball League. The announcement of Hurth's appointment was made at the same time the club's officers were introduced.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- The Federal Communications Commission appeared today to be as uncertain as broadcasters about the outcome of its recent notice that stations playing free phonograph records must identify the donors on the air.

Under the encouragement of improved automobile sales, stocks yesterday made their best gain since March 16 on the heaviest New York Stock Exchange turnover since March 9. Volume was 3,450,000 shares, against 2,840,000 on Tuesday.

Harry Horwitz and Milton Barkin, realty operators, have sold the property at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifteenth Street to builders represented by Joseph G. Abramson, lawyer. E. Louis Gothelf was the lawyer for the sellers.

The annual report of the New York Central Railroad contains a bouquet for the State of New York and a brickbat for New Jersey.

Dr. Kenneth W. Colegrove testified yesterday that "dark, mysterious forces" had persuaded the president of Long Island University to obtain the resignation last December of Dr. Edward V. Sittler. In 1940 Dr. Sittler took German citizenship and broadcast for Nazi Germany from Berlin until 1945.

BOSTON, April 6 (UPI) -- The New England Council reported generally poor skiing today in New England, except for Vermont where conditions were fair to good. No resorts operated in Massachusetts. The weather forecast was for fair and cold tomorrow, resulting in litthe thawing.

Mrs. Helen Kay, an aged recluse who died in a debriscluttered Bronx apartment last week amid a collection of stocks and securities worth $100,000, was buried yesterday. Only an undertaker and a grave digger were present in the Brooklyn cemetery.

AT sundown next Monday night, members of the Jewish faith the world over will gather in their homes to celebrate one of the oldest holidays on earth. It is the beginning of Passover, a 3,000-year-old festival of thanksgiving and joy.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A savings banker sought special consideration for mortgage loans today in a Senate bill that would set new terms for disclosing what a consumer pays when he borrows or buys on the installment plan.

WHO is a kind of shock unit in the fight against disease.

Directors of the General Foods Corporation yesterday proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock. They also raised the quarterly dividend on the present shares with the declaration of 70 cents, payable on June 3 to holders of record of May 13.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 (AP) -- Billings of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation showed a 5 to 10 per cent increase in the first two months of 1960 from the level in the 1959 period, Mark W. Cresap Jr., president, said today.

LONDON, April 6 -- President de Gaulle and Prime Minister Macmillan discussed Western tactics and policies for the summit conference for an hour this morning in Buckingham Palace. LONDON, April 6 -- Stock market prices moved downward here today as buyers became more hesitant.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 (AP) -- Sam Snead said today he had followed one of the oldest traditions in show business -- the show must go on -- in "throwing" an important match on a television series in December.

TWO large exhibitions open today. A loan show of paintings, drawings, monotypes and prints by Degas bows at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, and the Ninety-third Annual Exhibition of the American Watercolor Society opens at the National Academy Galleries.

Two more organizations endorsed Mayor Wagner's proposed appointment of Mrs. Joan O'Dwyer O'Neill as a city magistrate in letters to the Mayor yesterday. Mrs. O'Neill is a 34-year-old niece of former Mayor William O'Dwyer.
