The Communist Government of Yugoslavia formally assumed responsibility yesterday for paying interest on the defaulted external debt of the defunct Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
David Susskind is giving the West equal time to answer the Soviet Union on problems of disarmament and co-existence.

ST. LOUIS, April 7 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks, who once led by 26 points, held on for a 105-102 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight before a capacity crowd of 10,612. That tied the National Basketball Association four-of-seven play-off finals at three games apiece.
CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- The Mississippi River north of St. Louis kept its immense force pressed against straining dikes today, but they appeared to be holding.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 7 -- More than 1,000 upper classmen at the United States Military Academy attended an illustrated lecture on missiles today at Redstone Arsenal in Huntsville, Ala.
GENEVA, April 7 -- The East-West disarmament conference was confronted today with deadlock and a cryptic Soviet offer to start afresh.

MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 7 -- Senator Clifford P. Case tonight endorsed New Jersey's proposal to save the state's commuter railroad service as a "practical and apparently feasible transportation program within its own selfimposed limits."

AT the moment New York is rich in one-man shows by European artists, many exhibiting for the first time in the United States. An exception is Antonio Corpora, a 51-year-old Italian painter whose work has been seen here regularly since the late Nineteen Forties, and whose style evolved from a free interpretation of Cubism to lyrical expressionism.

The directors of the Chicago and North Western Railway and of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway at meetings yesterday in Chicago approved the purchase of the Minneapolis and St. Louis by the North Western.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today blocked the proposed sale to the public of bonda and common stack by Strategic Minerals Corporation of Austin, Tex.
Wives of two professors are responsible, for "Three in a Cage."

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Both rail and freight loadings last week were above the levels of a year ago. Rail loadings were slightly below -- and truck loadings were markedly above -- the preceding week of this year.
Two rare hood seals that had been cavorting in the sub-Arctic three weeks ago found themselves at the Coney Island Aquarium yesterday.

A TWO-SESSION pair game that the Greater New York Bridge Association will conduct on Saturday, April 16, at the Sheration-Atlantie Hotel for the benefit of the American Red Cross Disaster Fund, will be made the occasion of a testimonial to Curt H. Reisinger.

THE proximity of Passover finds fresh water fish very scarce and correspondingly expensive. This applies particularly to yellow pike and whitefish. Among salt water varieties, butterfish and flounders each shed a welcome 5 cents a pound this week.
New York's vast subway system is safe, but is subject to too many long service delays, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 7 -- Military and police units swept into the suburb of Nyanga today in a joint operation against African "terrorists, intimidators and criminals."
TOURS, France, April 7 -- Riot clubs and tear gas were used against peasants in two of eighteen towns where mass demonstrations against the Government were staged today.
HAVANA, April 7 -- Two prisoners were wounded by police fire this morning in the second riot in two days at the Principe Castle Prison here.

WHOEVER cooked up the notion of having Jimmy Gavin play tWe guitar and deliver the commentary for ''The Mime and Me" should go straight to the head of the class. Sheer inspiration -- that's what it is.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 7 -- The demand by South Africa's business and industrial community for modification of the country's harsh racial policies received important new support today.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 7 -- Women residents at East Oranga whose social and civic activities keep them out late in the evening may call for a police escort to see them home safely.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 1 -- Governor Rockefeller repeated today his oft-made statement that he would not accept the Republican Vice-Presidential nomination.
CLEVELAND, April 7 -- Atomic scientists here and in Washington sharply reduced today estimates of the time it would take for an area hit in a nuclear war to recover.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Secretary Thomas S. Gates Jr. placed the Defense Department's widely dispersed space-probing bases under tight central direction today. It was a move to quash interservice disputes.
LINCOLN PARK, N.J., April 7 -- Conflicting vernal impulses have stirred up a sharp controversy in this Morris County community.

Is there such a crime as un-Puerto Rican activities? The House Committee on Un-American Activities has arranged to submit this question to the Federal courts. The case arises from the action of thirteen Puerto Rican witnesses who appeared before the committee in San Juan last November and refused to testify on the ground that their activities were strictly not the committee's business.
LOME, Togoland, April 7 (UPI)-Togoland will raise an army with French backing to defend its borders after receiving independence April, 27, Premier Sylvanua Olympio said today.

A picture-and-text story of Moscow's Kremlin has been compiled by the photographer, David Douglas Duncan, and will be published April 18 by the New York Graphic Society. Called "The Kremlin," it contains eighty-three full-color plates and many full pages or two-page spreads of pictures of the buildings, interiors and art treasures within the structure.
The Welfare Department yesterday ordered one of its prized investigators to quit her job or abandon interest in a Bronx slum tenement that houses destitute city-supported families.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of April 5 referred to our draft report regarding traffic and accident conditions in New York City, but did not emphasize that we placed blame on the lack of citizens' support of public officials rather than on official inadequacies.

The Cuban Government apparently has given up hope of operating eight cargo ships it purchased in Canada in August, 1958, for $2,800,000. The vessels are being offered for sale by several ship brokers here.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased by $102,000,000 to $704,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserve balances in excess of requirements increased $56,600,000 to $414,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A Japanese bid to supply locomotives to the Panama Canal Company has posed a new test for the Administration's trade policies.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- California gave new encouragement today to Senator John F. Kennedy's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
Positive action by the United States was called essential yesterday to prevent a serious economic split in Western Europe.
The New York Chamber of Commerce formally adopted a resolution yesterday opposing Congressional control of certain activities of the Port of New York Authority.
CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- A continued recovery in some grain futures restored the contracts today to their higher ranges of the season, although the over-all market was mixed in a sluggish trade.
A potent nerve poison produced by microscopic sea plants is the agent that makes some shellfish dangerous to eat, a conference on marine biology heard yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Two state officials and a small-town banker gave support today to a bill that would set new requirements for telling a person what he must pay when he borrows money or buys something on the installment plan.

BONN, Germany, April 7 -- Dr. Theodor Oberlaender, a former Nazi accused by the Communists of war crimes, will shortly go on leave from his post as Minister for Refugees, political circles reported tonight.

MONTREAL, April 7 (UPI) -- Henri Richard figured in all four goals, scoring once and assisting on three others, and paced the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight. The game opened the four-of-seven playoff finals for the Stanley Cup.

The Getty Oil Company reported yesterday for 1959 a consolidated net Income of $10,661,083, or 67 cents each on the 16,004,228 shares outstanding. This includes dividend income of $2,421,030, but is exclusive of a special credit of $3,918,000, or 24 cents a share, representing the profit from the sale of the Pierre Hotel, New York, which was recorded last year.
The cast of characters for the tableau that will be part of the entertainment at the annual Italian Renaissance Ball has been announced.
WHITE PLAINS, April 7 -- Eighty officials of communities in Westchester gave their support tonight to the formation of a federation of all the planning commissions and boards in the county.

Robert Hall Clothes has leased three floors in the building being constructed at 441 Ninth Avenue in the blockfront between Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Streets. The lease involves 120,000 square feet of space and completes the renting of the building, although completion is eight months away.
GEORGETOWN, Del., April 7 (AP) -- A new technique for the recovery of nose cones and other space vehicles as they parachute earthward was demonstrated publicly today for the first time.
MOSCOW, April 7 -- Galina Ulanova, considered by many to be the leading ballerina in the world, was reported today to have retired last week.
EDDIE ARCARO enjoys his role as a celebrity and has steadfastly refused to hang up his tack and thereby end his spectacular career as one of the world's best jockeys.
LAUREL, Md., April 7 (AP) -- William Hal Bishop's Pete's Folly lowered the Laurel track record for a mile to 1:38 4/5 today in winning the $5,000 Patuxent Purse.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Senator John F. Kennedy has reached a critical point in his quest for the Presidency. His personal charm, his money, his religion and his dispassionate intelligence have carried him to a high plateau, still far below the summit; but, ironically, these very same factors are now beginning to cause him trouble.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Eight Senators joined today as sponsors of what a spokesman called a "liberal Republican" plan of voluntary health insurance for the aged.
Representative Ludwig Teller last night labeled his rival for the Democratic nomination in the Twentieth Congressional District a "disappointed, hypocritical office seeker."

Alabama Power Company borrowed $19,500,000 in the public capital market yesterday through a sale to Blyth Co., Inc., and Kidder, Peabody Co. and associates of first mortgage bonds on a bid of 99.55 for obligations bearing a 5 per cent interest coupon.

Charles and Milton A. Kimmelman, realty investors, have sold Sickles Garden, a five-and-one-half-story apartment building at 38 to 48 Sickles Street, adjoining the southwest corner of Sherman Avenue, in the Dyckman area of upper Manhattan.

Following are the texts of a letter from the Transit Authority to Mayor Wagner commmenting on a report on the subways by the engineering firm of Coverdale Colpitts, and the concluding section of that report:
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Treasury's first offering of a long-term bond in nearly a year did not produce much response from investors.

A resolution opposing the construction of a sidewalk cafe in the southeast corner of Central Park was adopted yesterday by the directors of the Park Association of New York City. They also opposed the construction of a permanent open-air Shakespearean theatre in the park.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) up to 15 points (75 cents off) yesterday.

Loans to business by fifteen large New York City banks dropped $94,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the like week last year, they declined $50,000,000.
Marshall Cassidy resigned yesterday as vice president and director of racing of the New York Racing Association.
Pleasure boating has come to mean more than navigating a craft on a vacationing cruise. Water skiing and skin diving have joined the basic boating sport.

The city demolished another of its fast-disappearing subway kiosks yesterday. The deed was accomplished at St. Nicholas Avenue and 181st Street amid oratory and well-pressed assaults upon vital statistics.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today took President Alberto Lleras Camargo of Colombia on a helicopter ride to his mountain retreat at Camp David, Md., and to his Gettysburg, Pa., Farm.
The last of 1,300 pounds of photographs that will transform the Astor Hotel into a facsimile of the Paris Opera are scheduled to arrive in New York today.

The Internal Revenue Service recently set forth criteria to be used by taxpayers in determining the deductibility of expenses incurred for education. The guidelines are appropriate for Federal personal income tax returns now in preparation.

ALGIERS, April 7 -- A Moslem who described himself as a former ranking official in the Algerian rebel provisional Government said tonight that he had deserted it because the rebels refused to make peace with President de Gaulle.
New York City Housing Authority borrowed $20,470,000 yesterday on serial bonds guaranteed by the city at an interest cost of 4.0104 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 -- Members of the Asian African group plan to ask for another meeting of the Security Council unless the South African Government promptly indicates it is willing to consult with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The House of Representatives passed by a voice vote today a bill aiming to keep retiring admirats and generals from stepping into high - salaried posts in defense industries as salesmen of armed services supplies.

WHEN Augustine went home to his native village of Rivisondoli in the mountains of the Abruzzi after eight years' hard labor in a railroad yard in Cleveland, he intended to stay there. He had saved his money, had never looked at a woman and had lived largely on beans and lentils.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Department-store sales in the nation last week were 22 per cent above the year-ago level.
LONDON, April 7 -- Amid ghostly reminders of the eleventh century in Westminster Hall, President de Gaulle denounced the weapons of the twentieth century today and appealed for their destruction.
Gamble Benedict and Andre Porumbeanu dropped from public sight yesterday after the marriage Wednesday at hunting lodge near Hendersonville, N.C.
In 1928 Sophie Treadwell's "Machinal" was bold and original "in form and viewpoint.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Thomas G. Corcoran was invited today to tell about his recent contacts with members of the Federal Power Commission.
Two guards were injured yesterday by three prisoners who tried to escape from the overcrowded Bronx House of Detention at 151st Street and River Avenue.
Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan dismissed yesterday a second count of a three-count Federal indictment against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. for income-tax evasion.
Stocks lost momentum yesterday afternoon, eased from 1 P.M. onward and retained only a small fraction of their earlier gains.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 (AP) -- Sam Snead drew a mild rebuke from the Professional Golfers Association tonight for continuing in a television match he had already lost under the rules.
The Bethlehem Steel Company said yesterday that only free collective bargaining could settle the ten-week-old strike of 17,000 workers at its eight East Coast shipyards.
THE shopper who feels that she has picked up several bargains at the supermarket might have second thoughts if she added up all the costs of those purchases.
Six hundred high school students -- prospective engineers, chemists and physicists -- heard the future described yesterday as "startling," "staggering" and "stupendous."
Spring is here, and a New York-Brooklyn romance budded yesterday. Reports were that the Bank of New York was making serious overtures to the Kings County Trust Company.

Candidates for the 1960 Tony Awards, named in honor of the late Antoinette Perry, wartime chairman of the American Theatre Wing, were announced yesterday by Helen Menken, president of the organization.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 7 (UPI) -- A full-page advertisement in The New York Times that solicited funds for the legal defense of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was denounced here today.

After a triumphant visit to London, President de Gaulle flies home today convinced that France and Britain will stand shoulder to shoulder with the United States at the summit meeting with Premier Khrushchev and that as a result the threatening crisis over Berlin will be overcome with "wisdom and resolution."
A new family comedy, this one about a French wife whose husband is an American architect, will start on Columbia Broadcasting System TV next season.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 7 -- By way of impressing an important adversary, the Yankees today put on a routine that could put them back in the king row this year. It certainly sufficed to upend Jimmy Dykes' Tigers, 2 to 1, for the Bombers' third straight victory.
Four thousand Connecticut and Westchester commuters on the New Haven Railroad were delayed up to one hour and nineteen minutes yesterday morning in arriving at Grand Central Terminal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is taking a larger part in helping Africa make the transition to a modern economy, the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations heard today.
Mayor Wagner asserted last night that his campaign to wipe the grime from the face of New York was advancing "at a speed I would call unprecedented in government."
LONDON, April 7 (Reuters) -- Following is the official translation of President de Gaulle's speech today to members both houses of the British Parliament:

MADISON, Wis., April 7 (AP) -- Wisconsin, playing the role of an ungracious host, swept to seven straight victories, and a defending titleholder came through as expected tonight in the opening bouts of the twenty-third National Collegiate boxing championships.
A leading British aircraft manufacturer warned yesterday that a "wildcat" rush to produce a supersonic airliner could severely damage aviation.
Fifty-four men were indicted here yesterday in the "ghosting" of Civil Service examinations for post office Jobs.

A new antifreeze said to be the first such product that need not be replaced from year to year was introduced yesterday. E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., producer of the fluid, said it need never be drained from a properly operating cooling system.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- In the mythology of the Presidential preference primary system West Virginia, though it has only eight electors and cast less than one sixty-second part of the national voting total in 1956, is now being hopefully looked at as the source of infallible omens of the outcome of the Presidential election of 1960.
The American Civil Liberties Union voiced "grave objection" yesterday to the "color or race" question in the current national census.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation, stepping up its nation-wide drive against airline bomb scares, announced today that it had arrested two men on charges of perpetrating such hoaxes.

LONDON, April 7 -- With buyers still hesitant, most share prices drifted lower in the stock market here today. Falls among industrials were small but sufficient to lower The Financial Times index of industrial common shares a full point, to 327.

YESTERDAY (April 7, I960) THE PRESIDENT Saw House Republican Policy Committee; met with National Security Council; flew to Camp David with Colombian President Alberto Lleras Camargo; attended with Mrs. Eisenhower a dinner at Colombian Embassy.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., April 7 -- A sweeping revision of foreign trade policy was urged or Congress today by James A. Chapman, president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute.

WHILE Long Island fishermen concern themselves almost wholly with small flounders and fresh-water trout fishermen in New York State grind their teeth at high water, the Outer Banks of North Carolina is rejoicing.

A lot of people think spring is late this year -- and they can document the reasons -- but a horticultural expert says he thinks they are just overly anxious to get out in their gardens again with rake and trowel.

The Treasury has included in its program of new financing an issue of long-term bonds, the first of its kind to be undertaken in almost a year. The new offering will carry a coupon rate of 4 1/4 per cent and will mature twenty-five years hence.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A high Polish official said today that his country would like to buy $100,000,000 worth of American machinery a year for several years.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., April 7 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy disputed Republican prosperity claims today by saying that 17,000,000 Americans "go to bed hungry every night."

Cocoa rallied strongly for the second day on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. Prices rose, although not as sharply as the day before, and closed 46 to 52 points (hundreds of a cent a pound) higher. A total of 818 lots, 30,000 pounds to a lot, changed hands for the year's second best volume.

THE entrance to the Victoriana exhibit that opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum is a door disguised as a window. But, once on the other side of the red velvet curtains, the sensation is that of having stepped through a looking glass.
This fall will witness the opening of a biennial competition for young musicians that will dwarf anything of its kind previously undertaken in America.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 7 -- Administrative officials of the six-nation European Economic Community are planning a friendly political and commercial approach to the new governments of Africa.

THE American Savoyards turned to "Utopia,Limited," last night at the Jan Hus House, and the report this morning is that Dorothy Raedler's verse - singers are continuing their good work. They sang it affectionately with taste and impeccability and in the best of voices.
LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- British critics today greeted a new play by William Saroyan, which he had written as rehearsals went along, with stinging criticism.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 7 -- Pioneer space explorers to reach Mars could be equipped with collapsible, rocket-driven trucks, helicopters and airplanes.

THE current parade of new Italian baritones continued last night at the Metropolitan Opera, where Anselmo Colzani made his debut in the title role of Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra." It was not only his Metropolitan Opera debut, but the first time he had sung this role on any stage.

LONDON, April 7 -- A private committee of British experts proposed today that Britain try to regain her supremacy in the air transport industry with the urgent development of a 2,000-mile-an-hour airliner capable of vertical take-offs and landings.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 7 -- Archbishop Joost de Blank of the Anglican Church said today that the Dutch Reformed Church of South Africa should be expelled from the World Council of Churches because of its failure to denounce apartheid, the country's policy of strict racial segregation.
Th bond market sagged n yesterday in an inactive ing session.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Permit me to applaud your editorial of March 30 "Mr. Hoffa and the Monitors." No generalization on that subject is better founded in fact than your statement: "From the very start Mr. Hoffa has used every conceivable device of evasion, stalling and litigation to avoid carrying out the recommendations for reform."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- A team of researchers at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons suggests that it may have found the cause of malignant hypertension. This is a form of high blood pressure that is almost 100 per cent fatal within a two-year period after onset.
LONDON April 7 -- The sudden decision of Jeremy Fry to withdraw as best man at the wedding of Princess Margaret and Antony Armstrong-Jones caused a sharp reaction today in Britain.

Johnny Dio, the labor racketeer and Theodore Ray, his reputed bodyguard, were found guilty yesterday of income tax evasion and conspiracy. Both will be sentenced April 28 by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld, who heard the case without a jury.
PARAMUS, N.J., April 7 -- Robert Morris continued his barnstorming drive for the Republican nomination for Senator with a five-county tour today.

PREMIER SYLVANUS OLYMPIC, a 57-year-old, man of many jobs, is not one to worry about portfolio niceties. For him the thing to do is to do. Sometimes called "Mr. Togoland," he is also Minister of Finance and Minister of Justice, and he shortly will be Minister of Foreign Affaire.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Eisenhower has a special way of chiding a stenographer who cannot keep up with his dictation or who asks him to repeat. The President simply praises, in superlatives, the efficiency and speed of some secretary he had in the past.
To save space when shipping peanuts, shell the peanuts.

Columbia University paid tribute last night to 162 athletes who won varsity letters in fourteen sports during 1959-60. The insignia and eleven special awards were presented at the thirty-ninth annual Varsity C Club dinner in John Jay Hall on the Morningside Heights campus.
An industry-wide investigation of the manufacture, distribution and sale of prescription drugs was started here yesterday by the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice.
A magistrate threatened yesterday to order the psychiatric examination of a landlord whose nonappearance in Housing Court was attributed, in a physician's note, to "reactive depression."

ALBANY, April 7 -- New York State announced today a $360,000,000 highway-building program for 1960-61. The total included $130,000,000 for Nev York City projects and $81,190,000 for work in the city's suburbs.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 7 -- The tide of public opinion seems to be ebbing away from the Communist party in Iraq.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 -- Arnold Palmer overcame a jinx today and took a two-stroke lead in the Masters golf tournament with a five-under-par 67.
THE novelty on last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center proved to be the least interesting item of an otherwise fine evening.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Senate approved one last concession to the South on the voting-referee plan today as it moved toward a final vote on the civil rights bill.
PITTSBURGH, April 7 (AP) -- Cigarette smoking can definitely be linked to lung cancer, an internal medicine and therapeutics specialist testified today in Federal court.

Sales of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company rose 39 per cent in the first quarter this year, to $9,100,000 from the $6,553,100 volume of the period last year, W.D. Cole, chairman, estimated at the annual meeting here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Since the National Defense Department of the Portuguese Government on March 24 denied our March 7 reports of an African nationalist uprising in Angola, we think it important that the public understand the facts.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 7 -- Joe Bonacorsa, a former New York University fullback who has become a harness racing pilot, achieved his first victory of the season at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The United States Government will support a French proposal to compel the use of designated "tracks" or sea lanes by passenger ships sailing the North Atlantic. Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, disclosed the new United States position yesterday.

ALGIERS, April 8 -- France announced today an electoral decree under which Moslems will gain control of all thirteen Algerian departmental assemblies in local elections next month. Europeans will be outnumbered in each assembly for the first time.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 8 -- The Netherlands and West Germany signed an agreement today covering the claims of Dutch citizens for injuries and losses resulting from Nazi persecution.
Mrs. Augusta Redman, the owner of several slum tenements, was attested yesterday by warrant officers who knocked and rang in front of her padlocked apartment at intervals for four hours.

A group of home owners in the Jamaica Estates area of Queens sought yesterday a revision of plans to widen Grand Central Parkway. They charged that the project would "wreak havoc" on property values there.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Vice President Nixon told a group of Protestant editors today that he would take the same position on birth control and foreign aid that President Eisenhower had. But the Vice President went on to say that he would favor having the United States provide scientific knowledge on birth control to nations that wanted such information to limit their population growth.

THE ratchets, gears, boilers, valves and casters that participate in the noisy life of industry are given new designations in Richard Stankiewicz's sculptures at the Stable Gallery, 924 Seventh Avenue at Fifty-eighth Street.

THOSE tired of the traditional Easter chick, bunny and egg decorations might be interested in making an Easter tree. An unusually pretty one has been created by East House, 1075 First Avenue. It consists of a twig embellished with colorful flowers made of tissue wrapping paper and is in the do-it-yourself category.

PITTSBURGH, April 8 (UPI) -- The dean of a Philadelphia medical school testified in a $1,250,000 damage suit today that a survey he once made for the American Cancer Society had indicated deaths from lung cancer were related to heavy cigarette smoking.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Three members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee criticized the foreign aid program today as wasteful, badly planned and plagued by politicians abroad and bureaucrats here.
CHICAGO, April 8 (UPI) -- The driver of a Brink's, Inc., armored car left a note saying, "I'm going out on a good drunk" today and wandered off with a money bag containing $30,000.

MOSCOW, April 8 (AP) -- Galina Ulanova, one of the world's greatest dancers, has been awarded a pension of 4,000 rubles a month but she is not giving up dancing. She will also receive extra pay for each performance.
CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Late selling wiped out most of a small general advance in the grain futures market today and left nearly all contracts down slightly.

ONE of the occupations in which women are almost as rare as whooping cranes is film editing. A technical and specialized skill, it was largely a field for men until World War II. At that time, the manpower shortage opened the door to a few hardy women.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 8 -- The president of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company defended today the conduct of Thomas G. Corcoran before the Federal Power Commission on a subsidiary's pipeline application.
LONDON, April 8 -- Prince Andrew, third child of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh, was christened today in the Music Room of Buckingham Palace.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent, reaching 120.2 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., April 8 -- New and highly specialized chemical fibers will burst upon the textile world in large numbers in the next few years, the convention of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute was told here today.

STONY BROOK, L.I., April 8 -- A vast expansion of the State University will be needed if the state is to keep pace with the rising demands for higher education, Governor Rockefeller declared here today.
PARIS, April 8 -- President de Gaulle returned today from his triumphal state visit to London with his prestige at home and abroad enhanced.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Repeated doses of potent cancer-suppressing drugs, at high levels impossible before recent advances in medical science, are being used to help some patients in advanced stages of the disease, a specialist reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla., today proposed a settlement of its long-standing natural gas rate case. The company apparently would get increases of $28,000,000 a year under its proposal, compared with $49,000,000 originally sought by the company.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- An agreement was reached today to end the strike by actors that has halted nearly all movie production here since March 7.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 8 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, arrived here today and immediately began talking about Soviet-Iraqi friendship.

A new textile processing machine that electronically controls the weight of fibers fed into it has been introduced by the Roberts Company of Sanford, N.C. Called the "AutoEvener," the device is one of a new line of worsted system preparatory machines developed by Roberts in affiliation with the Tematex Company of Milan, Italy.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The United States Court of Military Appeals reversed itself today and held that military boards of review had authority to reduce death sentences to imprisonment for life.

MONTREAL, April 8 (UPI) -- The coaches of the Stanley Cup finalists, Toe Blake of the Montreal Canadiens and Punch Imlach of the Toronto Maple Leafs, agreed today that their teams could and must play better.

WASHINGTON April 8 (UPI) -- The Federal Housing Administration reported yesterday that the average buyer of a new home who had a mortgage insured by the F.H.A. paid more for his house last year, but made a smaller down payment.

The United Fruit Company was jolted the other day when it heard that Cuba would pay only $6,000,000 in twenty-year 4 1/2 per cent bonds for 272,472 acres in Cuba that the company valued at $32,000,000. But the payment for the expropriated land would be even lower than apparent.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Nicholas Constantine Christofilos has patented one component of Astron, the elaborate equipment he is building for the Atomic Energy Commission in an effort to control the hydrogen bomb reaction for power production.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 (AP) -- A review of a controversial match involving Sam Snead ended today with an apology by Snead and a statement by the Professional Golfers Association that it would police future television golf shows that have its endorsement.

Cus D'Amato, who has lost his license to manage fighters in this state, received a thirtyday suspended sentence yesterday on his conviction of failing to answer a subpoena for questioning by the State Attorney General's office.
UNLIKE the weather, which people talk about but cannot change, idle chatter on other subjects can produce positive results.
Passover -- the week-long Jewish festival celebrating the liberation of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage more than 3,000 years ago -- will begin Monday at sundown.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed a bill today reducing the cabaret tax from 20 per cent to 10 per cent.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- Frank Sinatra has discharged Albert Maltz, the blacklisted writer he had hired to do a screen adaptation of "The Execution of Private Slovik."
PALISADES PARK, N.J., April 8 -- Robert Morris said here tonight that tax reforms and an easing of the tax burden on industry were vital if the United States was to remain industrially strong.

GENEVA, April 8 -- The United States and Canada presented their compromise proposal on fishing rights to the eighty-eight-nation Law of the Sea Conference today and urged the conferees to follow their example of composing conflicting views.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 8 -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court decried as a "myth" tonight the idea that the court was overworked.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer's victory today in the Masters Golf Tournament means that President Eisenhower will fly to Augusta, Ga., tomorrow for a week to ten days of golf at the Augusta National Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- Plans are being made for special arrangements by which to carry forward Government functions should there be threat of an atomic attack on Washington. Under the plans the Government is ready to start the first of eleven emergency buildings 100 to 150 miles outside the Capital for use of key officials.
SARASOTA, Fla., April 10 -- The Yankees today finally got around to solving the problem of preventing the White Sox from making off with one-run games.
Four thousand Palm Sunday worshipers thronged St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday in observance of the opening of the holiest week of the Christian year.

Only two of the eighty-nine nominees for the Tony prizes, Broadway's counterpart of Hollywood's Oscar and television's Emmy, were present last night at the cocktail reception given by Sherman Billingsley at his Stork Club, 3 East Fifty-third Street.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- Though the thirty-three-day actors strike was settled here on Friday, movie work will be resumed very slowly, beginning tomorrow.
Gov. Luis Munoz Marin urged New York's Puerto Ricans yesterday to use their voting power to solve their problems.

ALTHOUGH originally made under extremely primitive circumstances some 3,500 years ago, matzohs now are produced under very modern conditions. Giant machines do the mixing, rolling, conveying and packaging of a product that once was made by mixing flour and water and baking it in the sun or a crude fire-heated oven.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Public fascination with the census as a milestone in this country's own little population boom tends to stress the demand side of the picture and obscure the supply side.
AMSTERDAM, April 10 -- The Amsterdam Stock Exchange was active last week. The general stock index rose from 349 to nearly 360. The year's high was 372 (1953 equals 100).

ATLANTA, April 10 -- The Episcopal Society for Cultural and Racial Unity has issued a statement here terming "unfortunate" an Alabama Bishop's advice to ignore a church advisory on sitdown demonstrations.
JOHANNESBURG, April 10 (AP) -- The assassin, David Pratt, a wealthy white farmer, was described by a friend today as a man who "hates Nationalists."
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has called for legal action to eliminate "the broad pattern of Negro exclusion" from apprenticeship training in New York State.

The keen race between Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union and Bobby Fischer, the United States champion, continued yesterday in the international chess tournament at Mar del Plata, Argentina. Both were winners in the tenth round, according to a report received through South American news sources.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A delegation of fifteen Soviet officers is expected here soon to reciprocate the three-day visit of a delegation from the National War College to Moscow early this month.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Mrs. Blanche E. Reeg's Wantagh (L.I.) neighbors were able to do some additional prideful pointing toward a celebrated dog after tonight's competition in the International Kennel Club of Chicago show.
TEANECK, N.J., April 10 -- An all-day planning seminar on "North Jersey Faces Its Future" will be held Thursday at Fairleigh Dickinson University here.

IT is within the power of television to soar on the wings of the world's greatest art. With a dynamic, glowing production of "Don Giovanni," the National Broadcasting Company showed yesterday afternoon that even a towering masterpiece of the iyric theatre could retain its integrity and radiance in a medium that frequently aims lower than it needs to.

NOTHING that happens in Africa happens for the good. This sweeping statement is only one of the hundreds of risky generalizations, violent opinions and superbly confident recommendations that may be found in "The Death of Africa,"* by Peter Ritner. This last of a long line of books about the current state of affairs in Sub- Sahara Africa is a curious mixture of able topical reporting and of wildly controversial interpreting.
GENEVA, April 10 -- The Sonet delegation disclaimed today any initiative in pressing for a recess in the ten-nation disarmament conference.
Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson expressed the hope yesterday that the Legislature and the voters would authorize a bonus for veterans of the Korean conflict.
The number of workers covered by unemployment insurance in New York City rose by nearly 50,000 between June, 1958, and June, 1959, the Department of City Planning reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (UPI) -- Defense Secretary Thomas S. Gates Jr. hinted today that President Eisenhower might farther reorganize the nation's defense program to bolster United States military might.
An unparalleled growth in the demand for all forms of outdoor recreation has been forecast for the next twentyfive years in the New York metropolitan region and the country as a whole.

GENEVA -- Activity picked up considerably on the Swiss stock markets last week. The big chemical concerns at Basle were favorites among Swiss shares, but the commercial banks and the investment companies also got a good play.

ROME, April 10 -- Premier Fernando Tambroni's "business Government," composed exclusively of Christian Democrats, was falling apart today as one minister after another resigned or threatened to resign.

Before the year is out, railroads will be offering a sixty-five-hour freight service between New York and Los Angeles, Morris Forgash, chairman and president of the United States Freight Company, predicted last week.
With dealings limited, prices of cotton in the domestic market moved within a narrow irregular range last week on the New York Cotton Exchange.

A study of the problems of many senior citizens -- loneliness, inability to find worthwhile occupations and strained relations with their children -- was presented on Saturday evening on "World Wide 60" under the title of "The Living End."
LONDON, April 10 -- The optimism shown by the stock market in advance of the 1960-61 budget oozed away after it was presented to Parliament last Monday.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council announced yesterday that it had completed negotiations with representatives of West Germany for the resumption of debt service on the last two of eighty issues of defaulted German bonds over which the Bonn authorities assumed jurisdiction.

MADISON, Wis., April 10 (AP) -- A 22-year-old University of Wisconsin boxer battled for his life today after undergoing extensive surgery for a brain injury suffered in the National Collegiate championships.

THE time has passed when a tiny, bewildered pink-dyed duck seemed an endearing pet for a child on Easter morning. Many parents have learned that robust little humans do not know their own strength when they fondle fragile, young fowl.
WHEN a family moves into a new home, it takes months to "shake down" the living situation. But when a whole nation of families moves in at once, it can take generations.

Five American scientists and political specialists agreed last night that the Soviet Government caught for world's attention with its proposals for total disarmament, but at the same time warned of the "transparent" propaganda contained in the offer.
"To be or not to be?" was the Bard's query and the music reviewer at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young last night was tempted to answer in the negative.
NEWARK, April 10 -- Pasquale Pepi scored as the Newark Portuguese defeated the Elizabeth Falcons, 1 -- 0, in an American League soccer game today.

THE Juilliard School of Music gave the first of two pairs of concerts by its dance department at its concert hall on Friday and Saturday evenings. Friday's was devoted to the modern dance and Saturday's to the ballet.
Jose Ferrer will produce and portray the title role in "Hercule Poirot," a one-hour weekly detective series based upon Agatha Christie's mystery stories.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The 1960 census has been completed in the only disputed possession of the United States, three square miles of Caribbean real estate called the Swan Islands, once a pirate base.

The Franklin Small Business Investment Company has named Herman E. Goodman as president and chief executive officer, it was announced over the week-end. The company, licensed under the Federal Small Business Investment Act, is an affiliate of the Franklin National Bank of Long Island.
Ground will be broken next Monday at 10 A.M. for the new $7,812,800 police academy that will be built on East Twentieth Street between Second and Third Avenues.
A new labor-management approach to the controversial "featherbedding" issue on railroads has been recommended by a Federal consultant.
More than 17,000 idle shipyard workers from Boston to Baltimore are "tightening their belts," an official of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A House committee investigating the withholding of information from Congress by executive agencies has turned to the Department of the Interior.
HONG KONG, April 10 -- Premier Chou En-lai said today that there had been "no change in the tense situations" between Communist China and the United States.
The role of the mass media in helping to produce effective democratic leadership was more or less the subject of yesterday afternoon's concluding installment of "The Great Challenge" over Channel 2.
A joint contract to carry military passenger and cargo traffic overseas at reduced rates was proposed yesterday by four airlines.

Four vocalists, including the composer, performed a program of songs by Robert Fairfax Birch at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. The other vocalists were Pauline Seim, soprano, Gladys Kriese, contralto, and Martial Singher, baritone.

PARIS. Cartoonists have noted the parallel between King Canute, a Briton who did not rule the waves, and South Africa's Prime Minister Verwoerd. Both have been unsuccessful in ordering tides to halt. But Canute at least was reconciled to the inevitable.
ROME, April 10 -- Pope John XXIII, in a Palm Sunday homily today, exhorted parents to have many children.

HAVANA, April 10 -- The United States has asked Cuba to extradite two American pilots shot down in Cuba last month so they can face a Federal grand jury in Miami on their unauthorized flight from Florida.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Democratic Advisory Committee named today a committee of seven scientists and economists to plan now for the transition from a defense to a peace economy in event of world disarmament.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- A steel pin helped golf's man of steel today. Arnold Palmer gave an assist to the flagpole at the sixteenth green for his triumph in the Masters golf tournament.
A model Seder in the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue was attended yesterday by sixty children from two Protestant churches.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) -- Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri said today the United States could win an all-out nuclear war but was unprepared to fight an effective limited conflict.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 10 -- E. Chester Peet Jr. of the host club fleet, sailing Cricket, won the Interclub Division as the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual spring regatta of frostbite dinghies ended on a windy note today.

The northwest corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenge) and Forty-second Street, diagonally opposite Bryant Park, has been sold by John S. Schulte, who has owned the property for thirty-eight years.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 -- A leveling-off in new order volume continued in the steel industry last week. In some instances cancellations were less only because they had been so drastic in recent weeks and there was little to cancel.
CAIRO, April 10 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser plans further travels and talks with other chiefs of state after returning from his current trip to India and Pakistan next weekend.

Sperry Rand Co. The sale of the adding machine and cash register division of the Clary Corporation to the Remington Rand division of the Sperry Rand Corporation was announced yesterday by both companies.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 10 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers, getting five doubles among their thirteen hits, closed out the exhibition baseball season today with an 8-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants before 10,139 at Edmond's Field.
The learning process is supposed never to end. People who sell mutual funds are becoming more aware of this as the industry matures.
Rechargeable batteries that power an increasing number of end products for thirty to forty years may be heading into a boom.

Week Ended April 8, 1960 The strong upward movement of the British pound sterling continued in foreign exchange trading during the past week. Canadian dollar showed signs of weakness as it drifted lower on active and at times heavy dealings.
A floor in 3 West Fiftyseventh Street has been leased by Rose-Martin, Inc., advertising agency, through H.K. Negbaur Co., brokers.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 6 -- Beyond the big Victorian house a setting sun turned the Mississippi's brown waters into a sheet of gold and cast long shadows in front of the live oak tree and its silver Spanish moss.
Primary contests for Democratic district leaderships are in prospect this year in eleven of Brooklyn's tewnty-two Assembly Districts.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., April 10 -- Senator Robert C. Byrd is urging a coalition of "stop Kennedy" forces in support of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota in this state's Democratic Presidential primary May 10.
A campaign of saturated enforcement of the anti-litter law in various sections of the city will start about June 1, Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane announced yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- There was room at the top of the Masters field for Arnold Palmer again today. With birdies on the last two holes, the 30-year-old professional squeezed past Ken Venturi and won with a 72-hole score of 282.
ALBANY, April 10 -- In a filing cabinet in a second-floor work room of New York's gray granite Capitol there are 1,013 cardboard folders, each about 14 inches high and 6 inches wide.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, warned yesterday that he would not tolerate a strike of teachers in this city.
The Byline Award for outstanding reporting in 1959 was won by Martin J. Steadman of The New York Journal-American, the Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City announced yesterday.

EVERY woman has a private ambition when spring comes. She may resolve to clean out confused closets or to lose weight or to put up new wallpaper in her home. But the one faint stirring that affects most women, however briefly, is the desire to look prettier.

A Geographical Oddity News that officials of Ecuador are grateful to the Hat Corporation of America for reviving the Panama hat recalls the geographical oddity in which this fascinating article of fashion and commerce has been involved.
Union Theological Seminary's program in the interrelations of psychiatry and religion will be extended with the gifts of more than $500,000 from two philanthropic foundations.

The San Jacinto Petroleum Corporation has agreed to sell its interest in a group of oilproducing properties in Louisiana to the General American Oil Company of Texas for more than $27,000,000, Benno C. Schmidt, chairman of San Jacinto, announced yesterday.

THE program known as "Our American Heritage" has not been uniformly successful in its historical dramatizations, but last night's profile of Andrew Carnegie, industrialist and philanthropist, should warrant the presentation's return next year.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Tiros I, the television weather satellite, caught a hurricane off Australia with its camera today.

One of the largest domestic air freight-forwarding companies in the country, Wings and Wheels, Inc., of Flushing, Queens, yesterday took over control of another concern engaged in the same business, the American Shippers Company of Los Angeles.

Secretary of Labor Mitchell deserves support in his efforts to improve the condition of American farm workers, especially of those migrants whose lot he has called "ultimately intolerable in a society wealthy enough to correct it." Two moves in this campaign, of which he spoke in an address last week, are evidence of progress being made -- and promised.
Ninety-one per cent of 311 newspaper publishers in the United States have voted The New York Times the best daily paper in the country.

NEWTON, Mass., April 10 -- Edward Ray Speare, a retired industrialist who served for more than fifty years as a trustee of Boston University, died last night in Newton-Wellesley Hospital. He was 87 years old.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 10 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim reaffirmed a neutral and independent policy for Iraq today while sharing a platform with Anastas I. Mikoyan.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 10 -- The South African Cabinet held another emergency meeting this afternoon. After hearing encouraging medical reports on the condition of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd, the members decided to act on the assumption that Dr. Venvoerd would recover completely from the attempt on his life yesterday and that he would be able to resume his duties.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 10 -- Officials here believe Chile's proposal for a Latin-American arms limitation conference has received enough support for consultations to begin soon on an agenda and a time and place for the meeting.
ALBANY, April 10 -- State aid to regional, public library systems will increase by $1,600,000 under a bill signed today by Governor Rockefeller.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 10 (AP) -- Betsy Rawls of Spartanburg S.C., shook off a determined threat by Fay Cracker on the last nine holes today to shoot a par 73 and repeat her last year's victory in the $6,500 Babe Zaharias golf tournament.
President Alberto Lleras Camargo of Colombia and his wife will be greeted by the city today with the traditional noonday ticker-tape parade from the Battery to City Hall.

State Rent Administrator Robert E. Herman announced a new program of liaison and mutual assistance yesterday between his office and the District Attorneys of the city. He believes it will encourage speed the criminal prosecution, of rent-law violators.
TRENTON, April 10 (UPI) -- Rodger Ward of Indianapolis led all the way to win the 100mile national championship race for Indianapolis cars today at the Trenton Speedway.
Without an infusion of religious values the Zionist movement will become a "driftless, vacuous and meaningless con- cept," the president of the Religious Zionists of America declared yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is regrettable that in these difficult times, when our country is striving to tell the peoples of Asia and Africa that we desire to be their friend, the Southern reactionaries refuse to permit the Negro to enjoy the rights guaranteed him by our Constitution.
PARIS, April 10 -- French economic and financial circles are preoccupied with a slowdown in general business activity coupled with persistent weakness on the stock market.

ALBANY, April 10 -- At this cycle in the state's political year -- the thirty-day-bill period -- the Governor of New York leans most heavily upon a man listed in the budget as "Counsel to the Govrenor . . . . $20,000."
The Very Rev. John Vernon Butler, new dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, preached the sermon at the Palm Sunday service there yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 10 -- Ira Weisenfield's The Gem scored 11 points to take the Class A championship during the eighth annual junior Olympics horse show at the Thomas School of Horsemanship today. Reserve honors went to Yvette Cahn's Virginia with 5 points.
A dozen New Jersey schoolboys will prove next Wednesday that it is as easy to keep a 5 A.M. fishing date as it is to make a 9 A.M. class.
What has color television to do with automobiles? Apparently a good deal.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- One of the most intensive and broadly based lobbying operations in recent history has made health insurance for the aged easily the No. 1 issue before Congress this year.

BRUSSELS, April 10 (UPI) -- Jack Brabham of Australia beat the rain, a tricky circuit and Stirling Moss under extremely adverse conditions today. As a result he won the first Grand Prix of Brussels Formula II automobile race before 30,000 spectators.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 10 -- An uncertain calm prevailed in South Africa today following the attempted assassination of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd by a white farmer yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Democrats on the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy killed today, for the second consecutive year, the Administration's high-priority plan to build a new type of atom smasher at Stanford University.

A junior committee is helping with final plans for an Easter Sunday Soiree, a supper dance to be given in the Columns of the Savoy-Hilton Sunday for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- A committee of state Governors and Federal officials, set up three years ago with an eye to shifting some Federal responsibilities to the states, was disbanded today without having shifted much.

The business outlook is better than the business news that can be expected in the next few weeks, Dr. Emerson P. Schmidt, chief economist of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said yesterday in Washington.

New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $30,460,000 of temporary loan notes on April 19 to finance development of Benjamin Franklin Houses, a City-sponsored project subsidized by municipal tax forgiveness.
NEW DELHI, India, April 11 -- Communist China has made clear to India that it expects Premier Chou En-lai's visit here next week to go a long way toward settling the border dispute between them.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 11 -- Billy Haughton tonight took sole possession of the driving lead at Roosevelt Raceway. Although a distant last with the 44 -- 1 Amber Wayne in the featured pace, Haughton had three winners, bringing his total to thirteen.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today he had not been "strait-jacketed" by President Eisenhower on medical insurance for older persons.

BONN, Germany, April 11 -- Chancellor Adenauer's Government, stung by reports that large numbers of Germans were moving from the West to Communists East Germany, declared today that the Communists were falsifying the statistics.

Elephants danced in the courtyard of Bellevue Hospital yesterday. A man in purple tights teetered high on a wire. Six tumblers piled themselves into a pyramid, and zebras and llamas loped around the ring to waltz music from a brass band.

Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union and Bobby Fischer, the United States champion, posted victories again in the eleventh round of the chess tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Argentine news sources.

Now that Fernando Tambroni has failed to create a stop-gap government in Rome, Italians will perhaps face the fact that their whole political system is in crisis. The day Antonio Segni resigned -- Feb. 24 -- was the end of a road.
YESTERDAY (April 11, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Flew to Augusta, Ga., for golfing holiday.

First-quarter volume of the Bell System was "pretty well in line with our expectations," Frederick R. Kappel, president, told stockholders in the quarterly report released yesterday. Bell is made up of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its principal telephone subsidiaries.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Maurice A. Hutcheson, president of the Carpenters Union, was convicted today of contempt of Congress. Without invoking the Fifth Amendment, he had refused to answer questions before the Senate rackets committee.
Dr. Alberto Lleras Camargo President of Colombia, arrived in New York for a three-day visit yesterday, bringing messages of goodwill and cooperation delivered in fluent English.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- House leaders cleared the way today for final passage of the civil-rights bill, but the scramble for political advantage was just beginning.

KANSAS CITY, Kan. April 11 (UPI) -- The president of the 160,000-member International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, Iron Shipbuilders and Blacksmiths announced today his endorsement of Senator Stuart Symington's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

ALGIERS, April 11 -- Premier Michel Debre of France came to Algeria today for a three-day visit amid signs that the nationalist rebels had planned to greet him with a series of spectacular terrorist attacks.

Net income of the Hidden Splendor Mining Company for the quarter ended on Dec. 31 was $1,434,922, or 35 cents a common share. The report is the first since it became publicly owned.

White, Weld Co. and associates are offering today $18,000,000 of 5 1/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of National Fuel Gas Company due in April, 1985. The debentures are priced at 101.058 per cent to yield 5.05 per cent to investors.

Governor Rockefeller's signature on a bill significantly increasing state aid to public libraries missed by only a few days being a tenth anniversary celebration of Governor Dewey's signing of the first state-aid-to-libraries bill, on April 1, 1950. NICE, France, April 11 -- In a day or two, Marcel Cerdan Jr., 16 years old, will begin training for his second amateur fight, now being arranged for the end of this month or the beginning of May.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- New York's two largest banks are objecting to the language bank mergers.
MOSCOW, April 11 -- The windows of Moscow are opening again.

LOGAN, W. Va., April 11 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, exuberant over the reception of his Presidential campaign in West Virginia, said today that "we're starting here like we finished up in Wisconsin."

NEW YORK'S shop windows are filled with Easter trinkets, from chocolate bunnies to frivolous hats. Some of the most ornate and imaginative have been created from the simplest Easter symbol -- the egg.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 -- Princeton University has promoted twelve faculty members to the rank of professor, Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of the university, announced today.

Passover, the week-long festival that memorializes the liberation of the ancient Israelites from Egyptian bondage, began at sundown last night.

Six working mothers who will solicit funds from fellow employes for the Greater. New York Fund took a trip yesterday to see where the money goes. It goes, they found, for Ketchup and psychology, among other things.

New York University's Bowling team is not considered a varsity team on the Violet campus, but it's a national championship squad. And the members of the team are going after the national singles title in a tournament to be staged this month and next.

Thomas M. Graham, in association with Maxwell E. Miller, has purchased the ten-story apartment building at 105 East Fifteenth Street. They plan to rehabilitate the seventy-six-suite building, including the installation of automatic elevators and a new heating system.

A series of conferences to determine the final Western stand at the East-West summit begins in Washington today with a meeting between the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France. Shirley Temple will be the hostess and occasional star of a series of fairy tales and classic stories, to be dramatized next season on Sundays from 7 to 8 P.M. over the National Broadcasting Company television network.

A FATHER who comes between his daughter and her best friend gets a warm reception at a Family Day at Folk Dance House, 108 West Sixteenth Street. David Fox, his daughter Sally, 8, and Toni Squitieri, 8, come from New Canaan, Conn., to attend these monthly shindigs.
CLAIBORNE, Ala., April 11 -- Two questions are bothering everybody around the Claiborne Hunting Club right now: Whether there are more wild turkeys than ever this year, and what goes into latlooly.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., April 11 -- Vice President Nixon said today that Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts could clinch the Democratic Presidential nomination by winning the West Virginia primary on May 10.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads estimated today the net income of Class I lines for February at $28,000,000. This compared with a net of $22,000,000 in February last year and contrasted to a deficit of $10,000,000 in the 1958 month.

CLEVELAND, April 11 -- A scientist predicted here today that geochemists working in land-locked laboratories would beat oceanographers, drilling miles into the sea floor, in explaining the Mohorovicic Discontinuity.
Directors of the Washington Bridge League have tabled a motion to permit all members of the American Contract Bridge League to play in the summer nationals in the national capital in August, 1961.

PITTSBURGH, April 11 (UPI) -- The head of a cancer research and treatment institute in Buffalo, N.Y., testified today that cigarette smokers had a greater chance of developing lung cancer than persons who do not smoke.
GENEVA, April 11 -- The West, standing firm on the step-by-step disarmament plan rejected by Moscow, settled down today to a taut sort of waiting game with the Russians.
As in recent months, the National Association of Purchasing Agents has reported once again in its latest survey that business was good. There were, however, a number of disappointments.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 11 -- A conference of 300 delegates from fifty African and Asian countries opened today in Conakry, the capital of Guinea. It will be asked to consider a resolution demanding independence for all African lands by 1962, a conference spokesman said.
ELIZABETH LAWRENCE has stepped in where veteran retailers fear to tread. She has opened a custom dress shop.

Business men negotiating office leases in new as well as in old buildings are showing considerably more confidence in escalator clauses than they did fifteen years ago, when that contract device was first used, a specialist in leasing reports.
TUNIS, April 11 -- The nationalist Provisional Government of Algeria announced here today that it was ready to accept volunteers from any country to help wage the war against France in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Senate gave John L. McClellan ten months' stand-by authority today to investigate rackets through his Government Operations Committee.
LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- William Saroyan advised fifteen drama critics today they were mistaken about his new play "Sam, the Highest Jumper of Them All, or the London Comedy."

BALTIMORE, Md., April 11 -- The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission rejected tonight suggestions that the Government and the advertising industry hold hands to avoid embarrassing publicity on illegal advertising.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Two high midwestern officials of the International Longshoremen's Association repudiated today any attempt by a Chicago Teamster Union official to assume power over Great Lakes docks.

La Compagnie des Machines Bull will sever its relationship with the Remington Rand division of the Sperry Rand Corporation after July 31. In making the announcement, Dause L. Bibby, executive vice president of Remington Rand, said yesterday:
A Question About Writers When professional writers go on strike -- as they did in Hollywood -- they run the risk of raising an awkward question: Are professional writers necessary?

PARIS, April 11 -- A new trans-Atlantic economic organization with powers of decision is recommended in a report completed today by four "wisemen" acting on behalf of eighteen European nations and the United States and Canada.

IN ninth century Rome, the Pope's Easter dinner centered on roast lamb. There is no proof that this was the first time the meat became associated with the holiday but it does indicate that lamb is traditional for Easter.
IN "The Enchanted," which began last night, on "The Play of the Week" over Channel 13, Jean Giraudoux manages primarily only to Gallicize the art of confusion.
LOS ANGELES, April 11 -- Otis Chandler, 32 years old, was named today as publisher of The Los Angeles Times -- the fourth in its seventy-nine-year history.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, today called Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, "a Monday morning quarter-back" for criticizing the Treasury's handling of last week's long-term bond offering.
Two Brooklyn fuel oil dealers pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to charges of conspiring to bribe two former inspectors in the Bureau of Weights and Measures.
Three Saturday night track and field fixtures at Madison Square Garden have been shifted to Friday night dates because of the Garden's commitment to stage Saturday fights for television in 1961.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 11 (AP) -- Profits of E.L. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., for the first quarter of 1960 might be slightly below those of last year because of many price reductions, stockholders were told at the annual meeting today.
ROME, April 11 -- Under heavy fire from the left wing of his own Christian Democratic party. Premier Fernando Tambroni and his Government resigned this evening.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 11 -- There are a number of good reasons why the Red Sox may run into a lot of trouble this year. Jackie Jensen, their slugging outfielder, and Sammy White, a catcher, have retired, and Ted Williams has a pain in the neck.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming started today a permanent list of "diploma mills" in this country. He listed about thirty names.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The recent news item concerning the influx of Taiwan-printed copies of copyrighted American textbooks and best sellers is but a single dramatic instance of the impact of our copyright law. It highlights among other things the conflict between "cheap books" and the constitutional monopoly for the encouragement of authors and publishers.
The Federal Trade Commission is expected to undertake soon the task of policing co-operative advertising practices more rigidly.

Isaac Logart, the Cuban punching machine, celebrated his birthday last night by scoring an unanimous ten-round decision over Candy McFarland, a Philadelphia welterweight, in the main bout at St. Nicholas Arena.

TOKYO, April 7 -- Capacity audiences in Tokyo's huge Kabuki Theatre, the cathedral of the popular Japanese classical drama, are seeing a rare and spectacular ceremony this month. It is the actual proclamation, between acts of the regular program, of an addition to the small and exclusive roster of the recognized great performers of all time in this medium.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- Trade interest in grain futures centered today on new crop wheat months as dealers apparently expected a slightly bullish government report on 1960 yield.

ON Sunday the last of the network bridge programs was shown, ending the first season-long series in which contract bridge has been presented on television. (There were two network radio shows that ran long series, but not before this winter season has contract bridge had a television show.)

Trading in commodity futures was unusually dull and featureless yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices drifted aimlessly and irregularly. Wool and copper rose; cocoa, hides, rubber and sugar declined, and price movements for potatoes, coffee and cottonseed oil were mixed.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., denied yesterday in Federal Court that he had intended to make a false incometax return for his wife, Hazel Scott, when he filed her 1951 accounting for her in September, 1952.
Three city officials joined yesterday in warning builders against cluttering sidewalks and roadways in front of their projects with building materials and equipment.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Treasury bill rate rose by nearly a full percentage point this week from last week's level, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
TRENTON, April 11 -- Steady increases in municipal tax rates reflect an inflation spiral set in motion by heavy non-military spending by the Federal Government, Robert Morris declared today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that he has drafted legislation to provide aid for families of the nineteen Navy bandsmen who died in an air crash Feb. 25 over Rio de Janeiro.
DETROIT, April 11 (AP) -- Auto production has started a slide which, with occasional interruptions, probably will continue until the 1960 model run ends.

Banton L. Wyckoff, operator of a number of rundown tenements, was indicted yesterday along with an oil-burner company on charges of filing false statements with the Federal Housing Administration to obtain loans.
JERUSALEM, April 11 -- For L100 Israeli -- $55.55 at the official rate of exchange -- an Ethiopian this morning gained title to all the Israeli Government's leaven.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Amon the highly visible effects of a Presidential election year is the exta influence which certain lobbies acquire over Congressional action. These lobbies are the promoters of legislation granting subsidies to large population groups which are represented as ready to vote solidly in November for or against Congressional and Presidential candidates on the test of their attitude toward the Federal expenditure proposed.
A 26-year-old probationary policewoman, Vittoria Renzullo, received the Frank J. Keeler trophy yesterday for the student with the highest academic average at the Police Academy. Her average was 96.

NEWARK, April 11 -- Senator Clifford P. Case declared today that the Republican party was split because of an "irreconcilable McKinleyite" faction that wished to return the party to the "dark ages" of American history.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 -- President Eisenhower began his spring vacation today with a round of golf with Arnold Palmer, whose sensational finish yesterday won him the Masters Tournament here. Immediately on meeting Mr. Palmer the President congratulated him on his victory.

Let no one believe that the paltry refugee relief bill passed in an offhand manner by the House the other day can relieve this country of its responsibilities or can protect us from the charge that we are shirking our duty toward the homeless victims of political persecution.
The above advertisement on behalf of E.L. Anderson Rye or Bourbon ($2.90 a gallon) appeared sixty-six years ago. That accounts for the remarkable price.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd, reflecting the public optimism of the British Government, said today that he foresaw an easing of world tensions as a result of the summit meeting in Paris next month.

THE man who stepped up to South Africa's Prime Minister on Saturday, called his name softly and then fired two bullets into the head of Hendrik F. Verwoerd does not fit the stereotype of the wild-eyed assassin.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of April 7 "Result: Negative," commenting on the outcome of the Wisconsin primary elections, was in one sense itself negative. Among other things, it stated: "Wisconsin's primary did something else that was also negative.
HULL, Que., April 11 (Canadian Press) -- Eddy Paper Company, Ltd., and subsidiaries cleared $1,834,127, or $4.59 a share in 1959, compared with $1,987,236, or $4.97 a share, in 1958.
The rapid expansion of junior colleges is expected to play a vital role in providing higher education for a college populaion that may double in the next ten years, according to a new study.
ALEKSANDER KOBZDEJ, who believes that the only mission of a painter is to communicate in an "intimate manner," is the first avant-garde Polish artist to visit New York and show his work here.

Harvard, according to the consensus of the coaches attending the first rowing luncheon of the season at Leone's Restaurant yesterday, should be the eight-oared varsity heavyweight crew of the East to beat this year.

I HAVE an infamous army, very weak and ill-equipped, and a very inexperienced staff," the Duke of Wellington wrote a friend not long before the battle. In combat, however, that force was useful enough to make him a rather prominent figure in John Naylor's new book, "Waterloo."*
Vice President Nixon and some 175,000 other baseball fans are expected to turn out today for the start of the National League's eighty-fifth season.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 11 -- For twenty years the guy's been an enigma. And so help us, he still is.

Joseph L. Mankiewicz, a top Hollywood director-scenarist and winner of four Oscars (two for direction and two for scenarios), has yet to make his Broadway bow, either as a dramatist or director. He has attempted to in the past, but things did not work out to his satisfaction.

Columbia posted its fourth straight baseball victory by defeating the University of Vermont, 13-3, at Baker Field yesterday. The undefeated Lions unleashed a thirteen-hit attack, including a two-run homer by Tom Vasell, a sophomore third baseman.
Following is the text of a statement read by Adlai E. Stevenson, former Democratic Presidential candidate, at a news conference here on his return from a tour of Latin America:
SEOUL, Korea, April 11 -- Bloody political riots broke out again last night in Masan, a troubled port city in southern Korea.

Three all-America performers, a 7-foot 3-inch Frenchman and a 6-foot 9-inch center from the University of Hawaii were among the 101 college players selected yesterday in the National Basketball Association's annual draft.

The story of a young Austrian Jew who fled Nazi persecution in his homeland and practiced medicine in the jungle is told in "Doctor in Bolivia," which the Chilton Company of Philadelphia will publish April 21.
The city's move to consolidate and invigorate its slum clearance and housing programs received a setback yesterday.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., April 11 -- Senator John F. Kennedy found West Virginia's political trails rough and treacherous today.

Directors of the Horn Hardart Company, New York, have elected William J. Curtis president and director and president of the Horn Hardart Baking Company, Philadelphia. He also is a director of the baking company.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points down to 5 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

HAVANA, April 11 -- Pledges of the fullest support to Premier Fidel Castro in his fight against "Yankee imperialism" were made last night by delegates from fifteen foreign countries at the final session of Cuba's Communist Youth Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- A winter wheat crop of 977,000,000 bushels -- 6 per cent above last year's crop but 17 per cent below the record one in 1958 -- was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 -- Golf's greatest show will be back in town next year. No one is certain who the hero will be, but that does not matter. The Masters cast is always star studded; the script always exciting.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 11 -- Members of the Government emphasized today that the policies of Prime Minister Hendrik F. Vetwoerd would continue unchanged despite the attempt on his life.
