WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI) -- The Treasury today retreated from the stand it took eight months ago in favor of slapping an additional $46,000,000 a year in taxes on United States corporations with foreign subsidiaries.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Four men accused of posing as teamster union officials to extort money for unloading interstate shipments of meat here were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

Six persons, including the assistant principal of a Brooklyn public school, were arrested yesterday and charged with preparing or offering to prepare term papers and theses for master's or doctoral degrees for college students.

ALBANY, April 11 -- The State Tax Department estimated today that net income-tax revenue for the fiscal year just ended probably would run only about $11,000,000 over Governor Rockefeller's revised figure of $735,000,000.
A disagreement over the extent to which the $86,460,000 Jamaica racetrack housing project should receive tax benefits stalled approval of the program by the Board of Estimate yesterday.
Two independent directors whose initial films have aroused Speculation about an "American new wave" are preparing second projects to give the movement an additional push.

The purchase by the Underwood Corporation of the Olivetti Corporation of America in a deal representing more than $30,000,000 has been approved by the boards of both companies, it was announced yesterday.
A 40-year-old father, trapped on a Bronx roof as he held a knife against the throat of an 8-year-old girl, was arrested last night as a suspect in a series of sex assaults in the last six months.
First-quarter sales and earnings of the General Electric Company were slightly lower than in the 1959 period, Ralph Cordiner, chairman, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- Officials of two coal groups and an independent petroleum producers' association today criticized the decision of the Department of the Interior to permit a 12,000,000-barrel increase in residual oil imports in the next three months.

For seven days the tenants of a neglected building in Brooklyn groped their way to their apartments through hallways and up stairs lighted only by four flickering candles. Yesterday the candles were called a fire hazard by a city inspector and the windowless halls and stairs were plunged into darkness.
CHICAGO, Wednesday, April 13 -- Otto Kerner, candidate of the machine run by Mayor Richard J. Daley, scored a run-away victory early today in the Democratic gubernatorial primary.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals rejected today a request that it order the United States to halt nuclear tests.

The "My Fair Lady" company bound for a Russian tour got off last night at 9:15 o'clock after having been forced to return to New York International Airport three hours earlier because its K.L.M. plane developed engine trouble.

IT was only a small provincial university in the Midlands, but Stuart Treece was as happy there as he could have been anywhere in 1955 or thereabouts Stuart was 39 and head of the English Department. He was a bachelor whom women had always wanted to mother, a liberal and an intellectual whose mind had been formed in the Nineteen Thirties, when ideas were still important.

Signs of economic improvement have been spotted on the agricultural front by the American Farm Bureau Federation. In Washington yesterday, the big farm organization said that prices of farm products were on the rise and that producers were adjusting hog and egg production downwards and holding the line on dary output.

RABAT, Morocco, April 12 -- The decision by the Algerian Nationalist Provisional Government to accept foreign volunteers to reinforce its five-year-old rebellion against France will create difficult problems for Tunisia and Morocco.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 -- The world-champion Los Angeles Dodgers resumed their storybook ways tonight to whip the Chicago Cubs, 3 -- 2, in an eleven-inning National League opener. Chuck Essegian, a pinch-hitter de luxe, broke it up with a home run with two out in the last half of the eleventh.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation attained record first-quarter sales, shipments and earnings in the first three months of 1960, the nation's fourth largest steel producer reported yesterday. Avery C. Adams, chairman and president, said the results were the second highest for any three-month period in the company's 108 year-history.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Six labor unions asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to disapprove an Expanded strike insurance pact made by nine carriers.

Like the leaders of the West, the Communist rulers are also preparing for the summit, but not by diplomatic discussions; instead, by atomic brinkmanship and an intensified sovietization of East Germany. They are apparently determined to show the West that, with the Soviet's intent on defending East Germany's "social gains," German reunification in freedom is no longer possible.
CARACAS, Venezuela, April 12 -- A plan covering Government expenditures from 1960 to 1964 will be presented to the Venezuelan Congress this month by President Romulo Betancourt.

THE biggest show in town is on the faces of children at the circus. Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey have again taken over Madison Square Garden. There are two shows daily, at 2 and 8:30 P. M., except for next Monday through Thursday (April 18-21), when the evening show will be replaced by one at 10 A. M. Admission ranges from $2 to $6.50.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The grain futures market reacted generally today to constructive trade interpretations of the Government report on stocks of grains on farms as of April 1.
TORONTO, April 12 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens routed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 2, tonight and took a 3-0 lead in the Stanley Cup final play-offs.

PARIS. Almost exactly five years ago delegates from twenty-nine nations met at Bandung, in Indonesia, and formed the Afro-Asian bloc. This group is still far from coordinated and contains neutralist, pro-Communist and pro-democratic governments.
Forty-two qualifying sections have been established to pick the 150 entries for the thirty-fifth national public links golf championship, the United States Golf Association announced yesterday.

Patrons have been announced for the gala opening of the American Ballet Theatre's twentieth anniversary season at the Metropolitan Opera House next Tuesday. Mrs. Frederick B. Payne is chairman for the event, a benefit for the company.
Last night the Metropolitan Opera presented its final "Andrea Chemer" of the season, with five artists singing their roles for the first time with the company.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- House investigators disclosed today that they were checking other gas-rate cases involving possible off-the-record approaches to the Federal Power Commission.
CLEVELAND, April 12 -- Birth-control pills for men will probably be developed from chemicals used to fight cancer and bacterial infections, a scientist
YESTERDAY (April 12, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Continues golfing Holiday at Augusta, Ga.
LONDON, April 12 -- With demand remaining small and selective, a dribble of selling grain depressed stock market prices here today.
The scholarship fund of Skidmore College will be the beneficiary of the April 29 performance of the After Dinner Opera Company, a touring group that gives light operas in English.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 12 -- The Yankees today got their first glimpse of the Indians, rated by many as the second most formidable rival they'll have to face this year. What they saw left Casey Stengel wondering what they ed ball players in Arizona, where the Tribe did its training.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- Vice President Nixon today dedicated the Giants' new $15,000,000 home and called it "the greatest baseballl park in America -- a magnificent stadium in which to have a world series."

CINCINNATI, April 12 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Reds spotted the Philadelphia Phils four runs today and then rallied with the help of homers by Roy McMillan and a rookie, Tony Gonzalez, for a 9-4 victory.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The manufacturer of Viscount airliners threatened today to foreclose the mortgage it holds on Capital Airlines fleet of ninety-six planes.

FOR various reasons it took Spain a little longer than most European countries to enter the international art race with her own avantgarde painters. But now, fully launched, Spanish artists are receiving their full portion of attention.
The Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company borrowed $40,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday at an interest cost to the company of about 4.91 per cent.
GENEVA, April 12 -- The United States proposed today that Soviet and Western nuclear scientists meet in Geneva beginning May 11 to outline a coordinated program of research.
MONTREAL, April 12 (Canadian Press) -- The syndicate handling the $15,000,000 of debentures of Dominion Tar and Chemical Company, Ltd., announced today offering of the issue to the public.
Net assets of the Lazard Fund, Inc., declined $3,280,791 in the twelve months ended March 31, This was disclosed in the quarterly report released yesterday by the big mutual fund.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 12 -- The International Court of Justice ruled today that India acted within her rights in 1954 when she barred a Portuguese delegation from going to two enclaves where Indian crowds were seizing control.
CLAIBORNE, Ala., April 12 -- This was the day for seeing the panther, but nobody saw him. It was a shame, too, because this panther has got to be verified and documented and nailed down beyond cavil.

Potato futures prices tumbled in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May position dropped 35 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) during trading, the daily limit from the settlement price on Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations announced its opposition today to a plan of liberal Republicans for voluntary health insurance for the aged.

H.M. Horner, chairman, told stockholders of the United Aircraft Corporation yesterday that he did not think directors would feel it necessary to reduce the present 52 dividend. He made the statement in reply to a shareholder.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Word has been passed to mine union leaders in West Virginia that John L. Lewis would like to see the defeat of Senator John F.Kennedy in that state's Democratic Presidential primary on May 10.
BOSTON, April 12 -- Dr. John D. Black, economist, who was Henry Lee Professor Emeritus at Harvard University, died here today. He was a resident of Belmont, and was 72 years old.

Hayden, Stone Co., investment bankers, have leased 40,000 square feet of space in the forty-story office building being constructed by Samuel Rudin at 80 Pine Street. The lessees will continue their main office at 25 Broad Street and will occupy the additional space next month for their clerical and service facilities.
The Federal Trade Commission yesterday announced legal actions Involving five corporations accused of either giving or receiving discriminatory advertising or promotion payments.

The Erie Railroad's March earnings results will not be available for another week, but stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday were told "advance figures" indicated that operations were in the black.
Guy Lombardo said yesterday he was planning to re-enter speed-boat racing this spring.

St. John's defeated Fordhan University, 4 -- 3, at Jack Coffey Field yesterday in a Metropolitan Collegiate Conference baseball game. The Redmen got only one hit -- Artie Beato's two run double In the first inning after a pair of walks.
CHICAGO, April 12 -- A substance formed in the process of muscle fatigue has been shown to hamper the growth of animal cancer.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 12 -- Chuck Davis yielded only a pair of first-inning singles that led to an unearned run and struck out fourteen in pitching Navy to a 6-1 baseball victory over Bucknell today. It was the fourth straight triumph for the middies.
GENEVA, April 12 -- United Nations economists urged the industrial countries of Western Europe today to fight inflation by welcoming imports from the United States.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 12 -- Adlai E. Stevenson returned to the political wars tonight with a sizzling attack on the Eisenhower Administration.

No problem of United States relations within the hemisphere in decades has proved more difficult or more important than Cuban-American relations. It should by now be clear that no simple, easy or quick formula can be evolved. There is a long, stormy period ahead, comparable in some ways to the problem that existed in more or less acute form for about thirty years after the Mexican Revolution began in 1910.

WHEN word was passed, about a year ago, that for the first time track and field qualification standards had been set for the 1960 Olympics, the spiked-shoe set was seized by an acute attack of the heebie-jeebies.
MILWAUKEE, April 12 (UPI) -- Joe Adcock hit a two-run homer in the eighth Inning today, enabling the Milwaukee Braves to gain a 4-3 opening-day victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates before 39,888 fans.

The bond market threw off yesterday the spasm of discouragement that seized it on Monday. But this was not until after the two new issues of Treasury notes and bonds had drifted to new lows, and new corporate telephone company bonds of top grade had been priced to yield materially more than the levels of a week ago.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 12 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today that the nation's economy was moving forward at a snail's pace as the Eisenhower Administration remained "frozen in the ice of its own indifference."
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 9 -- Under the corrosive impact of the segregation issue, Alabama's political and social structure appears to be developing symptoms of disintegration.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 12 (AP) -- Arthur B. Homer, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said today that first-quarter earnings should be "pretty good," and 1960 earnings might be, too.
The Cuban Government has sent a photograph of Premier Fidel Castro to a Brooklyn junior high school pupil as "a token of his friendship for you and your fellow countrymen."
"Broadway seems to have died," Brian Aherne said yesterday in lamenting the fact that no new playhouses are being constructed to replace the rickety, outmoded theatres of today.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- When Adlai Stevenson arrived at the University of Virginia today, the student newspaper ran a full-page ad endorsing him for the Presidency.
MOSCOW, April 12 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that protests from Bonn would not blunt its propaganda campaign against the West German Government and Chancellor Adenauer himself.
THE following dinner menu is a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipeis given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

Manassa Mauler won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The event was a mere $7,500 purse called the East Hills, but Manassa Mauler won it with the same drive and courage that enebled him to take the Wood Megnorial last April 18.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter published in your columns March 31 Paul Blanshard discusses certain aspects of freedom in Spain. He writes: "No Protestant church or Jewish synagogue for Spaniards is allowed to look like a church or a synagogue, or to carry any label or sign identifying itself."

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Reversal of the nation's long standing policy, prohibiting railroads from owning competing water carriers would "ultimately lead to the destruction" of the waterway industry, L.P. Struble, president of Union Barge Line Corporation of Pittsburgh, testified today.

With Easter vacation under way for many college students in the city, six police officers and a private investigator were just at the start yesterday of a course of their own. They rose in time for an 8 A. M. class at the National Training Center of Lie Detection.

NORMAN, Okla., April 12 (AP) -- J.D. Martin surpassed the world pole vault record today with a leap of 15 feet 9 3/4 inches, but there was some doubt that his achievement would be accepted as a world mark.
NEWARK, April 12 -- The six Junior Leagues of northern New Jersey are planning a Junior League Symphony Night on Tuesday at the Mosque Theatre here.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, April 12 -- The new season at the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre here got into its full stride tonight with a distinguished performance of "The Merchant of Venice," which, in spite of its preposterous plot, should have the most sure grip on the public favor of any of the Shakespeare comedies.
The number of persons injured in city traffic decreased last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- An increase of 600,000 classrooms in ten years and a 50 per cent rise in teachers' salaries in five years were accepted today as national goals for education by the first conference on such goals.

Yesterday's Government report on labor market trends last month is less than pleasant reading. Contrary to normal seasonal fluctuations for March, the number employed fell by a quarter of a million persons, while the number of unemployed rose by 275,000. Moreover, the average work week declined somewhat to 39.6 hours, while the number of persons unemployed fifteen weeks or longer rose by 250,000 to 1,217,000.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 12 -- The Bergen County tax for 1959 apportioned to the village of Ridgefield Park was declared unconstitutional today. The decision by Superior Court Judge Donald M. Waesche is expected to affect county taxes through out the state.
The first municipal garage in the city's long-range, off-street parking program was opened formally yesterday at Jay Street and Myrtle Avenue in downtown Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI) -- A New York physician told Senate investigators today that some of the newly developed wonder drugs had caused liver disease and jaundice in some patients.
Former President Harry S. Truman came to New York yesterday and said he had made no choice for the Democratic nomination for President.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 11 -- Irritation has been growing among business men here over the increasingly close watch maintained by the United States over "strategic" goods imported from the United States.
With 55 per cent of New York State's population counted, Census Bureau officials estimated yesterday that the state had 16,500,000 persons.
The Port of New York Authority will go before the House Appropriations Committee today for $5,722,900 to cover the cost of ten harbor improvement projects.

The city's polio immunization program saved 162 lives and prevented 3,368 cases of the disease in the four years following its inception in 1955, Health Commissioner Leona Baumgartner told Mayor Wagner yesterday.

Both the Federal and New York State governments will impose penalties on persons who fail to file their personal income tax returns by the deadline on Friday. There are, however, instances of emergency that both governments recognize as sufficient reason for late filing and for which the penalties are waived.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Arab diplomats expect a new wave of violence in Algeria.

HORACE STONEHAM, the owner of the Giants, had reason to beam with delight at Candlestick Park yesterday. The gala opening of San Francisco's new ball park represented a thumping endorsement of his decision three years ago to move to the Far West.
BONN, Germany, April 12 -- Chancellor Adenauer warned his countrymen today that the Big Four powers might make a summit agreement at Germany's expense.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points off to 2 points up yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale).

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Defense Department published a report today that favors Air Force contracts with commercial airlines for most passenger and cargo flights now operated by the Military Air Transport Service.
A sober warning that the economic situation in Latin America was increasingly critical was issued here last night by President Alberto Lleras Camargo of Colombia.
CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here By the Department of Agriculture follows:
GENEVA, April 12 -- The average consumer was much better off in Communist Eastern Europe last year, experts of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.
Automation is playing an increasingly important role at the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Man has begun his first system atie search for messages from other worlds.
ALBANY, April 12 -- Governor Rockefeller expressed support today for Southern Negroes in lunch-counter sitdown strikes and Northern white students holding sympathy demonstrations.
Most of the high-flying "romance stocks" soared again yesterday in a quiet session of the New York Stock Exchange in which the standard investment issues did little.
ALGIERS, April 12 -- Premier Michel Debre of France declared in a broadcast tonight that Algeria would be partitioned if a majority of Algerians voted for independence.
WARSAW, April 12 -- Reports published today indicated that Poland might suffer a major crop disaster this year.

The property now occupied by a parking lot at 111 to 121 Third Avenue, between Thirteenth and Fourteenth Streets, has been sold by Fred H. Hill to Asher Dann Sons, builders, for improvement with a nine-territory apartment house.

The Travelers Aid Society of New York will benefit from a cocktail-dance-buffet supper, to be held at the new United Air Lines Jet Terminal at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, as part of the official dedication ceremonies on May 10.

NO matter how breathtakingly successful tonight's world premiere of the New York City Ballet's "Figure in the Carpet" is, it cannot surpass the brilliance of the many figures behind "The Carpet" and that of one woman in particular.

THERE are so many reasons for bridge players to remember Sidney Lenz, who died yesterday, that they could hardly be enumerated in a limited space. But probably bridge literature will longest record his application of the word "squeeze" to the play that earlier generations had called, unimaginatively, "forcing discards."
The observance of Africa Freedom Day comes at an electric moment in the spectacular evolution of a once-dark continent toward the sunlight of human dignity and independence.
Dr. Barbara Moore, the walking Englishwoman, arrived here yesterday by ship and departed for California by jet for a 3,200-mile walk back.

The New Jersey 500 national sports car rally last week-end was a difficult one both for drivers and navigators. There were many open check points, a number of hidden ones, and the average mileage was high enough, for the most part, to keep the teams on their toes.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Treasury asked the money market for $2,000,000,000 of one-year money today, and the money market responded -- at a price of 4.6 per cent.
LAKELAND, Fla., April 12 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers today traded Steve Demeter, a 25-year-old third baseman, to the Cleveland Indians for Norman Cash, a 25-year-old outfielder-first baseman.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 12 -- The advantage of starting from the rail in the season's first $25,000 free-for-all pace Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway will belong to Owen F. Elliott's Widower Creed.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N. J., April 12 -- Senator Clifford P. Case said here tonight that the fight by the President and the Republican minority in Congress against inflation might have at last brought that situation under control.

Mayor Wagner stood up before a City Hall sports meeting yesterday and drove his announcement right out of the park. New York, he said, definitely will have the long-talked-about $15,000,000 sports stadium in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens.
SOMERVILLE, N. J., April 12 -- Robert Morris hopped a train today to carry his fight for the Republican nomination for United States Senator directly to the commuters.

SEA CLIFF, N.Y., April 12 -- Thirteen-year-old Dean Siering, who talked his way into a free 1,500-mile trip by train and plane to Chicago and back to Buffalo over the week-end, returned to his home today.
SURGIDERO DE BATA-BANO, Cuba, April 7 -- The fishing cooperative organized here by the National Institute of Agrarian Reform has brought hope and prosperity to this ancient village.

RICHARD CASS, in his first New York appearance since 1957, gave a piano recital last night in Carnegie. Hall before a large and enthusiastic audience. And there was much in the young pianist's playing to arouse that enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Employment and unemployment took a decided turn for the worse last month, primarily because the weather was generally the most severe of any March since 1941, the Labor Department said today.

In his annual message to the City Council last week Mayor Wagner set for his administration a number of "goals for 1960." Among them was: "To move forward on a master plan for the zoning of the city, with assurance that the views of the people will be fully considered before final action is taken."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Encouraged by the comments of several qualified listeners, I submit a proposal in respect of sub-Saharan Africa. The rapidity with which so many communities of that continent are becoming independent nations and the short span within which this is being accomplished present an opportunity to the world unique in modern times.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France met today and called for a settlement of world problems by negotiation, not force.

The acquisition or a 126-acre site in the Hunts Points area of the Bronx for a new wholesale fruit and vegetable market has been informally approved by the Board of Estimate, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
Mayor Wagner assigned J. Clarence Davies Jr. yesterday to consolidate and revitalize the city's dormant slum-clearance and housing programs.

Two books by General de Gaulle will be published a day apart. One is the third and final volume of "The War Memoirs of Charles de Gaulle: Salvation 1944-46." It begins with the Free French taking over France's Government and ends \vith the general's retirement in 1946.

GASTRONOMICALLY, Manhattan is like the land of Cockaine, the fabled Utopia where fish jump out of the water and into the frying pan. Where else but on this island can a telephone call produce a fillet of kangaroo, a Burma jungle fowl or a whole bear for a charcoal spit?
Igor Stravinsky, the composer, and George Balanchine, the choreographer, will create for television a contemporary music and dance work based on the Biblical story of Noah.
Six historians and scholars have been appointed to an editorial advisory committee to serve as consultants to the editors of the Woodrow Wilson papers.
MADRID, April 12-Spanish political prisoners began a hunger strike today in Carabanchel prison on the outskirts of Madrid in protest against recent brutality by prison guards.
A statue: of a Cuban hero, Jose Julian Marti, has been sitting for five months in a Bronx yard because the Department of Parks refuses to allow it in Central Park.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 12 (UPI) -- Darrell Ducat James Dovas of Toledo, bowling together for the first time, rolled a 1,294 series today to for fourth place in the doubles at the American Bowling Congress tournament.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The decision of the Liberal party to renominate Ludwig Teller for Congress provoked a statement by Thomas Finletter that the Liberal party's action wag based on "a narrow view." I should like to bring out some pertinent facts which will prove that our decision is fully justified and in the public interest.

Four times within a stroke of defeat in the third set, Dwight F. Davis 3d fought his way to a surprising victory over Charlie Petrosky yesterday as the United States open court tennis championship began at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
The plight of Negroes in South Africa and the southern United States was related by three rabbis yesterday to that of the ancient Israelites in Egyptian bondage.
The West Central Texas Municipal Water District borrowed $9,000,000 yesterday on serial bonds secured by general taxation and special revenues. The borrowing cost 3.988 per cent in interest.
HAVANA, April 12 -- President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado renewed charges today that an international conspiracy was afoot against the regime of Premier Fidel Castro.
The United States Freight Company canceled plans yesterday to buy a 25 per cent interest in American Export Lines.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 12 -- The South African Government announced today that it would embark on a large-scale program to attract white immigrants.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator John F. Kennedy is counting on considerable labor support in West Virginia's Democratic Presidential primary on May 10 despite the opposition of mine union leaders there.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- Vice President Nixon, unopposed and without campaigning, polled 716,707 votes in yesterday's Illinois primary, final unofficial turns showed today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Health insurance coverage for retired employes and their families is expanding rapidly, insurance company executives said today, and new methods are being worked out to provide protection for elderly persons.
Former President Harry S. Truman walked nearly a mile here yesterday at a two-question-a-minute pace.

The Singer Manufacturing Company realized a 53 per cent increase in earnings last year on a sales gain of 11 per cent over the level of 1958, according to the annual report mailed yesterday to 11,000 shareholders.
THE PRESIDENT Continued golfing holiday at Augusta, Ga.
A nation-wide boycott of South Africa and South African goods was urged last night at an Africa Freedom Day rally in Town Hall.
MASAN, Korea, April 13 -- The tension that lies over the normally pleasant South Korean city of Masan is almost as palpable tonight as the clammy fog that obscures the beautiful harbor.

Enter a Visitor and Cigar The visitor entered eased himself into a chair, explored several pockets until from one he produced a cigar. He carefully peeled off the transparent wrapping and the red band before lighting the blunt end with a kitchen match, fired by a flick of his thumbnail.

ALFRED SHEINWOLD of New York became a colonel last week -- a Kentucky colonel. He went to Louisville to play in the Midwest Regional championships, and was rewarded with the keys to the city, a colonelcy on the staff of Gov. Bert E. Combs of Kentucky, and -- what is more important to a bridge player -- a victory in the Midwest team-of-four tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Since Robert A. Lovett testified before Senator Jackson's subcommittee several weeks ago, the impression has been growing that he definitely subscribed to some of the harshest criticisms of President Eisenhower and the National Security Council in their mutual relationship.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 13 -- The Dutch Reformed Church accused the Most Rev. Joost de Blank, Anglican Archbishop of Capetown, today of a "glaring injustice" and severed relations with him.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The political affiliation of Timothy J. Murphy, a Boston lawyer nominated to the Interstate Commerce Commission, will be studied by the Senate Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- A Congressional investigation of the handling by Federal Judge Dickinson F. Letts of the Teamsters Union-monitors case was asked today by Representative James Roosevelt, Democrat of California.
Robert Moses announced last night his acceptance of the offer to be president of the 1964 World's Fair in New York, effective May 15. The offer was made last month by the fair's board.
Directors of the Beech Aircraft Corporation will consider a stock split at a special meeting next Tuesday, Mrs. O.A. Beech, president, announced in Wichita, Kan., yesterday.

BOSTON, April 13 (AP) -- The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today raised the question whether mutual funds, thriving newcomers on the investment scene, have become captives of their advisory concerns.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 13 -- The Yankees broke camp and headed north today, with Casey Stengel admitting that several of his major problems for 1960 were still far from solved.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, April 6:
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 13 -- Governor Rockefeller issued a strong warning today against infiltration of Latin America by the Chinese Communists.
PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Vincent P. McDevitt, vice president and general counsel of the Philadelphia Electric Company, was elected to the company's board at today's annual meeting of stockholders.
BONN, Germany, April 13 -- The Federal Supreme Court reversed today a year-old criminal judgment against Herbert Blankenhorn, West Germany's Ambassador to France, who has been on enforced leave.

Harry MacNeill Bland, a retired dealer in Americana, and an authority on historic American prints, drawings, paintings, documents and books, died Tuesday in his home, 114 Morningside Drive, after a long illness. His age was 74.
WHITE PLAINS, April 13 -- Dr. Edwin G. Ramsdell, chief of staff of White Plains Hospital, died last night in his home at 14 Winslow Road after a long illness. He was 73 years old.
Many city churches will conduct services for Maundy Thursday today as the Lenten season moves to a close.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (UPI) -- Mike McCormick spun a three-hitter today and Willie Mays got four hits as the San Francisco Giants trounced the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 -- 1.

Joseph B. Rosenblatt, in association with Louis Broido, bought the eighty-four-year leasehold on the six-story building at 315 East Sixty-second Street, near Second Avenue. They plan to remodel the structure for occupancy by tenants in the furniture and decorative arts fields, Mr. Rosenblatt said the remodeling would take about six months.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 13 (AP) -- Cash from the sale of its properties will be used by the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway to enter another field of business, the line's stockholders were told yesterday.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 13 -- Almost 1,000 Africans milled about inside a hiring hall today looking for jobs in Capetown. Few jobs were available and the outlook was grim.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 13 -- Dutch Reformed leaders said today that they would welcome an investigation of the racial situation by the World Council of Churches.
Poetry reading is not oratory, a city magistrate ruled yesterday, whatever generations of school teachers and scholars may think of such poetic deliveries as Marc Antony's over Caesar's stabbed body.

Two infants died in a fire yesterday morning in a basement apartment at 590 West 187th Street. A third child was rescued by a neighbor who is a bartender at the Twenty One Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street.

Anybody who wants to register a Hungarian Vizsla or an Italian Spinone or a German Wachtel, all relatively obscure breeds of hunting dogs, can do so through a weekly newspaper called the American Field. It exists on the tenth floor of an office building at 222 West Adams Street Chicago, to keep followers of bird dogs informed and to maintain records.
STAUNTON, Va., April 13 (AP) -- Stockholders of A.S.R. Products Corporation, today approved its acquisition by Philip Morris, Inc., a major cigarette manfacturer.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is hopeful that two of its recent actions will check the inclination of "maverick" savings and loan associations to pay dividend rates out of line with those of other associations in their areas.

The warehouse containing 5,000 square feet of space at 163-10 South Road, Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by a client of Edward Wolff to an investor. The deal was negotiated by Balter Greenberg, Inc., brokers, who arranged a leaseback to the seller.

A book about the region now made up of Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska and Kansas has been written by Robert Athearn. To be called "High Country Empire," it will be published April 26 by McGraw-Hill.
MAR DEL-PLATA, Argentina, April 13 (AP) -- Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn moved into a first-place tie today in the international chess masters tournament.

LONDON, April 13 -- Stirling Moss, the runner-up for the 1959 world driving championship, was found guilty today of dangerous driving on a public highway. The British racing driver was fined u50 ($140) and his operator's license was suspended for twelve months.

LONDON, April 13 -- Britain announced today that she had abandoned the military development of the Blue Streak, the major weapon in her nuclear armory. The Blue Streak is a fixed-site ballistic missile with a 2,800-mile range.

The Long Island Rail Road resisted last year the nationwide railroad trend toward fewer and fewer passengers each year. It managed to increase its cash customers to 73,934,636 from 73,608,620, a rise of forty-four one-hundredths of 1 per cent, but important when measured against the 10.2 per cent drop in passengers handled by the three other largest passenger-carrying railroads in the East.
GENEVA, April 13 -- France, which carried out her first nuclear explosion only two months ago, warned today against the danger that other nations might acquire nuclear weapons.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 13 -- Tractors roared into action throughout Suffolk County today as potato farmers tried to make up for two weeks' delay in planting schedules. Two tractors and a truck were manned on most of the county's 600 potato farms.

TORONTO, April 13 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, needing only one more victory to win professional hockey's Stanley Cup for the fifth straight season, called off a morning workout today in protest of the early hour allotted by the Toronto management.

NEW HAVEN, April 13 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad said today it was preparing to seek another 10 per cent increase in commuter fares to New York City, before June 30. Commuter fares were raised 10 per cent Feb. 4.

Mayor Wagner has made such an excellent choice in J. Clarence Davies Jr. to be temporary chairman of the newly created Housing and Redevelopment Board that we have little doubt the appointment will become permanent. A real estate man with a heart, Mr. Davies brings to this job the integrity, the experience and the energy essential to the meeting of a challenging responsibility.
BONN, Germany, April 13 -- A West German official was asked today: How often do you think the Chancellor has to be reassured about the United States' intentions?
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The nation's active money supply apparently turned upward in March, ending a decline that began last August, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

"THE FIERCE LAMBS,"* by A.A. Hoehling, is an informal history of Americans at home and abroad in 1917, the year this country entered World War I wildly and enthusiastically unprepared for that great rendezvous with destiny.
An internal fight bubbled up yesterday within the Equity Corporation, a non-diversified, closed-end investment trust with ties to the banking, insurance, real estate, aircraft and other industries.

Irving Rivkin, Staten Island member of the City Tax Commission, accused the commission's president last night of "deliberate delay" and a "plot" to void reductions approved by Mr. Rivkin on Staten Island real estate assessments.
The Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority borrowed $20,000,000 in the public bond market here yesterday at an interest cost of 4.398 per cent.
THE New York City Ballet presented last night the principal novelty of its season at the City Center in the form of an hour-long ballet by George Balanchine called "The Figure in the Carpet."

A MAJORITY of women have a small but stubborn instinct about what clothes really look best on them. They are likely to resist, or at least challenge the opinions of a qualified male critic. Thirty-four-year-old Robert Mackintosh, a widely known designer for the theater and television, has coped with women and their wardrobes for years.

BY one standard, the exhibition of the Colin Collection, opening today at Knoedler's, is a hop, skip and jump affair. It includes a room full of Soutines -- sixteen of them -- and there are nine Dubuffets and nine Vuillards.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- New York waterway interests today sought a $1,500,000 Federal appropriation so that some economic return could be obtained from $23,000,000 already spent.

Battle lines are being drawn by Actors Equity to incorporate its demands in a new contract with the League of New York Theatres, which represents producers and theatre owners. The three-year agreement between both groups expires May 31.
Dwight F. Davis 3d was beaten in the United States open court tennis championship yesterday after he seemed to be headed for another highly creditable victory at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
The bond market registered yesterday a modest extension of Tuesday's price gains.

Edward Mulhare has decided tor make his next stage appearance in a straight part. There will be no songs for him to sing in "Memo for a Green Thumb," a comedy with melodramatic overtones, which is said to have "a very tricky plot."
A plan to divest Augusta Redman, a slum landlord, of direct control of her thirty properties was advanced in Housing Court yesterday by Paul Burt, her newly retained lawyer.
Over the years, Yale has been tougher for Columbia to beat than any of the Lions' other baseball opponents. And for ten and a third innings yesterday at Baker Field, the Eli was tough to beat.
Angry tenant groups charged yesterday that Martin Schulman, a real estate operator who trades in Greenwich Village apartment houses, had been seeking to evade state rent-control restrictions.

John J. Reynolds, a real estate man who has figured conspicuously in city realty deals for many years, charged yesterday that he had been "frozen out" of bidding for purchasing and developing the site of the Jamaica Race Track in Queens.

The scholarship fund maintained by New York alumnae of Mount Holyoke College will benefit from a tour on April 24 of five homes belonging to authorities in the field of interior design and decoration.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13 -- The United States and the Sudan proposed tonight that the United Nations Economic and Social Council call for "special efforts" to provide technical assistance for the newly independent states of Africa.

The courtrooms in and around Foley Square had among their spectators yesterday a group of ubiquitous spectators whose genius for finding seats has led them to brilliant careers in second-guessing the judge.
Caught without a trend in the middle of a holiday week, stocks moved uncertainly yesterday and closed virtually unchanged.
Dr. Alberto Lieras Camargo, President of Colombia, completed his New York visit yesterday with an optimistic smile but with serious words about Latin America in crisis.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Defense Department placed in orbit today an experimental space lighthouse to point the way to far more accurate navigation on earth.
CLEVELAND, April 13 (AP) -- The American Transit Association honored nineteen transit systems today for outstanding safety achievements during 1959.

IF it had not been for World War II, Dr. Richard Brandon Kershner would probably be stringing out yard-long mathematical equations today. Instead, he is developing the Transit space navigation system, whose first satellite was launched yesterday with more to come.
CLAIBORNE, Ala., April 13 -- Vanity cost a nineteen-pound turkey gobbler his life today when a hunter caught him strutting in a field, sneaked up on him while he bragged on himself and shot him dead.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) up to 3 points (15 cents a bale) off yesterday.
Part of the Times Square subway station in the area of Broadway and Forty-first Street was turned into an intensely hot, smoke-filled oven yesterday afternoon when an escalator caught fire.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- Resistance on both sides of the grain futures market held prices generally within a narrow range today in fairly active dealings on the Board of Trade.

Three weeks ago it was learned that Joseph R. McMicking, chairman of the executive committee of the Ampex Corporation, had placed 300,000 shares of that concern in trust and that these shares had been placed privately with a small group of investors.
NEWARK, April 13 -- The state will make an immediate study of Newark's transportation needs to complement the city's general urban-renewal plans.
PARIS, April 13 -- The 4-year-old grandson of the head of the Peugeot automobile company was kidnapped last evening. The abductors are demanding the equivalent of $100,000 ransom.
TRENTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Joint Appropriations Committee decided today to provide $7,000,000 for an administration transit plan by taking the money out of highway construction funds.
The city's proposed sports stadium for Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, may be covered by a dome on its opening day.

Irving M. Engel, executive chairman of the New York Committee for Democratic Voters, announced yesterday the committee's endorsement of seven insurgent candidates for public and party offices in the southeast section of the Bronx.

They ran a good mile at the Aqueduct race track yesterday. The Harbor View Farm's Francis S., favored in the featured $29,450 Bay Shore Handicap, covered the distance in the sparkling time of 1:36 in beating Edward Seinfeld's Don Rickles.

After acting on the voting-rights bill, it is important that the House turn its attention to another kind of civil-rights measure. This is what might well be called an educational-rights bill, one that would recognize the Federal Government's inescapable responsibility in the present crisis in American schools.

First-quarter sales and earnings of Revlon, Inc., were the highest in the twenty-eight-year history of the company, Charles Revson, president, informed some 475 shareholders at the annual meeting in the Essex House here yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 (UPI) -- Home runs by Ernie Banks and Frank Thomas tonight powered the Chicago Cubs to a 4-0 victory over Los Angeles and brought Glen Hobbie the first triumph of his pitching career over the Dodgers.
Television has discovered Mark Twain in a big way.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson asserted today that farm issues and problems were being distorted by three Democratic Presidential aspirants.
Two new electronic data-processing systems, one said to be the "world's fastest computer," were introduced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.

GENEVA, April 13 -- A United States-Canadian plan for a six-mile territorial-sea limit with a contiguous six-mile fishing zone won preliminary approval at the eighty-eight-nation Law of the Sea Conference here today.
Mayor Wagner pledged last night to continue and intensify the use of extra police power and improved street lighting as major weapons in the city's war against crime in the streets and parks.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Frederick H. Mueller voiced his opposition today to legislation raising the Federal minimum wage to $1.25 an hour and applying it to 7,500,000 additional workers.

SARASOTA, Fla., April 13 (AP) -- Tom Brewer and Frank Sullivan continued the fine pitching of the Boston Red Sox and blanked the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 0, today. Brewer and Sullivan treated 3,081 fans to a two hit performance.

CLEVELAND, April 13 -- Evidence that all the heavy chemical elements in the solar system were born in the death throes of at least one star that exploded more than five billion years ago was presented here today.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 13 -- Herman Graham Jr., who has devoted ten of his twenty-five years to harness racing, was among the 18,258 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. He was there as a spectator. Tomorrow night he'll be there as a driver.
A laden Dutch oil tanker caught fire off the Virginia coast yesterday and seven of her crew men were severely burned.
A plan to improve the flow of information about students between high schools and colleges was announced yesterday by the Educational Testing Service.
NEWARK, April 13 -- Senator Clifford P. Case warned today that Republicans must work harder than ever this year if they were to elect a President and make gains in Congress this fall.
New York Medical College at its centennial dinner next Monday will honor seventeen persons for contributing to medical education.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Representative Oren Harris warned the gas industry today that House investigators refused to accept a contention that off-the-record approaches to a Federal regulatory agency were an "accepted practice."

A cut back in allowable production in Texas reduced the nation's output of crude oil last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. At the same time, how- ever, refiners increased their processing of crude oil. Inventories of major refined products showed little change from a week earlier.

From time immemorial men have used the sun and other stars in the sky as beacons to guide their way in travel over sea and land. This morning there is a new beacon in the sky, Transit I-B, the first artificial satellite put into orbit specifically for the purpose of aiding navigation -- forerunner of a system of such beacons which will eventually permit ships and planes to fix their positions with great accuracy.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI) -- The former medical director of a major drug concern accused the drug industry today of profiteering and other questionable practices. He urged Congress to adopt restrictive legislation.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- Significant amounts of radioactive strontium can be forced out of the body even when treatment is delayed, a research report indicated today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The United States is prepared to equip Western Europe with Polaris missiles when they are ready about September, 1961. These specially designed missiles could be launched from mobile platforms on land or rivers.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- Vice President Nixon is planning an intensive Presidential campaign in California next fall -- the most intensive that California Republicans have ever known.
The storm flags have been raised over the direct mail advertising business.
Potato futures generally rose in active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The gain followed sharp declines on Monday and Tuesday. The near months were strongest.

WASHINGTON, N.J., April 13 -- Swinging into the final week of his campaign for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, Robert Morris toured six New Jersey counties today, meeting voters in supermarkets, barber shops and stores and on the street.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Western powers will propose at next month's summit meeting that East and West Berlin be united through free elections under either four-power or United Nations supervision.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 13 -- An anti-Communist newspaper here has charged that Communists tried to terrorize the southern Iraqi town of Hai several days ago.
LONDON, April 13 -- Prime Minister Macmillan declared tonight that despite their differences Britain and South Africa should work together wherever possible.

The Iowa-Illinois Gas and Electric Company sold $15,000,000 of first mortgage bonds yesterday to investment bankers led by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., on a bid of 100.21 for obligations bearing a 5 per cent interest coupon.

The combination of Mozart and Eleanor Steber brought a capacity audience to Carnegie Hall last night. Miss Steber, singing with the Symphony of the Air conducted by Robert Lawrence, presented a group of arias and concert arias.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The "policy" argument against the Forand bill made by the American Medical Association, the insurance industry and certain business groups is that the proposed program of assistance to the aged in meeting hospital bills signifies an increase in centralization of government and paternalism.
RICHMOND, Va., April 13 (AP) -- Robertshaw-Fulton Controls Company today reported earnings of $866,726, equal to 50 cents a share, during the first three months of 1960.
The Blue Cross has asked for a rate increase averaging 37.3 per cent, State Superintendent of Insurance Thomas Thacher disclosed yesterday.

Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury, declared yesterday that the United States must increase its production 50 per cent in the next ten years if it is to compete successfully with the non-free world.
American seamen and longshoremen picketed the Egyptian ship Cleopatra yesterday on her arrival here from Mediterranean ports.

The Celanese Corporation of America increased first-quarter sales to $66,700,000, from $58,890,000 in the 1959 period, but earnings were down slightly, Harold Blancke, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday in the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- The California State Supreme Court rejected without comment today a new appeal to spare the life of Caryl Chessman.

A new law to safeguard the freedom of the seas while adapting it to modern conditions has been approved by a substantial majority in the eighty-eight-nation conference working on that problem at Geneva under United Nations auspices. The conference acted as a committee-of-the-whole and the new law must still be passed in plenary session by a two-thirds majority before being submitted to ratification by the individual states.
The Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation announced several changes in its top management yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Internal Revenue Service today extended the deadline for filing Federal income-tax returns from midnight Friday until midnight next Monday, April 18.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 13 -- The Nassau County Medical Society said today it was taking "aggressive steps to weed out and eliminate wasteful practices" in medical care.

Mrs. Rollin H. Bates and Mrs. Philip D. Jennicon are among the members of a large committee working for the success of the fourth annual Junior Republic Ball. The fete, a project of the George Junior Republic's junior board of directors, will be held in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria May 6.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives agreed today to try to add hospitalization insurance to the benefits available to the aged under the Social Security program.
PARADERO DE DURAN, Cuba, April 8 -- Adelberto Pena, who lives in this village near the southern coast, about thirty miles from Havana, cannot remember having had a glass of milk until six months ago.
A Mexican and three American corporations were charged with violating the antitrust laws yesterday in the distribution of Mexican-produced Spanish-language motion pictures in the United States.

Archbishop Iakovos of the Greek Orthodox Church led a delegation of churchmen and Greek consular officials to Oceanside, L.I., yesterday to look at an icon of the Virgin Mary reported to have been shedding tears since noon Tuesday.
HAVANA, April 13 -- Civilian militiamen left Santiago de Cuba today to join the military forces seeking to eradicate the most serious armed revolt the Castro Government has faced.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) The debt-ridden Capital Airlines, threatened with foreclosure on its prized fleet of British Viscount airplanes, today summoned its directors to meet here Friday.

ROWING coaches are a conservative, tight-lipped breed who take a dim view of innovation and change. So it is no surprise to find that they turn thumbs down on the "shovel" oar that the Oxford University eight introduced in defeating Cambridge in their recent boat race at four and a quarter miles on the Thames.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- East Coast and Great Lakes shipbuilders urged Congress today to repeal a 6 per cent differential allowed West Coast shipyards in bidding on the construction of Government-subsidized merchantmen.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- The most varied, and perhaps the biggest, assortment of show business talent under one Hollywood roof these days can be found in a one-story office building that never turns out a movie, a play, a script or even a song.
EVERY now and then "A Second String" is almost worthy of Shirley Booth.

United States companies are pricing themselves out of potentially lucrative markets in the Middle East, according to a member of an official United States trade mission just returned from the United Arab Republic.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- Sugar Hart, a Philadelphia welterweight, tonight scored a fifth-round technical knockout over the Philippine champion, Rocky Kalingo.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. testified yesterday that a $4,000 cash deposit in his bank account in 1951 and $5,000 in cash taken on a European tour that year had come largely from his late father.
Navigation, whose complexities long kept mariners close to shore, acquired a new instrument and a new dimension yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- President Eisenhower sought today to focus attention on his Administration's effort to solve the farm surplus problem.

Sales and earnings of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company in the quarter ended on March 31 were higher than those of the 1959 period, Bowman Gray, chairman, reported at the annual meeting in Jersey City, N.J., yesterday.

SHREWSBURY, England, April 13 (UPI) -- The disqualification of Stirling Moss from driving on public roads for one year was a "great blow" because many of the ace driver's side jobs depended upon his holding an ordinary driving license, his lawyer told the court today after Moss was found guilty of dangerous driving.

The Algerian conflict has had its ups and downs, its hopes and fears, its optimism and pessimism. These are doubtless inevitable in a dynamic process that offers no clear-cut solution. Whatever happens, there is bound to be suffering and strife.
"THERE really is nothing to it," Mrs. Margaret Barron said recently. "They aren't difficult to make. Not difficult at all."

The United Carbon Company expects earnings in the March quarter to change little from the $1.48 a share cleared in the 1959 period, S. C. Coleman president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Rail-freight loadings last week were below 1959 levels, while truck loadings held virtually steady. Railway loadings were slightly above figures for the preceding week of this year and truck tonnages showed little change.

The assessment of real property for purposes of taxation must be conducted without fear or favor. State law in New York demands that the valuation fully recognize the facts of the market place. Full value is what an informed and willing buyer would pay to an informed and willing seller in a normal market. What a normal market is creates instant debate.

A major realignment of the Western defense structure has been initiated by the British Government with its decision to abandon its own long-range missile program and to rely for such weapons on the United States.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 14 (AP) -- The Textron Corporation has agreed to purchase the defense and aircraft business and major plant properties of the Bell Aircraft Corporation for cash reportedly in excess of $30,000,000.

The Railway Express Agency has leased the ground floor in the building at 760 Twelfth Avenue, occupying the blockfront between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets. The agency will use the space for expansion of its international division, which has outgrown its present terminal at Tenth Avenue and Thirty-third Street.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points off to 2 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

The Dow Chemical Company, in the nine months ended on Feb. 29, lifted its net income to $61,262,295, or $2.24 a share, from $41,768,855, or $1.59 a share a year earlier. Sales rose to $576,006,389, from $511,353,127, the report disclosed.

Two Dominican exiles, arrested for selling an anti-Trujillo newspaper at 110th Street and Broadway, prepared yesterday to plead the constitutional right of a free press in Manhattan Arrest Court, 152d Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Monday.

The Liberal party, announcing a slate of candidates in Brooklyn yesterday, said two Democratic legislators were being denied endorsement because of their support of the bill making a year's residency a condition of relief.
MUSSOORIE, India, April 14 -- The Dalai Lama said today he might visit the United Nations to seek justice for Tibet.

NEW HAVEN, April 14 (AP) -- Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, announced today increases in tuition for students and in salaries for instructors and assistant professors, effective July, 1961.
PATERSON, N. J., April 14 -- Senator Clifford P. Case continued today his almost casual mode of campaigning for renomination in Tuesday' primary election.
The wholesale commodity price index held at 86.1 on Wednesday, unchanged from Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 86.8 on April 17, 1959.
PARIS, Friday, April 15 -- Eric Peugeot, 4-year-old grandson of the head of the Peugeot automobile company, was found safe and sound early today after he had been abandoned by his kidnappers.

Jesus died on the cross, according to the Gospel of St. Mark, between the sixth and the ninth hours on the Friday before the first Easter. Christians in the city today will mark the three hours of suffering in services of prayer and meditation.

The Appellate Division heard arguments yesterday on District Attorney Prank S. Hogan's appeal to reinstate the indictment against Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan, and it reserved decision.

SOCCER -- the granddaddy of all football games -- comes as naturally as kicking pebbles does to a schoolboy. Soccer is that elemental and universally indigenous, even though its heroes are highly skilled in passing, dribbling and booting the round ball and it was no trick at all for Caesar's legions to teach it to the English.

Chicago, Ill., borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised in the public bond market by the sale of serial obligations maturing over twenty-nine years at an interest cost of 3.5955 per cent.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 14 -- The Most Rev. Joost de Blank, Anglican Archbishop of Capetown who has called for the moral isolation of the Dutch Reformed Church of South Africa for its alleged silence on apartheid (racial separation), was criticized today by other Protestant churchmen.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The long-planned union-management conference is about to get off the ground.
Reform Judaism will ultimately be practiced on a wide scale in Israel, two American leaders of that branch predicted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

The city's Superintendent of Schools was called as the final witness yesterday in the departmental trials of two teachers suspended Jan. 8 on charges of lying about past membership in the Communist party.

James R. Hoffa's plans for a nation-wide "conference of transportation unity" received a severe setback yesterday. Paul Hall, president of the Maritime Trades Department, of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared that such an organization would not be formed while Mr. Hoffa was president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 14 -- A new threat of racial unrest developed today in South Africa.
Union leaders urged yesterday that proposed increases in Blue Cross rates he investigated by a special committee representing labor, industry and the public.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Diplomatic sources said tonight that little or nothing had been, done to eliminate some important differences among the Allied governments at the meetings of Western foreign ministers concluded today.
BURLINGTON, Vt., April 14 (AP) -- A United States district court jury ruled today that a 1958 Brattleboro fire for which a man is serving a life sentence was not of incendiary origin.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended April 9 were 18 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of 1959. Only six selling days remained after that date before Easter Sunday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: With other Wisconsin newsmen and editors I am sorely distressed over the interpretation by some reporters -- including The Times -- that a "Catholic vote" emerged from the Wisconsin Presidential primary. The religious issue was insignificant with the Wisconsin voters.

WHEN he was a young man going to night school, Joe (everybody calls him Joe) Periconi was torn between being a lawyer or an athletic instructor. He chose the law. As a result of that decision -- and a demonstrated predilection for practical Republican politics (East Bronx variety) -- State Senator Periconi was sworn, yesterday to the Transit Authority, the three man board that runs New York's transit system.
TORONTO, April 14 (UPI) -- Led by Jean Beliveau, the Montreal Canadiens swept to their fifth consecutive Stanley Cup tonight with a 4-0 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
MOSCOW, April 14 -- Pravda expressed confidence today that a "partial and temporary" agreement on West Berlin could be reached at the summit conference of the Big Four powers in Paris next month.

BOSTON, April 14 -- Richard E. Krafve was elected president of Raytheon Company today a year after he joined the electronics company. Charles F. Adams, president since 1948, became chairman, a new position.
Fireworks are being touched off in the furniture advertising world.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 14 -- The season's biggest daily double pay-off, $559.40, made the evening a profitable and memorable one for bettors who had the foresight to couple Nos. 7 and 4 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- There is an interesting battle developing in the Democratic party between the old-timers who once ran this city and the new-timers who would like to run it in a somewhat different way.
Arnold Palmer and Sam Snead will represent the United States in the Canada Cup and International Trophy golf matches in Ireland from June 23 to 26.
PITTSBURGH, April 14 (AP) -- Vernon Law, backed by the lusty hitting of his Pittsburgh team-mates, blanked Cincinnati, 13 -- 0, today in the first Forbes Field game of the season.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The House Appropriations Committee reduced funds for the nation's space program today, including the high-priority project to place a man in space.
The American' Merchant Marine Institute declared yesterday that the State Department was "needlessly sacrificing the American merchant marine for foreign, interests."
Former President Harry S. Truman, inventor of the mobile seminar on politics, said yesterday that Presidential drafts were "hooey."

A 35-year-old Long Island laborer who had been sought as a suspect in the murder of Augie Pisano, nationally known hoodlum, was held in $75,000 bail last night in the Federal Court, Brooklyn. He was charged with being a fugitive in a government narcotics case.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 14 -- Bob Kewley pitched a three-hitter today as Army's baseball team defeated Columbia, 6 to 1, at Doubleday Field. It was the fifth straight triumph for the cadets.
Market sentiment turned for the better yesterday midway in a session of the New York Stock Exchange that looked like a duplicate of the gloomy ones that had preceded it.

Frederick R. Kappel, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, predicted yesterday that by using telephone exchange names the United States would run out of telephone numbers in the mid-Nineteen-seventies.

Bertram Jay Wysell, a lawyer since 1949, has been disbarred by the Appellate Division, First Department, as a result of proceedings started by an official watchdog committee of three bar associations on automobile accident abuses.

HAVANA, April 14 -- According to a report from Oriente Province tonight, 1,000 Government troops have surrounded Pico Turquino, Cuba's highest mountain, and believe that they have trapped Capt. Manolo Beaton and part of the rebel band he heads.

WOMEN'S reactions, as any man will testify, frequently are hard to predict Just how hard, Gimbels has found out Last year the store began a series of new ten-week sewing classes on the theory that, despite today's frantic pace and the wide range of available ready-to-wear, there are still spough women left to make such a project worth-while.
Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, will go to Israel next month to explore the possibility of setting up a port authority for that country.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey has slashed his national political headquarters staff 50 per cent since his primary defeat in Wisconsin.
CHICAGO, April 14 -- Research suggesting a link between common soil microbes and some important non-infectious diseases; including hardening of the arteries, was reported here today.
THINGS are complicated in "Bye Bye Birdie," which opened at the Martin Beck last evening. Things are also uneven.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- Two medical school authorities said today that drug concerns were wasting millions of dollars on unwanted "ballyhoo" promotion that should be spent on hospitals and research.

Liquidation and trade and commission house hedge selling lowered most potato positions in moderately active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Trade buying, based on firmer cash markets, limited the decline.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 14 -- The do-it-yourself craze has spread to tugboats. Two men are building one here -- almost in the center of town. They have parlayed innumerable week-ends, a good deal of sweat, some scrap steel plates and assorted other items into what will soon be a forty-ton steel tugboat.
A deadlock within the city's Tax Commission raised the threat yesterday that Staten Islanders might be denied any cuts at all in their revolt against increased real estate tax valuations.

Boris Spassky of Russia, with a 12-1 record, has regained his lead over the United States champion, Bobby Fischer (11 1/2 -- 1 1/2), in the international masters' chess tournament at Mar del Plata, according to reports received yesterday from the Argentine.
A leading Roman Catholic magazine declared yesterday that Senator John F. Kennedy's religion "obviously was a factor" in the Wisconsin primary.
TEANECK, N. J., April 14 -- Representatives of eight Northern New Jersey counties adopted a resolution today approving a $3,500,000 study of the transportation needs of the area.
ALBANY, April 14 -- With the rigors of the I960 legislative session largely behind him, Governor Rockefeller is assuming a more active political role on both the state and the national level.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Treasury took another step today aimed at curbing potentially harmful speculation in Government securities. The step was a limited form of "margin requirements." The Controller of the Currency told national bank examiners that banks under their supervision should require at least 5 per cent collateral against loans on Government securities, in addition to the value of the securities purchased with the loan.
Five Canadian airmen who had-been adrift in a rubber boat in the Atlantic 175 miles west of Bermuda for ten hours were rescued shortly before noon yesterday by a German freighter.

The average 37.3 per cent increase in rates for which the Associated Hospital Service has asked poses a tough problem in personal finance for most of its seven million subscribers. This would be the third increase in three successive years, making a total of 121 per cent over 1957 for individuals in group contracts and 106 per cent for families.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 14 -- Robert Morris tonight called for the liberation of people behind the Iron and Bamboo Curtains.

FOR the last ten years or so, Janos Starker has been generally recognized as one of the world's great 'cellists. But he has not been heard in a New York City recital, barring one previous appearance in a small hall.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 14 (AP) -- Thorne Wood, a left-hander from near-by Asheboro, put together a pair of 33's today for a five-under-par 66 and a. one-stroke lead in the first round of the $17,500 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Gulf Oil Corporation today posed a major court test for the Federal Government's controls on the importation of oil. Another big company was reported to be preparing a second challenge, on different grounds.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The absence of clear political differences between Senators Kennedy and Humphrey has considerable responsibility for highlighting the so-called religious issue which appeared in the Wisconsin primary and now looms in their contest in West Virginia.
ALBANY, April 14 -- Legislation that will provide $69,000,000 in additional aid for school systems in the state for 19.60-61 was approved today by Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Thomas Kennedy, president of the United Mine Workers of America, said today that the union had not endorsed any candidate ,in the West Virginia Democratic Presidential-preferential primary and did not intend to do so.
CHICAGO, April 14 -- The grain futures market scarcely moved today in one of the dullest trading sessions in several weeks.
The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday, 4 to 1 that wiretap evidence could be used in criminal prosecutions in state courts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- The United Nations has rejected the request of twenty-two Asian and African states for a special session of the General Assembly to consider the question of French atomic tests in the Sahara.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 14 -- Gov. Edmund G. Brown voiced concern today over possible harm to the Democratic party from bitterness in primary campaigns.

Check transactions at the twenty-six principal cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $25,071,266,000, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. This was 3.9 per cent below the $26,079,900,000 level of the week before, but 3.1 per cent above the $24,320,897,000 of the 1959 week.
ALTHOUGH the furniture for a theatre set may include only one chair, the search for this lonely item can lead to broader ventures.
ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Rockefeller named State Senator Joseph F. Periconi, a Bronx Republican, today as a member of the New York City Transit Authority. The post pays $30,000 a year.
GENEVA, April 14 -- The Soviet Union cheerily accepted today the United States' two-day-old proposal for a meeting of Western and Soviet scientists on the problems of detecting nuclear explosions.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- Peter Licavoli, a Detroit underworld leader already in prison for income-tax evasion, drew an additional sentence of six months today for contempt of Congress.

RICHMOND, Va., April 14 -- The Yankees completed their exhibition road show today with a performance that might have been titled "Fun on the Farm." They drew a crowd of 13,556, the largest of their spring campaign, and they battered their top minor league affiliate, Richmond, 15 to 10.

BUEA, British Cameroons, April 14 (UPI) -- Hundreds of persons were killed and hundreds more were seriously wounded by rebel tribesmen in the newly independent African republic of Cameroon last week, according to delayed reports received today.
Four frolicsome young chimpanzees went on public display at the Bronx Zoo yesterday for the first time and, for a while, put the Great Apes House into an unaccustomed tizzy.

Loans to business Toy fifteen large New York City banks dropped $29,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the like week of last year, such loans declined $6,000,000.
A record-breaking seven furlongs by the Pin Oak Farm's Derrick and a ten-day suspension to Eddie Arcaro for careless riding were the highlights of Aqueduct's racing program yesterday.
MAS AN, Korea, April 14 -- An old woman in a flowing Korean dress shook her fist in the face of a rifle-carrying policeman on the main street of Masan.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- There is a display case at the Library of Congress that carries a single caption -- this date, April 14 -- but the year is 1865.

QUANTICO, Va., April 14 -- The East's first major assembly of the outdoor track and field season will bring nearly 800 athletes from more than sixty colleges, clubs and service units into action here tomorrow and Saturday at the fourth annual Marine Corps Schools Relays.

COMPETING with chocolate rabbits, cream eggs and hot cross buns for the supermarket shopper's attention this weekend are specially priced hams and large turkeys. Whether the holiday meat chosen is a deliciously stuffed turkey or a diamond-studded ham, there is a good choice of refreshing accompaniments.
BONN, Germany, April 14 -- The Western Allies have agreed to oppose any Soviet move for East German representation during discussion of the German and Berlin topics at the summit conference.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Navy, with one experimental navigational Satellite in orbit; made plans today to launch another later this spring.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. angrily denied in Federal Court yesterday that alimony payments made to his first wife while he was in Europe in 1951 came from the salary of his former Congressional secretary.
WASHINOTON, April 14 -- Senator Mike Mansfield charged today that the nation needed Goverenment decisions and not "aimless drift."

OF Beethoven's large-scale works the "Missa Solemnis" is the most difficult to encompass. Leonard Bernstein conducted a performance at Carnegie Hall last night that made light of the difficulties and that worthily solemnized the Easter season.
SAN CLEMENTE ISLAND, Calif., April 14 -- The Polaris missile passed an important underwater launching test today in a twenty-two-second controlled flight at this Navy test range.
BARTLESVILLE, Okla., April 14 (UPI) -- American records fell in the trials and finals of every race today in the Amateur Athletic Union's indoor swimming championships.
Many a taxpayer now breathing a sigh of relief after his bout with income taxes may move from a state of arithmetical exhaustion to simple confusion as he sits down to address the envelopes.

The Long Island Rail Road made $335,000 last year on its 73,934,636 riders -- but not on the fares they paid to ride the trains.
