The profit was realized from renting concessions in its concourse in Pennsylvania Station to people who sold Long Island commuters everything from nuts (the kind one eats) to nuts (hardware) before they got on and after they got off the trains.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 14 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold warned today that the United Nations would "miss the bus" if it delayed any longer in assisting newly independent nations in Africa.

GENEVA, April 14 -- The United States offered today to end production of atomic and hydrogen bombs and to station international inspectors at all its nuclear plants provided the Soviet Union agreed to take the same steps.
DETROIT, April 14 -- The pace of auto sales continued at an encouraging rate in early April, according to dealer reports for the first ten days of the month.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which operates thirty stores including the Lord Taylor group, had record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended Jan. 30. This was disclosed in the annual report of Robert J. McKim, chairman, and Lewis P. Seiler, president, issued for publication today.
CLARA BARLOW, a soprano who made her debut here in 1954, and Joseph E. Howard Jr., who was making his debut, gave a joint program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 -- President Eisenhower accepted today,the resignation of William M. Holiday as chairman of the Civilian-Military liaison Committee, effective April 30.
The Chrysler Corporation yesterday became the first car manufacturer to ship new autos from Detroit to New York using the New York Central Railroad's Flexi-Van service.

Olgivanna Lloyd Wright, author of "The Struggle Within" and "Our House," will have her new volume of biographical reminiscences published April 25 by Horizon Press. It is "The Shining Brow -- Frank Lloyd Wright," a portrait of the architect who was her husband and an account of their life together.

The Trans-Hatton Corporation has purchased a plot, 44 by 77 feet, at 1449-51 Third Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-second Street, where the company is assembling a site for an apartment building. The purchase was for cash over a first mortgage of $83,000.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System decreased by $33,000,000 to $671,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserve balances" in excess of requirements increased $61,000,000 to $503,000,000.
The Patriarch of Constantinople, spiritual leader of all Eastern Orthodox churches, has made his first official appeal for a reunion of Orthodox, Roman Catholic and Protestant Churches.
A plumber in need of plumbing for his own property was fined $100 yesterday by Magistrate Herman Weinkrantz in Brooklyn Municipal Term Court.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a South African may I, through the channels of your newspaper, express my feelings of anger, scorn and disgust at the statement issued by your State Department on the recent riots in South Africa. It is time someone pointed out to the State Department that people in glass houses shouldn't throw stones.
LONDON, April 14 -- Book-makers soon may be contributing more than ever to the British way of life.

ROME, April 14 -- Amintore Fanfani, a Christian Democratic Deputy, conditionally accepted today the task of forming a new Government to end the fifty-day-old Italian Cabinet crisis. He was Premier twice before.
YESTERDAY (April 14, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Continued golfing vacation Augusta, Ga.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday follows:
The New York Philharmonic has received a grant from the Columbia Broadcasting System to help finance a seven-week tour of the continental United States, Hawaii and Canada.

George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, ordered the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday to abandon organizing, attempts in the Dominican Republic.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Half of American families and unattached persons had incomes of more than $5,300 last year.

A half-dozen amateur politicians told yesterday how they and counterparts across the nation were getting ready to try to sell Adlaf E. Stevenson to the professionals at the Democratic National Convention.
LONDON, April 14 (UPI) -- Thirty-nine world track and field records, eight by Americans, were ratified today by the International Amateur Athletic Federation.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, was not entitled to a passport to visit Communist China merely because he was a member of Congress.
EASTON, Pa., April 14 -- Lafayette College scored its third victory against two defeats today, routing Fordham's baseball team, 18 -- 11. It was Fordham's third loss in five starts.
THE stole is not all. This is spring's message from fur connoisseur Louis O. Wheeler, president of Gunther Jaeckel in Bonwit Teller.

PARIS, April 14 -- The French Cabinet made extensive changes tonight in the military command in Algeria. The changes appeared to be part of the shake-up that began after the European settlers', insurrection in Algiers in January.
A PARENT-AND-CHILD tournament at the Regency Club last night was unique in local bridge annals.
Hal Holbrook, who was scheduled to star as Mark Twain in a TV dramatization of the author's "Roughing It," has been replaced in the role by Melvyn Douglas.

ALTHOUGH a few novels are about dogs, or angels or fish, most novels are about people. And yet a surprising number of good novels contrive to dwarf their own characters and leave an impression in their readers' minds that they are primarily about something else: storms at sea, strikes, the Civil War, politics, medical research or the miseries of artistic genius.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 (UPI) -- Frank Thomas' pop-fly double in the ninth inning drove in the winning run to break up a home-run battle tonight and spark the Chicago Cubs to a 6 -- 5 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that in 600 taxicab hold-ups last year only sixty drivers used a special telephone number to expedite arrests.

That old bogeyman, inflation, has been exorcised recently by many economists, but not by all. One of the exceptions is Edwin B. Moran, executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Management. Yesterday he issued a statement here calling a general round of price increases "inevitable" by this fall because he believed producers could not absorb wage rises coming in the next few months.

"Blithe Spirit" bears a charmed life, having been seen on the stage, screen and television. Plans are developing for Noel Coward's "improbable farce," one of Burns Mantle's ten best plays of the 1941-42 season, to emerge as a stage musical.
The Egyptian passenger and eargo ship Cleopatra remained idle yesterday for the second day as two maritime unions continued picketing her at her Blast River berth.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 14 -- Tennessee Democrats chose a national convention delegation today uncommitted in theory but pledged in fact to Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas.
PARIS, April 14 -- The governing council of the French news agency late tonight apparently rejected a bid by the French Government to reassert greater control over the agency, independent since 1957.
Bond prices drifted down in Inactive trading yesterday.
CLAIBORNE, Ala., April 14 -- The prophecy uttered last night by Sheriff Charlie Sizemore of Monroe County proved pitiably correct today. Hunters heard turkeys gobble, but could not shoot one.
LONDON, April 14 -- Industrial share prices looked much steadier here today after their dullness of the last few days. The market will be closed for the Easter holiday until Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Two major business associations issued statements today approving the principle of a Senate bill on disclosure of installment credit interest rates, but they did not approve the bill.
THE parental role of ten places an adult in the embarrassing position of advising youngsters, "Do as I say, not as I do."

Jimmy Bostwick of New York and Aiken, S. C., the national amateur champion in 1959 and runner-up this year, and Jimmy Dunn, the professional at the Philadelphia Racquet Club, will meet at noon today for the United States open'rcourt tennis title.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- When the East of Madison Avenue meets the West of Hollywood the twain soon produce another frontier town here for the gunmen and horses of the boxed-in spaces of wild video.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) -- Eddie Sawyer, unruffled and smiling, resigned today manager of the National League's Philadelphia Phillies. He said that he simply didn't want the job.

ROUTING out "new talent" has gotten to be such a tiresome game that genuine new talent is sometimes drowned in the brouhaha. This should not happen to Ron Gorchov, a painter still in his twenties whose exhibition at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery, 24 East Sixty-seventh Street, really deserves serious attention.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 14 (AP) -- The American-manned space flight effort took another forward step today when an engineer emerged from seven days and nights in a sealed capsule where his oxygen supply came entirely from a "miraculous chemical."
After a number of frustrating false starts, spring appeared yesterday to be not only icumen in but here to stay.
Conditions in the city hospitals, ranging from leaking roofs to dwindling nursing personnel, were criticized yesterday by a citizens' group.

An amended plan of reorganization of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad was approved yesterday by the United States District Court here. This cleared the way for a vote on the proposal by bondholders and other creditors.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Inter-American Peace Committee of the Organization of American States appealed today for the release of political prisoners and of persons who have taken refuge in diplomatic missions.

The manufacture of "clean" records for gamblers with many convictions came to light here yesterday. The records were used to get light sentences for defendants who otherwise would have received heavy ones.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 15 (UPI) -- Birmingham's three-man City Commission voted today to institute a libel suit seeking punitive damages against The New York Times because of a Times article that said this city was gripped by racial hatred and fear.
The glitter of automobiles polished to their ashtrays will sparkle through the Coliseum today as the Fourth International Automobile Show opens a nine-day run.
Subway Fishermen Thrive The subway once again is carrying early morning fishermen to their favorite spots at Coney Island, Brighton Beach and Sheepshead Bay.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., April 15 -- The issuance of all building permits in Tuckahoe was suspended last night by the Village Board. It reported that there were gross defects in the old zoning laws and that builders were trying to capitalize on them.
JERUSALEM, April 15 (AP) -- Soldiers of peace marched along the Way of the Cross today.

The shortage of residual fuel ail that is said to loom for the East Coast may be made less severe by the import quota increase set recently by the Department of the Interior, Harry B. Hilts, secretary of the Empire State Petroleum Association, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 120.1 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Eddie Arcaro found himself in the unaccustomed role of hero to the crowd at Aqueduct yesterday. The 44-year-old jockey rode three consecutive winners and after each victory most of the 35,329 fans applauded him warmly.
Yuri Zavadski, head of the Mossoviet Theatre in Moscow, arrived here Thursday night to become the third guest director for the recently founded Institute for Advanced Studies in the Theatre Arts.

ACCORDING to forecasts for the development of the frozen food industry, frozen candies will be the next innovation. However, Herly Foods of New Jersey is already a jump ahead with its delicious rum balls.
School officials report a major speed-up in getting sites for new school projects for 1960 and future years. They also say that as much as ten weeks has been cut from former delays in design.

A group of upper West Side landlords banded together yesterday to fight a city program aimed at seizing and refurbishing squalid tenements in which desperately poor families are packed into single rooms.

BECAUSE he will be 83 in September, Bruno Walter is reluctant to undertake, exhausting assignments. He agreed to appear with the New York Philharmonic this season only when a special arrangement was made for him to conduct two concerts of this week's series of four and two next week.
SPRING and summer are directly symbolized in form and color in Larry Day's non-objective paintings at the Parma Gallery, 1111 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Federal Aviation Administrator E.R. Quesada said tonight that a special inspection of Electra prop-jet airplanes had turned up nothing thus far that would warrant grounding the Electra fleet.
ED WYNN performed beautifully last night in a sentimental and moving TV play about a play on Channel 2's "Desilu Playhouse."

OAKDALE, L.I., April 15 -- A 140-year-old mistake is to be corrected here during restoration work on the stained glass sanctuary window at St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church. The tiny Colonial edifice amid towering oaks on Montauk Highway is considered the second oldest religious edifice in Suffolk County.

ROME, April 15 (UPI) -- Pope John XXIII expressed hope for "a just and lasting concord between all people" and peace and prosperity for the United States in a Good Friday message to the American people today.

LE CASTELLET, France April 16 is often, in the Christian world, a somewhat festive day, coming as it does in usual proximity to Easter. But April 16, 1917, was a day of particular significance to Russia -- and later to the world.
A new ship service between New York and Florida is planned to offer cheap transportation for private automobiles for the Florida beach trade.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Industrial production dipped in March as expected, but by only one point on the Federal Reserve Board's index.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Studies throwing new light on the means by which nerve systems control the heart were described here today by scientists of the National Heart Institute.
Christians over the world will joyfully celebrate tomorrow the Resurrection of their Saviour, Jesus Christ.

Mayor Wagner expressed the hope yesterday that the city's Tax Commission could resolve its deadlock on the procedure for cutting Staten Island real estate assessments.
The scientist who reported four months ago finding that eggs caused cancer in mice told colleagues here yesterday of progress toward localizing the substance responsible for the effect.

New Yorkers looking to Easter Sunday mopped their brows yesterday and wondered what had become of spring. Only a few days ago, they recalled, it was winter, and then suddenly it was summer.

THE American Ballet Theatre will begin a three-week celebration of its twentieth anniversary on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. The opening performance will be a gala sponsored by the Ballet Theatre Foundation for the benefit of the company itself.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Congressional approval this year of some form of health insurance for Social Security pensioners now seems assured.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI) -- The president of the Airline Pilots Association said today that it was conducting its own investigation of Electra airliners and its members would refuse to fly them if it decided they should be grounded.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 16 -- Dennis D'Oca posted his fourth straight victory (second in the league) without a defeat in hurling Hofstra to an 11-1 Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference victory over Fordham today.
THE "little leaguers" of the automotive racing world, youngsters who own "karts," have become the latest concern of the National Safety Council.

ALDOUS HUXLEY'S "Point Counter Point" contains a touching scene in which Miss Fulkes, the conscientious governess, tries, after a long and tiring day, to improve her mind with Adam Smith's "Wealth of Nations."

The conversion of one of the city's worst slum buildings into a modern apartment house is nearing completion at 380 Riverside Drive.
With about seventy - two hours remaining before the Yankees' American League opener, Casey Stengel still had not come up with a formula for winning ball games regularly.
Antique French and other furniture, antique porcelains and a variety of other decorative and art objects, will be auctioned Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.
An Orthodox rabbi attacked yesterday what he described as signs of the debasement of love in modern society.
MARIA SCHELL, blonde Viennese actress, will have the title role in a television production of the comedy, "Ninotchka," on the American Broadcasting Company network Wednesday night.

New Yorkers looking forward to a pleasant and fair Easter day had their hopes dampened last night when the Weather Bureau predicted that this morning would be cloudy with a chance of occasional light rain.

MISSOULA, Mont. -- Tourists planning to inspect the Madison River Canyon this summer for evidence of last August's damaging earthquake will find an unexpected bonus. SCHOLAR, teacher, journalist, mystic, Tory, Paul Elmer More led a wavering career in his quest for moral authority. His mission in life, as he once wrote, was "to suit nobody" -- including, it would appear from this book, himself.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- Sam Jones of the San Francisco Giants pitched no-hit ball for seven and two-third innings today until a pinch hitter, Walt Moryn, hit a homer for the Chicago Cubs' only hit. The Giants won, 6 to 1.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Cheater E. McCarty has listed regulations to be followed at formal dinners in the officers' messes of his command -- the Fourteenth Air Force with headquarters at Warner-Robins Air Force Base, Ga.

TO THE EDITOR: Julius K. Nyerere won my admiration for the calm and persuasive clarity with which he expressed his case ("Africa Needs Time -- ," March 27). However, I must disagree with his contention that the existence of an organized opposition is a peculiarity of "Anglo-Saxon" democracy, rather than an essential prerequisite for effective democracy anywhere.

HOLLYWOOD FOR the first time in more than a month Hollywood was back in the movie business last week. The thirty-three-day strike by the movie actors was setttled and, though official ratification by the actors will not take place until a membership meeting tomorrow, the agreement provvided that those films interrupted by the strike could be resumed at once.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 16 (AP) -- Sam Snead shot a 4-under-par 67 today to vault into a three-shot lead with a 201 total for fifty-four holes in his bid for a seventh Greater Greensboro open golf tournament victory.

THE results of a survey made by the Caribbean Tourist Association among summer visitors to the Caribbean last year showed that younger people form the bulk of the visitors. Eighty-two per cent of those interviewed were under 45 years old and more than half (55 per cent) were under 35.

THE importance of the automobile to life in the United States needs no ballyhoo. But the sale of specific brands, sizes, styles and unusual features represents a never-ending challenge to the industry. Last year the American public spent more than $16,000,000,000 for cars and parts.

To the Drama Editor: One cannot pooh-pooh a man of the theatre like E.Y. Harburg, whose letter was published last week. WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 16 -- A young miniature poodle, Ch. Crikora Commotion, added to his stature by capturing the Twin Brooks Kennel Club event at the 102d Armored Cavalry Regiment Armory today.

ATLANTA, April 15 -- With the notable exception of the Negroes, many Southerners view the outcome of the Congressional battle over civil rights with unfeigned relief and some rejoicing.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended April 9 were 18 per cent above the 1959 level, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. The week before the gain from last year was 22 per cent. It was noted, however, that in 1959 Easter fell on March 29, three weeks earlier than this year.
A Connecticut office building, an ice arena and an open-plan residence are among the structures whose designers have won top awards in the American Institute of Architects' annual competition.

IN what he modestly describes as an essay, Princeton's gifted historian of science, Charles Coulston Gillispie, has written a bold, penetrating and very personal book. HAVE you ever heard of Fanny Fern? A century ago she was the most popular American novelist and the highest paid newspaper writer of her day. "Fanny Fern" was her pen-name; actually, she was Sara Payson Willis, sister of the New York journalist, N.P. Willis, once described by Oliver Wendell Holmes as "something between a remembrance of the Count d'Orsay and an anticipation of Oscar Wilde."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17 -- In tune with the jingle, "Polly put the kettle on, we'll all have tea," the world is probably drinking more of that brew than of any other beverage.
LOS ANGELES, April 17 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers capitalized on home runs and loose St. Louis play today for a 7-5 triumph at the Coliseum. The loss was the fifth straight for the Cards.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today that the Administration, though divided on how to provide medical care for the aged, agreed that older persons had "a real problem here."
The Rev. William A. Buell, one of New England's outstanding headmasters, will retire from St. George's School of Newport, R.I., after an association that covers a halfcentury.
Bobby Fischer gained a tie for first place in the final round of the chess tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday, according to a report from Argentina.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 17 (AP) -- Sam Snead birdied the last two holes today and won the Greater Greensboro open golf tournament for the seventh time. He had a closing 69 for a 270. He was fourteen under par and two shots ahead of the runner-up, Dow Finsterwald, who shot a final 68.
Four new films are slated to open in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
ALBANY, April 17 -- Narcotics addicts can be involuntarily committed to state hospitals for up to one year under legislation approved by Governor Rockefeller.
MEMPHIS, April 17 (AP) -- A baseball park grandstand went up in flames tonight, forcing a near-by hospital to evacuate patients from one wing.
Arrangements for the sale of the Mutual Broadcasting System to the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company are expected to be concluded this week -- possibly today or tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A move is developing in the Senate to increase the space budget proposed by the Administration by about $30,000,000 to give the space program some insurance for meeting failures and breakthroughs.

A FILMED visit to the countryside in which Jesus lived and died provided an outstanding Easter telecast Saturday night. The program, entitled "The Way of the Cross," was shown on "World Wide 60" over Channel 4.
A geographical reorganization of the two police borough commands in Manhattan to make them more efficient is being considered by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.
AMSTERDAM, April 17 -- A firm trend predominated for most international shares in the holiday-shortened week. Turnover of 15,300,000 guilders compared with last week's high of 22,500,000.
WEYMOUTH, Mass., April 17 (UPI) -- Henry Averell Gerry Jr., 18-year-old Harvard freshman and the son of a New York investment broker, was killed today in an automobile accident.

Mayor Wagner's proposal to increase the take-home pay of 105,000 city employes by having the city assume part of their contributions to pension systems was called unsound in a report made public yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission.

Max E. Weinstock, president of Rothmoor Corporation, largest manufacturer in Chicago of women's coats and suits, believes that his company has set some kind of record, but he isn't quite sure what it is. The company, organized in 1921, went "public" fourteen years ago, and since then has paid a dividend every year.

Robert Moses announced last Wednesday night his acceptance of the presidency of the 1964-65 World's Fair in New York. On Friday he delivered to newspaper desks, for Monday morning release, his first two brochures reporting on consultant studies for preparation of the site in Flushing Meadow Park and restoration of the park after the close of business nearly six years from now.
ALBANY, April 17 -- A state committee warned today that more money and more trained workers were urgently needed to assure the fullest possible development of the state's children and youth.

VAINO ALFRED TANNER, who has just been reelected chairman of Finland's Social Democratic party, is to that country's politics what Sibelius has been to Finland's music. When the Soviet Union wanted to avenge itself for the Finnish resistance in the wars with the Soviet Union between 1939 and 1945, it picked on Mr. Tanner, as a leading political figure of Finland, and branded him a war criminal.
A group of New York teenagers who formulated their own Bill of Rights have proved their ability to live up to it -- and cover the cost.

THERE once was an Olympic marathon runner who tried to beat the starting gun, a rather presumptuous approach to an event that extends twenty-six miles 385 yards. In a distance event it rarely makes any difference whether the start is hasty or leisurely. So this soothsayer is coming in a trifle late with his forecast of the National League race, a delay caused by circumstances beyond his control.
The Container Corporation of America has won top honors to the Saturday Review's eighth annual competition for distinguished advertising in the public interest.

An American edition of a travel book by Michael Alexander, called "Offbeat In Asia," will be published Friday by David McKay. The author tells of his 18,000-mile trip through Turkey, Iran and Afghanistan. Mr. Alexander, a relative of Field Marshal Earl Alexander of Tunis, was a British commando in World War II.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17 -- An unusual aid program for African economies will begin its fourth year this week.

QUANTICO, Va., April 18 -- Favored with good weather for the first time, the fourth annual Marine Corps Schools Relays produced performances of a caliber seldom achieved in the East this early in, the track and field campaign.
TRENTON, April 17 -- Republican leaders throughout the nation will watch with more that average interest the party's primary balloting in this state on Tuesday.
The use of tests in schools drew a mark of passing or better yesterday from a New York Times Youth Forum panel and its adult guest, Fred M. Hechinger.

The League of New York Theatres yesterday issued a reply to the eight pages of demands made by Actors Equity for a new contract. The union's agreement with the organization representing producers and theatre owners expires on May 31.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Complaints of censorship and of withholding information that could be made public without endangering national security have arisen among private study agencies that do contract work for the Pentagon.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 16 -- Nashville's traditional grace, wit and wisdom have been strained, but not riven, by the urgent stresses of the Negro drive against discrimination.

LE CASTELLET, France. If nothing else, the negotiations now taking place in Geneva prove how far behind the ingenuity of scientists the adaptability of statesmen lags. For, while lawyers haggle about territorial limits of sea space, man-made satellites whiz through the air space above each other's lands.
RALEIGH, N.C., April 17 -- Southern Negro student leaders urged President Eisenhower today to act to solve the racial problem.
Generally good business conditions and increased volume in new product lines enabled the Allied Chemical Corporation to report record first-quarter sales and earnings.

PAUL HORGAN'S "A Distant Trumpet' is a first-rate historical novel about the United States Cavalry, the Apache wars in Arizona in the Eighteen Eighties and the eternally mystifying, fascinating and dramatic complexities of human character. Mr. Horgan, who has lived most of his life in the Southwest, knows that region and its spectacular past as few men do.

Dr. Wernher von Braun declared yesterday that if man wanted a full account of what it was like on other planets he could not rely on instruments but had to decide finally to go out and take a look for himself.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif. April 17 -- Politics has hit Hollywood, and the Democrats seem to have scored a landslide victory over the Republicans.
MONTROSE, N.Y., April 17 -- A retired super-salesman is teaching the fine points of his art to recuperating mentally ill veterans to ease their return, to society and to jobs.

ESPECIALLY during spring and summer, the seasons for salad, olive oil becomes an important item on many kitchen shelves. For a French dressing of authentic charac- ter, a good olive oil is an essential ingredient. It also adds flavor to other dressings and sauces.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 17 -- Communist-ruled Yugoslavia's mass political organization, the Socialist Alliance, opens its fifth national congress tomorrow. Observers representing more than forty countries, but not the Soviet Union, will attend.
NEW DELHI, India, April 17 -- About 5,000 jeering Indians marched to the home of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today to protest his coining talks with Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman predicted last night that the Democratic national convention would be deadlocked with the result that Adlai E. Stevenson again would be seriously considered for the Presidential nomination.
MADISON, Wis., April 17 (AP) -- Charles Mohr died today at the University of Wisconsin Hospital.
MERGING American ingenuity with European craftsmanship has produced dividends in housewares for the nation's kitchens.
A strong indication that the New York World's Fair will run for two years was given in a report made public yesterday by Robert Moses, who will become president of the World's Fair Corporation.
The directors of the Fifth Avenue Association have voted unanimously against a proposal for a $500,000 sidewalk cafe and restaurant in Central Park.

William Street Sales' Ingenuity Award-contest deadline was last Friday. The contest was open to all members of the National Association of Securities Dealers who made any mutual fund sales in 1959. Plaques will be awarded annually.
The 1960 Easter Parade along Fifth Avenue yesterday was a study in moderation.
WARSAW, April 16 -- Bitter and savage satires of contemporary life have become the hallmark of the student theatres that flourish in the principal cities of Poland.

Six tons of bronze cathedral doors opened yesterday at the rapping of a bishop's staff to admit the gold-coped prelate, the Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, who greeted the crowds in the have with "Alleluia! The Lord is risen."
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Following are the texts of a telegram sent by the Rev. Harold Glen Brown of Portland, Ore., to Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts and of the Senator's telegraphed reply:
A hospital or a section of a hospital for alcoholics has been recommended by Edward J. McGoldrick in his annual report on Bridge House, the city's rehabilitation facility for male alcoholics.

New York women were warned yesterday not to take short cuts when walking alone at night and not to put keys under mats, but to double-lock their doors, and to report suspicious behavior by adults near schoolyards and playgrounds.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Government officials are expected to ask President Eisenhower this week to take emergency action to head off possible labor troubles on the nation's railroads.

Week Ended April 15, 1960 Rates were erratic on active dealings in the foreign exchange market during the past week though most of the world capitals had a short business week in observance of the Easter season.

Tomorrow's contest for the Republican Senate nomination in New Jersey illustrates what many serious students of American politics are coming to regard as two glaring defects of the direct primary system.

Pan American Week begins today. Each year at this time the nations of Latin America and the United States commemorate the first official International Conference of American States held in Washington in 1889-90. This is being counted as a seventieth anniversary. In any event, anniversaries are always useful milestones at which one looks back over the stretch of road just traveled and ahead into the unknown.
MADRID, April 17 -- Government and business, which all but stopped for Spain's Holy Week, will resume normal operations tomorrow amid rumors on the restoration of a monarchy.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., April 17 -- Mr. and Mrs. W.R. Ballard's chestnut gelding, Gift of Gold, from Newmarket, Ont., was ridden by Ballard to the open jumper championship with 12 points in the Glen Head horse show today.
A new constitution has brought full voting rights to thousands of disfranchised members of the International Union of Operating Engineers.
ROME, April 17 -- "A happy and holy Easter to all of you," Pope John XXIII said in English today as he sent his good wishes, in seven languages, to all parts of the world.
ROME, April 17 -- The detection of a subatomic particle identified as anti-sigma plus was confirmed by a team of Italian physicists here today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UPI) -- Vice President Nixon should wait until after the Republican convention before deviating from the Administration on any domestic issues, Senate Thruston B. Morton said today.
The movement of military personnel and their dependents by private steamship lines is expected to drop 75 per cent in the first six months of this year.

A REALIST who collects dreams is doing some wide-awake thinking about them for scientific purposes. The collector, Prof. Robert Dalton at the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell University is gathering the visions for future analysis in a new "dream project" now under way at the college in Ithaca.
The New York metropolitan area will continue to be the financial center of the nation for at least the next twenty-five years, according to a regional study made public yesterday.

Because Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd of South Africa and Southern racists here are pitting themselves against God their regimes are sure to end in disaster, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Pittsburgh is feeling some effects of the compact car. So is Europe.
Thousands of worshipers yesterday hailed the Resurrection -- supreme festival of Christianity -- in quiet meditation at scores of Easter sunrise services in New York and neighboring communities.

The Polish Ambassador to the United States, Romuald Spasowski, warned yesterday against the emergence of militarism in West Germany and what he said was the desire of "some West German politicians" to expand territory.

GENEVA, April 17 -- The Swiss stock markets shook off the lethargy that gripped them at the start of last week to finish with a burst of activity on the eve of a long Easter week-end. The markets were closed on Good Friday and will not re-open until Tuesday.
OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., April 17 (AP) -- Canoes manned by Dartmouth students were one, two, three today at the finish of the 218-mile race down the Connecticut River.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox and Washington Senators may play in the shadows later this season, but they monopolize the baseball spotlight tomorrow in the fiftieth anniversary Presidential opener.
CHICAGO, April 17 -- Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalism fraternity, announced today the winners of its twenty-eighth annual awards for distinguished service in journalism.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Democratic Advisory Council urged today that the United States and other capital-exporting nations double their investment in under-developed nations.
PITTSBURGH, April 17 -- The volume of steel order cancellations dwindled substantially last week.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator John F. Kennedy said today that no church should try to dictate to the Government, and that the Government should neither favor nor attack any church.
HELSINKI, Finland, April 17 -- Vaino Alfred Tanner, 79-year-old leader of Finland's Social Democratic party, was reelected party chairman tonight.

"Flowers in Art" is the title of an exhibition to be held Thursday through April 30 at French Co., 978 Madison Avenue, as a benefit for the Fifth Avenue Association's program of beautification of New York.
A 27-year-old artist and a 28-year-old writer will receive the $1,000 Rosenthal Awards of the National Institute of Arts and Letters for 1960.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 17 -- The Government was reported today to be considering sealing the South African borders with the Britlish protectorates of Bechuanaland, Swaziland and Basutoland to cut off the escape of political refugees.
RANGOON, Burma, April 17 -- Premier Chou hailed the relations between Communist China and Burma as an example for other Asian nations in a speech made public here today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (UPI) -- Eddie Mathews got to Robin Roberts for a homer, triple and double today and the Milwaukee Braves made it two in a row over the Philadelphia Phillies with an 8-4 victory.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 17 -- Three generations of Eisenhowers joined today in Easter services.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Supreme Court held today that Federal courts cannot en join maritime union picketing of so-called flag-of-convenience vessels when they land at United States ports. The vote was 8 to 1.
CHELSEA, Vt., April 18 (UPI) -- Frank W. Carpenter, 44 years old, went on trial here today for kidnapping and man-slaughter in a case that has baffled Vermont law officers for more than two years.
Al Stubbins is a blond, 6-foot Englishman with a pushed-in nose -- flattened by a soccer-ball.
The director of the National Cancer Institute, who has been cured of skin cancer, has been named president of the new Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

The successful completion of what is believed to be the first natural gas well to produce at five levels was announced yesterday by the Sinclair Oil and Gas Company. The well is in the Gulf of Mexico, forty miles off the Louisiana coast.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower urged the Daughters of the American Revolution tonight to follow George Washington's advice and "observe good faith and justice toward all nations," the quotation being from Washington's Farewell Address.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 18 -- Making up more than three lengths in the stretch, Sharon Rodney, driven by Joe MacDonald, scored a head victory in the $5,000 final trotting race of the Class C April series before 19,909 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Shakespear Said It Just Right Poets have writ ten line upon line of maudlin sentiment about April, such as, "Every tear is answered by a blossom,/ Every sigh with songs and laughter blent," or, "Pit, pat, pitter clatter,/ Sudden sun and clatter patter!"
The American Society of Real Estate Counselors has adopted a code of ethics for its more than 150 members throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, leaving for the Washington-Boston baseball game, stepped out on the White House south portico today to greet several hundred Easter egg-rollers gathered on the lawn.
Agency executives have their problems -- king-size problems -- when it comes to selecting television programs that will interest their clients.

SEVERAL stores in the New York area offer special services, clothing and equipment for children going to camp. Some of these are listed here. Also, other stores that do not carry camp equipment provide camp clothing in the children's sportswear departments.

Continuing negotiations between Freeport Nickel Company and the Cuban Government may yet open the way for a resumption of mining operations at the $75,000,000 Moa Bay works, a Freeport Nickel official declared yesterday.
TRENTON, April 18 (AP) -- Hundreds of out-of-state residents gave money to the Republican campaigns of Senator Case, associated with the liberal wing of the party, and Mr. Morris, a conservative.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. showed a drop of 4.5 per cent in earnings in the first quarter from the 1959 level despite a 6 per cent increase in sales. Total net income was down about 3 per cent.

TROUT fishing within 150 miles or so of New York is now pretty fair and getting better, especially, in near-by Westchester and Putnam waters. There are some fly hatches and fish have been taken in the last few days on dries.

PAU, France, April 18 (AP) -- Jack Brabham of Australia, the world driving champion, won the Grand Prix of Pau automobile race with a Cooper today after a thrilling duel with Maurice Trintignant of France. The Frenchman drove a Cooper Climax.
Opponents of the proposed sidewalk cafe in Central Park are planning to fight it before the Board of Estimate and the Municipal Art Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a natural gas case that is of major importance to producers and users across the country and of special interest to New York City.

SEOUL, Tuesday, April 19 (UPI) -- The decision to declare a form of martial law was made at a Cabinet meeting while the rioting was in progress. Dr. Rhee placed his Army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Song Yo Chan, in charge of Seoul's security.
Murray Shelton, who has pleaded guilty or been convicted sixteen times in Housing Court, won his first case there yesterday.
MOST women have moments of crisis with their own wardrobes. However, these problems seem downright playful compared with that of clothing a child going to a summer camp.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the growing proportion of old people in the population called for more attention to chronic illnesses and rehabilitation work by the hospitals.
Richmond Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco appealed to Mayor Wagner yesterday to intervene in the controversy over Staten Island assessments.
Contracts probably will be signed today or tomorrow for the return heavyweight title bout between Ingemar Johansson of Sweden and Floyd Patterson.
The Seamen's Church Institute of New York leased land near Port Newark yesterday to convert it into a recreational and spiritual center for 40,000 merchant seamen whose port of call is Newark.

Bernard Newman appealed last night to civic groups and political independents to join with the Republican party in this city in organizing and supporting a fusion ticket for the 1961 municipal elections.
NEW DELHI, India, April 18 -- Premier Chou En-Lai is expected to bring broad new proposals when he arrives here tomorrow for talks on the India-China border dispute.

More than 1,300 stockholders of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., gathered at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday to hear some pleasant news at their annual meeting. The news, given by John E. McKeen, president, was that first-quarter sales and earnings were "substantially" higher than in the like period of last year.

An operation on a 4-year-old Greek boy to correct a potentially fatal congenital heart condition was performed yesterday at the Parkchester General Hospital, the Bronx. It was made possible by his new-found friends in this country.
LOS ANGELES, April 18 -- A fourteen-member arrangements committee went over the grounds and the ground rules today for the Democratic National Convention.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 17 -- A Roman Catholic priest disclosed today that he was the author of a novel bitterly attacking apartheid, South Africa's policy of racial separation.
WARSAW, April 16 -- There are indications that all the Communist countries of Eastern Europe except Albania are adopting a more favorable attitude toward the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I congratulate The Times on the editorial of April 14 endorsing the appointment of J. Clarence Davies Jr. as chairman of the newly created Housing and Redevelopment Board and urging that James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, be retained in his present office.

The Lionel Corporation and it's subsidiaries showed a sharp recovery in the first quarter this year, with sales more than triple those of the 1959 period. They were $1,996,973, compared with $549,427.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points (50 cents a bale) down to 5 points (25 cents a bale) up yesterday.

The Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Alabama has asked the National Council of his church to "repudiate" a recent document expressing sympathy for the current Negro sitdown movement in the South.
The present college enrollment "crisis" has been called a "statistical illusion" by a university official here.
Zubin Mehta, a 23-year-old conductor from Bombay, India, will make his professional conducting debut in this country at three Lewisohn Stadium concerts in the summer.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 18 -- Former President Harry S. Truman said today that Communists were engineering the student sit downs at lunch counters in the South.
Two of the metropolitan area's most improved half-milers will oppose Tom Murphy on Saturday in a special 800-meter race.

Donna Patrizia Ruspoli, junior chairman of the first American Debutante Ball in Rome, and her mother, Princess Viriginia Ruspoli, will be honored at a reception given by the American Committee for the ball at the Gotham on May 11.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Senator Wayne Morse said today that when he went to Toledo, Ohio, last January and opened a teamster union candidate's campaign for Congress he received a lecture fee of $500 plus expenses.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- Increased demand late in the session and a lack of bearish influences steadied prices for most grains on the Board of Trade today.

THE devotion of Newbold Morris to the City of New York was never demonstrated better than on sixty-five consecutive evenings in 1940, when Fiorello H. La Guardia was Mayor and Mr. Morris wag president of the City Council.

MONTREAL, April 18 -- The St. Lawrence Seaway was opened for business at 8:27 A.M. today. The freighter Lemoyne, dressed in her ceremonial best with flags and bunting, led the way as she entered the first lock of the waterway at St. Lambert, opposite Montreal on the south shore of the St. Lawrence River.

THE shortest story in town is Jay Thorpe's seasonal collection of little furs. A subtle tale, it is a study in artfully worked skins fashioned into brief shrugs, tiny boleros, cropped jackets and cleverly manipulated stoles.

Vickers-Armstrongs, Ltd., British manufacturer of aircraft, filed suit yesterday in Federal Court here for $33,841,973 that it said was "due and payable" from its principal American customer, Capital Airlines.

The International Longshoremen's Association will consider a port-wide strike to support the Office Employes International Union. This was announced yesterday by Ben J. Cohan, secretary-treasurer of the office union's Local 153.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- A brisk demand for hogs pushed prices to their highest levels of the year on the Chicago market today.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., April 18 -- Senator John F. Kennedy lashed out today at religious bigotry and charged his opponents with trying to "gang up" to deny him the Presidential nomination.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 18 -- A grade-a-year desegregation plan filed with the Federal Court here by the city's school board was attacked today as unconstitutional.

Futures trading in fresh, medium shell eggs opened yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract was added to futures trading in potatoes and platinum and in spot trading of eggs and butter.

William Stone and David Poliakine gave a program of sonatas for violin and piano last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Stone has played previously in this city. His partner at the piano, Mr. Poliakine, was more of an unknown quantity.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 17 -- Bolivia has made a financial recovery during the last year that could be of lasting significance if followed up by measures to promote investment.

Enthusiasm seemed to return to the stock market yesterday. Volume rose encouragingly. There were good gains for stocks recommended by investment advisers and brokers. But when the day ended, some indexes found the market had edged up, other showed it off a bit.
MOSCOW, April 18 -- A big Soviet audience gave a fifteen-minute standing ovation tonight to its first view of an American musical comedy.
A leading Moscow writer has called upon Soviet intellectuals to join in a crusade to "bring light to the dark continent."

Jack R. Dick, 33, a former co-owner of the National Stove Company, was charged yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission of using a friend's name and credit to defraud ten or more firms that are members of the New York Stock Exchange.

SEVENTY-nine bridge players, officials and writers including their spouses in many cases, are to leave by chartered plane this afternoon from Idlewild for Turin, Italy, where the olympiad world bridge tournament will be played from next Saturday to Wednesday, May 4.
TRENTON, April 18 -- New Jersey voters will go to the polls tomorrow to nominate candidates for one seat in the United States Senate and fourteen in the House of Representatives.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, April 19 -- Thousands of anti-Government demonstrators surging toward President Syngman Rhee's palace were repulsed today by forty-five minutes of police rifle fire. Up to thirty persons were believed killed or wounded. President Rhee's Government declared "preparatory" martial law. There was no immediate clarification of the exact meaning of "preparatory" martial law.
YONKERS, April 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Freda and their three children are living in a home on wheels -- but going nowhere.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A Philadelphia record distributor linked to Dick Clark, the disk jockey, has agreed to a consent order forbidding payola as an inducement to broadcast records.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- A State Department spokesman denied today Premier Fidel Castro's charge that United States personnel at the Guantanamo Naval Base were participating in "counter-revolutionary" activity against his regime.

Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that Robert C. Weaver, former New York State Sent Administrator, and Walter S. Fried, regional director of the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency, would be named to the new Housing and Redevelopment Board.

The stars and the near-stars are at it again, trying to arrive at a satisfactory scoring system for match-play bowling. The Petersen point system is now most widely in use, but members of the Professional Bowlers Association will try a modified Petersen system during the second annual Paramus (N.J.) Open in New Jersey May 20 through 22.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Despite reduced employment and production, personal income advanced slightly in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

Reporting on his tour of inspection from coast to coast, Clifford (Tip) Goes, the chairman of the United States Olympic Rowing Committee, predicted yesterday that competition for places on the American team in 1960 would be the keenest in years.
DOUBLE all the good things said about the Phoenix' "Henry IV, Part 1," a few weeks ago. Familiarity with the chief characters and the story has given finish to the acting.
BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- As usual, Johnny Kelley is the man to beat in the Boston Athletic Association marathon tomorrow.
MOSCOW, April 18 (AP) -- Canada and the Soviet Union signed today a three-year trade pact under which the Russians will spend two dollars in Canada for every Canadian dollar spent here.

Plantings at Princeton University and several private gardens in that community will be included in the annual gpring garden tour of the Volunteer Associates of the New York Botanical Garden on May 12.

With its single beamish headlight, Cyclops 3d has rolled into the minds of quite a few Americans, it would seem. Not a one-eyed monster, not a guided missile, not even a new computer, Cyclops 2d is a myth of a car.
The boxer beat the brawler last night when Jose Gonzalez of Puerto Rico posted a unanimous decision over Bill Flamio of the Bronx in the ten-round main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

OSAKA, Japan, April 18 -- This year for the first time the International Music Festival of Osaka has included a Japanese opera. It is a strongly pro-American work that has Townsend Harris, the first United States consul in Japan, as its hero.

Tens of thousands of city dwellers and commuters were late getting to work yesterday morning as rush-hour delays disrupted schedules on the BMT and IND subways, the New Haven Railroad and the Harlem Division of the New York Central Railroad.
A huge carton of political campaign material, including a complete set of instructions for organizing Johnson-for-President clubs, arrived in New York yesterday from Austin, Tex.
A super-luxury compact car of unusual design and advanced engineering arrived from Italy yesterday and was hustled off to the Fourth International Automobile Show at the Coliseum.

PARIS, April 18 -- Some diplomats and officials of the Allies who have discussed the nuclear weapons situation with General de Gaulle, or to whom his meditations on their subject have been transmitted by their opposite numbers in his Government, reflect a contrast with political strategy in the United States that could not possibly be sharper.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 18 -- The Nationalist Government of Prime Minister Hendrik P. Verwoerd is wooing South Africa's 1,400,000 people of mixed race with strange intensity. It does not quite promise full equality, but hints that some of the more humiliating aspects of apartheid may be softened for them.
Mayor Wagner made it official yesterday that Newbold Morris, former President of the City Council, would be the second city-wide Park Commissioner in New York's history.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 -- A room 6 feet in all dimensions grows in a few hundredths of a second into spherical-shaped room of a 125-foot diameter. Even more quickly, the normal atmospheric pressure in the room rockets to 7,000,000 times what it was.
HAVANA, April 18 -- Two leaders of the Christian Democratic Movement, which last week issued a manifesto critical of the Government, have sought political asylum in the Ecuadoran Embassy.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- Movie production is expected to be stepped up beginning tomorrow, with filming due to start at studios that have not been in production for weeks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I wish to voice my protest as a Cuban against the letter written in behalf of President Eisenhower by Walter Howe to the Students Federation of Chile. We consider that it does not represent a true picture of the situation and represents an aggression to our revolution and our country.

Yesterday was the day of reckoning for the city's amateur accountants and professional procrastinators. They turned out in record numbers to prove that although they may not like to pay income taxes, they derive some enjoyment from paying them at the last possible moment.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today returned to a lower court for clarification a case questioning the power of Congress to take away the citizenship of men who leave the country to avoid military service.
TANGIER, Morocco, Tuesday, April 19 -- The booming, swashbuckling era of the ancient city of Tangier ended last night.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- The Soviet Union was reported today to have opened more cities and a Baltic beach resort to foreign visitors. Time limits for visits to the capital of the Baltic state of Latvia also are said to have been extended.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld today a deportation order against a 50-year-old Portland, Ore., house painter who was brought to this country from Finland when less than a year old.
LONDON, April 18 -- Britain's biggest and most significant demonstration against nuclear weapons ended in Trafalgar Square this afternoon with the cheers of a crowd of about 75,000.

Several lawyers and a retired New York City detective are being investigated in connection with the substitution of records showing no convictions for defendants with prior convictions in gambling cases.

THIS year's edition of "Master Drawings from Five Centuries" at the Este Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street, covers a lot of territory and covers it well. There are good Renaissance examples -- a fine little ink study of Hercules and the Lion by a contemporary of Titian, for instance -- as well as twentieth-century works.

Following the firm stand taken by the Western powers at Washington on Germany and Berlin, the Soviets now seek to surround Premier Khrushchev's brinkmanship with a deceptive air of reasonableness that does nothing to lessen their demands or threats. They continue to reject the Western peace plan based on German reunification by means of free and properly supervised elections, starting with "Greater Berlin."
TWELVE years ago this month the Helen Worth Cooking School was founded in a one-and-a-half-room apartment with three students and two chairs.

The investment banking community had under study yesterday a proposal to start the permanent financing of the Verrazano Narrows Bridge. This would be accomplished by the sale of $100,000,000 of long-term revenue bonds of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority bearing interest rates ranging from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent.

First-quarter net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation rose 35 per cent above that for the 1959 period on a sales gain of 4 per cent. Mark W. Cresap Jr., president, and Gwilym A. Price, chairman, reported yesterday that the company cleared $19,496,000, equal to 55 cents a common share.
DANBURY, Conn., April 18 -- Beardsley Ruml, who devised the pay-as-you-go plan for the payment of Federal income tax, died of a heart ailment this morning in Danbury Hospital. He was 65 years old.

OTTAWA, April 18 -- President de Gaulle arrived here tonight to begin a series of presummit talks with Canadian and United States leaders. He is expected to seek to promote a better understanding of French policies.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy predicted yesterday that new policemen would be required to be college graduates "in the relatively near future."

THE Ars Nova Orchestra played a concert at Carnegie Hall last night under the direction of Robert Mandell, with Vivian Rivkin, pianist; Alfred Zega, baritone, and Gerald Goodman, harpist, as soloists.
Two anti-Trujillo exiles were acquitted yesterday on charges of violating the city's Administrative Code.

NICE, France, April 18 -- In Italy, profits from the State-run soccer pools paid for the 1956 winter Olympics at Cortina d'Ampezzo. They also paid for the half-dozen new arenas constructed for the 1960 Olympics at Rome next summer and will pay for the games themselves.
HAVANA, April 18 -- Premier Fidel Castro charged today that United States authorities at Guantanamo Naval Base were connected with a plot to organize counter-revolutionary resistance in eastern Cuba.

GRANDMOTHERS out to pamper the young ones in the family will find their objective made easy with the opening of twin shops at Lord Taylor tomorrow. Called the "Grandmother's Boutique," on the seventh floor, the shops are divided into infants' and toddlers' sizes, and boys' and girls' clothes through the age of 10 years.

The Hupp Corporation, maker of air conditioning equipment, heating products and household appliances, is planning to expand into the roofing and siding materials business through a proposed purchase of a controlling interest in the Tilo Roofing Company.
The annual Clarence Derwent Awards for the best performances by an actor and an actress in non-starring roles have been voted to Rochelle Oliver and William Daniels.
ALBANY, April 18 -- Governor Rockefeller signed into law today a fifty-four-page bill designed to make state income tax regulations conform as closely as possible with comparable Federal regulations.
"The Tab Hunter Show," a filmed situation comedy series, has been scheduled by the National Broadcasting Company as a Sunday evening feature from 8:30 to 9 o'clock, effective next fall.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Senator Robert C. Byrd accused the forces of Senator Kennedy today of trying to assume and capitalize on an underdog role in the West Virginia Democratic Presidential primary.

THE customer is always right, at least as far as Best Co. is concerned. To cut down on expensive alterations for women who like misses' sizes and styling but whose figures demand a slightly different cut, the store is adding a new group of half-sizes to augment its present collection of misses' dresses on the third floor.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 18 -- The third annual report of the European Atomic Energy Community, to be published here tomorrow, reflects a decline in interest in nuclear power production because of high costs.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Treasury bill rate fell back somewhat this week after last week's large increase, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
BOSTON, April 18 -- An agreement for the sale of the South Station Railroad Terminal for $1,000,000 was signed today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am in agreement with your editorial of April 12 regarding the "paltry refugee relief bill passed in an offhand manner" by the House of Representatives last week.
Twenty-three professional men and women from the Republics of Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan in the central Asian part of Russia got a taste yesterday of campus life, Ivy League style.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 -- Stock plans for school buildings, such as are about to be introduced in New York State, were attacked today by the head of the nation's organized architects.
Steel production is expected to show a slight increase this week, reversing a steady six-week decline, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Another chapter of a success story that had been interupted for almost ten months because of a leg injury was written by Mrs. Ethel Jacob's Promised Land at Aqueduct yesterday.
ALBANY, April 18 -- State law-enforcement officials got new weapons today for waging war on professional gambling syndicates.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Vice President Nixon is working quietly on the farm problem with a twofold purpose.
Interest rates are tied closely to prosperity or recession, a New York University study finds.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 18 -- Sidestepping his ideological quarrel with the Kremlin, President Tito moved today to support Soviet Premier Khrushchev on a variety of international issues.
BOSTON, April 18 -- Hoping for the best, Casey Stengel marshaled his forces tonight for what could be the most important campaign of his career.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- President Eisenhower made his last appearance today as an opening-day pitcher. He interrupted his golfing vacation in Georgia to throw out the first ball of the American League season at the Senators-Red Sox game.
Bond prices drifted downward yesterday in a holdover of the listlessness that seized the market in the wake of the Treasury's last refunding and cash borrowing operations.

Earnings of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation for the first quarter rose sharply to $8,567,000, or 64 cents a share, from $6,395,000 or 48 cents a share last year, the company reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, April 18 (AP) -- Herb Score, the former strikeout artist for whom the Boston Red Sox once offered $1,000,000, was traded by the Cleveland Indians to the Chicago White Sox today for Barry Latman, a right-handed pitcher.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The artist in Communist China not only enjoys prestige, but also has a superior economic status, Sir Herbert Read said today.

THESE ARE MY LOVES, a solo entertainment, starring Claire Luce. Excerpts from a number of plays will be given. Presented by the Playhouse Company: production stage manager. Leslie Cutler: staging supervisor, William Astbury; artistic adviser, Florence Colebrook Powers; musical continuity.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn voiced hope today that a compromise plan of medical care for the aged could be worked out without getting into the field of "socialized medicine."
Three New York University professors were named yesterday as the 1960 winners of the Great Teachers Awards of N.Y.U.'s Alumni Federation.

THIS has been a prime season for early Marc Blitzstein. Two months ago the New York City Opera Company revived "The Cradle Will Rock." Last night the Composers' Showcase, which uses the Circle in the Square Theatre on off nights, brought back "No for an Answer."

BOSTON, April 18 -- Don't look now, but the American League season is finally getting under way. Honest Injun! The boys have been dilly-dallying for so long that some cynics were beginning to wonder if the Americans were waiting for the Continental League to catch up with them for a joint opening in 1961.

LONDON, April 18 (AP) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers stayed at the head of the English soccer standings with a victory today as the Tottenham Hotspurs and Burnley, who had been tied with them, lost their matches.

CAIRO, April 18 -- Stevedores and dockworkers in United Arab Republic ports said today that they would boycott visiting United States ships unless the freighter Cleopatra was unloaded and serviced in New York.

The defense rested yesterday in the income tax evasion trial of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Federal Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan told the jurors he hoped to give the case to them for a decision Thursday morning.

Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., which supplies electricity and gas to a large area of suburban New York and New Jersey, is making a subscription offering of 39,165 shares of convertible cumulative preferred stock to its present shareholders.
DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- Passenger car production increased last week as the nation's auto makers sought to achieve their planned April goal of 587,800 units.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Stork Club restaurant lost ground here today in its attempt to keep union pickets away from its doors after more than three years.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
THE scene was Blenheim Palace a few years ago. The Duke and Duchess of Marlborough were given a reception of some sort. Among those present were Perle Mesta and Sir Winston Churchill.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals here ruled today that union picketing of a General Electric Company plant at Appliance Park, Louisville, Ky., had violated the secondary boycott provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 18 -- About 400 Africans were arrested today in advance of a showdown expected tomorrow on a nation-wide protest work stoppage called by African leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Frank Kowalski, Democrat of Connecticut, charged today a "high pressure and coercive" drive was under way to collect money from Air Force officers and enlisted men to build a stadium at the Air Force Academy.

MILAN, Italy, April 19 -- Thirty-four countries are participating in the thirty-eighth Milan Samples Fair this year. The United States exhibit, organized with the cooperation of private industry by the Department of Commerce through its office of International Fairs, has proved extremely popular and has been drawing large crowds.

An issue of $100,000,000 of bonds, representing the first public financing of the $325,000,000 Verrazano-Narrows Bridge project, was placed on the market yesterday at prices equaling tax-exempt long-term yields ranging from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent.
There are rumblings from across the Atlantic.

BQSTON, April 19 -- The Yankees today took their first full stride toward retrieving the fortunes that slipped away from them in 1959. They helped open the American League championship season in Boston by thrashing the Red Sox, 8 to 4.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A plan of optional health insurance for Social Security pensioners emerged today as a likely basis for compromise legislation.

One hundred twenty-seven more persons were hurt in automobile accidents here last week than in the corresponding 1959 period, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. The total injured last week was 1,011.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Army permitted a first look today at an airborne radar system capable of taking detailed pictures deep into enemy territory from an aircraft flying over friendly lines miles away.
NEW YORKERS will see red -- and blue and green and yellow -- in a new light after viewing the exhibit opening today at the Cooper Union Museum.
The Commonwealth of Australia borrowed $25,000,00 in the United States public capital market yesterday at a cost of 5.671 per cent.
Paul Hall clarified yesterday which of his several maritime labor "hats" he was wearing last week when he attacked James R. Hoffa as a "notorious fink and whistle blower.''
NEW DELHI, India, April 19 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China arrived here today and received a welcome that was diplomatically correct but hardly friendly.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington said today the Civil Aeronautics Board had been "taking pot shots" at E.R. Quesada, head of the Federal Aviation Agency.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Roman Catholic educators were advised here today against a parochial or too-narrow concept of teaching if they were to attain excellence. They were also told that they had no "opening gambits -- only counter-moves" in the competition with other educational systems.
Assemblyman Frank J. McMullen of Bay Ridge has been proposed by the Brooklyn Republican organization as a successor to Aaron L. Jacoby on the State Public Service Commission.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 19 -- President Eisenhower offered today to give to the Government the bulk of his personal papers on condition that they be deposited and maintained by the United States in perpetuity at the Eisenhower Presidential Library at Abilene, Kan.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point (5 cents a bale) up to 10 points (50 cents a bale) down yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your April 15 editorial entitled "The Blue Cross Rate Raise" rightly points out that a large share of the proposed increases in Blue Cross premium rates relates to rising hospital costs. Unfortunately, the hospitals have been negligent in failing adequately to inform the public of the reasons for their rapidly rising costs, costs which have increased on the average by 15.2 per cent a year since 1946.

MRS. OTTILIE REILLY was one of those who introduced the game of canasta to the United States back in 1949, thus helping to start the biggest of all card-playing fads. Since then she has become nationally known as the authority on the various canastalike games, which now rival their parent game in popularity.
It is enormously ironic that former President Harry S. Truman should be the one to suggest that Communists are engineering the student "sit-downs" at lunch counters all over the South.

John W. McGovern, president of the United States Rubber Company, yesterday called the business pessimism of the last few months unwarranted. He forecast new records in sales and earnings for his company this year.
Fifty-three grants totaling $3,131,658, mostly for scholarship, research, education and travel, were announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It was with the greatest distress that I read the April 12 article "Fear and Hatred Grip Birmingham," by Harrison Salisbury, whose ordinarily balanced and perceptive reporting I have admired for years.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 -- Revival of the center core of cities is being hampered by misguided efforts to transplant features of suburban life to the center of town, a New York architect declared today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19 (UPI) -- Johnny Podres held the San Francisco Giants to five scattered hits today while pitching the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-0 victory. The triumph enabled the Dodgers to gain sole possession of first place in the National League.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A bill to let manufacturers fix retail prices for their products throughout the country was buried today in the House Rules Committee. By a vote of 6 to 4 with two abstentions, the committee tabled the so-called National "Fair Trade" Bill. The measure had been approved by the House Commerce Committee last May but had rested quietly in the Rules Committee since then.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Following is the State Department's statement today on Korea:

A total of $350 in fines was levied yesterday in Housing Court against the owner and lessee of 218-224 West 112th Street, a tenement where 350 multiple-dwelling violations have been listed by the city.
A major segment of the port of New York is threatened with a tie-up beginning at 7 A.M. tomorrow because of a dispute over the organizing of ninety white-collar workers.

VALDOSTA, Ga., April 19 (UPI) -- The Lowndes County Board of Education reversed its stand on a pupil-paddling case today and backed the teachers who had resigned and forced the closing of Hahira High School.

A TIDY band of British invaded a disarmed Manhattan Island yesterday In the frank noon sunlight. Clad in immaculate white woolen, pressed flannels and tweeds, they descended by air and by sea equipped with goodwill, tiaras, and a fashion collection they hoped would win the respect of American women.
Ingemar Jonansson, the world heavyweight champion, and Floyd Patterson are scheduled to sign contracts tomorrow morning for their return title bout.

BOSTON, April 19 -- One swing peeled off the years for Ted Williams and made him as bright, as buoyant and as eager as he had been in his rookie season in 1939. Grumpy during spring training and discouraged almost to the point of despair, the big slugger arrived at Fenway Park this morning for the Yankee-Red Sax opener with joy in his heart and a smile on his lips.
LONDON, April 19 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers increased their lead in the First Division of the English Soccer League today as the result of a lucky break on Nottingham Forest's ground.

PITTSBURGH, April 19 (UPI) -- Jim Owens, mixing a slider and sinker with an occasional curve ball, doled out three hits and struck out nine tonight to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

THE American Ballet Theatre opened last night a three-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House in celebration of its twentieth anniversary. There seemed, however, to be little to celebrate beyond the mere passage of time, and that, in all conscience, is no cause for rejoicing.

ST. LOUIS, April 19 (UPI) -- Stan Musial broke up a close game with a clutch double tonight, enabling the St. Louis Cardinals to beat the Chicago Cubs, 5 -- 2. It was the Cardinals' first victory in six games this season.

Whistree beat Moon Shot by a nose in the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday. The race was hardly one of the more important offerings of the local season, but it was a tingler, with Whistree winning in the final stride.
ALBANY, April 19 -- The creation of a special county commission to study the need for a medical college in Nassau County was authorized today by Governor Rockefeller.

Senator Clifford P. Case won renomination yesterday in New Jersey's Republican primary election. His margin of nearly 2 to 1 over Robert Morris marked a decisive gain for the liberal element of New Jersey Republicans.

IN 1916 there were more kinds of pioneers in Southern California than the first settlers of Hollywood's movie colony. Far more in keeping with the pioneer tradition were the families who had bought ten and twenty-acre sections from Mr. Sylvester Perkins in the 5,000 acres of treeless, waterless sage, cactus and sand country he called The Tract.
Secretary of the Interior Fred A. Seaton last night pledged his Federal agency's support for rehabilitation of four of the city's historical shrines in time for the World's Fair in 1964.
Labor's counterpart of a Presidential nominating convention will be held in Chicago Aug. 17.
The two leading performers for the forthcoming revival of "The King and I," which is to serve as the second item in the City Center's annual spring festival of musicals, were signed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Capital Airlines said today that at least part of the nearly $34,000,000 it owes a British aircraft concern is guaranteed against default.

The building at Old Country Road and Manetta -- Hill Road in Plainview, L.I., has been sold by Alexander Muss, the builder, to an investing client of Paul Crosney, broker, who negotiated the deal in conjunction with Baiter Greenberg, Inc.

Alastair B. Martin, a former national amateur titleholder, and J.S. (Bud) Palmer led the field into the quarter-finals of the United States open court-tennis doubles championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Daughters of the American Revolution were asked today to demand a Congressional investigation of the international culture exchange program.

A possible merger of Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., Fullerton, Calif., and the Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., New Orleans, is being discussed, it was announced yesterday by Norton Simon, president of Hunt, and E.A. Geoghegan, president of Wesson.
Democrats are planning a pay-now-see-later telethon to raise money to finance fall television appearances by their nominees for President and Vice President.
"The roof of the world," the majestic mountains and tortuous passes of the Karakoram and Himalayan ranges, will be the focus of great power politics today.
First-quarter interim earnings and revenues of American Machine and Foundry Company were higher than for any first quarter on record, Morehead Patterson, chairman, told the annual meeting yesterday.

CLEVELAND, April 19 (AP) -- A two-run single by Al Kaline in the fifteenth inning lifted the Detroit Tigers to a 4-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians before an opening-day crowd of 52,756 today at Municipal Stadium.

Ilka Chase, author of "In Bed We Cry" and other books, will have a novel published tomorrow by Doubleday. Called "Three Men on the Left Hand," it is a story about a girl making herself a career in New York and the three men whose gifts she wears on her left hand.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- Trade in the grain futures market today was limited generally to a few contracts with old-crop wheat again attracting the best support. It was up a cent.
