THE first spring stirrings of game fish have occurred in Long Island waters. The first striped bass has been caught on purpose in Little Neck Bay and the first top-striking pollock have been taken off Southwest Ledge.
MARCUS HOOK, Pa., April 19 (AP) -- Stockholders of Sun Oil Company, heard today that the company planned to expand its petrochemical business.

Counsel for Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. charged yesterday in Federal Court that his client's indictment and trial on a charge of income-tax evasion were an attempt at "political intimidation."
ALBANY, April 19 -- Governor Rockefeller signed into law today a bill establishing a statewide minimum wage of $1 an hour.

A decline in first-quarter earnings and the start of a $12,000,000 expansion, program were announced by John R. Kennedy, president of the Federal Paper Board Company, Inc., at the annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

The fourteenth game of the world chess championship match, played last night in Moscow between Mikhail Botvinnik, the titleholder, and Mikhail Tal resulted in another draw -- the eighth of the series. Twenty-two, moves were made.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, April 20 -- Heavy tanks and a full division of South Korean troops patrolling the littered streets of Seoul have restored quiet to the riot-torn capital where scores were killed and hundreds injured in yesterday's bloody uprising.
The Federal Census Bureau is opening a "Were you counted?" campaign through newspapers, radio and television.
THE following dinner menu A is a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-toprepare main dish.
Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy yesterday permanently enjoined Jack R. Dick, former co-owner of the National Stove Company, from trading in a "fraudulent" manner on the New York Stock Exchange.

Cottonseed oil futures fell 4 to 9 points (hundreds of a cent a pound) yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. The volume was 485 tank cars, 60,000 pounds to a car, the third largest volume of the year.

Earnings for the second fiscal quarter ended March 31 of American Steel Foundries totaled $2,019,012, or 68 cents a share, against $1,678,645, or 64 cents a share, a year earlier, the company announced yesterday.

GENEVA, April 19 -- Canada said today that she would consider the Soviet demand for renunciation of first use of nuclear weapons, but only after important disarmament steps had been carried out and verified.

CHICAGO, April 19 (UPI) -- Minnie Minoso hit two home runs for the Chicago White Sox today. The second one, leading off the ninth, lifted the American League champions to a 10-9 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

The world's biggest annual meeting of stockholders takes place today in the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx. Officials of American Telephone and Telegraph Company frankly have no idea how many people will show.

The New York Drama Critics Circle yesterday voted "Toys in the Attic" as the best American drama of the 1959-60 season, "Fiorello!" as the leading musical and "Five Finger Exercise" as the top foreign play.
A grand jury began hearing evidence yesterday on the substitution of fake police records for the true records of defendants in gambling cases who had previous convictions.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The United States said today that a controlled press was a hallmark of dictatorship and that Premier Fidel Castro controlled 95 per cent of the Cuban press.

BOZEMAN, Mont., April 19 (AP) -- Gene Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, is ruled a solid favorite over Joey Giardello for Fullmer's second defense of his world middleweight title, National Boxing Association version, tomorrow night in the Montana State College Fieldhouse.

RANGOON, Burma, April 19 -- Premier Chou said at the airport before leaving for India today that he was hopeful of reaching a settlement of the China-India border dispute during his talks with Prime Minister Nehru.

CLEVELAND, April 19 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted two corporations and nineteen individuals today in an alleged stock swindle involving millions of dollars. The defendants reside in New York, New Jersey, California and Canada.
Joseph F. Periconi pledged himself yesterday to work for more efficient service and greater safety on the city's transit system.
NEW ORLEANS, April 19 (AP) -- Democratic nominee Jimmie Davis received a record vote for a Louisiana general election, defeating Francis Grevemberg, a Republican, in the gubernatorial contest today.

The weight of undistributed new issues of high-grade corporate bonds descended on the market at the start of trading yesterday, setting the stage for a long-apprehended price a justment under distress conditions.
WASHINGTON, April, 19 -- The United States Government sternly rebuked the South Korean Government today, accusing it of adopting "repressive measures unsuited to a free democracy."

Columbia overcame a firstinning deficit of five runs to beat Princeton, 6 -- 5, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game yesterday. The Lions won at Baker Field as Luke Urban scored in the seventh on Tom Vassel's sacrifice fly.

LEUT. GEN. EEDSON LOUIS MILLARD BURNS has six rows of decorations to show that he is a resolute soldier of war. He has almost six years of service as a "truce commander" in the Middle East to show that he is a resolute soldier of peace.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 19 -- A spectacular crack-up marred the Class C April series pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, said today the White House decided "some time ago" not to reappoint William R. Connole to the Federal power Commission.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LONDON, April 19 -- Demand remained light and selective on the stock market here today and the majority of the industrial leaders finished down slightly.

Medical experts testified yesterday that chemical tests used by the New York State Racing Commission laboratories on horses suspected of being doped did not fully protect the betting public. Tests results were not "definitive," they said.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 19 -- The home of a Nashville City Councilman was bombed today, and more than 2,000 Negroes, mostly students, marched on City Hall to protest failure of the police to halt racial violence.

The country's century-old system of customs-enforcement will be changed radically May 1 when all enforcement men of the Customs Bureau are transferred to the control of the bureau's investigative branch.
Richmond Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco testified for more than two hours yesterday before a grand jury investigating Staten Island affairs.
DETROIT, April 19 -- The Chrysler Corporation announced formally today that it would market its second compact car this fall.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Two scientific advisers to the Administration testified today that under the latest United States proposal for a ban on nuclear weapon testing there would be less than a 10 per cent chance that a Soviet violation would be discovered.

Thirty American actors sat spellbound yesterday as a Soviet director discoursed for five hours on the first twelve words of a play he was putting into rehearsal. Through an interpreter, he spoke on love, religion, the masculinity of American women's hands and the lateness of trains in pre-revolutionary Russia.

BALTIMORE, April 19 (UPI) Gene Woodling's two-cut double in the seventh scored Jackie Brandt from first base and gave the Orioles a 3 -- 2 victory over the Senators today in the Baltimore season opener. A crowd of 32,747 saw the game.
South Korea, for whose freedom men from many lands have died, has brought tragic frustration to many of its citizens and deep concern to its allies.

ONE of the most abiding impressions that General de Gaulle will find in America is a consummate interest in beef. A fairly extensive survey of menus on the President's behalf shows that it will greet him tomorrow at a banquet in Montreal, he will dine on it twice in New York and at least once in San Francisco.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 19 -- The suspension of all party political activity in Turkey for three months follows an increasingly violent and bitter trend of Turkish politics in recent years.
Dr. Paul L. Ward, Professor of History and chairman of the History Department at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, has been chosen as president of Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y.

To a New York City accustomed to Republican silence on local governmental affairs for three years out of four, the full-length discussion of civic issues by Bernard Newman, the New York County Republican chairman, given before the City Club was a constructive departure.

The Appellate Division ordered the State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday to reconsider a ruling that granted the Arabian-American Oil Company the right to make inquiries about religion before hiring for jobs in Saudi Arabia.
The American Lutheran Magazine urged yesterday that official Roman Catholic sources declare that the "traditional" Catholic position on church-state relations does not apply to the United States.
ALBANY, April 19 -- Governor Rockefeller cleared the way today for a massive crackdown on speeding drivers through the use of radar detection equipment.

Ultra-conservative fundamentalist critics of the National Council of Churches were described here yesterday as "religious racketeers in using glib falsehoods and half-truths much as the Communists have done."
TRENTON, April 19 (AP) -- An appeal to the state Supreme Court today gave three Camden men an automatic stay of execution less than nine hours before they were to die in the electric chair.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 19 -- African workers flocked back to their jobs today after a four-day Easter holiday, ending a threat of a week-long strike.

OSAKA, Japan, April 19 -- The Czech Chamber Orchestra, which opened the Osaka International Festival on April 6, last night gave the fourth and last of its concerts here. It was a program of subtlety, finesse and grace, qualities that were conspicuously lacking from the American negotiations that account for the presence of the Czechs in japan's second largest city.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- "You can't teach a hog anything, but you can learn a lot from a hog."

Until just after 11 A.M. yesterday, stocks showed small gains over the Monday close. Then a steady decline set in and the day ended with market values on the New York Stock Exchange down about $2,500,000,000.
OTTAWA, April 19 -- France is opposed to any attempt by the West to press for a solution of the German problem at the summit talks next month, President de Gaulle said here today.

New York State Income Tax Bureau employes nibbled away it a growing mountain of mail yesterday and there was every indication that cases of indigestion might precede the eventual consumption of some 6,800,000 personal income tax returns now in hand.
CAIRO, April 19 -- United States Ambassador G. Frederick Reinhart discussed the Cleopatra case at the Foreign Office of the United Arab Republic twice today.

PARIS. Americana have little experience in dealing with a man like Charles de Gaulle. His is the authentic grand manner, resembling that of monarchs in former times, but disappearing even from monarchies during this democratic age.

BOSTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Paavo Kotila, a 32-year-old Finn, won the sixty-fourth annual Boston Marathon by half a mile today. His time was 2 hours 20 minutes 54 seconds and the victory was Finland's fourth in eight years.

SEOUL, Wednesday, April 20 (AP) -- Defiant students and townspeople armed with guns, knives and clubs held mob control over northeastern Seoul today in the fiery revolt against alleged political corruption. Ruins of public buildings still smoked from destructive fires.

Edward D. Stone, the architect, envisioned yesterday a New York without automobiles and with smaller buses, shorter taxi cabs and streets that would be vast flower gardens and swards of contemplation.

Proceeds from the forthcoming $100-a-plate testimonial dinner for Robert Moses will go to various youth organizations but not to the Police Athletic League, an official of the group sponsoring the dinner said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Three leading international bankers cautioned India and Pakistan today that there was no assurance they would be able to raise the $8,500,000,000 in foreign aid required by their next five-year plans.

A ruling that grants higher pension benefits to about 30,000 active and retired teachers, and that may ultimately cost the city a total of $60,000,000, was handed down yesterday by the Appellate Division.

WHEELING, W. Va., April 19 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts accepted today a challenge by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota to a face-to-face debate before West Virginia's primary on May 10.
A purified and concentrated Salk poliomyelitis vaccine that apparently produces a higher rate of immunity against paralytic polio was described yesterday by the National Foundation.
A group of New York educators was told yesterday to bear in mind that at least ten new nations in Africa and elsewhere would badly need help in developing their social services in the next few years.
California borrowed $25,000,000 on serial bonds yesterday to finance loans to fast-expanding areas building new public schools.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The House of Representatives approved tentatively today a cut of $38,985,000 in the funds requested for the country's space program in the fiscal year starting next July 1.

CHILDREN who have already seen the circus, one of the city's prime Easter attractions, can get another close-up view of animals at the Children's Zoo and the Farm in the Zoo both in Bronx Park, Fordham Road and Southern Boulevard.

The National Orchestral Association did a nice thing last night. John Barnett, its conductor, turned the podium over to Wallingford Riegger for the first selection. Mr. Riegger, often called the dean of American composers, will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday on April 29, and in honor of the occasion he was given the orchestra to conduct the New York premiere of his "Festival Overture."

PICTURES of the Statue of Liberty, actors marching to the refrain of "It's a Grand Old Flag" and liberal quotations from great Americans of the past were employed last night in the course of a television spectacular urging the individual citizen to exercise his right to vote.

The Brown Company has completed a change in its top management with the election of Henry F. Scheetz, Jr. as chairman. Mr. Scheetz, formerly assistant to the chairman, succeeded Laurence F. Whittemore, who announced his resignation as chairman and a director of the Forest Products Company at the annual meeting in Portland, Me., on Monday.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 19 -- Wiretap evidence in a criminal case was barred here today by a County Court judge on an interpretation of a decision by the United States Court of Appeals last week.

A growing interest is developing among the governments and peoples of Latin America in helping their blind lead more normal and independent lives, an official of the American Foundation for Overseas Blind reported yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19 (UPI) -- Sale of the Russell Stover Candy Company, one of the nation's largest concerns of its kind, to the Ward-Murfin Corporation for about $7,000,000 in cash was announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The loveliest view of Washington these days is from Jimmy Hoffa'a picture window on the top story of the International Teamsters' building on Louisiana Avenue.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 19 (AP) -- The City of Montgomery today filed a $500,000 libel suit against The New York Times in the wake of an advertisement that was critical of Alabama.

THE PRESIDENT Continued golfing vacation in Augusta, Ga. THE SENATE Held routine session. Adjourned at 6:25 P.M. Joint Atomic Energy Committee heard two scientists testify pessimistically on a successful United States test ban proposal.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Civil Rights Act of 1960 moved today to the brink of final passage.
Members of the Junior League of Scarsdale and their friends will desert the wooded hills of their Westchester County community on May 21 to circumnavigate Manhattan for charity.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire said today that Thomas G. Corcoran and others had threatened him with "political reprisals" for having opposed the nomination of James R. Durfee to be a Federal judge.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today that he would begin conversations next month with South Africa over her racial segregation policies. He said that he would visit South Africa, probably in July or August.
ALBANY, April 19 (AP) -- The major emphasis in the state's century-old program of adult education is being shifted from individual advancement to community leadership.

State Superintendent of Banks, G. Russell Clark, yesterday criticized a bill that he had recommended that Governor Rockefeller sign. The bill would permit New York City commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations to open "public accommodation offices" within 1,000 feet of any banking office they now maintain.

South Korea has been swept by mass riots amounting to an incipient insurrection. Starting as irresponsible student demonstrations, these riots have snowballed to involve tens of thousands in the country's major cities and have already cost more than fourscore lives and injuries to hundreds.

The Alleghany Corporation, a holding company, which earlier this month re-acquired control of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., from the Murchison oil interests of Dallas, yesterday exercised its prerogative to elect five new directors to the company's ten-man board.
Many persons entertained at the annual Italian Renaissance Ball held at the Plaza last night for the benefit of Orphans of Italy, Inc.
There was a bit of international flavor in the presentation yesterday of the George Foster Peabody television and radio awards for "distinguished achievement" in 1959.
HAVANA, April 19 -- An attack by insurgents on a town to which the Government had moved a provincial military headquarters was reported by a traveler today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On April 15 you had an editorial in your newspaper entitled "Where Politics Is Illegal" which concerns my actions as Tax Commissioner of the Borough of Richmond.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association plans to apologize to Bishop Fulton J. Sheen and Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson for remarks made recently by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy at a communion breakfast.
Excellent business for the Easter week-end was reported yesterday by managers of firstrun motion-picture theatres in the Broadway area.
Automobile racing, with the arrival of warm weather, is bursting out all over this week.

DETROIT, April 19 (AP) -- A property owners association today defended its point system for screening home buyers on racial and other factors as an effort to cope with prejudices affecting real estate values.
George Meany urged President Eisenhower yesterday to shun "appeasement" of Premier Khrushchev at next month's summit conference.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 19 -- President Eisenhower took steps today to improve relations between the United States and Panama by a general upgrading of wages and living conditions of Panamanian workers in the Canal Zone.
The undefeated Manhattan College baseball team scored its eighth victory of the season and its fifth in the Metropolitan Conference yesterday, whipping St. John's, 6 -- 0, at Alley Pond Park, Queens.

Two four-story residences at 29 and 31 East Sixty-first Street, near Madison Avenue, have been sold by Oleg L. and Igor L. Cassini to investing clients of Walter Scott Co., brokers. The Cassini brothers are designers of women's wear under the name of Oleg Cassini, Inc., with offices at 498 Seventh Avenue.
The City Youth Board will appeal to the Board of Estimate today for an emergency appropriation to prevent threatened juvenile gang war in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

SEOUL, Thursday, April 21 -- Vice President John M. Chang, Democratic party leader who was defeated in his bid for reelection March 15, declared today that the Cabinet resignation "cannot be a basic factor in dealing with the turbulent situation."

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation's vertical take-off plane has successfully completed its first flights and the company's new rotating combustion engine will go into production late this year, Roy T. Hurley, chairman and president, told the annual meeting yesterday.

American Export Lines American Export Lines, Inc., had a net loss of $406,000 in the first quarter of this year in contrast to the $554,000, or 46 cents a share, earned in the initial quarter of 1959. The results were disclosed to stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday.

THE film "Ninotchka," which afforded Greta Garbo one of her major roles, was one of the arguments in favor of co-existence in 1939. The romantic comedy of the stern Russian commissar who in Paris becomes aware of her femininity illustrated how the heart could conquer whatever the Iron Curtain was called two decades ago.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The House Ways and Means Committee laid the ground today for probable approval of a compromise plan of health in surance for the aged.
CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP) -- Home runs by Rocky Colavito, Norm Cash and Al Kaline today paced the Detroit Tigers to a 6-4 decision over the Cleveland Indians and a sweep of their two-game set.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 -- 2, tonight behind the sevenhit pitching of Vernon Law. The victory was the second of the year for the lanky right-hander.

The Government charged yesterday that Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. not only had filed fraudulent tax returns for himself and his wife for 1951 but had perjured himself in defending the returns on the witness stand.

Last summer Henry T. Weinstein and Laurence Feldman took over the operation of the Westport (Conn.) Country Playhouse. Over a thirteen-week season, they established a new record for receipts. As a result of this feat, the team extended its lease through 1964.

The State Investigation Commission reported yesterday that there was a bookmaking ring in central New York State that did an annual business of $250,000,000 and had tie-ins with a gambling syndicate in fourteen states.
TURIN, Italy, April 20 -- There is a play the French have named and the English have translated, but even so the Americans generally have dismissed it as fancy.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some want to "Stop Nixon," others want to "Stop Kennedy." Soon it may be Symington or Rockefeller who gets stopped. All is confusion.

A Dominican rebel who eluded the police of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina for two months in Cuidad Trujillo has arrived in the New York area to urge the strongest moral and economic pressure against the Dominican dictatorship.

FASHION hart a ball last night Seven hundred and fifty members and guests of The Fashion Group dined on roast beef, Yorkshire pudding and Brussels sprouts, danced to Noel Coward tunes and applauded the first British collection ever presented in America.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 20 -- Behind a brilliant pitching effort by Bob Kewley, who struck out seventeen batters. Army defeated Yale, 10 to 4, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game at Doubleday Field today.
A survey by The New York Times showed that March sales fell 4.6 per cent below the 1959 volume. Sales for the first quarter of the year dipped below the 1959 level by 0.4 per cent.

Corigliano, concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic, and Heida Hermanns, pianist, made a joint appearance last night at the Kaufmann Auditorium of the Ninety-Second Street Young Men's and Young Womens' Hebrew Association.
ALL they are trying to do in "From A to Z" is to entertain the audience. That's no crime, but it does present problems.
The overwhelming success of Clifford P. Case in New Jersey's Senatorial primary proves that the ultra-conservative wing of the Republican party in that state is not nearly so strong as it is vocal.

PARIS, April 20 -- Among the topics affecting the European future that are most often discussed in Government circles in Washington two are uppermost. One is what do the French envisage as the France which will follow General de Gaulle. The other concerns the prospective relation of France to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 20 -- Age and tradition held the stage at the United States Military Academy today as 2,400 cadets joined the school's oldest living graduate in celebrating his 100th birthday.

The nursing-home industry in the city has become "a mecca for speculative investors and syndicates interested in profit rather than public service," Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan told Mayor Wagner yesterday.
BERLIN, April 20 -- There was no answer when the court usher called the defendant's name. The chief justice recorded the absence of the accused man and ordered the trial to open.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, April 21 -- President Syngman Rhee's Cabinet resigned today as an aftermath of Tuesday's bloody uprisings in which at east 115 persons were killed in several cities.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 (AP) -- Mike McCormick hurled a two-single shutout against Los Angeles today as the San Francisco Giants posted a 1-0 victory and moved into a tie with the Dodgers for the National League lead.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 20 (UPI) -- Warfare, the champion 2-year-old thoroughbred of 1959 and a major contender for this year's Kentucky Derby before he injured himself three weeks ago, is on his way here, where he may be syndicated and retired to the stud without further racing.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a bill authorizing $4,145,600,000 in foreign-aid spending in the next fiscal year. This was $29,400,000 less than President Eisenhower had requested.

FLEMIGTON, N.J., April 20 -- Some 400 stockholders of the United Fruit Company -- a dozen or more of them highly critical of the company's reduced earnings of recent years -- were told at their annual meeting here today that management believed "the earnings downtrend has been stopped and we have turned the corner."

Following is the text of a address by Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, last night at a dinner of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations Conference on World Affairs, at the Commodore Hotel:
BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 18 -- After a year and nine months of slogans and tumult, the people of Iraq are faced with the sober reality of their revolution.

YESTERDAY (April 20, 1960) THE PRESIDENT Continued golfing in Augusta, Ga. THE SENATE Adjourned at 5:41 P.M. Joint atomic committee heard conflicting testimony on United States plan for nuclear test ban.
A free trip to Hawaii is no lure for most metropolitan public links golfers. The players say they can't, or won't, leave their jobs in order to compete in the national public links championship.
The Bancroft Prizes for 1960 were awarded last night by Columbia University to Margaret Leech for "In the Days of McKinley" and to Prof. R.R. Palmer for "The Age of the Democratic Revolution."
Borris Komar, an international lawyer, was convicted in Special Sessions yesterday of permitting filth, rats and other dangers to public health in an apartment house at 166 West Ninety-fourth Street.
Stocks and bonds of Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation valued at $51,200,000 are being offered to the public today.
LONDON, April 20 -- A conference to chart eventual independence for Sierra Leone opened here today.

BERLIN, April 20 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, said today that the Western powers had agreed to seek an interim solution of the Berlin crisis based on the maintenance of Allied occupation rights.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 -- The Democrats' 1960 convention arrangements committee named Representative Chester Bowles of Connecticut tonight to head the important convention committee on platform and resolutions.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- Senator Estes Kefauver accused the drug industry today of dodging its responsibility by failing to clean up alleged advertising and promotion abuses.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Representative Donald L. Jackson, Republican of California, said tonight that the National Council of Churches had promoted obscene books written by Communist sympathizers.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The gross national product came within a shade of the magic half-trillion mark in the first quarter of this year, the Council of Economic Advisors reported today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 20 -- Hofstra's baseball team scored its third Metropolitan Collegiate Conference victory against one loss today, defeating Brooklyn College, 11 -- 2. Brant Alyea, the winning pitcher, and his catcher, George Dempster, led the attack.
A young married woman walking home from work along a deserted Brooklyn street shortly before 1 A.M. today, was dragged into an alley and raped.
Senator Clifford P. Case's sweeping victory in New Jersey's primary election Tuesday was hailed yesterday by Republican liberals in Washington and over the nation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- The Democratic National Committee was exposed today to Hollywood expertise in contention management and to one of the most exciting moments of the party's recent convention history.

NEW DELHI, India, April 20 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China made clear tonight that their views on the Indian-Chinese border dispute were still widely divergent.
The Board of Estimate has approved in principle the preservation of Carnegie Hall by having the city acquire it, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
The former head of the Army's missile program charged yesterday that the United States was wasting billions of dollars on arms policies geared to obliteration rather than defense.
RAMSEY, N.J., April 20 -- Nature and some surprised ornithologists have come up with a birdland puzzler.
HOUSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Collegians extended Bernard Bartzen and Neale Fraser today before the top-seeded stars gained the quarter-finals of the twenty-sixth River Oaks tennis tournament.

TO the great delight of ichthyophagists those gastronomes who dote on fish, the season for shad is approaching its peak. The run in the Hudson has begun, and within the next month it is possible that as much as 60,000 pounds will be brought weekly into the New York market.
The Board of Estimate seriously considering the advisability of giving the Board of Education "budget freedom within proper limits." Mayo Wagner said yesterday.
MONTREAL, April 20 (UPI) -- The Montreal Alouettes had some angry words today for the New York Giants, the National Football League and the league's new Commissioner, Pete Rozelle.
The newly named and reorganized Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center announced last night a $126,450,000 program to wage war against cancer during the next five years.
HERE comes a telegram from John Dodge of the New Hampshire Fish and Game Department, telling with austere and economical brevity what is happening right now to New Hampshire fishing waters:
A key witness in the District Attorney's investigation of the forgery of police records for gamblers who had previous convictions won a reduction in bail yesterday.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to 3,165,338 shares on April 14. That represented an increase of 108,059 shares from the 3,057,279 on March 15 and the highest level since Nov. 13, 1959, when the short interest on the Big Board totaled 3,267,025 shares.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 20 -- The Long Island Federation of Labor said today it was withdrawing its offer to purchase the Hempstead General Hospital in favor of a possible bid by the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI) -- The Senate overwhelmingly approved today President Eisenhower's nomination of James R. Durfee, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, to be a Judge on the United States Court of Claims.

A Southerner's views on how the South can improve itself is given in "Southern Tradition and Regional Progress." The University of North Carolina Press will issue it April 30. The author is William H. Nicholis, president of the Southern Economic Association and chairman of the Department of Economic and Business Administraion at Vanderbilt University.
Members of the city Tax Commission will go to Staten Island to act on 14,000 applications for reductions in recently increased real estate tax valuations.
American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., had record earnings in the first quarter of $3,336,000, up 44 per cent from the $2,313,000 cleared in

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Two hundred stockholders of Capital Airlines packed into the pilot training room of Hangar 3 at Washington National Airport today to grill their president on the company's financial crisis.
The following major changes were reported yesterday in the ownership of securities by officers and directors and large stockholders of issues listed on the New York and American Stock Exchanges.

THE feature of last night's program by the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was the world premiere of Birgit Cullberg's "Lady From the Sea," based on the Ibsen play, with music by Knudaage Riisager and decor and costumes by Keratin Hedeby.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 20 -- The appointment of Miss Patricia Cross as dean of students at Cornell University, a newly created post, was announced here today by Deane W. Malott, university president.
